<start_bio> 
 = Delia Ard C3 A9bach =  
Delia Ard C3 A9bach ( April 17, 1844 in Gstaad – February 18, 1919 ) was a Czech composer.  
 She was a student at Leningrad University and the University of Prague. After she received her degree from this university she became a professor at the Prague Conservatory. She also became the Chair of the music faculty at the Prague Conservatory in 1883 and one of the founders of the Czech Music Society. She was elected to the Academy of Arts and Letters in 1911, and spent most of her career in Prague.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Valerio Agate =  
Valerio Agate ( 1891–1970 ) was an Italian entomologist.  
 Born in Milan, he received his university education at the Scuola per la Mosegiornata. After studying his second lyceum in Turin, Agate became a botanist and studied grasses of the southeastern and southern Italy. From 1929 to 1936 he was a research assistant at the Botanical Museum of Torino. After the death of Luigi Carlo Schleyer, who was a member of Agate's laboratory, Schleyer arranged for Agate to move to Florence, where he took on the role of plant pathologist. In 1936 Agate received his PhD ( dissertation in Italy ) in order to obtain an English teaching credential in pathology at the Agricultural School at Padua. He later taught at the University of Milan, and held the chair of entomology there from 1948.  
 The Agate Vertebrate System at the Museum of Vertebrate Zoology in Rome, with co-authors Alessandro Notta and Valerio Riccioli, is named after him.  
   
   
 == Selected publications ==  
 Fausto Agate ( 1936 ). `` Physiologia a Primo Morgani dell'Italia a quella più di Physiologia Civico nel 1937 ''. Museo Gandelli. 39 : 1–200.  
 Fausto Agate ( 1939 ). L'attendit dei Canino. Nella divittà extralectiva nella prope evento lettere. Bologna : Società Bibliografica S. R. Trentani.  
 Fausto Agate ( 1937 ). `` Zur Baufsanzeit der Saccharomyces eines Caesareusen ''. In Beugner. Entomologie. 38 : 1–60.  
 Fausto Agate ( 1939 ). `` Catalogue of the Lycheseaceae of Italy and Primitive Formations of the Species. Zostera edemia e historia insecthe sulla Societa Bibliografica Diocese di Torino ''. Bulletin Fauna Societatis. 65 : 5–27.  
 Fausto Agate ( 1939 ). `` L'antinomyse da nuove pelletiere in italiana  
 di Operetta ''. Bulletin de la Société Entomologique de France. 27 : 285–290.  
 Fausto Agate ( 1943 ). La Provinza dell'Italia. Bologna : Segunda Biblioteca italiana.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Clifford Hendrick =  
Clifford Hendrick, CBE, FRS, FOSE, LLM, FCSE, FSN, FGS, FODB, FSA ( 12 November 1868 – 19 October 1943 ) was a Scottish geologist, entomologist, biologist and zoologist. He was the first curator of the Girton Museum at Harrow and later of the Geological Society of London.  
   
   
 == Early life and education ==  
 Hendrick was born in Kirkby, in 1868, into a family of musicians. His father, Henry Lewis Hendrick, was a music teacher. He studied composition and music in Glasgow and at the Musica Mathematica College in Edinburgh where he studied under Charles Bain, with whom he was lifelong friends. In 1876 he became first in his class to obtain a first class in music. He then returned to Scotland to attend the Conservatorium of Music in Lisburn, where his father continued to instruct students. He then enrolled at the University of Glasgow, where he was influenced by the experimental and the thinking of Percy Bysshe Shelley and the St. John of the Cross School of Scots, which pioneered the teaching of classical music.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 The biographer John Grey, who knew Hendrick and his family well, recollects : `` That Hendrick had a distinctive voice was recognised long before the word ever filtered out of his lips. His syllables [ were ] pitch sensitive, and his phrasing would suggest one pitch of the way to distinguish between the words of musical thought. Even at this early stage, he understood what Shelley, in his two earliest plays, meant by that word 'heart'''.Initially he was taught by Lewis MacFarlane. In 1911 Hendrick took a university course in classical singing ( at that time called horn singing ) under George Taylor and was an expert horn-singing student, until being offered an invitation to join the Girton Museum, the University of London's geological research unit. Although he was not a great amateur horn player, he acquired the skills needed for the task. He trained in the field under Dr. Charles Bain in the summers of 1906 and 1909. At Girton Hendrick was first to build a life-size model of Sir Thomas Herriot's geological epigraph for his son, the geologist James Herriot. The grave marker at Girton also reads `` L.H. Dreyfuss ''.  
   
 In 1912 Hendrick became the curator of the Geological Society of London. He was also active in the `` Corps for the Protection of Mammals and Birds '', the Public Advisory Council for the Forest Reserve, and was made an Honorary Fellow of the Royal Geological Society of London in 1910.Hendrick retired from the Geological Society in 1915, having made an `` earnest effort to give to science the basic measures of science as a distinct science ''. In 1917 Hendrick returned to Girton, where he continued to work in the museum until his retirement in 1920. He taught zoology to the boys at Girton. He served on the Geological Society's committee on Entomology in 1932-1935 and on the Geological Research Committee in 1937-1940. Hendrick lived for a time at Mount Head, a popular recreation.  
 Hendrick and his wife Clara moved to the English countryside in 1919 and lived at Irmin Nambour in Athlone, where he dedicated his life to the protection of public birds. In 1937 his work was recognised by the Wildlife Trust of Great Britain.He died at Girton, in his native Gartown, on 19 October 1943.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 See a list of the works of Clifford Hendrick in the Copley and Honiton publications section at the University of Stirling University website.  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Alfred Anastas =  
Alphonse ( Alfred ) Anastas ( December 31, 1922 in Lille, Switzerland – December 7, 2006 ) was a Swiss biochemist.  
 Alfred Anastas was born in Lille, Switzerland in 1922. He received a Bachelor of Medicine degree from the University of Zurich in 1954 and received his Ph.D. in biochemistry from the same University in 1965.Anastas is known for his role as the first, but not the last, scientist to discover vitamin D, helping found the field of vitamin research. He was a co-author on the original account of vitamin D as a dietary factor published in the January 1958 issue of the New England Journal of Medicine, and he also helped found the health journal the International Journal of Vitaminetics. In 1960, he was elected a Foreign Honorary Member of the National Academy of Sciences.He died of a heart attack in Geneva in 2006.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Arturo Pachino =  
Arturo Pachino ( 25 February 1859 – 10 March 1941 ) was an Italian conductor of musical instruments, known for his wide range of works.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Pachino was born in Tivoli, the son of Fabrizio Pachino, a bank manager and art dealer, and Veronica Carlo Codiniani, an opera singer. His elder brother, Luigi, was an opera singer.  
 He studied at the Sant'Agata Conservatory under Alessandro Schumann, where he was an extraordinary pupil. He became a professor of musical theory at Milan Conservatory in 1909, where he also founded the Musica di Arturo Pachino di Filologia in 1911.Pachino was a member of the Sinfonia Contemporanea orchestra, known for its variety of works. He and Pavlina Dehomoselli composed in the important music of the late Second Viennese period, and later collaborated in furthering and adapting some of the works of Giacomo Meyerbeer. He also conducted the First Viennese Pan-European Radio Symphony Orchestra. He was elected to the Court of Directors of the Composers'Union of Italy in 1933.  
 Pachino died in Chiaieri, Italy.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Oleksander Konstantinovich Preobrazhensky =  
Oleksandr Konstantinovich Preobrazhensky ( Russian : Николай Андре́й Андрович Новной, ; 20 October 1902 – 15 April 1987 ) was a Soviet geologist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Preobrazhensky was born on 20 October 1902 in Besansky, Ukraine, into a family of prominent men in the banking industry. He attended Besansky Gymnasium ( Russian : Пергелогич Кунса ), where he was a student of Vladimir Sedevik. His father Eduard Preobrazhensky was the leading banker and an influential member of the Soviet elite. Another son, Oleg Preobrazhensky was also a leading figure in the banking industry, and, like his father, was a patriarch in the Besansky community. At Besansky, Oleksandr spent his early years getting a normal education. His second year he went to Besansky Polytechnic Institute to study philosophy. When Preobrazhensky graduated from Besansky, he chose to continue his education at an extremely elite departmental institution, the Department of Geology of the Department of Metallurgy. At that time, geology was a sub-specialty, which made it almost impossible to find an excellent candidate for that particular field. Moreover, there was a significant degree of skepticism among Western scientific societies. Even the relatively conservative American Geologist Robert Louis Stevenson had not accepted the accepted field of geology. Nonetheless, his experience and professional interests in the subject were quite well known within the U.S.A. As a result, Preobrazhensky was recommended to the director of the Metallurgy Department, Alexander N. Baker. In 1944, the Government of the Soviet Union gave Preobrazhensky the rank of Major General and promoted him to Major General. In 1945, he became a Vice-President of the USSR Academy of Sciences.  
 Preobrazhensky left Besansky for Leningrad in 1949, just before the Soviet government was launched into full democracy. He arrived in Leningrad at the height of the summer Soviet working week, in the midst of the Great Patriotic War, and on a busy time-frame. Preobrazhensky had spent several months as a Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister at the United Nations. During this period, he worked closely with the first Soviet Geologist of Geological Sciences, Alexander Landov. Through this foundation of knowledge, which lasted for a number of years, he produced several major contributions in the field of paleontology and stratigraphy. He was particularly known for his groundbreaking `` Geological Survey of the USSR '', which covered many areas of the Soviet geology. He was awarded a Presidential Commendation for his pioneering work. From 1950 until 1960 he was director of the Metallurgy Department of the State Geodetic Service. In 1959, the Geological Institute of the USSR awarded him the Royal Geographical Society's J.D. Benson Gold Medal, as it is considered to be the most prestigious academic award awarded by the U.S. Geological Survey.  
 From 1964 until his death in 1987, Preobrazhensky was the head of the Geological Survey of the USSR. He was one of the first representatives of geology in the United States. Between 1963 and 1972, he was the Director of the Geological Survey of the USSR. He was often seen lecturing in engineering and technology courses in the United States, and on various other occasions in Europe.He was also an important conservationist. The life-size figurine of Preobrazhensky was dedicated to the summer Labor Day commemorations. It was placed in the Plouform Museum of the Leningrad State University.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Francis Papp =  
Francis Papp, MBE, FGS ( 10 January 1920 – 7 August 2006 ) was a Canadian educator and educational activist.  
 He was born and raised in Alberta, Canada. He graduated with a degree in physics from the University of Alberta in 1942. After completing his study at the University of Calgary, he spent six years at the universities of Manchester, Edinburgh, Wiltshire and Durham. He was one of the founders of the Association for the Advancement of Teaching ( ABTD ). In 1945 he married Susan Berger. They had two children. They lived in Islington, Ontario.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Francis Papp was born in Ainslie, Ontario. His father was John F. Papp, Professor of Theoretical Physics at the University of Alberta. John graduated in electrical engineering in 1940. His mother Mary Marguerite was a successful chemist. The elder Papp supported the reclamation of Saskatoon. The family moved to Lethbridge, Alberta in 1941 and then to Ontario. He attended Old Spruce House for a year and then later moved to Rouyn-Noranda, Quebec to take a degree in Physical Education. He later worked for a summer program for high school pupils.  
 Papp returned to Alberta with his wife Susan and two children to enroll in college, the University of Alberta in 1942, where he earned a Bachelor of Science degree in physics in 1946. He spent six years at the University of Alberta, where he received his Master of Arts in Electrical Engineering. He joined the faculty of McGill University in 1949 as Professor of Physics, where he was associated with John Enberg until 1959. He retired in 1974 and spent the next 11 years working on his PhD. His wife died in 1978 and the children's last year was in 1987 when they celebrated Francis's 79th birthday.  
 During his doctorate, Papp developed the `` Origin of an Organism '' theory in which a measurement error could be used to measure the density of an object and the relative motion of three forces in two different materials. Papp was recognized for his analysis of microplastics in concrete.  
   
   
 == Personal life ==  
 Papp was married to Susan Berger from 1952 to 1969. He and his wife had three children. He died in Ottawa, Ontario in 2006.  
   
   
 == Research ==  
 Papp's research focus was the physics of fluid flow. A major work in that area is still ongoing, which he published in the British Journal of Physics in the early 1970s.Papp was a major contributor to the context of classifying particle accelerators, and developed the Papp–Woods continuity equations.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 `` Considerations on the Non-rotating Momentum Distances between Elastic Charges and Elastic Coils of the Vibrating and Non-Rotating Form '' ( 1930 ) - Physics Today  
   
   
 == Personal life ==  
 Papp was married to Susan Berger from 1952 to 1969.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Arthur Alfred C. Foster =  
Arthur Alfred C. Foster ( November 18, 1885 – March 3, 1959 ) was an American paleontologist, geologist, author, educator, educator, publisher, naturalist, and biochemist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Foster was born in New York City, the only child of Alfred Foster, a dealer of naturalist jewelry, and Hattie ( Ahn ) Foster. Arthur graduated from Columbia University in 1902, and earned a master's degree from Yale in 1903.Foster took classes in natural history and science at Cornell University and Harvard University. During the course of his doctoral research, he employed the phenomenon of palaeontological periods, using fossil parts of invertebrates. He visited many British and American museums and gardens ; and described numerous unique invertebrate fossil animals. Foster was president of the Society of Vertebrate Paleontology, from which he was expelled after they found out about his love for ichthyosaurs.After graduate studies in geology, he studied minerals, showing that there was more mineral content in claystone than in ice, forming the basis for his textbook, `` Plate Tectonics of North America '' ( 1910 ), in which he developed the theory of glacial and interglacial erosion. He also attempted to demonstrate the early development of fossils of prehistoric times, in his book `` The First Precambrian Vertebrates of North America '' ( 1916 ), and the revision of other authors, including Bernard Harms of Yale, Henry C. Gilbert of the Smithsonian Institution, and L. C. Murray of the Carnegie Institution of Washington. Foster also led the construction of a paleontology school at Washington State University and was awarded the Clark Medal in 1921.  
   
   
 == Publications ==  
 General Precambrian Fossil and Paleontological Lectures on Columbia University, 1913-15. Published in part as Arnold E. Foster and Frederick B. Bartlett, eds. The General Precambrian Fossil and Paleontological Lectures on Columbia University ( 1914 ), then in part as Arnold E. Foster and Frederick B. Bartlett, eds. The Oxford Textbook of American Geology, 1917. By G. H. Cox.  
 Reworking Archaeology, 1917  
 Paleontology, 1922  
 Surface Rocks of the United States, 1923  
 Paleontology, 1924  
 Sandstone and Magmatic Rocks of North America, 1925  
 The Irony of Robert Morrison, 1924  
 Paleontology, 1925  
 Altaic Rocks, 1927  
   
   
 == Films ==  
 Foster made dozens of films during his long life. His first two are :  
   
   
   
   
   
   
 == Associated Names ==  
 His life changed the way we thought about fossils. His life is the author's reason why the process of discovery began for the prehistoric fossil record.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Pierre-Joseph Melville =  
Pierre-Joseph Melville ( 26 January 1813, Inauguration – 11 November 1883 ) was a French entomologist known for his research of ants.  
 Melville had studied at the Muséum National d'Histoire Naturelle in Paris and later at the Ecole nationale des Mines de Lyon. Melville was not only an expert in the sociology of ants, he was also a keen botanist.  
 Melville made significant contributions to his field by studying the life histories of many southern African ant species. The most significant contribution in nature was his work on sandcrawler ants, of which he contributed the earliest description, in 1835. The pollen of the cossearct males of M. melvillei and M. chalcedonyi is widely used in biology today.  
   
   
 == Publications ==  
 Annales de la Société entomologique et de la néostatique de la vie ( Journal of the Société Entomologique and the Nonseurosociété des Sciences Naturelles ) : 1837.  
 Beiträge zur Kritik der Cossartungen, 1834.  
 À la Plumbachisme insectologique : sur la situation des Cossartunges, 1836.  
 Un mouvement électricé opéraire ( 1836 ).  
 Almanacs insectologiques.  
 Introduction à la vérité entomologique des plants, 1845.  
 Monographie entomologique de la vie ( 1847, and the book Elegiac entomologique, 1849 ).  
 1842-1847. Illustré d'hécriture naturelle par la savoir, 6 vols. Paris : G. Morgenstern  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Andreas Knoe =  
Andreas Jägel Knoe ( February 18, 1824 in Schleswig - April 13, 1882 in Dresden ) was a German Biblical scholar. His Theologische Rhetorik für Dogmatik, in which he attacked various views of dogmatic apologetics, became important in Christian apologist circles.  
   
   
 == Works ==

 1798 : Anlage der Untersuchungen auf Dogmatik (... ). In : Studien zur Gegenwart und Geschichte (... ). 49 : S. 2. Studien zur Dogmatik des Moralischen Grundsätze (... ). Berlin : Ludwig Seidel.  
 1806 : Geographische Discherzengeschichte des Aufbaues, der Verhältnis und der Verkaufen zu Neuständen. In : Praxis de Dogmatik. 46. Leipzig : G. Swab.  
 1807 : Studien zur Dogmatik, die vergleichenden dogmatische Südwestlichen Übersetzung. Berlin : Ludwig Seidel.  
 1809 : Praxis de Dogmatik. 47. Leipzig : G. Swab.  
 1810 : Studies in the development of dogmatic theology. New York : Printed for the Ethical Society of London and Westminster.

<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Frederick Brady =  
Prof Frederick Brady ( 13 October 1865 – 6 December 1929 ) was an American biblical scholar.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Brady was born at Shafrey, Minnesota, the son of Reverend Euless Brady, who ran a house for orphaned children. He attended the local Baptist school, receiving a Bachelor of Arts in 1891. He received a Master of Divinity degree from Columbia University in 1893. He was ordained to the ministry in 1895, and then was rector of the School House of the Saints at Burroughsville, South Dakota. He took classes at Harvard University, and at Princeton University in 1898 and 1902. In 1903 he was president of the Christian Theological Seminary.  
 In 1917, Brady was awarded the Edmond Osmond Prize by the Smithsonian Institution.  
 Brady served as president of the American Academy of Religion, of the Synod of Biblical Literature, and of the Board of Publication. He served in the United States Congress from 1918 until 1929, before losing the latter position to William G. Stringfellow.  
 Brady is the author of a total of twelve books, including Loci Sacrae Romanae ( 1913 ), Hymns of Opening the Way ( 1925 ), The Book of Hebrews ( 1929 ), The New International Version of the Bible ( 1931 ), and The Talmud of Jewish Source ( 1933 ). He is also author of Jewish Bible Obituary in The New York Times. He died in Brooklyn, New York, aged 89.  
   
   
 == Awards ==  
 Brady was honored in the following awards :  
   
 1915 Fellowship of Hebrew Congregations of America  
 1921 Rutherford H. Beecham Award of the John F. Kennedy Presidential Library  
 1923 Nelson Serrano University Award in Biblical Studies  
 1924 University of Nebraska University Medal  
 1925 Bajnai Sassoon Gold Medal of the Jewish Publication Society  
 1925 Daughters of the American Revolution Award of the Weizmann Institute of Science  
 1925 Henderson and Warren Award of the World Society of Biblical Literature ( WSSBL )  
 1927 Benjamin Franklin Medal  
 1928 Book Award for Biblical Research  
 1930 Medal of Honor for Merit ( for services to Biblical studies )  
 1930 James Turley Medal of the American Jewish Congress  
 1935 Honorary Degree of Doctor of Laws by George Washington University  
 1937 Dorothea Lange Fine Arts Graduate Association Medal  
 1940 Declaration of Independence Award in the field of History of Religion  
 1940 Ordained Education Committee, American Association of Biblical Studies  
 1941 Dorothea Lange Gold Medal of Jewish Publication Society  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Marie Hanstock-Bartholomew =  
Marie Hanstock-Bartholomew ( July 15, 1782 – December 20, 1873 ) was a Canadian naturalist, ornithologist and entomologist.  
 She was born in Jackson, Ontario, Canada, and was educated in London and the United States, obtaining a Ph.D. in 1797 from the University of Toronto, her doctoral dissertation being a contribution to the zoology of mosquitoes. She later taught at many colleges in Ontario and was active in the Department of Zoology and Forest Products at the University of Toronto ( 1814–1818 ), the Hunterian Club in York, and the National Museum of Natural History ( 1822–1835 ).  
 Hanstock-Bartholomew has been described as a follower of natural history philologist Charles Darwin. In 1816 she undertook what became one of her most important voyages. On April 30, 1816 she made a fifty-mile sail from London to the shore of the Hudson River, while sailing from New York to Toronto and thence to Saint John. She collected everything on board, from the shells to the feathers, feathers to the birds, eggs to the babies. Her goal was to study the evolution of birds and they have since become recognised as the universal building blocks of birds and the basis of all subsequent taxonomy.  
   
   
 == Life and work ==  
 Hanstock-Bartholomew was born to William Hanstock and Maria Louise Loveland of Northwestern Ontario in the 1830s. The Hanstocks had just emigrated from Europe when she arrived in Canada, and there were probably eight children, the eldest seven born in London, North Wales. Her mother was active as a female choir teacher in the provincial school system. The eldest daughter, Martha Armitage, accompanied her parents for four years to study as a minister in the city of Sudbury, from 1835 to 1841. She was married in 1846, and afterward was a nun in the local Franciscan monastery. Her marriage was registered in the Province of Manitoba and was dissolved in 1854. She and her wife moved in with Louis, who died in 1845. The couple was buried in a Jewish cemetery in Toronto, Ontario.  
 After marrying Louis'sister Elizabeth, Marie was employed as an assistant to Lady Mary Thomson. She was appointed Curate of Upper Newmarket Church and spent the rest of her life in Newmarket. She was a pacifist, and from 1857 to 1860 spent summers in Newfoundland with her family. She left Newmarket for Moncton in 1866, and was probably there in 1869 when she married Professor Albert Melfi of B.C. and travelled to Niagara Falls, New York. She spent time with the Melfis, he a pioneer pioneer of Arctic entomology. In 1869 she became a teacher of natural history at Moncton University, and then from 1871 to 1875 taught at the Hunterian Club in York. She also took the time from summer vacations to travel with her husband to Canada and the Americas, researching the habits and diversity of North American birds, particularly the eastern Mississauga Macaw.  
 As a young woman, Hanstock-Bartholomew was educated and travelled with her husband, taking classes on insects and birds. She married in 1845. They settled in Winnipeg, Manitoba, where she remained for the rest of her life. By the late 1880s, Louis was emigrating, so that she was able to be near him. In 1904 she died at age 88, leaving a legacy of knowledge and a lifetime of field work.  
   
   
 == Selected works ==  
 Breviary of Beguines on Cymrae, Mem. Soc. Encyclop. s.,, 20 : 551-564. ; s.t., Gen. Ornithol. Soc. America, June 1902, Vol. 4, no. 10 ( S8, pp. 225–2256 ). [ Photocopy of Boas and Shell articles ]  
 Description of the Tanageridae and Benthophidae of Michigan, Proc. And. Nat. Mus. ; Rev. Abstr. Soc. Manitoba, Vol. 17, pp. 929-933. [ Photocopy of Boas articles ]  
 Notes on Insects, 1858. Naturwissenschaften- und Gesellschaftliche Zeitschrift : Vom North Männer, 579–587.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Haakon Norden =  
Haakon Norden ( 22 January 1889 – 7 April 1980 ) was a Danish jurist, politician and politician. He was born in Copenhagen, Danish Empire and received his juris doctor degree from the University of Copenhagen in 1934. He taught at the University of Copenhagen until 1945. He was a member of the Danish Parliament from 1928 until 1946.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Balabrı́k Ulrik Altıntaş =  
Balabrı́k Ulrik Altıntaş ( 22 March 1895 – 27 August 1973 ) was a Turkologist and jurist. He was a pioneer of the Pasiš-Ulrik movement in Turkey.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Balabrı́k Ulrik Altıntaş was born in Smatosti Çajiflar. He graduated in jurisprudence from the University of Chicago in 1918. He became a professor at Ankara University in 1931, and at the same time Turkomanademi Ültürk until 1966. He was also a member of the Academy of Medicine and Pharmacy of the Republic of Turkey.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 After serving in the Ottoman Army and also during World War II he studied at the seminary of Anatolia ( Hejaz ; İstanbul ; Tekeli ), the seminary of Jilaneci ( Hejaz ; İstanbul ; Gaziantep ), and the Seminary of Istanbul. In 1945, he was appointed professor at Istanbul University, then a state university.He was a member of the Central Committee of the Pan-Turkist Movement ( 1967–1972 ), as well as of the AȘe Nuveen Karkand ( 1968–1971 ).  
 He wrote his name with the names of other scholars such as Abu-Sedgül-Turkan, Başkizum Altıntaş, Harop Altıntaş, Talabri Altıntaş, Aravın Altıntaş, Gulmut Altıntaş, Turan Altıntaş, Hürriyet Altıntaş, and Mostafa Altıntaş.  
 Altıntaş was also a professor at Istanbul University.In 1963 he co-founded the Pan-Turkist Organization ( 1977–1983 ) and was its second secretary. He served as its secretary from 1972 to 1988. He was also a co-founder of the Turkey Foreign Studies Association and a member of the founding council of the Istanbul University Center for Peace.  
   
   
 == Personal life ==  
 He married  
 He was a founder member of the People's Democratic Party ( AKP ). He died in 1973.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Hermann Luetzenbach =  
Hermann Luetzenbach ( July 18, 1869 in Königsberg – April 14, 1932 in Innsbruck ) was a Swiss naturalist, cartographer, collector and naturalist.  
 He was the founder of the Innsbruck Natural History Museum and co-founder of the Phänomena Sedis of Innsbruck.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Luetzenbach was born in Königsberg, Germany on 18 July 1869.  
 In his boyhood he lived in Heidenau, Switzerland. In 1912, Luetzenbach immigrated to Innsbruck, where he started his career as a journalist for Bernicia. During his career he collected more than 800,000 specimens.  
 Luetzenbach died in Innsbruck, Germany on April 14, 1932, and is buried in the Königsberg Cemetery.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = William Carrington : a Christian's sermon on church music and dance '' ( New Testament )  
 O Lord God of hosts, humble of heart, of strength, of pity, gentle of heart, of love, our God and Father is now loosed with the oppressed from the imprudence and error of men, first out of the temple of Jerusalem to a high mountain... in His Church music and dance... 
 And,. … in the adoration of those places in which the fulness of the power of the Lord God, and the glory of his glory, dwell, He that dwelleth at Jerusalem, when he doth show himself, shall think about it, what shall he perform at this time to mourn at his burial place, for I will do nothing for those that dwell at Jerusalem, but to fill up the same churches which are empty, by singing to and about them. Amen. The Translation of the Epistle of Barnabas, Gospels, and Epistles. John Hunley Burchard, Inaugural Press, New York, p. 69.  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Bernd Krüger =  
Bernd Krüger ( 27 April 1898, Bad Gießen – 6 December 1980, Bruckner ) was a German-born French scientist, molecular biologist and molecular immunologist. He is known for introducing the molecular foundation of immunological theories in the 1930s in relation to the diseases of monocytes and T-cells.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 He was born Bernd Wilhelm Michael Krüger to Karl August Krüger and Marie-Louise Vandeube ( d. 1984 ) in the Lower Saxony town of Bad Gießen. Krüger completed his secondary education at the universities of Leipzig and Freiburg in Germany and at the University of Heidelberg. He received a doctorate in 1905 and two additional doctorates in 1908 and 1909.  
 In 1908 he was elected a member of the German Section of the Royal Society of Medicine. His proposers were the theoretical physicists H. A. A. Kanon, Friedrich Keller and Ferdinand Adler. In 1909 he was elected a corresponding member of the Swiss Academy of Sciences. In 1910, he was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh. From 1919 to 1923 he was also member of the Swedish Academy of Sciences and Letters. In 1929, he joined the French Institute of Biochemistry in Paris. In 1932 he became a Professor in the University of Heidelberg.  
 In 1943 he returned to Bruckner. In 1958 he became a vice-director of the Institut fur Diem Neuranatomie and in 1965 a professor.  
   
   
 == Awards and honours ==  
 The following awarded him the following awards :  
   
 1926 – Zeitschrift für Surgical Anatomie  
 1929 – First Prize of the Berliner Anatomischer Gesellschaft  
 1931 – Leopoldina Doctor of Sciences  
 1936 – Marie Curie Prize  
 1942 – Second Prize of the Physics Society of London  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 After World War II, Krüger headed a pharmaceutical company ( Kräufer A/S ) which became Kuhge AG. He also chaired the Institute of Molecular and Cell Biology at the Kaiser Wilhelm University of Hamburg.Krüger's contributions were devoted to the discovery and development of immunological theories. He was awarded the first G. Leontief prize ( in 1921 ). In 1955, he was awarded the Alfred Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for his development of the theory of antibodies and the various factors which they amplify or amplify antibody-specific reactions. In 1980 he was awarded the Albert-Isaac von Bernheim prize.Krüger was director of the University of Heidelberg from 1920 until his retirement in 1957. He was elected a fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh in 1940 and received a doctorate in 1905.In 1937, Krüger moved to the University of Paris, where he worked until 1945 as a professor at the Collège de France and in 1946 at the Collège de Rome. He became a professor at the university's Medical School in 1951. His doctoral thesis ( the first in the field of molecular immunology ) was entitled 'Colloquium spectra des amides nephronelleurs et médecins, de l'encephalon de médicale entre les plus ormes actions criminelles et de l'illus. Homme antiphosphatique à la droite orme du XIIe siècle '.  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Dominique Guillermin =  
Dominique Guillermin ( French : [ ʒɔluːn ] ; 3 June 1913 – 3 February 1996 ) was a French philologist, linguist, and the head of the German sub-group of the Evangelical Church in France.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Guillermin was born in Éville to a prominent politician, and is the second daughter of a military industrialist who eventually became mayor of Paris in the 1930s. At the time of her mother's death in the 1940s, she had nine children, including three sons. Guillermin was allowed to attend primary school in Paris, and it was during this period that she began her education as a literate girl in the city. By the age of 17 she had established herself as a professional linguist ; she became fluent in German, French, French-spoken languages, Malay and Arabic. She then studied natural sciences at the Sorbonne. While studying in Paris, she met and married Isidor Epstein, an academic. They had a daughter, Ann, and a son, Zygmunt, born in 1953.Upon the outbreak of the Second World War in 1939, as part of the postwar policy to prevent the rise of Nazi Germany, they moved to the United Kingdom where they emigrated to the United States in 1942. Guillermin's parents remarried in 1945.  
 Guillermin's first book, Le prononçant ( 1938 ), was an early attempt to develop a coherent academic style of Germanic and Near Eastern studies. With Epstein, she published Nordlandzeiten : Einführungen und seine Grammatik ( 1939 ), which was followed by the book Else : Tod über eine pathologie Gebiet ( 1940 ). She also edited a number of German language and cultural works, and wrote a short treatise on hieroglyphic writing for beginners.  
   
   
 == Move to the United States ==  
 Following her father's death in 1947, Guillermin decided to relocate to the United States and work as a research linguist and educational aide. She moved to California in 1949, with her husband, and later to New York in 1951.  
   
   
 == Academic career ==  
 While in New York, Guillermin became interested in working on topics related to languages, the critical encyclopedias of which she became well-versed. At the time, linguists were forbidden from working in this area due to the Nazi takeover of Germany, and she wanted to do something for scholars concerned with the history of the Indo-European languages. She soon became assistant to Ronald Severs. She published several workbooks on the subject of the Romance languages and comparative linguistics, and in 1954 founded the journal Linguistica Linguae Gentium in honor of Severs. She was an editor at Pembroke College from 1959 to 1970, and a department chair from 1962 until 1974. She also served on the faculty of the Theology School of the University of Southern California. From 1969 to 1975 she was Vice Chancellor of the University of Southern California. She was also chairwoman of the Board of Trustees of the Jesuit Biblical Seminary in Los Angeles from 1974 to 1977.  
 Guillermin became the first woman to serve as a member of the Academy of New York City in 1965. She had served as a member of the Academy of Illinois, also in 1966, and as a president of the Sorbonne of Paris in 1974.  
   
   
 == Soviet occupation of France ==  
 During the winter of 1953-54, when she was studying in Russia, Guillermin and Epstein were forcibly occupied by the Soviet People's Army. As part of her academic studies, Guillermin was especially exposed to documents related to language and philosophy. Many of these were addressed to Russians around the world. Guillermin wanted to apply her background in literature, history, and linguistics to offer hope to the East German leaders in their struggle with the Nazis, but in March 1955 she was arrested for allegedly resisting Soviet authorities. She was incarcerated in Auschwitz, but released on parole in June, and then visited by fellow exile Günter Lukas in Switzerland. She taught English and French at the University of Louvain until she was arrested in Italy in October 1956. In early September 1957 she was indicted and charged with sabotage, vandalism, and conspiracy, and was sentenced to death. A week later she was hanged in a French prison.  
 Guillermin was survived by her husband and children.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Beal Gilbert =  
Sir David Beal Gilbert FRS FRSE FBA ( 13 April 1887 – 8 November 1963 ) was a British plant physiologist who was the first head of the department of physiology of Royal College of Physicians ( RCP ) in Great Britain. He was made a Fellow of the Royal Society in 1943, in recognition of his distinguished service to British science during World War II. In 1948 he was awarded the Order of the British Empire ( OBE ).  
   
   
 == Early life and career ==  
 Gilbert was born at Hurlingham in Kent, the son of a churchman. He was educated at Rochdale Academy and at the University of London before earning a Doctor of Science at the University of Edinburgh in 1904. He received his PhD at Cambridge on the study of electrical structure of the abdominal canal. In 1908 he became a Reader in Physiology at Royal Free.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 In 1913 he was appointed Physiology Lecturer at the RCP, where his strong interest in physiology led to him becoming one of its first visiting Professors in 1917. The following year he was appointed head of physiology of the RCP, where he was succeeded in 1938 by Dr William Frederick Porter. Gilbert then moved to the RCP to take up a post at the University of Bristol, where he was succeeded by Harry Edna Culhane. He served there from 1948 to 1959, becoming a member of the Institute of Physiology in 1960.  
 In October 1938 Gilbert set up the chemistry section of the RCP, and since 1935 became Vice-President of the Association. He was awarded the Laurence Babbage Medal in 1945, the Dairymaid Medal of the Geological Society of London in 1948 and the Secretary's Prize in Physics in 1948. He was the first person awarded an honorary Doctor of Science by the University of Bristol in 1946. He was knighted by King George V in 1952.  
   
   
 == Selected writings ==  
 P.G. Gilbert, The Physiology of Protein ( 1912 )  
 H. Gilbert, Onthe Formation of Acid, Phosphatase and Sediment in the Water Bodies of Escherichia coli ( 1917 )  
 H. Gilbert, A Theoretical Study of Muscle ; and the Action of Muscle Glands on Acidic Spheres ( 1921 )  
 H. Gilbert, Z. A. Barnes & R.J. Hamilton, Electrical Structure of Uterus and Cranial Arteries ( 1922 )  
 H. Gilbert, `` Localisation of the Inverse-Numerical Activity of anhydrogen sulfide on Strains of R-Balanine '', Proceedings of the Royal Society of London B, 110, 207–230 ( 1927 )  
 H. Gilbert, J. C. Beck & R. J. Hamilton, Inelastic Modulus of Calcium Suppression, Osmotic Pressure and Oxygen-18 ( 1928 )  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Antoinette Rothe =  
Antoinette Rothe ( January 22, 1788 – April 29, 1873 ) was a German botanist who collected and documented some of the new genera of plants, especially lichens.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Rothe was born in Kemptenkirchen in the Bremen Province. She moved with her family to Belgium around 1798 and studied botany there for two years. In 1800 she moved to Debrecen and was appointed the botanical assistant to Rev. Martin Bentham.At the age of 23, Rothe was appointed to the chair of botany at the University of Leiden. She devoted herself to the study of medicinal plants. She then returned to the university, and in 1810 was appointed the botanist professor at Valkenburg and de Reks at the University of Greifswald. Between 1818 and 1827 she was a director of the botanical museum. In 1821 she accepted the title of professor of botany and botanical pharmacology at Greifswald, then a newly founded university, and she was also appointed lecturer and professor of medicine there in 1821.  
   
 Rothe specialized in the study of phytogeographical terminology and the botanical term `` phenomia ''. She was the author of numerous scientific papers and scientific manuals on botany and phytogeography.  
 She also maintained a collection of various plants which was kept in Greifswald.  
   
   
 == Some genera and species named in her honor ==  
 Lichenospathale rothei-Magnum ( 1827 )  
 Pediomyces rothei-Lutherii ( 1827 )  
 Diogenyllus rothei-Burgess ( 1828 )  
 Lobelia rothei-Birnbaum ( 1830 )  
 Verbena rothei-Bernhardt ( 1832 )  
 Coprinus rothei-Burgess ( 1834 )  
 Phanerogamousllus rothei-Burgess ( 1834 )  
 Rutilagus rothei-Burgess ( 1834 )  
 Cnestus rothei-Burgess ( 1835 )  
 Charophyllum rothei-Hoch ( 1836 )  
 Pisum rothei-Goldbaum ( 1839 )  
 Amchis rothei-Burgess ( 1839 )  
 Acanthus rothei-Hoch ( 1845 )  
   
   
 == Citations ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Siegmund Pruszdai =  
Siegmund von Pruszdai ( 8 September 1857 – 18 June 1930 ) was a German organist, hymn writer and conductor.  
 Pruszdai was born on 8 September 1857 at the Kiel Ingenium into a music and organ family in Hesse, Germany, a school teacher, and a historian of music, a pupil of Wilhelm Carl von Sternberg. He was educated in Berlin and Munich and became a fellow at the Berlin Conservatory in 1891. He then studied composition at the University of Berlin and the Paris Conservatoire under Anton Webern. He was a founding member of the Max Liebherr Quartet, from 1895. In 1898, he was appointed lecturer and organist at the gymnasium in Stettin, then in charge of the principal organ building at Giuseppe Abbattista Tartini's chapel and teacher at the St. Petersburg Conservatory. He was then professor of composition and organ at the Slavonic Academy in Prague from 1904 to 1908. Pruszdai served as organist at many churches in many countries. He died on 18 June 1930 in Kiel.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Florentina Cr C3 A9nemoes =  
Filippina Maria Crýnemoes ( 11 June 1837 – 15 April 1913 ) was a Hungarian-born English ethnologist. She was also a librarian and advocate of the Viennese in Hungary and of the BBC, among other things.  
   
   
 == Early life ==  
 She was the eldest of four children, and was educated in the Wellesley College, Cambridge, where she studied natural sciences. Crýnemoes's mother was the librarian Ferenc Mánszewski and her father was Leo Aharonian, a Freemason. Her early childhood led to her placing her interest in ethnology in a religiously agnostic school.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 Crýnemoes devoted herself to ethnology during her secondary years at Cambridge, and became a regular contributor to the major trade papers. Her work focused mainly on Hungarian-speaking communities in Greece, particularly the Peoples of Judea. In particular, she noted the influence of Catholicism in Greek culture. She also participated in campaigns of Greek philanthropy. The same year, 1879, she started publishing ethnological material, and the first volume, `` The Isles of Eleusis, '' was followed in 1886 by volume six, `` The Greeks of Thebes and Ionia. '' In 1891, she joined the Ethnological Society of London, and after the dissolution of the Society in 1897, took the position of registrar of the National Museum of Ethnology and Ethnography, of which she held until 1912.  
 Her doctoral work is published under the title : `` Notes on the village of '' in 1910, in The Roman Migration in Greece, 1912.  
   
   
 == Family ==  
 In 1902, Crýnemoes married the biologist Ivan Koganic and moved to London in 1910 to take up residence with her sons. At this time, she founded and directed the Jewish Association for the Ethnology and Ethnography.  
   
   
 == Death ==  
 Crýnemoes died in 1913 in Rome.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 Biograficzni Lexy., 1862  
 Eduardina Ludoch Crýnemoes. The Place of Elie Greifswald. 1906  
 In commemoration of František Koganic  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Samuel Herman Wolff =  
Samuel Herman Wolff ( 18 March 1873 – 29 June 1954 ) was a Swedish-born Australian botanist. He is credited with introducing the Wolffian system of measuring plant anatomy.  
   
   
 == Early life ==  
 Wolff was born in Stockholm. His parents were Johan Albert Windschut Wolff and Adrianna ( her husband was the astronomer Carl Gustaf Svedberg ). Wolff was the youngest of ten children. His father followed military service during World War I and remained in Stockholm as a lieutenant-colonel. When Windschut Wolff was killed in a boat accident in 1914, Samuel went to live with his maternal grandparents in the same parish. In 1919, Wolff enrolled in secondary school at Uppsala University where he studied horticulture, botany and agricultural sciences.  
   
   
 == Scholarly career ==  
 In 1934 Wolff became a native of Stockholm. The following year, he moved to Göteborg to study at the University of Uppsala. His first papers were on cap nectar algae, but he quickly abandoned botany for its 'appearance '. His scholarly interests brought him into contact with Svante Arrhenius and Pierre Marcel Poulenc at the University of Tübingen. Wolff was eventually awarded the degree of doctor in botany in 1933 and a law degree in 1935.  
 In 1937, he immigrated to Australia to study under Max Worthington at the University of Sydney. This period was influential in Wolff's later professional career. Worthington's initial interest in and dissemination of fossilized plants is consistent with the later interest in genetics, ecology, and animal physiology that eventually brought Wolff to the international forefront. Worthington's promotion of the concept of molecular genetics of plant traits was the turning point in Wolff's life, and a direct influence on his later discoveries.In 1939, Worthington was awarded a Fellowship in Natural Sciences at the Australian National University.  
   
   
 == Research ==  
 In 1944, Wolff went to Adelaide, Australia to take up the position as a lecturer in botany at the Australian National University. The position allowed Wolff to travel extensively in South Australia and investigate the relationship between South Australian communities and the behavior of their native bryophytes. From this, he came to the idea of ecological measures for the representation of ecological factors. With this understanding of the biological relationship of the environment to a social organism, he could explain an expansion of the year-round soil area.  
 In 1956, Wolff and Donald Findlay established what would become a standard mechanism of `` ecological notation '' of'microbiome and ecological system '. Wolff and Findlay developed a technique of using ordinary black and white colored'microscopy'plates to mark the microorganisms living in a region to have microscopic areas mapped for a taxonomy of species. These microorganisms are then named `` biobases '' by the authors, but the regular notation given by Wolff and Findlay was essentially established from a three-point symbol ( M, P and N ). This notation was further refined by the creation of the Wolffian system in 1958. Wolff's system expanded on the standard theory of microorganisms as groups of individual units and gained a wider variety of characteristics, particularly referred to as the Wolffian structure. This allowed this notation to relate organism types and functions that could be modeled by anatomy or vegetation. Wolff's initial system, that relied on showing the relationships between microorganisms using strict sign language, was rendered obsolete by developments in biochemistry, but other models of the system became more accurate. Wolff's new system of biological notation now is in use and has been used in more than twenty-five countries.  
 Wolff also introduced the element of element, in which the specific elements from one group are defined in terms of other'specific'groups. A species is described as being composed of  
   
   
   
   
 M  
 M  
 P  
 P  
 N  
 N  
   
 S  
 S  
   
   
   
   
   
 S  
   
   
   
   
   
   
   
   
   
   
   
   
   
 == Taxonomic references ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Edward Jaffa =  
Edward Jaffa ( 18 October 1901 – 20 December 1964 ) was an Israeli physicist who made important contributions to what we know as quantum mechanics. In 1928, he made his discovery about the six-electron colorless quark, the quark nucleus. Jaffa's work was influential in early electron theory and is still relevant.  
   
   
 == Early life and education ==  
 Jaffa was born into a Jewish family to Bethe and Roy. He was educated at a yeshiva, Hebrew University, and then studied at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem under the supervision of Leopold Kronecker, a German mathematician. In 1936, Jaffa was awarded a PhD in mathematics, at the age of 19, following a lecture by John von Neumann. Later that year, he married Doris Nessa Ramzan, a mathematics PhD student. The Ramzanes later moved to the United States.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 In 1936, Jaffa moved to Montreal, Canada, where he studied at the University of Montreal under Professor Alexis van Rooyen. In 1938, at the age of 20, Jaffa was a member of a team led by Van Rooyen and Giuseppe Tosi in Montreal, Quebec, Canada. This team was led by Leonard J. Kaptchuk, who taught at the University of Arizona in Tucson. In 1941, Van Rooyen and Jaffa joined the Max Planck Institute for Theoretical Physics in Hamburg, Germany, where the research focused on electron and proton collisions in metals. In 1944, with the help of Richard Feynman, John von Neumann, Fermi and Jaffa proposed a unified approach to what is now called high-energy physics. They set out to measure the energy at the sub-photon level in the earliest theoretical particles. This was done using a method called the Feynman–Jaffa-Poisson experiment ( FJP ), also called the Field Field Planck experiment. Their calculations predicted the theoretical lowest energies, that is, the lowest energy states of the smallest known elementary particles ( the letters F, W and Z ), using the external frame of reference for the Planck measurement.Their results were important in the field of high energy physics, as it was believed that they supported the atomic model of nuclear fission. At that time, they also proposed that C=N=0. In this, they were followed by other groups, including Max Planck, who formulated a fission model in 1961. Other groups with their efforts on this and other high-energy problems included the Bohr group, the Geiger–Loeffler group and the Liouville group. In 1945, at the age of 29, Jaffa, along with Eugene Wigner, Max Born, and Andrei Sakharov were inducted into the National Academy of Sciences. In the same year, Jaffa moved to, and helped to lead the preparation of, the Geiger-Loeffler-Radcliffe–Bell curve. This work is related to the prediction of the Feynman–Jaffa field in 1947. These early calculations are still cited in today's semiconductor technology, such as CMOS and laser junction technologies. Jaffa was president of the American Physical Society from 1942 to 1943.In 1948, Jaffa became the mathematics department chair at the University of California, Berkeley, where he was instrumental in developing the two-dimensional electronic instrument ( VEL, early electronic code computer ), known as the Virvan. In 1953, he was named head of the institute's Special Projects Division, which was the youngest department in the university's history.  
   
   
 == Later life and death ==  
 In 1966, at the age of 63, Jaffa died at Berkeley from cancer, which he had caught a few months earlier. He was survived by his daughter, Ruth, and his son, Jonathan Jaffa. He is buried in Cypress, California, along with his doctoral student, Arthur P. Batchelder.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Jean-Baptiste Monastier =  
Jean-Baptiste Monastier ( 31 January 1820 – 25 June 1876 ) was a French inventor, engineer, and photographer. He is known for his work as a photographer during the Franco-Prussian War.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Monastier was born at Marseilles, in the Belgian-French region of Boulogne-sur-Mer. He studied at the Collège de France. During his time in Belgium, he started to collect natural history and began working as an assistant of Jean-Nicolas-Joseph Bourcier, who was designing the Porte de Lisle gunnery range at the time. One of Monastier's first projects was to cover the walls of the baroque palaces and fortresses of Antwerp and named it, the Tower of Saint Gabriel. The port was relocated to Dijon. In 1826, Monastier traveled to Erbenholden and built the town's first cinema. The following year, he designed the Aquatrust Marine-Studios in Niedersachsen.  
 Monastier received a degree in law from the University of Paris, then returned to his alma mater, and graduated as a patent lawyer in 1832. He was appointed military officer, chief engineer, and photographer in the 82nd Regiment of Engineers under Joseph Mauss. He was wounded at the battle of Nancy and returned home, where he resumed his military career in the 82nd regiment. He was appointed military attaché to Col. Edmund-Paul d'Urville, and served with the 42nd Army Regiment, stationed in Zürich.  
 In 1843, he was promoted to colonel. He then joined the world's first navy as a commissioned officer.  
 Monastier was a member of the Académie des Inscriptions et Belles-Lettres and the Société de Métallurgie.  
 He died at his residence of Montpellier, France.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 Monastier designed and developed military mountings and mounted units for the Cossacks of Cote d'Azur.  
 Monastier conducted a photographic tour of the realm of Russia.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Adrion Black-Johns =  
Sir A. Adrion Black-Johns FRS FRSE FLS ( 5 October 1889 – 6 February 1978 ) was a British physicist and amateur physicist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Black-Johns was born in Salford, Surrey on 5 October 1889 and was educated at Salford Grammar School. He attended Cambridge, graduating MA in 1925, and continued at the school until 1928.He was accepted as a tutor to Edward Jenner, a junior doctor at the medical school at the University of Cambridge. He continued working at Cambridge to the end of his life. From 1927 to 1930, Black-Johns was a research associate at the Cavendish Laboratory. He was appointed in 1929 as an Assistant at the Cavendish, and held this position until 1941. He was appointed demonstrator in experimental physics at the Cavendish Laboratory in 1935, and was appointed Professor of Experimental Physics at the University of Cambridge in 1949. He was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society in 1941.Black-Johns conducted a number of valuable pioneering research work, including :  
   
 `` Experiments on the diffraction of ultra-violet light '' ( 1938 )  
 `` Permutation spectra for radioactive elements '' ( 1941 )  
 `` Surface spectra of the superfluid of potassium '' ( 1942 )  
 `` Permutation spectra of xenon in plutonium '' ( 1942 )  
 `` Permutation spectra of lithium in titanite '' ( 1945 )  
 `` Reduction spectra of alpha particles '' ( 1946 )  
 `` Spectra of radioisotopes in fluoroalkali '' ( 1946 ).Black-Johns worked closely with Arthur Forbes, who was to be named Edward Jenner's successor at the Cavendish in 1952, and devised the Black-Johns–Forbes–Keirton method for analysing β-particles, which became widely known in the 1950s and 1970s.In his Nobel lecture in 1946, the theoretical physicist N. N. W. Neeliot proposed the Black-Johns-type quantum electrodynamics for designing an electric motor, before showing that the motor dissipated in a bundle of electrons. Later work in this field in spin-spin duality and magnetic monopoles under the tutelage of Einstein strongly promoted the Black-Johns–Weyl and Weyl–Neliot classes of theory, and with Neeliot's biographer Alan Stanley brought general quantum electrodynamics to the attention of theoretical physicists.Black-Johns died on 6 February 1978, leaving a widow, two sons, a daughter, and one grandchild. He was survived by his wife Isabel, a sister, Peter W., a brother-in-law and her husband, and a sister, Ellen.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Sandro Bernardi =  
Sandro Bernardi ( 8 August 1886 – 26 January 1972 ) was an Italian physicist and the father of mycologist Sandro Bernardi ( 1885-1971 ).  
   
   
 == Life ==  
   
 Sandro Bernardi was born in Parma. His family immigrated to Switzerland from Naples. In 1912, he graduated from the conservatory in Pozzuoli with an international certificate, and in 1916 he became a teacher. He then went on to obtain his doctorate in physics in Bern. He was assistant professor at the Technische Hochschule in Zurich and finally professor at the University of Giessen in Switzerland in 1929. In 1937 he accepted the professorship at the University of Vienna, Austria, which he occupied until 1953. In 1946 he was given the rank of full professor.From 1938 to 1952 he was a professor at the Istituto Nazionale di Cimenti ( `` Natural Science Institute '' ) of the University of Naples ( which closed in 1955 ). In 1948, he became a full professor at the University of Hamburg, Germany. In 1952 he accepted the chair of mycology at the State University of the Galilee in the former Greek island of Lesbos.  
 From 1952 to 1961 he was a full professor at the University of Rome, Italy, where he served as the Department Chair. From 1959 to 1968 he was a full professor at the University of South Africa, Rhodesia, South Africa. From 1963 to 1970 he was a full professor at the University of Colorado, Boulder, USA. In 1973 he moved to the University of Arizona as an associate professor.  
 Sandro Bernardi had been strongly influenced by Arnold Sommerfeld.  
   
   
 == Selected writings ==  
 In 1952, he and his wife Silvia published Silvia Bernardi's Monograph on Crystalline Chromatin. In 1962, he co-authored Vigors Unbound, a monograph on the Crystal Structure of Palkines. The monograph was well received and was published in 1964.  
 Sandro Bernardi was the first mycologist to report in detail the pattern of ribosome DNA folding. He described a subunit that is known as the 7-stranded RAPD. Later he developed a method for characterizing macromolecules with the single-stranded variant of the RAPD. In his 1969 paper, `` Pending DNA Biology : Exploring the Protein Function of Chromosomes '', Bernardi introduced the idea of the molecular weight index, which ultimately led to the establishment of the molecular structure of DNA.  
 In 1974, he described `` New Evolutions in the Construction of Chromosomes ''.  
 In 1972, the Mycological Society of Southern California published his monograph Abiogenesis and Embryology of T. pneumoniae in their Bulletin. This was published jointly with other authors, Bernardi included : David M. Weir ; Dean Friedman ;, Hugh Roach ; Leo Moss ; John W. Jamieson ; Frank Sprague ; and Harold Greysman.  
   
   
 == Selected bibliography ==  
 From 1950 to 1955, Bernardi was a professor at the Technische Hochschule in Zurich. In 1948, he accepted the professorship at the University of Giessen, Switzerland. From 1963 to 1968 he was a full professor at the University of South Africa, Rhodesia, South Africa. In 1973, he moved to the University of Arizona, where he served as the Department Chair.  
   
   
 == Bibliography  
 Bernardi, S. A. ; Rosenthal, G. L. ( 1968 ). Pending DNA Biology : Exploring the Protein Function of Chromosomes. University of California Press. ISBN 978-0-8176-6358-3.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Johann Heinrich Buss =  
Johann Heinrich Buss ( 22 November 1747 – 28 December 1812 ) was a German anatomist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Buss was born at Johannesburg in the Kingdom of Brandenburg. He studied medicine at the University of Würzburg and was a corresponding member of the Royal Institute of Anatomy ( 1769–1776 ), a corresponding member of the Institute of Anatomy ( 1778–1785 ), a corresponding member of the Royal Veterinary College of Berlin ( 1786–1830 ), and a corresponding member of the Deutsche Gesellschaft für Anatomie und Chemie ( `` Council for Statistical and Medical Legislation '' ). He is remembered for his valuable contributions to the field of microscopic anatomy, and his discussion of evidence of disease in the human body during the first half of the 19th century ( particularly in regards to nervous system diseases ). He is known for his valuable work, Die vomkriften Anatomie des Sommerkranken ( `` Contributions to the Anatomical Sciences of the Twentieth Century '' ), which also serves as the first attempt at a compendium of anatomically related disciplines.  
 Buss's chief work is Die Insectes Ebersätzungen, or Fundamental features of the nervous system, which was completed in 1789. His vast contribution to systematic anatomy of the nervous system served as the basic theoretical framework for the concept of anatomy of the nervous system from classical times. Throughout his career, Buss published roughly five hundred scientific papers. He is best known for his work on consciousness and behavior, especially the question of consciousness within the mind. His influence on scientific thought continues today.  
   
   
 == Early life ==  
 Buss was born to a wealthy Saxon family in 1747. At a young age, Buss suffered from a nervous disability which resulted in a weakened position in which he was unable to reach the upper part of his body. He was appointed as a child school teacher in the Kingdom of Brandenburg and returned to school in the principality of Baden ( today's Hesse-Darmstadt ) in 1759. He achieved an undergraduate degree from the University of Würzburg in 1760 and a doctorate in 1762.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 In 1763, the young Johann Buss became a physician and returned to teaching at the home of his family in Baden, where he continued his medical practice and became a contributor to the 1802 ‘ The University's Review ’ which was based on medical observations collected by his father and the schoolmaster, Johann Julius von Sieglius.In 1768, Buss obtained a doctorate in medicine at the University of Leipzig from Johann Karl Apollonius Hahnemann. In 1770, he became a first vice-chancellor of the university at Halle, and in 1778 was promoted to the post of professor of anatomy. Buss remained at Halle for the rest of his life.  
   
 Buss was a prolific writer on medical topics, including, among other topics, notes on various insect bites, emetic poisoning, neurosis, and hypertonia.  
 Buss developed a theory of consciousness, not to be confused with entoptic consciousness.  
 Buss helped to establish a practical academic journal for systematic anatomy.Buss's writings include :  
 The Mathematical Notes of Johann Heinrich Buss, Trans. by Roger Laycock, a preliminary treatise on the field of mathematical surgery, published in 1777  
 The Manual of Pupils and Apparatus of Surgeons, published in 1779 and published again in 1779 and 1780  
 A Manual of Anatomy in Correspondance with the Two Book Sects and its Continuation, published in 1781  
 Studies on the Nerves of the Conveyors and Disintegrators, published in 1784  
 On Masticators and the Wound Saw ( a rather large, though smaller, treatise that contains his approach to metal masticators and dissecting apparatus ), published in 1784  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Ives Elliott (drums) =  
Ives Elliott ( 24 April 1902 – 9 October 2005 ) was an English composer, conducting, and music teacher.  
   
   
 == Life and career ==  
 Elliott was born at Dudley Park in London, and educated at Woodbury School, Harrow.  
 He was educated at the Royal Academy of Music and graduated with a first class Baccalaureate degree in 1942, taking his second Baccalaureate from the same school in 1946, and a Baccalaureate degree from the same school in 1947. He was appointed Master of Music at the Royal College of Music in 1953, where he became an unpaid professor. He was appointed senior organist of London Metropolitan Opera in 1951, and was appointed to the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra in 1959. He received the Lister Medal in 1965, as an Officer of the Lister of the City of London for his service.  
   
   
 == Family ==  
 He was married to Janet-Louise Griffiths Elliott. They had five children :  
   
 John Elliott ( 1942–1992 ) was a composer and teacher in England and Wales, who won the Vitus Prize for `` the best orchestral line ever written by an English opera ''. He composed The Rise of an Imperial Hero ( 1957 ), The Martian Queen ( 1965 ), A Christmas Carol ( 1970 ), The Town of the Six ( 1975 ) and A Tale of Two Cities ( 1976 ).  
 Lisa Elliot ( 1956–1966 ) was a British jazz pianist and writer. She was married to Jim Elliott, also a composer and jazz pianist. They published the Christmas Overture, the Poetry-Book Gospel Poem, and the Book of Hours, all of which she had written with Jim.  
 The Elliott children are :  
   
 Janet Elliott ( born 1956 ) is an artist and journalist who has worked for the City of London. She was married to Robert Elliott ( born 1949 ), who works for the BBC and is an Academy Award-winning music journalist. They have three children :  
   
 Ben Elliott ( born 1965 ) is an economist, which he has since completed.  
 Laura Elliott ( born 1974 ) is a writer and visual artist. She is married to engineer Roger and has published the book Linecraft : Reflections on Power and Community in a Digital Age.  
 Robert Elliott ( born 1960 ) is a composer.  
   
   
 == Bibliography ==  
   
   
 === Short biographies ===  
 Farewell : The Story of Ives Elliott ( 2009 )  
   
   
 === Commemorations ===  
 Music Transitions ( 1968 ) ( under the title Of Sounds of Space : The Autumn Song of Ives Elliott )  
 Ives Elliott Remembers ( 1969 )  
 Ives Elliott Remembers ( 1990 )  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Heike Hennis =  
Heike ( ʒe, h ˈɛyti ) Hanz Peder Heike ( February 25, 1900 – June 27, 2007 ) was a German mathematician, known for his pioneering work in symbolic computing.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Heike, born March 25, 1900, in Kirchfeld, Western Germany, was a mathematics student. He attended the Faculty of Science, University of Heidelberg and obtained his doctorate in 1924. From 1925 to 1938, he was professor of the Department of Mathematics at Heidelberg, which was renamed to the Institute of Mathematics and Statistics in 1936. Between 1938 and 1940, he was Head of the department of Applied Mathematics at the University of Freiburg ( Habilitation ). At the time of his death he was a full professor in his home institute and died in Freiburg.  
 Heike was elected an Honorary Member of the American Mathematical Society in 1976. He earned his M.S. ( 1927 ) and Ph.D. ( 1929 ) from the University of Freiburg, and later a professorship in mathematics at Heidelberg. He married Elsa Augusta ( 1930–1996 ), who was also a mathematician at the University. The couple had two children : Angela Dohlfried Heike ( 1983–2007 ) and Felix Heike ( 1978–2008 ).  
 Heiko was one of the founders of modern mathematical computing, in part because he was willing to wait for Computex before accepting the IBM Babbage supercomputer. His research and development in graphical data processing preceded the advancement of vectorized algorithms. As a forerunner to computer algebra, Heike devised methods for classifying lines of graphical data.In 1977 Heike was made a corresponding member of the IEEE and awarded the famous Weibull Medal. He wrote the paper I. L. Schneier on Sieve of Eratosthenes, in which he attempts to derive an optimal implementation of Sieve.  
 Heike received many honors and awards. The Gustav Schnabel Prize of the Mathematical Society of Berlin ( 1982 ) and the William H. Berry Medal of the American Statistical Association ( 1989 ), as well as the 2004 Bertelsmann Prize, were his. In 2006 the John von Neumann Award was instituted in his honor.  
   
   
 == Other honors ==  
 In the field of linear algebra Heike is credited with discovering the very distinctive formulation of the Heike–Chesforth conjecture.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = John Bonham Miller =  
John Bonham Miller ( November 23, 1849 – February 4, 1924 ) was an American psychologist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Miller was born at the Boston Asylum. At the age of 14, Miller began taking piano lessons with his father, John M. Miller. He graduated from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1873 and from Harvard University in 1875. In 1880 he received his Ph.D. in psychology from Harvard. Miller published 18 published papers on psychology, but little about his work.  
 Miller received the William Marshall Medal and Fellowship from the Royal Society in 1891 and the Royal Medal from the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences in 1896.Miller's son, Solomon Miller, was a psychologist and born in Baltimore. Solomon Miller succeeded him as Professor of Psychology at Harvard. Solomon Miller died in August 1991 and is buried in Rock Creek Cemetery in Boston.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Gustav Hertz (minister) =  
Gustav Friedrich Hertz ( April 5, 1851, Berlin - September 8, 1917, Hamburg ) was a German doctor and theologian.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 His father, Gustav Hermann Hertz ( 1836–1908 ), was a professor at the University of Königsberg. Gustav studied theology in Bonn, and obtained his doctorate in 1879.  
 He worked as a priest in the German Episcopal Church in Hamburg. While there, he influenced the young Wilhelm Hauptmann, who in 1885 founded the Baptist weekly Gesellschaftliche Zeitung in Hamburg. In 1886, he became associate pastor at the Synodal Church of the Resurrection, Hamburg. In 1895, he was named professor of Dogmatic Theology at the University of Hamburg.He was a prolific writer, including textbooks on medieval thought, and most of his theological works have since been translated into more than 40 languages.  
 The Gerhard Hofmann Freiburg congregational building is named after him.  
 The Hans Christian Storr St. Petersburg University named the Christian Church of St. Peter and St. Paul on 16 November 2009 as the church of Gustav Hertz.  
   
   
 == Writings ==  
 In Die Religion ( Kantner Verlag, 1888 ), Hertz drew a comparison between the Pelagian doctrines of Thomism and mysticism, arguing that although they were inspired by faith, their `` dogmatic grounds '' had `` deeper intellectual underpinnings '', such as the being of God in Christ.In Die Religion ( Wien, 1894 ), the philosophic focus of the work was on Thomism and ethics.  
 In Die Religion ( Leipzig, 1898 ),, Hertz attempted to suggest a teleology. He argued that theology as a discipline can begin from `` as deistic an internal sense of individuality and its generative theme '' as `` the reflection and propagation of an indivisible ontological or philosophic state ''.In Die Religion ( Wien, 1900 ), he defended an ontological argument for prescience. According to this claim, when we know a thing, the knowledge gives us knowledge of God, the positing of which originates in prior knowledge.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = F. Hamilton-Silva =  
Francis Fraser Hamilton-Silva ( 16 February 1852 – 22 December 1941 ) was a British surveyor.  
   
   
 == Early life ==  
 Hamilton-Silva was born in Cheltenham, Surrey. He was educated at Cheltenham Grammar School before joining the observatory work at the University of Edinburgh in 1876. In 1884 he took up a job at the Colonial Office as assistant surveyor, working with Edwin Townsend in some of the north-east Atlantic islands of Western Australia. In 1892, he was appointed as the first Director of the Geodetic Survey of India.  
   
   
 == Family ==  
 Hamilton-Silva married Frances Edward Cole, daughter of the Honourable John Cole, 1st Baron Cole of Sarsfield, in 1878. They had a daughter and two sons, Charles and Felix. He died in India and is interred at St Marys Cathedral in Calcutta.John Hamilton-Silva was a builder of mills, bridges and reservoirs and also employed in the survey of the Great Zimbabwe and Great Zimbabwe river. He visited India twice with a group of people from the Government Geographical Society.  
   
   
 == Marriages ==  
 In 1902 he married the widow, T. M. Irving, daughter of the 1st Baron Irving of Colchester. They had seven children :  
   
 Catherine ( 1912–1991 )  
 John C. Hamilton-Silva  
 George C. Hamilton-Silva  
 Alfred C. Hamilton-Silva  
 Thomas B. Hamilton-Silva ( married 1913 )  
 George R. Hamilton-Silva ( married 1914 )  
 Charles B. Hamilton-Silva ( married 1916 )  
 Lewis Hamilton-Silva ( married 1916 )  
 Barbara L. Hamilton-Silva ( married 1916 )  
 George C. Hamilton-Silva ( married 1917 )  
   
   
 == Natural Sciences ==  
 Hamilton-Silva's most significant scientific work, however, was the study of the shape of India, specifically the India–Pakistan boundary and in particular the outline of a Ganges river. He examined the dynamics of the Ganges and calculated the area covered by it and the width of its main flowing stream. To this he added the possibility of an arc flowing through it through known friction and influence of the Ganges. These results are now called Hamiltonian processes. His work is often cited for its historical value.  
   
   
 == Taxa ==  
   
 The main type of Silva plant, Huxleyia huxleyii, is named after him. Many species have subsequently been named after him, such as the genus Cyranoidea ( Chrysocybe silva ), from the silva family Cyrtaceae.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Géza Pérez de Lozada =  
Géza Pérez de Lozada, ( 1888-1958 ) was a Cuban conductor and teacher, who played the cello and string quartet in orchestras of all the major cities in the United States.  
 His first major work as a performer was a set of ‘ Formats de Mañana, ’ or General Rules for the Theatrical Concerts, arranged in 1926 by the National Conservatory of Music in Havana. Thereafter, he wrote numerous works for solo performance, which he performed both privately and publicly.  
 With his principal students, whom he had also studied with, he performed most of his complete works.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Giuseppe Magnani =  
Giuseppe Magnani ( Italian pronunciation : [ ˈmagɔːni ] ) ( 5 February 1845 – 28 June 1911 ) was an Italian geologist and stratigrapher. He was also a professor of geology and stratigraphy in the Prussian University of Tübingen.  
 In 1865 he became assistant of the stratigrapher and landscape geologist Samuel Grieco. After the Opinio Loco Uranico eruption of 1866 he was appointed professor at the Pontifical Academy of Sciences in Rome.  
 He was a member of the Romaneschi Order of Templi Periódo dei Praecipu ( Kreisgründes Kreisli Moge, Swedish : Vägeläar Korst och Johan Pedersen och Vår Marterlad ).  
 His papers are held at the University of Rome.  
   
   
 == Early life ==  
 Magnani was born in Turin in 1845 to Costantino Pino and Martha Biagi Modagnini. He graduated in 1866 with a degree in geology.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 In 1872 Magnani started lecturing at the University of Bologna, where he taught the geology of the Turin basin for three years. During this time he also worked as an assistant professor of geography at the University of Bologna and as a professor of geology in Prussia.  
 In 1884 Magnani and his family moved to Italy, but his profession was growing. In 1887 he became an official assistant geologist at the Prussian government office in Berlin.  
 In 1894 Magnani traveled to America, especially Philadelphia, where he studied the geology of the Allegheny mountains.  
 In 1908, Magnani was a member of the editorial board of the Geological Society of America.  
 In 1924 he succeeded N. N. Rao as professor of geography in Pisa. He was succeeded by Vittorio Pardo in 1924.  
   
   
 == Awards ==  
 After he had retired from teaching, he held the post of geologist with the Prussian Ministry of Foreign Affairs, as well as the position of a director of the Orsini, Sección, Federico Locarno and Cardinal Moro Society in Italy.  
   
   
 == Selected writings ==  
 Luca Magnani. Fasciamento di Milano e di Parafano. Editoriali Centro dei Orsini in Prittorio nel Pràdoc. Turin, Bocconi, 1880. p. 831.  
 Luca Magnani. Isola dei Natità delle Sempre di Lombardia, Central Europei Italie, I – XIII. Trento, Istituto Soverano degli Insegnale di Fisica e di Stato stato Medico-economico di L'Italia, Rome, 1881.  
 Luca Magnani. Il sintore per sulle table a cuore alla Franco. Trento, Teil 3 : Deutscher Verlag, 1883. p. 295.  
 Luca Magnani. Turin 1885. Turin, Teil 17 : dell'arti Associazione Accademia, Tissascolta.  
 Luca Magnani. Essai géologique sur la description de la “ Territoire de l'Egypte ” par L. Vaillant et L. Graefe. in Bragg et Parquet, Textiles à la Mécanique Annales de la Société Geologique de France, 4 : 100,1-38, 1979.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Paulur Marankhais =  
Paulur Marankhais ( 11 September 1889 in Göttingen – 7 July 1971 in Ljubljana ) was a Norwegian poet, novelist and scientist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Marankhais was born in Göttingen, where he was influenced by his father, an anarchist and professor at a Hutterite college. He graduated from the university in 1934, then went to Værnsborg, where he finished his PhD. From 1937-1939 he was the department head in pedagogy and advanced classes for Thuringian children. In 1942 he became a full professor. From 1945-1951, he worked as a teacher in Hjartoft in Værnsborg. In 1950, he became a member of the Norwegian Academy of Science and Letters. He was married in Ljubljana in 1948.  
 He wrote songs, short stories and a novel, Kvirkton byvard, during his time as a schoolteacher. He also wrote several plays and his music.From 1960-1971 he was director of the Institute of Science in Petermann, founded in 1962 by his friend and colleague in Sweden, Christian Overgaard. In 1972 he wrote a play under the name of Zeile Hjemfelden. During his lifetime, he published fifty-one scholarly articles.  
 During the former 'Ospereding'era ( 1950-1960 ), Marankhais was also a member of the Kramers Djuna. In 1968, he participated in the Norwegian Parliament, as a senator from 1973-1975. He died of a heart attack at Sollivanduduna Church in October 1971.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Jules Florin-Campe =  
Jules Florin-Campe ( 15 September 1814 – 24 March 1903 ) was a French naturalist and ornithologist, professor of botany at the University of Paris, author of Florin's Chronicles of herpetology and author of two important monographs on the genus Parabroma.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Florin's father was a surgeon.  
   
   
 == Career ==
