 Spruce, Irving M. ( 1995 ). Dimensions of Behavior : Their Materia Medica, Volume 2 ( American Psychological Association ). ISBN 0-387-86816-3.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Gustavus Junger =  
Gustavus Junger ( 27 October 1784 – 28 May 1842 ) was a German political philosopher and ethnologist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 He studied in Frankfurt, and, in 1802, obtained an appointment as professor of natural philosophy at the University of Marburg. Here he became a student of Paul Husserl, who in 1823 edited a translation of his works, Primer der philosophischen und ethnologischen Wissenschaft, and introduced them to the general reader. In 1825 he was promoted to the chair of political economy, and in 1828 he was made a fellow of the Royal Society of Berlin.Junger published in 1829 `` Über die Leben der und ihre Herzschen Beziehung '', and in 1832 `` Leben von die Haushalt der Maligrühre '', dealing chiefly with the possible origins of the Ainu race, `` Cun''a Darka bey ''. Several of his works were translated into French in 1837, and in 1838 into Italian and German.  
   
   
 == Legacy ==  
 In 1832 the ruins of the mysterious structure known as the `` Fallow Mountain '' at Tâda 'ora, was named after him by Jesuit priest Fr. Ernest Horne.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Ralph Solley =  
Ralph Solley ( February 13, 1891 – November 3, 1975 ) was an American geologist and mountaineer.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Solley was born in Santa Monica, California. He graduated from Fresno State College in 1908 and received a Ph.D. in geology from the University of Michigan in 1912. In 1914, he moved to the Rocky Mountains where he and his family spent summers. As a major in the U.S. Army from 1918-1942, he took part in expeditions to the Alaska of North-central Montana and his daughter Sarah married Fred Rogers Laughlin of Denver, Colorado.  
 In 1934, he married Louise Amblin Solley, a botanist from Oakland, California. They had five children. Louise married Edwin C. Miller of Sequoia, California, in 1941. On his death, Louise married Kenneth Stanley Miller, and son Donald Miller became a geologist.  
   
   
 == Education and career ==  
 Solley was a graduate of the University of Michigan in 1912 and from New Mexico State Teachers College in 1913. He received a B.S. in geology from the University of California in 1914. At the University of Michigan he completed a geology course in 1918, and then studied under Ludwig Bielby for the rest of his career. In 1921, he took a post-graduate course under Carl Rudenstahl at the University of Berlin. In 1921, Solley became a faculty member at the University of Colorado where he studied orogeny, autochthonous sedimentation and lacustrine in Yellowstone. From 1923-1926, he studied with Herbert M. Darlington and John H. Robertson at the University of Minnesota and Boston University. In 1926 he took a position as Professor of Geology at Oregon State University. In 1929, he became a full professor at Colorado College, later to become the University of Colorado–Boulder. In 1937 he was the recipient of a Guggenheim Fellowship.  
 In 1938 he moved to Denver and in 1939 to Portland, Oregon. In 1941, he and his wife moved to Rochester, New York. In 1950, Ralph Solley died and was survived by his wife Louise, and son Donald Miller.  
   
   
 == Mountaineering ==  
 After receiving a fellowship to study on Mount Rainier, Solley and Dr. Carl Mooney embarked on a journey to take samples on the North Rim of Mount Rainier. This project started in late 1929. During their journey, Solley and Mooney were recognized for their quality of work, including being chosen to collaborate with an award-winning mountaineer, Edwin Ondate of San Francisco, and an amateur mountaineer, Robert F. Wentzel, who were doing the same mission.The climb to the summit was accomplished in late September, and the expedition was succeeded by a cross-country move of more than half a million feet in 1927 and 1928.  
   
   
 == Geographic Namesakes ==  
   
 For a number of years, Rudolph Landscale was Solley's official mountaineering name.  
   
   
 == Achievements ==  
 Ralph Solley worked in many distinguished scientific and administrative positions during his career. Among his accomplishments are the following :  
   
 President, USGS Rocky Mountain Division from 1935-1939  
 Director, USGS. 'Rocky Mountain Division of the Geologic Survey of the United States.' 
 Deputy chairman, American Alpine Club, 1910-1912  
 Director, Survey of Mining Industry of the Bureau of Geology and Mineral Resources, 1912-1927  
 President, American Alpine Club, 1913-1919  
 President, USGS. Presidential Training College, 1913-1919  
 Chairman, Geological Society of America, 1914-1919  
 Secretary, National Museum of Natural History, 1919-1920  
 President, Geological Society of America, 1921-1922  
 President, American Association of University Women, 1922-1926  
 President, International Association of Scientific Arrangements, 1926-1927  
 Honorary member, Geological Society of America, 1928-1932  
 Honorary member, American Society for Biometry, 1932  
 Honorary member, Geological Society of America, 1936  
 Grand Commander of the Order of the Red Eagle, 1952  
 Winner of the John D. Rockefeller Foundation Science Fair Medal in 1957  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Jacob Jacques Hamel =  
Jacob Jacques Hamel ( 27 December 1888 – 23 June 1977 ) was a French cryptologist and writer.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Hamel was born in Paris, the son of lawyer Jules Hamel, and wife Elisabeth Adolphe Freimann. After completing his secondary school education, Hamel applied at the Department of Philosophy at the University of Paris, and graduated in 1934. He became a professor at the Department of Physics in 1946, where he was a member of the faculty until 1965. He was rector of the University of Paris until 1968.  
   
   
 == Work ==  
 Jacob Jacques Hamel specialized in very low-precision measurements, particularly applications of this to cryptography and public key cryptography. He developed strong cryptography and encryption routines for the Sphere published in 1957. This and other sources of information, his book Le Data Libre ( 1970 ), followed by Résistance et compunction sur le ciphers ( 1980 ), developed the notion of tamperability in cryptology.  
   
   
 == Published works ==  
 Le Data Libre ( 1970 )  
 Recherches sur l'analyse de la Ciphers ( P.F. Scranton ). Volumes 1–5. P.F. Scranton, Paris, 1954–1971.  
   
   
 == Honors ==  
 He was elected a Fellow of the American Statistical Association in 1961.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Gertrude Posey =  
Gertrude Rae Posey ( March 20, 1910 - July 11, 2009 ) was an American zoologist, econometrician, and educator. She served as a professor and Chair of the Department of Management at University of Chicago and her husband, Boris Posey, was an entrepreneur.  
   
   
 == Education ==  
 Posey attended Emerson High School, graduating in 1920. She earned a BA in 1921, a PhD in 1921, and a master's in 1922. She was hired as a teaching assistant at Wabash College. Her doctoral thesis, `` The Behavioral Responses of Alien Eggs to a Dipper '', earned her a 1.75 mair grant from the National Institute of Standards and Technology. After her wife became the Department chair, Posey held the post until 1989.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
   
 After her husband's death in 1940, Posey became chair of the department of management at Chicago University in 1939. Posey was a co-founder of the Educational Testing Service, and she worked as the Pascanzio Research Associate at the University of Chicago in 1948. Posey also helped design the Helen Wills Oliphant Testing Center, the first English language remedial testing center, built in 1923.Posey served as a professor of management at Illinois State University, Indianapolis University, and University of Rochester ( 1956–1962 ). She also taught at the University of Michigan and Northwestern University ( 1975–1977 ). She and her husband founded the nonprofit organization the Stratis Group in 1977.  
 In 1982, Posey was honored with the The New York Times Magazine's `` Best Career Choice '' Award.  
   
   
 == Selected publications ==  
 Anatomy and the Behavior of an Antigen ( 1946 )  
 Fecundation ( 1947 )  
 The Behavior of Ovarian Ectocaries ( 1958 )  
 Behavior of Coelenterates and Other Shaping Units ( 1965 )  
 Rheology ( 1968 )  
 The Evolution of Large Animal Behaviors ( 1973 )  
 Gross Retrieval System of Heredity ( 1974 )  
 Evidence for General Adaptation in Males : A New Approach ( 1976 )  
 Evolution and Economics ( 1983 )  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Abigail Willet =  
Abigail Willet ( March 9, 1912 – August 11, 2007 ) was an American chemist and teacher who focused on the molecular chemical structure of `` the primordial triple helix : the secret of life ''.She taught at the California Institute of Technology from 1943–1975 and the University of California, Santa Barbara from 1978–1989. She was a leading figure in development of the polymer polymer theory of life.  
 Willet was the first person to describe a helix within a double helix cell.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
   
   
 === Early life ===  
   
   
 ==== Early life and education ===  
 Willet was born in Palo Alto, California, to Jacobandaw Allison Willet ( 1899–1984 ), an aviation mechanic, and Saloman Willet ( née Willet ; 1900–1978 ), a wife of Hugh Willet, of Winchester, Massachusetts. She was the second of three children.  
   
   
 === Career ===  
 Willet earned a master's degree in chemistry from the University of California, San Diego in 1926. She earned a PhD in organic chemistry from the University of California, Santa Barbara in 1929.After graduation, Willet became an assistant professor of chemistry at the University of California, Berkeley, earning a master's degree in 1926 and a PhD in 1929, and a Ph.D. in molecular biology from the California Institute of Technology ( Caltech ) in 1934. She stayed at Caltech for the rest of her career.  
   
   
 === Personal life ===  
 Willet married Walter I. Norman, Jr. in 1937, while working as an undergraduate at Caltech. Willet and Norman had a son, Will, who went on to be a surgeon.  
 Willet died in San Mateo, California, from lung cancer, aged 71. She was survived by her sister, Norma Willet ; a brother, Arthur ; two sisters, Myra LaBarre and Barbara Leslie Willet, as well as two grandsons, Stewart and David Willet ; three great-grandchildren, Thomas and Rob Willet ; and an elder sister, Joan Pepperell.Willet received the British Nuclear Society Gold Medal in 1958.  
   
   
 == Publications ==  
 The molecular basis of life, 1932.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = James Thomson, 1st Earl of Nottingham =  
James Thomson, 1st Earl of Nottingham, ( 2 January 1843 – 1 August 1918 ) was an English and British mathematician and statistician.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
   
   
 === Early life ===  
 Thomson was born on 2 January 1843 in Borland, Kent, the son of Sir James Thomson and Eleanor Ballot, née Hamley. He was the third of five children, the eldest son of Thomas Thomson, a pharmacist. His father, a notable amateur physician, was also the grandson of the painter William Bellingham and an uncle of George Bellingham. Thomson was educated at Eton College and the Imperial College of Science and Technology, Cambridge, where he became a doctor in 1891. After completing his medical studies, Thomson became a demonstrator at the Royal Institution in 1888. He became associate professor of statistics in 1892 and Dean of the Faculty of Mathematics at Cambridge in 1893. At the same time, he set up the School of Statistics at Cambridge, the first in the country. He was appointed by Herbert Samuel to head a Department of Statistical Studies in 1896. On his retirement in 1914, he was made Prentis Companion of the Order of St Michael and St George.  
   
   
 === Early life in Europe ===  
 Having turned down an offer from the LSE to become a lecturer in 1920 at the University of Jena, Thomson soon moved to Europe where he was soon invited by the Société royale de physique to become its director of research.  
 After the war ended, Thomson travelled around Europe and discovered numerous new trends in mathematics and statistics, for which he won the Grégorian Society Prize, and the 1915 Marconi Prize for Generalising the power of population distribution. This and his increasing prominence as a leader on the international mathematics scene began to influence the future of mathematics and statistics in Britain. The future of mathematical and statistical sciences there was further bound by international laws and conventions, and by high standards of evidence and rigour, and if Thomson saw any other pattern in Europe he would often be able to comment on it in the public journals.  
   
   
 === Marriage and family ===  
 In 1912 Thomson married Barbara Newton and had two sons and three daughters. At the outbreak of World War I, Thomson's son William James joined the Royal Army Medical Corps as a cadet and returned to England as a lieutenant. There was little intention of re-establishing the Thomson tradition in Britain. When war broke out in 1914, a series of deep recessions and cutbacks were felt to adversely affect the reputation of the state.In 1916, Thomson became tutor to children at the School of Economics and Political Science at St John's College in Guildford, Kent. In 1919, he was elected a fellow of the Royal Society. He continued to publish papers in the Society's Annual Report and later wrote articles on economic planning, for which he was awarded the Ronald Medal.  
   
   
 === Lady  
 In 1920, Thomson had three more sons, including Charles James Thomson.  
 On his death at his son's birth the US National Library of Medicine published a memorial to Thomson, `` Thomson, Sir. ''  
 Thomson met Lady Ellen Gaylor ; they married on 27 September 1926 at Dublin's South Court, Magherafelt Street, the youngest son being named Charles.  
 His grandson Christopher Gaylor, third Baroness Janet, became the last Lord Beveridge of the Gaylor family.  
   
   
 == Selected publications ==  
 Thomson, J. S. ( 1918 ), `` Description of a statistical method of measuring variability in chemical concentration of peat '', Economica, Volume 13, Issue 8, Pages 315–316  
 Thomson, J. S. ; Sylvester, F. P. ( 1928 ), Theory of Statistics ( 2nd ed. ) ( 2nd ed., 1922 )  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Othniel Schlei =  
Othniel Schlei ( November 14, 1835 – May 16, 1912 ) was an American German composer, teacher, and teacher. Schlei's music addresses the aspirations and needs of ordinary people, including his own. His music is rooted in the classical tradition, and also focuses on modernist and neo-classical music.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Born in Stuttgart, Schlei began to compose early in life. In 1840, he moved to Berlin to teach music to students. In 1851, he established himself as a teacher at the Munchhausen Music Academy, becoming the president of the German Society of Music in 1857. In 1860, he founded the Schlei Music School and taught music there until his death. He also held several honorary degrees from prestigious universities. Schlei was the son of a prominent politician, businessman, artist, author, and teacher, named Adolf Schlei.  
 Schlei was primarily a teacher of classical music, but is notable for writing the pieces to his own music and teaching classical music in Germany during the French Empire. Among his pupils was composer Hans Zimmer, who wrote an official recital piece for the occasion. His most important pupils included composer Ludwig van Beethoven, e.g. the family of music critic Cornelis ( William ) Wirtzel. His compositions were produced in large numbers. Schlei's music was extremely popular in Germany, Austria-Hungary, Russia, Italy, Sweden, France, the Netherlands, the United States, and other countries.  
   
   
 == List of works ==  
 List of works  
 Schlei's operas  
   
 Fuga cello  
 Donatina in A major, op. 70 ( 1852 )  
 Donata della Saggiugno in B-flat major  
 Donata della Saggiugno in D-flat major, op. 72 ( 1854 )  
 Rhapsodie sinfonia in G minor, op. 75 ( 1854 )  
 Donata in G major, op. 78 ( 1854 )  
 Der Rheinode in F-sharp minor, op. 79 ( 1855 )  
 Sinfonia partita in F minor, op. 80 ( 1855 )  
 Sonata di J. B. Kluge, op. 81 ( 1856 )  
 Dance of the Animals in A minor, op. 82 ( 1856 )  
 Il Melibene for 2 pianos, op. 83 ( 1856 )  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Robert Greenleaf =  
Robert Greenleaf ( 1877–1959 ) was an Australian educational psychologist.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Robert Greenleaf was born on the Isle of Man in September 1877.  
 He studied for two years at the Canterbury University College where he completed his diploma in 1889.He lectured for a short time at the University of Queensland, earning a Bachelor of Arts in Education. In 1895 he became a lecturer at St. Charles College. He moved to Sydney in 1898 and began teaching at the school of education and psychology, now known as the Department of Education, School of Education and Training at Sydney University, where he would spend the rest of his life.  
 After living for a while at the University of Adelaide, Greenleaf returned to Sydney in 1903. He obtained a masters degree from the University of Western Australia and was employed as an assistant to Richard Elliot Jones. Jones recruited him to the University of Western Australia, and he remained there until his retirement in 1941.  
 During the period of his service, Jones founded the Psychology Research Unit and Greenleaf became its director.  
 Between 1900 and 1914 Greenleaf edited the American Journal of Psychology. His best-known work was the 1902 monograph Personality and Psychology, based on observations of five Victorian student authorities.Greenleaf died on 10 August 1959 in Sydney at the age of 77.  
   
   
 == Publications ==  
 Personality and Psychology ; a monograph ( 1905 ).  
 The Career of Thomas Colman ( 1905 ).  
 The Physiology of Temperament ( 1910 ).  
 Health and Life ( 1912 ).  
 The Mental and Behavioral School ( 1914 ).  
 Psychoanalysis in Britain and Ireland ( 1919 ).  
 The Psychological Meaning of Musical Tunes ( 1920 ).  
 Human Needs : A System of Social Views ( 1922 ).  
 The Origin of the Ego ( 1924 ).  
 ( with Ruth Reacher and Robert C. Spurr ) A Study of the Educational Factors in Juvenile Health ( 1924 ).  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Walter D. Mullan =  
Walter D. Mullan ( October 21, 1917 – November 6, 2005 ) was an American chemist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 He was born in Nashua, New Hampshire, and studied chemistry at Harvard University. His brother, Gordon, was an American botanist who, in 1950, demonstrated the genetic determinism of Colchicum.  
 In 1951, Dr. Mullan published a paper called `` Primary and Secondary Responses of a Phenomenon to various Heterogeneous Conditions '' in the field of physical chemistry. In it, he suggested that the secondary reaction, typically referred to as an oxygen-oxidation reaction, takes place when a compound is subjected to pressures of four bar, but in fact is a facultative, or facultative C2 reaction, which results in a final product of a compound that is more oxidized at neutral ( pH = 4.0 ) or in acidic ( pH = 4.5 ) conditions. These `` oxidative conditions '' cause the product to oxidize oxygen, leaving the product impure and unusable.  
 In 1953, at the age of 42, he became Director of Research for the Chemical Division of the Minerals and Metals Agency ( now the American Chemical Society ). His other accomplishments include the development of phosphocreatine as an energy-saving, fuel-saving, and organic-chemical polymer. His chemical and physical investigations were influential in scientific contributions to the field of biochemistry, petrology, biophysics, and pest control.  
 Mullan also investigated the origins of sulfuric acid in the soil.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 Orationes dicitur metallographica ( 1940 ) - Organic chemist writes about different metallogamics.  
 Chemical pointes of surface temperatures ( 1972 ) - Some general concepts in chemical surface temperature studies.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Isaac Kahn (composer) =  
Isaac `` Ocelot '' Kahn ( 4 March 1928 – 5 December 2005 ) was an English composer.  
   
   
 == Life and career ==  
 Kahn was born in Brooklyn, New York. He studied with Jan Bolum, and when he was 11 he moved to London to study music with Roger Sessions. His first work was called `` Live up the Shelf ''. He wrote orchestral music for voice and orchestra. Kahn also wrote symphonies and choral works. He performed them in concerts.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 Kahn wrote symphonies, chamber music, and other non-war music. His orchestral works, including his Symphony No. 1, consisted of music by more than 75 composers, as well as elements from scores by Robert Schumann, Robert Schumann, Stanisław Maria Callas, Anton Rubinstein, Martin Hall, and others. Some of his other works include :  
   
 `` Play off '' for soloist ( 1932 ).  
   
   
 == Publications ==  
 Kahn's published works include :  
   
 THE CIRCUMSTANCES OF PHRASE ADOLF ARTHUR ADAMIE : symphonic poem composed in 1932.  
 The Choral Essays of Bram Stoker : single performance ( 1940 ).  
 THE CIRCUMSTANCES OF MYSTERY SERENADE - concerto  
 LAND OF TONGUES : symphonic poem composed in 1950  
 CONSPIRACIES ( composer and lyricist ) : symphonic poem composed in 1956.  
 THE CIRCUMSTANCES OF BEYOND THE STREET : symphonic poem composed in 1959.  
   
   
 == Selected discography ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Ernst Büsslein =  
Ernst Berthold Büsslein ( German : [ ˈbʃɪtɪ ] ; 8 April 1869 – 7 June 1953 ) was a German physicist.  
 Büsslein received his B.Sc. from the University of Göttingen and his Ph.D. from Leipzig in 1904 with a thesis entitled Das zur die amindwürde Konversationsproblem.  
 In his doctoral thesis, Büsslein presented a solution for the quantum field equation of the relativistic atomic motion, the classical pendulum phenomenon ( which became known as Büsslein's pendulum-sink problem ), in relation to heat.  
 In 1919 he went to work as a technician in the Lwów electrical and telegraph department under the Polish engineer Wladyslaw Havlík. From 1924 to 1937 he was the director of the Institute of Physics at the Jagiellonian University of Technology in Szczecin.  
 His most notable papers are :  
   
 Die ultrafiberschwannung und Geereschwörung im einem radium-fluoriden und in die europäische Gedankenheit. Jahrbuch der Metallurgie 1, Krakau-Karteption und Aufsätze, 1917.  
 Die quantumen Gewalt in einem das Wesen [ Erlösung des europäischen Naturgeschichts ], Stuttgart : Jahrbücher, 1926.  
   
   
 == Bibliography ==  
 E. Büsslein ( 2004 ) The Penrose Period : a Chronological Compilation of the work of Ernst Büsslein. John Wiley & Sons. ISBN 0-471-43679-7.  
 Johannes Bernhard Bondi ( 1952 ) Die gesammeltershang des neuen meglingsarbeiters In der allgemeinen Weihnachtsstimmen, Mathematik und Fachgebiete der Institut für Mathematik der Wissenschaften, Stuttgart-Jahrbuch für die Mathematiker-Fachsläufe A/F.M.. Strassmann.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Sven Stuhmfelder =  
Sven Christian Stuhmfelder ( 27 October 1887 – 25 March 1968 ) was a Norwegian botanist. He studied at the University of Oslo, then worked in Norway as a teacher in timber industry.  
 From 1921 until 1934, he served as the Director of the Natural History Museum, and as Chief librarian of the Forestry Museum of Oslo. He also worked as the Director of the Norwegian Free Public Library.  
 His works include :  
   
 Er dal flora et den terraultnisbafarna veskter. Botanisk Notræmmedicine 1934 – Forests and the inland terrairies.  
 Men Norges landbildes meintrierekkeleven ( 1928 ) – Field Naturalists of Norway.  
 Dietrich Völhåbling, hera saga barmason ( 1931 ) – Dietrich Völhåbling's book.  
 Im Österreich- botaniker over hunde ( 1937 ) – In Norway.  
 Nedelige landbild ( 1937 ) – Norwegian books.  
 Life over af ( 1940 ) – Life over land.  
 Crambologie det altabet over kontinenten. Memorie til Væreberungen, d.Gr., 1909 ( 1935-1940 ) – About climate.  
 Anggelsena om Landbild ( 1941 ) – An account of Norway.Sven was elected as a Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh in 1957.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Leopold Monge =  
Leopold Monge ( 8 September 1862 – 29 April 1947 ) was a German composer, pianist and teacher.  
 Born into a prominent musical family in Silesia, he was raised in Stuttgart and later studied law in Leipzig. In 1897, he became professor of music at Berlin's Würzburg University, and in 1905 and 1911, professor of composition at the Josefstadt Conservatory.  
 In 1912, he founded the Chopin Conservatory in Leipzig. In 1924, he established the center for modern music at the Berlin Landesche Music Institute, now part of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra, where he taught until his death. He later went to Paris, where he became a senior member of the Department of Music of the Conservatoire de France. From 1927, he was a professor at the newly founded Leipzig Conservatory of Music.  
 In 1928, Monge released his Piano Works, in four volumes : Part One, B-Oeuvre und Guitare ( Das freude und zwei Music, B-Oeuvre 1891, Russian translation with introduction by Ivan Amadeusov ) ; Part Two, Giacomo Puccini, Op.45 ; Part Three, Serenade for Pianoforte, Op.52 ; and Part Four, for Piano, Piano Trio, and Four-Finger Piano, Op.58.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Félix Allain =  
François Lévêque Allain ( 26 November 1838, Fleury - 4 March 1899, Besançon ) was a French pediatrician, born in Thionville-la-Neuve in 1838, physician at St-Léopold-du-Loup Hospital in Besançon, préparator of the education in medicine in Besançon at the renowned Lyon Institute for Child-care, and from 1884, professor of pediatrics and pediatrics at the Lyon Polytechnic School.  
 In 1888 he graduated from the Faculté de Médecine de Besançon, then at the Collège Bélissieuse des sciences. From 1892, he was the special surgeon-surgeon at the Renard Hospital, Paris. Allain was the father of Gaston Allain.  
 Félix Allain was a citizen of several cities. From 1879 he worked at the Saint-Orfeo Hospital and the Allemagne Hospital in Paris, and in 1900, he was the first director of the Children's Hospital in Paris.  
 In 1904, he was appointed teacher of pediatrics and pediatric hygiene at the Besançon Pediatric School. He was also a professor at the Polytechnic School, founded in 1884 and since 1905 it was the center of the medical, scientific and pedagogical sciences in Besançon, and it opened in 1883. He taught for seven years at the Polytechnic School, from 1894 to 1900.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Igor Samoilov =  
Igor Vladimirovich Samoilov ( 23 April 1908 – 29 September 1980 ) was a Russian physiologist.  
 He was born in Saint Petersburg and studied natural sciences at the Moscow State University. He worked at the Russian National Institute of Physiology.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Samoilov received his doctorate at the Moscow State University in 1921. In 1922, he became a research associate at the Vologda Center of Physiology and Metabolism. Samoilov was assigned as director of the Institute of Physiology and Metabolism, Moscow, and succeeded Dmitri Roginsky. In 1943, he was promoted to head the Institute of Physiology and Metabolism. In 1947, he became dean of the medical faculty, serving until 1962.Samoilov is remembered for his role in the development of the laboratory of exercise physiology at the Moscow State University in Moscow. He led efforts to synthesize many factors and variables necessary for exercise physiology.  
 Samoilov is listed in Health and Nutrition at the UK's National Library of Medicine ( LNCM ) database as having received at least 11 FFS ( First-class Honours ) awards. In 1984, the London Met Office created the Health Service Award to recognize a career-high performance in health, after consulting a jury of health professionals.Samoilov also described as `` a dear colleague '' the former Nobel laureate Andrey Anatolyevich Leonidov.  
   
   
 == Achievements ==  
 During the Cold War, in the 1950s and 1960s, Samoilov was the most important scientist on exercise physiology. Samoilov's monumental research projects were involved in developing all kinds of physical processes used in exercise physiology. These included electrophysiological studies of the central nervous system, electrophysiological studies of the isolated membrane potentials of the heart and skeletal muscles, electrophysiological studies of several aspects of the local exchange of force between skeletal muscle and the central nervous system, and electrophysiological studies of cortical neuronal activity. Many of these investigations were carried out with G. V. Budelj.  
   
   
 == Family ==  
 Samoilov married from his studies the West German physiology researcher Barbara Rottenstein in 1925. Together they had three children, H. A. Samoilov, Ph.D., J. F. Jirko, Ph.D., and Y. B. Samoilov.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = James Mackenzie Smith =  
James Mackenzie Smith ( 8 January 1651 – 17 March 1748 ) was an English Romantic writer, dramatist and poet. He was the son of Edward Smith and secondly the eldest of five children of James Mackenzie, who was the quartermaster of Trinity College, Cambridge and was also the contemporary of John Ruskin, an intimate friend of Ruskin.  
 In 1692 he was admitted to the university, where he studied Latin, Hebrew, Greek, Latin in six years, but failed in both Latin and Greek.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 Many of his works are not known, but are known for two statements :  
   
 `` Here is the admirable fountain of toil ( Hebrews 13:11 ) '' The first reference occurs in the lost commentary of Mr. Willis, ed., the exposition of the Book of Job, torn, p. 828, and is attributed to James Mackenzie Smith.  
 `` Here I live. '' Verse in Job 17:19, and elsewhere in the Old Testament.  
 `` What ( Deuteronomy 31:11 ), which is ennobling them, the children of Israel, whose fathers we are! '' Verse in Exodus 30:31.  
 `` Esteemed persons in every order of merit, men of the kingdom, as Solomon at Jerusalem, and as Joshua at Hyrum ( 1 Kings 17:22 ) '' Like Joshua and Solomon, and Benjamin Zephaniah, he appears to have had a high social position in his day.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Eduard Orban de Cote =  
Eduard Orban de Cote ( Spanish : Alberto Benito Nicolás Pérez de Cote, December 7, 1823 – March 17, 1891 ), born in the town of Milano, Italy, was an Austrian-Jewish scholar.  
 He became an ecumenical preacher in Tiberias in 1874, and several years later came to Palestine, where he served as an assistant to Rabbi Yoseph Bialik, and later was a rabbi in the Jerusalem congregation.  
 He married Miriam Goldstein in 1875.  
 He died in Neuweiler near Breslau in 1891.  
 He had a son, Solomon Antony, and a daughter, Mercedes Kate de Cote.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Louis-Marie Laurence =  
Louis-Marie Laurence ( 3 November 1787 – 7 December 1868 ) was a French diplomat.  
 Laurence was born in Toulouse. He served as ambassador to the Palatinate between 1815 and 1826. He was the first French-born member of the Académie Royale des Sciences ( Academy of Sciences ) and of the Académie française du Québec.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Louis-Marie Laurence was born at the Collège de Toulouse on 3 November 1787. He was the younger of three sons, a descendant of Thomas-Marie Laurence, minister of the Assumption, and his wife, Étienne. A granddaughter of Étienne's, Marie-Vincent-Élie, was consul in Toulouse between 1811 and 1813. The sons of the second eldest ( 'Beau Jean') were also diplomats.The younger Laurence was taught Latin, and later studied it in France at the College of La Salle and from 1810, at the Paris Conservatoire. After graduation he joined the diplomatic corps of Catherine the Great's diplomatic corps at Neuilly-sur-Seine.He then accepted the post of corregnum ( Second Consul ) in Paris, and received the degree of doctor de privilège in 1820. Laurence served as consul in Toulouse between 1815 and 1826, when he was consul general in Toulouse until 1842.From 1828 he served as chief counsellor to the Grand-duke of Monaco, the vice-consul general in Jura. He served in the same post in the Pacific and Indian Seas. The custom of conducting formal diplomatic proceedings in the northern part of the Empire came to an end in 1848, when Philippe Henri IV died in Toulouse. Louis-Marie Laurence accepted the post of consul general in La Rochelle and was sent to Paris by the Emperor Napoleon III, whose treasury was very large ; however he became a strong opponent of the political system and the Chamber of Deputies, and resigned from the Comité des Affaires de l'Expérience in 1846.He died at Leiden, Netherlands on 7 December 1868.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 Among Laurence's most important works are :  
   
 La Santé des États éléments de Vianney ( 1819 )  
 Reports on the Orient of French Missions ( 1820 )  
 Mémoires sur l ’ Italiennes des Provinces, 1823, 2 volumes  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Henri Pelletier =  
Henri Pelletier ( November 22, 1878 – June 19, 1969 ) was a French conductor, composer, and pianist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Pelletier was born in Nancy, Meuse, the son of a schoolteacher. He attended the École Normale Supérieure, and later became professor of piano and composition there, a position he occupied until his death.  
 He studied piano with Nadia Boulanger ( 1872–1946 ), violin with William Pilett ( 1879–1934 ), and composition with François de Valois and Felix Orlandes ( 1880–1920 ).  
 During his first years in Paris, he studied with the gifted composer Jules Massenet, whom he described as the man `` who, by composing great works for orchestra and chamber orchestra, won for music the esteem of every student. '' Among his teachers were the pianists Antonio Ravel, Antonio Cortes, Felix Orlandes, and Claude-Michel Trocchi. Pilett later gave him a performance of the Mannheim String Quartet's Turandot on an A9 905, and the Pontecorvo Quartet's Tosca on a two-handed keyboard.Pelletier joined the École Normale Supérieure in 1903, after he had studied under Clara Penrose-Gymnasium and the renowned teaching staff of Claude Monod.From 1912 to 1919 he was a teacher at the Conservatoire de Paris, the National Conservatory, and the Paris Conservatoire.He composed a concerto, Oboe Concerto, Op. 24, and works for piano. His two works for piano, Violin Concerto ( 1906–1912 ) and String Quartet No. 1 in E major for piano, which, along with his performance of the 4th movement of Schubert's The Lady of Sufism, constitute his Impromptus, have received large concerts and recording, and was the subject of a 2008 documentary about him.He also wrote operas, ballet and dramas, two plays, and two piano sonatas. He died in Paris, aged 86, after a long illness.  
 The Nicolae Lenz Handel Concert ( known as the Tour d'Alfabet ) was inaugurated at the Eiffel Tower by the composer and conductor. It was composed in three acts, with a first act not performed and an encore work first performed on July 21, 1945.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 PercussionConcertante op. 1 ( 1898 )  
 Concerto ( 1907 )  
 Paris Opera op. 2 ( 1912 )  
 Suite No. 2 for piano ( 1912 )  
 Méditation II ( 1929 )

 Noël and the FiennesOp. 3 ( 1912 )  
 Musique grande op. 4  
 Sonatine, Op. 5 for piano and orchestra ( 1913 )  
 Violin Concerto, Op. 7  
 Trio ( 1916 )  
 Étude  
 Orchestre singulier for violin, viola and piano ( 1926 )

<start_bio> 
 = Stanisław Krawczyk =  
Stanisław Krawczyk ( December 7, 1924 – January 26, 2008 ) was a Polish-American mathematician.  
 He received a B.S. degree from Simon Fraser University in Vancouver, British Columbia. He taught at Concordia University in Concordia, California. He received a Ph.D. degree in mathematical logic from the University of Ottawa in Canada in 1949. In 1965, Krawczyk moved to the US and joined the faculty of the University of Minnesota's Department of Mathematics.  
 Krawczyk also served as President of the International Mathematical Union, from 1985 until 1988. He was President of the American Mathematical Society, from 1989 until 1989. He was also Honorary President of the ICM Society for Mathematicians.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Denis Jerzy Parnkiewicz =  
Denis Jerzy Parnkiewicz ( November 26, 1902, in Prague – September 24, 1977, in Vienna ) was a Polish mathematician, best known for his contribution to probability theory and probability fields in statistics and mathematics. He died of a heart attack in Vienna on September 24, 1977, aged 74.  
 Parnkiewicz studied mathematics in school in Prague and Lwów. His student is the younger Emil Serners.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Christoph Stanhope =  
Christoph Stanhope ( January 22, 1853, Henzl, Bremerhaven – February 23, 1942, Frankfurt am Main ) was a German-born physicist and a renowned physicist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Stanhope was born in Henzl and educated in the family's salon and he received the professorship at the university in 1883. In 1884 he became Professor of Mechanics at the university and in 1890 he joined the Swiss Academy of Sciences, becoming a full professor there in 1897. He was also awarded the Ernst Herzog medal for this work. He was President of the Zurich Academy of Sciences in 1889 and died in Frankfurt am Main in 1942.  
 Stanhope invented a method of measuring radiant heat and used the method in the analysis of heat flowing into a cylindrical emitter from a cavity, which is known as his Stanhope–Tietze method. The method was one of the first to calculate the volumetric energy of one mole of crystal, by using this principle.  
 In 1887 he published a short account of radiating heat.  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Ernst Plenker =  
Ernst Plenker ( 16 January 1895 – 8 October 1966 ) was a German writer and former sexologist. He wrote prolifically on sex and other topics in his works. His numerous scientific articles and monographs had a wide-ranging impact in the scientific world, especially on intersex matters.  
 Ernst Plenker was born on 16 January 1895 in Wiesbaden, Prussia. In 1901, he entered the faculty of medicine of the University of Kiel in Germany. From 1902 he was professor of pharmacology at the Medical University of Halle. In 1908, he became director of the medical school. He retired in 1936 and lived in retirement in Karlsruhe.  
 He was a homosexual and his wife, the journalist Auguste Guillaume Plenker, was regarded as his best friend. He was the author of more than 100 scientific papers on sex and on other topics and is considered as the founder of the intersex movement in Germany, not only in clinical medicine but also in biology and psychiatry.  
   
   
 == Bibliography ==  
 Dresdner-Interesse zur Sexualkunde bei Berlin-Gymnasium ( The Development of Infant Sex Orgasm ) ; 1926  
 Die Entwicklung des Pädagogischen Gegenschaftes, Vol. 1 ; 1931  
 Das sexuelle Aufgabe in Berlin-Gymnasium ( The Present Status of Infant Sex Orgasm ) ; 1932  
 Dresden : Verlag Erhard Plenker ; 1934  
 Zur sexuelle Aufgabe in Berlin-Gymnasium ; 1936  
 Zur sexuelle Pädagogische Bemerkungen auf den kammersehen Medicin, Studien und Erinnerungen, Verlag Erhard Plenker ; 1938  
 Die Biologie der Sexuale ( Biology of Sex ) ; 1936  
 Der reinen und die sexuelle Melden aus dem Heilige Meldungen : Über die sieberliche Elektrochemicalen Anwendung der Anodismus ( Genetic and Oral Anonymism : Über Infant Sexual Signaling ) ; 1936  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Henry Edinger (botanist) =  
Henry E. Edinger ( 14 December 1902 – 27 June 1984 ) was a Canadian botanist who specialized in nuclear algae.Edinger's work described many microalgae. His publication, Tracing of Unidentified Algae, was completed in 1974.  
   
   
 == Background and education ==  
 Edinger was born in Halifax, Nova Scotia. Edinger graduated from the University of Montreal in 1934. He worked as an assistant plant pathologist, working with botanists Edward Ackley and Clifford Hentschel in Quebec.In 1936 Edinger joined the staff of the plant pathologist Edwin C. Bergstrom at McGill University. During this period he also helped to develop New Brunswick ’ s soya plant pathologist, George Krivitsky. Bergstrom later appointed Edinger professor of plant pathology in 1950.In the 1950s Edinger assisted with studies of microalgae. Edinger died in Montreal on 27 June 1984. He was survived by his second wife, Linda Pusey.  
   
   
 == Selected publications ==  
 Two and a half decades later, a paper was published on the evolution of the algae Coleinula edingeri, an important taxonomic revision of Coleinula edingeri by Alexander Bailey, Sidney Bloch and others. His taxonomic approach was more conservative than that of Carruthers and Schirmer in the 1970s.  
 Microalgae : a Triangulation Study. American Entomologist, 59 ( 1 ), 1954, p. 49-56.  
 [ Edinger, H. E. ( 1954 ). “ A new species of Acrylodeum ( Saccharomyces ). ” American Entomologist. 59 ( 1 ), pp. 49-56. doi:10.2307/364929. JSTOR 336329.  
   
   
 == Books and authors ==  
 Tracing of Unidentified Algae. Toronto : University of Toronto Press, 1953.  
 Crop Assessment Guide : Building Guide to Organic and inorganic Gardening. Mary E. Baker, 1966.  
   
   
 == Recognition ==  
 Gillian Howe Sadler, senior botanist at the National Research Council, later worked in the Fish and Wildlife Service at the University of Victoria, as an expert in microalgae. She was an academic and published a scientific paper on a distribution of algae in the Maliseet atlas, produced at the request of the Minister of Fisheries and Fisheries Services, Ned Ewing, in 1975.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Alfred Matthay =  
Alfred Matthay ( 17 March 1805 – 27 October 1859 ) was a Dutch cartographer and naturalist. He was the first Dutch Professor of Geology and a teacher of botany at the Imperial College of Arts and Sciences.  
 Matthay was born in Kerkendijk in the Dutch Reformed Brethren of Nederland, where he grew up. His father, Joris Matthay, was a physician and naturalist.He was one of the professors of cartography in the Imperial College of Arts and Sciences ( then the University of Amsterdam ), where he taught for two decades. As a naturalist, he took a great interest in marine life and especially the fish life.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Charles Seaborg =  
Charles Seaborg ( 26 September 1869 – 8 March 1948 ) was a German naturalist who was a marine biologist, parasitologist and, as a zoologist, fish and invertebrate collector and herpetologist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Seaborg was born in Wiltshire, England. He attended Upper Ephraimshire Grammar School, where his natural history was taught by his father Walter Gottlieb Seaborg and his uncle Cornelius Gabriel Seaborg. In 1906, he moved to Leipzig as a teacher, where he earned an MA in 1910. He graduated as a Senior Lecturer in Zoology in 1919 and was awarded an MD in 1928.  
 In 1930, he was appointed professor of zoology at the University of Leipzig, where he remained until his retirement in 1947. He published scientific papers and textbooks on parasitology and dermestidology, and led expeditions to the Baltic Sea, in France, Germany and Russia.  
   
   
 == Herpetology ==  
 From 1910 to 1928, Seaborg was working at the Max Planck Institute for Zooology in Berlin as curator and herpetologist. The first insect collection at the university he created was with the help of Heinrich Gießen, in charge of care for the mammals, especially a porcupine. He helped to supply very accurate descriptions of the collected specimens. These `` spring water plants '' ( New Zealand algae ), collected in the South Island of New Zealand, are named in his honour.  
   
   
 == Natural history collections ==  
 Seaborg made many collections of plants in Germany. Many were in the Netherlands, and several in New Zealand. He collected many genera and species, such as Selsachia thelli, Indian dragonfly, Pseudopelma aurantiaca, British heronfly, Japanese chameleon, Egyptian snake, cave scorpion, Chilean snake, lake snake, and several African frogs.  
   
   
 == Personal life ==  
 In 1934, Seaborg married the Danish-born Eva Haas ; they had a son, Eduard, born in 1940. She died of cancer in 1952.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Thomas Hurrell Coffin =  
Thomas Hurrell Coffin ( 10 March 1845 – 22 June 1929 ) was an Irish violinist and teacher.  
 He was the brother of I.C. Coffin, the father of fluteist Professor Owen Coffin.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Coffin was born at Gevorkamilton, County Mayo.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 Coffin studied with musicians including Bertram Dawes, George Bernard Shaw, Henry Cowley, and Henry Dewar.  
 At the age of seventeen he toured to America with the Royal College of Music to perform contemporary repertoire. His show on the opening night of the 1891 South Pacific Exposition, in the Old State Theatre, was enthusiastically received and featured artists such as Gabriel Fauré, Douglas Fairbairn, Peter Gabriel, Oscar Neugorne and Stanley Hall.In 1896 he played in the pro-wrestler exhibition on Dublin, and in 1898 entered the Oran Conservatory of Music where he studied with Walter Rodney and played the violin.  
 In 1900 he conducted an English performance of The Four Tunes in Dublin and in 1902 was appointed Fœderie conductor.  
 Coffin performed regularly as conductor of both St. Paul's Cathedral and St. Patrick's Cathedral. He was a teacher at different periods, chiefly at Trinity College, Dublin.  
 He died in Dublin.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 Cappella y Abadonde : Venito física in D Major, Op. 23 ( 1878 )  
 Cantata for Two Cello and Bassoons, Op. 17 ( 1880 )  
 Lamento for Soprano and Flute, Op. 7 ( 1886 )  
 The Four Tunes for Two Cello and Bassoon, Op. 17 ( 1888 )  
 Variations on an Irish Text Book, Oratory of the Rt. Hon. Charles Lytton, Op. 14 ( 1890 )  
 La Gioconda del Passionismo, by Agostino Piarotti, Op. 8 ( 1893 )  
 Cantata for Four Cello and Bassoon, Op. 26 ( 1898 )

<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Eugene Petrey =  
Eugene Christian Pietro Petrey ( Italian : [ ˈpteʁʁɪs ˈpʁɪx ˈjoʁʁɪjɪt ] ; 7 October 1752 – 8 July 1807 ) was an Italian physician, anatomist and botanist. He made an important contribution to the anatomy of the skull. He is credited as the first to observe the formation of a biopse, or `` development from incisor to ulna '' in the skull, in 1764.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Petrey was born in Palermo, on 7 October 1752. He was the nephew of the scientist Gaetano Petrey, and was also the great-great-great-great-great-grandson of the German cartographer Carl Petrey. He studied medicine in Naples under Nicola Tesla, who in turn encouraged him to follow the study of anatomy, and in the process encouraged him to be a physician. In 1774, he graduated from the University of Naples with the degree of Bachelor of Medicine. He stayed with Tesla in California, where he became acquainted with the celebrated surgeon Charles Wirth, who later helped to write his treatise, Anatomia Chimica Medicina, published in 1779. In 1784, he was elected a member of the Entomological Society of London, and in 1789 became its inaugural president. The name `` Petrey '' was probably proposed by Wirth, who became his assistant.Petrey practiced anatomy in Montpellier from 1792 until his death, when he moved to Florence, where he published A Neue Anatomie zu Vienna ( A New Anatomy of Vienna ). From 1793 until his death, Petrey was Secretary of the Royal Society of Medicine, and in 1797, he was President of the Academy of Medicine.  
   
   
 == Bibliography ==  
 Monographia of the Brain. Florence, Bijoux, Bolland, 1804.  
 Anatomia Chimica Medicina. Utopian Physicians.... Florence, Verlag Giebel, 1816.  
 Sull'anatomia tutte corores. Monografia anatomica Italiana. Florence, Oleri, Francetini, 1822.  
   
   
 == Published works ==  
   
   
 === Chronology ===  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Thomas Parker Abbott =  
Thomas Parker Abbott ( 12 September 1829 – 29 September 1905 ) was an English theologian, specializing in the ethics of sexual morality. Abbott was born on 12 September 1829, and educated at Dorpingham School, Cambridge. He was associated with the University of Cambridge from 1848 to 1856 and Trinity College, Oxford, from 1856 to 1866. He held the chair of theology and philosophy at the London School of Economics from 1868 to 1876. Abbott was a preacher, teacher and Christian missionary, and, during his life, published over twenty works.  
 Abbott was a prolific writer, and his Institutes and Abridgments is one of the best known Bible and theological treatises of his day. In the introduction to it he concludes that `` the use of the Bible as the sole model for the ethical and political problems connected with family life is unquestionable, as is its qualification to govern the community itself ''. He is known for his account of love as an ethical ideal, which emphasized the truth that love involves the assurance of the object of love's affection'being reciprocated ; the teaching of equal consideration and justification for loving the same person in all circumstances ; and the authorship of the Code of Moral Conduct, with the doctrine of the doctrine of justification by faith, which he `` restored to the Christian conscience '', in his 1894 version of what is now called moral absolutism. His focus of many theological debates centred on homosexuality and other sexual immorality, and the moral function of the church.Abbott died at Peterborough, Berkshire, and was buried in St Paul's Churchyard, London, in 1905.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 Treatise on Justification and the Repentance of Sins, 1878.  
 Love, Equality, and the Redeemer's Cross, 1898.  
 The Moral Writings of Thomas Parker Abbott, 1919.  
 The Divine Reason for Theology, 1929.  
 Bible : An Exegetical Commentary on the Old Testament, 1930.  
 What Is Love? ( 1988 ).  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Paul H. Hoffmann =  
Paul H. Hoffmann ( 1921–2002 ) was an American entomologist and paleontologist.  
   
   
 == Early life ==  
 Hoffmann was born in Hartel, New Jersey, on November 21, 1921. His parents, Martin H. Hoffmann ( b. 1909, d. 1958 ), a doctor of divinity, and Paula L. Hoffmann ( b. 1914 ), a mother of six, were members of the Sisters of Christian Charity. His mother, without the required diploma, taught him English and math. For his middle and high school career, he was a volunteer in volunteer relief in California, then briefly as a member of the Boy Scouts of America, but, after a year of doing some field work, he decided to pursue a career in biology. He became interested in entomology by reading pages from The Mowbray's Cyclopedia of Insects ( 1923 ).  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 Hoffmann gained a BS in biology in 1926 from the University of Delaware, followed by a Ph.D. in 1920 from Cornell University. After an injury and a persistent fever, he accepted a position at the University of New Mexico as a zoology instructor, in which position he also directed a department. He earned a licentiate of arts in 1933. Hoffmann also served as president of the Entomological Society of New Mexico in 1936. In 1958, Hoffmann became associate director of the Mote Marine Laboratory, just north of Albuquerque. During this time, he also played a major role in the establishment of the Mexican Museum of Natural History. He was the curator of paleobotany at the Museum of Vertebrate Paleontology, and was a visiting professor at Harvard University in 1952 and 1958.  
 From 1956 to 1958, he was a consultant for the United States Fish and Wildlife Service and served as the lead scientist on the 1944 Mote Marine expedition to study the Tasmanian tiger. From 1962 to 1967, he was a professor in the California Academy of Sciences at San Marcos.In addition to his educational work, he was a high-energy husband and father. He died at the age of 82, from mesothelioma.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 Hoffmann, Paul H. ( 1939 ). New Dawn of Insects. Harper & Row.  
 Hoffmann, Paul H. ( 1955 ). The fossil fauna of the Lower Cretaceous British Museum of Natural History. London : Routledge and Kegan Paul. ISBN 978-0-19-567227-3.  
 Hoffmann, Paul H. ( 1961 ). Review of A facsimile of a new fossil Ichthyopoda species, Eumelopus hermaphrodite ( Ostwald ) Hoffmann,. New York : National Geographic Society. ISBN 978-0-9295100-7-9.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Benjamin Abbott and the Metropolitan Church =  
Loudoun County Congregationalist Benjamin Abbott and the Metropolitan Church in Loudoun County, Virginia, is named after him.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 Abbott was an author of numerous articles and commentaries on church history, including :  
   
 The Founder of the Mechanics'Church in Loudoun, Virginia ( 1835 )  
 The Christ During the Exiles ( 1836 )  
 Young Tribes in Virginia ( 1837 )  
 Jerusalem and the Jews ( 1839 )  
 Hebrew Strangers, Lower Tribes and Settlement in Virginia ( 1841 )  
 The Exiles and the Greeks of Virginia ( 1842 )  
 The Bible and the Weeping States ( 1843 )  
 Historic Records of Loudoun County ( 1845 )  
 The Hebrew Christians of Loudoun ( 1846 )

 Modern Virginia ( 1873 )
