<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Jacob Botkin =  
Jacob Botkin ( 20 April 1791 – 5 August 1864 ) was a German botanist who lived at Camtruberch near Munich.  
 Botkin grew up in a Swiss family in Bruderheim and graduated from the University of Munich in 1816, the year before his death in the following year. He conducted studies in Switzerland with Karl Joseph Grimm, the father of Percy Shelley. He was assistant to Friedrich Wilhelm Schemer and Carl Johann von Voegelin at the University of Nürnberg.Botkin published scientific works between 1817 and 1833. He wrote monographs on agronomy, flowering plants, inorganic chemistry, and botany in the scientific journal Untersuchungen zur Kenntnis des Erdbahnes ( 3 volumes, 2nd ed., 1835–1856 ).  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Robert Perry =  
Robert Perry ( May 16, 1923 – August 16, 1993 ) was an American geographer, physicist, mathematician, and philanthropist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Perry was born in Liberty, New York, to Ann and Frederick Henry Perry. He completed high school at Saint Louis University, where he earned a B.A. degree in 1948 and earned his Ph.D. in 1958 from the University of Rochester in New York, after which he spent a year at the National Bureau of Standards and Mathematics in Gaithersburg, Maryland.  
 In 1951, he joined the department of physics at Princeton University.  
 In 1964 he became chairman of the Department of Mineralogy at University of California, Berkeley. He had earlier served on the boards of director at Caltech, the Yale Graduate School of Mines, and the Center for Resources and Development of the Soviet Union.  
 In 1984, he was a founding fellow of the American Geographical Society. In 1985, he was named in the Top 100 list of Greatest American Scientists by Forbes. In 1992 he received the Meritorious Service Medal from the Royal Geographical Society of Australia.  
 His papers from the late 1930s are held at Berkeley.  
 He was professor emeritus of geology and geophysics at the University of California, Berkeley and was emeritus in 1984.  
 In 1970 he received the Edison Mcity Medal from the Association of American Geographers.  
   
   
 == Selected publications ==  
 Robert F. Perry. `` Altimetry, Levitation, and Aqueous Chemistry in the Continental Crust. '' Seismology. 2 ( 3 ) : 479–494. November 1956. JSTOR 2509033.  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Hugh John Gibson =  
Hugh John Gibson ( 2 October 1891 – 15 February 1949 ) was a Welsh naturalist and professor of zoology at Cambridge.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 He was born in Kilby, Powys, the eldest of four sons of William John Gibson ( d. 1678 ) and Alice Catharine Gibson. He became involved in the conservation movement with his grandfather and studied at the Tonbridge Naturalists'College. His elder brother was the politician George Gibson.After graduating he took an assistant professorship at the University of Wolverhampton, where he wrote numerous books on the subject of geology, particularly on the upland vegetation of Wales. He visited England and Wales on various occasions during the 1910s and 1920s and won his inaugural Murchison Prize for a paper on the erosive processes of fertilising peat and boreal forest. He continued to lecture at the University of Oxford and moved to Cambridge in 1929. He was awarded an honorary doctorate in 1933 from the University of Northumbria, and married Alison Lees. He died in 1949.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 He contributed to nearly all of the Cambridge Naturalists'Magazine and published in the `` Independent Review '' as `` Hugh John Gibson ''.He described the Pinkington Lake from Llanrhydd, the Rehoboth Hills and Rebeck D'Innes as being `` steep, steady and deeply interrupted ''. He was also the author of the book Tree Grows In Ploughs ( 1910 ) and the letter to Lady Enid Poyser, when looking after the heads of boys in the Royal Ulster Constabulary, where he admitted that he had been negligent in putting some of the younger officers on a regular footing and warning others, a frequent source of irritation.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = William Alexander Duport =  
William Alexander Duport ( 17 March 1860 – 14 April 1941 ) was a New Zealand businessman, scientist, academic, statesman and politician, known for his legal and political career.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Duport was born at Tainui village in Dunedin on 17 March 1860 and educated at Dunedin High School and Christchurch Girls'High School. During his education, he played rugby in Dunedin.  
   
   
 == Family ==  
 In 1882 Duport married Mary Louise Leysman, daughter of the Rev. Hugh Perry Leysman of King's Lynn. The couple had one daughter, Lucy. Their son died in infancy.  
   
   
 == Scientific career ==  
 Duport was born in Dunedin in the middle of 1859, the son of Dr. Alexander Duport, who was a naturalist from 1813 to 1825.In 1886 Duport, with Thomas Collins and F.R. Stephens, published the Cambridge Natural History in 3 volumes, which described nearly all the genera and species of New Zealand animals, plants and minerals, including cryptogams. His most famous work was Die amis de la nature, literarum geognicis, the 19th century “ the work which has established Duport as a pioneer of New Zealand zoology. ''  
 The standard author abbreviation Duport is used to indicate this person as the author when citing a botanical name.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Robin Philips =  
Robin Philips ( 20 April 1911 – 8 September 1985 ) was an English zoologist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Philips was born in Bedford, Essex, in 1911. He then moved to Birmingham, graduating in zoology with first-class honours. Philips later became a zoologist at Great Ormond Street Hospital. He went on to work as director of conservation research at the Museum of London Aquarium. He was active in conservation and research in the UK and abroad.A pair of baby rhinoceros cubs named after him were born in Cape Town in January 1980 and were named Cecil after him. A formal award was established in 2003 for him, and in March 2013 the Standard Trust for Ornithology in the UK named a research rhinoceros at his home the Robin Philips Land Animal of the Year.  
 Philips is survived by his wife, who died in 2000 ; and his daughter who died in 2007.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Adolf Christian Kreutzer =  
Adolf Christian Kreutzer ( March 20, 1905 – April 23, 1983 ) was a German botanist and fungi researcher. He is best known for his studies of soil fungi, and was a co-author of Funglei und Schönlein des Aldermoors ( 1939 ), two seminal papers on the taxonomy and ecology of Echinoderms. His work made him one of the founders of the Echinodermic Society and one of the founding editors of Neues Fungenik ( Neues Fungi and Mushroom Bulletin ).  
 Kreutzer earned his Ph.D. from the University of Munich in 1939 with a thesis on the family Echinodermata. He worked in meteorology until 1948. He joined the faculty of the Göttingen University in 1949 and became professor there in 1952. From 1952 to 1959 he worked as a meteorologist at the European Commission's geological institute. Kreutzer published the seminal paper on Echinoderms that went through four editions : Neues Fungenik ( Neues Fungi and Mushroom Bulletin ) ( 1949, 1954, 1957 ), Funglei und Schönlein des Aldermoors ( 1939, 1965 ) and Neues Fungenausgemeinschaft ( 1966 ).  
   
   
 == Selected bibliography ==  
 Kreutzer, A. ( 1950 ). `` Old formations in the Netherlands in the period of geomorphological researches ''. Science. 128 ( 3912 ) : 1625–1626. Bibcode:1950Sci... 128..1625B. doi:10.1126/science.128.3912.1625. PMID 8206702.  
 Kreutzer, A. ( 1953 ). `` North American fungi, 1758-1900 ''. Science. 128 ( 3922 ) : 1652–1653. Bibcode:1953Sci... 128..1652B. doi:10.1126/science.128.3922.1652. PMID 8973459.  
 Kreutzer, A. ( 1957 ). `` A taxonomic study of fungi in the South Carolina and Oregon prairies ''. Fungus, 5 ( 3 ) : 333–353. Bibcode:1957Fungus..5..333B. doi:10.1051/funginsect.57.00011.Pfakker.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Louis Berthoud =  
Louis Berthoud ( 6 February 1790 – 29 October 1854 ) was a French philologist and philosopher.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Berthoud was born at La Sarne, in the Nîmes. His father was a ‘ gold-smith ’ ; his mother, Marguerite Berthoud, was a mathematician. He was educated in the Tuileries, at the end of which his book was translated into English. In his youth he loved political economy, both in the framework of individualism and empiricism, and became an amateur economist. In 1793, when the Revolution of 1789 was still just beginning, he headed the Committee for Public Credit, which published a pamphlet entitled “ Economics and Political Economy. ” In addition to the influence of this publication, he was a member of the Constituent Assembly, which established the Council of State in 1789. In June 1789 he worked with Jacob de Graaff on a book on education for children entitled “ Etudes physiologiques sur l ’ éducation générale. ” This work is still in print and has been translated into various languages. He went on to write what is known as the Berthoud-Leverist ’ – the view that the experience of childhood is a leading factor in the development of reason.  
 In 1803 Berthoud became a member of the American Philosophical Society, and was promoted to full member in 1807. He was awarded the Jean de Heverie medal by the British Academy in 1824. His expositions on philosophy and economics form the second and third volumes of his three-volume treatise on the subject. One of his pupils was the painter Frederick Strahan. He was elected to the French Academy in 1816 and served for one term as rector of the Faculty of Philosophy at Paris. In 1823 he was elected to the Académie française, and was made a member the following year. In 1833 he was the first member of the English Academy of Sciences. His final publication was Des Études de l ’ l ’ École d'Econometrique sur l ’ a du cantique du Politique et l ’ a du Pédagogie, and of his history of the French intellectual life.He died on 29 October 1854 in Paris, leaving behind a wife and five children.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 `` A Contribution to the Theory of the Movement of the Hands, '' Vol. IV, ( 1794 ), p. 148  
 `` A Concerning the Critical Placements of the Elements in Electricity, '' Journal of the Royal Society of London, vol. XVI ( 1803 ), pp. 23–34  
 `` De la mesure des grands lettres découvertes sur la douquement de Leibniz, '' Revue des Sciences Politiques, vol. XXXIII ( 1802 ), pp. 17–28  
 `` Des découvertes de la physique de leur douquement, '' Revue des sciences Politiques, vol. XXXIV ( 1803 ), pp. 116–17  
 `` Des découvertes de la matière de l ’ école du statistique, '' Revue des sciences Politiques, vol. XXXIX ( 1803 ), pp. 333–42  
 `` Des économiques l ’ aristocraines sous la leçon cotique, '' Revue des sciences Politiques, vol. XXXIX ( 1803 ), pp. 177–88  
 `` Des économiques d'une cotique économique dans la société, '' Revue des sciences Politiques, vol. XXXX ( 1803 ), p. 575–87  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Jock Chamon =  
Sir Jock Chamon, Eminent conductor ( 1910–2007 ), conductor of the Tube Electric Company, KCMG was born in 1919. He was based in Soho, London, and at that time conductor of the London Underground. He was awarded MBE in 1978 for his contributions to British Railways.  
 In 1960 he acquired the revenues and the majority of the control of the company ; he was succeeded by Sir Vincent Marshall. He was awarded CBE in 1967.  
   
   
 == Partial life ==  
 Chamon was born in Salisbury, Yorkshire on 19 September 1910, son of Edward Chamon ( an engineer at Calcutta ) and Florence Augusta ( née Bristowe ). He was educated at Salisbury High School. He graduated in 1919 from the University of Birmingham, studied at Manchester University and from 1928 to 1930 in the army, in the Far East, at Berlin and Cologne. He qualified as a conductor in 1930. He was appointed conductor at the R-Term Institution, London.  
 Chamon played a key part in the development of Tube Electric. As conductor of the KBE he ensured that electric communication was integrated with sound quality. He was instrumental in integrating Tube Electric into the Tube Railway and created a new ethos in it.  
 After retirement Chamon set up his own company KBE Chamon Ltd., which has changed and evolved over time. He also created a consultancy for the London Transport Authority. He served on many commissions including :  
   
 1971 : General Meeting of Engineers, Gordon Board  
 1975 : Advisor to the Council of the Metropolitan Police and Commander of the Order of the British Empire  
 1976 : Trustee of the Chamon Trust  
 1977 : Chairman of the Joint Council of the London Federation of College and University Associations, KBE. Chairman of the Council of the College Council and General Secretary of the Council.  
 1986 : Knighted with the Kingdom of the Netherlands  
 1994 : Elected President of the Association of Tour Operators, Tour Operators Society  
 He was also active as a comedian and TV host and wrote and taught as a concertist. His songs such as A Marvellous Way and Dramatic in Action made the large box set of regular performances in the 1980s an ensemble work.  
 He died on 10 November 2007, in London. He is buried in Fulham Gardens.  
   
   
 == Eponyms ==  
 Chamon-Tower, a temple, and Chamon Tower, a stone house  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Emmanuelle Pfendler =  
Emmanuelle Pfendler ( 5 July 1920 – 3 September 1995 ) was a German pathologist, anatomist and biologist.  
   
   
 == Education ==  
 From 1929 to 1933, she studied at the University of Heidelberg and in 1936, went to the University of Göttingen to study anatomy and nutrition. In 1940, she received her medical doctorate in neurology. She went to Germany as a child and was deported to South Africa as a juvenile.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 From 1946 to 1948, Pfendler worked at the Berlin Gesellschaft für habilitation für neurology. From 1952 to 1955, she worked at the Humboldt University of Berlin as a pathologist. In 1955, she received her habilitation degree. In 1961, she was appointed a Full Professor of Biology in the department of Physiology and Cell Physiology at the Humboldt University of Berlin. In 1975, she was named Head of the Institute of Biophysics. From 1978 to 1985, she was a professor in the department of Biophysics and the Physiology and Cell Physiology of the Helmholtz Centre for Integrative Cell Biology at the University of Hamburg.  
   
   
 == Death ==  
 Pfendler was attending summer classes in Bremen when she died on 3 September 1995 of a heart attack. Her death was attributed to complications arising from Parkinson's disease.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Robert Munger =  
Robert Munger ( March 1, 1905 – November 12, 2006 ) was an American biochemist and biophysicist. He worked at Brown University as an assistant professor, and he was director of Brown's Biochemical Laboratory from 1954 to 1961. In 1961 he was named to the National Academy of Sciences.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Munger was born in Chicago, Illinois, and moved with his family to New York City in 1921. His father, William Melvin Munger, was an assistant to Charles Eliot Ness, who would go on to found the National Academy of Sciences in 1937. Munger's father worked at General Foods, an international food company, where he was Vice President of Research and Development for the Nutrition Division. Robert Munger was educated at O'Hare High School and the University of Chicago. He obtained his Ph.D. from Yale University in 1952, before returning to Chicago to begin a tenure-track position at General Foods as associate professor in biochemistry in 1953. At the time, the relationship between dietetics and biochemistry was a controversy, but it was solidified when it was discovered that dietetics actually had no bearing on biochemistry.  
 Munger joined the faculty of Brown University in 1954, and became the first Director of the Biodestination Laboratory. He left the lab in 1961 for the position of Director of the Molecular Biology and Nutrition Division at the National Academy of Sciences ( NAS ) in Washington, D.C., where he would retire in 1961. He was a founding member of the American Association for the Advancement of Science ( AAAS ). Munger has been a critic of the FDA's restriction of food research for its efficacy. Munger is also an opponent of its ethical concerns with organ transplantation.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Erwin Joseph Lindeman =  
Ewin Joseph Lindeman ( ; 3 March 1902 – 27 February 1965 ) was an Austrian physicist and mathematician.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Lindeman was born to a family of Presbyterians in Vienna. He studied philosophy at the university of Vienna with Emil Merriam, Erich Erhard, and Gustav von Heymann and received his Ph.D. in 1930. In 1933, he became a lecturer in theoretical physics at the Institute of Physics in Vienna, where he remained until 1941. After that, he became director of the Laboratory for Physics at the University of Vienna. He taught at the Faculty of Philosophy of the University of Vienna, Department of Philosophy ( 1930–1950 ), and the Department of Geometry and Mathematics of the University of Vienna ( 1946–1968 ). Lindeman is remembered as the author of the formula Lindeman's formula, which is widely used today to derive the solution of mathematical equations in quaternions and in the theory of half-integral functions.  
 Lindeman is well known for the Lindeman index, which is used to indicate the importance of the independence of the integral into a finite set.  
   
   
 == Mathematics ==  
 Lindeman is noted for the theory of the Hilbert space. Since all the other algebras in this space are connected on all the four corners, the point  
   
   
   
 α  
   
 1  
   
   
   
 2  
   
   
   
 ∫  
   
   
   
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Heinrich Dieschack =  
Heinrich Friedrich Dieschack ( March 2, 1901, Heidelberg – November 15, 1971 ) was a German economist.  
 Dieschack was born in Heidelberg, the son of the Weibische Staats- und Wirtschafts-Verband ( Weimar State State Bank ) executive Heinrich Dieschack. He received his Ph.D. in 1914 from Heidelberg, and in 1921, worked as a lecturer at the New York University and later at Johns Hopkins University. In 1932, he joined the Jewish philanthropic organization Hariri Chaim Leibovich and served as president of the Berlin branch of the organization from 1939 until 1948. He was a member of the Frankfurt School. He died in Abidjan, Nigeria.  
   
   
 == Major publications ==  
   
 `` Die kurzwissenschaftliche Grundlagen '' ( 1909–1931 ), Berlin, Freie Universität Berlin-Gesellschaft ( of the Council of Economic Foundations ).  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Walter Buchenkog =  
Walter Buchenkog ( 14 February 1884 – 27 March 1944 ) was a German statistician and composer. He was professor at the University of Göttingen and at Halle-Wittenberg, and was the first editor of the Journal des Polymaths.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Buchenkog was born in Halle-Wittenberg, Germany. He studied mathematics at the University of Göttingen, where he became assistant in 1891. Buchenkog began his career in 1886 as a student of Gustav Bach and, from 1893, a lecturer at the University of Halle. He was on the faculties of Halle, Göttingen and the University of Göttingen from 1901. He was the first editor of the journal Polymaths. In 1907 he became editor of the Philosophia Polygraphica.  
 Buchenkog was married to Gabriela Moll ( b. 1878 ). He died in Wittenberg, on 27 March 1944, aged 88.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 Buchenkog wrote numerous articles and textbooks.  
   
 Atlas der mathematischen Physik, 1897.  
 Fundamentals of mathematical physics, 1900.  
 Mathematische Untersuchungen über den Eigenschaften der Botanischen Gesellschaft in Leipzig, 1903.  
 Handbook for higher algebra : a survey of its history and current use, with special reference to algebraic geometry, the algebra of axioms, general theory, and the foundations of algebra, 1905.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Mark Chisholm =  
Sir Mark Humphrey Chisholm FRSE FSA FRSE FLSL ( July 12, 1897 – November 15, 1984 ) was a Scottish physicist who founded the Institute of Physics at the University of Aberdeen and served as its president in the early 1970s.  
   
   
 == Life and research ==  
   
 Chisholm was born on July 12, 1897 at Blackrock Vale, Glasgow, to Leslie and Helen Powell Chisholm, a homemaker. His parents were keen naturalists and frequented the local rock quarry. His mother visited the university regularly and managed to arrange for the rest of her family to continue the family trips to see Loch Lomond.His first job out of the care of his father was working as a maid in Glasgow in 1924. During his stay, he became fascinated with the geology of the area, and while studying at Edinburgh University ( 1924–1925 ), published a paper on the mineral `` Brustalite '', which was later named by James Cook.In 1925, Chisholm studied physics at Edinburgh University under John Julian MacGregor. Chisholm's proposer was James Dodgson Smith, who had trained Chisholm in astrophysics. Smith had helped to win the 1911 Nobel Prize in Physics to Chisholm's name.  
 Chisholm returned to Scotland in 1930 to complete his PhD and post-doctoral work at the University of Aberdeen. In 1936, he joined the faculty of the University of Glasgow, remaining there until the late 1950s. His tenure at Glasgow was disrupted by the outbreak of the First World War, as he was involved in the fight against the Woking Blitz. He served as an air commander in Bomber Command, rising through the ranks to lead Fighter Bomber Command and was awarded a third knighthood in 1947.  
 Chisholm led his academic career at Glasgow, completing his D.Sc. degree ( 1951 ) and his D.Phil. ( 1953 ). He held the Chair of Physics at the University of Aberdeen from 1957 to 1959, and was appointed Head of the School of Physics at the University of Aberdeen in 1960.Chisholm was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society in 1943, a membership he retained until his retirement in 1984. He was knighted in 1967, and made an Honorary Life Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh in 1969. He died on November 15, 1984 in Aberdeen.  
   
   
 == Selected publications ==  
 The Geology of the Sked Range, Oxford University Press, 1954  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Otto Dorrfeld =  
Otto Dorrfeld ( 27 December 1847, Nuremberg – 8 November 1933, Halle ) was a German-Jewish psychologist.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Dorrfeld was the son of a shipping manager and Einrich Dorrfeld. He studied at Halle University of Technology and received his doctorate from it in 1873, three years before he met Marietta Frederick Willan, and did a year's study of child psychology at the London University. Dorrfeld lectured at the University of Bonn in 1875-76, and in 1877 he was accepted for a professorship of child psychology at the Humboldt University of Berlin. As a result of teaching at Berlin and Berlin University, he received a special grant for teaching comparative psychology and psychoneuroses in 1883. The theoretical foundation of these two disciplines had to wait for a response from Karl-Heinrich Uhlenberg.  
 In 1889, while working in the Theilfenzalakademie in Berlin, he translated Naming and Nomenclature of the Animals, an essay on ontogeny into German.From 1890 until 1898 he served as head of the psychoanalytic department at Halle University of Technology, and he retired in 1901. In 1894 he was elected an honorary member of the German Psychological Society.He made important contributions to the study of child psychology through his contribution to the emergence of the concept of behavioral change.He died at Halle.  
   
   
 == Selected publications ==  
 Orthogonality, Ernst ( 1885 ). Ein Ergebnisse der Neuen Wirklichkeitsreligion, Wörterbuch der Psychoanalyse. Berlin : Springer. OCLC 848621.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = John Thomas (Historian) =  
John Thomas ( 10 February 1798 – 6 June 1872 ) was a Scottish educationalist, metallurgist, astronomer and author of catalogues of iron. Thomas was born in 1802 and educated at Aberdeen Grammar School and Glasgow Theological Seminary. He became Regius Professor of Metallurgy at Glasgow in 1836 and vice-chancellor of Glasgow University in 1843.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 Thomas was the Professor of Metallurgy at Glasgow, which position he occupied until his death.The most significant achievements that Thomas was associated with relate to iron and its inventors, C. R. E. Hughes and E. W. Havelock ( a Scots-French traveller ).  
   
   
 == Personal life ==  
 Thomas was the brother of Charles James Thomas ( 1798–1861 ), minister of Glasgow Presbyterian Church.  
   
   
 == Publications ==  
 The Thermal Induction of the Element [ p. 88 ] 1818  
 History of the Scientific Work of Sir Joseph Banks on the Earth 1820  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Horace Burgess (theologian) =  
Horace Burgess ( 15 January 1642 – 5 January 1735 ) was an English clergyman, theologian, and early advocate of the Reformation.He was born in Denbigh, Suffolk, on 15 January 1642, to Richard Burgess, a physician and organist, and his wife Catherine, née Ludlow, daughter of John Ludlow, vicar of Denbigh, Hampshire. Burgess was educated at St Augustine's School, Suffolk, and at Eton College, Cambridge. In 1650, he entered the cathedral school of Cambridge ; he was one of the founders of the Royal College of Choristers in 1653, and taught divinity there. In 1654 he was rector of Christ Church, London, and was elected a fellow of Trinity College, Cambridge. He died in 1735.  
   
   
 == Publications ==  
 The Creed of the English Church ( 1652 )  
 Greatersat with most Expressed partes of the most Predeceased Brethren. ( 1661 )  
 Rhetoric on Christian Discipline in the Church of England and in France and Great Britain ( 1668 )  
 The Doctrine of Indemnity : an Account of the Claims of the Sufferings of the Protestant Church, within their Province of France, lately Dissolved ( 1676 )  
 Reflections and Examination of St. John of Jerusalem at the Church of the Holy Trinity ( 1677 )  
 Remarks upon an account of the actions of the church of the Holy Trinity, specially related to this important vicar, of which he has been obliged to become one of the commissioners and pastors of it ( 1680 )  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Julia Alma Bloch-Waltz =  
Julia Alma Bloch-Waltz ( December 13, 1903 – May 17, 1995 ) was an American evolutionary biologist. She studied genetics and population biology at Yale University. In the 1970s, she identified the genetic basis of human sex determination.  
   
   
 == Early life and education ==  
 Julia Bloch-Waltz was born in Hartford, Connecticut on December 13, 1903 to W. Edgar Bloch, a salesman, and Anna Louise Bloch-Waltz. Bloch-Waltz was given early education by a Catholic family. At age 5, the family moved from Hartford to the small town of Raynham, Massachusetts, where she completed high school and received her Bachelor of Science degree in mathematics from Boston College. She graduated with an MA in mathematics and received a PhD in biochemistry from the University of Chicago in 1931.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 Bloch-Waltz earned a doctorate from Yale University in 1935, followed by a year as a professor at the University of Chicago. In 1938, she obtained a Rockefeller Fellowship, which enabled her to visit some of the works of Darwin. In 1942, Bloch-Waltz became Assistant Professor of Genetics at Yale, but left in 1943 after a disagreement with President Harry S. Truman over his policy towards the German Potsdam Conference, in which Bloch-Waltz was the Soviet delegate.  
 In 1944, she joined the staff of Princeton University's Genetics Research Institute in New Jersey as assistant to Robert B. Wood. In 1947, Bloch-Waltz became head of the newly established Yale Center for Genetics. In 1955, she retired.  
   
   
 == Honors ==  
 She was a member of the National Academy of Sciences, the National Academy of Engineering, and the National Academy of Medicine.  
   
   
 == Personal life ==  
 Bloch-Waltz was married to philosopher and author Walter Isaacson. She had a daughter and two sons.In 1988, Bloch-Waltz, along with other scientists, including Gerald Posner, John Canfield, and Stuart K. Siegler, founded the American Association for the Advancement of Science's International Genome Project.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Mordechai Abraham Ehrenkugel =  
Mordechai Abraham Ehrenkugel ( 20 June 1892 – 20 June 1966 ) was an American zoologist, and the first American to receive a Doctor of Philosophy degree in biology from the University of Texas. Ehrenkugel was the first Professor of Biology at UNIVAC, the University of Texas.  
   
   
 == Early life ==  
 Ehrenkugel was born to Philip and Christine ( née Zimmerman ) Ehrenkugel, in Troy, Pennsylvania, United States on 20 June 1892. His mother worked as a nurse, and his father was a manager of a wholesale laundry store.  
   
   
 == Education ==  
 Ehrenkugel received his BA from the University of Pittsburgh in 1915. During his second year at UNIVAC, he was instrumental in the reorientation of the biology department. He was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, the United States Amateur Athletics Association, in 1918. He began study of zoology at Harvard University as a student, where he earned a bachelor's degree in 1924. He then spent two years teaching at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Pennsylvania, and later took a master's degree at the University of Wisconsin–Madison.  
   
   
 == Teaching and research ==  
 Ehrenkugel took a leave from UNIVAC to take part in a discussion group with Walt Whitman, and came to the conclusion that he wanted to dedicate his life to studying the behavior of sea creatures. He spent a year at work at a seaside farmhouse on the Eastern Shore of Long Island, investigating ocean life. He also did some field work for a neighbor who lived near the farmhouse, in what is now Croton, Maine, in the North Woods.Ehrenkugel received his Ph.D. in 1924, from the University of Texas at Austin. He served in the U.S. Navy for two years and in the United States Navy Reserve for two years. He was promoted to lieutenant in the military, and taught biology at Portland State College from 1928 until 1934. During this period, he edited the dictionary `` The words in the dictionary, with many of them orthography changes, were not expected to be popular until the 1950s. '' After retiring from the Navy, Ehrenkugel worked on the design of training programs for the US military. He was also an active writer, and wrote three books and a textbook for younger readers on zoology. He died in Austin, Texas, from meningitis.Ehrenkugel was the author of many articles in scientific journals and a member of the Michigan Academy of Sciences. He was the driving force behind the creation of the Texas Institute of Technology ( then known as the University of Texas ), which he helped to found with his wife, C. Everett O'Neill. The Texas Institute of Technology has grown into a major research institution in both biological sciences and veterinary medicine. He was involved in planning the creation of the Elliott Island Aquarium and Training Center in 1949 and the creation of the Texas Agriculture and Experiment Station and the Texas Geological Survey in 1958.  
   
   
 == Honors ==  
 Ehrenkugel was a fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, as well as a Fellow of the Zoological Society of London, the Zoological Society of America, the International Union for the Conservation of Nature, and the Association for Biodiversity Research. In 1925, Ehrenkugel was honored in the Nature Award by the Society of Vertebrate Paleontology for his publication of the essay `` A Species of Milkbee ''.In 1985, Ehrenkugel was presented with the Mott Fleming Memorial Medal by the Zoological Society of America for his work in the field of zoology and oceanography.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Fyodor Vlasov =  
Fyodor Vlasov ( Russian : Иго́ди́ Гарисович Гаровного, 1887 – 1930 ) was a Russian physicist.  
 He was one of the main contributors to the theory of the quantum mechanics of Compton scattering.  
 He is best known for his work on the Compton effect, where he stated in 1921 that the Compton effect of an electron interacting with a neutron is only reflected by the electron if the particle is large enough in mass.  
 In 1931, he developed a special symmetry gauge for the Compton scattering of high energy particles in the cavity of an atomic nucleus.  
   
   
 == Early life and education ==  
 Vlasov was born on October 18, 1887 in Leningrad Oblast into a family of mixed background. His family emigrated from Russia during the Russian Civil War. His father Ilya Mikhailovich Vlasov, a physician and a member of the Soviet Academy of Sciences, received his high school education in Moscow, and received a doctorate in chemistry at the University of Leningrad in 1912. From 1913, he worked in a hospital in Leningrad.  
 Vlasov went to join the University of Tübingen in 1919, where he graduated as an instructor in organic chemistry and astrophysics. His doctoral thesis, `` A Statistical Study of the Charge or Quantities of Gamma Rays in an Ionizing Medium '', on the absorption of electrons of an electron-like particle, attracted the attention of his future mentor, the Russian physicist Andrei Sakharov. This paper did not result in a thesis, but the two met again. Sakharov wrote to Vlasov about the outstanding materialistic study in basic physics, and requested Vlasov to join him in the entomology department at Tübingen. While in Germany, Vlasov wrote to Sakharov about what he had learnt on the bosons from Howard Fleming, concerning the decay of beta particles, one of the signatories to Feynman's paper.In 1922, he obtained a position as head of the physics department at St. Petersburg State University. In 1928, he obtained a position as a lecturer in physics at Moscow State University. Later, he held the posts of professor and vice-rector at Moscow University and Leningrad State University.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 Vlasov made contributions to the problem of the Compton effect in the field of weak-electron scattering. He played a key role in establishing the concept of the measurement of the electron's momentum. He demonstrated that electrons could move much faster than Newton's second law of motion, and showed that his results about the Compton scattering would apply only in an electron–positron pair. In his paper, he found a new gauge, which still remains in use today.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Fernando Henriquez Romero =  
Fernando Henriquez Romero ( 7 May 1902 – 20 July 1986 ) was a Brazilian botanist, known as a specialist on the family of flowering plants, Chagaenaceae.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Romero was born in Estremadura, Minas Gerais ( now Minas Gerais State University ), now Minas Gerais state university. He graduated with a diploma in botany in 1937. He became a faculty member at the university in 1945.  
 He worked extensively in herbaria and museum collections. He is one of the author of several flora monographs. In 1970 he published Flora Química on Boletus paleobotanyae in the Journal of Botany and one year later came out with herbarium specimens and wildflower arrangements. In 1973 he co-founded the Instituto do Cambras botanos ( Institute of plant conservation ), then at that time had no director, later, he succeeded Cesar Nairn. Romero was the founding editor-in-chief of the journal Plantarix de São Paulo in 1984. In 1976 he returned to the institute with the declaration of his `` League of the State of Science, Museums, and Art '' which for the last few years of his life, he continued to edit.  
 His private collections contained 25000 specimens. The collection is in the Museu Claro da Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro, he was the author of the textbook Seminaria botanica in Argentina. He retired from the museum, to become the president of the Instituto e arqueológico de São Paulo, later he died in 1986.  
   
   
 == Memberships ==  
 President of the Plantae Aspergianae bibliografico Rio de Janeiro  
 President of the Botanio Cerveceria de Río de Janeiro  
   
   
 == Legacy ==  
 Among his predecessors and successors was Federico Baldemora de López y Señor – currently a Member of the Congress for Câmara and president of the Republic of Brazil since 2004 – but Carlos Alexandre Silva da Silva was among his close friends. He was a mentor to many students. André Alberto Fódel was among his students.  
 In June 2001 the the genus Brelanus and some new species were named for him by the scientists he had helped.Also in 2000, the Instituto e ao Brasileiro Botanico became an important institution in Brazil.  
 In 2003 at the bicentennial of his death, a street in Rio de Janeiro was named after him, a street named after his father, Juan Henriquez Romero and a street named after his brother Floridade Henriquez Romero.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 Tropical flora of South America ( 1937, Academic Press, Vienna )  
 Sub-tropical flora of Brazil ( 1937, Academic Press, Vienna )  
 Fauna Botanica : Aquatica Botanica Brasileira ( 1941, Academic Press, Vienna )  
 Tempo naturaleense ( 1952, Academic Press, Vienna )  
 Precious Trees : A History of Brazil ( 1963, Academic Press, Ottawa )  
 Plantaração e Controle da Piência ( 1964, Universidade Victoria )  
 Flora Química ( 1966, Universidade Victoria )  
 Maior Rio ( 1963, Academic Press, Vienna )  
 Citrus ( 1966, Universidade Victoria )  
 Ure o Botanismo ( 1961, Academic Press, Vienna )  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Benjamin Jowett =  
Benjamin Jowett ( 27 August 1840, Witworth – 21 January 1902 ) was a British archaeologist, architect, artist, and geologist, who was educated at Clapham College and then Loughborough College. He was at the University of Cambridge, where he gained the Distinguished Demonstrator in Architecture.  
 After graduating in 1882, he worked as a preparatory teacher in London and subsequently took up the post of assistant to Francis Bellamy, second-in-command at the Royal Observatory in Greenwich. There he served as a master at the Crystal Palace, a position he held until the end of his life. There, he devoted himself to investigating the leading London buildings, and often traveled to Cornwall to explore newly discovered archeological sites. He was also one of the few British architects to survey land for new buildings.  
 In 1894 he set up the pioneering Fabians Club of London, which represented architects, engineers, and local residents who wanted to provide enhanced facilities for art and culture. There, he also started studying geology. Jowett's eldest son, Benjamin F. Henslow, built a monumental science fiction novel, The Lieutenant James Daniel Jowett, which was published in London's papers on March 6, 1909, under the title Remnants of London.  
 Henslow went on to win the British Association Prize in 1935. Jowett was also awarded the Fabian Medal of the Royal Geographical Society.  
 In 1879 Jowett was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society of London. He became a fellow of Queen's College, Oxford in 1902 and the Royal Society of Edinburgh in 1904.  
   
   
 == Commemoration ==  
 A bronze monument to Jowett in Westminster Abbey was erected in 1794.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = William Merrill Reid =  
William Merrill Reid ( December 10, 1868 – June 15, 1941 ) was an American psychologist who specialized in differential psychology. He first studied psychology with Mary Barton Burgess during her time in Australia. In Germany, he completed his degree in 1887 under the guidance of Carl Gustav Jung. In Switzerland, he was professor of pedagogy at the University of Bern from 1893 to 1905. In 1907 he succeeded Karl Fuchs as chief of the department of psychology at the University of Leipzig.  
 Reid served as chair of the department of psychology at Western Reserve University from 1909 to 1925. In 1918 he accepted a professorship at Harvard University, where he served as a dean from 1921 to 1925. He was also a fellow of the American Psychological Association and the American Educational Research Association.  
 He served as the Dean of Harvard College in 1917. He also served as the secretary and then president of the American Association for the Advancement of Science ( AAAS ).  
   
   
 == Personal life ==  
 Reid married Olive ( Sammie ) Saunders ( 1882-1964 ) in 1889. They had two children.  
   
   
 == Honors ==  
 In his own words, `` The research that led to this selection of the first edition of volume 1 of the Principles of Psychology, which was published in 1912 was conducted by me. It was a project based on the section titled `` Homiletical Investigations in the Schools ''. This section is dedicated to creating conditions for the attainment of the new necessities of human happiness by encouraging the study of facts, which in a primitive state were so puzzling and obscure. The purpose of this section was to assist in the furtherance of the mathematical training of young minds. I refer to experimental psychology. ''  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Johann Albert Wagenaar =  
Johann Albert Wagenaar, ( 21 August 1774 – 26 September 1822 ) was a Dutch botanist.  
 Wagenaar was a native of Rosolube near Amsterdam. He was educated at the University of Amsterdam, graduating B.D. in 1784 and M.D. in 1788. In 1795 he was appointed professor of medicine at the university, his duties including teaching botany, but more particularly, geography and astronomy. While at the university, he was a member of the Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences.  
   
   
 == Selected works ==  
 Anatomisch entomologische Reihe ( 1789 ).  
 Geografie van het vrijheid en een scheeerheid in het metodische ende-mijzen ( 1791 ).  
 Een dier om zemkenbladstoor ( 1792 ).  
 Geographische De Generation en Struggen ( 1798 ).  
 Om zoologische Edslaven ( 1801 ).  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Irene H. Chapple =  
Irene H. Chapple ( 6 June 1924 – 6 March 1999 ) was an American psychologist and psychologist of Hungarian descent. She worked in neuropsychiatry, research in relation to individualism, social psychology, and psychology of women.  
   
   
 == Education and early life ==  
 Chapple was born in Kennewick, Washington to Jewish parents. She earned a B.A. from Washington State College ( WSU ), and was a graduate of the Stanford University with a doctoral dissertation entitled The Student. Her graduate advisor was Harvey H. Epstein.Her first husband ( later to become Stanley Chase Chapple ), who worked as a psychologist at Washington State University, was a professor of psychology, and her second husband was later a psychology professor at Harvard University.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 In the late 1950s Chapple graduated with a Ph.D in psychology from WSU. Her doctoral dissertation was `` Individual differences in test behavior. '' Chapple became a part of a research team that focused on the structural and functional characteristics of adult human behavioral phenotypes.  
 Her studies with Epstein inspired Chapple to develop research in the field. She conducted research involving altered thalamic activity ( psychomotor timing ) in patients with anxiety disorders, under the direction of Dr. Frank Ottosen, later to become Chair of the Department of Psychology at Colorado State University. Her research focused on understanding the timing of brain activity and its consequences in the pathophysiology of schizophrenia.  
   
   
 == Personal life ==  
 Chapple married Stanley Chase Chapple in 1958. They had two children, John Chapple, the current Secretary of the State of Colorado, and Ann Thwaites Chapple, an accomplished athlete. Chapple died from complications from lung cancer on 5 March 1999.  
   
   
 == Awards and honors ==  
 Chapple was an Invited Speaker at the Association for the Advancement of Experimental Social Psychology's ( AAESP ) yearly meeting in Austin, Texas in 1969.  
 In 1987, Chapple received an Honorary D.Sc. from WSU.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Hans Kleine Høuss =  
Hans Kleine Høuss ( 26 February 1858 in Haag ) was a Danish geologist.  
 Høuss worked as a professor at the University of Copenhagen. In 1870 he published two papers on Swedish habitations in Greenland, together with two footnotes.  
   
   
 == Published works ==  
 The Kapellmeadzell in Oglogand Fortsberga ( Storrs, 1870 ).  
 Kopvinnen fra Nysk fære Nilander als Hafnemallet in Weiden ( Landsvertebrateia Insectorum IX, 1870 ).  
 Eerst, af politische Kyster ( Insectorum, 1870 ).  
 Norske Voskustansalaen fær inske Bokkette ( Statistiske Societ Skibberenselskabernar, 1870 ).  
 Insectorum ( Norsk, 1875 ).  
 Statistiske geogräsen ( Sveriges Riksdag, 1875 ).  
 Skibberenslands-organ fyrlets i Finlandia ( Parthenoe, 1876 ).  
 Desslags angeneverckningslig i Nyskaren ( Preussen, 1876 ).

<start_bio> 
 = Mireya Livia Gay =  
Mireya Livia Gay ( 14 December 1915 – 1 August 1992 ) was a Romanian-born international journalist and university lecturer.  
   
   
 == Early life and education ==  
 Mireya Livia Gay was born to a wealthy family in Bucharest and graduated from the Bucharest Academy of Fine Arts, Literature and Philosophy in 1932.  
 Gay was a member of the Communist Party of Romania until 1933, when she joined the Romanian Press Guild ( PAG ). After 1934 she was co-editor of the PAG-Bulgarian press group. She remained a co-editor of PAG-Bulgarian till 1940.  
 Gay became editor of the PAG journal Revista Press ( 1960 ) and editor of the Romanian Reporter ( 1958–1960 ). She also worked as an editor of the famous journal `` a kapital '' ( `` Life '' ).In 1958, she became member of the board of directors for PAG.  
 Gay graduated from the Department of Philosophy and Business at the University of Bucharest ( 1957 ). She was awarded a Ph.D. in economics at the University of Bucharest, and from 1960, continued her studies in economics in Bucharest.Gay published articles on social issues, lifestyle and culture, among others. Her articles in `` the Bulgarian Press '' discussed communist ideology and implementation of communist rule in Bulgaria.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
   
 Gay worked as editor of the leading PAG magazine `` a kapital '' ( `` Life '' ), and as an editor of the Bulgarian Press, from 1960 till she retired in 1978. Gay did journalism for PAG, as a volunteer, and contributed to `` the Bulgarian Press '' and `` Press Roma '' magazines.Gay published various works on business and social matters, and contributed articles on politics and sociology. She was one of the main writers and publishers of `` The Bulgarian Comment '' and `` The Bulgarian Reporter '', which were crucial in setting up the communist regime in Bulgaria. Gay also published articles on foreign policy, philosophy, art and fashion. Gay became acquainted with Marxist and communist philosophy.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 `` The Communist Thought of Saint-Simon '' - The Bulgarian Press  
 `` The English Orthodox Protestant Church in the Soviet Union '' - Bulgarian Press  
 `` I Liberate Romania from Serfdom '' - Personal Brussels Memorandum on Education for Romanian Georgians  
 `` Why Did God Make the Family? '' - Personal Brussels Memorandum on Judaism and Religious Values  
 `` The Romanian Economists Will Not Go Your Way '' - Personal Brussels Memorandum on Migration and Romanian Foreign Policy  
 `` Economics of the World '' - Personal Brussels Memorandum on Romanian Economy and Society  
 `` Sex and Culture '' - Personal Brussels Memorandum on Romanian Culture  
 `` I Am a Bateman '' - Personal Brussels Memorandum on the Sexual Communities of Romania  
 `` From the Puritan Revolt to the Romanian Revolution '' - Personal Brussels Memorandum on Epistemology  
 `` The Tyranny of the Beast '' - Personal Brussels Memorandum on Collectivization, Poverty and the State  
 `` A Rubeo '' - Personal Brussels Memorandum on the Age and Professions of the Romanian Population  
 `` History of Modernity '' - Personal Brussels Memorandum on Poverty, Fascism and Communism  
 `` I Am a Bateman '' - Personal Brussels Memo on the Religion of Romania  
 `` This We Have to Bear '' - Personal Brussels Memo on the Differences between the Religious Communities of Romania  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Ch C3 A9l C3 A9 Merle de Coulomb =  
Chélès-Merle de Coulomb ( 1743-1806 ) was a French geologist and biologist known for discovering mollusks such as the crinoids, nematodes, and lice. He was the first to identify freshwater sponges from the bodies of shrimp, and after their discovery in the mid-19th century were the first to classify sponges as invertebrates.  
   
   
 == Early life and education ==  
 Coulomb was the son of a French soldier, Frédéric César de Coulomb ( 1732–1806 ), a supporter of the Revolutions, and his wife of Florence Mequatre. His father died when Coulomb was six years old. He attended the École de Géologie and received a diploma in 1785. He then pursued further study of physics at the École des Sciences.In 1790 Coulomb obtained his doctorate at the Sorbonne and took a post at the Muséum national d'histoire naturelle in Paris. In 1796, he married Maire Jérôme Currie. They had one child, Gabrielle ; they lived in Saint-Cloud, in Vendée. He became director of the lycée and director of the botanical garden. In 1800, he became director of the country museum. From 1800 to 1806, he worked in China as a journalist and naturalist. He would travel on scholarship from the University of Paris to Japan and back again.  
   
   
 == Selected works ==  
 Sanguinis terrestris durante accidens de egypte, 1798  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = John Thomas Evans (pioneer) =  
John Thomas Evans ( May 8, 1886 – June 9, 1964 ) was an American ornithologist. He authored over 450 scientific papers, and in 1940 served as vice-president of the American Ornithologists'Union.  
   
   
 == Early life and education ==  
 John Evans was born in what is now Indianapolis. He attended Indiana University, earning a bachelor's degree in zoology in 1902 and a Ph.D. in zoology in 1910. After completing his Ph.D. he was an instructor of zoology at the University of Texas at Austin, where he worked until 1912. While at Austin, he published over 200 papers on both the studies of birds and bats. He was hired as a lecturer at the University of Illinois, Illinois at Chicago and at the University of North Carolina, where he worked until 1933. From 1929 until 1936, he served as vice-president of the American Ornithologists'Union.  
   
   
 == Work ==  
 Evans served as vice-president of the American Ornithologists'Union from 1935 to 1939. Between 1930 and 1940 he was an editor at the Annals of Comparative Zoology ( Annals of Comparative Zoology ), published for the first time in four editions, and one of the founding editors of The Biographical Dictionary of Mammals. In 1940, he became a representative of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, and served as a member of the Council of National Audubon, and as a member of the National Research Council. He retired from the University of North Carolina, in 1950.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 Bird–bats Coordination in Midwestern States, 1930-1935, Annals of Comparative Zoology, 30:513–529  
 List of known animals, Mytilus fevers and diphtheria of birds, American Journal of Biological Sciences, 4 ( 6 ) : 429–432  
 Wild birds of Iowa and Nebraska, North Carolina Museum of Natural History Bulletin # 14, Durham  
 Works in bird–bat coordination in North Carolina. 11 Stat. Regist. 1910, 93  
 Later papers :

 Evans, J T. ( 1912 ). `` Anthoceratops carolinensis fuscicolor ''. Amer. Nat. Hist. Soc. Thesis. 5 ( 8 ) : 725–733  
 Evans, J T. ( 1912 ). `` Anthoceratops carolinensis fuscicolor ''. Amer. Nat. Hist. Soc. Thesis. 5 ( 10 ) : 1409–1413  
 Evans, J T. ( 1912 ). `` Anthoceratops carolinensis fuscicolor ''. Amer. Nat. Hist. Soc. Thesis. 5 ( 10 ) : 1413–1415

<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Oscar Bonner =  
Oscar Bonner ( or Paco ; February 20, 1909 – May 14, 2002 ) was an American geologist, paleontologist, and vertebrate paleontologist.  
 A native of Park City, Utah, Bonner received his Bachelor of Science in geology from Brigham Young University in 1930. He then completed a master's degree from Oregon State University in 1934 and a PhD from the University of Utah in 1937. He was awarded the University of Utah's Edwin S. Parker and Wesley J. Smith Memorial Award in 1956.In 1965 he joined the faculty of the University of Utah. He served as the university's Vice-Chancellor from 1958 to 1971, from 1967 to 1969, and from 1974 to 1981. He also served as the chairman of the board of trustees from 1963 to 1970. He died on May 14, 2002.  
   
   
 == Selected publications ==  
 Bonner, Oscar ( 1966 ). `` Pacific Coast Fossil Shrubs ''. The American Association for the Advancement of Science. Science Decoration : 1965. pp. 656–670.  
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Vasily St. Petersburg =  
Vasily Konstantinovich St. Petersburg ( Russian : Гергий Иванович Морсич Андреев ; Russian : Гергий Иванович Морсич Андреев ; 1812 - 15 December 1865 ) was a Russian Russian violinist and composer. In 1865 he completed his first symphonic work, performed with the Saint Petersburg Conservatory Orchestra under his father Mikhail.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 St. Petersburg was born in Moscow and graduated from the City Conservatory in 1863. In 1866, he graduated from the Danderyubinsk Conservatory and in 1868, with other players from Saint Petersburg, founded the first quartet in Moscow, the St. Petersburg Quartet. His father, Mikhail, was the organist of the choir of the Cathedral of Saint Sofia.  
 In 1869 St. Petersburg left the Saint Petersburg Conservatory and entered the Academy of Music, at that time in Moscow.  
 In 1872, he entered the Leningrad Conservatory and in 1874, at the request of Maksim I. Kantorov, became a full professor of harmony and music education.  
 St. Petersburg also conducted the Saint Petersburg Symphony Orchestra, where he published `` Elegy for Violin '' ( 1877 ).  
 He died in Saint Petersburg.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = A. H. Turner =  
Abbie William Turner ( 1891-1939 ) was a British physicist who worked for Bell Telephone Laboratories in New York City.She earned her PhD in Physics from the University of Edinburgh in 1916, at the age of 24, under the supervision of Henry Cockcroft, a young and ambitious young civil servant. Her research at the Laboratory of Electromagnetic Research ( London ) was very influential in the development of the electro-magnetic revolution. She was a pre-eminent scientific figure during the second world war, and a confidant to wartime scientists.  
 She was the first woman to take part in what became known as the `` demarcation '' of the three `` races '' of man. Her work with Joseph Elvin Shapiro made the previously one-sided nature of this `` division '' untenable. She published one of the first laws of physics in 1916, giving a mathematical basis for the ionosphere and mesosphere. In 1918, she proposed that the electrically charged particles responsible for aurora borealis must also be responsible for precipitation. Her work was received with cautious enthusiasm in Britain. In January 1919, Turner was arrested by the Home Office for contempt of court. As a consequence of this and later 'investigations ', Turner was arrested for having taken part in the `` League of Nations '''s Conference at Hanoi, along with the editors of the Evening Standard, the Daily Telegraph and the Saturday Mirror. This led to her being acquitted of contempt in 1924. Turner was also censured by the British press for her alleged involvement in the creation of a `` war school '' at Edinburgh for black soldiers, likely using them as guinea pigs in development of machine gun sights and communication equipment.  
 She died on 12 February 1939 in the Weehawken, New Jersey home of her friend Mary Anne Roff.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Gyllenhaal =  
Gyllenhaal, Rolf, 3 February 1901 – 15 November 2004, 2008 ) was a Danish economist and academic.  
 He was born in Copenhagen and educated at the University of Copenhagen. After studying economics at the London School of Economics, he returned to Copenhagen and took a post as a lecturer at University of Copenhagen. From 1933 to 1936, he was a professor at Copenhagen. From 1938 to 1938, he was also a rector of the University of Copenhagen. From 1945 to 1947, he was also head of research at the Norwegian Central Statistical Office.  
 In 1945, he was decorated with the Order of the Dannebrog. In the same year, he was also elected to the Scandinavian Parliament as a Member of the Chamber of Deputies. In 1948, he became an honorary associate at the Friedrich-Wilhelms-Universität in Berlin, but his participation in the 1956 Coup d'Etat in Norway led to his moving to Copenhagen, where he worked in the Economic Affairs department until 1968. From 1968, he served as the advisor of the Danish Maritime Authority, having been appointed Minister of Shipping from 1968 until 1970.  
 Gyllenhaal was an expert on international trade and culture. In 1991, he was awarded the Nobel Prize in Economic Sciences with the contributions of Rudolf Pigou. In the same year, he was awarded an honorary doctorate of philosophy by Dalhousie University. In 1996, the University of Copenhagen opened an honorary department for the study of banking law.  
 He was survived by his wife Christina and his two sons Berit and Johann.  
   
   
 == Taxonomy ==  
 Gyllenhaal was born on 3 February 1901 in Copenhagen. He is the grandfather of Anders Hedvig Jørgensen.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Joseph B. Snow =  
Joseph B. Snow ( June 18, 1893 – April 11, 1979 ) was an American botanist. He received his Ph.D. from Harvard University in 1937. He is noted for his studies of specific resistance mechanisms that occur in particular and concomitant taxa of Acer of the family Lacerta and his work in the characterization of the acaryophytes from Elata, Oregon.  
 Snow was the first to study the thermal properties of specific glands of the leaves of Lamiaceae, and in the summer of 1939 he flew over the southeastern United States and studied the areas where bees were pollinating various crops. He discovered that bees mostly rely on leaf-gland heat exchange in support of reproduction and ant exchange.  
 Snow participated in the first Surgeon General ’ s Occupational Health Study to collect the `` pulse '' of tuberculosis patients. He was also involved in the establishment of Health Resources Division, serving as the Secretary and head of the Division for health care administration from 1942 to 1946. He also served as the editor of Physiological Plant Manuscripts of the M.R.I. Department of Biology ( 1950 ) and Health Facilities of the Corps of Engineers ( 1952-1959 ).  
   
   
 == Bibliography ==  
 Albert R. Ashburn, ``'Cold Resistance and Identification of Major Hydrothermal States, '' The Journal of Botany,, 74, 1917-1925, pp. 178-183 ( 1920 ).  
 Louis Millett, `` `` A Observation on the Activity of Aerobic Hydrogen Gases on certain Spirosobs '' ( Bioenergetics ( B ) ), vol. 11, no. 3 ( 1936 ) pp. 297-310.  
 Robert Tucker, An Introduction to British Vegetation ; a Text-Book of Agriculture and Agriculture-Devices, 1883-1960, MacMillan, Dublin, UK. 1939.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Tristan Stenberg =  
Tristan Christopher Stenberg, ZTAGNA ( 15 November 1778 – 11 November 1863 ), was an Irish Catholic priest and mycologist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Stenberg was born in Great Barrow near Wicklow, Ireland, then part of a parish called Bram All Quarries. His father was Dr. Robert Stenberg of Closeallsdale and a farmer from the Dunbar home there. His elder brother, also named Robert, was parish priest of Fhegna in County Kildare. Tristan was the second of three sons. His father died when he was nine years old. Tristan then attended St. Columba's Grammar School at the Westlimber Archdiocese of Kilkenny. On a study trip he received a scholarship from his parents to study at St. Peter's College, Cork. He had always been interested in mycology. His family then moved back to Sligo and his studies there were interrupted by World War I. He returned to Ireland and married Elizabeth Braithwaite in 1802. They had three sons. His first marriage was to Catherine Peebles, a University of Clare woman. He then moved to Ballina to study mathematics with William Andover Gregory. When he returned to Cork, he joined the University of Bantry in 1812 and took his doctorate from Cambridge in 1813.  
 In 1817 he moved to India and worked on various scientific papers, including one on the biotaxy of the common dwarf roseae.  
 He made a trip to Kilchangra, Western Ghats during the February-March of 1823, investigating the cold formation of Lake Kulkarni.  
   
 He was ordained a priest in St. Stephen's Basilica of Heidelberg in 1826. He taught physics, chemistry and mathematical sciences at the University of Adelaide.  
   
 In 1829 he left Adelaide and settled at Rathtinagar, Kootenay County, British Columbia.  
 He undertook field research in southwestern Saskatchewan ( south-central Alberta ), exploring the Crowsnest Pass. He became an authority on grizzly bear and cohoing population health, analysing captive specimens and early field releases. This work resulted in the introduction in British Columbia of the gray-headed bushy ground squirrel in 1829. He is credited with making a major contribution to the knowledge of the forest ground squirrels in the Northwest Territories, the Yukon and northern Quebec and the discovery of morphological and physiological similarities between North American black bears and species from the rainforest interior of southern Venezuela, although these similarities were probably false. He published on the identification of the Columbian lynx, being the first to name the land mammal.As a professor, he introduced mycology to Canada and to the United States, pioneering the study of fungi in mycology, which had previously been poorly studied and not well supported by the general public.  
 From 1831 to 1854 Stenberg worked at the botanical gardens of Toulouse, and in 1836 became curator at the New York Botanical Gardens.Stenberg died in August 1863 at Palms, New Mexico, and was buried in St. Luke's Churchyard, Carrick-on-Shannon.  
 He was the son of Robert Stenberg of Bunheran and Charlotte Catharine Stenberg. His sisters were Agnes, wife of the botanist M.C. Burt, and Bernice, wife of the botanist, W.R.C. Whitney.  
   
   
 == Family ==  
 His youngest sister was also a researcher. His mother was the poet and novelist Susan Hecht Stenberg.  
   
   
 == Publications ==  
 Scats : A Case of Neonicosperm Derivation ( 1822 )  
 Quinionnal Schillaci, Oculof. Procès des Antiquités de la Suisse de l'Oxferre de Japon, 19 : 37–43 ( 1822 )  
 Catalogue des Mycologie à l'État de Féminine de Luce ( with Benjamin Knowles and Thomas Condie ). ( 1824 )  
 Epiphonomena Donatus ( 1830 )  
 Gynenischen Florarum ( 1840 )  
 Nymphae et Mesopelorrhagems Romantéris corhildearum ( 1844 )  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Karl Saul Bockert =  
Karl Saul Bockert ( 25 September 1858, Copenhagen – 18 July 1917, Lemberg ) was a Danish neurologist, one of the founders of the neuropathology branch of the Swedish anatomical system, one of the most distinguished of the leading figures in the history of neurology, and one of the first psychologists to develop the concepts of human neurophysiology.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Bockert was born in Copenhagen. He obtained his medical doctorate in 1894 and his neurology doctorate in 1898. From 1896 to 1898 he worked in the neurology department of the Odense University. From 1902 to 1905 he was an assistant at the Royal Veterinary Hospital and from 1905 to 1906 he was a professor at the University of Copenhagen.  
 From 1909 to 1918 he was director of the mental hospital of the Royal Orthopedic School, Copenhagen. He was the first Danish author to develop concepts of physiology in association with clinical problems ( in 1914 his book Symbolic Anatomy of the Brain as a Treatise of Diseases ). During the Second World War he moved to London to take up positions at the Hôpital Theoretical Institute and the Institute of Comparative Anatomy of the Royal College of Surgeons of Great Britain.  
 After the war, Bockert devoted himself entirely to clinical research and began to focus on aspects of human brain anatomy. In 1904, the Chair of Neurology at the University of Copenhagen was created, and in 1924 he was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society of London.  
 In 1919 he became the first professor of neurological pathology in Sweden. He served as the first president of the board of health of the Royal Norwegian Society for Neurology and Neurosurgery ( Norwegian : Kristiannekrående kirke fornar våldligt, for doctorologisch optik och och neuroptikar ), and he was a member of the Board of Neurological Research of the Swedish National Board of Health ( Norsk ). He was the medical superintendent of the Karls Region's Special Pediatric Unit of the Royal Pediatric Hospital in Gävle. Bockert and his son Gustaf Bockert Kinturkert founded the psychological hospital and hospital depts.  
 He died on 18 July 1917, the father of the Swedish neurologist Gustaf Bockert, who wrote the book Svenska stålligt ( The Pain-Relief Society ) in recognition of Bockert's contributions to psychology and neurology.  
   
   
 == Selected publications ==  
 Köbund och hlævde text bist arkonomiskningen af Sek. Svenska str. statist, 1884 – Köbund as a text for physiological analysis and malpractice.  
 Svenska florina och public och gråtte hörara, 1884 – Biograph on public buildings, public life and school.  
 Biologisk av studier och akademisk ockeren en personne i lændning i medulla, 1886 – Clinical studies on pathology and medical studies.  
 Kunstliga osteologiska ei middel medulla. ( Scientific medicine and psychiatry ), 1886 – Professional manual of osteology.  
 Das Diagnostik der Psychiatricnismus, 1889 – Diagnosis of the mental illness psychiatricism.  
 Kommission förelletiser medisatik, 1889 – Laboratory for clinical research on pathological investigations.  
 Theorie der Anatomie der Gebiet, 1892 – Theory of anatomy.  
 Kulturbeset och enmindelige aforening och obstetenskrifter af indymne, 1893 – Clinical systematics.  
 Europäische embryologiske från bataille af Persinsorge. 1890 – European embryology.  
 Thierkur meder. Aufgaben anfangje sigr i medhordiert söder en viertelsekning, 1899 – Homeopathy.  
 Epidemiology for clinical and pathological research, 1900 – Epidemiology in clinical and pathological research.  
 Insekten och för skilda ennegriftelsen sverige, 1902 – Insemination at low temperatures.  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Werner von Ritter =  
Werner von Ritter ( 29 August 1853 in Munich – 12 January 1921 in Munich ) was a German naturalist and palaeontologist who made important contributions to paleontology, including discoveries in the Cambrian explosion of fish and plankton in Central Europe.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Ritter was born in Munich, the son of Wilhelm von Ritter, a physician who studied medicine in Munich and with Karl Friedrich Grimm. He graduated from the University of Munich in 1873 with his M.D. in medicine. He received a Doctorate of Philosophy degree in 1877 from the University of Leipzig. In 1878 he took his Ph.D. degree from the University of Heidelberg, where he served as director for six years. In 1884 he was appointed to the chair of Zoology at the University of Tübingen and became senior curator in 1888. He was a member of the Zoological Society of America from 1890 until 1901 and of the German Academy of Science from 1901 until 1914.  
 He was appointed an honorary professor at the University of Munich in 1914, and a corresponding member of the Geological Society of London from 1915 to 1926. In 1879 he went to Berlin to join Friedrich Wilhelm Böhm-Bawerk, the director of the museum there.  
 Ritter received his PhD degree from the University of Heidelberg in 1880. He was a member of the German Academy of Sciences from 1901 until 1914.  
   
   
 == Scientific works ==  
 Ritter wrote a number of scientific papers and published several volumes on ornithology and plant and animal biology. Among his scientific works were :  
   
 Die Bau der tettungen Flora München 1890 – Bulletin on the flora of the Mediterranean region.  
 Preis im geologischen Erforschung in den Schweizer Abhandlungen der Verständnis des Provinz Ursaegypti 1912 – Preface to the Geological survey in North Africa.  
 Die Streistung in den Schweizer Abhandlungen der Verständnis des Provinz Ursaegypti 1880 – Description of the Streistung on the northern strip of the Comoros archipelago.His major work, The Cambrian Explosion in Fish and Porphyrin, was written in 1892.  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Moses Reinke =  
Moses Reinke ( 13 October 1889 – 9 March 1969 ) was a Jewish theologian and minister.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Moses Reinke was born in Sigdrup, Denmark in 1889. He was the son of Hermann Reinke, a member of the underground railroad system, and his wife, Rebekah Kay. He studied at the University of Copenhagen, receiving a doctorate in 1896.  
 In 1896, while still in Copenhagen, Reinke became a Lutheran pastor in Netreb utgård in Aalborg. Two years later, Reinke began publishing his theological works, under the pen name Manfred-Isaac Lenz. His discourses on theology in the Encyclopædia Britannica of the University of Copenhagen reached more than 250,000 copies. Reinke's work on the `` holy book '', the Holy Scriptures ( also known as The Berufganges Mysteriæ Encyclopædia Britannica ), was the first significant text-critical and text-critical textual study of the Old Testament. Other publications by him in the period were the commentary on Isaiah and the books of Esther and Jonah, the commentary on Psalm 145 ( 1894 ) and the commentary on Jonah, which also came under the pseudonym Lenz.  
 He spent the next three years in Germany, mainly in Berlin, before coming to Denmark in 1897. In 1897, he became a doctor of philosophy at the University of Copenhagen, and was then made dean of the Norwegian Faculty of Religious Education. He took part in a seminar on the ordeals of Judaism in Copenhagen in 1897. In 1900, he became the first priest in the church in Netreb, and served as rector from 1903 until 1906.  
 From 1908 he devoted himself to preaching the Gospel to the Jews of Denmark. In 1909 he was engaged in pastoral work at the General Synod of the Church of Denmark. In 1909 he became a member of the High Court of Justice and as a court judge, he published about 100 articles. He is known for writing the book The Great Mystery, in Danish. In 1912 he co-founded the Academic Council for Theological and Epistolic Culture.  
 In 1916 he was appointed minister of the Norwegian Church in Germany, and in 1920-22 he was acting president of the chapter of the congregation in Jerusalem. In 1925 he became head of the Norwegian Union in the All-Christian Union of the United Nations.After the Nansen movement ended in Germany, Reinke was invited to lead a conference in which he would attempt to find the Holy Grail. In 1934, he was forced to resign after an incident at the conference. He went on to teach at the University of Oslo. He died at his home in Kalmar in 1969.  
   
   
 == Selected bibliography ==  
 Reinke, Moses. The Great Mystery : A Hermeneutical Survey of Jewish Revelation, trans. M. Ellis ( 1896 ). The Great Mystery Press. ISBN 978-0804359042.  
 The Great Mystery : A Hermeneutical Survey of Jewish Revelation, trans. M. Ellis ( 1905 ). New York : Random House.  
 Life in the Court of Judgement, trans. E. Steinbauer ( 1922 ). New York : Harper & Brothers.  
 Historik en jahus. Eine Bedeutung der Kaiserlichen Staat : Zur Geschichte des Judenthums zu Berlin, 1895-1900, trans. Richard Moncrieff ( 1902 ). Oldenburg : Germania.  
 Theologische Übersicht über die Lutherboten, trans. Emil Polzer ( 1933 ). Leipzig : Zeitschrift für theologische Dogmatik.  
 The Bible in Dialogue, trans. O. Hartmann ( 1935 ). London : Thames & Hudson.  
 Die religiellen Wegen bis zur Theologie der Jansenismus. Berlin : Heidelberg.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Arnold Becker =  
Arnold Becker ( ; born May 4, 1934 in Joas, Denmark ) is an American singer, piano teacher, and director of the United States National Choral Society.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Becker was born in Joas, Denmark to Lars Becker and Patricia Schwendener ( née Kronlund ). He lived with his family in Jordan, then in British Mandate Palestine during World War II. He was raised in New York City by his mother who taught piano at the City College of New York. From 1942, he was a student of Charles Marx, then an instructor of piano at St. Louis University. He earned a BA in musicology from the University of Oklahoma in 1946, and a PhD in music theory from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill in 1950. He taught privately for two years at Cape Cod Public Schools and from 1952 to 1960 he was professor of musicology at the city academy in New York. He also taught music at Villanova University. Becker was married to Marjorie Elise ( née Troysen ) from 1963 to 1984. Becker, who had diabetes, died in 2002.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Ingemar Haldan =  
Ingemar Haldan ( 12 March 1822 – 9 March 1906 ) was a Danish chemist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Ingemar Haldan studied chemistry at the university in Copenhagen and from 1838 to 1843 in Petter Lund University. He went to London in 1840 and to France in 1842, on the same route as Lambert-Preus ( 1813 ) and he stayed there three more years. In 1851 he went to the United States to learn chemistry, earning his Ph.D. degree in chemistry from Cornell University in 1853.  
 In 1850 he moved to New York City, where he started to teach chemistry at Columbia University. In 1856 he founded the third grade chemistry class at Columbia. He joined the Union Chemical Union and served in the office of the president of the Union in 1857-58.  
 Haldan was a friend of Samuel Rosenstock Peabody and Richard Feynman.  
   
   
 == Contributions ==  
 Ingemar Haldan is best known for his discovery of hydrogen sulfide, but a thorough discussion of his work can be found in Studies in Aseninium Nuclei, 1858. He also invented the hydrogen plasma, which gave rise to the use of hydrogen or H2O.  
   
   
 == Writings ==  
 Über die Befreiheit der Thiochromorphism in das weitere Inorganische Compound. ( 1859 )  
 Untersuchungen über einige Befreiheit der Thiochromorphism in das Weitere Inorganische Compound. ( 1861 )

 Über die Befreiheit der Thiochromorphism. ( 1863 )  
 Travallungen der Thiochromorphism. ( 1865 )  
 Untersuchungen über die Befreiheit der Thiochromorphism. ( 1866 )  
 Untersuchungen über die Thiochromorphism. ( 1868 )  
 Über die Befreiheit der Thiochromorphism. ( 1869 )  
 Lehrbuch der Chemie. ( 1872 )
