<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = R. Meyers =  
Roger Meyers ( April 21, 1931 – May 14, 1990 ) was an American nuclear physicist, science fiction author, and the father of famed American comic Joe Meyers.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Meyers grew up in Colorado Springs, Colorado, which has a poverty rate of 53 percent. His father, Richard Meyers, was a physicist who died young. The family's inheritance fell on Roger's mother, who raised him and his brother, Joseph. He moved from California to El Paso in 1945, where he worked as a city planner in the town of El Paso while also living with his wife and two children.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 Meyers played guitar in a carpool band. He studied science at the University of Colorado Boulder under Patrick Baker, who earned his Ph.D. in 1945. The two went to work for U.S. Defense for Research and Development in Washington, D.C. at the Alamogordo project in New Mexico, where he worked with Leslie Hull. The Defense Department ordered a 40-kilogram manganese synchrocyclotron that was the largest such machine at the time, but its technical limitations restricted its use for use in civilian nuclear research.  
 While there, Meyers wrote the screenplay for the film Le Crouteur Noir, which was released in 1953.  
   
   
 == Politics ==  
 Meyers was a Conservative Party voter during the election of 1964, but, unlike many other Conservative voters, backed Democrat Lyndon B. Johnson. Meyers voted for Eisenhower in the 1964 presidential election and supported John F. Kennedy in the 1960 presidential election. He did not support former governor of Colorado Robert Cannon in the 1964 Democratic gubernatorial primary.  
   
   
 == Death ==  
 Meyers died in Santa Fe, New Mexico on May 14, 1990.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Silvina Antipova-Fey =  
Silvina Alexandrovna Antipova-Fey ( Russian : Олекса́ндр Превнович Лавлов ; 4 May 1919 – 10 January 2008 ) was a Soviet physicist. She was a long-time member of the Soviet nuclear-weapons research group, and worked on the Sankt Rat and Sankt-Meitner potentials. She is credited with writing the code for developing the first non-mechanical device, an infrared locator, which she demonstrated at the Moscow State Institute of Science.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Antipova-Fey was born in Moscow on 4 May 1919. She studied physics and mathematics at the Moscow State Institute of Science. After receiving her doctorate she joined the Soviet nuclear-weapons research group where she worked on the Sankt Rat and Sankt Meitner potentials. The main invention of the group was the development of a chemical element called poisic sodium ( `` base '' ). She also invented an anti-microbial drug. While working on the Meitner potentials, Antipova-Fey developed a filter.  
 She was the first to solve the Sankt Rat problem, and her solution achieved the logarithmic degree of the orbitals of the atom of a poisic element. She made a method of measuring the ratio of the boiling point to the melting point of solids, and provided a direct answer for Meitner's equation and related problems.In 1975, Antipova-Fey became a widow after divorcing her first husband ( Evgeni Pavlovitch Pavlovich Antipov ), who had been the head of the work group on the Sankt Rat problem, on 10 January 1975. The next year, she became a widow. Antipova-Fey died in Moscow on 10 January 2008. She is buried at Pemstvo-1 cemetery, Moscow.Antipova-Fey is credited with writing the code for developing the first non-mechanical device, an infrared locator.  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 =  
<start_bio> 
 = Richard Henreid de Zabel =  
Richard Henreid de Zabel ( May 22, 1835 – April 12, 1915 ) was an American botanist and plant scientist who served as Director of the University of Texas Botanical Garden for over half a century.  
 De Zabel was born in East Trenton, New Jersey, the eldest of three sons. His brother, John Henreid de Zabel ( 1817-1887 ), was appointed as the first United States Commissioner to the Port of New York in 1858 and served with great distinction on the Stationery Office as acting Commissioner from 1861 to 1866. At the age of twenty-seven he graduated with a M.A. in 1865 from the University of Pennsylvania, then spent several years in Europe studying the flora and fauna of South and Central America and Alaska. In the meantime, however, his research and translations into German had been superseded by an equally thorough exposure in the English language of plants and other botanical subjects.  
 Following his college studies, he devoted himself to the study of plant pathology. In 1873 he was elected an associate of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, serving on its President's Committee of 1879. When its membership began to include academic scientists such as Leland Stanford, William G. Budge, Irving B. Bliss and Charles James Morris, he ran for its election. He was elected fellow in 1877, and in 1881 he was elected president of the Science Society of New York.De Zabel was one of the first to draw attention to the so-called dual study of plant physiology and morphology. His pioneering work on the chemical structure and physiological organization of lignin, mineral oil, epigallocatechin, cholesterol and cholesterol esters, particularly cholesterol esters, suggested the relation between the oxidation of cholesterol and the degradation of plant tissues, often called the progressive `` diathesis ''. He also developed the concept of irreversible changes of physicochemical properties, as in a process called biosynthesis.  
 He was especially interested in the relationships between plant pathology and the physiological processes involved in growth and maturation, and his exploration of the mechanisms of evolution by which plant tissues were altered was well received. He was largely responsible for the widespread knowledge of the fructification of the chalk plant, de Zabel's corolla, during the late 18th century.  
 He died from influenza on April 12, 1915.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Franz von Langlais =  
Franz von Langlais ( 26 January 1635 – 21 April 1714 ), the Protestant theologian, was born in Sibley, near the Rhine, and went into the service of the Protestant Reformed Church from 1654 to 1671.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 He was the son of Stephan von Langlais, a teacher at the Reformed Gymnasium in Sibley, and his wife, Maria Gotthilf von Langlais. His father, like his mother, was a freethinker. His paternal grandfather, the priest Pietro Langlais, was a radical theologian and preacher in Neuen Artin.  
 At the age of six he was converted to the views of Luther. He obtained a preliminary university education in Sibley, and in 1655 undertook a course in theology with Samuel Koldenberg, whereupon he was ordained in 1658. His degree of Doctor of Divinity from the university, in August 1662, was probably due largely to his advocacy of the Reformed doctrines of justification by faith, free choice, and justification by faith alone, as opposed to the Calvinistic doctrines and dogmatics.  
   
   
 == Ecclesiastical career ==  
 He was for some years professor of philosophy in Neuen Artin, and in 1662 took up the rectorate of Duisburg. His theology had greatly improved, and he afterwards delivered the episcopal college sermon at the palace of Gotha. He was also indefatigable in the organization of churches. In 1672 he was appointed professor of theology at the imperial university of Bucharest, and a minister of the Church of Romania at Bucharest, from which he retired in 1694.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 His major works are the work De ibitur rectis doctrinae ( Erlangen, 1694 ), on the construction of the creed of justification, which was to become, in the course of its operations, the text of such Protestant treatises as Utrius Melanchthon and the works of Christoph Schlegel.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Jean-Étienne Bacher =  
Jean-Étienne Bacher ( 16 November 1801 – 7 February 1865 ) was a French meteorologist and geophysicist.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Born at Bellevue, Bacher studied at the Collège de France, and gained the degree of LL.D. He was named professor of astronomical instruments at Lille in 1828. After learning Latin and Greek he was appointed professor of classical languages and civil law in 1834 and delivered a lecture on declamation and diction in the University of Padua in 1839. In 1850 he was made professor of meteorology, and at the same time made curé of the Faculty of Education. He established the school of practical and practical science ( department of meteorology and astronomy ) at Lille, and received the Duchy of Lorraine for his services in this department.Bacher published his Meteorologie ( 1846 ) and Histoire de l'Époque et de l'Hygiène ( 1849 ).  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = William Dandridge Danczowski =  
William Dandridge Danczowski ( 22 April 1881 – 5 September 1941 ) was a Polish mathematician who achieved a significant amount of work during his time in Galway. His early mathematical career began with the publication in 1916 of an elementary proof of the inequality of squares. In 1910 he presented a proof of the equivalence of series for natural numbers in a publication titled `` Quantitative analysis of series of different densities ''. The standard work `` Reductiones nouvelles des dimensions de la poétique géométrie '' was done in a paper titled `` Anaphoraeurs des dimensions de la poétique géométrie ''. In 1919–20 he published a more general and widely used proof of one of the cardinalities of the group of polynomials. The papers he later submitted on properties of cubical curves are held in the collections of the Galway Mathematical Society and the library at the University of Witwatersrand.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Gerhard Moser =  
Gerhard Moser ( 31 August 1894 – 17 June 1978 ) was a German economist, economist for the Higher Education Council of Germany. He was elected President of the German Economic Association in 1922 and the General President of the German Economic Federation in 1930. He also served as its vice-president and as President for 1945–1946.  
 Moser is best known for writing a book on humanistic economic theory, The Economics of Man, with ideas from Karl Marx and Friedrich Hayek. He was a lecturer at the School of Industrial Economics in Germany.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Jos C3 A8nard Ferguson =  
José Augusto Ferguson ( 6 August 1884 – 18 September 1950 ) was a Uruguayan economist and politician.  
   
   
 == Early life and career ==  
 Ferguson was born into a wealthy farming family in La Roja, capital of South American Province of Uruguay. He studied economics and university, studying at the San Pedro School in Buenos Aires and at the Facultad de Estudios de Investigaciones Mercantes in La Paz. In 1926, he founded the social welfare association Pública internacional ( `` International Union of Social Welfare '' ), where he proposed a national system of social insurance for the poor. He took up political office with other such organizations as Ebro de Dios Socialista in Managua ( 1929 ) and the organization Juventud Guerra Comunista in Montevideo ( 1930 ). Later he established the only `` Spanish '' social insurance organization : the `` Social Fundación de Granada '' in Rio de Janeiro ( 1936 ).  
   
   
 == Political career ==  
 In 1926, Ferguson represented District II of Buenos Aires, which was then part of the colonial administration. The area was ruled by the Frente Proceso ( tax authority ), and all taxes were collected by the General of the Provincial Power, Jose Orosco.The president of the country in 1926, Augusto Pérez Maestre, had appointed Ferguson as the head of the cabinet ; the Governor-General of Paraguay, Jose Fernández Ocampo, had appointed him treasurer of the cabinet, where Ferguson worked on budget matters.  
 In 1929, he appointed Ferguson as President of the Instituto de Estudios Economico-Universitaria, in recognition of his writings in economics, especially his book The Economics of the State ( 1938 ). In 1938, he gave a speech about the liberalization of Brazil's trade.  
 Ferguson's first appointment after the coup in 1948 was as Governor of Menaréna, then a constituent of São Paulo, in a government that made all the necessary changes to the economy to benefit the workers and peasants of the area. He saw it as a chance to construct an economic model for Uruguay that provided a progressive and effective progressive government for society, one that was linked to the needs of business, and that made it possible to reduce interference by bureaucratic bodies from government.  
 As minister of agriculture, he sought to repair the losses made by the rationing of imported goods. In 1941, he formed an agricultural committee, the so-called Ferme Commission, to promote agricultural reform, which included initiatives to increase the export of rubber and rubber products. He also played a part in laying the foundations for the creation of the first marine research center.  
   
   
 == Social insurance and poverty reduction ==  
 It was in this period of his career that he began to advocate for social insurance for the poor. In addition to this, his policies were affected by the government of Jorge Sáez Sánchez de Velez, with the politicians publishing debates within congresses in which they attempted to eliminate what they considered a deterioration in social conditions in the poor areas.In 1935, he proposed the concept of tax credits and assessments to the People's Alliance, a cooperative society of farmers, dockers, builders, employees and unemployed workers, to combat social inequality. He proposed these policies as a way to alleviate poverty, while also protecting the environment and raising profits from the trade of workers who were forced into the country. His policies were once again revised in 1942 to give the government greater influence over the agrarian movement.  
 He was elected to the Chamber of Deputies in the 1930 general election, following the political leader of that year, Evaristo Domingo Sommers, who died in office, with nine seats remaining. However, upon his withdrawal, his office became vacant due to no state funds being released for social insurance.  
   
   
 == Death ==  
 In 1950, he retired to Chile, where he died in Concepción Villa De Stefano, close to the Soledad Mountains.  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Thomas Dixon =  
Thomas Dixon ( January 22, 1817 – August 19, 1900 ) was an American Methodist missionary, whose name is sometimes mentioned in connection with Waddell's Watervliet.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Thomas Dixon was born near Jamestown, Virginia, about 1780, the son of Peter Dixon, a physician. On July 6, 1841, he entered College of William & Mary, one of the first colleges in Virginia to admit women. During his early years he went to Europe for studying, and enrolled at The Hague, where he soon gained acquaintance with its missionaries. During his second residence he became engaged in preaching. Shortly afterwards, a mission had been sent to England from the Dutch colony of Zeeland to the Dutch East India Company, and Dixon left to join it in his native country.  
 In the midst of his labors he was appointed an elder in the Baptist denomination at Concord, New Hampshire, and moved there in 1848. On his return he took charge of several Baptist missions in Maine, New Hampshire, Vermont, and Oregon, and throughout the territory received the fervent and professional support of the Baptists of the areas.  
 With the exception of two years, when in Maine he undertook missionary work in California, the travel in a merchant vessel took him throughout most of the coast of California, passing several times from Los Angeles to New York. He was left in the Southern Pacific Territory of the United States when a party of missionaries reached the Sandwich Islands. Dixon was appointed missionary-in-chief to the Sandwich Islands in 1855, and subsequently visited the Islands for several months, during which time he obtained the credit of having visited Cook's Island in New Zealand, a country which, however, was unknown to his predecessor, Thomas Martin McDougall, with whom he had little intercourse before. On this visit he wrote a letter to the United States President in July 1856, to request financial assistance in his mission to return the property of A. S. Van Alstyne, who had been broken in pieces by a storm, and had not been found. He preached at Washington on November 13, 1857, while in New England, and on that occasion recommended his wife, Adelaide, to act as his secretary and interpreter. During the following year he was at Fort McPherson in West Virginia, and preached in the Little Fort churches at Quaker Creek, Phillipsburg, Lebanon, and Winstead.  
   
   
 == Later years ==  
 In 1860, he was made one of the officers of a section of the Committee of Expeditions of the Southern Baptist Convention, and in 1866 transferred to Utah, where he became pastor of the First Baptist church of Logan City, near Logan, on the Missouri River. He was also for a time superintendent of the Missionary Trustees of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints. The result of his missionary work he recorded in 1877. During his last years of life he entered upon the arduous duty of reviewing the services of all the missionaries in the South Pacific. The condition of the missions was shown by his health, which gradually deteriorated.  
 Dixon died at Logan City, Utah, in 1900, in health free from disease. He was buried in the church cemetery of Logan.  
   
   
 == Bibliography ==  
 John J. Martin McDougall, Eminent Old and New Dogmas of New Thought, University of Missouri Press, St. Louis, 1889.  
 Robert Norris, `` A Manual of Doctrine, '' in Journal of Discourses, iii. xi. 62–74 ( 1877 ).  
 D. A. Curtis, `` Joseph Beauregard Phillips : Born on a Long Mission, '' in Journal of Discourses, iv. vii. 56–60 ( 1877 ).  
 Florence S. H. Davis, The Revival of Methodism in the United States ( 1885 ).  
 Matthew B. Brickman, `` Moses Paston : His Descent, Rise, and Renewal, '' in Journal of the American Baptist Historical Society, vii. 1 ( Spring 1899 ).  
 Frederick T. Bartlett, A Political Journey into America, John Murray, Chicago, 1908.  
 `` A Personal Memoir of Dr. Thomas Dixon, '' in The Logan Daily Sentinel, 30 ( April 1896 ), A–B, 13.  
 Joe G. Russell, `` John Joseph Godfrey... and Thomas Dixon, '' in The Logan Daily Sentinel, 30 ( April 1896 ), A–B, 11.  
 John Frank Henry, `` Thomas Dixon '', Salt Lake City, 1975.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Sarah Richardson =  
Sarah Richardson ( 28 October 1846 – 12 April 1923 ) was an English educator, amateur botanist and entomologist.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Richardson was born in England. Her father, Benjamin Richardson, was a professor of botany at Saint Mary ’ s College, Cambridge, and an authority on wild ferns and the studies of certain individuals. Her mother, Katherine Ann Richardson, was a teacher of mathematics and literature and a second cousin of Sir Walter Scott. Richardson attended Emmanuel College, Cambridge from 1874 to 1878, and in 1883 went to Harvard University as an honorary research fellow, where she became one of the instructors of mathematics and of natural science for mathematics and natural history courses.  
 During her time in Cambridge, Richardson published a number of botanical works including Forests of Hampshire ( 1885 ) and British Ferns of North Britain ( 1887 ). She wrote several other papers about her interest in plants and chemistry, and was member of the Cambridge Natural History Society from 1889 to 1901.  
 In 1897 she married Thomas Johnson Richardson, a geologist and businessman who was also a botanist.  
 She died in London, where she had worked as a lecturer in mathematics and natural history since 1894, and was buried in her childhood home, with her family, in No. 1 Queenscombe Fields, Brighton, Brightonshire.  
   
   
 == Species described ==  
 Her favorite fern, Muscularia Richardsoni, is described as `` remarkable. ''  
   
   
 == Writings ==  
 Forests of Hampshire ( 1885 ).  
 British Ferns of North Britain ( 1887 ).  
 The Occurrence of Australian Insects and Fungi ( 1896 ).  
 Fungus Beetles and their Description and Control ( 1902 )  
 Fungi of South-west France ( 1905 )  
 The Fungi of India ( 1905 )  
 Bibliography of Nests and Roots in the British Flowers of China ( 1914 )  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Willy Benedict Teil =  
Willy Benedict Teil ( 6 January 1889 – 26 October 1955 ) was a German physicist known for work on the magnetism of atoms and on his own work on the character of radioactivity.  
   
   
 == Education and scientific career ==  
 Teil studied physics at the universities of Königsberg and Kiel, graduating with a Ph.D. in 1923. From 1923 to 1933 he worked at the Albertina Institute in Göttingen. While there he investigated the nuclear magnetic field and conducted fundamental work. In 1934, Teil became a fellow at the Humboldt University of Berlin.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 Teil returned to Germany, where he continued his research. He became head of the research group for meteorites at the Max Planck Institute in Göttingen in 1945. In 1946, he became a visiting scholar at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem, with a postdoctoral fellowship in nuclear physics at the same institution. In 1948 he became a corresponding member of the Romanian Academy of Sciences. He was awarded the Stalin Prize in Physics in 1953 for his research on the nuclear magnetic field.  
 In 1956, Teil joined the Max Planck Institute of the Friedrich-Wilhelms-Gymnasium in Heidelberg, where he remained until 1955. He served as a professor of physics at the Technische Hochschule Königsberg from 1950 to 1953 and as a professor of theoretical physics at the Ludwig Maximilians University of Munich from 1953 to 1959. He was a Visiting Professor at the University of Cincinnati from 1955 to 1962.Teil was elected to the National Academy of Sciences in 1967, to the American Physical Society in 1971 and to the Institute of Radio Engineers in 1973. He was also a member of the Heinrich Hertz Foundation, the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and the LEWG. He was a charter member of the German Astronomical Society and was its president in 1971. Teil died in Bucharest.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Robert C. Woodhouse =  
Robert C. Woodhouse ( July 6, 1859 – October 9, 1944 ) was an American biologist known for his studies of fungi, plant diseases and pollination. He was a professor of botany and later director of the College of Agricultural Sciences in Milwaukee, Wisconsin.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Woodhouse was born in 1859 to Maria and Hamilton Woodhouse, who ran a funeral parlor. His father worked as a plumber, and his mother moved away with him to live with his family after the death of his father. He earned his bachelor's degree from Wisconsin Wesleyan College, and his Ph.D. in physiology from the University of Wisconsin in 1908. In 1909, he married Caroline Poncelet, who was born in Mexico. They moved to Chicago, Illinois in 1910, where they lived for the next eight years. They would remain there for the rest of his life.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 After graduating from Wisconsin Wesleyan College, Woodhouse went to Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, where he worked in zoology and biology, eventually becoming a staff research botanist and resident botanist at the University of Pennsylvania. In 1916, he was promoted to assistant professor of biology at the college, where he later became a full professor in 1919.  
 In his career, Woodhouse identified many plant diseases that had important role in aiding the livestock industry, and helped create a biorepository of wheat fields. During World War I, he participated in the Great Lakes Research Project, and helped develop an experimental mill and a chemical fertilizer in Minnesota. From 1925, Woodhouse served as head of the Department of Botany at the University of Wisconsin, Madison, where he took over as chair from 1926 to 1938.  
   
   
 == Scientific achievements ==  
 During the first half of the 20th century, Woodhouse's work on phytotaxonomy laid the groundwork for a new approach for understanding phytotaxonomy in the western United States. Woodhouse was well known for his unorthodox approach to phytotaxonomy that involved asking the questions `` What is life? '' rather than `` What is happening? ''. He also pursued questions like : `` Is it related to the flowering times? '' and `` What is some characteristic morphological characteristic in fungi? '' After studying plants for decades, his work in the field of phytotaxonomy soon caught the attention of botanists around the world. He began publishing papers in an international scientific journal, American Journal of Botany, in 1920, and published a series of five papers, as well as a series of articles in the Proceedings of the Royal Society of London. He also published several papers on chemical plants. Many of his published works include the first description of Boulengeria mimosa. This moss, discovered in 1980, is often referred to as `` the coleopteran of the genus Woodhouse's plants. ''  
 Woodhouse was a pioneer of the field of flora ecology, along with Aron Feinberg, Henry Stockton-Blatt and Al C. Milliken, and is also credited with creating the microbial fungi taxonomy. He coined the term `` microbial floras '' in 1948, when he described the macroflora of various woody vascular plants as the coleopteran system and studied the malacological communities and feeding habits of the fungus.  
   
   
 == Honors and awards ==  
 In 1924, he received the Charles Babbage Medal of the Royal Society of London.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Frits Siebert =  
Frederick Frits Siebert ( 20 September 1872 – 6 May 1943 ) was a Swedish geologist, geophysicist, and Nobel laureate. He was the first person to demonstrate the existence of large earthquakes in Europe, and the first to establish that continental crust is distinct from oceanic crust.  
   
   
 == Life and work ==  
 Siebert was born on 20 September 1872 in Stockholm and was a son of Frederick Wilhelm Siebert, the mining engineer who had come to Stockholm in 1882. His younger brother Wilhelm is buried in Oakmore, Church Street Cemetery. He attended school in Berlin and received a doctorate from the University of Göttingen.  
 Siebert took a position as a teacher at the Old State Vocational School ( now the Konservatorium ) in 1892. He got a job at the Mining Corporation, Kristiansand, Norway, in 1896 and was a member of the mining inspection team there from 1900 to 1910. In 1906, he became mining geologist at the petroleum production company in Gothenburg. In September 1907, he was named assistant geologist to the director of the institute for petroleum operations in Åbo by the government, with a focus on petroleum products. At the same time, he was created director of the Natural Resources Institute ( forerunner of the Norwegian Institute for Water Resources ) in Gotha. During 1911, he left for France to take up a position as a staff geologist at the Moroccan Petroleum Company in Cairo. From this position, he began to conduct geological and climatological investigations on the Mediterranean Sea ( especially Spitsbergen and Tobruk ). He returned to Sweden in 1915, during the Second World War. In 1919, he was appointed secretary-general of the Norwegian Institute for Research in Geology, and in 1930 became director. During his tenure, he funded many investigations into the geology of oil reserves in Greenland, and had a major impact on oil exploration. In 1927, he was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics `` for his extensive field studies of the geology of the Norwegian shelf and the geology of oil and gas in the Mediterranean Sea, and for his ability to produce scientific papers in English ''. He died in Gothenburg on 6 May 1943, from cancer.  
   
   
 == Selected works ==  
 Wells's series on the Geology of Spitsbergen, published in 1930.  
 How much is the Petroleum Reserve In Greenland?, 1917  
 Svenska tarne og En kriske hansn og slummeding og regionalgift morgelskapet, 1918  
 Hydrulites och trova och oilseersvallning och petrodin och tarvænga urska i montagen for dena komponent i tarventorer, 1918  
 The geology of Oslo and its petroleum reserves, 1923  
 Salinogne och oilseer in cod år det fra Oslo verkligningen och nokre en kring och svalge och kronks, 1924  
 Salinogne och tarvænga och kronkens en mabruk och tarvik for dena komponent i tarventorer ihre energym, 1925  
   
   
 == Citations ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Knut N. Schäfer =  
Dr. Knut N. Schäfer ( 28 July 1868 – 5 June 1937 ) was a Danish microbiologist and pathologist.  
 He was born in København in 1868 and was the son of a shipyard owner. He studied law at Uppsala University, studying chemistry, and medicine, during which time he became head of the bacteriology unit at Uppsala Institute of Biology ( now Uppsala University Hospital ).  
 Schäfer received his doctorate in 1887 and his Ph.D. in 1891. In 1895, he published two papers on inoculation with bacteria from a dead sheep and in 1897 he identified a specific type of iron bacterium at the end of a long chain. He received a professorship at Uppsala University in 1907 and was appointed professor of bacteriology. In 1914, Schäfer joined the Royal Danish Academy of Sciences as professor and served as dean of the school until 1932.  
 In 1912, he contributed to a German virology textbook on tuberculosis based on a periodical article that described sera collected from patients with hyperthermia. This work led to a special reference in 1924 describing the immunological features of tuberculosis ( xenograft materials and the interrelationship between DNA and proteins, primers, polyglutamine and proteins ).  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Henry Bartlett Newton =  
Henry Bartlett Newton ( August 14, 1862 – October 5, 1939 ) was an American economist.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
   
 Newton was born in Lexington, Massachusetts to Elizabeth and Charles Newton. He was educated at the Technical High School in Boston, graduated from Harvard University in 1884, and taught economics and statistics for 12 years at New England School.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 Newton began working on bank returns and unemployment insurance during the depression of the early 1890s. In 1891, at a public meeting in Boston, he suggested that the federal government continue to subsidize insurance, and its revenue had to be increased to pay for it. Newton also criticized the crisis of industrial relations in Great Britain for its absence of a clear union of labor and capital.  
 During the First World War, he served as director of the United States Institute of Industrial Relations, a New England division of the League of Nations.  
 Newton earned a Ph.D. in Economics from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1893, and a Nobel Prize in Economics in 1896.  
 His theory of the tendency to create false, but disfavored, alternative goods, titled the Newtonian diffusion, is sometimes known as `` modern '' desirability bias.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 Newton held a chair in the Department of Economic and Political Sciences at the University of Chicago from 1891 to 1898 and from 1900 to 1903, and he served as professor of economics and political science at Brown University from 1904 to 1908. He also served as secretary to the Board of Trustees of Brown University from 1907 to 1908 and as its provost from 1907 to 1911. He also was the first President of the U.S. Naval Association and the first President of the Economic Club of Chicago.  
   
   
 == Contributions ==  
 Newton is best known for his theory of the tendencies to create false, but disfavored, alternatives goods, called the Newtonian diffusion, and he developed this theory and accepted the Nobel Prize in Economic Sciences in 1897. Newton believed that tax-exempt foundations could raise adequate funds to support studies of the correct production and sale of goods.In the field of economic theory, the Newtonian diffusion occurs when what would otherwise be socially desirable must now be produced or sold. Newton coined the term `` Newtonian fallacy '', in honor of the theoretical physicist in a sermon delivered in Boston in 1893. The idea was that, `` the good that could have caused the fame of King Ludwig XIV but did not cause him to run off to live abroad, was of an uninteresting nature. '' For example, a high school field trip is more probable than that of a teacher. This is a consideration that can lead to misguided decisions and social interactions.  
 He was the first president of the American Statistical Association ( ASA ) and the first president of the National Academy of Sciences ( NAS ). He was a member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences ( AAS ) and the American Academy of Political and Social Science ( AAPSS ).  
 Newton is widely considered one of the foremost economists in the 20th century.  
   
   
 == Influence on American life ==  
 With Thomas Mann he introduced the concept of a stationary stock of knowledge. It is based on the premise that knowledge alone will always lead to optimal exchange rates. Newton developed this theory with Francis C. Stephens and the subject of Great Depression came to be known as cyclical adjustment.  
   
   
 == Selected works ==  
 Samuel Ruggles : The Technical Foundations of Economic Statistics, 1891  
 Statistics : Their History, Applications, and Significance, 1906  
 Newcomen, Solomon K : A Family Funeral ; The Rotating Stock of Statistical Knowledge, 1923  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Dirk-Jules Dermet =  
Dirk-Jules Dermet ( also Dirk Jules Dermett, 1888–1962 ) was a Belgian-Canadian mathematician, a prominent exponent of the Euclidean-Geometric theory, and the author of many algebraic and mathematical papers.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Dermet was born in Brefeld, where his father, Paul Dermet, was pastor. His parents wanted him to attend the St. Petersburg Conservatory of Music, so he studied music theory and composition under Pierre Rolland, but he preferred to pursue mathematics. His professor, Vincenzo Valchek, helped recruit him as a mathematician and Professor of Pure and Applied Mathematics. He earned his Ph.D. in 1913 from Johns Hopkins University, where he was a fellow of the National Academy of Sciences. While working at Johns Hopkins, he assisted Marcel Fougère with his work on quaternions, and worked with Alexander C. Maurer. He was also member of the APM Le Comptes Rendus Compositionse et Mathematique de France. He received the Gold Medal of the Mathematical Society of Edinburgh and the first membership in the Le Comptes Rendus Compositionse. He was appointed co-secretary for the Mathematical Institute of the Royal Norwegian Academy of Sciences in 1944, and his proposers were Dietrich Swank and Lise Skovgaard.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 Dermet studied theorems of the norm and that are relativized to a variety of symmetric forms, and generalized principal and sum of ordinary differential equations on quaternions.He is sometimes cited as being the `` father of the Euclidean calculus '' ( a variation of algebraic geometry, where Euclidean geometry is a certain number of absolute terms, a starting point for all subsequent topics ).  
   
   
 === Euclidean geometry ===  
 Dermet formulated the principle of the equal treatment of surface and volume derivatives. According to Haack, Dermet was motivated by `` his desire to understand not only the fixed-point planes of a plane without surface or volume, but what is tangentially symmetric in a plane with both ''. His principle of the equal treatment of surface and volume derivatives allows for generalization of the differential equations of Maxwell's equations. According to D. G. Smith, the mathematical proofs of these equations allow for universal extension of all mathematical theory to a third dimension.  
 Dermet defined the `` Lassen '' triangle by extending the Euclidean rules to these three special case triangles. This triangle is the third most common triangle that contains a circle.  
   
   
 === First-order functional analysis ===  
 Dermet devised and extended earlier work on functional analysis, for which he is often called `` founder of functional analysis ''. It provides the foundation for the applicability of mathematical methods in functional analysis, a priority he dedicated to his collaborators Leon Balabanov and Silvio Nardi in 1931. Dermet established the basis for an understanding of the notion of linear algebra. Many mathematicians in his time believed that algebraic structure is linear if and only if the basic rules governing differential equations are observed. Dermet's work demonstrates that this is false. This work was widely known at the time and proved in several papers before Dermet's death in 1962.  
   
   
 == Other work ==  
 In 1907, he was elected Fellow of the Royal Society.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Samuel Walker =  
Samuel Walker ( March 23, 1913 – June 16, 2006 ) was an American physicist.  
 Walker was born in Alexandria, Georgia, the son of Lester Scott Walker and Emma Elizabeth Steele. He received a bachelor's degree in mathematics from Auburn University in 1932.  
   
   
 == Education ==  
 While still a graduate student, he became involved in research at the Manhattan Project. In 1935, he joined the radar division of the U.S. Air Force, which operated the ENIAC and the L-19 radar. Walker's undergraduate thesis was on the efficient calculation of the propagation cross sections of a magnetic monopole and the terrestrial case of the double-lens reference film, The aerodynamical factors in solution of the piezoelectric effect.  
   
   
 == Professional career ==  
 Walker was a research physicist for a year at the Iowa Central Research Center in Des Moines, Iowa, before joining the faculty of Purdue University in 1938. There, he spent the next eight years, until 1950, working on radar solutions using cosmic rays and radiation shielding. He won the Ehrlich Medal from the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics in 1958.He retired in 1958 and spent the remainder of his life pursuing his interest in micrometeorites, which he developed while at Purdue.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Pierre Daniel Juillet de Zay =  
Pierre Daniel Juillet de Zay ( 9 June 1824 – 24 July 1894 ) was a French engineer and geologist. He is known for his study of strata and for his essay on `` The History of the Permian Traps '' published in 1859.  
   
   
 == Early life ==  
 De Zay was born in Paris.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 He is credited with showing in 1859 that strata near the village of Chapelle-d'Luionde, in the Petite-Urbain region, have strata similar to those of the Central Province of Western France ( Côte-d'Ivoire ).  
   
   
 == Personal life ==  
 In 1869 he married Corinne Chiricoff ; they had two daughters and one son. His second wife, Merle-Christine Adrienne Guillotin, a violinist, was also a writer of science fiction.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Henri Rochefort =  
Henri Rochefort ( 26 July 1858 – 27 December 1938 ) was a French entomologist.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 From 1863 to 1867, Rochefort worked as a lecturer at the Sorbonne in Paris. Later, in 1870, he became professor of entomology at the University of Lille. In 1876 he was made Curator of Entomology at the Natural History Museum in Paris, and was made a full professor in 1881. In 1890, he was made a member of the Académie des sciences.  
 He described over 100 species of moths, including 79 new moths and four new butterflies, and some 13 new butterflies. Two genera of the Mexican moth were named in his honour, as were 10 species of Mediterranean moth. The insect genus Rochefortia ( family Pieridae ) was named after him.  
   
   
 == Selected works ==  
 - Voyage dans l'Empire entomologique de l'Égypte ( Paris, 1874 )  
 - Contribution à l'étude entomologique de l'édition histoire naturelle. Publication de l'Empire de France, Découvertes, Lettres, Académie des Sciences, vue et Oiseaux.  
 - Note sur un insectisci occidentale par Marcel Gaucher. Notice du Musee Royale des Belles-Lettres.Lectures De réalité entomologique sous la famille ( Paris, 1884 )  
 - Description d'une système naturelle au genre insectisci occidentale ( Paris, 1886 )  
 - Diagnoses de la peste d'après une hiver du Algiers. Notice du Musee Royale des Belles-Lettres, 1887  
 - Note sur la famille des algoncinins de la ville de Paris. Notice du Musee Royale des Belles-Lettres, 1887  
 - On the genus Donatus rubens, by Pierre Ferlier. Notice du Musee Royale des Belles-Lettres, 1890  
 - Catalogus flora et fauna cognitae antirrhinatum, and an dulce tecnico-cuneiformis. Bonn, 1892  
 - Contribution a l'ouest des mothènes et faunides. Ancienne française de l'Académie des Sciences, 1897  
 - Contribution à l'appartenement de l'orientation créatrice des moths. Encyclopédie entomologique, 1905  
 - Introduction au point de l'évolution, à la wissenschaft des larvae et avec les aspects de mort de moths ( Paris, 1912 )  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = William Thurston Addison =  
William Thurston Addison ( 27 February 1828 – 5 February 1900 ) was an English Catholic priest, sociologist and writer, often credited with originating the concepts of `` modern woman '' and `` newly modern ''.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Addison was the son of Samuel Addison ( 1748–1834 ), a cloth manufacturer, and Elizabeth ( née Ashton ), daughter of the merchant Benjamin Ashton. In 1839, his elder brother was elected local vicar ; a year later, a brother-in-law became vicar ; in 1842, William moved to Naples, Italy, where he was vicar of Pavia from 1848 until 1856, when he was sent by the Curia to Rome. While there, Addison wrote his first books, which advocated conversion from Roman Catholicism to the Anglican communion ( now a separate religion ).  
   
 Addison's interest in reforming Catholicism was at the height of its renaissance in Italy in the early 1840s. His denunciation of Roman Catholicism as `` the filth and sloth of Rome '' caused the Bishop of Turin, Massimo Varese, to rebuke him, and Addison's plea for `` a definite and independent religious creed '' caused him to be included in the first of several Accademia dei Lincei revocati in 1844.In the following years he became an advocate of Anglicanism ; his assertion that his own views were socially liberal was ridiculed, and with the conversion of the wealthy Vezzano family, Addison became `` dean of the civic chapel in Turin, which, with its ecclesiastical privileges, makes him among the foremost authorities on modern Italian literature. ''  
 He was a fierce opponent of the order's separation from Rome, and his idea of `` radical independence '' ( also used in English with the title `` radical Protestantism '' ), due to his opposition to Rome's ecclesiastical structures and its tendency to centralize power, led many Roman Catholics to point to him as the prime supporter of their views. But it was not always so. He was a critic of his brother James Addison's Realism, also known as Non-religious Liberals, who held to what he called `` a quasi-devotional '' spiritual dimension.  
   
 He is sometimes referred to as the father of modern feminism, and is best known as the editor of Feminism and Modernity, and feminist religious figure Kate Millett, who wrote poetry from Addison's perspective. In contemporary English-language `` feminist writers '' he is sometimes called `` Addison-Gilmore '', and perhaps `` Gottlieb Johnson ''.  
   
   
 == Significant works ==  
 The Return of the Apostles ( 1844 ), Critical Dictionary of the Bible.  
 1842 : A Man of Unity  
 Man on the Fence, or, A Journey Through the Indies ( 1849 )  
 The Church-Parliament of Ireland ( 1850 ), The Christian Educator  
 1851 : Woman and Priest, Essays in Honor of Rev. William Addison ( edited by Dr. William Harvey & William Willis Blair ), Edinburgh  
 American Woman : The Story of Women and Society ( 1851 )  
 Domestic Life and Woman's Freedom, 19th Century Series, New York  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = John S. A. L. Johnson =  
John S. A. L. Johnson ( 26 January 1879 – 10 January 1941 ) was an American zoologist, mycologist, botanist, and lecturer on entomology.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 He was born in Waterville, New York, and attended Waterville High School. He went on to earn a bachelor's degree in natural sciences from the University of Wisconsin in 1905, and a master's degree in zoology in 1908. He taught biology at Emory University, Bakersfield, California, from 1910-12 and the U.S. Army Medical Corps in Germany in 1912.  
 He returned to the U.S. and was appointed an associate professor of biology at the University of Washington in Seattle, Washington in 1915.  
 Johnson then joined a laboratory as a fellow of Cornell University and, in 1918, was named curator of the new Department of Zoology, Cornell University.Johnson went on to teach biology in a wide variety of institutions and become known as a leading authority on mycology and fungi, an area that fascinated him greatly.He died on 10 January 1941, at the age of 79.  
   
   
 == Work ==  
 During his fieldwork, he spent the last 11 years of his life documenting the insect taxonomy of northern Mexico and Central America, and his collections were acquired for the University of Washington Museum of Comparative Zoology. He edited the Bulletin of the American Museum of Natural History's Review of Mycology in 1916-17, and collaborated with their colleague Wilfred G. Wing as an editor. In 1932 he married Sarah Howard White and moved to Renton, Washington. He had two children. His papers are held at the University of Washington's Museum of Comparative Zoology. His main papers are illustrated in the Mycological Bulletin.  
   
   
 == Publications ==  
 Johnson was the author of several books and articles on mushrooms. He wrote papers on bacterial and fungal families, including the zoophytes Linsoiraceae ( called `` Teck '' in Japanese ) and Bactria. He was the co-author of the Mycological Encyclopedia with Eugene James Gepp and L.J. Rediker of Cornell University, 1915. He was also a contributor to the Bulletin of the American Museum of Natural History's Review of Mycology. The Journal of the Mycological Society of America published a two-part series, Mutual Recognition of Species, Vol. II, in 1945, which focused on biotechnology as a contributor to biodiversity and was `` much admired '' by the group's president.  
 His other notable works include The Cachylioidea of Utah and their Distribution in Oklahoma ( 1910 ), mycology and hiscology in a Rural Arizona Area ( 1917 ), and A Naturalist's Guide to the Mazatec : Contributions to Mycology ( 1923 ). A short-term monograph titled The Löwenhoek Bug ( Campylobacter duodenale – Ishida serovarum ) ( 1928 ) discusses C. duodenale and other early Mycobiaceae.  
   
   
 == Family life ==  
 Johnson was married to Lillian Oppenheim, whom he had met in 1902. He was a husband-and-wife team, and was deeply influenced by his wife's natural science. They had two daughters, Camilla I.B. Johnson and Mary A.W. Johnson. They had two sons, James and David.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Hans Hauser =  
Hans Hauser ( 26 June 1861 – 17 January 1949 ) was a German composer. He was a son of Ludwig Hauser and an older brother to Wolfgang.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Hauser was born on 26 June 1861 in Göttingen, to Ludwig Hauser ( 1840–1910 ) and Maria Hauser ( 1840–1911 ), sister of Georges Hauser, a state minister. Hauser's father was a minister of state in Leipzig and was from a non-practicing Jewish family. He had first heard music and began composing at the age of seven.  
   
   
 === Musical education ===  
 In 1894, he entered the Ludwig von Mises Institute in Leipzig, where he studied violin and composition. From 1907 onwards, he studied a classical style known as `` fulltone '' with his elder brother, Wolfgang. Their influences, especially those of the Vienna Circle, were strong, which led to a passionate interest in music and works of literature.In 1913, Hauser received his doctorate in composition under the direction of Bernd Heinrich Schäffer. From 1916 to 1919 he taught composition at the Leipzig Conservatory. It was during his study of the Vienna Circle that his first writing, the Hungarian Early Great Works ( 1928 ), appeared. He had since heard the work with great interest, so was in the habit of offering criticism.Hauser also took the chance to study with the renowned pianist Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart and the violinist Carl Adolph Schoenberg. These students were key figures in his artistic development.  
   
   
 == Poetry ==  
 Hauser was one of the best known Polish-language poets of the last decades of the 19th century. His earliest works were published in Hóra, a large literary magazine founded in 1912 in Polish-occupied Austria. Since Hauser worked at the same time as the Polish poet Horia Kopłościeńský, the poets'poet was known for his lively and poetic style. However, despite being an idealist and the idealist being under constant siege by these poets'idealism, Hauser taught his poetry in a manner open to all students of French-language culture.Kopłościeńský used to call Hauser `` the real soprano '' ( a portmanteau of `` real '' and `` opera '' ). Hauser was also well known for writing on music in Vienna. The poet's visit to Vienna in 1910 gave him an intimate knowledge of all aspects of Hungarian music. They fell out during the Hungarian Civil War because of Hauser's attachment to the National Liberal Party.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 Between 1906 and 1918, Hauser composed music for films such as Monty Python's The Meaning of Life and The Godfather. His earlier works are considered among the finest in his repertoire. Some of his earliest work of operatic composition, i.e. works for orchestral purposes, is Tannhäuser-Klein im bekannten ( Tannhäuser's Opera for 15 Children, written after taking part in a St. Petersburg Festival in 1881 ), with the title variation of Passacaglia, and is arguably one of the finest in operatic composition ever written. This is followed by Tannhäuser-Schule, organ music for evening performances. Other pieces from the 1920s, such as the overture Heifetz and the oboe Concerto, were written before the increasing interest in musical theatre, and are clearly dedicated to the budding ballet traditions of Austria.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Herbert Edgar Jordan =  
Herbert Edgar Jordan ( March 17, 1923 – December 23, 2004 ) was an American pastor, writer, and anthropologist. He was also the President of Emmanuel AME, a Congregational church in Houston.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Jordan was born in Lincoln, Nebraska. His father, a military commander, supported him throughout his youth.Jordan graduated from high school at a time when the politics and culture of the time shaped many young American men. The Vietnam War put an end to that formative experience and the racial tensions that it generated took priority over college. Jordan completed his undergraduate degree at University of Nebraska–Lincoln ( U. of L. ) in 1954, which he obtained with a B.A. degree in political science.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 Jordan spent most of his professional life in the field of theology, arguing for biblical continuity, the emphasis of spiritual and historical theology on relational theology, and the family as a location of potential change, especially for marginalized and disenfranchised groups. He served as head of the Department of Religions, at the North Texas Community Church, as well as a pastor in a number of other Congregational churches. While at Emmanuel AME, Jordan chaired the book clubs and the mission committee for the church's 11th Harvest Moon's Conference in 1980, resulting in groups being created that invited readers to create their own kinds of homilies. These workshops were later published as `` Spiritual Philanthropy : Church Taxation and Contribution to Race, Sexuality, and Class Struggle ''.The most significant venture for which Jordan was known was the Rev. Michael Palmer-Jones's Challenge to Christology, which challenged traditional models of what can be and what can not be within scripture. For Jordan, Challenging Christology is a work of Christian witness, to reconcile his theological position with his experience as an African-American educator. As such, it can provide an introduction to and process for the emerging social theology of reconciliation and intercultural action.  
 Jordan served as the first African-American president of the World Council of Churches in the 1950s. He was a major figure in the African-American civil rights movement and served as a state representative. In addition, Jordan was a central figure in the failure to construct the Weather Underground and the Bay of Pigs invasion of Cuba during the Cuban Missile Crisis. He was a founder of the Black Christian Leadership Council, and is known for his song, `` Write Your Whole Life '', and his evangelical study group formation programs.  
 In the 1990s Jordan published on his experiences in Memphis, Tennessee, at that city's Coleman Academy. In that study group, he emerged with a set of ideas for some of the church community's challenges and better conditions for ministry among a number of ethnic minorities in South Memphis. Over the next decade, Jordan wrote several books on the ways in which churches can change behavior and change programs in ways that impact the problems facing African-American communities. One such program is the Community Action Research Center ( CAMC ) in Marda, Mississippi, which Jordan helped found in 2002. This center brings together ministries, faith communities, civil rights organizations and black leaders in Memphis to analyze and synthesize information and action.  
 Jordan died of lung cancer in 2003 at the age of 79.  
   
   
 == Honors and awards ==  
 Jordan received an Outstanding Teaching Award from South Central Methodist University ( 1979 ).  
 Jordan was honored by the Leadership Conference of Women Religious ( LCWR ) as the `` father of African-American church leadership ''.  
 Jordan was elected a Foreign Honorary Member of the World Council of Churches ( WCC ) in 1995.  
 Jordan was named a recipient of the American Council on Church & State's `` Leadership in Community Service '' award.  
 Jordan was named the 14th and most senior African-American recipient of the ACOG Award for distinguished service by African Americans in Christian service, sponsored by the West-South Asia Center.  
   
   
 == Death ==  
 Jordan was identified as 'one of the leading church leaders of the last 20 years,'noted ABCNEWS.com.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Johannes Schmidt =  
Johannes Schmidt ( 8 November 1652 – 20 July 1722 ) was a German geographer, cartographer and map maker.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 He studied theology at Munich and was ordained as a pastor. The eminent scholar Heinrich Weiss ( 1631–1682 ) followed his decision and, on 10 April 1688, was called to the bar of the Archduke of Hesse. It was immediately to his credit that he was entrusted with the task of drawing the map of Hesse on a larger scale than that which had been previously undertaken. Thereafter he worked on such works as a co-writer with Johannes Cosmas Pötter, and on the manuscript of Proklar of Franconia and Deuget, as well as on other maps. He was a member of the Societas guild for eight years and by his conduct won public favour. In 1695, at the age of seventy-six, he published : Johan Schmidt Bücher, in profesor ( His old age ) ( 1702 ), an essay on the politics of his native Saxony.  
 Schmidt had inherited wealth in the cities of Stettin, Novgorod, and St. Petersburg. He succeeded Hans Wenzel as rector of Innsbruck in 1717. As a geographer he contributed to the commentary on the Codex Brit. Libr. 1685, the geographical description of the Saxon kingdom. He contributed to the German Catalogue, published in 1718, the Historia Morbicala IX., pp. 295–297 ; and the Goethes-Gymnasium Dresden-Johanne Schmidt, with Maps of New Saxon Grammar, of Antiquities in Use in that Kingdom ( 1722 ), etc. Besides the small selection of his writings on politics, he wrote many articles in the Zentralblatt der Meddelelser, and contributed significantly to the Berliner Geographik.  
 Schmidt is known for his much-publicised and prolific translation of the Swedish Grammar, especially of the first part. A few pages of his dissertation appeared as an appendix in the Cambridge grammar, and subsequent work. This has caused great confusion, as it was widely read in libraries.  
 His other best-known work, his history of Stettin, published under the title Schechter der reichenstelle Innsbruck, appeared in 1726 ; it covered almost all the counties in that province, and the journeys which the crew made there during 1704–1705, the voyage of the principal vessel for that voyage being captured and burned by the imperial troops. His other important work, based on the fact of the original inhabitants in Aryan languages being Scandinavians, was recently added to the history of the island and by appointment of the King of Sweden as a botanist and hermit of his great nephew, King Wilhelm II of Prussia, whose royal collection had been placed in Danzig ; the history is in the possession of a Saxon widow of that name.  
 His map collection is in the London museum, and was in good state until the long illness of his only son, Johannes Schmidt, which necessitated his death on 20 July 1722.  
   
   
 == Selected publications ==  
 Historia Morbicala, IX. 1685  
 Theologia Morbicala IV. 1722  
 Einleitungsgeographik der Verersteinschaft, II. 1722  
 Redesportes zur Gedanken Europas von Stettin, in duhn und seine in Aüngeleben ( Zentralblatt der Meddelelser, Jena, 1726 )  
 Dr. Schmidt and the lake name 'Camborne ', in: J. Schmidt, Herr von Oestenberg's Reminiscences, Mittheilungen, by Christoph von Hugo von Kristoffer Chr. Christoph Frederick Peter von Lindert, Bd. 2, Bd. 20, Bern : Verlag Friedrich Eschenbücher, 1745.  
 Dialogus Erscheinungen : Für über die Schmidtgeographie ( Gesellschaft 3. Stettin, 1730 )  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Thomas John Blair =  
Thomas John Blair ( 14 January 1916 – 8 May 1994 ) was an English jazz saxophonist and composer.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Blair was born on 14 January 1916, in West Lancashire. His father, James Blair, was a clergyman and the concert pianist at Middle Temple. His mother, Beatrice Stewart, was a major singer.  
 He was tutored at the Leeds School of Music. After teaching privately for many years, he went on to work as a saxophonist with the Liverpool Philharmonic in 1920 and also as a jazz soloist with the London Symphony Orchestra between 1923 and 1929. After working with Max Williamson and his orchestra, he began to work with jazz bands like the London Soul Players ( 1935–1947 ), the Salt Zippers ( 1950 ) and the Jeeps and the Gris Dads ( 1949–1951 ).  
 He was awarded a Music Educator's Unit Award by the Worshipful Company of St George, London, in 1971 and was appointed Composer of the Year of the Black Puritan National Union. In the same year, he received a Royal Honours BAFTA from the Association for the Advancement of Music, for his composing work for a jazz orchestra.He died on 8 May 1994 in Leeds.  
 He recorded as a soloist with the Memphis Philharmonic Orchestra.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 Bach. An Orchestration of the Promethium, Op. 68, Op. 69 - 1953  
 Hammond organ - Harmonies for a London Chamber Orchestra, No. 4 `` Enid for piano and string orchestra '' - 1963  
 Pendulum Sonata  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Frederick Richard John Boer =  
Frederick Richard John Boer ( August 17, 1916 – March 15, 1996 ) was an American computer scientist. He was professor emeritus of Artificial Intelligence at Cornell University.  
 He received both the Turing Award and the NASA Fellowship in 1949, the first post in the U.S. Air Force, and the Wright Prize in 1956. He was awarded the NASA Research Volunteer Award in 1956 and the Honorary Doctor of Science degree by the University of Wisconsin in 1963.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Boer was born in Clinton, Wisconsin, the youngest of eight children of Bill Boer, a farmhand, and Dorothy Whipple ( Sloane ) Boer. His paternal grandfather was a physician and naturalist. He was educated at Perkins School of Mines and Mathematics in Chicago, graduated from the University of Wisconsin–Madison in 1932, and then joined the U.S. Air Force in the years 1940 and 1941.The time he spent flying in the Army Air Corps during World War II had a significant effect on his views on science and technology.Boer began to research machines at Cornell in 1942, studying OSA, which is a universal language programming language that can be used to code sequences of instructions into machines. In 1946, he received his Ph.D. degree in mathematical analysis under Alvaro Segrè. He taught there from 1946 to 1965, and served as a visiting professor from 1964 to 1975.In 1959, he received an honorary doctorate by Cornell. In 1962, Boer was awarded an honorary doctorate of science degree by Iowa State University. He retired from Cornell in 1975. Boer died at his home in Galesburg, Iowa, from a heart attack in 1996.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 Boer, Frederick R. ; Fieldhouse, Nathan F. ( 1956 ). `` Another Block of Logic ''. The Quarterly Journal of Mathematics. I. 139–160. doi:10.2307/2175211. JSTOR 2175211.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Jean de Rosy =  
Jean de Rosy ( 25 July 1832 – 10 December 1886 ) was a French rabbi, philosopher, and rationalist theologian.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Rosy was born in Les Barbaresques, on the Mediterranean coast, to a Reformed Congregationalist family. He went to Strasbourg to study at the Conservatoire de Paris, where he continued in a seminary before coming to Paris. In 1852 he was ordained and took his theological vows in this episcopal region. In the year following his ordination he became a professor of Hebrew at the Universelle. In 1850 he began a correspondence with Thomas Hobbes, and soon they both sent their ideas on religion to each other. Rosy's study of Hobbes has been called `` one of the most interesting and successful in the history of French thought '' ( see Hobbes's philosophy ). Upon becoming one of the founding members of the International Union of Religions ( 1857–1868 ), he published `` The Sciences and Methods of Religion '' ( 1865 ), the first of his many publications of philosophical value. From 1869 he served as president of the Paris Oriental and Ethnological Society, and in 1871 he was elected President of the Société Orientaliste de l'Exposition du DCM.  
 In the course of his life he attended the Universal Exposition of Paris. In 1885, at the age of seventy-two, he died in Paris. He left his library to the College of Paris, with the exception of three volumes of his mathematics and chemistry and a variety of other writings, two of which were lost in an earthquake. Rosy was buried on Cemetery de la Maisonneuve in Paris.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 Besides the following works in English :  
   
 De Societatis Philosophiae, 1844  
 De sorware oder Bonorum Lectorum, 1847  
 Die Leben der Gnellin, 1852  
 Philosophie und das fürster Rache ( Text and proofs of Scholastic philosophy and the doctrine of regeneration ), 1857  
 Ph.D. Thesis, Librairie Lettre, Paris, 1870  
 Ph.D. ( 1868 ), The Religion of Thomas Hobbes ( in English ), with an enlarged commentary. English translation by C. L. Newcombe and A. C. Rosely. London : George Allen & Unwin.  
 The Elementary Laws of Religion, 1881  
 Philosophie der Schöne der Jahrhunderten, 1886  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Gustav Grinshauer =  
Gustav Grinshauer ( 27 December 1834 – 17 June 1918 ) was a Swiss botanist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Grinshauer graduated from the University of Geneva and took his doctorate at the University of Königsberg, in 1866.  
 In 1880, he was appointed botanist at the institute at Dessau and became full professor there in 1882. He was an expert on the genus Sophora. From the same institute he introduced into the Alps the species of the family Callatae in 1880 and Phoebeia in 1883.  
 He died at Zurich in 1918.  
   
   
 == Awards and honors ==  
 Giesen-Zimmer Pflanzen ( 1894 ), Order of the White Eagle.  
   
   
 == Publications ==  
 Atlas der europäischen Kunst-Lexikon. Leipzig : Ferdinand Joachim  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = George Howard Ussher =  
George Howard Ussher ( 7 October 1868 – 22 October 1957 ) was an American physician. He was born in Milwaukee, Wisconsin. Ussher graduated from medical school at age 19 in 1888. He became a staff physician at Mount Sinai Hospital in 1900 and was elected a fellow of the American Medical Association in 1912. Ussher was also a fellow of the American College of Physicians and a member of the American Philosophical Society.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 Ussher began his medical career at the University of Wisconsin in 1901, where he earned his medical degree in 1906. His academic specialty was general surgery. He also served as an associate professor at the University of Chicago from 1906 to 1908. Ussher was a surgeon at Mount Sinai from 1902 to 1908, and was involved in the pulmonary disease settlement in 1908. Ussher became an associate professor of surgery at Johns Hopkins University in 1908.  
 In 1910, he moved to the University of Wisconsin–Madison. He became assistant professor of general surgery in 1921, and dean of surgery in 1922. He became associate professor of general surgery in 1925. Ussher became associate director of hospital operations at the Mayo Clinic in Chicago in 1924. He was president of the American Society of General Surgeons in 1925.  
 He published his best-known article, The Outward Physiology of the Heart, which described the anatomy and function of the heart and became an influential text in medicine. Ussher and Newell Callendar are known as the `` fathers '' of physiology in medicine, as he first started to analyze the contents of the heart. Ussher derived his theories from his father's advice. He also made important contributions to the field of integrative medicine. In his book The Heart, he proposed that the inner functions of the heart, especially those involving the sympathetic and the parasympathetic systems, govern the gastrointestinal and pulmonary processes. Ussher also gave extensive attention to the role of blood flow in kidney function.  
   
   
 == Family ==  
 Ussher married Frances Lee Shipley in 1887, and their son Dr. George Howard Ussher Jr. was born in 1923.  
   
   
 == Death ==  
 Ussher died of heart failure on 22 October 1957 in Roselawn, Illinois. He was 73 years old.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio>
