<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = David Baumgartner =  
David Joseph Baumgartner ( Hebrew : היה אורן נחרי‎, November 15, 1905 – September 17, 1992 ) was an American biochemist.  
   
   
 == Early life ==  
 David Baumgartner was born in Davenport, Iowa. His mother, Francine Baumgartner, was a homemaker and assisted her husband, a business manager, in running a textile firm. In 1936 he received his A.B. degree in chemistry from Cornell University, and his Ph.D. in biochemistry from New York University under the supervision of Heikki Olesen. Baumgartner, also a research associate in Max Neuberg's laboratory at Cornell, was also an investigator at Yale University under Max Neuberg. He worked on the synthesis and analysis of benzene and natural products.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 In 1950 Baumgartner was named chair of the Department of Biochemistry at Yale. He held this position until 1970 when he was promoted to associate professor, and then full professor in 1973. As an associate professor at Yale, he collaborated with graduate students M. Esslemont-Roch, Paul Klinebauer, and Lawrence Scott Miller. In 1976 he moved to New York to become associate professor at Rockefeller University. In 1978 he was made an emeritus professor.  
   
   
 == Honors ==  
 David Baumgartner was made an Officer of the American Chemical Society in 1969, and a Rockefeller Foundation Distinguished Scholar in 1976. He received numerous honorary degrees and honors from institutions such as Harvard University, Drexel University, the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, and Yale University.  
   
   
 == Personal life ==  
 Baumgartner married Katharine A. Wertheimer on May 24, 1946. They had four children : Mary Barbara, Richard, Daniel, and Miriam. Baumgartner's second wife died in 1958, and he remarried in 1969 to Allison Smyth.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Martin Koch =  
Martin Koch ( 17 August 1844 – 18 May 1909 ) was a German chemist and naturalist.Koch was born at Muldeberg on 17 August 1844. He studied medicine at the university of Munich. In 1879 he was employed as physician at the spa, located at the old northern part of Rostock, on the slopes of the western end of the Huldorf Mountains. In 1886, at the initiative of Ernst Wilhelm Schiller, Koch embarked on a geological expedition to the Silesia, as part of the École polytechnique series. The Oteyrds–Koch ( Ostere — for the West — and East—Großes Oteyrds— ) expedition lasted three years from 1886 to 1890. It comprised the exploration of the coal field of the northern region of Duchy of Silesia, the mineral olivine, the first `` extreme drift '' to be recorded, and then the discovered coal deposits of the Silesian coal belt and the Upper Rhine basin. The explorations were supported by the Russian Royal Treasury ; Koch made extensive collections and that country's libraries are preserved.  
 Koch was made Professor of Botany and Mineralogy at the University of Munich in 1895 and 1911. In 1905 he was awarded the Patronage of the German Academy of Sciences.  
 He published the catalogue species de tardigrade and plexotrichum in two parts and a catalogue of genera Deuterocoratia. His papers were published in the Jahrbuch für Pflanzengeschichte 1884-1900 edited by J. A. Schröder, with the help of the aid of the St. Petersberg society and with the assistance of his grandson Martin Koch.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Ivan Meldahar =  
Ivan Michaelovich Meldahar ( Russian : Андре́й Песович Ве́доров ; January 16, 1903, Moscow – January 10, 1981, Moscow ) was a Soviet ophthalmologist. He was appointed a member of the Academy of Sciences of the USSR in 1962. He was a prominent Russian neurophysiologist.  
   
   
 == Early life ==  
 Meldahar was born on December 16, 1903 in Moscow. His parents were Vasilij Meldahar, a physician, and Nikita Vasilievna Orlovna ( née Iohlen ), a teacher. He attended a local gymnasium before the Second World War. In 1946 he graduated from the Moscow State University with a diploma in Law.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 During World War II, he served as a physician for the People's Armed Forces.  
 In 1949 he was appointed the second physician of the Medical Commission of the Imperial Russian Navy, serving under General Sergii Preobrazhensky. In 1950 he was elected to a national assembly. In 1952 he became the first professor of the Department of Ophthalmology, Moscow State University, in 1957 to become a doctorate. He was also the first dean of the Faculty of Medicine of Moscow State University, where he worked for over thirty years.  
 In 1963 he became an honorary member of the Academy of Sciences of the USSR. He received an honorary doctorate in 1973. He is buried in the town of Semyonovka, Pskov Oblast, Russia.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Paul Runnemann =  
Paul Rünemann ( 18 August 1893 – 30 November 1963 ) was an Austrian psychologist and an expert in mysticism.  
   
   
 == Early life ==  
 Paul Rünemann was born in Landshut, but grew up in Vienna, and then in Berlin and Leipzig. After a high school education at the Reichenberg Gymnasium, he joined the University of Vienna. In 1919 he entered the rectorship of the St. Thomas More Abbey and was ordained in the name of St. Thomas himself. After this he worked as a teacher in the Reichenberg Rhenish Conservatory. In 1922 he moved to London, where he was hired by the London Society of Science and Art. After leaving the British Society for Psychical Research he worked as an editor of the Journal of Mind and Nervous Attraction. In 1929 he was named the Institute Professor of Psychology and Scientism at the University of Leipzig.  
   
   
 == Professional life ==  
 Rünemann spent many years as a teacher, journalist, and tutor in Vienna. He joined the editorial staff of the journal Optik und Psychik and is best known for his studies of the effect of the influence of extreme social pressure on the mind. In 1926 he published The Pure Mind : The Creative Eye of Heaven. This book was written from an extreme theoretical point of view. He advocated a mystical/empirical spirit as a distinctive faculty in the human mind. He believed the mental creations, and the consciousness or cosmic manifestation of the world, could be understood in terms of the unconscious mind, the esoteric emanations of the human soul, and the purely materialistic experience of the work of the spirit. Rünemann was a friend of Wilhelm Reich and wrote his story of Wilhelm Reich from Rünemann's point of view, which was used by Reich in his theosophical experiments and which resulted in Reich's death from a suicide attempt in 1936. In his essays in Psychology and Psychical Research he maintained that the major problem with current psychology was that it was not concerned enough with the cognitive element. This was felt to be out of step with the mystical aspects of nature, thus leading to a degradation of mysticism and pseudogamy. Rünemann strongly held that religious activity must be done according to the mystical rites of the times, and strongly opposed any attempt to substitute psychological science with that of material science.  
   
   
 == Select works ==  
 Otto-Georg Savolli, Giornale occulto e per i vero, Mondadori, 1922  
 Achim Neuheit und ein Schwaben, Memoirs in Cult and Religion, 1932  
 Mystisch-psychologischen Untersuchungen, 1932  
 Religion und Zeit, 1929  
 Raumschwundiger, Feuerinnstimmenkünf. eine physiologie und hystellologie, 1933  
 Weber und Stuttgart, 1936  
 Apotheker, Orbe und erwennungen in Vorträge bei Eigenschaft als historisch-scholzlers  
 Aufklärung des Ordnungsgruppen, und ihre psychologie, 1935  
 Oecumenismus und evangelischen Theologie, 1939  
 Einführung, Untersuchungen, ander einige lehrte eigenschaftlicher Zeit, 1950  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = David R. Ricks =  
David Ricks ( 26 February 1936 – 14 August 2004 ) was an American particle physicist and atmospheric chemist who created such famous works as `` Radioisotopes and Proton Detection '', `` Elementary Physics '', `` Low Temperature Physics '', `` The Energies of High-Energy Physics '', and `` Superconductivity. ''  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Born in Saginaw, Michigan, David Ricks had four siblings, and attended Iowa State University.  
 In 1967, Ricks and his family moved to California. He obtained his BS in Physics in 1969 from the University of California, Berkeley, and completed a PhD in physics from the University of Minnesota.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 In 1973, he became a doctoral student at the University of Minnesota in Minnesota.  
 Ricks was a Fellow of the American Physical Society ( APS ) from 1974 to 1980. He also served as President of the APS from 1981 to 1984.  
 Ricks was appointed to the  
 post of Editor of the Physical Review.  
 The Radiometric Energy Level and the Cosmic Microwave Background were named after him.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = John Yew =  
John Yew ( May 13, 1871 – April 8, 1933 ) was a New Zealand diplomat, economist, politician and philanthropist, as well as a pioneering campaigner for early childhood education.  
   
   
 == Early life ==  
 John Yew was born in the parish of Lygon in Worcestershire in England to Robert Yew, a Scottish soldier and Mary Louise Green, and was educated at the Royal Charter School in Edinburgh. He graduated in 1891 with a BSc and first class honours degree in economics from Cambridge.  
   
   
 == Diplomatic career ==  
 Yew became Secretary of State for Finance from 1901 until 1924.  
 From 1924 to 1934, he served as MP for Plymouth, Plymouth and Devonport, and for Hull and Malling ( wasldld ) from 1934 to 1935. He later served as Treasury Minister.  
   
   
 === Politics and social welfare ===  
   
   
 === Strategy in education ===  
 Yew wanted to address the fundamental problems facing England by promoting early childhood education. He opposed the and social guidance – the teachers did not have a clue what was going on in their classrooms, but came to the lessons wanting to make the students understand things. In the 1920s, Yew introduced national early childhood education guidelines and pupils were encouraged to study the ancient languages of Greece, Latin, Chinese, Latin, Syriac, Egyptian and Syriac, and to read Latin, Greek, Arabic, Hebrew and Hebrew poetry.  
 Yew introduced national education plans in different parts of the country, initially in London and later in Plymouth, Plymouth and Devonport. Yew supported the local government action which guaranteed funding for public schools and set an example for districts by mandating that every child had access to breakfast, lunch and three hours of gymnasium every day. The government also abolished the forced serving of food on Fridays and Christmas Eve in the majority of schools.  
 Through his influence, Plymouth District School Board and the city of Plymouth United spent considerable sums on resources for the early childhood and high school systems.  
   
   
 === Small change ===  
 Yew was also concerned about the impact of the first world war on the country's war industries. From 1931 to 1939 he was involved in research into fighting in Greece. During his time in Malta he worked to combat the Japanese menace. He was worried that money spent on the war could only be used in the next war. As a result he offered personal funds to buy the Macedonian Iron Company's Ironhead.  
   
   
 === Postwar ===  
 Yew was now involved in other concerns, including providing financial support for survivors of war and a contribution to the reconstruction of civilian housing, especially at a time when many casualties had resulted from bombing and sabotage, when few families had a home.  
   
   
 == Personal life and death ==  
 John Yew married Augusta Golightly in 1901, and moved with her to Whitehaven in Cornwall. They had two sons and a daughter. John Yew died in 1933. He is buried in Sutton Coldfield Cemetery, Plymouth.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Arthur Samuel Hutton =  
Arthur Samuel Hutton ( 9 October 1867 – 21 June 1933 ) was a Tasmanian zoologist and botanist. He was born in Ross Tasman, Tasmania. He went to school in Coffs Harbour where he studied at the Botany Department until 1880. He worked for three years in the Botany Department of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Melbourne and Melbourne University. In 1880 he moved to the city of Bondi and became assistant to the keeper of the city zoo at Bondi. He made his first scientific discovery in 1888, on a dried foot of mole snake, `` Grundlandi pisum '' or bed-nose leopard snake. In 1893 he came across the Antarctic fish, Diverticula rivasionis, when digging the petroleum fired lighthouse at Murchison Point, in the station at Bondi, to collect fossils for the Zoological Society of London. After 1892, he worked as the zoologist of the Kingsbury Zoo. In 1895, he published The Worm Nest of a King Neptune and Tropical Albatross, in which he described about 200 species.  
   
 Hutton described several species of rhea, their eggs ( the larvae ) and fetuses, and also a genus he described as `` West tropheria '' or Starfish. Hutton also collected plants. He described the fungal genus Hadruplozone and the pollen genus Mausomia, which is a collection of African and Asian plant species including saplings, berries, seeds, snails, pear trees, succulents, dried seaweeds and cardboard packets.He and his wife, Emily Redson, moved to Ross Tasman in 1889 when they came into conflict with the adjoining Woolworths'store as the local traders demanded cattle and harddrink supplies. After returning to Melbourne in 1891, he worked with Henry Moore, a Tasmanian pioneer entomologist. The couple lived in Hamilton until they died in Berlin in 1931.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 Tasmania Park ( 1897 )  
 Man from Air : the Colourless Field Book of the Taxonomic and Physiological Hints ( 1908 )  
 Other Fish, Butterflies and Plants ( 1919 )  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Charles Montgomery Cresson =  
Charles Montgomery Cresson ( February 3, 1907 – October 18, 1980 ) was an American physicist. He was born in Cincinnati.  
 Cresson served on the editorial board of The Economist from 1941 to 1966.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Otto Heckel =  
Otto Heckel ( 23 June 1782, Richtig – 13 May 1843, Braunschweig ) was a Baltic German naval officer and author of several historical, geographical, scientific and historical-mathematical works.  
 He is most known as a geographer and map-editor, who later became Principal Geographer at the Baltic State Historical Museum, which he directed from 1803 until his death.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Heckel studied as a student in Cologne and settled in Gotland, where he studied archaeology and geography under Hans Christian Kuzma ( 1749–1829 ) and Alexander Warkentin ( 1751–1839 ).  
 After spending a year in Bamberg, Heckel returned to Germany and studied further in Leipzig and Berlin under Julius Schmid ( 1739–1801 ), Friedrich Tchaikovsky ( 1743–1807 ), and Carl Eduard Elster ( 1754–1826 ).  
   
   
 == Military career ==  
 After an engagement in the Silesia War of 1812, Heckel was awarded the rank of lance corporal ( equivalent to captain ) by the Prussian army.  
   
   
 == Researches and publications ==  
 Heckel contributed to all the major historical and geographical works of the 19th century, including :  
   
 Geography of Eastern Europe  
 Geography of Duchy Russia  
 Geography of Poland, Lithuania, Estonia, Latvia, Estonia-Lithuania, Latvia-Pomerania  
 Geburtstag des Wehrmacht von Freiberg  
 Geburtstag des Duchy Volhynia  
 Atlas aus der Deutschen Theologie  
 Atlas aus dem Deutsche Tageblatt  
 Buchsätz. Sammlung 1810 [ 1 ] ( 7 ), 91–120.  
   
   
 == Honours ==  
 Heckel was a member of the Berlinische Staatssammlung, the Royal Historical Society of Freiburg and Düsseldorf, the Royal Danish Academy of Sciences, and the Herbarium in Berlin.  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = William Binney Carpenter =  
William Binney Carpenter ( June 17, 1921 – August 28, 2006 ) was an American educator and scientist known for his work with selenium, as well as for his work with the plants he chose to study.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
   
   
 === Early life ===  
 Carpenter's father, Albert Carpenter, was born in Keokuk, Iowa, and grew up in Clinton, Iowa. After graduating from Iowa State University in 1950, he received his doctorate from Columbia University in 1952.Carpenter spent the next fifteen years working for several US companies including Boeing, Rolls Royce, General Motors, Standard Oil, and Peabody Coal.Carpenter was a member of Phi Beta Kappa, the Alpha Phi Alpha fraternity, and Trinity Evangelical Divinity School. He was married to Joyce Marie Brown Carpenter, who became a teacher in 1970. They had three sons. He was survived by his son, William, and his two daughters and five grandchildren.  
   
   
 === University of California, Berkeley ===  
 Upon graduating in 1970, Carpenter moved to Berkeley and began a seven-year involvement as a scholar of the selenium on the Berkeley-Berkeley Seepage Group. He retired from his faculty position at California, after 37 years of teaching there. Carpenter was a charter member of the Sigma Xi in 1982.In 2002, his daughter Joyce died of cancer, and an infant son was born on August 28, 2006, just a few months before his death.  
   
   
 === Massachusetts Institute of Technology ===  
 Carpenter moved to MIT in 1996. In the summer of 2001, he resigned his post as a professor of public administration and economics, and worked for the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Center for Sea Energy.In 2005, Carpenter retired and moved to Sierra Leone with his daughter to work on issues affecting the country's water supply. While in Sierra Leone, Carpenter also conducted work on selenium which ultimately led to his joining the Seabees'Club of America in 2007, and this has since become a national organization for selenium researchers.  
   
   
 == Selected publications ==  
 Carpenter, William Binney, ed. ( 2000 ). The plants that delighted him. New York : New York University Press. ISBN 978-0-231-94404-0.  
 Carpenter, W. Binney, ed. ( 1997 ). A philosophical introduction to selenium, Presses Universitaires de Montpellier. ISBN 978-0059116681.  
 Carpenter, W. Binney, ed. ( 1996 ). A history of selenium, Presses Universitaires de Montpellier. ISBN 978-0-231-94395-8.  
 Carpenter, W. Binney, ed. ( 1994 ). St. Augustine's Seagrasses. New York : New York University Press. ISBN 978-0059113613.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = John Ruskin =  
John Ruskin, ( 21 June 1801 – 19 January 1873 ) was a Scottish anatomist and ichthyologist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Ruskin was born at Glencoe, Bloomsbury, Scotland, the son of Robert Ruskin, 1st Baronet, and Abigail Bloch, daughter of William Bloch, 3rd Baronet. In 1820 he was apprenticed to a London physician by his uncle, John Ruskin. He left the physician's office on leaving the family physician, Sir Edward Ruge.  
 He trained at Drury Lane School in London and at the Royal College of Surgeons, and was admitted to the degree of M.D. in 1825. He joined the Society for Promoting Hygiene ( SPR ) at Eton, London, where he was engaged as a lecturer on dissections, on 24 April 1835, and was immediately promoted to assistant practising general practitioner on 28 August 1835. In 1837 he became lecturer in anatomy, and in 1841 the president. He held the position until his death.  
   
 He was the author of an important work on the structure of the vertebrae, the third volume of which was first published in London in 1852. In 1858 he issued a large edition of his works under the title, The Anatomy of the Great Pyramid ( No. I, London, 1861 ).In 1861 he published a short biography of himself ; he subsequently entered a secret correspondence with the Lubbock Observer, in which he confessed that he had performed the testinal tear at Cairo in 1859 and identified the cause of the deformity and called his ‘ Revelation on the Wizard ’ on the preceding day.He died at Staplebridge, in central London.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Burdjevsky =  
Burdjevsky ( Russian : Седрий Рологич Хделевич ; 12 January 1874 in Suzdal – 29 November 1935 in Moscow ) was a Russian pianist and composer.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Burdjevsky studied composition under Vasily Brusilov, music theory under Nikolai Pushkin, piano under János Kempe and piano with the famous Austrian pianist Franz Liszt, and worked as an organist in the Gazeta l'Opéra.He was the brother of the composer Oleg Burdjevsky, whose works include the piano sonata Sinfonia in B minor, and the film `` From the Moor ''.  
   
   
 == Selected Works ==  
 Beethoven  
 Sonata ( 2 Op. 76 ) ( 1861 )  
 Scherzo ( 1890 )  
 Griechische Recitalen über drei Nachtmusik ( 1892 )  
 Vorlesungen über Sonatina ( 1893 )  
 La Broglie und Leipzig Overture ( 1893 )  
 Russian Song Cycle  
 Notes from Siberia, 1870  
 Ring cycle  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Rochambeau Drummond =  
Rochambeau Drummond ( May 12, 1862 – July 10, 1934 ) was an American botanist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Drummond was born in Bristol, Connecticut and studied in South Africa at Uppsala University, and then in Philadelphia. He traveled extensively throughout Europe, and studied botany from a colonial perspective, sharing his travels with a museum in Hamburg.  
 In 1862 he married Gertrude Elmer Missad, daughter of Paulian Secor Missad, a Presbyterian minister in Philadelphia, and Charlotte Briggress. Drummond served as president of the Field Naturalists Club of Philadelphia from 1877 to 1879. He also served as editor of the Annals of Botany from 1879 to 1882.  
 Drummond was one of the founders of American botanists. He was named President of the Botanical Society of America in 1876, and also served as President of the United States Commission on Flora of the Philippines.  
 In 1882 Drummond married Augusta Thornhill Stahl, sister of Richard Stahl, publisher of the Austin Courier. Drummond died in Cincinnati, Ohio.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Edward Groferer =  
Edward Wood Groferer ( July 28, 1910 – August 18, 2001 ) was an American cellist and composer.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Born in West Bloomfield, Massachusetts, he studied at the Juilliard School and the Conservatory of Music in New York City, where he was taught by Milt Jackson. After leaving Juilliard in 1934, Groferer began to play professionally in major concert halls and chamber orchestras, under the direction of Milt Jackson, where he performed as a soloist in the soloist sections of the New York Philharmonic, Boston Symphony and New York Philharmonic. In addition to his solo work, Groferer also composed several chamber works for cello and piano. Among these were `` Under the Narrow Spring '' and `` Opening to Summer '', the latter for the violoncello.  
   
   
 == Recordings ==  
 Groferer is noted for a wide repertoire of recordings including works for cello, viola, horn and strings. The vast majority of his major works include solo cello works. The following is a selection of his recordings, listing as many of his works as possible :  
   
 Albums  
   
 Violin Concerto for Viola and Piano  
 Polonaise for Viola and Piano ( Collection # 2356 )  
 White Capriccio for Viola and Piano  
 Hymn to The Echoey Man for Cello and Viola ( Collection # 3102 )  
   
   
 == Trivia ==  
 Groferer was the nephew of composer R. L. Groferer.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Frederic van der Zuyten =  
Frederic van der Zuyten ( Dutch : [ ʀɑ̃tɑ̃dɐ ] ; 1831–1892 ) was a Dutch economist who is noted for introducing in 1850 the label Krampf keframofricus ( `` Keframorefo service '' ). The Krampf was the prototype of the `` hut hut '', a modern-day property in the Dutch housing market. The Krampf was in turn one of the two or three highest rated Dutch housing markets in the early 19th century. It is also noted as one of the main obstacles in achieving urban planning.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 van der Zuyten was born in Liège. Although he had considerable technical and personal experience in literature and education, in the long run, he did not stick to his profession for long, instead joining a private firm and becoming a partner of a landowner in Dijon, in the south of the country. After the fall of the Iron Crown, he moved to Brussels, where he resided for the rest of his life and was eventually one of the important persons who helped to break the wall between Brussels and the countryside. During that period he organized several hundred agricultural guilds in Belgium. In 1862 he died and was buried in the Dutch town of Leuven.  
   
   
 == Bibliography ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Udo Perl =  
Udo Perl ( 10 December 1875, Kiel – 24 September 1951, Frankfurt am Main ) was a German physicist and inventor. He made important contributions in the field of electrical engineering, optics, and magnetism. His invention of the valve valve, which eliminated the need for valves and other complicated mechanical operations in electricity production, led to the industrial application of mechanical valve operating systems.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Perl's mother died when he was three years old, after which his father returned to Germany and was sent to study at the University of Kiel. He studied engineering at the newly created Technische Hochschule in Hamburg, during which he designed an early motor vehicle, and then for the remainder of his academic career studied mechanical engineering at the University of Heidelberg. He returned to Kiel in 1911 to study engineering. After gaining his Ph.D. in 1920, he worked at the Deutsche Physikalische Gesellschaft ( DPG ) in Berlin, becoming a Privatdozent in 1926. There he was part of an electronic experiment-group, where he formulated the principle of the perihelion flow ( which he independently demonstrated in 1916 ), which allowed the dynamic regulation of transformers to be used for control. From 1928 to 1932, Perl was also professor of mechanical engineering and electrical engineering at Kiel.  
 In 1925 Perl received his Ph.D. from Kiel, but was kept from it by prohibition legislation in Germany. Instead, he was placed in a Theresienstadt internment camp, for eight months during which he worked on digital circuits for Siemens in Leipzig. In 1928 he went to work at the Deutsche Physikalische Gesellschaft ( DPG ) in Berlin as a Privatdozent, and remained there until 1949. There he was involved in research into transmission electron microscopes, infrared detection and control systems, and radar.  
   
   
 == Work in Germany ==  
 On 27 March 1939, at the opening of the Second World War, Perl was drafted into the Allied Armed Forces. He was interned in Sachsenhausen, Germany. On 8 May, the Nazis arrested him and stripped him of all his possessions, including his car, and sent him to a camp in Ravensbrück, where he remained for three months before being sent to the Nazi concentration camp of Jömno for six months. After being liberated by the Soviets on 5 June 1941, he then transferred to the Rhine-Eisenach Military Hospital where he was interned until the end of World War II.  
 Perl's nuclear research career took off from there. In the late 1950s he developed an early apparatus for magnetically levitating a tablet using spark flux, using an aluminium stick to force the structure to bend, the same kind of technique that had been used in experimenting with magnetism in diamonds.Later work on magnetrons started in Germany, by Wilhelm Hsieh. Perl played a key role in applying magnetrons to ferroelectric circuitry, but with a very small yield. Perl proposed a method that used large, silent, and static sparks to generate complex magnetic fields, such as magnetic fields around a solid source. He demonstrated this at a theoretical level in 1958 in the paper `` A prototype magnetic superhydrophobe '', which he presented at the European Physical Society meeting in Leipzig. He also worked on using magnetic fields to generate light with superconductors.  
   
   
 == Later life and legacy ==  
 Perl died on 24 September 1951, at the age of 75, in Frankfurt am Main.  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Jack Cuthbert =  
Jack Cuthbert FRS ( 1887–1968 ) was an English marine biologist.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Cuthbert was born on 7 July 1887 at Madavera in Scotland, the son of an industrialist, John and Louise Mardell Cuthbert. He attended Louth school and Trinity College, Oxford, graduating with first-class honours in 1925. His master's thesis in organic chemistry was read on 24 March 1927, with the title : `` The electrical activity of the phytoplankton of the East Fens ''.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 He had been an employee of the East Fens Botanic Garden in a school at Kew but left to become curator of zoology there, from 1927 to 1936.  
   
   
 == Awards and honours ==  
 He was made a Fellow of the Royal Society in 1932, and later conferred the title Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh. His 1951 tribute to Karl Pearson, D.Sc., Hon. LLD, emphasized that their lives had been `` relatively alike and therefore not altogether distinguished by being full of separation and friction ''. In 1968 he was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society of London.  
   
   
 == Selected works ==  
 Cuthbert, J. T. P., 1925. The biochemistry of the marine gastropods. Chem. Nat., 47, 536–538.  
 Cuthbert, J. T. P., 1927. The electrical activity of the phytoplankton of the East Fens. London : Mad.Acad. Chem. J, 1, 68–69.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Carl Friedrich Auger =  
Carl Friedrich Auguste Auger ( 30 January 1804, in Berlin – 13 November 1891, in Hanover ) was a German theologian and educator.  
 In 1830 he completed his studies at the University of Berlin ( Leipzig ). In 1839 he succeeded Carl Friedrich von Döpfner as professor at the University of Würzburg. From 1845 until his death in 1891, he was the Lutheran pastor of Ruhr, where he founded the city's Prussian Academy of History, Philosophy and Law.  
 He translated the seven-volume work on the `` Neo-Latin '' languages of the 4th–2nd centuries by the Latin scholar Alexander Rabinas. In addition, he authored at least five works on the history and philosophy of the Church in the late fifth and sixth centuries, among them `` Rameau's Historisch-Protestantischen Kirche, '' ( Rameau's Counter-Propaganda Against Modernism ), of which only three parts have survived. In 1837 he founded the journal Evangelische Staatwissenschaften, which became a center of discussion in a theological dispute between the Protestant theologians of the German Reformation and the Catholic writer Cardinal Pietro Caracalla.  
   
   
 == Selected writings ==  
 Jacob Grimm und Seeliger ( 1793 )  
 Das Pechenaryus ( 1798 )  
 Die Bibel der Alten und seine Sinne ( 1799 )  
 Grahweis der Europäischen ( 1798 )  
 Zum exegetischen Untersuchungen ( Berlin, 1803 )  
 Mitteilungen aus dem Hessen im 16. Jahrhundert ( 1814 )  
 Lehrbuch der science deutschen Literatur. Lehrbuch für Sozialpolitik. ( Frankfurt/Main, 1825–7 )  
 Theorie der christlichen Literatur. Abhandlungen und Zukunft in historischen Literatur und Politik des Begriffs, '' 1st ed., Berlin, 1854.  
 Das Mythologie und ihre Biblik des Alten and Summa theologiae cum tertia litterarum ex principio ex ad scripturam ecclesiasticarum, '' Leipzig, 1788–8 ; 2nd ed., Hanover, 1797 ; 3rd ed., Frankfurt/Main, 1810.  
 L'influence qui s'été en ceux d'un Aggióge du Nouveau Testament de Christ. Paris, 1801.  
 Der Religion der menschlichen Antwort und ihre Vater der Fremde. Berlin, 1804.  
 Theologische Studien. Mainz, 1813 ; 2nd ed., Leipzig, 1823.  
 Deleugran. Abhandlungen und Zukunft der Literatur. Göttingen, 1837.  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Rudolph Stefan-Gut =  
Rudolph Stefan-Gut ( 14 May 1876 – 19 March 1959 ) was a Jewish-Germans political scientist, proponent of the Franz Boas theory of history, founder of eugenics and the founder of the Racial Studies Association ( HRA ) in the Netherlands.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Gut was born in East-Prins on 14 May 1876. He studied at the Universities of Göttingen and Leipzig and received his doctorate from Göttingen in 1925. His doctoral thesis, Karl Heinrich Röchlicher Gesellschaft, was written under the direction of Rudolf Steiner. In his book Geschichte der entde – or `` History of the Intelligence of Man '', Gut proposes that a knowledge of the long-term state and history of racial intelligences is an essential prerequisite for successfully understanding modern societies. The book is still relevant today. The book has found a wider readership through the continuing analysis and publication of several more recent books by the award-winning eugenicist and self-proclaimed expert on racial genetics Fred Pearson and academic editor Jürgen Trusendli.  
 At the same time, in 1926, Gut founded the Jewish Scientific Society ( Nordhausselstverteidigungsprogrammationsgemeenschaft ) in the Netherlands, which publishes several textbooks on sociological genetics.  
 Gut was an important promoter of eugenics, which played a key role in the founding of the racial sciences, of which the heritage-based views on human race are a staple in history-sociology. He argued that hereditary laws govern human behavior, and that the intellectual and cultural environment of the children of one single racial group can best explain their general behavior. In an opinion piece published in the Zeit newspaper, Gut strongly supported Eugenics by Eugen Bleuler ( 1850–1932 ). His position changed after his death. In 1971, The Jewish Scientific Society defended its original position, and published an open letter to critics and supporters of the eugenic teaching methods.  
 Rudolf Gut was a member of the executive committee of the International Commission for the Scientific Study of the Race ( ISR ) and served on its scientific advisory council.  
 The Racial Studies Association ( HRA ) was established in the Netherlands in the 1960s under the presidency of Jan Brose, with an annual budget of about 25 000 Korvarts. The HRA publishes Handbuch zur Biologie und eugenicwissenschaft ( Historical and Eugenic Biology ) and Racenet ( Race and Social Information ) ( 1976 ).  
   
   
 == Personal life ==  
 Gut married Alice Wegener in 1902 and had one daughter, Naomi.  
   
   
 == Research ==  
 A reader reviews this text, describing the following :  
 `` Gut's work, which is profoundly empirical and quite very complete... took place during a period during which eugenics and racist ideas were widely accepted. In his book, Rudolf Steiner and Gustave Flaubert also made statements about populations which were applicable to the native nations of Europe. Fritz Springmeier tried to explain why Africans ’ utopia, for example, was not accepted in Germany. ''  
   
   
 == Views and legacy ==  
 Friederike Haerland wrote a rebuttal in Human Culture and Psychology in The Human Soul, a number of later scholarly reviews and critiques about Rudolf Gut's views on racism and eugenics, and in The Erasmus Review, where Haerland accused her editor of being an anti-Semitic bigot, `` [ A ] number of current and former schoolteachers and political experts, including Steiner and others at the university, as well as some prominent members of the Dutch public, have characterized Gut's work on the Continent as reprehensible, destructive and pedagogical poison. ''  
 Another controversial period in Rudolf Gut's career, is considered as part of his debate in `` Race and Society, '' as mentioned in a discussion of Rudolf Gut in Migration & Ethnic-European Relations. Since from 1871, these two interests have significantly split the basis of biology scholarship in the Netherlands, after the backlash against the earlier, German-dominated, eugenic and racial sciences, and criticism and criticism of Marxism.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Irene Anne Kirke =  
Irene Anne Kirke ( February 4, 1913 – December 3, 2004 ) was an American botanist, geneticist, and homeopath.  
   
   
 == Life and career ==  
   
   
 === Early life ===  
 Irene Anne Kirke was born in Stamford, Connecticut. Her father was a New York lawyer.  
 In 1926, Kirke received her doctorate from Harvard University in Physiology and Genetics. That same year, she and her brother moved to Coral Gables, Florida. Kirke worked at Marlboro Coffee Company, and worked at Mt. Vernon Hospital as a lab assistant.  
 In 1941, Kirke moved to the University of Hawaii, and received her M.D. from the University of Hawaii in 1942. She subsequently worked as an assistant in the department of botany at the University of Hawaii and as a researcher and a researcher educator in the College of Medicine, Honolulu. Kirke and her husband, Arthur O. Kirke, were involved in helping to found the Hawaii Pacific Botanical Garden in 1944. Her research involved the physiology of bryophytes, the fungi. She was a professor of medical microbiology and pathology at the University of Hawaii, and a visiting lecturer at Massachusetts General Hospital.  
 In 1945, Kirke moved to Westville, California and joined the faculty of the medical school. In 1948, she moved to the Department of Botany at Columbia University, where she spent the rest of her life as an adjunct professor. In the early 1960s, Kirke became interested in medical homeopathy, and published `` Basic Principles of Homeopathy ''.  
   
   
 === Personal life ===  
 In 1935, Kirke married Edward Torrie Wendell of Buckhorn, Oregon. They had three children : Shelia `` Joan '' Torrie Kirke, D. D., Rita Diane Kirke, D. D., and Zephaniau Maile. She died in November 2004 in Arco, California.  
   
   
 === Awards and recognition ===  
 Irene Anne Kirke was made a member of the National Academy of Sciences in 1991. She received the Amos T. Wilson Medal from the San Diego chapter of the International Society of Homeopaths in 2002. The John A. Woollett Foundation named a botanical garden in her honor.  
 In 2016, the National Research Council awarded her the American Association for the Advancement of Science Medal.  
   
   
 == Selected works ==  
 Basic Principles of Homeopathy  
, M.D. ( 1942 ). Medical Microbiology. New York : Wiley.  
 The Nearest Ancestor in Homeopathic Medicine  
, D.D. ( 1954 ). Primary Problems in Homeopathy. F.B. Macmillan & Co. ; 798 pages.  
 Basic Principles of Homeopathy ( 1957 ). San Diego : CRC Press.  
 Basic Principles of Homeopathy ( 1994 ). San Diego : CRC Press.  
   
   
 == Selected bibliography ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = John Douglas Hutson =  
John Douglas Hutson ( 1879–1964 ) was a British Assyrian translator and artist. His collections of Arabic-accented images from Syriac and Syriac-Babylonian inscriptions are housed at the Central Museum of Liverpool.  
   
   
 == Family ==  
 He was married to Lizzie Herschel ( 1873–1954 ) and had three sons and three daughters, first daughter Laura James ( born May 8, 1895 ) ; second daughter Joan ( born September 7, 1928 ) ; and third daughter Patience ( born May 6, 1945 ).  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 Selections from the Syriac ( 1953 )  
 Syriac and Babylonia, ( 1953 )  
 A few Arabic-character portraits

 Turkish Language CD set by Midway Publications ( Turkey )  
 Arabic-Manuscript or Altar Decoration by John Douglas Hutson  
 Arabic-Artwork by John Douglas Hutson and Wilson Bowerman  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Anthony Lucas =  
Anthony, C3 B6rch Lucas ( July 18, 1880 – September 29, 1954 ) was a French violinist, music composer, music teacher, and conductor. A student of Adolf Ritter, Lucas founded the premiere Bartók Institute of Music in Paris. Lucas also acted as the conductor and choirmaster of that school for more than 40 years.  
   
   
 == Early life ==  
 Lucas was born to a Jewish family in Paris. After studying at the Théâtre national d'administration in Paris, he served in the French Army and worked at the École internationale des musiques in Paris.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 Lucas founded the Bartók Institute of Music in 1896, devoted to music, and remained its artistic director until his death. Its students included Alfred Cazenove, Jacques de Molin, Marie Fay-François and Johan Stoklasa. Lucas arranged for the German composer and concert pianist Gerhard Binder. The institute is now a cultural center for both music and science.  
 Lucas was known for his influence as a professor of English and Slavic literature. He also sang in the Hamelin Choir ( 1923–25 ) and the Arcola Quartet ( 1926–28 ), among others.  
   
   
 == Selected works ==  
 Exécutée intonationnaire, concertino et contrapuntale dans la livre enseignement de Paris, 1892 ; dedicated to F. Bernon-Chandler.  
 Les Canons du Concerto d'enfants en Italie, etc., Éditions du Capricorn, 1926 ; also recorded by Herbie Flowers  
 Sonata de la Guerre, Opera, contrapuntale et quartet, Opera, 1909–14 ; also recorded by Marjorie Aldon and her daughters Sylvia, Guillaume and Claude-Pierre Astier  
 L'Orléans Concerts, 1913 ; also recorded by Carlos Osorio ( 4 )  
 1868 Adagio in E-flat major, [ Ode 3 ], for wind quintet, Op. 23 ; dedicated to Alain Philipp ( 11th Mayor of La Rochelle )  
 Electra, séance, sur un marché les fils de 4 miléième dans son piano, Op. 31, for clarinet and percussion  
 Variations piano orata, Op. 37 ; dedicated to James Ewing  
 Medulla oblongata for violin and piano, Op. 40 ; dedicated to Edward Hoskin  
 Solo piano oratorio, Op. 41 ; dedicated to Beethoven  
 Solider's ‘ A Souvenir ’, concertino and choral, for violin and piano, Op. 42 ; dedicated to Adolf Schmetterling ( 18th Emperor of Austria )  
 1883 Violin Concerto, with Louis Chétis and others ; dedicated to Leopold Thurnauer  
 Polonaise in F minor, Op. 55 ; dedicated to Michael Bechara  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = G. V. R. Shankar =  
G. V. R. Shankar ( 27 September 1892 – 8 February 1973 ) was an Indian professor of experimental physics, known for his pioneering work in the field of pure electric measurement. He also worked on the problem of single-electrode penetration in metallic semiconductors. He was the first to measure the weak electric charge of a high vacuum current. He was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1947.Shankar was married to Jehanappa, an Indian colleague and lifelong friend and sometime collaborator. They have one son and three daughters.  
   
   
 == Early life and education ==  
 Shankar was born in Kanpur, India, the second son of Chandrasekhar and Satara Shankar, and the elder brother of T.S. Shankar. His mother, Jehanappa, worked as an art teacher at Anand Vihar, Kanpur. His father, a textile trader, was an eminent scientist. He was educated at Kanpur, Santiniketan and Oxford University. He took his PhD under the supervision of Dr. Raman Venkataraman in 1938, with another lecturer, Sir James Thomson, on the general theory of charge transfer in metals and quantum electrodynamics.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 Shankar spent a short period of time in Europe before returning to India in 1939, where he stayed for several years. He then joined the Institute of Science, Pune, India as a research associate. He became, with other Indian physicists like V. U. Majumdar, a professor of physics at the Indian National Science Academy in 1950, and a professor and head of the department of experimental physics at the Physical Institute of India.  
 Shankar was in charge of both the major physics departments in India, and helped to introduce the concept of RRI-physics in this country. He carried out his work on low-voltage conductivity in nickel and tin, on electricity levels in grains of paraffin, and on the connection between temperature and electrical charge. He studied the mass and electron densities of cathode-ray tubes.  
 Shankar received the Turing Award from the Institution of Electrical Engineers in 1958.  
   
   
 == Personal life ==  
 He married in the early 1930s Satara Shankar. They had one son : Vipin ( 1917–1998 ), Professor and Head of the Department of Physics at University of Madras ( UP ). Shankar received the Gaikwad Award for his work on metallic film for the IIT Jodhpur and later the Tata Memorial Award in 1975 for his paper on electrodeposition of nickel and his paper on Raman varshub and Raman diffraction spectroscopy.  
   
   
 == Selected publications ==  
 Recent Advances in Measurement of Electromagnetic Absorption in Nickel and Tungsten ( with A.V.M. Bhabha and S.M. Raman ), Nature, vol. 249, pp. 3599–3602 ( 1935 ).  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Hans von Liebbinghaus =  
Hans von Liebbinghaus ( December 20, 1872 – February 8, 1959 ) was an American neurosurgeon and neurophysiologist who was a pioneering scientist who discovered how neurons communicate and control behaviour.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Liebbinghaus was born in Königsberg, the son of an attorney and a younger sister of neurologist Karl Liebbinghaus. In 1905, he completed his Ph.D. in pathology from the University of Strasbourg. In 1910, he became the first chairman of the Department of Physiology at the University of Berlin, and his research areas included cerebellar ganglion tract abnormalities and oligodendroglia and the peripheral effects of apophysis on neural transmission. In 1922, he married Marie Elizabeth Zechsohn, daughter of the botanist Carl Zechsohn. He retired in 1943 and after a brief period as a lecturer in neurology in Berlin, in 1959, he began research in the brain at Boston University Hospital as a head and spinal surgeon. He became professor of neurophysiology at Boston University in 1964.  
   
   
 == Awards and honours ==  
 In 1938, he was awarded an honorary doctorate from the University of Zurich by Franz Joseph Gaubatzky, a German Nazi official. In 1941, he was awarded the Charles I. Richardson Medal of the National Academy of Sciences by the American Society for Neurology.  
 In 1941, he was awarded the commission of honor ( Höherer ) from the Kaiser Wilhelm Society.  
 In 1941, Liebbinghaus was awarded the C. Zechsohn Medal by the American Board of Neurology. In 1942, he was inducted as an associate of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.In 1948, the New England Neurological Society founded the Hans von Liebbinghaus Foundation, which later became the Hans von Liebbinghaus Nurses'Hospital of Greater Boston. The hospital house is now known as Liebbinghaus House.  
 In 1953, he was awarded the Congressional Gold Medal, and the Turner Medal of the City of Boston by President Jimmy Carter.  
 In 1967, the State of Massachusetts established the Hans von Liebbinghaus University at Providence.Liebbinghaus died on February 8, 1959, in Providence, Rhode Island, at age 76, from complications of heart failure. His obituary in the Boston Herald described his early life and work, and how he became an early and successful neurosurgeon :  
 In 1893, he was appointed head of the neurosurgery department in the University of Heidelberg. His main interest in the hospital was anatomy, but he was especially concerned with the problems of the frontal lobe.His early work was mainly in neurosurgery, especially of the cerebellar ganglia, and included an anatomy of the cortex that enabled him to make precise anatomical comparisons with the cerebral cortex of other brains and thereby to devise new therapeutic instruments. He was perhaps the founder of the new terminology of the cerebellum.In 1898, he became the first neurosurgeon to utilize C. Zechsohn's prism in the analysis of cerebellar structure.  
 In 1921, after his second wife, Katerina Schmitt, died, he and his wife moved to Paris, France, where he settled into a successful career in neurology, founding the Institut universitaire de Neurologie sur le Stéphane, then known as the International University of Neurology. The institute served as a center for clinical neurology and neurosurgery.  
 In 1925, he became a full professor and subsequently became an honorary professor at the University of Louvain.  
 In 1936, the American Society of Neurology awarded him the prestigious The Harris Card = Franklin Medal for Advancing Research, giving him the highest distinction of scientific achievement.  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Gertrude Frederick Innes =  
Gertrude Frederick Innes ( October 25, 1883 – December 30, 1941 ) was a prominent prominent activist for women's suffrage in both the United States and the European theater.  
   
   
 == Early life ==  
 Innes was born in Williamstown, Maine on October 25, 1883.  
 Innes was a member of her church's choir, the Lesley Society. She met R. A. Keen in 1886 while working in New England, and the two began to fall in love. They traveled to England, and were married on July 1, 1887, in Woodstock, Massachusetts.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 Innes was an eloquent voice on behalf of women's suffrage, organizing for suffrage legislation at the Worcester Political Conference, as well as president of the American Association for the Advancement of Science. She went on to lecture at Harvard University and Washington College, and was married in 1915 to Sylvester Knuth Innes, a nephew of the famous journalist and historian John Dos Passos. They raised a family, including a son, Thomas Knuth Innes, who served as the first New York City Police commissioner. Innes served on the faculty of Washington and Lee College. She also took a position as executive secretary of the American Association of University Women, also serving on the board of directors of the Russell Sage Foundation, and as president of the New York Woman Suffrage Association.  
 She was appointed head of the United States State Commission on Labor in 1920, and was instrumental in starting the Alabama case. This case was known as the Innes v. Alabama labor case, and the U.S. Supreme Court was reluctant to uphold the case. Innes successfully argued that Alabama could not compel public employees to pay for equal rights, as the burden to be borne lay entirely with Alabama.Innes died in Fairfield, Connecticut, aged 80.  
   
   
 == Select publications ==  
 The Modern Party : its Background, Its Growth, and Its Prospects, ( 1916 )  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Hildegard Weyler =  
Hildegard Weyler ( 4 February [ O.S. 4 February ] 1781 – 19 August 1838 ) was a German paleobotanist and pharmacologist.  
 She was born in Neustadt, near Berlin, and studied at the Universities of Berlin and Leipzig. She was the author of the report on Inocybe Cooperacus discovered by Shevelle in 1816.  
   
   
 == Early life ==  
 Weyler was the daughter of an old tailor. Her father was a strict Calvinist. She was educated at a children's school and taught herself the Latin language. She also took piano lessons. On the death of her mother, a grandson recommended her to a medical doctor. Weyler left that state after twelve years to pursue further study at the University of Berlin. In 1821, the college offered her a scholarship, but she declined the offer as she was interested in botany and religion. In her acceptance letter she had commented that her chosen profession was not a scientific one ; however, she was interested in botany as she had met someone from the `` Medizinische Hochschule '', who was interested in botany.  
   
   
 == Academic career ==  
 In 1828, Weyler began her studies in medicine, but she also earned a position as a chemist for the Kolozlov Mining Company. In 1829, she was appointed assistant chemist at the local St. Bartholomew's Hospital. This position fulfilled some of the requirements for a medical doctor's position. In 1830, her appointment as a medical doctor was made permanent as she was `` opposed to the division of labour. ''  
 Her work included cleaning out unhealthy soil and preparing fungi for the service of patients. Her area of expertise included the fungi of Schickellen and Gmelinia and the remains of some Silurian mushrooms collected by Alexander Herms.Weyler retired from the city of Kiel, where she lived, in 1834. She died in Kiel, Germany.  
   
   
 == Letters ==  
 In her professional correspondence with botanists, Weyler commented that she sometimes preferred the literary more than scientific writings in her field. Her letters are interspersed with remarks and factual information, and do not always contain the subject matter in question.  
 Her first writing was dedicated to Carl Friedrich Stegemann ( 1779-1852 ) and Philipp Christian Schöppert ( 1767-1831 ).  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Ross McKendrick =  
Ross McKendrick ( October 3, 1897 – July 29, 1971 ) was an American phycologist and research biologist from Bellevue, New York. He was a member of the Linnean Society of London, the Botanical Society of America, and the American Society for the Phycological Study of Plants.  
   
   
 == Early life and education ==  
 McKendrick was born in Schenectady, New York, to Edward Harris McKendrick, a mechanical engineer, and Florence Dobbins, who was his future wife. He attended Syracuse University and then the University of Chicago, receiving his Ph.D. in plant physiology from Columbia University in 1928.  
   
   
 == Work ==  
 McKendrick is most remembered for his efforts to distinguish different types of ecological systems from a tree or forest, especially the grasslands of the southeastern United States, an area of international concern in the late 1930s. During the 1930s, McKendrick helped form and field a research expedition which discovered the distinctive grasslands of the southern United States. These grasslands covered nearly a quarter of the land mass in the southern United States, where similar to Scotland, American naturalists were trained to recognize grasses and shrubs from a distance. He described 11 species, many of which also became taxa. These include the desert woodpecker `` Grey Fox '' and the west coastal duff from Florida. The pea, which the botanist also named Pitta genus, was endemic to the region. By 1930, McKendrick was organizing field research trips in southern Ohio, Florida, the Carolinas, and even the Virgin Islands.  
   
   
 == Death and legacy ==  
 He died at the age of 65, in late 1971. The late McKendrick maintained a strong relationship with the ecologists and scientists of the time, always accompanying them on field trips and courting them and his wife, Florence. The book, in particular, provides an early and intimate study of a man who wanted to collect an immense amount of information about an ancient and exotic flora. McKendrick, in his book Lost World : Twenty Years of Research on the Rhizomes and Fungi of Western North America, recognized that these plants, if collected and studied, would reveal patterns of adaptation, reproduction, and disease from time to time, and would provide important clues to provide the unique knowledge of the plants that would later be assimilated by paleontologists and botanists to link the phenological processes of American flora to specific, historical species.McKendrick had stated that the focus of his career was not botany but archaeology and paleontology. During his work in the 1950s, McKendrick took his interest in plant paleontology, and his second book of papers, Paleoproterozoic Ecology, was based on his fossil finds. He also explored grassland ecology with himself and the biologist Dorothea Lange, writing their paper, `` A Field Pilot Study of Skipping Ridge Meanderings in North Carolina ''. McKendrick's Molluscs and Botany : An Archaeological Translation of `` Systematics and Evolution of the Saprobic Class. '' was published in 1957. It is, however, for the first time in English, in a volume that has been published for several languages.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Bernhard Bernhard =  
Bernhard Bernhard ( German : [ ˈbɑllə dən, ˈbenbɛ ] ; 27 August 1869 – 14 December 1943 ) was a German physicist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 He was born in Jena and graduated in 1904 from the Jena Technische Hochschule ( now University of Jena ).  
   
   
 === Education ===  
 Bernhard Bernhard received his doctorate ( Ph.D. ) in physics in 1918. The following year, he applied for a position as a research associate at the Institute for Photographic Research ( IGAP ), which at the time was a sub-department of the famous IBM ( German : IBM GmbH ), IBM Europe ( German : IBM GDR ), IBM Asia ( Chinese : 管世高報辷, lit. Asia-Pacific Research Center ), a division of IBM Corporation. At the time, Bernhard worked at the Jena Technische Hochschule as an assistant in charge of the optical microscopes. From 1920 until 1922 he was Head of the Electrical Theory Department ( 2nd F. E. ). During the Second World War, he stayed at the IGAP and continued his education at the Berlin Technical University ( BDU ), remaining as an associate professor until his retirement.  
   
   
 === Academic career ===  
 In 1920, he received the following research grant from IGAP :  
   
 X-Ray Laboratory ( now IBM Research Center )  
 Electromagnetic Laboratory ( now IBM Research Center )  
 Graphene Research Center  
 Electrochemical Laboratory  
 Materials Science Laboratory  
 Medical and Pharmaceutical Laboratory  
   
   
 === Publications ===  
 A View of the Long-Range Imaging Calculation ( 1922 )  
 Electromagnetic Resonance Technology for Guidance ( 1924 )  
 After graduation from BDU in 1925, he worked as a lecturer at the Technical University of Berlin.  
   
   
 == Honors and awards ==  
 Adolf Ewald medal  
 Hermann-Eugen Tummina medal  
 Hartshorn prize  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = B. B. Guy (pioneer) =  
Prof. George Dwight Guy ( 24 July 1912 – 6 September 1984 ) was a British physicist, anatomist, academic and journalist. He was a pioneer in the study of the cerebral cortex, and was the founder of the brain research institute at the University of Edinburgh, known as the Department of Cognitive and Brain Sciences, where he worked as its Director from 1951 to 1955.  
   
   
 == Education ==  
 He was born in Dublin, Ireland, to a leading Irish printer and industry executive, James Clark and Charlotte Hinden. He was educated at Trinity College Dublin, the Royal College of Physicians of Edinburgh and the University of Cambridge.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 In 1954 he joined the Department of Cognitive and Brain Sciences, when it was opened by Dr Harold Poynting. In 1955 he joined the Department of Anatomy and the Centre of Stem Cell Biology at the National Institute for Medical Research ( NIMR ), and subsequently its World Health Organization ( WHO ) seat. He was Professor of neurobiology at Trinity in 1958, and Chairman of its Department of Anatomy. In 1962 he was elected an Associate of the Royal Society of Edinburgh. His landmark 1952 study of the brain's wiring in animals at Cambridge contributed greatly to the development of neuropsychopharmacology, and culminated in its 1979 publication by Sir John Lilly. At the invitation of Lilly, he then moved to the University of Edinburgh as a lecturer in neuroanatomy and neurosurgery. The Centre of Stem Cell Biology at the University of Edinburgh also acquired its original name from him.  
 Guy was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society in the Society's Society of Biological Sciences in 1964, and served as its President from 1971 to 1980. He was made a CBE in 1976. Guy died in Edinburgh on 6 September 1984.  
   
   
 == Honours and research ==  
 Guy was awarded the George Plimpton Medal for Science in 1981. He was also a recipient of the Royal Society's Medal of Honour in 1984.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Aaron Dement =  
Aaron Dement ( Hebrew : ויאכל געברע‎ ; 17 August 1912 – 27 October 2001 ) was an Israeli intellectual and sociologist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Dement graduated from the Hebrew University in Jerusalem in 1952 and subsequently obtained his PhD in social sciences from Columbia University in New York City in 1964. Dement joined the faculty of Columbia University in 1960, becoming dean of the Graduate School in 1966. He was a professor at Technion in Jerusalem and later a professor of international relations at Fordham University in New York. In 1968 he was the first professor to speak at the Nuremberg trials of the Weimar Republic. From 1970–79 he was president of Tel Aviv University.In 1972, Dement was an editor of the former student publication Israel Political Science Review.  
 Dement earned a doctorate ( M.A. ) in sociology from American University in 1970. His doctorate was followed by his dissertation on the rules of markets in liberal countries. In the 1980s, he became Director of the Institute of Political Studies in Tel Aviv University and served as its founding chairman.  
   
   
 == Bibliography ==  
 Dement, Aaron ( 1979 ). The Stalinist State : The Realist Logic of New Deal Jewish Socialism. Westport, CT : Praeger. OCLC 63139928.  
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Thomas Van Meter =  
Thomas Van Meter ( 19 May 1813 – 21 December 1882 ) was a British clergyman, clergyman, theologian, sift and aid to the theatre, writer, poet, Bible scholar, miscellaneous writer, amateur collector, reformer, and activist of many records.  
 Van Meter was born in Hertfordshire, England, and was educated in Brighton, Oxford and London, where he was educated to become a lawyer. He was a Fellow of the Church of England and of the Boy Scouts of Great Britain and Ireland.  
 He did many studies in natural sciences, history and philosophy. In 1849, after his Christian faith had been healed, he turned his attention to literature. He studied classical, romanced in novels, music, newspapers, theater, writing, and amateur archaeology. In 1850, he became a scholar of ancient, medieval and early modern poetry. In 1852 he edited and published George William Hoddle's series of volumes on the history of the ougliaths in Sicily, for which he won the scientific Charles Perrin Medal, and in 1856, published a biography of Hoddle's teacher, Marker with A Few Essays ( engraved by Richard Barr ).  
 Van Meter was deeply influenced by Hume, Huxley, Cavendish, and the Mormons and practised criticism and criticismism with an almost obsessive zeal. He considered God to be a pragmatic legislator and instructed himself with a hard gaze upon all rational forms of reasoning and to apply them to his own life and the world. He was interested in ethical, moral, political, and social questions and wrote with a passion and zeal for the cause of Christian ethics. His use of the word `` truth '' during his life was enamoured and encouraging.On the outbreak of the Crimean War in 1861, Van Meter, who was then a minister, gathered a party of friends and emigrants, mostly Jewish and brought them together in a railway inn called the Rambouillet to discuss a case. Van Meter became head of this meeting and would carry on a long, painful, difficult, intractable debate and personal disputes with its erudite audience.Later Van Meter would remain in close correspondence with Robert Penn Warren, director of the Illuminating Academy in Dublin and other, established, abolitionist writers. Van Meter became closer to the abolitionists by their meetings in Elstree, and a secret correspondence developed with Harrison F. Grier. This correspondence would culminate in a collection entitled Sins of the Fathers in which Grier came to criticize Van Meter's invective, his exposition of philosophy and his writings on society. In 1872 Van Meter was the author of several pieces for reissue in England and in the United States. The three booklets given for this purpose are called The Fall of Man ( published in the United States in 1876 ), Men's History of a Wicked Economy ( published in the United States in 1878 ) and The Penal Reformers ( published in the United States in 1884 ). He died in London, England, but his last published work was in 1882.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 Van Meter's titles for verse and journalism were collected under the title :  
   
 The Fall of Man ( 1850 )  
 The Prophets ( 1855 )  
 The Penitent or the Penitent ( 1857 )  
 A Taste of the Spirit ( 1858 )  
 Expelled from England ( 1860 )  
 These Worlds ( 1864 )  
 A Comment on the Old Testament ( 1865 )  
 The Importance of a Morbid Duty ( 1867 )  
 Slaves or Masters ( 1867 )  
 The Observation of Antiquity ( 1870 )  
 The Bread-bearer ( 1871 )  
 The Hourglass Round the World ( 1871 )  
 Going on Watch ( 1872 )  
 A Man's Promise ( 1873 )  
 Paradise, Scars on the Town of Lyons ( 1873 )  
 A Collection of the New Testament ( 1873 )  
 The Fall of Man in Five Parts ( 1876 )  
 A Brief View of Hobbes ( 1877 )  
 The Seven Deadly Sins ( 1879 )  
 George William Hoddle, Makers of the Greatest New History of the Church ( 1881 )  
 Thomas Van Meter : A Life of Grace, Magnificence, Excellence and Complacency ( 1886 )  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Asa Rourke =  
Asa Rourke ( 3 June 1913 – 6 February 1996 ) was a British geographer.  
 Born in London to a Congregationalist family, Rourke was educated at St Pancras Grammar School and George Edward William's School in London. He worked in the Geological Survey of India from 1954 to 1955. He received his PhD in geology from London University in 1964.  
 After moving to Australia in 1969, Rourke did time-waste work in the mining industry, including working in Turkey. His 1972 doctoral thesis was on the geological history of South Australia and the Queensland–Melbourne Balfour Agreement, co-authored with Adrien A. Sontag. In 1973, Rourke published his Australian Geological Community.  
   
   
 == Publications ==  
 The Geological Branch of the British Geological Survey, British Geological Survey Proceedings, Vol. 4, 1949.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Heinrich Groene Hesse =  
Heinrich Heinrich Groene Hesse ( 7 October 1849 – 6 January 1936 ) was a German linguist and educator who helped develop German-language education and reform education. He also established the then-new school of phonetics in Berlin.  
   
   
 == Early life ==  
 Hesse was born in Aix, in Mecklenburg–Schwerin, into a Jewish family. He studied the language and took up specialised learning in Pashto and Armenian. In 1865 he was elected member of the University of Berlin, and from 1868 to 1870 he taught for one year at the Free University of Berlin.  
 In 1871 he accepted the position of Privatdozent in Berlin, and later became a Privatdozent for the University of Leipzig and of the University of Göttingen. In 1884 he became Privatdozent in Freiburg and from that year to 1891 director of the Deutsche Grammatik der Nachrichten-Lexikon und Zahlrhein.At Freiburg, Hesse became expert on the Acayenne and Paimatik dialects. He also developed a lexicon of Afrikaans, a language classification system.Hesse held a Chair in the Education of the People in the Russian Empire and taught for many years at the Higher Higher Institute of the Higher German State.  
   
   
 == Notable achievements ==  
 Groene Hesse's work has been widely respected in German-speaking East and West, and in a number of international languages. His central contribution was to establish a school for phonetics in Berlin, the first such school in the world.  
 From 1876 to 1882, Groene Hesse, both as a linguist and educator, established the Deutsche Grammatik der Nachrichten-Lexikon und Zahlrhein in Freiburg. Groene Hesse also directed the language program in a number of German universities, and had various students accept advanced degrees in the schools of the New Testament. The `` Bibliothek Gebiete und Grammatik der Nachrichten-Lexikon und Zahlrhein '' ('Bibliothématique and Grammar School') at Freiburg is regarded as an exemplary and high-quality unit, closely paralleling some of the American schools.  
   
   
 == Selected works ==  
 Handbuch der Vollkommensysteme in Schlesien  
 Orthography and orthography education for school-aged children  
 In : Handbuch der Vollkommensysteme in Schlesien. Theologie und mathematische Monographien : 589-608, 1882.  
   
   
 == Related resources ==  
 `` Hesse '' : Full text at Aragon Books ( in German )  
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Christian Benedikt Reif =  
Christian Benedikt Reif ( 25 June 1789 – 27 January 1856 ) was a German anatomist and histologist who worked in the Swedish Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences, now the Royal Institute of Technology ( RIT ) in Stockholm.  
   
   
 == Early life ==  
 Reif was born in Halle/Köthen and went to school in Holle.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 Reif studied medicine at the University of Giessen. In 1814, he took a position in the Privatdozent in Hamburg, where he completed his licentiate with a thesis on the wing and thigh-bones of the human abdomen.In 1819, he moved to Berlin to study medicine. Upon returning to Hamburg, Reif was employed by Theophilus Gross as an assistant to one of his students, Friedrich Wilhelm Myers. Reif remained in Berlin for the rest of his career.Reif took the chair of anatomy and histology in Hamburg in 1829, the same year he married Louise Ann Gustav Olaf Jostensens. They had five children :  
   
   
 == Legacy ==  
 Reif's son, Heinrich Reif, became a leading German entomologist and is considered the father of entomology in the United States.His son Albert died in 1835, and a grandson, Christian Reif ( 1844-1881 ), became a leading German entomologist and is known for his research of Eutempunctata mortsum, the verrucosa moth.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Barbara R. Netter =  
Barbara R. Netter, M.D. ( 1913-1967 ) was an English gynecologist and obstetrician who specialised in the management of ectopic pregnancies. She was an assistant physician to Dr R. F. Moulton at the Watsons Eye Hospital in 1935.  
   
   
 == Early life and education ==  
 Barbara Netter was born on 2 April 1913 in Wallingford, Yorkshire to Maurice J. and Barbara Jane Netter. She was the daughter of Walter R. and Maria Evelyn Gower Netter. In 1928 she entered Heriot-Watt University College, London, where she studied Medicine, graduating with First Class Honours in 1935.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 She worked at Salford General Hospital as a Midwife for 20 years, working with a number of women for whom the hospital was short of staff. Netter started working in obstetrics and gynaecology at Salford General Hospital on 2 June 1938 and held the position of Chief Midwife for the hospital until her retirement in 1955. She was made an Honorary Professor of Gynecology at Salford General Hospital in 1963.Netter spent most of her career working on ectopic pregnancy and provided health advice for women concerned. She was one of the first obstetricians in the UK to refer women with ectopic pregnancies to the Watsons Eye Hospital. In 1932, she published a article on the ectopic pregnancy of female patients. The article said that none of these women had the disease at the time of delivery ; they had attempted a vaginal delivery to be sure.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Leono Palli =  
Leono Palli ( 1869-1941 ) was an Italian violinist and composer.  
   
   
 == Life and career ==  
 Palli was born in Rome to a family of Jewish descent. He studied with the renowned violinist Luciano Fusari and Percival Ossiano. He later relocated to London in 1898 to work as a professional violinist and composer under the violinist and conductor Davide Petruccio. Palli was a correspondent member of the Royal Academy of Music and the Société pianique de France from 1910 to 1936, and its last president from 1937 to 1941. He died in 1941 at age 92 in Rome.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Georg Fischer =  
Georg Fischer ( 30 August 1884 in Kirchhöhle, Baden-Württemberg – 10 August 1941 in Kiel ) was a German mathematician, mathematician known for his work on cohomology and that of Ellsberg.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Georg Fischer studied at the University of Kiel with Bertrand Russell and had a successful career in Berlin as a graduate student in 1903. After the outbreak of World War I he returned to Berlin and joined the math department, teaching until 1935. Fischer's interest in social problems led him to form what is now known as the social problem group, an academic scientific community made up of mathematicians interested in the `` social and political situation of the middle classes in Germany and in the state of society at large. '' In 1929 he became vice-president of the German Academy of Science.  
 During the Second World War he served in various positions in the Wehrmacht and was a member of the Baader Judenrat ( National Security Council ). In the 1950s and 1960s, Fischer was editor of the main journal Annalen der mathematischen Wissenschaften, but in 1965 he retired.  
   
   
 == Work ==  
 During World War I he published books on the mathematics of probability and applied mathematics. Fischer's work, along with Fergus Henderson and Georg von Inzeti ( 1879–1934 ), made important contributions to the field of differential geometry, especially the foundations of the abelian groups. It dealt with problems related to error in the theory of numbers, the potentiality axioms of the theory of processes and binomial differential equations.  
 Some of the later books that dealt with real number theory, and particularly problems of distributivity, were :  
   
 In Zwei entwurfenden eines nach Verbrandtungsverbrauches : eine Anwendung, König und Allgemeinen Versuch zur mathematischen Vortrage ( 1919 ), Wien : München.  
 Grundzüge zur finchische und afrikanische Methoden über den Theory der veränderlichen Interpungen auf die popperbildenden integrale des Liebigverlusts ( 1920 ), Wien : Berlin.  
 Die Biographie und der technische Biographie zu den katholischen ihres Mathematischen und Erziehungsatztums in Staaten und Säugetiere, München : Anton G. Hochschild.  
 Erinnerungen der sociologischen Logik ( 1919 )  
 Einbahnung aus der Machtgewirtschaftslehre ( 1923 )  
 Vorlesungen über die läuftliche Studie ( 1924 ).  
   
   
 == Selected bibliography ==  
 Notes on analytic methods in the theory of finite numbers  
 Problems of distributivity  
 Fundamental results of the problem theory of finite numbers  
 Basic problems of algebraic analysis  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Johann Georg Fuchs =  
Johann Georg Fuchs ( 7 June 1760 – 24 February 1789 ) was a German mathematician who developed a conception of elasticity derived from the theory of a curve, which he called `` the tricklederkraft ''. He also made contributions to the development of thermodynamics.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Johann Georg Fuchs was born in the Rhineland, in modern day Germany. He received a PhD in 1794 at University of Tübingen and a master's degree in mathematics in 1799. He was professor of mathematics at Breslau ( now Leipzig ), where his younger brother Anton, later professor of mathematics at Breslau, also made mathematical contributions to the development of mechanics.  
 His mentor was Johannes Kepler. The Rheinisch constant is named after him.  
 From 1793 he was professor of mathematics at Leipzig, from 1798, professor of mathematics and astronomy, and from 1798 the director of Leipzig's Mathematics Institute.  
 In 1776, Fuchs published a mathematical study of the microscopic structure of quarks, making contributions to the development of quantum mechanics. In 1787 he published an analysis of graph theory.  
 In 1793 he contributed to the development of thermodynamics, demonstrating how the compressibility of molecules can change the energy of an electric charge by changing its composition. For this same reason, his equation which predicts the force at a material surface called deformal kinetics can also be applied to matter in general.  
 His works included the equations describing Boltzmann's laws of states, special relativity, and quantum mechanics, which are largely derived from original work of Robert Hooke.  
 In addition to his contributions in mathematics, Fuchs was interested in biology. He was a member of the Society of Natural Sciences of Leipzig, was Vice-President of the scientific society, and was an honorary doctor of medicine at the University of Leipzig.Fuchs was also an amateur botanist and cactus grower.  
 Fuchs is buried at Heuwischer Regensburg, near Beuenen-Schönlein.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 Handbuch der Differentialgleichungen mit die früheren Frenkelzustand ( Berlin 1794 ),  
 Partial, tabellen and naturhistorische Grundlage der Naturgeschichte ( Berlin 1807 )  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Michael L. Lynch =  
Michael Lance Lynch ( February 9, 1919 – August 11, 1999 ) was a noted Canadian experimental physicist. He is best known for his work on nuclear structure and decay with his work on the decay of beta decay.In 1954, Lynch was inducted as a Fellow of the Royal Society of Canada.  
   
   
 == Background ==  
 Lynch was born in Montreal, Quebec, Canada, to Ralph E. L. Lynch and Jessie `` Guinot '' Lynch. His parents were both graduate students. His older brother was physicist Robert L. Lynch ( 1931–1986 ), a pioneer in electron-discharge physics and co-discoverer of the chlorine atoms. His younger brother, Gerald Elliott Lynch ( 1947–1985 ), was a research scientist in the Nuclear Weapons Project of the Department of the Atomic Energy of the US.  
   
   
 == Education ==  
 Lynch attended the Collège de France.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 In 1954, Lynch published in the American Journal of Physics a paper describing a beta decay involving the decay of a proton-decay covalent bond. This was the first documented description of beta decay, and the first evidence that covalent bond decay was occurring in a muon-like chemical event.  
   
   
 == Research ==  
 In 1963, he was awarded a Guggenheim Fellowship with an extension to the Hahn–Morse State Laboratory in Philadelphia, where he remained until he was named senior scientist in 1969. In 1969 he was the first to describe alpha decay ( see Echeverria equation ). In 1975, he described his first beta decay experiment.  
 In 1987 he was awarded the Robert L. Lynch Medal of the American Physical Society for `` outstanding contributions to nuclear physics, nuclear energy, and basic research in the field of neutrons. ''  
   
   
 == Final years ==  
 Lynch received the Honorary Doctorate of the University of Saskatchewan in 1979 for his research on beta decay. He retired from the university in 1990 and was awarded an honorary Doctorate of Laws from University of Saskatchewan in 1997.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Cornelis Kummer =  
Cornelis Kummer ( 1 December 1734 in Schoenbrunn, Bavaria – 7 May 1848 in Vienna ) was a German orator, writer and composer. He is notable for his ‘ Geschichte des Jasiens de Nuremberg ’ ( Dictionary of German Nuremberg ).  
 He studied at the University of Breslau and was professor of music in Lausanne from 1762.  
   
   
 == Works ==
