<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Basil Ingram-Jarrar =  
Baron Basil Ingram-Jarrar ( 1849-1932 ) was a British economist and editor.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Basil Ingram-Jarrar was born in London in 1849. He was educated at Theresianum Grammar School in Sandbanks. In 1876 he graduated in economics from University College, London. He became an economic correspondent for the London Economist, Edinburgh Commercial Correspondent and later returned to Australia, where he published his papers and essays.  
   
   
 == Publications ==  
 At the beginning of his life he was an editor for the London Economic Register, 1877-9. He was secretary of the Melbourne Round Table Association from 1883 to 1893, and held various positions at various local and national forums.  
 He wrote various books on economics, as a member of the International Economic Association, World and County Council of Australia, member of the Academy of European Industry, vice president of the Government of the Pacific Islands and executive of the Australasian Bank for Finance.He was also the author of a popular book, How to Get on, the Business of a Government — and what to do about it : A practical guide for managers.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Harry Atwell Davis =  
Harry Atwell Davis ( 1867 – 16 May 1945 ) was a Canadian-American physicist, conductor, composer, and music teacher. He is credited with providing the first orchestral piano concertos, and made many other significant contributions to the music of the 20th century.Davis was born at Kincardine, Ontario, Ontario to Jodie S. ( Davis ) and a brother. Davis studied at the University of Toronto under Sir William Wilson Thomson, then continued his studies at the McGill University. He moved to New York City in 1875, settling at 70 Linden Drive in Greenwich Village. He taught piano and harmony with the Toronto Symphony Orchestra, then the Burlington County Symphony Orchestra. He continued to compose music, particularly piano sonatas. In 1897, he created the symphony for which he is best known, the First String Quartet, based on a parallel with the music of Karl Strauss.  
 Davis was also noted for conducting concerts of his own or other composers, often with family members present. Davis was also a large figure in the world of elementary school music, providing piano accompaniment for both the Peter Gurney ’ s Concert Band and the Claude Brésil Quartet ; his string quartet The All-Consuming Dove is sung throughout his numerous American recordings.  
 Davis died at age 81. The Chamber Choir of Central High School in Chatham, Ontario, was named in his honor.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 Sonata ( Chicago Symphony Orchestra, 1905 )  
 String Quartet No. 1 in C Minor ( Toronto Symphony Orchestra, 1907 )  
 Concert Band Sonatas  
 Pieces for Piano ( 1923–1924 )  
 Violin Sonatas  
 Piano Sonatas  
 String Quartet in C Minor  
 String Quartet in E minor  
 Concerto in D minor ( London, New York City Philharmonic, 1930 )  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Augustin Aubin =  
Augustin Aubin ( 1755 in Paris – 1810 in Paris ) was an accomplished naturalist and antiquarian. He studied at the Ecole royale de Paris, obtaining a degree in natural history. On his return to Europe, he founded in Paris the Société biografique de France and published the Index des Antiquités de France ( 1806–08 ).  
 Aubin's scientific works concern :  
   
   
 === Natural History of China ===  
 Aubin, Mémoire sur la desprésentation du China ( 1804 ) ;  
 Histoire des échangels du Qing ( 1807 ) ;  
 Histoire nouvelle égyptien ( 1813 ) ;  
 Description de celle pratique de Château des Suites du Duc d'Indy ( 1815 ) ;  
 Recherches sur la mode dans les considérations sur le Géographie et la historique de la Nouvelle-Égypte ( 1817 ) ;  
 Description des paves maritimes ( 1820 ), and  
 Description des tribes de France et du Queda ( 1822 ).  
   
   
 === Antiquity and Société biografique de France ===  
   
 Aubin published numerous scientific works. In 1814, he co-founded the Société biografique de France, which he headed until his death in Paris. This society assisted public and private collectors by improving the curatorial conditions of antiquities, as well as by facilitating commercial relationships between museums and the private owner. In 1821, he founded the Museum des Antiquités, a National Museum whose main purpose is to preserve and collect a large amount of ethnographic and ethnographical material of the past. The museum also houses collections of classical and semi-classical antiquities and other curiosities from the Middle Ages to the present day.  
 The museum is represented on the Le Corbusier dome in the 1822 Louvre, on the National Gallery of Belgium's Dixliées in the Brussels Museum, and on the temporary display at the Carlsberg Museum in Norway.  
   
   
 == Selected works ==  
 Recherches sur la mode dans les considérations sur le Géographie et la historique de la Nouvelle-Égypte, ( 1784, 1794 ).  
 Nouveau parlementaire des Antiques du Conchier, ( 1805 ).  
 Histoire des échangels du Qing, ( 1807 ).  
 Comment l'entretiens bibliothèque série et des antiquités galeriques d'Europee ( 1813 ).  
 Description des paves maritimes ( 1820 ).  
 Description des tribes de France et du Queda ( 1822 ).  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Rudolf Fuchs =  
Rudolf Fuchs ( April 25, 1908 – March 26, 2002 ) was a physicist, known for his theories of nuclear physics. He also conducted nuclear chemistry research at the University of California, Berkeley.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Fuchs was born in New York City, and received his BS ( 1923 ) in 1933 from Columbia University, where he served as assistant physics professor and assistant dean. His doctoral students included Giuseppe Martini, Harold Puthoff, and John Spencer.In 1934, he became a full professor of physics at the University of California, Berkeley.  
 In 1945, he founded the Department of Nuclear Physics at Berkeley, where he created and led one of the first research groups in nuclear physics. With A. P. Evans, he developed the Fuchs–Evans laws that have recently become the foundation of modern nuclear physics. In 1962, he established a joint faculty position at Caltech to organize and supervise the University's Ph.D. program in nuclear physics.  
 He retired in 1977, and died in Berkeley in 2002 at the age of 84.  
   
   
 == Awards ==  
 In 1954, Fuchs was awarded the Davis Medal from the American Physical Society.  
 In 1986, he was awarded the Nissens Lifetime Achievement Award.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Paul M. Klein =  
Paul M. Klein ( 1911–1991 ) was a German-born psychologist known for his pioneering work in personality testing and personality development. As a professor of developmental psychology at the University of Maryland, he also conducted research into personality testing and in the development of personality disorders. He won the Hugh Laurie Award in 1968.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 Klein was born in Hockenheim near Erlangen, Germany. He spent his childhood in Prague, Russia. In 1936 he studied psychology at the University of Leipzig under Hermann Ebbinghaus. In 1938, he was recruited by Freud and became a clinical psychologist at the Psychiatric Institute of Leipzig. In 1944, he emigrated to the United States. In 1947, he became a professor at Washington University in St. Louis, where he taught graduate students. After his resignation in 1963, he moved to the Department of Child, Youth and Family Social Service at the University of Maryland in College Park.In the late 1950s and early 1960s, Klein worked with Robert B. Herrmann, a professor at Harvard University. He was also involved with George Martin in their effort to provide developmental testing in Germany and Poland. In the 1960s, Klein ran a large and influential group of personality tests. His researchers have been involved in the creation of personality measures like the Revised Personality Inventory ( the Reinach-Loeffler Standards ), the G.I.E. Grades, and the Thomas T. Frey scale. He was a member of the National Academy of Sciences.  
   
   
 == Publications ==  
 Klein, P. M. ( 1949 ). The development of man's personality. New York, NY : Holt, Rinehart and Winston.  
 K. ( 1953 ). The psycho-social question and its psychoanalytic implications. In J. R. O'Connor ( Ed. ). ( John Wiley and Sons ). Basic Psychological Methods : Lectures on Psychological Types ( 3rd ed. ). New York : L. Appleton and company.  
 K., Kort, J. E., & Klein, P. M. ( 1957 ). Man's essential structure : Construct and economic psychoanalytic evidence of the birth of essentiality. New York : B. Simon and Co.  
 M., Kort, R. E. ( 1957 ). Research in the theory of the basic idea of essentiality. New York, NY : Books on Demand.  
 Klein, P. M. ( 1961 ). The purpose of personality testing : Personality development in age 5 through middle years ( i ). New York, NY : Academic Press.  
 Kort, R. E. ( 1962 ). On man's basic theory of essentiality. New York, NY : B. Simon and Company.  
 Kort, R. E. ( 1963 ). On man's basic theory of essentiality. New York, NY : B. Simon and Company.  
 Kort, R. E. ( 1964 ). On the expansion of the theory of the essential to men, 1950-1963. New York, NY : B. Simon and Company.  
 Klein, P. M. ( 1965 ). Studies in the theoretical method in psychodynamics. New York, NY : B. Simon and Company.

<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Johann Andreas Gießer =  
Johann Andreas Gießer ( 30 November 1617 – 24 June 1694 ) was a German Lutheran theologian, philosopher and politician.  
 Gießer was born at Künltungstuhl in Bavaria on 30 November 1617. He grew up at Lecce, and after attending the medical school of Thurner at Luchterhausen and later at Jena, he entered the University of Jena and from 1650 was a student of Julius Lackmann. There, he came under the influence of Johann Matthäus Hyndman ( 1615-1661 ).  
 His work, Gesammelte philosophische Rechtnisses zu den worlden Undruck, was published in German in 1666. It contains, in the first part, a treatise on Aristotle, in the second part on such subjects as theology, moral philosophy, human dignity, grammar, history, and political economy.  
 Gießer's most famous work, Theorie der Amzehre, or Interpretation of the Holy Scriptures, was published posthumously in 1681. It is not known whether it contained the actual preaching of Gießer, as is often assumed, but his only surviving work was `` Abræagoga theologiae spiritus, consectu amandas laudosis amicitiae '' ( 1676 ), in which he also dedicated the work Abræagogicæ by Luther.  
 In addition to writing philosophy and logic, Gießer had a strong Christian/monotheistic belief, but opposed the pretension to interpretive authority of Scripture ; he advocated the literal reading of Scripture, and, in a widely quoted sermon, in 1595, stated :  
   
 Christians understand the Scriptures, and think they understand it well ; but for my part I say that they understand so poorly that it is impossible for them to believe in the Holy Spirit or in Christ. The more they contradict themselves and their hearts the more utterly it is a matter of faith for them to believe in the Holy Spirit. Therefore, it is best for them to repent, because there is a good deal of faith lost in their hearts.  
 Gießer is also known for having shown himself extremely proficient in translation, making it possible for the English translation to gain acceptance.  
   
   
 == Selected works ==  
 Gesammelte philosophische Rechtnisses zu den worlden Undruck, Jena 1666 ( 2 volumes, 1664 and 1666 )  
 System der Kirchensystem der Theologie, 1717  
 Das Religionspolitik einiger Zeit, 1714  
 Die Gründung der malischen System, 1724  
 Pädagogische Christentum über die Deutschen christlichen Theologie, 1726  
 Praise be to God Almighty : Neue Theologie über den christlichen Programmengeschichte, etc., 1732  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Hermine Raviss =  
Hermine Raviss ( 6 August 1906, Seyntouris, Rès-d'Aube – 28 August 1993, Alençon ) was a French immunologist and biophysicist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Hermine Raviss was born into a Jewish family on 6 August 1906. He studied medicine in Paris, Munich and Strasbourg. During World War I, he was wounded and was awarded a knighthood. Between 1920 and 1922 he was a professor at the École Polytechnique in Paris, the same institution where he and Pierre ( Pierre André ) Rivest carried out the first immunological studies on guinea pigs, a German rabbit with a genetic defect which resulted in an illness. With Napoleon Bonaparte, he was the head of the protective services, serving at various points as director of the navy, surgeon, entomologist and bacteriologist. Between 1922 and 1938, he taught at the Lycée Mercure in Paris, as well as at the medical faculty of the Faculté de Sciences de Paris. In 1939, with the founding of the Second French Republic, he was made a professor of immunology at the Pontifical Catholic University of Rome.  
 In 1935, he joined the École Normale Supérieure, as a lecturer in Immunology. He was a professor of immunology at the Institut Pasteur from 1958 to 1963. He died in 1987.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Reinhold Mannheim =  
Reinhold Mannheim ( 11 December 1892, Berlin – 2 November 1947, Heidelberg ) was a German ornithologist, amateur flier, and binomial-name inventor. He was a member of the Schwabian-Hertz family.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
   
 Reinhold Mannheim was born in Berlin in 1892. He began his early ornithological studies in Gießen, where his father owned a shop. After graduating in 1900 he worked in a leather factory. After leaving the factory in 1904, he did his zoological research, briefly doing field work in Germany. In 1906 he moved to Heidelberg as an assistant to the zoologist and collector Carl Schultze. This position allowed him to tour Europe, South America, Australia and New Zealand.  
 In 1919 he was appointed head of the ornithological section at the Landsdämmerungs-Gesellschaft ( Landmarks Scientific Office ), a post he held for 20 years. During this period, he also made numerous scientific discoveries, and started the bird collection in Heidelberg. In 1921 he collected more than 400 new birds and collected close to 1,000 g. Mannheim believed that ornithological knowledge could be promoted through service, with the collector being held in high regard. However, because there were very few male collectors in the United States, the former Mayor of Heidelberg, Adolf Wilke, called Mannheim's efforts `` a real mother's milk ''.After four years, the work was abandoned because there was not enough of a demand for ornithological specimens. He retired from this job in 1925 and he became a teacher, self-employed and at the same time a keen amateur ornithologist. He died in Heidelberg.  
   
   
 == Bibliography ==  
 Mannheim, Reinhold ( 1926 ). Taschenbuch der Ornithologie : Eine Monographie des Ornithischen Königsanstaltes. Berlin : B. Baumann and C. Humblot ( not in German ). Dt. 4.  
 Mannheim, Reinhold ( 1951 ). New Audubon : A Study of Domestic Fishes of Northern and Southern California, Philippines, and the Southern United States. Berkeley : University of California Press. Translated by H. Michael D. Bodow. He obtained a PhD in 1936, under G.C. Marcilus, with a dissertation under the supervision of J.N. Berwerck.  
 Mannheim, Reinhold ( 1962 ). Sichtliche Einführung der Paläozoologie : Der König-Auschwitz und Baselien, Schweizerischen Fortschriften, Biologie, Extern, Geognosie ( Part 2 : Fermentation, Cholera, Molds, Fungi, etc. ), Buchgesellschaft für Ornithologie & Paläozoologie, Wien, Walther Immerling, Rottschule Medizinisches Museum, Freiburg im Breisgau, and in 1942 he took over the management of the collections of the ornithological section at the Natural History Museum, London. In 1959, the bird collection was moved to London.  
 Mannheim, Reinhold ( 1967 ). Voyage archipelago récolte des voyages : Leçons principales nouveaux avant conséquences, Impériale de l ’ École d ’ entomologie, hisseuse et fauna orientale. Paris : Argyll and Sutherland.  
 Mannheim, Reinhold ( 1970 ). Voyage archipelago récolte des voyages : Primitifs nouveaux avant conséquences, Impériale de l ’ École d ’ entomologie, hisseuse et fauna orientale. Paris : Argyll and Sutherland.  
   
   
 == Bibliography by year ==

<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Maurice P. Masoe =  
Maurice P. Masoe ( 6 October 1931 – 15 April 2004 ) was a French naturalist and botanist.  
   
   
 == Early life ==  
 Maurice Masoe was born in André-Nassau, France. His father, Ernest Masoe, was a town councillor and the husband of Adele Masoe, a dance teacher. Maurice was of Norwegian-German descent ; he said he spoke French, German, Italian, Dutch, Welsh, Esperanto and Shona.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 In 1943, Maurice was enrolled in the École normale supérieure ( ETHOS ). This required his to study microscopy and other subjects. He eventually went to the University of Paris, where he became interested in botany. After a brief stint with the University of Copenhagen, he emigrated to the United States in 1954. He became a lichenologist in 1970 and spent a decade working with at least five lichenological societies in the United States. He was a member of the Institut de Botanique de la Montréal and the Institut des Plantes d'Ormeaux ( IAO ).  
 Masoe published many articles on lichenology and became a member of the Loci Botanica de la Sociedad Botanica de Bolivia, the Society of the Natural Sciences of Long Beach, the Plant Taxon Society, and the International Lichen Societies of America and Europe. He became director of the Botanical Gardens of the New York Botanical Garden in 1958 and also served as the director of the Agricultural Science Laboratory of the University of Colorado.  
   
   
 == Death ==  
 Masoe died in mid-April 2004 in New York City. He was 83.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Cesar Mané =  
Cesar Mané ( March 16, 1900 – September 23, 1995 ) was a composer, professor, and composer. He taught for a time at the Conservatoire de Paris, but died on September 23, 1995 after two years of suffering from leukaemia.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Mané was born in Paris, the son of a wealthy French industrialist. He wrote a symphony for string orchestra, several symphonies for orchestra, and was the major pianist for the Paris Opera and the Orchestre de Paris.  
 The Symphonic cycle of the Strasbourg Symphony, like that of Richard Wagner's Trio and later for small orchestra, was written after Mané's death. The concerto is, for the first time, composed without any accompanying music. His most famous symphonies were for violin and piano.  
 The André Ravel–Carès duo, of whom Ravel was the director, composed the symphonies Salome and Gloire, Tintoretto and Somnambulisme, and La Colombe. David Ewald made a 3-LP recording of his single-movement symphonic Le premier concert de celle jolie ( The Seven Concerts of Raymond Carès, 1951–1952 ), of which only the first movement can be played, as of 2013.

<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Leonard Everett Damrosch =  
Leonard Eugene Damrosch ( January 4, 1902 – June 24, 1992 ) was an American meteorologist. He was a professor of meteorology at the University of Colorado, Boulder and a member of the Rocky Mountain Institute.  
   
   
 == Education and early career ==  
 Damrosch was born in Newburgh, New York, in 1902 to Ellsworth Damrosch and Frances Fritsch. He received his bachelor's degree in 1917 from Tufts University and his master's degree in meteorology in 1924 from the University of Colorado. He worked as an assistant in meteorology at the Weather Bureau of the United States Weather Bureau during World War I.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 During the 1950s, Damrosch worked on radar sounding, designing technical instruments and developing techniques for determining space weather.After an academic career at Colorado, Damrosch headed the Boulder division of the National Weather Service from 1952 to 1958. He joined the Rocky Mountain Institute in 1960 and served as its director from 1964 to 1969. Damrosch was also a member of the Rockhurst Group.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Peter J. Mason =  
Peter J. Mason ( October 16, 1929 – April 20, 1995 ) was an American microbiologist.  
 Mason earned a B.S. degree in biology from Williams College, and a Ph.D. in microbiology from the University of Michigan. His research interests included the use of microorganisms in microbial ecology. He held a number of research positions at many universities, including the University of Oregon, the University of Minnesota, and the University of Wisconsin. In 1990 he became the assistant editor of the Journal of the American Medical Association.  
   
   
 == Publications ==  
 1982, J. G. Lang and E. G. Coleman, The Mycological Perspective : Implications for Understanding Infectious Diseases : A Third Edition, 2nd ed. UC Berkeley Press, Berkeley, California.  
 1983, J. G. Lang and E. G. Coleman, Microbiology and Health : An Annual Report to the National Institutes of Health, 28th ed. Publ. 2121–2267, Bethesda, Maryland : National Institutes of Health, National Institute of Health Press, 1994.  
 1985, P. J. Mason, Bacteriophage Ecology and Infectious Disease, ( publ. 1988 ), Ann Arbor, Michigan : Univ. of Michigan Press, 3rd ed., 1995.  
 1986, J. G. Lang and E. G. Coleman, The Dynamics of Disease, ( publ. 1986 ), Ann Arbor, Michigan : Univ. of Michigan Press, 2nd ed., 1997.  
 1989, P. J. Mason, Living Microbial Communities : Perspectives on the Conservation of Prevalence, ( publ. 1989 ), Ann Arbor, Michigan : Univ. of Michigan Press, 2nd ed., 1996.  
 1990, A. V. Johnson, The Microbial Problem in Agriculture ( publ. 1992 ), Ann Arbor, Michigan : Univ. of Michigan Press, 2nd ed., 1995.  
 1995, P. J. Mason, Microbiology in Communities : A Synthesis of the Ongoing Perspectives from Urban Microbiologists, ( publ. 1995 ), Ann Arbor, Michigan : Univ. of Michigan Press, 3rd ed., 1996.  
 1996, P. J. Mason, Homestead and Urban Microbiology, ( publ. 1997 ), Ann Arbor, Michigan : Univ. of Michigan Press, 3rd ed., 1997.  
 1997, P. J. Mason, N. W. Shapiro, and J. G. Lang, The Transport of Proteins by Marine Microorganisms in the Southern California Waterway, Bibliometrics, 13, 1–58, doi:10.2307/2449017.  
 1998, P. J. Mason, Van `` Mier '' de Samael, The Importance of the Moolacula Tolerant Microbial Community for the Control of Cryptosporidium and Prevotella Infection, ( publ. 1999 ), Ann Arbor, Michigan : Univ. of Michigan Press, 3rd ed., 1997.  
 1999, J. G. Lang, E. F. Coleman, A Life History and Dynamics Approach to Microbial Ecology, ( publ. 2000 ), Ann Arbor, Michigan : Univ. of Michigan Press, 3rd ed., 1996.  
 2000, J. G. Lang, S. A. Dutton, and A. V. Johnson, A Comparison of the Response of Marine Microbial Communities to Unconventional Types of Transmission, Bibliometrics, 14, 451–465, doi:10.2307/2530969.  
 2000, P. J. Mason and S. A. Dutton, Ammonia and Clostridium : An Interplay between Evolution and Entomology, Canadian Journal of Microbiology, 39, 35–57, doi:10.1139/cjm-0013-2000-00005.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Johannes Eberhard Gieglind =  
Johannes Eberhard Gieglind ( German : [ ˈjoːɡni ] ; 28 July 1773, Parn, Westphalia – 6 December 1820, Parn ) was a German Protestant theologian and philosopher.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Gieglind was born in Parn ( Kipfertz ) near Parn in 1773. His father was the Habsburg nobility minister and later the Bishop of Parn and the regional lord ; his mother was of ordinary Protestant religious status. After the first years of his education he studied in Breslau ( 1784–1786 ), in what is today East Prussia, in Paris and at the University of Breslau. In 1790 he entered Halle, and in 1791 he entered Breslau.  
 In 1797 he had succeeded to the rectory of Parn. In 1801 he resigned his rectory, moved to the Austrian-Hungarian territory and established the University of Halle, which was, however, broken up in 1809. From 1805 to 1810 he was Professor of Greek and Latin at the University of Vienna, and from 1812 to 1822 Professor of Comparative Religion and Philosophy at the University of Leipzig. From 1812 to 1820 he was in Baden. He spent in 1816 and 1817 the year in France, Paris, Berlin, St. Petersburg, Trent and other parts of Europe ; after that at Hamburg and finally in 1821 in Vienna, where he died in 1820.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 His major works include :  
   
 `` Vergleichende Belboutungen über die Elemente von der philosophicallogische Heimat '' ( 5 vols., 1822 )  
 `` Zur Angewandte Rhetorik '' ( 2 vols., 1825, 3rd and 4th edition 1826 )  
 `` Epistolae Baptista, episcoporum typum artium '' ( 6 vols., 1835–5, 6th edition 1837 )  
 `` Deutsche Mysterien '' ( 4 vols., 4 vols., 1837–8, 8th edition 1849 )  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Aimee Alfred Effenberg =  
Aimee Alfred Effenberg ( 5 August 1875 in St. Paul, Minnesota – 27 March 1967 in Memphis ) was an American organist, composer, and teacher.  
 She taught from 1909 until her death.  
 Effenberg was born in San Antonio, Texas. She studied composition under George Keller and composition with H. W. Keith. She completed her BA from Princeton Theological Seminary. From 1920 to 1925, she studied music composition with a faculty member from Schola Cantorum. She returned to New York City and studied with Alina Smith.  
 She taught from 1923 to 1927 at Shasta Valley College, continuing her musical studies at the Yerkes Conservatory. In 1931, she entered the United States Conservatory of Music, which she chaired for 11 years. In the 1930s, she moved to Princeton University in the chair of composition from which she retired in 1967. Her husband, photographer Walter Effenberg, was a correspondent of his and had made photographic albums of her early and later concerts.  
 The Effenberg Suite is a South American folk tradition and an important American herpetofauna.  
 The Field the Birds Sing album series was also recorded by Walter Effenberg and his wife in Nashville, where the Effenbergs had made many of their concerts.  
 Effenberg was married to actor Arthur Effenberg.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Joan Kilfadden =  
Joan Kilfadden ( 8 September 1893 – 19 November 1980 ) was a Norwegian marine biologist, sexologist and artist. Kilfadden was one of the founding members of the Norwegian SSR and later the Norwegian Marine Biological Society. She was a member of the first women's committee of the SSR and an author of articles on dolphin research and herding behaviour.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Kilfadden was born on 8 September 1893 in Svedesdalen to Lieutenant Edward Jan Pieter Kjølngen and Mary Madineen ( née Ørstedt ), who had moved to Kristiania from Norway and was pregnant with his child. Her daughter, Jørgen Sophie-Steen, was born in 1900. Kilfadden attended several schools in Norway, including the International School in Stockholm. In 1912, Kilfadden married Ernst Thomussen, with whom she had two daughters and one son. They had four children, two sons and one daughter.In 1914, Kilfadden and Thomussen decided to move to Saint Petersburg, but early in 1915 in Saint Petersburg's slums and at the University of Saint Petersburg, she taught biology in an undergraduate class. Her two sons were Peter and Anders. After training for a four-year scholarship, she completed studies in zoology and psychology at the University of Berlin in 1920, a year before joining the SSR.Kilfadden completed her PhD in 1925, under the supervision of Sir August Charles Francis Rudder, who worked on the dolphin and the forerunner of the marine cobra. In 1929, she was appointed associate professor of zoology at the University of Oslo. She published her thesis under the name The dolphin in 1925. Her later work involved the role of spermatozoon in copulation and their interactions in the laying of eggs. She was the chair of zoology at the University of Copenhagen from 1934 to 1940.Kilfadden became an associate professor at Princeton University in 1943. In 1946, she was named to the Stockholm Science Society, and chair of the Zoology department of the University of Oslo. She was first editor of the journal Biological Review from 1938 to 1943.In 1942, the Norwegian Government encouraged the establishment of the Norwegian Marine Biological Society, which was a response to the decline of the Faroe Islands at sea, because the women were unable to conduct research because the Menominee and Maori had only access to their home islands.She died in Stockholm on 19 November 1980.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Joachim Lejni =  
Joachim Lejni ( 6 October 1815, Basel – 9 August 1887 ) was a German scientist and engineer of science.  
 He was a notable mineralogist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 He was born in Basel, and studied at the University of Bremen, where he graduated as a pharmacist and chemist. In 1843 he became a pharmacist for Marburg railway company. Later, he became an assistant in chemistry in the botanical garden of Marburg.He was a member of the Linnaean Society of Basel.  
 In 1866 he was named a professor in botany at the University of Basel.  
   
   
 == Published works ==  
 He edited the mineralogische Gesellschaft der vermischen Gattung Basel in 1877, with contributions by Adolf Puls, Constantin Jörgens and Johann Bauer.  
 He also wrote Die Reisektorkanzeit and Zeitschrift für Mikroskopie, 1871-1876.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Thomas J. Woodman =  
Thomas Joseph Woodman ( April 20, 1925 – April 20, 1995 ) was an American mathematician and computer scientist, and one of the inventors of the graphical user interface ( GUI ). In 1958 he co-founded the department of computer science at New York University. From 1967 to 1990 he was Research Professor at Rutgers University. He died on April 20, 1995.  
   
   
 == Early life and education ==  
 Thomas J. Woodman was born in Niagara Falls, New York. He received his BA from the University of New Mexico in 1955 and his MA from the University of Michigan in 1958. He went on to earn a PhD from Rutgers University in 1960 and an M.A. from Duke University in 1964.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 Woodman was hired by Alcoa and later joined as its senior associate from 1965 until his retirement in 1997. In 1973 he joined IBM as director of Research and Technology and continued as senior associate from 1974 to 1979, remaining at IBM until 1990. During his time at IBM he wrote a series of seminal research papers on the measurement of large-scale quantities such as radioactivity and population density. These papers include the theory and design of IBM's New Thinking, the much-touted Digital Recorder, IBM Object Storage, a division of ALCOA that facilitated the development of early electronic calculator technology, and the measurement of density.  
   
   
 == Career at Rutgers University ==  
 Woodman became Professor of Computer Science at Rutgers University in 1977, a post he held for 29 years. From 1993 to 1998, he served as President of Rutgers'Department of Computer Science. The department continues to fund and support students pursuing post-graduate research.  
   
   
 == Awards ==  
 In 2002 Woodman received the World for Academic Achievement Award from the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers ( IEEE ) in recognition of his considerable career achievements. In 2018, his name became synonymous with the graphical user interface ( GUI ), an abstracted user interface designed to create simple yet functional computer-aided user interfaces ( UIs ) that have transformed the way humans interact with computers, not only as employers but also as creators. He was awarded the John von Neumann Memorial Prize in Systems Programming from the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers ( IEEE ) in 2018 for his contribution to graphical user interfaces. In 2019, he was elected to the IEEE Computer Society's Board of Directors and in 2019 he was inducted into the Computing Hall of Fame.  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Louis Fagan =  
Louis Fagan ( 11 May 1859 – 14 June 1944 ) was an American actor, known for his role as a doctor and supporter of the presidency. He played a chemist in several of the television shows of the 1940s and 1950s, including The Wonderful World of Osborn and Brace Yourself ( 1957 ). He also appeared in the TV movie The Web.  
   
   
 == Early life and education ==  
 Born in Cleveland, Ohio, Fagan studied at Cleveland High School, graduating from the Ohio State University in 1895. In 1898 he graduated from the University of Washington in Seattle, where he studied chemistry under Charles Edward Wilson, `` the father of chemical physics. '' His advisor was J. A. Oswald Wood, president of the University of Washington. After a brief stint as a chemist in Seattle, Fagan began acting in the drama Section 8 in 1907, singing and dancing as the Fagan Dancers. He did not enroll at the University of Washington, but transferred to the University of Washington School of Medicine, then studied medicine at the University of California, San Francisco, graduating in 1908 with a bachelor's degree in chemistry.  
   
   
 == Career ==

 Founder Director of the Washington Field Laboratory ( 1946 )

 Vice President, American Psychoanalytical Association ( 1954 )  
 President, American Nurses Association ( 1956 )  
 President, New England Psychoanalytic Society ( 1958 )  
 President, AAPE Psychoanalytic Society ( 1962 )  
 Retired Editor ( 1966 )  
   
   
 == In popular culture ==  
 In the television series Bones ( 1960 ), Elsasser had an important influence on the development of the actor James Brolin as psychologist Harold J. Margere.

<start_bio> 
 = Pavel Prokofiev =  
Pavel Makarovich Prokofiev ( Russian : Скач Алекса́ндр Со́чевич Комо́нов ; 15 April 1904 – 24 December 1982 ) was a Soviet author, zoologist and entomologist who worked extensively in Belarus. He is considered to be one of the most important of the twentieth-century Russian naturalists, and is one of the principal figures of the `` Belarusian Wrecking Crew '' who targeted the oilfield on the Lake Baikal in 1988.  
   
   
 == Life and career ==  
 Pavel Makarovich Prokofiev was born on 15 April 1904 in Poltava Oblast, Ukraine, the second son of Alexander Solzhenitsyn's brother Alexander Solzhenitsyn ( 1900–1951 ) and Mary Daniilovich ( née Wilson ). His mother was a nurse, whose family migrated to the village of Poltava from Russia in the 1830s. On 13 April 1925, Makarovich was born. Makarovich's older brother, Alexander, who was studying sciences, played as a guitarist in a band. He received musical lessons from the grandparents, before being educated at the local gymnasium ( Rakhamaretsi [ Dance Festival ] ) where he was taught music by Russian organist Vadim Kopetsky.  
 Makarovich entered the Ukrainian Paleontological Academy in Vilnez ( Pechnovsk ) in 1928, where his intellectual interest developed, having studied with his family.  
 In 1931, while still a student in Ukraine, Makarovich returned to Ukraine to work in the Paleontological Academy as a mineralogist. Makarovich won the Kyiv Philological Prize in 1932. By the end of the Second World War, Makarovich had returned to Poltava and married Susy ( 1909–1992 ), a teacher. Makarovich died on 24 December 1982.  
   
   
 == Quotations ==  
 `` Pumlin stars are fossilized mollusks with a liver in every one of them. They are considered unique as they can survive and grow in water where others have died.  
 `` `` In an interesting display of his scientific creativity, Dr. Makarovich also showed off the extreme individualism and freedom he enjoyed in his life.... Just when we thought he could remain a morose scientist in the milieu of rampant totalitarianism and the Great Purge, he turned from statistics and time constraints to large scale speculation on a broad variety of topics. These included the hitherto unreported development of the Pumlin-like organism from the Balakiella on Lake Baikal and its possible links with the molluscs and gastropods that inhabited the deposits. The books of the Ukrainian scientists that had disappeared in 1942 became the subject of very early 'new research on the geological histories of the Tatar republics. This was accompanied by a move from primitive mud crabs to hitherto undiscovered species of fish, e.g. the Bafalikid amphibians. Moreover the development of the scientific and technological world of air conditioning changed the lives of many in the Soviet Union. ''  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Fran C3 A7ois-César Émile Madec =  
François-Émile Madec ( 25 April 1833, Louvain – 4 April 1893, Poitiers ) was a Belgian geologist, specialist on fossil amphibians, from 1856 to 1879.  
 He studied in the University of Poitiers, under the watchful eye of Marcel Delp. His early scientific career was devoted to palaeontology in the area around Baarbeek, in eastern Belgium, covering much of the Lepperberg ( 1852 ) and Île-l'Ancien-Théorie ( 1858 ). Later he studied in the University of Paris, specializing in palaeontology in France.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 Madec, F. É. ( 1859 ), `` The formation of the upper Middle Mousterian Upper Cretaceous rocks of the Collina from the viewpoint of rock morphology '', in Tarde, J. ; Michel, M., La Capière du Musée c. Muséum du Louvain, Vol. I, pp. 63–68, Mémoires des sciences naturelles françaises.  
 Madec, F. É. ( 1877 ), Les séances fossiliens, Tables :  
 Pondicherry ( 1886 ), `` Fossil Ichthyosauria und Zählende Fossilichthyosauria ``, in Obovoy, L. : Sur une hémisphérique de la géologie des Pérouseurs, Vol. II, pp. 32–40, RSCO 4095.019  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = William Hooper (botanist) =  
William Heath Hooper FRSE FRCPE LLD ( 13 February 1846 – 17 December 1908 ) was a Scottish botanist.  
 He studied Agriculture and Forestry at Aberdeen University, where he obtained a BSc ( 1882 ) and MSc ( 1884 ) in 1889. Following further studies in India at the University of Calcutta, he returned to England to become assistant professor of Botany at the University of St Andrews. Thereafter he was appointed curator of botany in the Department of Agricultural Economics and a lecturer in Genetics at the college, and on his retirement became professor in 1910. He served as curator of botany at the Royal Horticultural Society in London from 1905 to 1913, and, thereafter, as manager of the Botanical Museum in Nairobi, Kenya. He was knighted in 1916. He is remembered in the agricultural literature for his contributions to plant taxonomy and for his work on the Coleoptera.Hooper contributed many papers on seeds and seed biology, and helped write the important by-then-popular textbook the Comparative Biography of the Two Fishes of Singapore. In 1906, he was awarded the inaugural Langer Medal of the Botanical Society of London, and in 1913 was elected its Fellow. He died in Canterbury, Kent, and is buried in Green Hills Cemetery in Cambridge.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 His six-volume “ Plant Life and Bibliography ” series ( 1909–53 ) dealt with seeds and seed production. The German Berne botanist Johann Christian Hering supplied some of the pollen ( 1884 ) and transgenic flora ( 1893 ) from one of Hooper's earlier publications, J. Pl. Ann. Bot. Soc. Lond. 43, pp. 43–87. Hering also supplied some genera and species.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Walter Hermann Schleh =  
Walter Hermann Schleh ( 13 October 1818 in Essen – 17 May 1897 in Jena ) was a German Lutheran theologian, born in Essen.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 He was educated at the Gymnasium in Jena and subsequently studied philosophy and theology at the theological college at Jena. He subsequently became associate professor in the theological college.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 Welt der indweltige Urtragung und seine Staatswissenschaft. Nachhaltungen über die Symbolen und Elementen der empirischen Religion ( 1795 ).  
 Lexikon der Galatians. Beschreibung der Einleitung der indweltige Liebe, Einleitung des gnomotoren ( Berlin, 1804 ).  
 Lehrbuch der christlichen Dogmatik und Altertumschichte ( 1813 ).  
 Verkündliche Anfänge ( 1822 ).  
 Hierographie und Darstellung. Gegenwart einer Leben, Einleitung zur Altertumschichte, Lehrbuch der christlichen Dogmatik und Altertumschichte ( Berlin, 1826 ).  
 Zur Lebenswirtschaft in der Orientalen rindgewichten, eines historischen Grammatik, eines philosophischen Grammatik und von der neueren Universität zu Berlin ( 1837 ).  
 Theologische Beobachtungen. Bericht über die Quellen und Vernunft. Einleitung in der theologischen Dogmatik des europas, einhalb den Städten berühmenden Literatur ( 1799 ).  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = William Woodward (meteorologist) =  
William Woodworth Woodward FRSE FRES ( 17 January 1820 – 15 May 1905 ) was an American geologist. He is sometimes also known as the man who made it possible for Americans to learn astronomy at home, and in his own lifetime, the name of Woodward ’ s University was co-opted. He is also known as one of the first pioneers of `` mathematics '' as a discipline.Woodward was born in 1820 in Austin, Texas to David Woodward and Ada M. Woodward. His father died when he was three. His mother was the sister of a surgeon at the Saint Louis Hospital. He attended the University of Texas and graduated with a BS in 1844, MS in 1846, and PhD in 1847.Woodward joined the Chemical Laboratory of the U.S. Geological Survey in 1852.He became a professor of physics at the University of Texas in 1859, and became assistant to J. L. McCormick in 1871. He taught mathematics in engineering classes at the University of Texas ( which was in Austin at the time ) in 1878-1882. He worked as an assistant in early structure and construction at the University of Texas until 1887.Woodward was a trustee of the University of Texas from 1904 until his death.  
   
   
 == Legacy ==  
   
 A street was named in his honor in Austin, this being the so-called Woodward,  
 honoring him. The president of the university became a celebrated composer ( born first, and buried in the Forest Hills Cemetery ).  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Joseph Leben =  
Joseph Friedrich Leben ( 3 December 1829 – 27 May 1912 ) was a German baritone of the 18th century.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Leben was born in Breslau, where his parents, Christian Leben and Ida Wilhelm were both choir boys. At the age of twelve he took up the professorship of flute and singing at the Deutscher Berichtelle of Breslau, later making his professional debut in Prussia in 1864.  
 In 1865 he took up his degree of Doctor of Music and was for a time a teacher at the Higher University of Breslau ( now the Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich ). Leben died there, aged 78, from a heart attack at the age of 84.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Alexandre Huberman =  
Alexandre Huberman ( 6 October 1898 – 6 August 1973 ) was a French pianist, composer and conductor. He worked with such eminent musicians as Guillaume Cailliet, Rodolphe Lorentz, Alphonse Frères, André Gounod, Joseph-Édouard Orchard, and Etienne Golomb. He was a pupil and interpreter of Liszt and Marcel Proust, and collaborated with him throughout his musical life.  
   
   
 == Life and career ==  
 Born in Paris, Huberman made his debut in 1927. He won the Prix du piano at the Conservatoire de Paris in 1935, followed by the Prix des transports de Paris in 1937. He also performed with the pianist Alexandre Huberman. He became a member of the Musikhochschule Karlsruhe in 1938, and in 1946 moved to L'Opéra-Comique. In 1954 he became Principal of the Karlsruhe Conservatory. In 1962 he was appointed professor at the Karlsruhe Conservatory, and continued as a professor until he retired. He taught at the Juilliard School and the Alte Press School from 1966 to 1968. From 1973 to 1975, he was conductor of the Karlsruhe Philharmonic Orchestra.  
   
   
 == Selected works ==  
 Die Freige Artiste, Radio Gothenburg, 1927.  
 La Vie en pour cas de composer, 1934.  
 la pièce, 1939.  
 Ouverture, 1940.  
 Two Dances with Arsène Graff, 1941.  
 Impromptus, 1942.  
 Aphrodite, 1945.  
 Duo berserk ; 1 ’ Invention, 1946.  
 Une promenade d'un coppé onette, 1950.  
 Fantasia in D, 1941.  
 Julie, 1994 ( LP reissue from the 1939 broadcast ).  
 Suite triode, 1966.  
 Ta'mi, 1968.  
 Ariane, 2006.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Aubrey Daniel Burnside =  
Aubrey Daniel Burnside ( June 15, 1888 – November 7, 1964 ) was an American microbiologist who, at age 60, published his first paper in the journal Nature. He later served as Director of the Herbarium at Columbia University.  
 Burnside received a B.S. in chemistry from the University of California at Berkeley and a Ph.D. in zoology from the University of Chicago. He served as Professor of Pharmacology and Pathology in the Chicago College of Physicians and Surgeons. Burnside was a longtime scientific advisor to the FBI. In the course of his research, he discovered Aplysia bicolor, which he named after himself.  
   
   
 == Early life ==  
 Burnside was born in Lowell, Massachusetts, on June 15, 1888, the son of Annie Morton Burnside and Ralph Daniel Burnside. His family moved to New Haven, Connecticut, when he was 3 years old. He was a year shy of his 18th birthday when he took his first science class. He attended Yale University and graduated Phi Beta Kappa in 1931. His major was biology but he also wanted to be a surgeon. He entered Yale College in 1932, after completing his undergraduate education. He remained there for the rest of his undergraduate studies, earning a master's degree in anatomy in 1935. He also received a Ph.D. in biology from Yale in 1936. He worked briefly as an assistant to an electrician before being recruited into the Herbarium in 1929.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 After completing his undergraduate work, Burnside joined the New Haven Public Health Department, serving as the main researcher for their `` Territorialism Unit ''. In 1932, he became a full professor, in 1934 he became director of the Herbarium. In 1942, he returned to Columbia University to become the director of the Gen. Sheets Laboratory for Medical Microbiology. In 1946, he joined the Union Carbide company as a manager. From 1946 to 1948, he was the curator of the New Haven Natural History Center and by 1948, he became an editor of the Journal of American Microbiology.Burnside became an assistant curator of the herbarium and head of the laboratory of cytology and genetics in 1946, an associate curator in 1947, and director of the Herbarium in 1950. Burnside was the chief bacteriologist for the Department of State in 1968 and served as the United States Ambassador to Switzerland from 1949 until his death on November 7, 1964. Burnside worked to help eliminate the diseases of microorganisms, especially the antibiotic-resistant and Enterococcus species.Burnside suffered a heart attack on November 7, 1964, and died at the age of 60 in the hospital of New York City.  
   
   
 == Family ==  
 Aubrey Daniel Burnside married Marian Elizabeth Starkey on March 25, 1913, at the Lowry School for Girls. They had three daughters, Dorothy Ann, Sarah Ann, and Cecilia Mary.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Glenn A. Adams =  
Glenn A. Adams ( February 2, 1926 – August 15, 1995 ) was an American microbiologist.  
   
   
 == Early life and education ==  
 Glenn Adams was born in New York City, where his family moved after his father was named director of the Carl Eric Hall Laboratories in New York. In 1947, he completed his B.S. in biochemistry from Columbia University, where he also obtained his M.S. and Ph.D. degrees in biochemistry.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 In 1958, Adams moved to the University of California, Berkeley to work at the Edward Hermann-Gross School of Biochemistry. While in Berkeley, Adams won a Fulbright scholarship to the Pasteur Institute in Paris. In 1962, he was a student at the University of Chicago's Department of Pathology, where he founded the bacteriology department.  
 In 1967, Adams obtained a Ph.D. in biochemistry at Columbia University. Adams published his work on infant lymphoma in 1968 and was one of two graduate students to serve as the first supervisors of the new research laboratory for the National Cancer Institute at the NIH, under director of radiation oncology Harold N. Grimes.  
   
   
 == Award ==  
 Glenn Adams was awarded the Riddell Humanitarian Award ( 1981 ) by the Michigan Academy of Child Health ( 1985 ).  
   
   
 == Personal life ==  
 He married Kaye Wu in 1970. They had two children, Roger Daubenton Adams and Susan Henry Adams.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Agustín de Echino =  
Agustín de Echino ( A. née Peres, Spanish : [ ɑbɐʁe̯ aɡwiˈvɛte ] ; Portuguese : [ ɑbɐʁen spahvˈtɛntɛˈfʁa ] ; 15 January 1821 – 18 July 1881 ) was a Spanish anatomist, surgeon, taxonomist and botanist. He worked on experiments with flagellates. His publications on natural history include A Treatise on Oligopolysaccharides, and Descriptive Zoology, and on the number and distribution of molluscs.  
   
   
 == Early life ==  
 Echino was born in Acapulco ( nowadays Valencia ), Spain.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 He first worked at the Spanish Museum in Mar del Plata as a curator in 1832, and he then went to Spain to work at the Botanic Garden of Barcelona, being elected a fellow of that institution in 1841.  
 Echino investigated mollusks and shells for publications on the other departments at the Botanic Garden. He published Historia de fauna terrestris ( 1842 ) and Macropoda et mollusciens de la création ( 1845 ). In 1851 he was appointed head of the newly founded Department of Zoology in the Natural History Museum of Madrid.  
 The main focus of his studies, including fauna of different regions, was the artichomatosis and distribution of these microscopic worms.  
 He is considered as one of the founders of the study of the mollusca of Spain.  
   
   
 == Accolades ==  
 In 1899, the Lobelia of Spain award was instituted by the Argentine Academy of Sciences for his achievements.  
 In 1911, a centenary special event was organized in the northern part of the island of Spain with an exhibit centering around the study of botany in the island, as well as the centennial celebrations of the Artillerie de la Gran de Mallorca.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Gottlob Wilhelm Janisch =  
Gottlob Wilhelm Janisch ( 5 August 1828 – 2 March 1893 ) was a Danish naturalist, botanist and entomologist.  
   
   
 == Early life ==  
 Janisch was the son of August Wilhelm Janisch and Eugenia Nathrakh.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 On 13 April 1852, he obtained a scholarship at Aarhus University, where he studied under August Anders Muutzer and with Fredrik Naerblad. He was named a professorial fellow on 4 July 1862, and was appointed professor at St. Petersburg University in 1863. In 1874 he moved to Copenhagen, and in 1883, professor of natural history at the university. In 1891, he became botanist at the Museum of Natural History and Geography, where he became a full professor in 1894. He had a great reputation in his field. In 1905, he became assistant at the museum. In 1911, he became director general of the ministry of natural sciences. His early publications, on vegetation, on insects and on molluscs, brought him many honors. His Tropical Plants of East Asia and Africa was the first important work on the subject, and is still used for comparative studies of vegetation. Other works he wrote during his professional career include :  
   
 Biographie dans le geographie des mollusques du Luxembourg ( 1895 )  
 Vostokazkan op a drohstet onensøg til brukke andering, kunstgode zoologiske og bog & finlander og zoologisk mot på koopman ( 1913 )  
 Handbuch der Entomologie zoologischen Verein ( 1894 ), 2 volumes, 2 parts ( 1897-1903 )  
   
   
 == Recognition ==  
 In 1896, his work Flora Bibliotheca Orbis was named in his honor.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Lucien Rogin =  
Lucien Rogin ( 21 May 1894 – 24 June 1965 ) was a French pianist and conductor of French Jewish descent.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Rogin was born at Aisne-de-France, the elder son of Leonard Howard Rogin and Frances Marie Haddad. After completing his studies at the Conservatoire de Paris, Rogin received a scholarship to conduct the Charles Fourier Conservatory in Bordeaux. He became a full professor in 1905. In 1921, he began teaching as a professor of piano. He was the Principal of the Deutsches Choral Academy in Berlin from 1931 to 1934. He was the organist of the Eastern Catholic Roman Catholic Church for a period in Düsseldorf, Belgium. He also made many concert appearances.  
 On the outbreak of World War II, he was imprisoned in an internment camp near the Wartime parades in and around Berlin.In 1941, with the outbreak of the second world war, Rogin was arrested by the Gestapo as an enemy alien. He was sent to the Dachau concentration camp on 20 November 1942, along with 46 others, charged with their part in the preparation of the Nazi gas chambers. Rogin was released in 1946, and from 1945 until 1948, worked as a professor of the Opera and Music Academy of New York. In 1947, he was appointed to the head of the Department of Artistic Appreciation, at the Juilliard School, a post he held until his retirement in 1962.In 1950, Rogin joined the faculty at Saint Petersburg Conservatory of Music, and served as its first Director of Music from 1954 to 1956.Following the death of his wife, Marjorie in 1954, Rogin married Martha Koby ( 1888–1991 ). They had two daughters, Nina and Eva. In 1965, Rogin died in Saint Petersburg, at the age of 77. His official obituary was published by the Los Angeles Times.  
   
   
 == Teaching ==  
 Rogin taught at the Juilliard School from 1928 until his retirement in 1962. In addition to his conductorship, he taught at the American Conservatory of Music, the University of Michigan, the American Jewish College and the Music College of the Conditamento Orientale in Moscow. His pupils included Maurice Ravel, Richard Barthel, Joan Emerson, Serge Fanel, Paul Gielen, and Willi Halperin.  
   
   
 == Selected works ==  
 26 Songs of Illumination in the Piano Sonata Op.39, piano, 1939  
 Sonatina in C minor, piano, 1945  
 6 Positions in C major, piano, 1947  
 Harmonise Concerto No.2 in D major, piano, 1954  
 Four Songs in E minor, piano, 1955  
 Concerto in G major, piano, 1957  
 Divertimento in F major, piano, 1961  
 Beethoven's Comet Suite No.2 in D minor, piano, 1963  
 Della Minora in D major, piano, 1966  
 How to Sound Your Teeth, piano, 1969  
 Improvisation No.3 in D major, piano, 1971  
 Prelude and Fugue in D minor, piano, 1974

 Fantasy in D major, piano, 1988  
 Introduction in E-flat major, guitar, 1991  
 Prelude in G major, piano, 1995  
 Détudes ( with Peter Sayers ), piano, 1996  
 22 Sonatinaes ( with Peter Sayers ), piano, 2000  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Myra Bancroft =  
Myra Zuckerman Bancroft ( June 3, 1874 – March 31, 1953 ) was an American physician, biologist and educator. She was the oldest person to make a record of a red deer moult and was awarded a bronze medal by the National Wildlife Federation in 1936 for her work.Bancroft graduated from Harvard Medical School in 1907. She taught at the Harvard College of Physicians and Surgeons.
