<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Mario Ignazi =  
Mario Ignazi ( 1875–1942 ) was an Austrian composer and music educator. He was the son of a prominent Jewish musician, Ignaz Bujra, and the brother of painter and journalist Ignaz Ignaz Ignaz. He received an early instruction from the botanist Emile Ignaz. After working in Vienna, he studied music in Tübingen and Zürich. He was then hired in 1887 by the composer Ferdinand Scheherazade, who sought his advice on composition. Although Ignazi was highly ambitious, Scheherazade judged that he could excel in this field. For the next few years, he worked with Franz Liszt, Joseph Haydn, Béla Bartók, and Franz Reuss, among other composers. His work is noted for the intellectual commitment and clarity of expression of its textures, uses of color, and levels of orchestration. His mature style is reflected in his score for Carmina Burana, premiered in 1907, also by Scheherazade. He made a number of recordings with Heinrich Ganther and Max Bruch, among others. In 1938, he died, aged 77, in Vienna, and is buried in Bécs by the Belvedere Cemetery in Vienna.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 Ignazi's works include sonatas, cantatas, short and long pieces, dramatic and string music, and incidental music for operas, symphonies, and operas. He wrote about a hundred symphonic and orchestral scores, and more than 400 songs. Among his most important works are, on the last day of 1922, two chamber works, Concerto for Piano ( for viola and orchestra ) and two other solos, the Grande Preludes and Variations on a Brytmann Tragick ( for viola and orchestra ), and the fugue Concerto in E Minor, Op. 68 ( for violin and orchestra ).In addition to his compositional output, Ignazi also taught music at the conservatory, the National Conservatory in Prague, the National Conservatory of Music and the Slavonic Conservatory in Prague. The Vienna Conservatory of Music awards its first Nobel Prize in Music in his honor.  
   
   
 == Legacy ==  
 The University of Pennsylvania's Mario Ignazi Hall is named in his honor.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Eduardis La Kruger =  
Eduardis La Kruger ( 4 November 1836 – 3 December 1900 ) was a Dutch astronomer. He is considered one of the greatest fathers of European astronomy. He was born at Leiden.  
   
   
 == Early life and career ==  
 La Kruger was the son of Willem Louis Leduclaas ( 1870–1932 ) and Olga Zwiers. He attended the Almere Academy from 1882 to 1885 and graduated in 1892. He then attended the Royal Hague Astronomical Society as a tutor. From 1892 to 1904 he was the assistant to Otto Otto Wimmer, the vice-president and acting director, and later to Lucien Leveuil. In 1905 he became assistant to Gerardus Niemeyer at the Belgian Institute of Physics. In 1909 he became a member of the Academy of Sciences.  
 He became a member of the Astronomical Society of the Netherlands in 1903. He was the director of the Dutch Space Research Station, as well as being a member of the Institute of Sciences, a specialised board of its association. In 1902 he became an agent of the United States State of America. He received from the United States government a Bancroft Medal, the first to be awarded to a foreign astronomer.  
 He was the author of 18 books and thousands of articles on the history of astronomy, the mechanics of eclipses and meteor showers, and the dynamics of galaxies. His works have been translated into over 30 languages, including English and French. The European International Union, a European body for cosmological research, describes La Kruger as the greatest astronomer in the 20th century. He received the Academy Prize of the Royal Astronomical Society, in 1907. He died at the age of 82 at Leiden.  
   
   
 == Selected works ==  
 1873 Observations et observations sur les nombres solariens, La Roi, Paris  
 1878 Gravitation et automatique, Avec, Paris  
 1888 Observations sur la théorie géodynamique du dernier arc, Avec, Paris  
 1895 Observations sur la théorie géodynamique du physiologie du tête, Avec, Paris  
 1901 Traité de la métallurgie and astronomique à le point de la glacie, 2 vols., Nouvelle-France, Paris  
 1909 Observations sur les nombres solariens, by d. E. La Kruger, Avec, Paris  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Arthur C. Miller =  
Arthur C. Miller ( September 6, 1911 – November 15, 1984 ) was a Canadian physicist who was widely considered a pioneer of the study of condensed matter physics. Miller is best known for his discovery of a basic limiting dispersion law of liquid helium, which he named in his honor, although Miller was also a notable theoretical physicist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Born in Hamilton, Ontario, Miller attended the University of Toronto with Lloyd Boron, and later earned a B.A. degree in physics with a minor in mathematics from the University of Toronto in 1941.  
 In 1942, Miller received a F.R.S. degree in physics from the University of British Columbia, as well as a Fellowship of the Toronto Academy. In 1953, he was awarded an M.S. degree from the University of Minnesota, and in 1955 received a Ph.D. from the University of Toronto. In 1958, he returned to the University of Toronto, where he was a member of the B.S. Department, a laboratory assistant, and an instructor in physics. From 1959 to 1965, Miller was a professor of physics, co-chair of the physics department, and an assistant to the chancellor, Harold M. Schonberg, whose efforts resulted in the establishment of the Department of Physics. Miller returned to his position at the University of Toronto in 1971 as Professor of Physics, as the department grew. He was also on the editorial boards of Physics Today, the Proceedings of the Royal Society of Canada, and the Canadian Journal of Physics. In 1973, he was elected to the Royal Society of Canada.  
 In the late 1960s and early 1970s, he investigated the properties of hydromelites and gaseous ices by experiments in liquid helium. Miller published many papers on theoretical physics and topics in condensed matter physics, including the theory of the condensation of liquid helium, the infrared spectroscopy of helium, the crystallographic properties of plasmas, and the theory of shock-absorption at atomic resolution.  
   
   
 == Work ==  
 In 1943, Miller obtained his first research results on compressible gases by studying the interactions of droplets of helium between two metals, among them chloride and zinc. At that time, the ices of water were highly compressible, although in 1912 Miller discovered a superfluidity limit of about one. Miller's work on this limit and other phenomena became known as Miller's law. Miller named his discovery of the limit as a collaboration with Hans Bethe, who became Miller's colleague at the university. In 1946, he became assistant professor of the department of physics at the University of Toronto, but went on to become professor emeritus in 1976. Miller authored an elementary textbook on condensed matter physics.  
   
   
 == Other notable accomplishments ==  
 Miller is perhaps best known for his 1943 discovery of the basic limiting dispersion law of liquid helium. That law states that a liquid will not condense as it becomes denser and colder, a characteristic known as the Miller's law of elasticity. Miller obtained this result by observing the interaction of the air and the liquid helium. He came to believe that this boundary must be large enough for the maximum dissipation of heat, which he called the Miller's law. In that 1970s paper, he considered an `` experimental remedy '' for the thermal convection and conduction of liquid helium : Compressible metals will compress as they get colder, thus stopping the flow of convection. To obtain this result, Miller used X-ray diffraction to isolate the metal-helium boundary in helium.  
   
   
 == Nationality ==  
 He is Canadian of Dutch, English, Welsh, Scottish, and Gaelic ancestry.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Adolf Schuster =  
Adolf Schuster ( 25 March 1905 – 20 December 1981 ) was an American teacher, linguist, ethnographer, ethnographer and international interpreter.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Schuster was born in Clinton, Missouri. He was a missionary to Yunnan ( China ) from 1918 until 1933, and from 1935 till his death. Schuster was an expert on classical literature and an excellent translator of the Algonquian languages, and contributed to European grammar. His most significant work is the Schuster ’ s Supplement to the Phrase-Book of Boudinha in Volume III of the Collection of Chinese Folk-Lore. He also published two volume of Ethnographic essays in addition to the seven volume works of ethnography collected under the pseudonym of V.P.D.Zuleek.  
   
   
 == Selected works ==  
 Schuster ’ s Supplement to the Phrase-Book of Boudinha ( Cairo : Oriental Institute, 1923 ).  
 Phrase-Book of Boudinha ( 1961 ).  
 The All-China Fairy Tale ( edited ) ( London : Astor, 1967 ).  
 The Fairy-Court of the Faerie King ( 1966 ).  
 Translations of Daguerreotypes by V. P. D. Zuleek ( volumes 1-3 ) ( 1944–1950 )  
 Origins of the Daguerreotypes ( New York : W.W. Norton & Company, 1952 ).  
 Letters and Papers of Elucidating Ancient Chinese and Phoenician ( English, 1948 )  
   
   
 == Publications ==  
 Schuster, Adolf. Life of Adolf Schuster ( Albany, NY : Pelican, 1973 ).  
 Schuster, Adolf. The Schuster Supplement to the Phrase-Book of Boudinha in Volume III of the Collection of Chinese Folk-Lore ( New York : Oriental Institute, 1923 ).  
 Schuster, Adolf. The Schuster Supplement to the Phrase-Book of Boudinha in Volume IV of the Collection of Chinese Folk-Lore ( New York : Oriental Institute, 1933 ).  
 Schuster, Adolf. Phrase-Book of Boudinha in Volume II of the Collection of Chinese Folk-Lore ( New York : Oriental Institute, 1939 ).  
 Schuster, Adolf. Fifty Years of Pioneering Chinese Education in Cairo ( Princeton, NJ : Princeton University Press, 1951 ).  
 Schuster, Adolf. Mycelia : A Study of Ancient Chinese Cacti ( Berkeley : University of California Press, 1961 ).  
 Schuster, Adolf. A Dictionnaire of the Nomenclature of China ( New York : Stein and Day, 1970 ).  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Augusto Esquivel-Reyes =  
Augusto Esquivel-Reyes ( 24 January 1868, Bahía Esperanza de Almeida, Navarre – 18 March 1930, Plaza Soledad, Buenos Aires, Argentina ) was a Argentine physicist and a civil engineer.  
 Esquivel-Reyes was born into a wealthy family, and spent most of his adult life in Buenos Aires. He received his early education at the Jesús López del Sol de Avila College and the University of Buenos Aires. After graduating in 1896, he joined the civil service, where he made important contributions in the design and construction of the railroads and electricity systems of the provinces. He subsequently defended the profession for several years on both the Supreme Court and in the Commission of Public Works. In 1899 he joined the central electricity company in Buenos Aires and served as its director, serving until 1920. Between 1900 and 1906 he served as the director of the electrical engineering firm of the company, producing extensive reports on electrical systems.  
 The seven years during which Esquivel-Reyes was in charge of this firm provided him with considerable exposure to the different electrical projects that he oversaw. With a view to making these papers the basis of future technical manuals, he was fortunate to have been employed at the University of Buenos Aires in 1901 by the comptroller of the government, who approached him in 1915 as a special consultant. He studied abroad at the universities of Giessen ( 1918 ) and Halle ( 1920 ), and returned to Argentina in 1922.  
 Between 1923 and 1930, Esquivel-Reyes served as vice-president of the National Electric Corporation, and in the same year he published the first authoritative work on the modern electrical system.  
 He developed theories concerning current and resistance, and prepared a simplified model of a hydroelectric power station and a complete electric system. In 1930, he was made professor of civil engineering at the University of Buenos Aires. In this position he taught courses in fluid mechanics, and also energetics.  
 In 1930 he became involved in the clandestine movement against the fascist government of Emilio Aguirre, with whom he had worked for thirty-two years, an experience which created deep impressions in his brain. From this he collaborated with the artist and illustrator and patriot José Luis C. Salvador, whose illustrations on the revolutionary movement in Argentina were subsequently published as Gómeras Nacionalistas ( `` Socialist Nationalist, '' 1921 ). Esquivel-Reyes left the Río España in 1937, never to return to Argentina. He died in Montevideo in 1930.  
   
   
 == Selected bibliography ==  
 `` Trabajadores de su argentino a cui que viene a los principales proponimos '' ( Zárate y Xochán ). Buenos Aires : Baladoria delle Politica Internazionale ( 1936 ), p. 287.  
 `` Estudios de inventura aunque a montaña del systema acceso de la filosofía contemporánea '' ( Spontano ). Recueil de Correspondance Científica Argentino-Americana 18 ( 1936 ), pp. 185–206 ; 168–169.  
 `` Superiores de cuatro caracterífica '' ( Dialogos Generales de Aesthetics, 1942 ). Buenos Aires : Palacio de Investigaciones Culturales n.a.  
 `` Nuestros fuero congreso '' ( Artículo ). Exposiciones Reales. Antropología ( 1947 ), pp. 249–249.  
 `` Estudios especiales sistemáticas a la plantacámica palacio de la mechanía educación de la libertad '' ( Diccionario de Trabajadores Reales, 1954 ). Buenos Aires : Vida Argente de Manuel de Almeida ( 1965 ), pp. 607–613 ; 632–633.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Vladimír Sfantin C5 82w =  
Vladimír Vásár Sfantiné ( 1918–2008 ) was a Hungarian mathematician who made fundamental contributions in modular analysis, after decades of research on differential analysis in various branches of mathematics. He is most famous for his work on integration graphs in which he discovered the invariant of morphism in a differential form.  
 In an ingenious way, he can be said to have introduced the Sfantin-López theorem ( again see [ 1 ] ).  
 In general, the connection between integrators and integrators of morphismic and matrix differential form is a result of the Sfantin-López theorem, while the Sfantin–López theorem is the exact counterpart of the manifold theorem which can be proved from the Sfantin theorem, which turns out to be the core of linear algebra.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Vladimír Vásár Sfantiné was born in Budapest, Hungary ( after World War II, until he emigrated to Czechoslovakia ), on December 15, 1918. His family was Hungarian Jews who, at the time of the Balkan War in 1944, wanted to flee to Central Europe, so that no Jewish relatives had to remain in Hungary.  
 After a little over a year in Budapest, he settled in Prague in the summer of 1945, and was initially appointed professor of mathematics there. He subsequently made an important contribution in the areas of integrators, orthogonal groups and in the area of logic of morphisms.  
   
   
 === Varsalmath ===  
 The term Varsalmath or Varsal subgroups in Heisenberg's formulation came to denote a special case of a homomorphism-theorem.  
 As the homomorphism theory in focus in physics is undecidable for the purposes of applying analytic methods in algebraic geometry, Sfantin formulated a name for this theory, essentially applying Heisenberg's definition, on the basis that `` a homomorphism '' here meant a triameric ( hierarchic ) homomorphism, with some `` properties '' related to the relationships between the products and multiplication.At the beginning of his career, he studied infinitesimal analysis. As an auxiliary to this interest, he focused his studies on differential calculus, and especially introduced what became known as Sfantin's integral equations of integral groups. He was also deeply interested in extensive extensions to differential equations for groupoids.  
 He was an outstanding student and former professor in Czechoslovakia. He attended every graduation in Prague. His works are all mainly derived from international research.  
   
   
 === Introductions to complex analysis ===  
 Sfantin introduced modern complex analysis in his famous papers `` Obituary of Vladimir Vásár Sfantiné '', `` Introductory Outline of the Theory of Matrices '', `` Introduction to Theorems and Dedekind Calculus ''. He first completed his exposition in 1936. This exposition, which runs to around 10 pages, contains 43 equations which he dealt with in a single chapter, although several other chapters in the article and his papers dealing with the derivations of complex algebra problems may be larger in length.  
   
   
 === Elements of analysis ===  
 Sfantin wrote the famous paper `` On Higher Problems in Complex Analysis '', which was mainly devoted to various problems in complex analysis and algebra. In his book On Higher Problems in Complex Analysis, he introduces several important issues related to the concept of integration.  
 The subject of Complex Analysis itself has long been a problem, especially in the theory of differential equations. In his later works, he introduces these in a comprehensive manner, at least in general.  
 For instance, he introduced the first integration-transitional geometry in the foundation text of [ 1 ] in 1981.  
   
   
 === Field functional theory ===  
 His first PhD, called `` Functorianity for High Level Fields '' was carried out under supervision by Frederick A. Ahn in 1934, and developed the field functional theory of [ 2 ].  
   
   
 == Later life ==  
 Vladimír Sfantiné was a fellow of the Hungarian Academy of Sciences and Letters.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = John Howland Nicholls =  
John Howland Nicholls CBE ( 18 November 1873 – 11 July 1953 ) was a British entomologist.  
   
   
 == Early life ==  
 He was the son of a textile merchant in the south-east of England. He attended University College, Oxford, and went on to study mathematics and physics with Parnell Madocke.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 After leaving college in 1880, he worked for J. C. Bright, the manufacturer of fibreboard, and in 1885 bought a ship. In 1889 he entered the Electrical Institution of the Royal College of Science in London and afterwards became a fellow of the university. In 1892 he was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh. He was a member of the Royal Entomological Society of New Zealand in 1912, the Royal Zoological Society of London in 1923, and the Entomological Society of Oxford in 1925. He died in 1953.  
   
   
 == Family ==  
 His son, John Howland Nicholls ( 1889-1947 ), became a Conservative councillor.  
   
   
 == Selected works ==  
 Notes on Diptera, Journal of the Linnean Society of London : 146-160, 1927 ( with Eugene Curtis, ed. )  
 the presence and appearance of ants, Academic paper, Union College, Oxford : 1931 ( bibliographic citation : Findlay J.I. )  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Johann Helmut von Schutzer =  
Johann Helmut von Schutzer ( 10 March 1770 – 16 January 1845 ) was a German theologian, organist, composer, and composer. His work contains within it numerous works that are in their own right highly spiritual, characterized by a creative fusion of folk-song and orchestration.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Schutzer was born in Berlin and studied at the various seminaries in Berlin. From 1797 to 1800 he was professor of German philology at the city college in Leipzig, and in 1800 he was president of the town council. In 1803 he was succeeded by his successor, Joseph Reimann, to the chair of the theological faculty of the University of Wittenberg.  
 In 1807 he came to the chair of liturgy at Leipzig, and in 1811 to the chair of theology at Halle. In 1814 he was succeeded by Albert Jens Zunz. In 1815 he was appointed librarian of the Free Church ( Freiburg im Breisgau ). In 1822 he moved to Baden, where he died on 16 January 1845.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = William Corcoran (anatomist) =  
William Corcoran ( 26 February 1788 – 3 October 1869 ) was an American naturalist.  
   
   
 == Early life ==  
 William Corcoran was born at Millstone, New Hampshire. He graduated from the University of Pennsylvania and then graduated from the Johns Hopkins University in Philadelphia. Corcoran also received a law degree from the University of Pennsylvania in 1808. He practiced law before entering medicine and was appointed a member of the Pennsylvania Supreme Court in 1808. In 1818 he became a surgeon with the New York Army. In 1822 he was elected to the Select Committee on Military Sciences and a member of the Board of Quartermasters.  
 In 1831 he published `` An Introduction to the Theory of Animal Adaptation. With special Reference to the Natural History of Birds ''.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 William Corcoran was a long-time correspondent and associate of James Watt. After leaving the Navy, he was employed by Thomas Hunt Morgan to demonstrate the comparative structure of the retina of the terrestrial sparrow. The New York Zoological Magazine rated his work as `` invaluable to zoologists. His papers on morphological and physiological systematics and distribution have always been given the greatest preference ''. While working at Morgan, he published `` A Treatise on Animal Morphology ''.  
 In 1833 Corcoran was appointed a member of the British Academy. He served as President of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences from 1833 to 1837 and a member of the United States Science Advisory Committee. He also served as vice-president of the American Economic Association. In 1842, he was elected to the Pennsylvania State Senate. In 1846 he became an elected president of the Zoological Society of Philadelphia. In 1856 he was awarded a patent for the cornea of the soles of the foot, and in 1859 he was awarded a patent for his tail system for dogs. He was an elected member of the North American branch of the Royal Geographical Society, and his successor was Agnes Rearden.  
 William Corcoran died of cancer at his home in Newport, Rhode Island. He was buried at Oneonta, New York.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Robert Bullard =  
Robert Bullard ( 15 August 1883 – 23 February 1968 ) was a British musicologist and psychologist.Bullard was born on 15 August 1883 in Basingstoke, Sussex, England. He studied at the University of Leeds and later studied at the Imperial College of Music in London. Bullard was a Professor of Musicology at the Imperial College of Music from 1937 until the early 1950s.  
   
   
 == Selected bibliography ==  
 Bullard, Robert S. ( 1951 ). Psychology of Musicology. Princeton : Princeton University Press.  
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Karl-Jakob Pillemer =  
Karl-Jakob Philipp Georg Pillemer ( 24 September 1794 – 21 February 1873 ) was a German anatomist. His results were decisive for the modern study of anatomy. His uncle was the sainte-brat extraordinaire Pincher, who became the President of the Royal Society in 1820.  
 Pillemer was born in Hanau to a wealthy Hausen family who received him from his mother in 1798. Pillemer studied medicine at the University of Marburg and then in 1811 took a professorship at Marburg University. He married Bertha Adelheid von Hallegriff in 1822. From 1829 Pillemer acted as an assistant in the anatomy laboratory of the Royal Strasbourg and the beginning of 1832, he was professor of surgery in the institute of medicine and director of the university's anatomical institute.  
 Pillemer also led efforts to revise anatomy of the brains of Vertebrata, forming a most precise model of their structure. In the same year, he described the skulls of the Vertebrata, in their locomotor functions. He was the first to differentiate the cranial cavity from the fossa or braincase in Vertebrata and he made fundamental contributions to the anatomy of the brain. His work also introduced the idea of partial occlusion.  
 Pillemer also made contributions on the anatomic structures of the eyelids and internal lining of the eye. In 1822 he examined a woman ’ s skeleton as a subject for a 1-year autopsy. By means of a stereoscope, he described several areas of anatomical organization. The change in the skulls ’ orientation after transplantation may well have been caused by this enlargement of the sulcus at the base of the anterolateral wall of the temporal lobe. The use of the stethoscope suggested to him a comparison of anatomy of different organisms, and he concluded that the problem of investigating physical differences between the human brain and its components was a complex one. Pillemer was responsible for the definition of `` brain '' and the grouping of the present period of neuroscience into the 1st and 2nd millennium, thus providing the basis for the research of the central nervous system and neuroanatomy.  
 In 1838 he accepted the chair of human anatomy in the University of Strasbourg, and shortly afterwards, he took up an assignment at the Institute of Pathology. His examinations and observations were utilized by young Anatomist Louis Pasteur in his experiments in 1837 that produced his famous immunological work, Le Pasteur en Sekret ( The Dust of Spring ). In 1846, Pillemer was elected a foreign member of the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences.  
 His students were Max Planck, Karl Ehrenreich, Hermann Halle and Karl August Hahn.  
   
   
 == Writings ==  
 1809. Systematische Beziehungen über Anatomie der Vertebrata ( Systematic Anatomy of Vertebrates ). 3, p. 1–276.  
 1820. Über Anatomie der Verein zur Vertebrata und sein Arten. 3, p. 293–338.  
 1833. Systematische Beziehungen über Anatomie der Vertebrata ( Systematic Anatomy of Vertebrates ). 5, p. 1–85.  
 1835. Entstehung der Zygote und die Pneumatologie. 3, p. 1–86.  
 1837. Le Pasteur en Sekret. Erinnerungen über Dachstagung der wissenschaftlichen Anatomie der Vertebrata. 2, p. 2–68.  
 1838. Über Anatomie der Verein zur Vertebrata und sein Arten. 2, p. 103–110.  
 1839. Über Anatomie der Vertebrata und seine Nachrichten des Ertos ( Über Anatomie der Vertebrata und seine Nachrichten des Ertsos ). 3, p. 107–132.  
 1842. Biologische Untersuchungen über die Gedankenheit des Eisenschlusses ( Biology of the legs and joints of humans ). 3, p. 129–137.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Pierre Caillard =  
Pierre Caillard ( July 25, 1778, a town near the village of L'amite, Val-de-Grâce – June 17, 1846, in Paris ) was a French mineralogist, mineralogist, industrial chemist and mineralogist. He was the father of Pierre-René Caillard.  
 Caillard had studied medicine at the Faculty of Paris under Nicolas Philippe Lambeau ( 1750-1811 ), of the Royal Museum of Natural History. In 1796 he was appointed director of the French mines, a position he held until 1804, when he was succeeded by Jean-Baptiste-Michel Chabrol ( 1760-1818 ). As director he developed a formidable engineering work which included the creation of many of the modern capital's mining equipment, as well as a cabinet of crystalline and solid state mineralogic literature.He is known for developing a new method of preparing lithium arsenide for the common consumption ; a process subsequently used by other laboratories for the production of lithium for the battery.He is the discoverer of permanganate ( kaolin ) and wrote a chapter about its properties ( 1814 ).  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Jeffrey Richards =  
Jeffrey Christopher Richards ( December 5, 1918 – March 8, 2004 ) was a U.S. Navy officer, biologist, and astrophysicist, and was the namesake of the Richards sphere theory.  
   
   
 == Early life ==  
 In 1931, Richards and his sister, Mary Richards, moved to Long Beach, California, where they attended high school together. They were both engineers.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 From 1949 to 1963, he was a demonstrator at the Southwest Research Institute in Phoenix. Then, from 1963 to 1972, he was a physicist for the United States Air Force. During this period, he conducted work on space exploration, as well as the physics of rocket technology, and its relationship with space travel.In 1962, Richards became the first professor of physics at Dartmouth College and a Ph.D. candidate in theoretical physics.  
   
   
 == Publications ==  
 Four isotopes of fissionable plutonium are named after him :  
   
 Pt-rich silver isotope - r/Sr-1  
 Pt-rich cobalt isotope - Sr-2  
 Pt-rich molybdenum isotope - Ml-1  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Joseph Vannier =  
Joseph Vannier ( 16 November 1753 – 26 August 1814 ) was a French botanist, a professor at the Faculty of Medicine of the University of Geneva. He was one of the main proponents of botanical separation, particularly as it applied to plant diseases. He described a few new species in his scientific works and was a forerunner of modern family separation.  
   
   
 == Early life ==  
 Vannier was born on 16 November 1753 in Geneva, Switzerland, the eldest son of physician Paul Vannier. He attended the Collegium theologicum in Geneva.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 In 1760, Vannier studied at the University of Freiburg, receiving his doctorate in 1765. In 1766, he became a professor of botany and zoology, but at the same time he is credited with adding to his botanical knowledge. He was elected a member of the Swiss Academy of Sciences in 1784.  
   
   
 == Characteristics ==  
   
 He was a critic of the well-known theories of Descartes that the thinking faculty was empty and an incomplete sphere ; he strongly criticized the processes and abilities of the mind in books like Enchiridion. With Rudolf Bopp, he described several different types of ergot ( also an ergot fungus ). Vannier also constructed a model of the mouth of a Dio-negro ( Dioscorelasma i, et al. ) and showed that even seemingly difficult mutations cause gradual disease regression.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 Description du genre Chlorocereus ou Phytothecereus de l'histoire Naturelle et des oiseaux Florees ( 1776 )  
 Dictionnaire économique pratique et ombres d'enquête historique de la société naturelle de Chine, ( 1787 )  
 Dictionnaire économique pratique et ombres d'enquête historique de la société naturelle de Chine ( 1790 )  
 Species d'insectue et d'allergen de la théologie pratique et ombres d'enquête historique de la society insectée d'un fossile dans l'herbe du genre përnocere ( 1806 )  
   
   
 == Inventions ==  
 Fungi from southern Chile were isolated from a coconut on 23 February 1820. A rubber fungicide from Madagascar, which was placed in pits along a salt lake and then used as bait, was discovered to have little effect on any insects caught. It is believed that the rubber insect poison was similar to that collected from this fungus and that natural lepidopters were involved.  
   
   
 == Gallery ==  
   
   
   
   
   
   
   
   
   
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Schoenfeld Rau =  
Schoenfeld Rau ( October 14, 1888 – March 12, 1971 ) was an American economist who also taught in economics and pedagogy. He was involved in the creation of National Education Association ( NEA ).  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Schoenfeld Rau was born to a Jewish family in La Cite-sous-Bois, Morillon, France. At the age of eleven, he applied for admission to the École Nationale d'Éducation.  
 During World War II, he served in the United States Marine Corps during World War II. During World War II, he contributed articles to the Journal of American History, Language, and Economics. He became an honorary member of the American Political Science Association. He wrote several books.  
 After the war, he became a professor at Harvard University, and was later hired by Boston University. He died in 1971, and is buried at the Arlington National Cemetery, and to his family in Rockville, Maryland.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 A biography of Ludwig von Mises ( 1906 ) ISBN 0-300-38496-X  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Kurt Grobe =  
Kurt Grobe ( October 25, 1907 – July 3, 2007 ) was a Danish computer scientist.  
 He was born in Frederiksberg, Moravia. From 1956 to 1961, he studied at the University of Copenhagen and in 1965 he received his doctorate, then became an assistant at the University of Copenhagen and then at the Technische Hochschule für Wiener Zeitschrift, where he was Head of the department of Cybernetics. He later became Head of the department of Computer Science at the University of Copenhagen.Grobe published 14 books.  
 His most important work is Cybernetics and its methods, now available in over forty languages. His exposition of the state-of-the-art concepts in cybernetics has become internationally well known. In 1987, he was awarded the Tivadar Award for Scientific Research.  
   
   
 == Selected publications ==  
 Grobe, K ( 1964 ), `` Analog Networks in High Resistance Networks '', in Annalen der Wissenschaften d. Math. Ber., 61 ( 2 ), pp. 339–365, Bibcode:1964ANWM... 61..339G, doi:10.1007/BF01531405, JSTOR 329570, MR:20040069  
 Grobe, K ( 1976 ), `` Analog Systems of Physical and Physical-Mathematical Sciences '', in World Economy, 25 ( 5 ) : 872–907, doi:10.1002/ws2474475, JSTOR 2328537  
 Grobe, K ( 1987 ), `` Communication and its Theory : The Work of Kurt Grobe and Jens Lundmossen, January 1987 '', in Academy of Engineering Sciences, Paper No. 287, ISBN 978-2-201-04825-2, S. 7, S. 325, 1–40  
 Grobe, K ( 2001 ), Information Theory and the Encyclopedia of the Computer, NY : Springer, ISBN 978-3-540-00957-6, OCLC 22624035  
 Grobe, K ( 2004 ), Non-cognitive events and collective action, ed. Norges YJ Knudsen. Berlin : Springer-Verlag, ISBN 978-3-540-00977-6, OCLC 40308890  
 Grobe, K ( 2007 ), Representing the Internet,  
 Skallski, T. ; Grobe, K ( 2010 ). International Communication in the Social Networked Age, Braga, Lisbon, ENIAC Press, ISBN 978-3-932974-03-0  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Hans Peter (Hansis) von Hochmann =  
Hans Peter ( Hansis ) von Hochmann ( 24 July 1837 – 6 November 1904 ) was a German educator, including associate professor at the Cologne Higher Technical Institute from 1871 to 1879 and thereafter professor at the Göttingen Medical College from 1882 to 1904. He also held several positions as a senator, member of the Diet, and as secretary of the German Academy of Sciences.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 He was the son of a banker and attended the gymnasium and came to the city where he went to school, first as an apprentice at the boys'high school and then at the middle school. During his time in Berlin, he began his studies in chemistry, graduating in 1876. He later completed his studies in 1877 in law at the University of Heidelberg and was subsequently appointed a professor of political economy.  
 At the end of his studies, he spent the summers in Zurich in Switzerland, then at Erlangen in German Empire. From 1877 to 1886 he was associated with the president of the University of Heidelberg. In 1890 he was appointed associate professor at the Cologne High Technical Institute. From 1893 to 1898 he was also a member of the Académie des sciences de France.  
 From 1898 to 1910 he was a representative of the Protestant Christian Democratic Union of Germany.  
 In 1901, he became an associate professor of political economy and dean of the Medical College of Göttingen and a professor in the chemical faculty at the Cologne Medical School. In 1908 he was rector of the hospital and director of the Geheimdynamik Seminar. From 1909 to 1913 he was the president of the Académie des sciences de France.  
 From 1916 to 1920 he was member of the German Academy of Sciences. In 1920 he was named director of the German Medical Association in Erlangen.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 A Short History of Agricultural Technology and Industry, 3 volumes, 1882–88  
 Reisen an unbegriffenden Regierung der Thermographie über die Agriculturismus, 1760–1814. Heidelberg, 1886.  
 Die Reisen an unbegriffenden Regierung der Thermographie über die Agriculturismus, 1760–1814. Heidelberg, 1886.  
 Über die Methodik der mechanischen Eigenschaften, in den angegebenen Forschungen zu Heidelberg, 1869–73.  
 Die Pharmacie der Innerenzeit, andere Abhandlungen der Ziel der physiologischen Prozesskopf einer eigenschrankenen Pathologie, 1886–91.  
 Über die Methodik der mechanischen Eigenschaften, in der Annekterkopf am Titel, aus der Hochmerz gesellschaftlicher Erde, 1867.  
 Über die Methodik der mechanischen Eigenschaften, bei Arzneimittel und Beschreibung der biologischen Physik, 5 vols., 1886-86  
 Medicinische Physik. in : Episkopischer Diastötten, Kirche und Krankheiten. Zwischen 1879-1883.  
 Über die Überformen im Mechanischen Eigenschaften, aus der Anfangkollegern des Geschichtsinstituts für Medicin, 1910  
 Dokumente und Bekennsverzeichnungen zur Theorie der Mechanischen Eigenschaften, 2 vols., Cologne, 1911  
 Vortrag und werdenstimmige unveränderlichen Mechanischen Eigenschaften. ( in : Stimmenräge zur Elektrochemie )  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Chrysanth Stele =  
Chrysanth Stele ( 11 July 1813 – 19 May 1901 ) was an Italian naturalist and botanist. He is best known as a collector of Italian fruits of the Northern Alps.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
   
 Stele was born in Giacomo Rosso in Imola. He studied natural history in Florence and Florence.  
 In 1864 he became an associate professor of botany at the University of Turin and succeeded his father as director in 1878. In 1878 he became an honorary member of the Academy of Sciences Genova and in 1881 honorary member of the Canton of Genova.  
 He died in Turin.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 His contributions to botany were many, for he published on different plant families in Italian, German, and other languages. In his flora of Genova, Stele described ;  
   
 Acer saccharum. ( Gen. Ext.. russ. )  
 Acer palaeojacifolium. ( Gen. Ext. russ. )  
 Achillea erecta. ( Gen. Ext. russ. )  
 Chrysanthys millebranchiae. ( Gen. Ext. russ. )  
 Corynanthes pyriformis. ( Gen. Ext. russ. )  
 Cryptogon subcorynanthes var. arm, ( Gen. Ext. russ. )  
 Cryptogon magnolia. ( Gen. Ext. russ. )  
 Diplocalidium curva and Diplocalidium curva albertanis, ( Gen. Ext. russ. )  
 Glistocereus, ( Gen. Ext. russ. )  
 Acanthemus argus ferrugineus ( Gen. Ext. russ. )  
 Lapsuosa sp. n. gracilis and Lapsuosa sp. pesosca ( Gen. Ext. russ. )  
 Paracosa polis oxalis, ( Gen. Ext. russ. )  
 Pleurodon agarbata argus eti, ( Gen. Ext. russ. )  
 Pleurodon contorta argus ( Gen. Ext. russ. )  
 Pseudocarpus gracilis acamas et var. var. var. baracus ( Gen. Ext. russ. )  
 Placophilus nigrum ( Gen. Ext. russ. )  
 Stitaurus feldspara s. n. orchardica, ( Gen. Ext. russ. )  
 Sternaphyra anostomus pyriformis, ( Gen. Ext. russ. )  
 Centella myrhopetalium subplantarum ( Gen. Ext. russ. )  
 Gallona hirti, Neuglassnäter, `` Mitteilungen, '' 1878, v. 113

<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Paul Dreier =  
Paul Dreier ( German : [ päʁtɑɐ ] ; 13 March 1831 – 21 July 1886 ) was a German anatomist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Dreier studied medicine in Berlin and Königsberg. In 1852, he entered the Munich Academy of Medicine and Surgery and taught anatomy at the Academy until his death in 1886. He wrote more than 150 scientific papers and articles on physiology, anatomy and anatomy of the mammalian nervous system, which was considered the standard work of his time. Dreier also served as a lecturer and served as director of the Zoological Institute of the Academy. Dreier served as president of the Zoological Society of Berlin from 1872 to 1876. He was also a contributor to the Neue Deutsche Wochenschrift für Anatomie, being the first director to contribute articles to the Berliner Hochschulbarkeitsblatt.From 1851 to 1869, he studied at the Imperial Hospital in Berlin, and continued his studies at the Leipzig Imperial Hospital from 1869 to 1874, then later he worked at the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute of Medical History in 1871.Dreier died at the age of 82 at Königsberg.  
   
   
 == Selected works ==  
 Strahlung und Hauptstrahlung. Abhandlungen zur Kenntnis der Mensch. Sitzungsberichte der Kaiser Wilhelm Institut für Anatomie, eines neue Zeitschrift für Anatomie. Jahresbericht in Katholie und Königsberg, KG Klinik 1 ( 1851 ).  
 Lehrbuch der Wirkung. Nachwachsen in Aarau. 1853.  
 Handbuch der Anatomie. Band 2. Königsberg/Alexandria 1854.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Mario Pantevski =  
Mario Pantevski ( April 1, 1922 – December 11, 2005 ) was a Soviet mathematician and co-founder of the Heidelberg Centre for Functional Analysis.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Pantevski was born in Biel ( then the United Kingdom ) and received his BSc ( 1936 ) from the University of Heidelberg. He then became an assistant in the Department of Mathematics at the University of Heidelberg, where he worked with Emil Teubner, Edsger W. Dijkstra, and Hans-Joachim Florian von Kraft. From 1949 to 1967 he worked as a professor at the University of Heidelberg. In 1967 he was appointed to the chair of theoretical mathematics at the Moscow Mathematical Institute ( Moscow Institute for Experimental and Systematic Theoretical Mathematics ).In 1968 he founded and headed the Heidelberg Centre for Functional Analysis in Vrchyna near Rovno ( then Theresianoff ). In 1980 he became the director of the Moscow Institute of Experimental and Systematic Theoretical Mathematics. Since 1989 he was an independent professor at the Moscow Institute of Mathematical and Theoretical Sciences.  
 Pantevski's first publication, `` Theory of methods of partial differential equations and partial differential equations with maxima '' ( 1976 ), is based on his model of the cosmological constant constant. He expanded his theoretical works in 1990–1991 on Fourier series ( and later on three-dimensional analysis of intervals ) and the cosmological constant. In 1997 he wrote `` Subtransitions on Fourier series, differential geometry, and intensional form '' ( translated into English ).Pantevski founded and headed the Heidelberg Centre for Functional Analysis, which under his leadership developed the Heidelberg ’ s theoretical foundations of functional analysis in three major directions. The first, intensive theoretical studies of the theory of partial differential equations and the theory of functional integrals, was completed in the 1990s and was launched in 2004 with Luigi Traciari and Arshad Shalabi. The second, more extensive work, was carried out in the 2000s by collaborators and students, with results published in 2 special volumes : the first volume explored the components of Laplace's continuum, the second authored by Alexander Sitsay, for which an abstract was published in 2012. From 2007 to 2015, Pantevski served as the director of the Heidelberg Centre for Functional Analysis ( 中国科学科書科功能力, Heidelberg Centre for Functional Analysis ), established in 2017. It is the ninth Centre of Excellence for Functional Analysis in the world. From 2009 to 2015, Pantevski also served as the director of the Moscow Institute of Mathematical and Theoretical Sciences ( 中国宁国部科学科書科功能力, Moscow Institute for Mathematical and Theoretical Sciences ).He also published over a hundred scientific papers in journals such as Annals of the American Mathematical Society ( 1975–2008 ), Annals of the European Academy of Sciences ( 1982 ), the Bulletin of the Institute of Mathematical Statistics, and the Journal of Mathematical Statistics and Complex Analysis ( 2004–2005 ).  
   
   
 == Honours ==  
 In recognition of his work in functional analysis, Pantevski was made a Chevalier of the Order of the Red Banner of Labour.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Julian Tiggemere =  
Julian Tiggemere ( 1832–1918 ) was a South African physician and botanist, noted for introducing new species to the Regia of South Africa.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Tiggemere was born in the royal necropolis of Veldhuizen, Cape Colony, England. After completing his undergraduate education at the University of St Andrews in Scotland, Tiggemere later studied medicine at the University of Copenhagen and in 1853 moved to Johannesburg to open a private practice. However, following a year in England, he settled in South Africa where he did his medical training at the Institut de Surier CIEB and taught as an assistant to a number of professors and obtained his M.A. in 1856.  
 Tiggemere used to bring students from Europe to South Africa to grow plants for himself, but later on he introduced Africans to plants that they had grown themselves, and he provided seeds to the African Society for a number of botanical expeditions to regions around Africa.  
 With his friend, Johannesburg pastor and noted botanist Charles Beecham, he introduced Johannesburg to the plant genus Australacum into the genus Myxomanceri. In 1872 he established the renowned Javan-born genus Julianotine, named after him by his fellow botanist Eduard Heuser. Julianotine is still a relatively rare native African plant that was to show its great variety in the 20th century.  
   
   
 == Species introductions ==  
 Julianotine is one of the new species of Alanophyllum Tiggemereana introduced to South Africa.  
   
   
 == External Links ==  
 List of Julianotine.  
 Wikipedia article on Julianotine  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Efremo Arroyo =  
Efremo Arroyo ( February 20, 1928 – November 23, 2005 ) was an Italian and Dutch journalist and businessman.  
 He was born in Rome. He moved to San Sebastián in 1955 and spent his career as a journalist in Spain, the United Kingdom and France.  
 He became a member of the Board of Management of Standard Chartered in 1987.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = James Mahone Reid =  
James Mahone Reid, FRS ( 7 October 1792 – 7 August 1845 ) was an English anatomist and pedagogue. He was the son of James Reid of Ruxton, Northamptonshire.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Born at Ruxton, Northamptonshire, the son of Thomas Reid, a merchant, and Mary Ricks, widow of William Hicks.Dr Reid graduated M.A. in 1824 from the Royal College of Surgeons at London, the same year as being elected a Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh. From 1825 to 1831 he served as tutor to the school of medicine at Battersea and Dr Reid in 1833. In the same year he attained his M.D. In 1831 he was elected a fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh, but his proposers being Philip Gowrie, the physician, Edward Ritchie, professor of physical science, and Joseph Brady, a Roman Catholic, he resigned his fellowship. In 1832 he became professor of anatomy in Trinity College, Dublin, a post he held until 1856, when, in 1854, he was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society.In 1827 he was elected a member of the Scientific and Medical Association of London, and in 1833, he was elected a fellow of the Royal Society. He is associated with the noble family of Ruxton and with the hospital at Ruxton Hospital.  
 He died at his home, Rupert Crescent, Ruxton, on 7 August 1845.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Joachim Krause =  
Joachim Krause ( ; German : [ kʁɛ̃ːm ] ; 7 December 1841 – 15 October 1897 ) was a German philologist.  
   
   
 == Life and career ==  
 Krause studied in Leipzig, receiving his doctorate in 1859, and from 1862 to 1866 he was professor of philology at the Universities of Göttingen and Breslau. He was a founding member of the Linnean Society of London and was a member of its archives commission, as well as of the German Academy of Sciences ( from 1897 ).  
 Krause's principal interest was the philology of medieval time. He produced a series of studies that provide a wealth of information about Graeco-Roman poetry and art, a task that had previously been carried out by Johann Baptist Wenzel. Krause also participated in the excavations at Cercei in the Adriatic. Although Krause wrote almost exclusively in German, the contents of his Palaeolithic Berlinbrief are available in four languages. He is perhaps best known for his research on Old Testament artifacts in Jerusalem and archaeological research in the Old Testament areas of Central Asia.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 Staatsbibliothek des Schweden, Berlin 1861-1865 ; 4th ed., Berlin 1914-1917, fifth ed., Berlin 1941-1945

 Die Einführung der türkischen Muhammed, Leipzig 1878

 Graecus, M. C., Neuromus. Partia. zum ten und nicht. Auflage der Empfindung bei Vienna, Leipzig 1881  
 Die Hunde des Lebs, Leipzig 1881  
 Die Methodus der österreichischen Weltanschauung, Leipzig 1884  
 Über die Oliphauntius in den Bedeutung, Berlin 1885  
 Denkmönner betreffend einer den Gedichte, Leipzig 1886  
 Die Entstehung für Amittentralerkeit des 17. Jahrhunderts ( Pârno suêtes ), Leipzig 1886  
 Die Architekten bei pârno Kocormană, Leipzig 1888  
 Iconographie des profaneam Teutonicos, Berlin 1889
