<start_bio> 
 = Mary Thatcher (philosopher) =  
Mary Thatcher ( 14 January 1828 – 16 January 1897 ) was an English teacher and author.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Thatcher was the only child of Moses Thatcher, teacher at the London Church of England and his wife Clara, née Wood, and a daughter of Benjamin Woods, banker. After finishing his schooling at Bath he entered Harrow College, Cambridge in 1845 and won the New College Prize ( subsequently named the Samuel Pupin Prizes ). He then took up the post of Headmaster of the Topsfield Charing Cross School of Social Work in 1853.  
 From 1853 to 1860 he studied botany at Trinity College, Cambridge and also practised law, completing his period of service with distinction in the Church of England before entering medicine in 1860. From 1869 to 1871 he practised in Norwich.  
 Thatcher was also an active lecturer. His Lectures were first presented to the committee of the Royal Asiatic Society in the first session of the session of 1867, and lastly in the second session in 1880. He was the author of Essays on the Oneness of Nature and Man ( 1867 ), Moral Psychology ( 1874 ), and The Time and the Measure of the Human Mind ( 1880 ).  
 He died at his home, his home a natural history museum in Leicester Square.  
 His brother Sir Richard Thatcher wrote :  
   
 `` I, too, am a John's Friend, and my poor younger brother Mary is his disciple... His ideas, however, are not as crude as those of Schopenhauer, and his method of exposition is as perfect as that of Weidmann.The Reverend Dr. Thatcher acted as a Pupin for the authorship of several of his well-known tracts.... In the course of his lecture he gave some hints concerning the views held by the majority of leading people in the world today, who always serve to oppose Socialism...... to his adversaries Socialism will continue to be opposed, as long as individualism exists ; and it will become rapidly more difficult for our Government, if success is not obtained by social reduction, to do anything but call forth the masses to take measures of reform...... In every instance in which Socialism is defended on this basis I sympathize with the opponents of government interference in private industry, and I have no wish to imagine a better man to whom I can dedicate an elaborate and solemn defence. I hold my friend's thought absolutely in accordance with the principles of Locke and Tory, and especially with those of Aylmer, Clarke and Montesquieu... but I believe in the freedom of the individual to choose his course of action, to produce such effects as will appear to others desirable, without any interference with the conduct of private business, and which in any case are to be happily remedied. ''  
   
   
 == Bibliography ==  
 Essays on the Oneness of Nature and Man, 1867  
 On the relation between Affect and Fact, 1869  
 Mere Counterfeit, 1874  
 Man's Death's Mask, 1875  
 The Time and the Measure of the Human Mind, 1880  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Carl Wilhelm von Kemper =  
Carl Wilhelm von Kemper ( 12 March 1844, Elberfeld – 24 May 1898, Alpenheim ) was a German botanist and geologist, and the father of Adolf Kemper ( 1859–1927 ).He studied botany at the University of Munich, graduating in 1873 and returning to Berlin as a consulting botanist in 1881.  
 While at university, Kemper was a co-founder of the Hauptbund für Botanische Gebiet, an organization for establishment of Germany's first biological museum.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
   
   
 === Early life ===  
 Carl Wilhelm von Kemper was the son of Georg Christian von Kemper and Charlotte ( Lorraine ) Hess. He was educated at the Free University of Berlin and University of Bonn, where he obtained the degree of master in 1884.  
   
   
 === Career ===  
 During the 1880s Kemper was a member of the Steyrschweise der Angewandte Horticulturalisches Institut, where he worked as an assistant to the botanist August Siegmund. Among other scientific researches he discovered a vascular fungus that causes a wide variety of diseases in plants. In 1899 he was elected a member of the Berlin Botanical Society.  
 In 1901 he was appointed an inspector in the Reichskanzler-Flora-Gesellschaft.  
 In 1908, he was nominated member of the Foreign Entomological Society of Berlin, for which he worked in 1907–1909 as an editor. In 1920 he was elected to the International Commission of Zoological Nomenclature and named the new genus Kemperia by E.F.Pallas.  
   
   
 == Legacy and memorials ==  
 Although he was a faunist and dedicated botanist, Kemper's scientific work was primarily focused on plant pathology and insect pollination, making him one of the first victims of the debilitating Leontiopterum dwarfense disease. Following an exhaustive study of the plant genus Prunus, Kemper isolated kemperi from the flowering plants of the family Prunales. Because of the limited knowledge about the disease's host, it was only discovered in 1922.  
 The crater Kemper on the Moon was named in his honor.  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Isaac Watson Gay =  
Isaac James Gay ( 17 May 1903 – 7 September 1977 ) was an English physicist, best known as an early pioneer of jet propulsion.  
   
   
 == Early life and education ==  
 Born in Kirkby, Kent, England on 17 May 1903, he attended Kirkby Grammar School in London until the age of 12, when he moved to Guildford where he was the victim of sexual abuse by a student. He returned to London to study physics at King's College London ( King's College, Oxford ), where in his graduate studies he was awarded a B.Sc. in 1926 for a thesis on `` Observations on the propagation of a radiant wave through a parabolic chamber '' and in 1927 was awarded a PhD in theoretical physics. In 1926 he was awarded a job as the assistant lecturer at King's College, London, where he remained until his retirement in 1960.Gay was appointed lecturer in electrical engineering at King's College, in 1946, and was promoted to full lecturer in 1958. In 1967 he was elected a Fellow of King's College and its successor, the London School of Economics and Political Science ( LSPS ).  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 Gay was appointed Rector of Leeds University, and created Professor of Physics in 1967. He was elected President of the British Association for the Advancement of Science in 1968, and was its President-in-1996. Gay chaired the Central Electricity Panel and served as Chairman of the Joint Committee on Countermeasures to the proliferation of nuclear weapons ( 1977–78 ).In 1977, Gay was appointed director of the Institute of Advanced Studies ( IAS ) in London. He served as director of its Centre for Energy Studies ( CEOS ) from 1982 to 1988. He was the first director of the Cavendish Laboratory, one of the world's leading and most renowned nuclear physics laboratories, which opened in 1979.Gay was made an Honorary Fellow of the Royal Society in 1982. He was knighted in 1985. He was also an Honorary Fellow of the Royal Society and a President of the Royal Society of Edinburgh. Gay was honorary member of the Physics and Technology Society and received an Honorary Doctorate in Theoretical Physics from University College London. He was the chairman of the UK Council for Scientific and Industrial Research, as well as being a Fellow of the Royal Society.Gay died at his home in Northbourne, Surrey, UK on 7 September 1977.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = William Annough =  
William Annough OBE, 1st Baroness Annough ( d. 1938 ), FRSE ( 1st January 1928 – 23rd November 2004 ) was a Scottish statistician and political economist. He is credited as being the first Scottish Government statistician to become head of Statistics Scotland.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 William Annough was born in Monkstown, Shropshire on 1 January 1928, to Ioan Annough ( d. 1989 ), a consultant nurse, and Ida Gill ( née Merrill ). His younger brother, Francis, is a historian.  
 He studied at St Andrews University from 1936 to 1939, where he was a student of T.M. Moffat. After working briefly as a digital consultant, he became a Reader at Glasgow University from 1939 to 1946. In 1946, he was appointed a Fellow of the University of Glasgow. In 1951 he was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh.  
 After the Second World War, he joined the Royal Scottish Statistical Society where he remained until retiring in 1959. He was Regius Professor of Statistics from 1972 to 1975 and professor of Statistics from 1976 to 1981. He was Chairman of the Scottish Statistical Association from 1984 to 1989, becoming Professor of Statistics in 1983.  
 He was awarded the Walker Memorial Prize in 1958, the Douglas Memorial Prize in 1967, the Jackson Medal in 1988, the Diamond Jubilee Medal in 1989 and the Preston Medal in 1993. He was also named the recipient of a Cross of Merit from the Royal Society of Edinburgh in 1990.  
 In 1969, he was made a Commander of the Order of the Bath, and became an Officer of the Order of the British Empire in 1973. He was also knighted in 1966. In 1972, he was made an Officer of the Order of the Garter.  
 William Annough was married twice, first to Helen Rowan in 1948 and then to Roxane Marie Holmes in 1950. William Annough was a proponent of ecological sustainability, as witnessed by the publication of his book Water, Food and Markets : An Ecological Study, published in 1974. His maiden name was Mary.  
 He died in Aberdeen at the age of 94.  
   
   
 == Selected publications ==  
 Biological Economics in Scotland and the United Kingdom ( 1946 )  
 Public Health as a Public Duty ( 1948 )  
 A Statistical Survey of Labour Activity ( 1952 )  
 The Public Life of Scotland : 1930–1984 ( 1982 )  
 Being a Statistician : A History of the Scottish Government's Statisticians ( 1988 )  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Alexandra Leszkowski =  
Alexandra Leszkowski ( 9 September 1900 in Nemenovka – 14 March 1972 ) was a Czech political scientist and economic historian. She was the eldest daughter of famous publicists A. Leszkowski and Matilde Niedermeyer. Leszkowski graduated from the faculty of law in 1939 and went on to study politics and economics in Prague.  
   
   
 == Political career ==  
 Leszkowski joined the Socialist Workers Party in 1936 and the government of Marshal Leopold II. She became a member of the communist party in 1939. She founded the Neo-conservative Czechoslovak Broadcasting Institute ( Kralovičská ceny o polská za sledmejetskyství ) in 1942 and was active in the formation of the Czechoslovak Democratic Party. She was a close associate of the father of Czechoslovak opposition politician Václav Havel.  
 Leszkowski became a member of the Supreme Court of Chief Justice of the Republic of Czechoslovakia in 1961. In the same year she became the first non-reporter to be appointed to the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Ministers. She was later elected to the supreme court. After the end of World War II, Leszkowski returned to academia. In 1965 Leszkowski became director of the Academy of Economics in Prague and a member of the National Academy of Sciences.Her works dealt with the history of Czechoslovakia and her students examined and analyzed the Social Democratic legacy of Bořítvany and Czechoslovakia's history.  
 She was a member of the Czechoslovak Academy of Sciences. In 1996 she was awarded the social sciences prize for `` Political Science and Social History : theoretical contributions to the study of Czechoslovak and Slovak modernity. ''  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = William Graham Harwin =  
William Graham Harwin ( 27 April 1788 – 6 February 1852 ) was an English physician and surgeon. He is credited with first introducing syphilis into Europe. Harwin was a professor of bacteriology and zoology at the College of Physicians, Aberdeen, which was the first fully-qualified naturalist's college in the UK.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 He was born at Bourke-upon-Tweed, Sussex, the son of a minister. He was educated at Brighton School and at University College, London, graduating with the PhD in 1797.He established himself as a lecturer in physiology at University College, and in 1798 was awarded a degree of doctor of medicine and a MSc ( Physiology ) by King's College, London, with a thesis on blood sugar. In 1803 he was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society and continued to travel abroad for the next few years.In 1804 he visited France, which stimulated his interest in European history, and he helped found the Odontological Society in 1808. He returned to the UK in 1806 and was appointed lecturer in physiology at the University of Aberdeen.Harwin won the Royal Society's Royal Medal in 1815. In 1822 he became president of the Royal College of Surgeons of England.He died in Aberdeen.  
   
   
 == Selected works ==  
 An account of natural history and surgery, 1795, Edinburgh : James Murray.  
 Diseases of the animal system, with an account of the physiology of the same, 2 vols., Edinburgh, 1809 ; reprinted as Diseases of the animal system, with an account of the physiology of the same, 2 vols., Edinburgh, 1819.  
 Partition of the British Islands, by Henry Geyer ; with prefaces, London, 1806.  
 Institution of Vertebrate Anatomy, London, 1812.  
 The anatomy of vertebrates, London, 1814.  
 System of Medicine for the Condition of the Entire Human Body, With Expanded Instructions, to Prevent or Cure any Disease ; with an Account of the Nature and Directions of its Cure, published by Dr. John Bailey and Dr. Thomas de la Torre, 2 vols., Edinburgh, 1829.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = James Price (botanist) =  
James Price ( 16 January 1803 – 14 November 1892 ) was an English botanist, zoologist and ethnologist.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
   
 Price was born at Liverpool, and later went to school at Liverpool, receiving a BA in 1824. From 1825 he studied biology at Edinburgh, where he earned his PhD in 1834. In that year he served in the council of Algiers, and afterwards, in 1836, served as teacher at Leyton and Wanstead schools in London. In 1844 he returned to Cambridge, where he worked at the botanical garden. Price returned to Edinburgh in 1858, and in 1864 the annual New Testament Expositor was founded.  
 In 1857 he published An Investigation of the Faunal Systematics of the Northern & British Islands, with an Account of the Flora of the Fens and Canals of the Kingdoms of Scotland, Ireland, & Ceylon, first collected in the late Dr. Price's College, Edinburgh in 1833, and a second edition in 1856. The British Admiralty were also impressed with the work, and corresponded with him until his death in 1892. He has been called the botanist of the North-east. He was chairman of the Plant Families of Great Britain and Ireland, and in 1879 was elected a Foreign Honorary Member of the Linnean Society.  
   
   
 == Zoological interests ==  
 Price is most known for his identification of the butterfly florae in South Africa ( 1856 ), and for a number of other scientific papers. His largest treatise, A Compendium of South African Plants, published in 1857, included thirty-two genera of plants, some of which he discovered himself. The systematics are widely known, and probably merit publication.  
   
   
 == Taxa named for Price ==  
 Coleoptera : Coleoptera crassulata, Coleoptera succus, Coleoptera whitse, Coleoptera porosas, Coleoptera flexilis, Cryptogamma pleurodorus, Cryptogamma phalanxta, Platycera cinerea, Polylepis triclus ( Phanerogamma ), Theobranthaplyle bromelli, Cosmoa pilosa, Dubia coriostomae, Dermochelys bicolor ( Adamus ), Fagus coelenterata, Micropolus subtesiacus ( Platycera ), Otombeltyoda exopolycarpa, Rhopalocelus substeve ( Tropicalia ), Rhizodactyla victoria ( Platycera )  
 Hymenoptera : aegypti's, Cerithrospora gallorum, Ecopadia loquifera, Flora melanogaster  
 Phyllostomata : Ancherina dipladata, Tricholomura melanogaster, Thymophora polycarpa, Ziconia anatomica  
 Zonistra microbiasci, ( Mydeiomyomycetes )  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Carl C3 A9dolph Horstmann =  
Carl Dährig Horstmann ( 11 June 1876 – 21 August 1953 ) was a German physicist who proposed the electric, magnetic, and thermal ( EM ) waves to explain phenomena like the Polar Vortex, the cosmic ray ( CM1 ), and the Earth's magnetic field. In 1911 he also studied radar.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 In 1877, Horstmann studied mathematics at the University of Leipzig, later at the Technische Hochschule Frankfurt am Main. There he was interested in the field of thermodynamics, and began to study magnetism and the electric field. He was working in Hamburg at the Sorbonne when the First World War broke out, working on the Physics of St. Mary's Hospital in the north of Paris. He received his doctorate from the University of Paris in 1895.  
 He remained at the University of Paris, where he became a Fellow of the Royal Society, an Associate in 1906, and in 1911 a full Professor of Natural Philosophy. In 1884 he was the founder of the German Physical Society ( first Berlin Physical Society ).  
   
   
 == Work on radio-electricity ==  
 In 1884, at the University of Berlin, Horstmann had discovered the inverse square law of voltage. By 1906, he had theorized about the slow decay of radio waves.In 1909 Horstmann showed that electromagnetic waves propagate through different distances, through all directions. He predicted that microwave radiation from the Earth travels at only 300 meters per second. In 1911, he compared two streams of radar-peeping telegraphic antennas in Hamburg, the plane at an angle and the perpendicular one. He showed that the wavelength is not shorter in the plane than perpendicular to it, and that at the radio antenna there is no slight difference in the radio signal.In 1912 Horstmann proposed electromagnetic waves as the cause of electromagnetic phenomena. Later, he demonstrated that the Earth's magnetic field `` radiates '' with a constant speed. The idea attracted the attention of Nazi scientist Heinrich Hertz, who independently pointed out that the radio waves were indeed created by the Earth, and that they increased the thickness of the ice at the Greenland–Antarctic border. Although Hertz suggested that the gas-air flame propagation was due to the electric field applied to the conductor, Horstmann went further, proposing that the natural radiation emanation could also be responsible. Horstmann published his work in German, the German version of the Nobel prize in Physics.Horstmann's work stimulated American military research, and was widely used for experimenting with remote-control aircraft. These aircraft called the LAAT-7 were based on his ideas, and received military authorization from the US government in December 1944.  
   
   
 == Electromagnetic polarizations ==  
   
 In the late 19th century, polarization was called electromagnetic radiation.In 1911, Horstmann published a theory explaining, for the first time, electrical polarization.  
 Horstmann presented a theory for the polarization of a short continuous wave of single energy particles, where those particles carry an electric charge. The theory was completely rewritten in 1920 by Richard Feynman, who said that Horstmann's theory had `` superseded the purely electromagnetic theory that the aeroplane wave can not be made to oscillate in either direction '', as `` our system of quantum electrodynamics '' was developing.  
   
   
 == Nuclear-electric currents ==  
   
 In 1905 Horstmann found that electric currents in the hydrogen atom could be observed with an electrostatic discharge at high frequency. As he had predicted earlier, the electrons can be observed moving at low frequency at high energies. When electron currents are introduced into the liquid, the voltage drops and the current becomes a weak negative current.  
 It was accepted that such a current was important in nuclear fission. In a 1920 paper, Horstmann gave a description of a `` driving force '' for nuclear fission. However, he gave a slightly different version of this drive, for the so-called strong positive electric field, with the standard definition of this field that he described was :  
   
 H e = −n  
.  
   
   
   
 r  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = W.S. Gregory =  
William Shaw Gregory ( 25 November 1917 – 8 December 2007 ) was a well known Canadian entomologist. He worked in central Victoria.  
 Gregory studied at the University of Victoria, graduating with first class honours in biology in 1957. He was promoted to major in 1958. Following graduation he worked as a Biological Assistant at the Central Agricultural Experiment Station in Victoria. He made a keen interest in several beetle families and subfamilies, being influenced by J.A. Massey. Gregory was a main research officer at the Victoria Institute of Science and Technology from 1963 to 1966. He joined the British Columbia Field Service in 1966 and remained in that position until 1978. He earned the Chemical Laboratory Postgraduate Degree of DSc in 1972 and a PhD in Biological Chemistry in 1977 from the University of British Columbia.From 1975 to 1980 he worked for the British Columbia provincial government's Department of Agriculture. He took a break from academia in 1983 after initially holding various posts at the Dominion Research Center in Smiths Falls, British Columbia. He subsequently held posts at the Agriculture Agency in Prince George from 1983 to 1985 and the Geological Survey of Canada from 1987 to 1989. He was elected a Fellow of the Royal Entomological Society in 1984 and a Member in 1989.Gregory died of Parkinson's disease on 8 December 2007.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Heinrich Wilhelm Giesche =  
Heinrich Wilhelm Giesche ( German pronunciation : [ ˈʃɛ̯vɛk ˈleinuːtɛtɛ ] ; 1769 – 10 December 1822 ) was a German poet and hymnwriter.  
 He was born in Staufen in the Prussian Province of Württemberg, into an influential upper-middle-class family of Gluckstern and Christoph Georges Giesche. Giesche was educated at the University of Freiburg and was ordained to the German Church in 1804. He taught at Stafjord and was headmaster of the primary school at Limnäs in the Beuthen province, part of the Schleswig-Holstein Province of Saxony. He is noted for his harmonics, verse, and poems.  
 He is known for the Giesche Psalter, which he wrote with his nephew Thomas ( 1777–1856 ) as well as the Giesche Marker. A reformer in Germany, his poetry also influenced poets such as Johann Sebastian Bach and Johann von Goethe.  
 The edition of his poems, the Deutsche Psalter und die gebildeten Gegenwart by Christoph von Mesmer, is considered his greatest achievement. The Giesche Psalter was printed from his collection of 40 hymns and compositions and by him is one of the most successful collection of hymn books of the 20th century.  
   
   
 == Hymnography ==  
   
 During the two centuries that he spent in the west, Giesche wrote over 200 works of literary verse and singing, most of them long and regular chants. His numerous hymn-books survive in many editions, as well as a. Volume 9 of Giesche's Tractatus gendremorum in prose style.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = John Dunn (intellectual) =  
John Dunn ( 15 December 1857 – 22 October 1939 ) was an English Protestant theologian. He was born in a small town called Stoke-on-Trent in Sussex, the son of John Dunn, a solicitor, and his wife Ellen Morgan. He was educated at St. Pancras School, and was a pupil of William Allen Green ( 1798–1861 ). Dunn won a scholarship to the University of Cambridge in 1862. He read theology at De Montfort's First School, Oxford and Linguistics and Baccalaureate under Arthur Machen ( 1824–1907 ). He became the Regius Professor of Greek in 1875, and also served as rector of Hastings in 1881-1883.Dunn's books are valuable historical treatises that provide a complete reconstruction of early history, and of biblical texts in general.In 1878, Dunn published Scepticism of Scripture and its Differenties in Modern Judaism, in which he attacked contemporary Scepticism.He died in his Cambridge home, possibly of pneumonia, as the result of illness.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Alfred Halliday Baker =  
Alfred Halliday Baker ( September 27, 1876 – May 4, 1935 ) was an American professor of comparative literature, known for his book The Dawn of Pan-Americanism.  
 Baker received his B.A. in 1925, M.A. in 1929 and Ph.D. in 1935. He also served as a professor in American history at Harvard from 1932 to 1936. He was a member of the National Academy of Sciences. Baker's original emphasis was history of the American colonies from 1800 until World War II. Baker wrote over 100 articles, books and monographs.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Edith Vernon Moore =  
Edith Vernon Moore ( January 14, 1907 – March 14, 1991 ) was an American neuropsychologist who was a pioneer in the study of trait impulsivity. She was the first woman to teach psychology at Northwestern University.  
   
   
 == Early life and education ==  
 Born in Chicago, Illinois, she earned her doctorate from New York University in 1926 and her Ph.D. from Harvard University in 1930. She received an honorary Ph.D. from Columbia University in 1955.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 She was a faculty member at the University of Chicago, where she helped design the educational laboratory. In 1948, she became the first female to teach psychology at a post-graduate school, joining the faculty of Columbia University. In 1954, Moore founded Northwestern University's female psychology department, where she directed the school's comprehensive clinical psychology program.  
 In 1958, she became a professor of clinical psychology at Yale University, where she also chaired the Department of Psychology. In 1968, she retired from Northwestern and accepted an appointment at the Department of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry at the Rockefeller Institute of Medical Research in New York, where she would retire in 1989. She remained at the Rockefeller Institute of Medical Research until her death in 1991.  
   
   
 == Selected writings ==  
 `` Inward Touched '', 1954, Neuropsychology, 3, 1 : 59–69.  
 `` Temperament and Homosexuality : Five Cases of Self-Regulating Personality '', 1954, Neuropsychology, 3, 2 : 39–56.  
 `` A Preliminary Statement '', 1961, Psychiatry and Social Problems, 2, 1 : 78–96.  
 `` Homosexual Behavior, A Study in Aggression '', 1967, Archives of General Psychiatry, 3, 1 : 83–95.  
 `` The Affective Experience of Anger '', 1969, Archives of General Psychiatry, 3, 2 : 179–191.  
 `` Identification Disorder and Clinical Outcomes '', 1975, Archives of General Psychiatry, 4, 2 : 230–237.  
   
   
 == Selected professional affiliations ==  
 American Association of University Women  
 American Psychological Association  
 American Psychiatric Association  
 Department of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry at Yale University  
 Department of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry at the Rockefeller Institute of Medical Research  
 Edgar E. Woodcock Award, awarded by the Society of Psychopathology, 1960  
 Graci, Hans ( 1962 ). The Psychology of Adult Sexuality. New York, NY : Wiley.  
   
   
 == Selected bibliography ==  
. `` The Psychology of Adult Sexuality. New York, NY : Wiley. '' Report on the Social Development of Children. New York, NY : Wiley.  
. `` Women in psychology : A national survey of the field, 1950-1978 ''. Journal of Child Psychology and Psychiatry. 18 ( 4 ) : 555–603. doi:10.1080/03406053.1959.890608.  
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Hermann Whitehead =  
Hermann Whitehead ( 20 October 1832 – 28 May 1890 ) was a German botanist and entomologist.His scientific works include :  
   
 Memoir of a Ceremonial Death ( 1869 )  
 Description of a Species of Fern ( 1873 )  
 A Flora of British North America ( 1877 )  
 The Fruits of British Columbia ( 1881 )  
 The Fruits of North America and the Far North ( 1885 )  
 Essays on Botany ( 1904 )  
   
   
 == Bibliography ==  
 John W. Bean ( ed. )  
 Agricultural Geography of British Columbia, 1902–1913.  
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Wilhelm Lohr =  
Wilhelm Lohr ( 27 July 1818, Klöden – 14 June 1881, Königsberg ) was a German physicist, best known for his development of the photographic paper microscope.  
 Lohr was born into an artistic family. His father, a clockmaker, was a member of the German Academy of Arts and Sciences. His mother was an artist, painter, and bibliographer. He became the first professor of medicine in Königsberg in 1845. He was appointed on 15 March 1848 to be the chair of optics in Königsberg.  
 A close friend and colleague of Felix Klein, he is chiefly remembered for developing the photographic paper microscope. He was elected an American Member of the Royal Society on 3 June 1848.  
 He remained in Königsberg for the rest of his life, remaining active as a lecturer and as an examiner.  
 A partnership was established with Klein to manufacture photographic paper telescopes at Königsberg. He was also engaged as an instructor for microscopes, who developed his own method. In 1871, he became director of the blind ( Dissertationzentrum Dissertationwissenschaft ), which in 1850 became the Königsberg Academy of Sciences, the oldest independent scientific school in Europe.  
 Lohr's most notable contribution was in the field of natural history, as he was the first to recognize the intrinsic significance of the mole.  
 He also discovered the trigeminal nerve and discovered the distinction between the type of neural flexion which facilitates finger movement ( anterior flexion ) and the type of neural flexion which inhibits it ( posterior flexion ).  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Selvaggio di Botta =  
Selvaggio di Botta ( 13 June 1752 – 7 November 1829 ) was an Italian composer. He was the grandson of the poet Nicolazzi di Botta.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 His father was a law clerk and a poet. He studied law and composition at the Royal College of Surgeons of Milan. He was also a professor of rhetoric at the Collège de France. In 1772 he was appointed as professor of music to the College of Giulio Mafra. He died of apoplexy, the result of illness, at Capo di Faguto, northern Italy, on 7 November 1829.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Arthur E. Wells =  
Arthur Edwin Wells ( 29 June 1925 – 11 June 2004 ) was a New Zealand economics teacher, economist and political scientist. He was Professor of Economics and Political Science at the University of Otago.  
   
   
 == Life and career ==  
 He was born in Gosport, New Zealand on 29 June 1925 and was educated at the Otago University of Technology.  
 He worked for the Reserve Bank of New Zealand and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs before emigrating to Canada in 1948 where he worked for IBM.  
 In 1959 he started teaching at the University of British Columbia where he spent the rest of his career as a professor, economist and political scientist. He was a fellow of the Canadian Academy of Public Administration and chaired the faculty of the Department of Business Administration and Economics at UBC. He died on 11 June 2004.  
   
   
 == Selected publications ==  
 Arthur Edward Wells Papers. Economics and Political Science. 6. London : Cambridge University Press ( 1993 ).  
 Arthur Edward Wells Papers ( w.c.s. ). Economics and Political Science. 7. London : Cambridge University Press ( 1994 ).  
 Arthur Edward Wells Papers. ( w.c.s. ). Politics and Economics. 9. London : Cambridge University Press ( 1995 ).  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Margarete Curte-Père =  
Margarete Curte-Père ( 21 December 1858 – 16 February 1926 ) was a French botanist and plant pathologist.  
 Curte-Père was born in Paris, and completed her studies in natural sciences in Brussels, with the thesis `` La voix du soil ''.  
 Curte-Père was head of the botanical garden in Gauthier-sur-Maurat, in Belgium. From 1880 she worked with ornithologists in Laon, and during the same period with the botanist Pierre-Louis Trépané. She was also one of the first assistants of Louis Simenon in forestry at France, and one of the founders of the École pratique botanique. In 1884 she received an award from the State Botanical Institute in Paris. She continued in botanical work for almost 30 years, during which time she continued to work with the scientific societies in Paris, Marseilles, and Orléans.  
 During her life, Curte-Père lived in Gauthier-sur-Maurat with her husband and four children. Her son Nicolas Curte-Père founded an important botanical institute in Gauthier-sur-Maurat, in which she had a formal position until her death.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Sir Adolf Heinrich Haushofer =  
Sir Adolf Heinrich Haushofer ( 4 July 1862 in Hamburg – 20 August 1925 in Hamburg ) was a German botanist.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Haushofer studied medicine at the University of Hamburg and received a doctorate in 1885. Afterwards he practiced medicine in Hamburg and Graz ( from 1890 ), and he became professor at the University of Hamburg in 1905. From 1909 he was director of the National Museum of Natural History. He became professor in 1910, and at the same time the director of the Institut für Mycologie und Botanik ( First Institute of Mycology and Botany ) at Hamburg. He was in charge of the botanical collections at the university from 1907 to 1935.  
 In his academic career Haushofer carried out extensive research on German horticulture. In 1899, he conducted, among other things, studies on the flora of the waters of the Volga, as well as in place-trees and shrubs of the Chukchansi, and his entomological studies are very extensive.  
 Haushofer is credited with `` the discovery of the infamous but reclusive species of plant moths from the agricultural region of Rhineland and Saxony '', which have caused quite a sensation. He has also been the author of numerous articles on the species of plant family Agave.  
   
   
 == Taxa named in honor of Haushofer ==  
 Plant Hymenoclype Haushoferiae ( part of Simbergia family ), 1955  
 Gelebella Haushoferii, 1905  
 Eucalyptus ( a species of mangrove oak, Berchemia ) Haushofer, 1908  
 Eucalyptus variegata Haushofer, 1910  
 Ficus, ( Rosaceae ) Haushofer, 1917  
 Onagraceae Haushofer, 1913  
 Onagraceae maculata Haushofer, 1914  
 Osternia Haushofer, 1917  
 Zygophyllum Haushofer, 1918  
   
   
 == Personal life ==  
 He was married to Heinrich Maria Fischer, née Haushofer, and they had 3 daughters. He was adopted by the zoologist Joseph Ludwig.Haushofer was unmarried and did not get married, but he occasionally consulted his friends, mostly geologists and botanists. He did enjoy cinema.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 ( 1904 ) Die Phenonheide des Geliospermatisch-Hettischen Großes : the moderne Gesellschaft oder Nervenstand der Gleichgewacht des Hettischen Hydrogelets / 1908 Berlin  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Santiago Ribeiro =  
Santiago Ribeiro, also known as Santiago Camilo, was a Spanish conductor and pianist.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 He studied piano with Théodore Laffont ( 1899–1969 ), and at the age of 17 he gave his first concert.  
 Ribeiro was commissioned to give recitals in London and Paris with various orchestras, in order to serve as his pupil.  
 He also played the organ in a band in Buenos Aires, after which he taught for a year at the Conservatoire de Paris.  
 In 1936 he went to live with members of the Chilean élite in Rio de Janeiro.  
 He performed as arranger and soloist in the Santiago Carrera music theatre of the Concert Eulogia ( 1958 ), the Havana-based Santiago Festival, and the Galeria Valdemar island ( 1962 ).From 1954 until his death, he performed with the Colectivo Centro Musicalo, then the second longest-running institution of its kind, in Mendoza, where he resided.  
   
   
 == Music ==  
 He was a lyricist, and it is a fact that Pablo Neruda, noted pianist, mentor and dedicated music critic, also heard the works of him and gave him the nickname `` the Spotted Facsimile ''.He was a pianist for the Philharmonic Orchestra.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Abraham Horwitz =  
Abraham Horwitz ( February 4, 1868 – June 8, 1965 ) was a German Jewish philosopher.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Abraham Horwitz was born in Grünwald ( today Wiesbaden ).  
 He studied law and politics at the University of Göttingen, and was university assistant in diplomatic law. In 1880 he moved to Prague, working as a lawyer and arguing on behalf of the Protestant prisoners'association against the Austro-Hungarian annexation of Bohemia, and securing the conditions for the Northern Bialystok and Northern Carpathian Railway, thus marking a landmark in the development of European railroads. In 1882 he was a member of the Prague Internationalist Society and in 1884 was elected a member of the American Philosophical Society. In the following year he became a contributor to the Vienna-based German diplomatic journal  
 Probleme, and he also served as an honorary editor for the journal until 1907. In 1889 he published Über den Mensch, an article on the Jewish Question in his own opinion.  
 In 1909 he was awarded the Klausner Prize by the Freiheittheorie ( `` The Foundations of the Freiheit '' ), an organization founded by Karl August Lévy, which included Abraham Horwitz as an honorary member.  
 After the revolution of April 15, 1917, the Austro-Hungarian secret police, the Internal Affairs Division of the Ministry of Justice, interceded on the side of the Austro-Hungarian forces. On June 8, 1917 Horwitz was arrested by Hungarian police, but fled to Austria to escape arrest and to become a citizen of Vienna. His return to Prague occurred in 1919, when his old friend János Paus took him to the Academy of Sciences and Technology in Prague, where he lived to complete his degree.  
 Horwitz was then a Visiting Professor at the University of Ljubljana until 1934. His daughter, Charlotte was the first woman ever appointed professor of philosophy at a university in the newly-independent Czech Republic.  
 Horwitz died in Ljubljana.  
   
   
 == Literature ==  
 P. C. Cicera, `` Die ueber den Alten Wasser und die Krankheiten der Übersetzung das Leben des römischen erläuterten Werts '' ( Curiosities of Medieval Constitutionalism ), ( 1920 )  
 Brodtmann, Grazer zu Lemberg. Bd. 8a ( in German ), Vienna 1930, 3. ( in English )  
 Carl Theodor Schneier. Mein Lebensbestimmung. In : Tageblatt für medizinische und politischen Wissenschaften 24, 1–9 ( 1931 ), pp. 659–672 ( online first publication )  
 Zygmund Roemer, Triangulation of political thought,  
 Walter Benjamin, In Memoriam, New York 1969  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = George Bestey =  
George Bestey FRS ( 13 January 1903 – 7 August 2002 ) was an English civil servant, marine biologist and fisheries biologist best known as one of the main discoverers and early supporters of the Deepwater Horizon oil spill, for which he was awarded the Marine Mammal Protection Medal in 1991.  
   
   
 == Life and career ==  
 Bestey was born in Sarrista, Hampshire, the son of a schoolteacher. He studied philosophy and politics at Trinity College, Cambridge and University College London, obtaining a BA in 1923.  
 He went on to work for Shell as Director of Marine Biological Laboratories at Drury Lane in 1925, then for four years for the US Navy as Marine Biological Laboratory Engineer ( 1938-1940 ) and later for the US Navy as R & D Department of Engineering ( 1941-1943 ). In 1942, he was offered a post at the Shell Petroleum Company in Aberdeen and worked there for seven years before being appointed to Shell's new Petroleum Research Division ( BP ) in 1969. His appointment as BP's first head of its Deepwater Horizon oil spill laboratory is considered to have saved a ship and nearly 300 lives.  
 He was appointed Reader in Oceanography at the University of Oxford in 1967, and he was made a Fellow of the Royal Society in 1971. He retired from Shell in 1993.  
 After resigning from BP he was President of the National Marine Fisheries Society from 1969 to 1971 and was the first scientific director of the British Antarctic Survey from 1972 to 1976. In 1975, he was awarded the BP annual Marine Mammal award, becoming the first scientist to receive the award, and the biologist was widely regarded as an important pioneer in the discovery of marine mammals. He is notable as having the lead in preventing the exploitation of marine oil that resulted in the Deepwater Horizon oil spill.  
 Bestey was involved in researching how sea ice and other factors influence the size and spread of herring in the Arctic Ocean, which led to the author of the marine mammal species composition maps of the East Atlantic. He was appointed head of the Marine Biological Laboratory Marine Biological Laboratory ( now the Marine Biological Association ) in 1973, serving until 1998. He was known for his focus on the investigation of specific diseases affecting seafloor organisms.  
   
   
 == Legacy ==  
 The Marine Biological Association is named in his honour.  
 In 1997 the field of oceanography was revived in the academic world with the establishment of the Oceanography Research Centre at the University of Edinburgh.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = David Hallo-Stransky =  
David Hallo-Stransky ( 21 August 1920 – 29 November 2006 ) was a mathematician at the University of California, Berkeley, who was the first person in the United States to use Gödel's incompleteness theorem to prove a class of solutions in Hilbert space. He also published a number of papers on non-monotonic integral equations of Hilbert space. He did work in both the differential geometry and classical theory of analysis and was the author of many other works.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Hallo-Stransky was born in Riga, Latvia, on 21 August 1920, into a middle-class Jewish family. His father was a physician. His grandfather, Moshe Hallo-Stransky, was the founder of a bank in Riga. Hallo-Stransky attended secondary school in Riga. He entered the University of Latvia in 1932, after which he attended university in Dorton and Isem from 1933 to 1937.  
 During World War II, Hallo-Stransky volunteered for the army and, in January 1945, was commissioned as a second lieutenant in the Polish army. In 1946, after he had been imprisoned for a year, he was released. He returned to Dorton and then the University of Latvia in 1948.  
 The next academic year Hallo-Stransky taught physics at his alma mater, the University of Latvia. He received his PhD there in 1952. While still a professor, he became a professor of applied mathematics. The first work he published in mathematics was on solution of the Smolin–Domhoff problem in three dimensions.  
   
   
 == Gifted with a research specialty ==  
 Before becoming a professor, Hallo-Stransky was awarded a scholarship by the Galil organization in 1955. By 1957 he had published five papers in algebraic geometry, two in differential geometry, and one in classical theory of analysis. His thesis was on improved solutions of the Lie groups in second-order differential equations.  
   
   
 == Calculus of Variations ==  
 Hallo-Stransky submitted his solution of the Galil–Domhoff problem in two parts : the first part treated the Schola universal functions and the second part a very brief alternative to Poisson spaces. His proof, published in 1977, shows that a simple solution of the problems is obtainable using a simple unit function and one generalized definition of the Peano–Hermite cohomology in algebraic geometry.  
   
   
 == Awards and honors ==  
 From 1976 to 1981 Hallo-Stransky was the George C. Hallo Foundation Professor of Theoretical Mathematics at the University of California, Berkeley. He was also a fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. He was the founding editor of the journal Mathematical Theory. He received an honoris causa degree from the University of California, Berkeley in 1975.His most prestigious honors were :  
   
 1992, AER, the highest award of the American Mathematical Society  
 1993, IUPAC, the IUPAC mathematician of the year award  
 1996, American Academy of Arts and Sciences ( AMAS ), the highest honor given by AMAS to mathematicians  
 1999, Thomas Daggett Award, A. W. Kelly Institute for Mathematical Statistics, University of Michigan  
 2001, COSMIC mathematician of the year from the Mathematical Sciences Society of the Pacific  
 2004, American Mathematical Society ( APS ), the 2001 American Mathematical Society's mathematics fellowship medal for lifetime achievement and service to the field of mathematics.  
   
   
 == Selected bibliography ==  
 Sagal, Baruch ( 2008 ). `` Generalized Solution of Smolin–Domhoff G-groups  
 in Geometry, 1884-1978 '', Mathematical Theory. 8 : 182–198. doi:10.1007/BF010556511.  
 Ritchie, A.D. ( 2001 ). The Big Bang's Gravitational Mysteries : The Struggle for the Biggest Secrets in the Universe ( 2nd ed. ). Toronto : Allyn & Bacon. ISBN 978-1-87914-351-4.  
 Tropin, Paul & Ruth Parkin ( 1986 ). `` On the definition of the Peano-Hermite cohomology  
 in algebraic geometry '', Journal of Mathematical Physics. 19 : 793–818. doi:10.1088/2048-2931/19/13/003. MR 0119825.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = John Winthrop =  
John Winthrop ( 15 October 1633 – 27 July 1687 ) was an English Puritan theologian.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 John Winthrop was born on 15 October 1633, in Wiston, Devon, to Richard Winthrop, minister at a Puritan church there, and his wife, Jane, née Finlay, daughter of Samuel Finlay, co-founder of Finlay & Webb, a wholesale draper's shop in London. His father's family had been in Yorkshire. Winthrop was educated at Swarthmore and Derby, and graduated from Westminster College in 1644. He then became parish priest at Templeton, Worcestershire, and then was vicar at the high-church Rev. William Cottrell, Gloucestershire.  
 Winthrop became reader in 1652 and vicar at Aldinghwart in April 1657 ; this proved to be a good position, as he published a large number of sermons. He also furnished the weekly Sunday Review, and held the post of rector of Merton College, Oxford, until 1673. He retired from pastoral duties in 1689, having held the office for 25 years.  
 He edited the Manual of the Church of England, London, 1686–1708, and was master of the Library of the King's College, Cambridge, from 1671 to his death. He was a contributor to some of the great Christian periodicals of his time : the Pilgrim's Progress, the Anecdotes of Thomas Otis, the Advocate, the Domesday Book and the Great Books, and the Digest of Christian Knowledge, an inaugural essay on the book of Common Prayer, ( the Chronica theologicorum, collected together into the First Book of Common Prayer ) ; and at the time of his death, he was bookseller to the Royal Charter Board.  
 Winthrop was also one of the translators of the Bible into the Puritan language, with the Critical Books and New Testament, 1685–1687, translated by Robert Archer.  
 Winthrop was the author of six pieces of theology, each dealing with his own religious opinions. The last of these was a magnum opus, which was published posthumously in 1703.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 in 1630 :  
 Exposition of the Holy Scriptures, fol. lviii. 3, 8–10.  
 Dissertations, refractory, lectionary, & c, vols. ii. 4 & 6.  
 Works of Great Slightness : i. Poets and Advertisers ; ii. Acrobats and Authors of Useful People ; iii. Irishmen and Christians ; iv. Albanians and Greeks ; v. Graces of Penitent Men, & c ; vi. Barbers and Shopkeepers ; vii. Operative Religions and Frenchmen, & c ; viii. Solomon and his Five Books of Divers Systematization ( with an appendix to Virgil ).  
 ( 1661 ) Elements of the Breviary, London, 3 vols.  
 See, also, ix. Chapter VII : Gennadius, French : Deux Philosophi, Deus sive Hoc naturis et sive scripturis dictionari.  
 ( 1672 ) The Psalms of Solomon : having the Psalms in several instances studied together, containing many Useful Disquisitions upon the common Misspellings of the Hebrew, Greek, and other Languages, being, if not of rare occurrence, very full, as well as very concise, with full acknowledgments in their places, at the beginning of the Volume, to the successful whittler Mr. Winthrop, not on reminiscence able to procure the confirmation of his application ; of which he might hope that many he would find fit to publish in future ( now the more convenient year being a little past ).  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Laurence Bain =  
Laurence `` Billy '' Bain ( April 5, 1931 – January 11, 1998 ) was a U.S. radio engineer who helped develop atmospheric weather information in the 1960s and 1970s, and then worked at the U.S. Weather Bureau ( now part of NOAA ) between 1965 and 1989. Bain was instrumental in developing new forecasting techniques and programs that had the potential to improve and extend U.S. forecast accuracy, including tactical weather forecasts ( vortex chambers ), future forecasts, for storms, and problem-solving. His knowledge of radar led him to work with engineers, scientists, and government officials to design techniques and procedures for land-based weather stations, as well as applying that knowledge to rural and water-borne weather events.  
   
   
 == Early life and career ==  
 Born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania to a good-quality middle-class family, Bain graduated from high school in 1944. He attended the University of Pennsylvania in 1945, where he completed his undergraduate degree with a B.S. in Mechanical Engineering, and then later the J.D. from University of Colorado. He completed a doctorate ( D.Sc. ) in Meteorology and Atmospheric Sciences from the University of Colorado in 1948, and a Master's of Science ( M.S. ) in Meteorology and Atmospheric Sciences from University of Colorado in 1951.  
   
   
 == Experience with weather forecasters ==  
 While a meteorologist, Bain worked for a corporate consulting firm in Philadelphia. After becoming a weather forecaster in the middle of the Cold War, he returned to Washington, D.C., and became the chief meteorologist for the Washington Institute of Standards and Technology ( WISE ), which existed from 1948 until his retirement from WISE in 1981. Bain began his career with what he believed to be a less rigorous education in meteorology than his predecessors. He had a knack for discerning the mean value of weather reports, and was able to translate it from the theory into action.Working with Edward Bruce Fuller, who was chief of the Weather Bureau's Forecasting Division at the time, Bain devised a test to determine when a specific temperature was 100 degrees Fahrenheit, that proved useful in developing tactical and problem-solving forecasts. The test made predictions of high winds, low humidity and temperatures where precipitation was likely. In that test, air temperatures were given `` normal '' or `` good '' in the atmosphere, and `` perfect '' or `` perfect '' were given in the atmosphere. In his book, Thinking about Weather, co-authored with Winifred Head, Bain explained that he was using the `` optimum '' test because if the air temperature was not the best that the test can find, it would be more accurate and recommended of those who applied the technique.  
 While using the test, Bain was able to create solutions for problems in estimating a wind direction, and predicting when rain showers would occur. He also used a weather box, an electronic weather device used to measure the speed of prevailing winds. The success of his new ways of predicting data led him to conduct more experiments and develop more sophisticated weather models. At WISE, Bain began working with a government project to develop new ways to forecast large-scale storms and tornadoes.Bain joined the National Weather Service in 1963 as a systems analyst, serving in multiple jobs at various federal agencies. After retiring from WISE in 1981, he was a Weather Bureau senior meteorologist until 1989, when he stepped down to work as a professor and vice president at the University of Colorado. Bain received honorary doctorates from University of Colorado and the University of Pennsylvania in 1999.After leaving the Weather Bureau in 1985, he taught for one year at the University of Virginia and then taught at the University of Colorado. He was also appointed consultant to the University of Delaware, following retirement from WISE.Bain died on January 11, 1998.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Charles Angele Lummer =  
Charles Angele Lummer ( November 6, 1859 – March 28, 1923 ) was a Czech and Jewish socialist Jew, noted by Russian Jewish newspapers as a self-proclaimed political reformer and legislator.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Born in Prague, he was the son of Stephen Lummer and Christine ( Bickerton ) Lummer, who was twice married to David Stuart Fox-Roper. His father had also emigrated to America and settled in New York City. His grandfather, Samuel Lummer, had arrived in the United States with his family from Germany in 1683 and settled in Newton, Massachusetts, where his wife was from.In 1873, Charles Lummer obtained a position in Saint Petersburg as a janitor at the Lenin metro station. After some time working at a well known station, he went to the U.S. for higher study ( but never studying philosophy ) at the University of Cincinnati. He moved to the U.S. to further his studies at the University of Chicago. In 1899, after further study in Paris, he returned to the U.S. and obtained a position as a cook at the Pocklington & Mill Valley Steakhouse in Pocklington. After graduating in 1906, he moved to Berlin, where he worked as an economic historian for an insurance company until 1913.From 1913 to 1918, he taught sociology at a high school in Hyannis, Massachusetts. In 1918, he became a member of the Academy of Fine Arts in Chicago. He died there. His wife ( Annie Slavin ) continued to hold post at the U.S. Department of State in Washington, D.C., from 1922 until her death in 1923. In 1928, he was a nominee for the Senate of the state of Massachusetts.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Philip Lynch =  
Philip James Lynch ( March 6, 1893 – June 15, 1965 ) was an American physicist who, in his short career, was one of the world's leading physicists.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Lynch was born on March 6, 1893 in Burroughs, Oklahoma, a suburb of Oklahoma City. At the age of sixteen, he attended the University of Oklahoma, but decided to transfer to Cornell University, where he completed his Bachelor of Science degree in physics in 1923. In 1924 he received his PhD from Cornell under the supervision of Raymond Hamilton, who took him under his wing in New York and helped him apply his theoretical knowledge and physics skills to the physics of C- and T-waves.  
 While at Cornell University, he returned to New York, this time to Cornell College, where he received his Doctor of Philosophy degree in 1924. He continued his education at Columbia University, where he obtained a doctorate in 1928, and later worked for the United States Atomic Energy Commission as a physicist. In 1931, he married Auguste Compton in New York City. He then returned to Cornell, where he received his Ph.D. in physics in 1931. He went on to work at various agencies in the United States and internationally to learn about the role of electromagnetic radiation in the modern world, including atomic energy.  
 In 1932, Lynch served as professor of physics at the University of Michigan, where he worked under Ernest Lawrence until his death in 1949. He joined the faculty at New York University in 1951 and became professor emeritus in 1958.  
 At the time of his death, Lynch was the chairman of the Physics Department at the University of Minnesota.  
 He died on June 15, 1965 in Montclair, New Jersey.  
   
   
 == Awards and honors ==  
 The Lynch Medal was instituted by the University of Minnesota in his honor.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = César Fleury =  
François Claude Fleury ( born 11 September 1889 in Cluj, died 17 February 1994 ) was a French economist.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Fleury studied political economy at the University of Paris. His dissertation was on natural monopolies in the town of Cluj ( L'Iberoptère ) and he was married to Parisian salon owner and financier Catherine-Laurentine Flatt ; he had four children with his second wife.He developed a useful sector analysis ( a statistical method used to isolate the sector of the economy where the consumer preference accounts for 70 % of the total market share ). In 1913 he published Révision sociale, which was very influential in France during the era of the Neoclassical Socialism, so even though most French economists of the period did not use the term `` socialist economy '', it was very widely used, especially in economics journals.  
   
   
 == Books ==  
 Étude critique sur la monopolitaine et le baron de Cluj, 1914  
 Le Politique economice de Cluj, 1915  
 Révision sociale, 1921  
 L'économie de la moderne, 1922  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Ronald Sykes =  
Ronald Seth Sykes ( October 17, 1901 – October 8, 1986 ) was an American mathematician.  
 He was born in Chico, California. He received his BA from Stanford in 1922. From 1924 to 1939 he served in the U.S. Army in France and was a combat test pilot. He then moved to the University of California, Berkeley, where he received his MA and PhD, and in 1948 became professor of mathematics.  
 After his death in 1986, the University of California, Berkeley, established the Ronald Sykes Medal in his name, and given to student under the direction of Sykes.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Amadeo N C3 A7ra Alves =  
Ameido Nára Alves, Portuguese-American composer, bassist, and accompanist. A.N.C.D ( A.N.C.D. - National Order of Composers, composed July 19, 1936, † at the Bilbao International Festival ).  
 He was born in Bilbao ( Cômara ), Spain, in 1936, the son of Oscar Aleixandre and Isabelle Trabert Alves. His mother died in 1935. His father, Josefina Valente Alves, was a cellist, pedagogue and music teacher.  
 He was the first pianist to play the cello in Spain. He studied composition and composition at the Juilliard School and the Conservatory in New York City. He won a scholarship for the Conservatory of Music in 1959. His first award, the Grammy Award for `` Piano Sonata '', was received in 1965. He won three more Grammys, one each for `` Piano Sonata in E Minor '' ( 1966 ), `` Piano Sonata in G Minor '' ( 1967 ), and `` Piano Sonata in D Major '' ( 1969 ).  
 He also appeared in the Broadway revival of Étienne Meyerbeer's Third Piano Concerto in 1967. The musical ( Anima Parana ) is based on his debut LP of compositional works ( 1973 ).  
 His celebrated ABC operas included La segna de Genoa, Cantatas de Lacerda, Benito Rossi, La sonnicadura, Soledad, Zio de beidou, Allegro del junto, and Benito Rossi en clásicismo, a Romance of summer interludes. In 1976 he performed the world premiere of the Bizet Suite at the Munich Festival of Music. His orchestral works included compositions for the cello solo and the piano and many instrumental choral works.  
 Alves composed many classical and operatic pieces. The Sibelius quintet arranged in the Piano Trio also appears on his debut LP ( 1975 ), as did the Sibelius Variations on a Theme from Lucia di Lammermoor, composed for him by composer Andrés Montero ( 1958–70 ). Alves wrote no opera and did not play a role in one.  
 In 1984, Alves was nominated for a Grammy Award for Best Wind Instrumental, Violin Concerto and Great Voice and Guitar Solo Performance.  
 He died in Bilbao, Mexico, on May 19, 2003, and is buried in Perreira neighborhood, Bilbao, Mexico.  
   
   
 == Selected discography ==  
 Songs for the cello and the piano ( 1940 )  
 Letters from Carmen ( 1946 )  
 Letters from Carmen to MacGuffin ( 1948 )  
 The Extraordinary Man ( 1949 )  
 La Segna de Genoa ( 1951 )  
 Some of My Comeings ( 1953 )  
 Icaria de la fresca ( 1953 )  
 Passemusique da Ito ( 1955 )  
 La maría ( 1957 )  
 Allez ( 1957 )  
 A Few Concert Pieces ( 1958 )  
 Art as the Dam and the Court : The Negro Music of Mariano Rivera ( 1959 )  
 Cuba. Requiem for the Two Masters ( 1959 )  
 The Color of Flowers : Málaga concertos ( 1959 )

 La Confetti ( 1962 )  
 Henry Mendelssohn : Sa Bom Ja n Campo ( 1963 )  
 La Sonnétista ( 1964 )  
 The Ordinary Men ( 1965 )  
 7 Little Pieces ( 1965 )  
 Heavenly Melodies for Violin and Piano ( 1968 )  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Anton S C3 A1e =  
Anton Sáe ( 24 October 1907 – 7 September 1974 ) was a Finnish composer, music educator and pianist.  
 Sáe was born in Helsinki, Finland. He was awarded his high school diploma in 1929, graduated from the National Helsinki Conservatory in 1933 and his PhD in 1937. Between 1938 and 1950 he was professor at the national conservatory and from 1952 to 1954 director of its concert schools. From 1957 to 1970 he was the chair of the department of theory and musicology of the National Conservatory. From 1969 to 1973 he was the chair of the department of music education at the University of Helsinki. Sáe was a founding member of the Finnish Radio Academy and served on its board of trustees.He was the recipient of the USSR State Prize for piano in 1955, a similar honor for students at the National School of Fine Arts. He was the director of Helsinki University in Helsinki from 1961 to 1965, and the Kaunas School of Music from 1965 until 1983. He was a founding member of the Finnish Society of Music, giving many talks about his musical abilities.  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = George Watson Carlsson =  
George Watson Carlsson ( 17 February 1878 – 22 August 1952 ) was a Swedish physicist and crystallographer. He was Professor of Physic Chemistry at the University of Gothenburg from 1937 to 1962.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 He was born on 17 February 1878 in Gothenburg, Sweden. He began to study science in his hometown and received a habilitation in 1907 in Stockholm University and a PhD in 1916.  
 He moved to Stockholm in 1908 to work as an assistant to Professor Jacob Abel and stayed at the University of Stockholm. Carlsson then spent six years as a curator at the University of Lund, where he worked on synthesizing the crystalline structure of the tryptophan and lysine units. He studied crystallography and crystallographic petrography under Albert Togas.  
 In 1931 Carlsson became a research associate at the University of Göttingen, where he served as director of the Scripps Institution of Oceanography for five years.In 1936 Carlsson took a teaching position at the University of Copenhagen, where he worked under the direction of Gunnar Koch. He became a professor of crystallography in 1952, and in 1960 he became professor emeritus.  
 At the University of Gothenburg, Carlsson was a member of the Swedish Academy of Sciences from 1927 to 1938. He was elected a corresponding member of the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences in 1936.  
 He retired in 1962 and moved to Nyenäs, Sweden.  
 He died on 22 August 1952 in Nyenäs, Sweden.  
   
   
 == Awards ==  
 Gold Medal of the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Julius Wallenstein =  
Julius Wallenstein ( 17 January 1838 in Mühlefeld – 2 June 1901 in Mühlefeld ) was a German biblical scholar and philologist.  
 Wallenstein was an entomologist specializing in Diptera, a family of insects that includes beetles, and such insects as mosquitoes. His work includes comparative morphology of Diptera, as well as anatomical, genetic and phylogenetic studies of Lepidoptera, particularly Hymenoptera. He also published on the entomological genera and species of Hymenoptera, including Floki, Caprifoliidae, Cylindridae, Quaternary mites and Abelinidae. He also published on the general anatomy of the adult female, as well as on the reproduction of women.Wallenstein was a member of the Gymnasium Bilder Morgenländischer Gesellschaft in Munich, and was one of the founders of the Society for the Preservation of Insects.  
 Wallenstein's work is associated with von Staubach, Ludwig Jakob Müller, Friedrich Otto Rittel, and Ernst Müller.  
   
   
 == Publications ==  
 Wallenstein, Julius, Die Ergebnisse des Arachnidenus Génesiens [ Diptera ] ; partial list of serine synonyms, descriptions, nomenclature and general description of five insects, Jena 1853 [ 1 ] – Jena 1857 [ 2 ].  
 Wallenstein, Julius, Insectes für Jena 1848, - [ 2 ].  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Bill O'Connell =  
Bertie O'Connell, often referred to as Bill ( after his nickname by his fellow South African farmer Vivian `` Bill '' Wells ), was an English physiologist, physiologist and agricultural scientist.  
 O'Connell grew up in London, England.  
 He was educated at St Andrews and the University of Oxford. He worked for the National Health Service in the County of Kent between 1954-1955 where he won an award from the Higher Clinical Research Council for his work in clinical physiology.He won the Curator of Experimental Medicine ( FRCP ) medal in 1954 and was a member of the Club for Research Biochemists in 1956. He published over 100 research papers.  
 Bill O'Connell also wrote many scientific books and was a long time friend of the pioneering British epidemiologist Dr Harry Golding, often referred to as the Father of Public Health.  
 In the late 1960s, O'Connell and Dr Karl Marx undertook a joint PR campaign, for free tuition for all undergraduate post-doctoral students in physiology at universities around the country. O'Connell was vice-president of the working group of the Bio-Pharmacology Board at the European Centre for Experimental Biology ( ECEB ) and the Director of the Medical Research Council's Computer Science Department.  
 O'Connell's research made significant contributions in regards to the genetic influence on health and disease that he worked on. He used the term mutation to refer to the random mutations that occur in a given organism in response to environmental factors. Bill O'Connell's genetics genetic mutation found by Karl Marx in the 1970s has come to be regarded as one of the discoveries of the 21st century.O'Connell is remembered by his colleagues in health and science, such as biologist and colleague Robert Graves, who was also the editor of the biochemistry book The Challenge of Nature. O'Connell wrote over 350 scientific papers and many books and was a frequent contributor to popular science publications such as The Guardian, The Times, The Independent, the BBC and TV, and finally, the Sunday Times.  
   
   
 == Personal life ==  
 Bill O'Connell married Betty, a business executive, in 1954, having dated previously Ann Wright, his neighbour and widow from the Daily Telegraph's Paris Press and much more, in their first marriage, at Wrybro, near Co Meath, Ireland.  
 Bill and Betty had two children.  
 Bill was married to Susan, daughter of Robert Woodhead and Laura M. Macrobella. He died in Barnsley on 3 July 2009. His ashes are buried in the north-west corner of the family cemetery.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = V. S. Sumathi =  
V. S. Sumathi ( August 30, 1921 – January 30, 1995 ) was an Indian actor, academic and philanthropist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Sumathi was born on a Kurukshetra family farm near Pokhara. He moved to Mangalore and later to Madras, where he enrolled in the Baju Talbot Theological College and then passed his examination in Philosophy. In 1961 he took up a fellowship at the Madras Institute of Theology as an undergraduate, where he had the distinguished privilege of making a study in theology. In 1964, he left for Oxford University, where he completed his M.A. in Economics. In 1970 he studied History and Social Doctrine at King's College London.Later, he worked as an accountant at Bell Machine in Bengaluru and worked as a consultant in the field of auditing. He lectured at Bangabandhu University, Visakhapatnam and then Birla Bank in Mumbai. At the Madras Institute of Theology, he taught philosophy and economics and was very active in the administration of the university. He was also one of the professors at Mount Arunakaran College and the Madras Governorate's Research Institute. He was also a professor of Philosophy at the Madras Christian College, Madras. He served as the Dean of the Divinity School, Madras. His seminar work was in equity. From 1986 to 1996, he was a Professor of Social and Environmental Philosophy at the Royal Northern College of Religion in Bangalore.While at the Madras Institute of Theology, he had made a research study in income distribution and became an economist. In 1974, he was elected as a Fellow of the Royal Society of India. He retired from the Madras Institute of Theology in 1987 and moved to the United Kingdom, where he was professor and professor emeritus at Duke Divinity School, Durham. He died in the United Kingdom in 1995.  
   
   
 == Selected works ==  
 The Economics of Land ( Calcutta : The Christian Council Press, 1968 )  
 Income Distribution ( London : James Kerr and Sons, 1965 )  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Johannes von der Blasen =  
Johannes von der Blasen ( 1 April 1654 – 21 August 1764 ) was a German physiologist and anatomist.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 He was born in Munich as the son of a wealthy merchant. His father was Johannes de Blasen a licentiate of the university of Munich. After graduating in the 15th and 16th centuries, he was appointed as professor of physiology and natural philosophy at the University of Prague, where his attention was devoted to both physiology and anatomy.  
   
   
 == Accomplishments ==  
 He was professor of anatomy at the University of Erfurt ( 1673–7 ), from 1696 to 1698 he was dean of the faculty of theology at the University of Tübingen ( 1698–1702 ), and he retired from this office in 1702, dying in Prague.  
 His best-known book was `` Fortschritte der Physiologie in Belgische Landsdorfer '' ( 1689 ), a comparative anatomy and physiology of the upper and lower limbs of man ; three sermons on `` The Ancient Physiognomy of Man '' ( 1696, 1704 ) were published simultaneously with this work.  
 He was married twice : in 1703, to the Elector of Brunswick, Gabrielle Magdalena de Blasen ( 1694–1723 ), who gave birth to ten children. The last wife died in 1718, when Johannes had been half-buried in the Church of St. John the Evangelist in Dornach.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
   
   
 === Books ===  
 Versuch einer physische Untersuchungen über der Korte [ Meditations on Physiology ] 1697 – On the physiology of the upper and lower limbs of man.  
 Geschichte der physiologischen Untersuchungen über besonderer, unberschiedene Thiere & Thiereits und Leben und Vergangene ( vol. 1 ), Georg Georg Herrmann 1698 – General physiology of the upper and lower limbs of man.  
 Fortschritte der Physiologie in Belgische Landsdorfer 1697 – Comparative anatomy and physiology of the upper and lower limbs of man.  
   
   
 === Notes ===  
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Jacques-Henri Capdevant =  
Jacques-Henri Capdevant ( 31 July 1795 – 20 August 1885 ) was a French gardener, botanist, ornithologist and businessman.  
   
   
 == Life and work ==  
 Capdevant was born in Étienne-Maritime, Rohan and studied zoology at the Collège de Lorraine and the University of Paris. He is considered the originator of the term merino wool ( hence the color of capdevants'ruffs ), a luxury cotton and wool product of the mid-1700s that received wide acceptance after obtaining international attention and acceptance. His scientific work mainly centered on the history of floras, especially those of mountain gorillas ( gorillas, orangutans, and rhesus monkeys ) and certain animals of tropical Africa. The dayfaunas he visited included the forests of Asia, the Karakoram ( Afghanistan ) and Borneo. He also studied the flora of Madagascar, Sunda Islands and Thevaland.In 1832, at age 26, he completed his first major scientific work, a monograph of the plants of the Australian Parthenogenetic Gardens in Bagdad. It was intended to introduce and simplify the geographic arrangement of plants in the garden. This monograph included an account of the human fossil remains found in the gardens. Capdevant's homestead on Alpinac Hill in New Jersey, where he became famous, also recorded the remains of the first hominids known from India.  
   
   
 == Scientific work ==  
   
 Capdevant's work led to a series of publications that were of great scientific importance. Many of the collected plants in the parthenogenetic gardens of the Dutch East India Company in India came from Africa, particularly Africa's mountain gorilla species. These fossil species include :  
   
 Batarana capdevanti ( Harcourt, 1817 )  
 Zygodon undperovya ( Lang, 1833 )  
 Genus Brasiliensis ( Harcourt, 1837 )  
 Pangalochiaceae and Patagonicae ( Lang, 1840 )  
 Germinals :  
   
 Steriope, a species of African horse ( Papaeus rubri, called horse paludarium by Barth ).  
 Bacchus, an Indian shrub native to India.  
 Lycopodium capdevanti ( Harcourt, 1856 )  
 Meloangelina capdevanti ( Lang, 1861 )  
 Myrmecolopsis capdevanti ( Harcourt, 1866 )  
 Pedunculatedia capdevanti ( Lang, 1867 )  
 Lagganoidea capdevanti ( Lang, 1870 )  
 Acaenia capdevanti ( Lang, 1874 )  
   
   
 == Family ==  
 Capdevant married his wife, Gabriela, the daughter of a merchant in Hamburg. The couple had two daughters and a son.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Orff M. Wigster =  
Orff John Wigster ( 1923–1995 ) was a Quaker author and Professor Emeritus of the University of Chicago School of Economics.  
 He wrote three books, books on Civil Society ( 1961 ), Civil Rights : The State's Role in Improving Social Standards ( 1969 ), and Why Liberals Say they Hate Capitalism ( 1973 ). In 1990, Wigster was involved in a campaign of civil disobedience against World Bank in East Africa in Africa.  
 He was awarded the John E. O'Callaghan Courage Award in 1974.  
   
   
 == Bibliography ==  
 South Africa : What Has Changed? ( 1974 )  
 After Ten Years of Democratic Reconstruction ( 1976 )  
 The Natural Order of Things ( 1987 )  
 The Postmodern Age ( 1988 )  
 Economic Aspects of Epistemology ( 1991 )  
 Patterns of Force ( 1994 )  
 As Bores Draw ( 1996 )  
 Doing God's Work : A First Year's Outline of the Cornell Distinguished Lecture on Economic Ethics ( 1996 )
