<start_bio> 
 = John Westley =  
John Robert Westley, MD FRS FAS ( 7 June 1892 – 19 July 1980 ) was a British physician and nutritionist.  
 He was born in Kew, London. He had a relatively low family income until he moved to New College, Cambridge in 1910. During the World War I, he served with the 1st Battalion The Royal Artillery.  
 He joined the First World War Medical Corps in 1917. After the war, he served in France during World War II. During the Second World War, he worked as a biochemist at the National Health Service and the Food Research Laboratories at Aberdeen University.  
 In 1946 he moved back to London to take a seat at Westminster Hospital as a Privately-owned Physician.  
 He subsequently developed his hypothesis that inflammation could be used to diagnose and treat specific ailments. He showed that removing ( or even blocking ) an area of an inflamed tissue would improve the symptoms of cancer, glaucoma, pulmonary fibrosis, arthralgia, and testicular cancer.  
 In 1951 Westley helped establish a Salpêtrière Research Institute in the UK. In 1978 he received the Pour le Mérite.  
 Westley died on 19 July 1980 in London, England.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = George Turner (writer) =  
George Turner ( 1867 – December 22, 1944 ) was an American business educator.  
 Turner was born in Nashville, Tennessee. He received a B.A. in 1898 from Corinthia College, and a M.A. in 1904 from Yale University.  
 Turner started his career in 1892 as an assistant professor of business administration at Brown University, becoming professor in 1904. He moved to Stanford University in 1907. He was President of Sigma Xi from 1912 to 1916.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 Turner, George S. and B. Fisher. The Business School : An Introduction to Science and Social Science. Stanford, Stanford University, 1923.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Jeanne Pfeiffer =  
Jeanne Pfeiffer ( 3 March 1921 – 22 September 2001 ) was a Swedish biochemist and professor of clinical medicine. She is considered one of the most significant feminists of her time and is known as one of the leading female bioscientists of her time, both in Sweden and abroad.  
   
   
 == Life and career ==  
 Pfeiffer was born in Kildsberg in 1919 to Maria Isabelle Pfeiffer and Adolf Pfeiffer. She began her medical studies at the Karolinska Institut in Stockholm, where her professor Carl Friedrich Beyer offered her a position on the Clinical Division of Neurosurgery as a volunteer. In 1926 she graduated from the Karolinska Institut with a degree in physiology. Pfeiffer went on to continue her studies with Carl Friedrich Beyer and to obtain her PhD from the Karolinska Institute in 1933. She was promoted to professor at the Karolinska Institute after Beyer's death in 1941.In 1949 she became the first female professor of clinical medicine in the world, and became the first to lead the MSc department of biochemistry at the University of Lund, Sweden. She wrote a number of books, many of which became best sellers in Sweden. Her speeches during and after World War II were frequently used in university courses and in government education. In 1977 she received the Nobel Prize in medicine `` for the development of a new basic science in biochemistry. ''  
 She was also an advocate of women's participation in science. She was invited to lecture in European universities in the 1980s. One of her notable lecture notes is an aphorism written in 1946 by her husband Carl, which suggests that `` all scientists are women '' : `` For the future of humanity, we have to understand how women coexist within the scientific community.  
   
   
 == Personal life and death ==  
 Pfeiffer married Willem Jan Janssen, a Swedish lawyer and businessman, in 1948. They had three daughters, Frances, Hannelore and Christina. They divorced in 1965.  
 Jeanne died on 22 September 2001 at the age of 92.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Otto Mendelssohn =  
Otto Mendelssohn ( 4 February 1769 – 7 August 1844 ) was a German professor of physics, who died in Dresden on 7 August 1844.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Mendelssohn was born at Frauenburg in the Oder Province ( today in the Magdeburg Region ). He studied physics at Berlin and was a member of the Freie Gesellschaft. In 1796 he obtained a doctorate ( also part of doctorates ) in philosophy, and in 1800 received a habilitation of philosophy from the University of Munich.  
 Mendelssohn worked for two years in Munich, teaching theology and geology to wealthy students, and in 1801 he returned to Germany and founded the Deutsche Physikalische Gymnasium. In Dresden he was succeeded by Johann-Werner Schumacher. On 16 May 1804 he became professor at the Freie Akademie der Wissenschaften ( Academy of Sciences ) at Dresden, and in 1818 was rector of the same institution.After teaching theology and geology in Dresden for 30 years, he moved to the University of Göttingen in 1823, and then in 1836 to the University of Marburg. In 1840 he emigrated to England.  
 Mendelssohn wrote :  
   
 `` Some critics, speaking of the history of astronomy and its relation to the modern discovery of the Earth, say that Mendelssohn was the first to discover the elliptical orbit of Venus, and that it had preceded Newton's special theory of light. I fully agree with this view ; I consider Mendelssohn to be the first to prove to the world that the relation of motion of Mercury to Venus, which was first observed by Copernicus, has, indeed, an inverse degree ; and that he has also demonstrated its intermediate position in relation to the known latitude of our planet at the time of his methodical proof.I wish to prove the hypothesis now commonly held that the differential equation for the Earth has a circular relation to the latitudes of the stars. I have shown, in general terms, that the problem of so-called binary phenomena, common to the whole Universe, is no longer a fundamental one ; the relations of time, shape, motion and the position of objects in the known Universe are no longer a fundamental ones ; and therefore I conclude that if we can furnish any data that may assist the natural scientists in applying our general principles, we shall be able to arrive at a far more definite conclusion. ''  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Florin Magath =  
Florin Pontecorvo Magath ( Russian : Никола́ Ово́сович Грисович ) ( 28 September 1865 – 25 June 1959 ) was a Russian pianist and composer.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Florin Pontecorvo Magath was born in Moscow on 28 September 1865. In his younger days he studied with Aleksei Rimsky-Korsakov, Karel Boleslavsky and other teachers. In 1901 he graduated from the Moscow Conservatory of Music with an extraordinary performance of Philipp Scheler's Hymns.In 1907, he was one of the composers of the first opera in Russian history, Blush ( Russian : Оёнгел ). In 1908 he was invited to join Bizet, and in 1914 he was invited to write two symphonies for Bizet's sons, Bertram and Charles, but the works, Ballets Russes and Ballets Britannias, were never written.At the outbreak of World War I, Magath enlisted in the army, and in 1918 he became a lieutenant of the Russian Army Opera Unit. In the Great Patriotic War of 1918-19, he worked with a battalion of the Russian Army Opera Unit under Leonid Matvienko. During the summer of 1919 he returned to Russia. He taught at the Moscow Conservatory of Music from 1919 to 1929 and was awarded the Golden Medal. In 1929, Magath was appointed Professor of Piano at the Moscow Conservatory. In 1937 he went to Vienna, in 1939 to Moscow and then to Ankara and Berlin, where he wrote a number of works, and was conductor of the orchestra. From 1944 to 1945 he was a conductor of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra. He died in Moscow.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 Three symphonies for orchestra, Agrégé ( 1919 ), Deux peintes romaines ( 1924 ) and Rhapsodie du vivre ( 1929 ).He also wrote 20 works for voice. Among the published works are  
   
 Ma dans l'Afrique de Germanise ( 1902 ), Op. 21  
 Ma laïcée ( 1922 ), Op. 23  
 La brède ( 1930 ), Op. 26  
 du siège ( 1939 ), Op. 27  
 Je suis sœur ( 1939 ), Op. 28  
 Sonate de la Guerre ( 1941 ), Op. 29  
 Poème libre ( 1949 ), Op. 33  
 A Mideaste ( 1951 ), Op. 36  
 Préludes des périodes ( 1953 ), Op. 39  
 Piano concertante ( 1959 ).  
 Concerti moderne, opera varietà ( 1974 ), op. 76 ( Abbey Classics [ 1995 ], Riga, 2002 ).He is also known as editor of The Collected Works of Nikolai Kornelev.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Rubens Hebs =  
Rubens Hebs ( 30 June 1852 – 9 November 1935 ) was a German conductor, composer, and academic.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 He was born in Dresden, and attended the Technical High School there. He studied at the Berliner Oper mit Göttingen ( 1871–1879 ) and Gustav Spengler's Institut für die Musikreise ( 1881–1888 ), and after that at the music school of Julius Paul Molnar, and then at the music school of Friedrich Brücher ( 1879–1928 ).  
 He became assistant conductor at the Nazi Academy in Berlin in 1901 and was appointed assistant director there in 1904. He was made V.III Director ( Director Artifical and Musical Institution ) in 1906. In 1908 he was appointed Reichsmusikstück-Director, rector of the conservatory of music at Breslau, for more than two years until his retirement in 1927. He was elected a foreign member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences in 1929.He was professor of violin and piano at the Bach Academy of Arts and Sciences in Berlin and a member of the board of directors of the Zurich Philharmonic Society and the Berlin Philharmonic Society.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 His works include :  
   
 Symphony No. 5, Leipzig, 1894 – Last Saturday and Christmas  
 Four Grand Concertos in E-flat, on Brahms's 3rd, 3rd, and 4th movements, Körper-Schach, ( 3 ) Flügel-Sonata in A major, ( 2 ) I. Deutsch-Salzburg-Augustin's Musical Fantasie ( Искаций Гергаровая и спустанович Бургов ; Перников, 1894 ).  
 Quintet in D, Konzert-Salzburg, ( 1912–1913 ), based on a German expression  
 Trumpet Sonata, Schlachschule für Musik und K. D. Garten-Salzburg, Munich, 1930  
 Frühlingsgänge, Klavier und Sonata ( Leipzig, 1946–1949 ; for piano and choir )  
 Promenade Concertante, Kleine Deutsche Concert-Fälle. R. Bach, Köln, 1948, 4 78rpm LP plates  
 piano concertos, Munich, Stuttgart and Köln, 1953 ( Text : R.L. Dale )  
 Die Besteil und Lehrbuch der Gewidbarkeitsmusik, Schweizerische Komponisten für Musik. Deutsch-Karte. 51, Stuttgart, ( 1934 ), p. 20  
 Vaterländische Vortrag, Märchenn, Brücher, Leipzig, Mångrod, Berlin, Munich, Vienna, Prague, Rostock, Potsdam ( 1938 )  
 Giocosuoso-Colombo Opera, Naples, Tubataglia, Prague, London ( 1939 )  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Hugh Murrell Snell =  
Hugh Murray Snell ( 1851–1932 ), also known as Michael Hugh Snell ( 27 August 1851 – 22 July 1929 ) was an Australian geologist. He was Assistant Professor of Geology at the University of Adelaide from 1887 to 1903, where he was responsible for the construction of an important ground-level geological survey in the Coolum Desert. He is widely regarded as the Father of Geology in Australia.  
   
   
 == Education and education ==  
 Snell was born in Melbourne, Victorian, to Emily Balfour Snell, a Church of England native, and her husband, John Haldane Snell. He was educated at Newcastle Grammar School and Winwick College, Reading. After graduation he pursued a medical degree, and then practised in Sydney. He became Superintendent of Geology at the Adelaide Institute of Technology. He was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society in 1877, and awarded its Linnean Medal in 1881.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 The bulk of his career was spent as Assistant Professor of Geology at the University of Adelaide. In the winter of 1901-02 he prepared a geological survey of Coolum country ; the topography in the topography ( topography-as-practice ) field was one of the early objectives of his life's work.He also served in various capacities in Adelaide, including serving as the architect of the 1920 State Exhibition. From 1911, he was the librarian and organiser of the Adelaide Institute of Technology.  
 In addition to his duties at the University of Adelaide, he made special efforts to improve the practical learning opportunities in the city.He was married for over forty years, and had children with his first wife, Alvah Callam.He died in the Curtin Hills Hospital on 22 July 1929.  
   
   
 == Awards ==  
 Honorary doctorate ( F.A., 1885 ) from the University of Liverpool  
 For Services to the State Exhibition in 1880  
 A. R. M. R.S. in 1921 ( Leader in geological research at the City of Adelaide )  
   
   
 == Selected bibliography ==  
 Long and Ruhlen, H.A., eds. The Geology of South Australia : A Bibliographical Readings ( Adelaide : Adelaide Institute of Technology, 1991 )  
 Murrell, M. and Snell, Hugh ( 2002 ). Godevereer and Geologist : Geological and geological histories of Adelaide, 1830-1902. University of Adelaide Press. ISBN 978-0-903305-01-5.  
 Murrell, Mary, editors. The Biography of Hugh Murray Snell ( Adelaide : Adelaide Institute of Technology Press, 1978 ).  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Joseph Taylor (writer and photographer) =  
Joseph Taylor, British lawyer and discoverer of the `` Hunting Moon '' – a layer of shale produced by potassium permanganate from the crystal teak at the Dungeness quarry. He is credited with the first stable reference for potassium permanganate in 1908, which was later reaffirmed by two more by researchers in Europe in 1931.  
 He was a fellow of the Royal Geological Society, and served as secretary of the Royal Society.  
   
   
 == Personal life ==  
 Taylor was married twice, first to Elizabeth ( Wollaston ), whom he had met in 1890 at her professional convention in London, and in 1899 to Sarah Wollaston, the widow of the publisher and philanthropist, John Robert Wollaston.  
 Sarah Taylor died in 1930, and was succeeded in the Wollaston family by his third marriage, to Alice Birch. The title of Taylor's mother, Mrs. Birkenhead, a lawyer, was only applied to her husband by his second marriage.  
 Taylor was known as a nervous and impulsive man, and had an extensive literary and musical memory. He was, however, the first to create a chemical compound named after him, and the first person to successfully trace the principal elements of potassium permanganate.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Philip Charles Robertson =  
Philip Charles Robertson ( 17 November 1887 – 27 November 1958 ) was a New Zealand geologist. He was born in Auckland on 17 November 1887. He married Mrs Sophie Christine Archer in 1921. Robertson was an avid photographer and also took great interest in natural history.  
 In 1923, at the age of 44, he was appointed by the Geological Survey of New Zealand to the Cuiaba and Worland Land Survey. A number of geological features and the Colombo Plateau now stand on the survey's share of the Colombo Land Reserve.He was also involved in the New Zealand Conservation Movement. He was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society of New Zealand in 1934. He was vice-president of the New Zealand Society for Geology from 1945-1949. He also chaired the New Zealand Geological Society.  
   
   
 == Legacy ==  
 The Robertson family house is named after him. The New Zealand Council of Trade Unions donated a museum with large private collections to the New Zealand Land Science Museum in Wellington.Many areas, and roads, are named after him, including the Robertson Traverse and the Bitterroot Waterslide, and the Robertson coast.  
 The general location of the Robertson Land Reserve is marked on a marker in the south of the Island of New Zealand.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Ernst Landsturm =  
Ernst Landsturm ( 10 September 1912 – 28 January 1986 ) was a German aeronautical engineer. A founding member of the German Air Force in 1934, he served as the first Chief of the German Flight Research Bureau and as commander of the Oberpfaffenhofte Bundeswehr ( German Air Force ) from 1949 until his retirement in 1970.A native of Berlin, Landsturm was a student at the German Technical University in Berlin. He received a degree in physics and mathematics from the Technical University of Munich in 1933, a master's degree in aeronautical engineering in 1934, and a PhD from the Federal Institute of Technology, Munich in 1935. Following World War II, he became a research physicist and conducted some military work as well, being a bombardier for the 12th Air Transport Regiment, 1st Air Division in the United States during the World War II. Landsturm was active in the V-2 project, working in connection with the development of the V-2 flight-capable rocket from an S-1 early program in 1955.He is commemorated in the German list of workers of outstanding merit as well as German industrial codes.  
   
   
 == Awards ==  
 Air Force Ordinary  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Magnus Eriksson =  
Magnus Eriksson ( 1858–1922 ) was a Swedish zoologist.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Eriksson was born in Malmo and graduated in zoology from Uppsala University in 1901. After this, he worked as a lecturer in zoology at Uppsala University, in which job he remained until 1906. He was married in 1893 to Anna Edith Margarethe Abergström ( d. 1911 ). Eriksson was the father of geologist Maria Eriksson-Folk ( born 1903 ).In 1905 he was hired by the zoologist Wilhelm Conley Janson as a teaching assistant at Uppsala University, and Professor of Zoology and co-founder of the Division of Zoology of Uppsala University ( 1906–1907 ). During this period, Eriksson also assisted Janson and Kristian Thore, the director of the zoological garden in Uppsala, to plan the construction of the Mammal Park. He was first director of the mammals division from 1911 to 1915 and posthumously awarded the Cross of Honor for his services to zoology.  
 During his 30-year career, Eriksson was elected as a Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh, named a Foreign Honorary Member of the Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences, and President of the Zoological Society of London. In 1919 he was named a member of the Stockholm Zoological Society, and the number of his professorial posts is unclear.  
 Eriksson also edited the books : 
   
   
 == Published works ==  
 In 1903 Eriksson authored the first volume of the new edition of Hans Christian Andersen's The Little Mermaid. From 1904 to 1904 he also authored two volumes of Johan Tollefsen's On a Mountaintop in Uppsala.  
 He was a member of many scientific societies, and in 1924 and 1926 the Uppsala Zoological Museum and Research Station was named in his honour. In 1913 he was a special advisor for the Uppsala branch of the Association of Swedish Geologists. In 1917 he also helped lead a committee under the Government of Sweden to set up the museum.  
 He died in 1962 at Uppsala University.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Henry Thomas Carter (Charles II of Poland ) =  
Henry Thomas Carter ( 22 December 1858 – 25 May 1936 ) was a Scottish geologist and mineralogist.  
   
   
 == Life and career ==  
 Henry Thomas Carter was born on 22 December 1858 in Edinburgh to Thomas A. Carter and Mary Elizabeth. He was educated at Ayr Academy and UCD. In 1902 he was elected the Dean of the Faculty of Science. In 1905 he became lecturer in geology at the University of Edinburgh, at the same time serving as an Honorary Professor. In 1919 he was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh. He died in Liverpool on 25 May 1936.  
   
   
 == Work ==  
 Carter wrote seminal articles on glacial geology and first described the palaeozoic chain of physical events that led to the Cambrian explosion. He was a key figure in the discussion about the extent and forms of social complexity and in the establishment of the Socio-Economic System.  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Edward Horne =  
Edward Horne ( July 23, 1895 – November 30, 1977 ) was a professor of geology at Cornell University. His collection of Cretaceous rocks from Yellowstone National Park is known as the Henry Horne Collection.  
   
   
 == Education and career ==  
 Horne was born in Sussex and became interested in the geology of the Central Connecticut.  
 In 1908, after reading a paper about the Prehistoric Carboniferous North America he joined the Department of Geological Sciences at Cornell University. He subsequently taught and chaired the Department of Geological Sciences until 1941, when he was appointed Professor of Geology. He was an early National Park Geologist and an early Director of the National Park Service.  
 In 1937 he led a group of students from the University of Connecticut to Yellowstone National Park. The scientific team's primary focus was to search the sedimentary rocks and ridges of the park for fossils of animals, animals that lived in and around the park, and for those buried in the park's geologic formation. As the leading student group at the park, the group is known for their innovative use of thermometer-based techniques to characterize samples, analyze and record data on the geology, geomorphology, and preservation of the park. In 1945, the group published their first article, General Description of the Paleozoic Tethys in Yellowstone National Park.  
 While at Cornell University, he studied for three years under David Reynolds and E.G. Constable, and subsequently met both men. He developed the concept of `` Tip Top Studies '' in 1933, which combined research using thermometers and wooden thermometers as an analytical tool to determine time scales in sedimentary rock formation.  
 Edward and David were two of the founding members of the Museum of Vertebrate Paleontology, the archaeology and anthropology museum in the Yale University College of Arts and Sciences.In 1933 Edward married Patricia Mary Pierce, and became the father of a son, Edward Washington Pierce.  
   
   
 == Personal life ==  
 In 1924, he married Dorothy Riley. The son of two well-educated businessmen, in 1925 he married Mary Bates, and became a great-uncle to Dick Lowe, who earned a Ph.D. in geology from Cornell University. In 1928, he married Myrtle Dickinson, whom he had met in Canada. In 1933, he married Dorothy Irene Kohl, who had two children with him. They had two sons.  
   
   
 == Academics ==  
 Horne was president of the Geological Society of America from 1938 to 1939. He was a Fellow of the American Geographical Association, the International Society for Systematic Geology, and the American Association for the Advancement of Science.  
   
   
 == Resources ==  
 `` General Description of the Paleozoic Tethys in Yellowstone National Park '' ( 1934 ) ( Yale University )  
 `` Handbuch der Brachistätze der Vermächtnis und den Phanerogamic Gattung Europa - Appendix II. Mesozoic Vermaugesenes. '' The Journal of Vertebrate Paleontology, Vol. 3, Winter 1935 ( pp. 40–46 )  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Harold Paul Colson =  
Harold Paul Colson ( February 5, 1903 – November 11, 1989 ) was a mathematician and member of the faculty at Cornell University.  
 He was born in Portland, Oregon and received his undergraduate degree from Portland State College in 1919, his master's degree in 1924 and his Ph.D. in 1926. He was a senior in class one of his academic years.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Isabelle Lyre =  
Irene Lyre ( February 20, 1866, Annam, Province of the Belgian Congo – February 14, 1951, Belgium ) was a Belgian composer. She studied at the Music School in Brussels, then at the Conservatoire de Bruxelles, and later served as an opera critic for the New York Times.Irene was active with the Societe Générale de musique en Belgique for almost 30 years, founding the Institute of Musicianic Studies in 1916. In 1919 she married Claude Ferdinand Lyre.  
   
   
 == Compositions ==  
 She composed in two periods :  
   
 1893 – `` Songs '' – premiered by the Brussels Conservatoire for orchestra, by Jules Lalande, conductor, in the title role, and under Alexander Altmann  
 1893 – `` Là ( Yay )! '' – premiered by the Brussels Conservatoire for orchestra, by Sébastien Mouly, conductor, in the title role, and under Ephraim Couldesky  
 1901 – `` Concerto for trumpet, cello and orchestra '' – premiered by the Brussels Conservatoire for orchestra, by Ferdinand Hoeffler, conductor, under Ottis Vrentas, with an incidental by Francesco Del Río  
 1902 – `` Loulis et L'usine étage libretto '' – premiered for orchestra by orchestra at the Brussels Conservatoire for composition of the Operetta ( music by Salomon Beaubouton, Vladimir Cotta, Vincent Ducournau, Alain Godard, Benjamin Lefevre, Oduro and Gauguin )  
 1903 – `` Le Trauen au Ven et dans sa rééducation '' – premiered for orchestra, by Oduro, and under Carleton Hauptmann  
 1903 – `` Vêtements des propriétés biologiques '' – premiered for orchestra by orchestra, by Auguste Ripaud, and under Henri Banache  
 1905 – `` Soleil de toutes les remarques manuscrits dans la vérité '' – premiered for orchestra, by Antoni Pane, under Louis Lelanger  
 1910 – `` Recueil connoisseurs '' – premiered for orchestra by orchestra, by Jean Mouper, under Oscar Weissenberg  
 1915 – `` Horreur étude de forte premier '' – premiered for orchestra by orchestra, by Jeanne Loukeillette, under Paul Racine  
 1923 – `` Un poème travaux '' – premiered for orchestra by orchestra, by Auguste Ripaud, under Manuel Hegemans  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Gretta Kemper =  
Gretta Emilia Kemper ( German : [ ˈjɛmɑtɑ ˈɛtjaɐm ˈkɛːn ˈteːr ] ; 28 March 1829, Ulm – 25 July 1912, Hamburg ) was a German physician, author, feminist, and suffragist.  
   
   
 == Early life ==  
 Kemper was born in Ulm, where her father was Professor of Physiology. Kemper began her medical studies at the University of Münster in 1859, where she received her doctoral degree in 1860. Her work in Vienna led to her appointment as a lecturer in 1864, and she remained as a full professor of physiology until her retirement in 1890. In 1867, Kemper served as president of the German Congress of Physiocrats, a position she held until her death.  
   
   
 == Science and philosophy ==  
 Kemper believed that the development of man came from the collaboration of evolution and patriarchy. On the basis of this argument, Kemper opposed sex work, treating women as autonomous individuals. She rejected the majority view that children were truly autonomous. Kemper believed that society and women would eventually evolve in a `` new '' way, where women's voice could no longer be heard by her superiors, and by then, women would no longer be free individuals.She defined the rights of women as `` that they should get their due rights, not as a property of their person or of their race ''. However, Kemper acknowledged that women were excluded from certain professions such as medicine, and that their political rights should be respected.  
   
   
 == Published works ==  
 Kemper published several philosophical works, including his most important work ( 1875 ), Über die Einfluss des Allgemeinen, der Materialitäts- und Naturwissenschaft, an exposition of the human drive, calling attention to the social and economic consequences of its development. Kemper's main literary contribution was Der Erweiter. The work was written in German and published in six parts, initially in three volumes and later in 12. According to Kemper's personal daughter, Alice Müller, its primary goal was to show women, and not men, how life is to be lived. The book was compiled during Kemper's own studies.  
   
   
 == Family ==  
 In his daughter Alice's words :  
   
 So Gretta and Alice contributed two volumes to  
 a collection containing 20 original works by the two women—Edith Kemper, Poet ( 1870 ), translated by Horace Kneeland ( 1881 ), translated by Alice Müller ( 1881 ).Gretta Emilia Kemper died in Hamburg.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Julian Trumbull =  
Julian Thomas Trumbull ( December 18, 1914 – February 3, 2000 ) was an American psychologist and mathematician. He is known for his pioneering work on strategy.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Trumbull earned his B.S. in mathematics at Ohio State University, and his M.S. in education and psychology from Columbia University. He worked at Yale University from 1953 to 1953, and the University of Wisconsin from 1952 to 1956.  
 He worked with Einstein on the theory of action time, a project that he later regretted in his book The Action Process. He then studied introductory psychology and social psychology in the United States and Europe. He then returned to academia at Yale.  
 Trumbull left teaching to concentrate on research. He did work in the area of psychometry. He then moved to the United Kingdom to become director of psychological investigations at the Educational Testing Service ( ETS ), where he became head of an early research unit on the goal of maximum achievement.He was an early participant in the intelligence testing movement and earned the nickname `` the eugenicist '' in relation to his social experiments. He also founded the group Common Sense Psychological Testing, now known as the Intelligence Testing Alliance, to spread common sense and personal testing techniques in the field.  
 Trumbull died of heart failure in 2001.  
   
   
 == Honors and honors ==  
 1916 : Fellow of the Royal Society of London  
 1935 : CUNY graduate and Landon Prize ( with Gertrude T. Grogan )  
 1937 : Research Fellow of the Human Relations Research Council, and Stanford Research Institute  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Karl Frederik Herberwein =  
Karl Frederik Herberwein ( 21 August 1836 – 6 October 1902 ) was a German-Australian botanist.  
   
   
 == Education and early life ==  
 He was the son of Swedish father and Danish mother. He was educated at Christiania Gymnasium, and attended school at Heidelberg, Heidelberg University and Munich University, where he obtained a degree in 1868.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 He was employed in Hildesheim botanical garden from 1874 to 1879, and in 1865-66 became inspector in the botanic garden of Rheinhessen. In 1872 he married Bertha von Reitzig ; they had one son and one daughter. After the death of her husband in 1872, he was made a member of the Abt Harnack–Sommerschule der Universität Heidelberg, and in 1882 was appointed as inspector of the Hildesheim Botanical Garden. He collected for A. H. Hermann Hortus Zoologischer Gesellschaft Königlichkeit, the tenth edition of the Collected works of Franz von Harnack ( see Königlichkeit ).  
 In 1883 he was elected a foreign member of the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences ( one of the 100 foreign members ).  
 His earliest botanical work, called the Abbildung in den natürlichen Organen ( `` Zoological and natural principles in nature '' ), was published in 1878. In the same year he made, in collaboration with Frederick Benjamin Galpin, a collection of 270 species from all parts of the world, together with an 8¼,000-page German dissertation ( German : Geschichte der Gesellschaft für Tierkräfte und Professoren, Ordnung durch Klasse und Krieg ). He made a second great multi-volume study in the Llewellynian families. He also published a work on ornithology and a separate treatise on the insects of Florida ( `` Insects of the United States and British Florida '' ) in four volumes, after his return to Britain in 1885.  
 As a novelist, he wrote many books of fiction, including the 1909 book A Thousand Beautiful Trees ( Auslegungen mit Gotteschichte der Elektrochemie, 1st edition, Frankfurt, 1894 ), a book that achieved almost universal popularity. In addition, his other notable works include several articles in Bauhaus periodicals.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = C.W. Mackin =  
Concord College Professor C.W. Mackin ( August 22, 1857 – November 27, 1931 ) was an American educator, most famous for writing the popular textbook, Teaching in the United States ( 1905–1908 ). He was known as the father of American experimental education.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 The son of Benjamin Mackin, an attorney, and Adeline Branden Heifetz, a naturalist, he grew up in the family farm, known locally as the Hispanics'Cottage. He received his B.A. from Concord in 1889, and M.A. ( 1892 ) from the University of Chicago. His undergraduate education was at the Wharton School of Finance ( business ), and from 1889 to 1895 he taught business administration at the Portland College, which is now Massachusetts Institute of Technology.  
 In 1896 he married Priscilla Sanders Wilson, daughter of Phyllis Sanders Wilson, a pastor in Lowell, Massachusetts. They had four children : Dorothy Camilla Wilson ( 1895 ), Everett Priscilla Wilson ( 1899 ), Charles Edward Wilson ( 1901 ) and Elwood Wilson ( 1903 ).  
   
   
 == Teaching ==  
 In 1901, as a foreign correspondent for the Toronto Star and as a university lecturer, he began his collaboration with Henry Edmund Broad, who would go on to write most of the broad principles for modern teaching. In 1903, the first nationwide distribution of the second edition of the Textbook of Modern Education was released, and though being one of the final editions of teaching instruction, its potential scope was large, and great volumes on the subject were produced for it. As the teaching of evolution developed, this widely distributed textbook became a standard textbook. It came to be known as the `` Textbook of Modern Education ''. A companion book, The Teaching of Christian History, was released in 1903. The book was widely used during the next half century.  
   
   
 == Publications ==  
 The Teaching of Christian History ( 1914 )  
 Teaching in the United States ( 1905–1908 )  
 Contributions to the Higher Teachers'Manual ( 1910–1911 )  
 Teaching in Schools ( 1909 )  
 A Problem of Teaching and Learning ( 1916 )  
 Schoolroom Rules for Adults ( 1917 )  
 Teachings : ( With Henry Edmund Broad )  
 The Teaching of Christianity ( with Helen E. Bell ) ( 1918 )  
 The New Testament in the Schools ( with Adeline Hamilton Johnson and William Norman Smith ) ( 1920 )  
   
   
 == Scientific research ==  
 Concerning the Degree of Knowledge with Special Reference to the Mechanisms of Learning ( The Reading and Unmaking of Moulded Paper ) ( 1912 )  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Thomas Harvey Hellyer =  
Thomas Harvey Hellyer ( July 29, 1819 – June 26, 1878 ) was an American printer and teacher.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Hellyer was born on July 29, 1819 in Cincinnati, Ohio. He was ordained a minister on March 5, 1848.  
 After completing a basic education in Ohio, he attended the School of Pharmacy at Syracuse, New York, where he studied pharmacy for a year. From 1862 to 1867 he taught pharmacy at the Campbell School, Cleveland, Ohio. He then traveled to England, and in 1868 travelled to France to assist Henry Madley MacKenzie, professor of the liberal arts and philosophy at the Collège de France.  
   
 He lectured in Greek and other languages at the College of Philadelphia, and from 1873 to 1875 taught classes in mathematics at both the college and public schools. In 1877 he was appointed a professor of religious education at the Kansas State Teachers College, and in 1880 was named to the faculty of theology at the University of Nebraska at Omaha, succeeding D. G. Mitchell.  
 He died on June 26, 1878 in Lincoln, Nebraska.  
   
   
 == Selected publications ==  
 Holland, A. S. ; Hornby, W. R. ; Bleeker, L. S. ; Lamb, John H. ( 1878 ). Notes on the Pathologic Practice of the Mucus of lice.Glyphics and African Legends, 1880.  
 Hellyer, Thomas Harvey ( March 5, 1848 ). `` Contribution to Greek and Latin by Frederic Gibbon and Joseph Priestley ''. Dissertation. University of Nebraska, Omaha.  
 North American Mascogium, London, 1866, 8vo.  
 History of Plaismotrium, Proc. Acad. Soc. U.S.A. 1, 1893.  
 History of Psillogramma, Proc. Acad. Soc. U.S.A. 1, 1893.  
 A Collection of Relics of the Toltecs, Proc. Acad. Soc. U.S.A. 2, 1894.  
 The Soil and Earth of the Great Plains of North America, Proc. Acad. Soc. U.S.A. 3, 1899.  
 Voyage to the Islands of Java, Proc. Acad. Soc. U.S.A. 3, 1899.  
 Fortifications of Mexico and Chihuahua, Proc. Acad. Soc. U.S.A. 3, 1899.  
 In memoriam, Proc. Acad. Soc. U.S.A. 4, 1900.  
 Illustrations of Elephants, Proc. Acad. Soc. U.S.A. 4, 1900.  
 The Bear, Giant, &c., 1883.  
 The Mills of Hercules, Chap. XV, Joseph Priestley ( 1868 ).  
 Epilogue to The Mill of Hercules, Chap. XI, Joseph Priestley ( 1872 ).  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Eunice Hemingway =  
Eunice Hemingway ( born 14 September 1895 in Kansas City, Kansas – died 16 April 1973 ) was a prolific amateur ornithologist, author, and conservationist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Eunice A. Hemingway was born on 14 September 1895 in Kansas City, Kansas. She graduated from the University of Kansas in 1908. From 1908 to 1916, she was employed as an education official at Fisk, Kansas. In 1917, she married George W. Hemingway, a geologist, geophysicist, and geomorphologist with whom she had four children. Their children included Walter W. Hemingway, Dr. Edwin J. Hemingway and Estelle W. Hemingway. During her career as a geologist, she worked for the New York Geological Survey ( now the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation ) as a field geologist. She began collecting as a teenager in 1936 at an anonymous observatory, and has since been dubbed the `` Lost Child of Natural History '' by Lauren Greene. Eunice Hemingway lived in Southern California for the rest of her life and published several books. She did not plan to be a conservationist, but began having spontaneous `` animal musings '' at the age of ten.  
   
   
 == Awards and honors ==  
 Nantucket Sound National Seashore, H.E. Hemingway Island, Boston, Massachusetts, US  
   
   
 == Family ==  
 Daughter of Lawrence Hemingway and Gloria Adams Hemingway  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = G. Warren Naff =  
G. Warren Naff ( November 12, 1898 – June 12, 1995 ) was an American crystallographer and geneticist known for his research on DNA and protein.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Naff was born in Oak Brook, Illinois, into a prominent and wealthy, German-American family. He obtained his B.A. from Northwestern University, and a Ph.D. from Stanford University in 1931. He worked as an associate professor at Michigan State University from 1934 to 1945. He then became director of the Institute of Protein Biology at the National Academy of Sciences from 1943 to 1946. He was director of Stanford University's Department of Molecular Biology and Genetics from 1946 to 1948. He was elected to the National Academy of Sciences in 1948, the year he was elected to a full term on the NAS.  
 In 1949, Naff was a National Research Council Research Fellow, where he led research efforts involving the study of the conformational and functional aspects of DNA. He also conducted a series of important studies on the structure and function of genes. His major contribution was the creation of a computational model of the large number of inducible steps necessary for DNA synthesis, a feat the researchers referred to as “ tying the knots ”. Together with fellow American, George Barnett, and I. P. Z-Huang, Naff developed a program, Aglar, which eventually contributed to the construction of a computer program called Multilocus Sequencer.Naff and Barnett published several publications between 1946 and 1956 and 1951 and 1955. During this time, Naff was also the first to make molecular modeling of protein complexes.Naff also designed a program which provided higher performance for basic and applied biology.  
   
   
 == Death ==  
 Naff died in Boulder, Colorado, in 1995, aged 78. He is buried at Owl Hill Cemetery.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Heinrich Sachs =  
Heinrich Sachs ( 16 June 1859 – 11 November 1943 ) was a German mathematician. He was born in Alsace. He became interested in mathematics in school, and spent his early years teaching at the CIE Technical School in Vienna.  
 Sachs studied at the Technical University of Munich, studying under Ludwig Boltzmann, giving a thesis on rational functions on rational operators and integral calculus ( 1860 ). He obtained his doctorate in 1881.  
 In 1883, Sachs published his work on a series of questions concerning continuity of equations on the metric given by the famous series and its applications to the calculus of variations. He also did postgraduate work under A.E. Maunder at the Technical University of Munich. His mathematical papers included contributions to the Klein formulations, the theorems of general vector calculus, and the type theory of binary functions.  
 Sachs was interested in transcendental analysis and adopted it in 1884. He discovered the theorem of Singleton, before reaching Fermat's Last Theorem of 1906. Sachs published many papers concerning transcendental analysis as well, including a monograph on Hilbert spaces and a monograph on disjunction surfaces ( 1893 ). Sachs was a fellow of the Royal Swedish Academy of Science and Letters, and a Fellow of the Mathematical Society of Edinburgh, Royal Society of London, and American Mathematical Society. He was also an honorary member of the Association Germanische Deutscher Akademie, the League der Physikalisch-Mathematik and the National Academy of Sciences of the USSR.  
   
   
 == Research and educational career ==  
 In 1906 Sachs published his Göttingen thesis on Integral Calculus with Jacob Boltzmann.  
 Sachs's doctoral work on differential equations, Real Solutions of Differential Equations and Unitary Solutions of Differential Equations, was the basis of his thesis and should be seen as an extended work of Lectures on Calculus. Sachs shared some of his former supervisor's interests : he developed the first non-harmonic proof of the Fermat's Last Theorem. His numerical solution for the Klein–Riemann integral in a simple subject ( For elliptic differential equations in a geometric form ), and proved that ( using approximation ) there are other solutions where both the analytic and harmonic parts of the equation are differentiable at the same time, with one ( unknown ) being the Fourier series. This included solutions for complex numbers and number theory. Sachs was elected a fellow of the Royal Swedish Academy of Science and Letters in 1909. He contributed a paper on generalized differential equations ( 1911 ) to the volume On the approximations of diffraction for long waves.  
 Sachs died in Vienna on 11 November 1943.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Elsa von Saint-Saëns =  
Elsa von Saint-Saëns ( 19 January 1912 – 6 February 2007 ) was a Dutch comparative psychiatrist and psychologist who played an important role in the development of the concepts and clinical research on bipolar disorder, post-traumatic stress disorder ( PTSD ), alcohol use disorders and other psychosomatic conditions.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Elsa von Saint-Saëns was born on 19 January 1912 in the city of Heidelberg, on Dutch South West Europe. Her mother was Viljoaf St. Jean and she studied at the Eindhoven University of Technology ( 1918–1925 ).  
   
   
 == Education ==  
 From 1926 to 1938 she studied at a private university in Stellenbosch, South Africa. After graduation she entered the faculty of psychiatry at the King's College Hospital in London ( 1940–44 ).  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 At the beginning of World War II in 1940, Stenbosch, South Africa, was part of the British Commonwealth colony. Stenbosch was under threat of occupation by the Nazis in September 1940 and only 2 days after leaving Germany Stenbosch was threatened and killed by the Nazis, the university was closed down, and Stenbosch family took refuge with relatives in England. Stenbosch moved to England in 1944 and became a psychiatry resident in London in 1946, teaching a seminar on Post-traumatic Stress Disorder. In 1946 she obtained her PhD in Psychology at King's College Hospital.After the end of World War II, Stenbosch returned to England. During this period she worked at the Department of Psychiatry at the University of Bristol.  
 During this time she also became interested in the concepts of schizophrenia and bipolar disorder and in the measurement of stress, the use of complex variable methods and analytical medical subjects.Stenbosch moved to the University of Texas ( Austin ) in 1957, where she headed up the department of psychopathology, a group that became the flagship of the college of psychiatry. She moved in 1976 to the Department of Psychiatry at Stanford University and this time also became the focus of clinical research. During this time she published a landmark and influential book titled Development and Studies of the Function of a Lively Mind. She also was involved in a series of controversial publication, published in the 1960s and 1970s in which she published controversial findings, such as the findings that manic depression was a normal mental state and the recognition that schizophrenics had brain damage and deafness.  
 In 1969, the State of Texas received funding for the relocation of Stenbosch to the United States, where she was a clinician and researcher at the Cleveland Clinic.  
 Stenbosch moved to the University of Toronto, Canada where she took up positions as the Chair of the Psychology Department. There she focused her career in taking biobriefs in order to answer people's questions on their research and clinical backgrounds. She moved to then University of Birmingham and from 1972 to 1981 also was the Chair of the Psychology Department at the London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine. In 1981 she joined the staff of Saint Marys Hospital in Jamaica and completed her PhD at Birmingham.  
   
   
 == Career milestone ==  
 In 1982 she joined the European Association for Mental Health and created the multi-disciplinary European Association for Psychiatric Research in Behavioral Medicine ( EAPBRIM ), for which she developed a unique treatment paradigm called the psychology of professionalism. In 1989 Stenbosch started a new phase in her life, through study tours of South America where she and other researchers studied the cultures and beliefs of the indigenous cultures, with the intention of better understanding the workings of the world of psychology, as one of the colleagues was going to go to Vietnam and suffer with post-traumatic stress disorder for 4 years. Her case was reported in the British journal Archives of General Psychiatry.She was also a champion of the creation of understanding the many facets of issues, history and cultural divisions, skills, abilities and dispositions that some people carry in order to cope with the realities of life. She was on many journalistic and medical stories, for example, discussing her experiences as a researcher for The Times newspaper on Mental Health Research.In 2004 she died in Jamaica from the complications of cardiac arrest, after a long illness.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Jean Joseph Mclaughlin =  
Jean Joseph ( Joe ) Mclaughlin ( 25 January 1886 – 8 November 1971 ) was an Irish writer, industrialist, lawyer, educationalist, and political economist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 He was born on 25 January 1886 in Creggan, County Sligo. His paternal grandfather, Ignatius Mclaughlin ( 1833–1894 ), was a small merchant from nearby Lower Carnarvon. His maternal grandfather, Julius Mclaughlin, ( 1845–1901 ), was a wealthy industrialist from Longford and a founding partner in Bell Electricals. The family home at 22 High Street, off St Giles Road, in the small community of Ravenhill, was also named Mclaughlin's House. A school has also been set up in Mclaughlin House, and he has a statue of a black gentry ( coat of arms, gunsmith ) erected in his honour.  
   
   
 == Education ==  
 At a very young age he was brought up by his parents on Longman Road in the Clondalkin district, Dublin. Jean Joseph attended Counties Road Catholic School, Clondalkin in 1892. In 1894 he was admitted to Queen's College, Dublin.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 In 1896 Mclaughlin moved to Limerick, where he became a professor of economics, and a member of the academic staff of the city's Royal Agricultural College. He held the posts of Professor of Economics and Vice-president of the Sociological Society of Ireland. He was also elected to the National Advisory Council of the Gaeltacht.In 1909, Mclaughlin became a full member of the newly founded Department of Public Instruction in Dublin, and on 11 January 1914, he was appointed principal of the new De Luise College, at Sligo. After a short period of time he returned to his work at Sligo as professor of political economy at Queen's.  
 After retiring from teaching, he became chairman of the board of the Irish Railways in 1913, and subsequently Director of the Dublin Railway.  
 In 1931 he was appointed commissioner of excise in Co Dublin.  
 In 1935 he became a Member of the Royal Irish Academy and received the Irish Cross for his services to the Irish Republic.  
 He died in Rossville, County Down in 1971.  
   
   
 == Family ==  
 The Mclaughlin family was the second of three children, born to Reverend James Maclennan and his wife Eliza Burke Maclennan. His father was a rich businessman from Creggan who established a large manufacturing complex in Donnybrook, County Armagh. Jean Joseph was the third son, and both his brothers also became powerful figures in Irish life. The youngest brother ( born 1917 ), Patrick Mclaughlin, was Governor of the province of Northern Ireland.  
 His father died in 1916. He was married to Emma Napoletti, daughter of the factory owners Hugh and Helen, who died in 1916. After the death of his father, Jean married Helen in 1920. He and his wife had two children together : Pauline, who died in 1953, and James, who died in 1960.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Giovanni de Apia =  
Giovanni de Apia ( born Giovanni de Armani in 1867 ) was an Italian astronomer.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Giovanni de Apia studied under Ottavio Maria Arrigoni in the observatory of the Conservatory of San Siro and Paris. He received his doctorate ( on Palaearctic theory ) in 1881 under Giuseppe Saini. He was an assistant to Luigi Argyrotta and to Pietro Bertoni. In 1887, he became assistant professor of solar physics at the University of Padua, later professor of mathematics at the University of Padua. From 1893, he was a professor at the University of Rome.  
 In 1892, he was the first person to recognize that of the quasar P 552 near Messina was ejected into the Pleiades. He himself conducted extensive surveys of the archipelago in 1898. The oldest feature, the rondeli, which he named after him, is now the object of research in photometry. He was the father of Italian astronomer Gennaro Apia.  
 The crater Apia is named after him.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Ben William Dudley =  
Ben William Dudley ( February 1, 1896 – December 27, 1968 ) was an American economist and economist. He was the director of the Bendix research group from 1934 to 1956.  
 Dudley was born in Newburgh, New York, the son of Joseph `` Adam '' Dudley and Margaret ( Smoak ) Dudley. Dudley attended Harvard University, graduating in 1919. He earned a B.A. in mathematics in 1924, M.A. in 1927 and Ph.D. in 1933 from Harvard. After several years at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, he earned his M.A. in 1936 and became a professor of economics at Wesleyan University, where he was named Dean of Studies in 1942. He was a fellow of the American Economic Association, the National Academy of Sciences, the American Philosophical Society, the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and the American Statistical Association.  
 Dudley was the president of the American Federation of Labor in 1946 and was a member of the AFL-CIO and the Council of Economic Advisors of the U.S. Senate from 1948 to 1960.  
 Dudley died in the Beechwood Park Hospital in Newton, Massachusetts, at the age of 88.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Johann Jakob Sachs =  
Johann Jakob Sachs ( 16 August 1801 – 27 November 1877 ) was a German physician.  
 He is often called `` The father of toxicology ''. He was the first to use formal histological techniques in the field of hygiene.Sachs was a `` judegamen '' of Polish-German descent who emigrated from Germany in the period 1819 to 1828. He was born in Düsseldorf and died at Rier in Berlin-Friedland-Rhineland ( now Chernigov in the Russian Federation ).  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Sachs was born in Kaunas in 1801. He graduated in medicine from the University of Kaunas in 1821, at the same time holding a professorship there. He died in 1877.  
   
   
 == Eponyms ==  
 He discovered the disorder, fulminavirus rytiosemia, of pericarditis, second only to von Knorring ( 1819 ).  
   
   
 == Bibliography ==  
 Neue Werke der Physiologie und Physiognosie. Versuch über die Epigallocytose-individuate Abhängigkeit über die Teilenmedizin der Technischen Gesellschaft. 10. Berlin, 1829.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Nikhil Uppal =  
Nikhil Uppal ( 5 July 1925 – 3 July 2000 ) was an Indian naturalist and director of the Indian Institute of Sciences ( IISc ), Bangalore.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Uppal was born in Goa. He worked at the Hindu Academy ( IAS ) from 1945 to 1949 and the Institute of Botany and Department of Botany at IISc from 1950 to 1951.  
 Uppal then worked at the IIM Bangalore. From 1959 to 1961 he was Director of IISc. He was also the vice-president of IISc from 1965 to 1968 and the vice-president in 1962 to 1968. Uppal had also served as the Indian representative at the UNESCO, Berlin in 1959 and as a member of the Indian National Science Academy Committee. He was a member of the council of academies of IISc, India, USA, Japan, Pakistan and China. He was also a co-founder of the Botany Department of the IISc.  
 Uppal was a Fellow of Academies of Science, Academies of Europe, Indian Academy of Sciences, the Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts, Sciences and Letters, the Indian Academy of Science ( AIAS ), Indian National Science Academy, and was also a member of numerous other scientific societies in India.  
 He died on 3 July 2000 from complications of cancer.An inscription on his grave in the Hindu National Cultural Mission Cemetery at Vadodara reads :  
 The son of the pioneers of vegetation science, Nikhil Uppal.  
   
   
 == Legacy ==  
 The Nikhil Uppal Memorial Tower in Bangalore was constructed in 1973. A high-rise building was also named after him.  
 Uppal Chair of Botany at IISc, Bangalore has been named after him by Ben Goldacre.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Florentijn Josef Onk =  
François Florentijn Josef Onk ( 6 December 1844 – 15 March 1928 ) was a Dutch entomologist, and the father of entomologist Carl August Johan Onk. Onk was born at Knuvalder Heer, Schaffhausen, to a noble family. He studied at Utrecht University and the University of Utrecht, before going to Copenhagen where he received his doctorate in 1875 with a dissertation entitled Zoologisches Zoologisches Boschiens II, pp. xii–xx. He remained there a decade until he began lecturing in natural history at Utrecht. While on lecturing, Onk published some 20 papers on the beetles, the Lepidoptera of Southern Holland ( 1881 ), the neotropical bee ( Coleoptera ) ( 1884 ), the entomologist genus Namus ( 1896 ), and the genus Encyrtini ( 1894 ). He also worked on the plant and animal kingdom, identifying several species in Plants of South Africa.  
 Onk began publishing Nature newspaper in 1888 and the daily Volkskrant ( from 1894 ). He was elected member of the Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences in 1904, served as president in 1907, and was elected president in 1907.  
   
   
 == Published works ==  
 Florentijn Josef Onk : Van farbeleerd van de begevenen antwoordde zoologische Desinokornen. Aleste 1878.  
   
   
 == Family ==  
 In 1886, he married the botanist Maria Nilonoff, daughter of the collector Risto Nilonoff. They had five children.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Enrique de Melo =  
Enrique de Melo ( 6 October 1881 – 10 November 1963 ) was a Spanish composer and musicologist.  
   
   
 == Life and career ==  
 Melo was born in La Chancia and died in Madrid. He studied with Ramón y Cajal, of whom he was the first disciple. In 1913 he moved to Madrid and there became an associate professor in the Musikums Rossonas where he taught until his death.He wrote mainly works for instrumental or singing, and compositions for electronic music, but also wrote pieces for piano, and even in 1943 he performed the first piano concerto written for him, later being released under a text by Ernest Sterndale. He also wrote a score of the Hollywood epic Rock of Ages and was a critic of the music of René Magritte. Melo also wrote other short, family-friendly pieces and wrote, in one play, Don Juan.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = D. V. Manne =  
D. V. Manne ( 19 July 1910 – 3 December 1996 ) was an English chemist, author, naturalist, educationalist and politician. He was a Director of the Royal Society, the first director of the National Curriculum, Head of the British Ceramic Society, Academician of the Royal Society of Edinburgh, Honorary Doctor of St Andrews and Fellow of several other organisations.  
   
   
 == Life and work ==  
 Manne was born in Glasgow in 1910.  
 His father was Scottish scientist Alan Manne, an eminent paleontologist and vice-chairman of the Geological Survey of Scotland. He was also an entomologist. He graduated from Glasgow Grammar School and Trinity College, Cambridge. In 1946 he graduated with a degree in chemistry from University College London.He was Head of the British Ceramic Society from 1948 to 1962. He served as Treasurer and Vice-President of the Royal Society from 1964 to 1967.In his later life, Manne began his editorial activities, publishing a comprehensive, authoritative dictionary of the English language.  
   
   
 == Personal life ==  
 He was married to Bessie Dundas ( née Marisch ), a science writer and women's rights campaigner and a widow. They had a daughter, Nancy, and five sons and six daughters.  
   
   
 == Selected publications ==  
 Red Whales in a Coalfield, a volume of Manne's field writings published by the Geological Society, 1972.  
 Food Chemistry in a Changing World, The Chemical Spectral and Molecular Aspects of Man's Will, Prodigious Work of Richard Levi and Alfred Provan-Peyser, published in 1972, and an accompanying synthesis, published in 1974.  
 Curriculum vitae : Note to Director, Royal Society, Wealden, Scotland, where he lived from 1959 to 1960.  
 Nature Speaks : Some Modern Tales of Science, Naturalist, Author, Educator and Public Service, privately printed editions, 1975.  
 Debates on Chemistry in a Changing World : Part One, An Introduction to Chemistry in a Changing World, Book 2, Philip Lewis, Alan Manne, Kate Watson, Naturalist, Author, Educator and Public Service,, 1975.  
 Chemistry in a Changing World : Part Two, Personal Chemistry and Food Chemistry in a Changing World, Author, Educator and Public Service, ISBN 0-520-40966-7, 1980.  
 The Hand in Biology, 1977, ISBN 0-521-08171-0  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Giuseppe Fe C3 A4gno =  
Giuseppe Fehetti ( 31 December 1851 – 23 August 1893 ) was an Italian composer and conductor. A representative of the period of early 20th-century Italian music, he received his first opera in 1893 and took his first concert in 1895. From 1894 until his death in 1893 he was a member of the Giovenchi Arcadio, and from 1899 until his death he was a professor at the Mussolini's conservatory in Città d'Azione. Fehetti was a founder of the Fiorentina Opera company and has also been a noted classical pianist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Fehetti was born on 31 December 1851 in Monte Carlo, to a wealthy and influential Jewish family, who fled the Holocaust in order to be settled in Italy. His father Giuseppe Fehetti, a successful businessman, raised his three younger siblings, from whom he received numerous musical instruments as a child. While a boy, he loved classical music, especially the German music. He also dedicated his short musical career to string quintet and piano.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
   
 In 1899, he joined the firm of Amati-Tal, a firm in Trento, where he also worked as a music instructor. In 1904, he succeeded Alvaro Ulrich, as professor at the Conservatory of Fiorentina, and from 1907 to 1908 he was the director of music studies there, as well as becoming a lecturer at the conservatory. In 1908, he was made a major in the Italian Armed Forces, he was assigned to the Salonika Riflession and gave concerts there. He also held a teaching position at the Secco school in Milan. In 1912, he accepted a post as the director of the Mussolini's conservatory, and with a meeting of Francoist members in Milan, he was chosen to be the first director of the so-called `` `` Francesco Lincei Society '' ( the first meeting of the `` Lincei Society '' was held on 13 August 1913 ). He was a firm supporter of the Milan Riflession, of which he was its president from 1913 to 1916. Fehetti was also a leading supporter of the Monte Carlo City Council, which was established on 22 December 1918, as an important focal point for the Italian music movement.Fehetti was active in Italian classical music. He founded the Opera which premiered the following works :  
   
 `` Giuseppe Febbiano '', based on a play by Gian Giacomo Zola  
 `` Mateinogliature ''  
 `` Giacomo Benevolence '', an opera about Giuseppe Benevolence which premiered in a youth's dance hall in Vitebsk in 1900  
 `` L'amore curasse ''  
 `` L'amore terra ''  
 `` Trovatore il pupilito, sostenuto violoncello ''  
 `` Serpenso da più 'violin nel ecolo ''  
 `` Teroncolle di Vito ''  
 `` Bambino ossia ''  
 `` Amatorio for bass violin and piano, in C minor, BWV 2085 '', which won the Greco-Roma National Conservatory prize, in 1902  
 `` Aleccino imperio et violoncello '', based on a symphonic poem by Andrzej Jodorowski  
 `` Natività accailli '' ( with Giovanni Barbirolli ), for mixed voice  
 `` Volpi filosofia '' ( BWV 2401 ), for female voice.  
   
   
 == Personal life ==  
 Fehetti married his second wife, Priscilla `` Vivienne '' Barbieri, on 4 June 1899. They had a daughter by their first marriage, and a son by their second marriage.He died in Naples.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Paul Kurtzmann =  
Paul Kurtzmann ( November 14, 1728 – June 7, 1815 ) was an American naturalist who was best known for his investigations of the effects of age on vegetation.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 He was born in Winona, Minnesota, and studied at the University of Minnesota, graduating in 1774. After an unsuccessful career as a shoemaker in the Salt Lake Valley, he returned to practice in Winona and then was a physician in Winona until 1807. In 1801 he became professor of botany and phytogeography at the University of Minnesota and subsequently returned to the university as full professor and professor of anatomy in 1805. In 1812 he was elected president of the Society of Antiquaries of Minnesota. He died in Winona, Minnesota in 1815.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 His scientific publications include :  
   
 Illustrations of the Natural History of Trees in the United States  
 Physiological Features of Trees  
 The Years of Forest-Lion Expansion  
 Autumnal Planting in Washington and Jefferson County, Michigan  
 Vegetable growth in forested and open ground  
 Vegetable and animal reproduction in the United States  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Markus Messerli =  
Markus Messerli ( 2 March 1838 – 14 March 1910 ) was an Austrian naturalist and horticulturist.  
   
   
 == Life and work ==  
 Messerli was born in Mecklenburg, Württemberg, where his father was an engraver, as well as a researcher. From 1875 he studied at the Royal Prussian Academy of Arts and Sciences, obtaining his M.D. in 1880. From 1883, he traveled to Vienna and the Netherlands, visiting as many scientific expeditions as he could. Following his return in 1891, he continued his research in zoology, botany, flora and fauna of Europe and the Netherlands. From 1890 to 1896, he was head of the natural history collection at the University of Tübingen, and was a member of the Austrian Academy of Sciences, the Royal Academy of Agriculture and the Royal Botanic Garden. In 1896 he created the first ( together with Kjell Barth ) textbook on botany, Geognostik. In 1898 he became honorary member of the Austrian Academy of Sciences.In 1905 Messerli became the first to record the biodiversity of the Neisse Gulf region. For a time, he even surveyed the sea floor in Antarctica. The greatest care he gave to distinguishing species, as many of them had a huge impact on the ecology of their habitats, as did the genus Ephydropedis.  
 After the 1905 elections, Messerli was appointed provincial naturalist in the new administration of Rudolf the Bold, a vision he pursued with determination and perseverance. After his retirement in 1909, he moved to Brussels, where he also served as the director of the Regional Museum and as vice-director of the Natural History Museum in Bruges. He died in Bruges in 1910.  
   
   
 == Species named in honor ==  
   
   
 == Publications ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Baronne Dubois =  
Baronne Dubois FRSE FRS ( 16 August 1842 – 20 June 1896 ) was a Scottish physicist and experimental chemist.  
 He was born in Aberdeen. His father was Governor of Northern Ireland and he was educated at the Aberdeen Central Grammar School.  
 In 1861 he graduated from the University of Aberdeen. He joined the Royal Navy as an officer in 1865. He was commissioned second lieutenant, Commander of the Ordnance Works at Salisbury in 1869. He was sent to France in 1869 to replace John Craighead in HMS Tarleton. On board Tarleton he was the main engineer and physicist. He retired on 8 November 1891. In 1893 he was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Oscar Vodiano =  
Oscar Romano Vodiano ( 26 September 1846 – 9 August 1920 ) was a Roman Catholic priest, mystic, writer and spiritual leader.  
 Vodiano was the son of the noted poet and seminarian, Octavianus Vodiano. He entered the seminary of St. Patrick's Cathedral on 18 August 1875. From 1893 to 1900, he was the secretary of the Annales de la Cagliostro.In 1898, Vodiano became a professor in the Institute of Philosophy at the Pontifical Gregorian University in Rome. During World War I, he was a member of the Red Cross, and was twice sent into France. During the First World War, he was the Roman auxiliary bishop of the Roman diocese of Meissen-Urach.  
 His Bible translation was published posthumously in 1918. He died at Rome in 1920.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 Clerical work and mysticism, translated from the Polish : [ czecimowo ] ( Little Polish Hymn ; translated from Polish with foreword by Vodiano ), 1886  
 The Posthumous Life of Oscar Vodiano, 1877–1891 : a translation into English of the translation of the lost Zend Avestan lawgiver Archimandrite Antonín Ethelbertus Vossius by Oscar Vodiano, 1895  
 A Mind Has Seven Faces : a review of the most important works of Oscar Vodiano by Arthur Zabern Cordero, with introduction by Josef Vundiger and Dante Chladecki, NY : Columbia University Press, 1987, ISBN 0-231-04858-2, pp. 97.  
   
   
 == Bibliography ==
