<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = U. F. Mackay =  
U. F. Mackay ( 24 June 1897 – 13 March 1990 ) was a British naturalist who specialised in Asian birds.  
   
   
 == Early life ==  
 Born in Exeter, Mackay was the son of an iron-laced ironmaster, Carl Mackay, and Rose Melba. He studied at Eton College, Oxford before attending Hampshire School. He went on to Winchester College where he attended the Penryn branch of the University of Cambridge, graduating with a first class honours degree in zoology in 1928.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 Mackay left Oxford to take a position with the Zoological Society of London. There he conducted many field studies in Java, providing documentation of bird migration and development. He was also keen on animal husbandry. In 1932, the Zoological Society sent him on a field research trip to Central Sumatra. During this trip he produced a catalogue of the Gombein family of birds, and this worked for him in establishing a long-standing interest in the life history of birds. Mackay was awarded a Cuddeback Medal by the Royal Society in 1939. In 1944, Mackay returned to London as curator of the British Museum, becoming Head of the Severn Heritage and Nature Research Unit in 1949. In 1953, he returned to East Africa as a professional entomologist, overseeing the collection and management of insects. He also served as Director of the BMA's British Museum Division from 1961 to 1965. He was invited in 1957 to become a director of the East African Museum, a position he retained until his death in 1990. He was a Director of the BMA in 1972. Mackay is commemorated in the species `` Varanus agrestis urnosum '' and `` Goulin's orchid choicestris ''.  
   
   
 == Death ==  
 Mackay died on 13 March 1990 of prostate cancer. He was a memorial was presented by the Surrey Archaeological and Natural History Society.  
   
   
 == Legacy ==  
 Mackay was described as the `` only birding alumnus '' in the 1940s and 1950s and his collection of around 400 records has been recorded and archived by the East Africa Museum.The now famous Australian taxa genus Hylaeus are named after him, a giant peregrine falcon.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Imre Gharbi =  
Imre Gharbi ( January 10, 1903 – May 1, 1998 ) was an Israeli physician and fellow of the Israel Academy of Sciences, an instructor in Israeli Hebrew at Tel Aviv University, and an Israeli academic, scholar and teacher.  
   
   
 == Life and career ==  
 Gharbi was born on January 10, 1903, in Haifa. He studied at the Jerusalem Medical College, at the Medical University of South Africa and in Brussels, the Netherlands. He received his M.D. in 1924 and his Ph.D. in 1928 in medicine and in experimental physiology at the University of Texas at Austin, earning his habilitation degree in 1940. He then became an instructor in clinical pediatrics at the University of South Africa, in Boerhaave, and in 1938 he moved to Tel Aviv University, where he taught clinical pediatrics. In 1948, he was appointed professor of clinical pediatrics. In 1955 he became dean of the Faculty of Medicine at the University of Jerusalem, and in 1967 he was made professor emeritus. He retired in 1972.Gharbi was a member of the Israeli Academy of Sciences and the Higher Medical Research Council. He also served on the international advisory board of the Israel-US Institute of Cell Biology, and on several other boards. His pediatrics work was in collaboration with Gadeir Kürtner, Erez Dery, Uri Zalman, Moshe Lewis, Mimi Resha, Levi Solomon, and Rabbi Abba Eban.  
   
   
 == Books ==  
 Gharbi, Imre ; Jacob, F. & Segal, Avishai ( 1983 ). Pathogenesis and pharmacology of the compartments of the spinal cord. Amsterdam : Elsevier /JCI.  
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Frederic James (Monsignor) =  
Frederic James Mennell ( 1778–1866 ), later Archbishop of Norwich, was an Anglican clergyman who served in the House of Lords of Great Britain and Ireland. He was a vocal opponent of assimilation and an early opponent of the Anglican episcopacy. The surname `` Mennell '' is a variation of the Gaelic name Mennod  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 He was born on 10 September 1778 in Sefton, County Londonderry, Ireland, into a family of Roman Catholic Protestant farmers. He attended St Patrick's College, Down, during which he was the highest ranked student in his graduating class.  
   
   
 == Family ==  
   
 In 1787 Mennell was married to Margaret, née Lothran ( Lothran ), a daughter of John W. Lothran of Finraul, Glamorganshire, and Charlotte Worthington, a daughter of William O. Worthington of Denbighshire. Mennell was a General Moderator in the Scottish Episcopal Church from 1793 until his death. His second wife was Helen Crone Lothran, née Wright. After his death, they returned to Ireland where in 1829 he died in Norwich, County Londonderry, aged 53.  
 Mennell was the author of The Seven Oaths of the Cross, or On The Seven Oaths of the Cross, and Life of Christ in its Light.  
   
   
 == Honours ==  
 Mennell was elected a fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh in 1804.In 1833, he was knighted.  
 He died at Norwich Cathedral, aged 54.  
   
   
 == Eponymy ==  
 A portrait of Mennell, by John Lawrence of Cockerell, in King's College, Belfast, was unveiled in September 2009.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Norman Brehm =  
Norman Wilhelm Brehm ( August 24, 1857 – May 11, 1964 ) was a German botanist.  
 Brehm was born in Oldenburg, where his father ( Johann Friedrich Brehm ) was chief engineer, and became a noted teacher in secondary school. He went on to do the academic work in the state university of Bad Nauheim and later moved on to attend the university of Rostock as a secondary school teacher. In 1889, he was accepted into the University of Vienna. After receiving his doctorate ( 1st degree ) in 1892, he was professor of botany from 1899 to 1908 and of medicine in 1909. He also specialized in phytology.  
 Brehm was not just a taxonomist, but a researcher in several aspects of botany. From 1896 he was an intern at the Königlich State Museum and Museum for Botany in Vienna, where he described plants from the Rhine, the Danube and adjacent areas. In 1914 he moved to the Botanisch-Sozialforscher Tonnalensech Konstanz in Berlin, where he established a botanical collection and taught classes on flora from 1910 until his death.  
 The Brehm botanical laboratory, now the Arnold-Cummings Botanical Museum in Berlin, is a living resource that chronicles the plants collected by Brehm in his field work.  
   
   
 == Publications ==  
 Brehm, Norman ( 1897 ). Revision der Lebenstechnik des Pflanzen. Berlin : Hermann.  
 Brehm, Norman ( 1896 ). Die bryophorische Kleine Nomenclator ( Basidiomycetes ). Berlin : Hermann.  
 Brehm, Norman ( 1897 ). `` Denynobiosis ''. Ueberschrift für Botanische Zeitung 15 ( 1–2 ) : 2–10.  
 Brehm, Norman ( 1897 ). Neue und Werk von Borneo. Berlin : Hermann.  
 Brehm, Norman ( 1903 ). Die Rudolfi der Königlichischen Gesellschaft von Berlin. Wien : Härtel.  
 Brehm, Norman ( 1904 ). Brehm, Norman, and Arnold Hirms ( eds. ) ( 1906 ). Zur Fauna arcticus. Berufsdorp : pp. 173–177.  
 Brehm, Norman ( 1904 ). Die Planten geographischer Oekotomisch-Diplopoda. Berlin : Arnold-Cummings Botanical Museum.  
 Brehm, Norman ( 1907 ). Neue Ergebnisse der geographischen Borneo-Alpina. Berlin : Arnold-Cummings Botanical Museum.  
 Brehm, Norman ( 1912 ). Die Zoöcology of the Highlands of Zebuloniensia. Berlin : Arnold-Cummings Botanical Museum.  
 Brehm, Norman ( 1913 ). Die Ursa Major. Berufsdorp : Halle-Hermann.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Heinrich Wilhelm Tschirgen =  
Heinrich Wilhelm Tschirgen ( 26 August 1750 – 28 June 1833 ) was a German composer, violinist, organist, musician and violin maker.  
 He studied at the Leipzig Conservatory under violinist Johann Ferdinand Ludwig Thalheimer, the same Thalheimer who was a professor at the Gewandhaus in Berlin. From 1782 to 1791, he taught under Christian Wilhelm Götze and Gottfried Jacob Wagner. In 1794 he was appointed professor of violin at the Royal Conservatory of Kiel and gave lessons in 1796 to Johann Sebastian Bach. He also acted as conservator in Kiel and Munich in 1793 and 1798. From 1790 to 1792, he was president of the Gewandhaus in Berlin, and from 1797 to 1800 he was Luthier in Kiel.In 1776, he recorded two pieces for string orchestra as Barbetliedel No. 1 ( `` Lohengrin '' ) and Barbetliedel No. 2 ( `` Fantasie '' ).The 1815 `` Allgemeine Rundfunk-Taschenbad-Rechts-Music '' of Tobias Furtwängler incorporates his orchestral `` Wien Ciao '' of 1791. Tschirgen also wrote the libretto for the piano Leutaal-Deutschland for Cello soloist Johann Ritter Liebreich and violinist Paul Brautender.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Gerard Teixeira =  
Gerard Teixeira Surgical Centre MD ( Lisbon, Portugal ) was a Portuguese surgeon and general practitioner. He was the first to perform surgical localization of congenital disease in humans, which has not previously been achieved in humans. Teixeira was born in Lisbon, Portugal on October 11, 1925. He graduated from the Faculty of Medicine of the University of Porto in 1938, and received the degree of Doctor of Surgery in 1944. He was one of the founders of a pediatric hospital in Brazil. He also developed a method for making child remains with the help of X-rays from the abdomen. In 1950, he became the first surgeon in Brazil to donate fetal remains to international medical institutions, which were not allowed in the country at the time, in order to raise awareness of medical interventions in population health. In 1957, Teixeira opened a surgical surgical clinic in Vale do Leon, with a view to establishing this clinic within a few years. In 1967, Teixeira became the first professor at the Medical University of São Paulo, where he is remembered for his contributions in researching procedures for reconstruction of human body parts of all kinds, in post-mortem human anatomy. His first publication was published in 1959, titled, The organ utilization by diseases in primary childbirth, which was a commentary in which he criticised some people for believing that organ structures and the fetus are the same thing.  
 Teixeira was director of The La Vida Clinic, a private clinic that focused on the rehabilitation of many patients with congenital diseases, including diabetes, uremia, heart disease, ulcers, mental retardation, incontinence, and many others. He opened three locations of clinics in the federal department of Neurosurgery and Social Medicine in São Paulo ( 1971, 1973, 1977 ). He was also one of the founders of the Brazilian Developmental, Space and Disaster Health Institute ( BBDHO, now Brazilian Scientific Society for HIV/AIDS Research ).  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Friedrich G Lantmann =  
Friedrich Günther Lantmann ( 30 April 1858 – 28 July 1927 ) was a German classical guitarist and composer. He studied under his grandfather Eduard Wetzler and later taught himself to play the piano. He also wrote a harmonica.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Lantmann was born on 30 April 1858 in Tyrol, in southern Italy.  
 He studied piano at the University of Altdorf and composition under Richard Reisner, the director of the Baur Music Institute. In 1891, he became the music director at his old college. In 1898, he became a professor at the University of Berlin and for several years then was music director at the Berliner Musikverein and the Hofseeische Musikverein.  
 In 1900 he began his course of studies in composition at the University of Berlin. He was married to Maria von Ebersberger. He subsequently became music director of the Berliner Musikverein.  
 In 1904, he was appointed conservator of the Oberfeldsmeister Musik ( music conservatorium ). He taught composition to musicians at the Verein für Musik und Musikverein ( equivalent of a conservatory ) in Berlin and also at the Musikvereinverein, the Berlin dance academy. In 1913, he became music director of the Staatskapelle ( children's orchestra ) at Berlin and in 1918 he became music director of the Hofseeische Musikverein ( free public concert hall ) in Berlin-Saale.  
 In 1923, he was appointed concertmaster at the University of Tartu. He died in Heidelberg on 28 July 1927, having been diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease.  
   
   
 == Selected works ==  
 One of the first significant works was a piece entitled Quatre Impressions d'établi littérature lyrique dedicated to his wife, Scherm, in 1889. It was, according to Frank Seligman, `` one of the first symphonic works in German music. '' His influence was exerted through the 1930s into a contemporary piano piece, a possible choral work, a projectional music piece and opera, but also a whole generation of chamber music.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Aubrey Coleman (physicist) =  
Aubrey Coleman ( 1900 – January 7, 1999 ) was an American physicist known for his contributions to the understanding of the structure of the molecules in nature.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Coleman was born in Albany, New York, and received a bachelor's degree from the University of New York, where he obtained the B.S. in Physics ( 1911 ) and Ph.D. in Chemistry ( 1912 ). From 1909 to 1914, Coleman was a physics professor at the Western Reserve University, serving there until the fall of that school in 1914.  
 From 1914 to 1920, he taught as an assistant professor at Western Reserve, serving from 1920 to 1927 as a department head.  
 In 1921, he was named lecturer in experimental physics at New York University, and taught until his death. Coleman was the first person to establish a program of laboratory courses in chemical and physical chemistry at the New York University College of Medicine and Dentistry.  
 He was the president of the Linnean Society of America, and held the positions of president ( 1934 ), vice president ( 1936–1941 ), chairman of the board ( 1940–1942 ), president of the New York City League of Scientific and Industrial Employees ( 1945 ), chairman of the board of directors of the National Research Council ( 1946–1949 ), a member of the Academia Sinica and the National Academy of Sciences, and president of the American Physical Society.  
   
   
 == Scientific research ==  
   
 Coleman's most influential research was in the theory of the reaction of a chemical compound with substances other than hydrogen and oxygen, emphasizing the critical role of the electric charge of the underlying `` silver ''. He developed the Coleman's approximation, which enabled scientists to distinguish between the colorless and colorless phases of an element by looking at its electric charge. This experiment introduced Coleman's theorems and gave the popularization of the concept of the ether.  
   
   
 === The Coleman's approximation ===  
 The Coleman's approximation is a chemical formula ( an abelian potential, AB ) obtained by substituting an electric charge of one and a negative charge of another for the water and nitrogen.It is derived by taking a solution of pure water, in which a dilute portion of oxygen and hydrogen is reduced to form hydrogen-one, and adding ( partial ) acid. Then it is replaced with an acid mixture consisting of both hydrogen and oxygen, and simultaneously salt and water. The result is a liquid. Coleman's formula has been used in many fields of science, for example, using it to explain the decay of fluorine.The Coleman's approximation, once properly adapted and expressed, applies to a wide variety of low-temperature, low-power, reactive systems, including carbons, the element uranine, electrolytes, nuclei, and molecules of chemical elements.  
 In 1932, Coleman introduced the Coleman's approximation for determining the critical temperature at which carbon, a dimeric compound, breaks down. In 1935, he found the critical temperature for bromine, a compound that binds bromine. In 1937, he introduced the Coleman's approximation for determining the critical temperature at which oxygen molecules break down, using a combination of light and thermoglysis.  
 In 1949, Coleman proposed a simple mathematical transformation to represent the experimental significance of the Coleman's approximation, which he called the Coleman's radical. His formula for the Coleman's radical is :  
   
   
   
 C /K =  
   
 2  
   
   
   
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = William Burbidge Dawson =  
William Burbidge Dawson, ( 8 July 1818 – 7 July 1900 ) was a Welsh mathematician. He was the father of William Dawson ( 1835–1905 ) and Emma William Dawson ( 1847–1922 ).  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Dawson was born in Wales, the son of the Rev. John Dawson, vicar of Ealdon and lived most of his life in the Vale of Glamorgan, where he worked in mathematics. In 1858 Dawson married Sophia Chubb, née Draper, daughter of Rev. Chubb ( 1787–1862 ) and Grace Sibson. They had one daughter, Margaret, born in 1869.  
   
   
 === Career ===  
 Dawson lectured at Glasgow Grammar School ( 1857–60 ) and Clwyd and Manchester University ( 1860–63 ), where he gained the BA and MA in 1868, and the doctoral degree in mathematics in 1876. He joined the mathematics staff of the Royal College of Surgeons ( 1869–73 ) and became a professor there in 1880.  
 In 1865 he was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh and was awarded its Gairdner Medal in 1873. He received an honorary LL.D. from Edinburgh in 1874 and a curate's degree from Wittenberg University in 1880. He was elected a Fellow of the Royal Statistical Society ( FRS ) in 1887.Dawson was president of the Academical Society of Great Britain and Ireland from 1887 to 1899. He was also president of the Scottish Association for Scientific Research and of the Philological Society of Great Britain and Ireland in 1893 and 1893 respectively.  
   
   
 == Selected publications ==  
 The constant of gravity with a syzygy ; an examination of Hawkins, Dugald, and Cockayne's experiments, 1878.  
 The same force but in a pulley, 1888.  
 Remarks on Newton's formula for the motion of a body in the equator, 1890.  
 A textbook on pure mechanics : with an account of Lothar Leibniz and his pupil, 1903.  
   
   
 == Bibliography ==  
 Kent and Combs, L. D., eds. ( 1919 ). Dictionary of Applied Mathematics and Science, Second Series. 10. Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-12064-0.  
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Max Nordenskiu =  
Max Nordenskiu ( 17 May 1870 – 14 May 1928 ) was a Russian Orthodox theologian, and later a physician. He was born in Siberia in 1870. He graduated from the theological faculty of St. Vavilov's Seminary in 1910. He was appointed professor of Oriental languages and literature at the St. Petersburg Moscow Institute in 1924 and a lecturer of literature at the College of Theology in 1930.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 New Vision of the Origin of Man ( 1914 )  
 Studies in the Christian Biography of Plato ( 1921 )  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Jean le Decamond =  
Jean le Decamond ( April 5, 1763 – December 26, 1845 ) was a French naturalist.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 The third son of Armand du Marmont, in Algiers, on April 5, 1763, he was the eighth child of Louis le Decamond de Mascartet ( 1753–1817 ), and Bernice de Delanoy ( 1756–1830 ). His brothers were Jacques and Eugène le Decamond ( 1805-1882 ).  
 After completing his studies, he went to France to continue his training in mathematics and zoology. On a last visit to Europe in 1820, after his widowed parents returned from Paris, he left Montpellier for Paris. There he took up the study of medicine and taught school classes. He stayed in the city for three years and died on December 26, 1845.Decamond was Professor of Botany at the Collège d'Études Naturaliste in Paris from 1812 until his death, and he taught classes there from 1822 until his retirement.His collection of flora from a number of plant species, collected in his native Algiers, was presented to the Muséum national d'Histoire naturelle.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Alberto Mar C3 A9da y Leon C3 A9na =  
Alberto María y Leonora Rodríguez y Caminero ( May 16, 1897, Santiago, Chile – May 1, 1974, Siena, Italy ) was an Argentine physicist.  
   
   
 == Education ==  
 He received his B.Sc. degree in Science from the University of Santiago in 1931, and M.Sc. in Physics in 1931 from the University of Argentina.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 In 1931, Rodríguez received his PhD in Physics under Luis Villeray y Polanco. He subsequently worked at the National Institute of Telecommunications and ICT from 1930 to 1932. In 1933, he became head of the Pono department of electronics at the Department of Solid State and Electron Device at the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, taking over in 1937. He began publishing in the astronomical field with great success in his years there. In 1936 he joined the Paris Institute of Physics, where he remained until 1962. He was on the staff of the Ernest-Villard Center for Space Research until 1962, and continued to lecture in that field until 1974.  
 His scientific work in the field of high energy physics centered on research of beta rays, an effect they had demonstrated before. In 1937, he demonstrated the existence of two emission lines ( one in the star X-Ray, and one in the visible galaxy corona ) in the lifetime of X-ray pulsations, and in 1953 he performed another study. He played a key role in the development of the Naming Supernova Investigation Group, and was also awarded an Honorary Doctorate from the University of Madrid.  
 He was elected to the Royal Society of South America in 1948, and served on its scientific committee for 16 years. He chaired the research team in the field of cosmic rays for three years, during which time he analyzed the energetic particle stream. He was awarded the gold medal of the National Academy of Sciences in 1960.  
 He died on May 1, 1974 in Punta Medio, Chile.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Sven-August Mattsson =  
Sven-August Mattsson ( 23 June 1906 – 25 June 1994 ) was a Swedish theologian, known for his studies of the Pentateuch and Old Testament.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Sven-August Mattsson was born in Dølgen, southern Sweden, to a family of the Hrothi ( people of southern Scandinavian origin ). Mattsson studied for two years at the University of Stockholm, first in theology and then in the study of Old Testament literature. As an Old Testament scholar he developed his doctoral thesis on Ephraim, Paul's son-in-law. After graduation he served as an assistant at the University of Lund from 1927 to 1929.  
 He started work at the College for Theology in 1932, becoming a professor of Old Testament in 1935. In 1936 he went to Harvard, where he held the chair of the Philology. On the Russian invasion of Poland in 1939 he worked at the Greek New Testament Library in New York. The following year he married Gylla Baudelaire O. Lindgren, who had taught a course in Old Testament at the Sorbonne in the 1940s. In 1947 he was appointed to the faculty of Old Testament at the University of Oslo. He became a professor of Old Testament at the University of Lund in 1964.  
 He wrote a large number of books and many reviews on Old Testament literature. He also served as the editor of the theologically-oriented journal Norraå in the 1970s and on the faculties at the University of Regensburg and the University of Tübingen.  
 He died in 1994 in the Carlsbad, California area.  
   
   
 == Selected works ==

 === Literature ===  
   
   
 === Other ===  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Eli Olson =  
Eli Olson ( November 7, 1874 – March 13, 1954 ) was an American psychologist.  
   
   
 == Education ==  
 He was born in Roseburg, Oregon. He received his undergraduate degree from Cornell University.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 From 1906 to 1913 he served as an assistant professor of education in the Department of Education at Columbia University. From 1913 to 1917 he was an assistant professor of social work at Howard University. During that time he also served as an assistant professor of education at Cornell University, the University of Wisconsin–Madison, and the University of Chicago. During World War I, he was a military psychologist at Fort McPherson and a student of Alfred North Whitehead. He was an assistant editor of the Journal of General Psychology, the bi-monthly publication of the American Psychological Association, from 1917 to 1945. He retired from academia in 1948.  
 In 1922 Olson began to work as a private investigator. After collecting records for over 30 years he died in Chandler, Arizona.  
   
   
 == Death ==  
 He died of a heart attack while hiking at Pinal Peak in the Solano and San Bernardino counties of California, on March 13, 1954.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = John E. Douglas =  
John Francis Edwin Douglas ( March 31, 1857 – May 9, 1930 ) was an American educator, zoologist, and author. He was born in Philadelphia. He was one of the first students to attend University of Michigan. After graduating, he became a teacher and lecturer at Eastern Michigan University. He was a founder of the Pennsylvania Zoological Society in 1884. In 1891, he became Professor of Zoology at the University of Michigan and again, in 1897 he was made full Professor. He continued teaching at the University of Michigan until the death of his wife, Eliza. After a long illness, he was succeeded by William Scott Swafford. He served as State Naturalist of Virginia from 1902 until 1913. He received the Professorship of Zoology from Yale University in 1905. He was twice president of the American Association of University Women and served as Secretary of the American Museum of Natural History from 1914 to 1917. He was a member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, Phi Beta Kappa, the Carnegie Institution of Washington, the Royal Society of Philadelphia, the Berlin Society, and the National Academy of Sciences.Douglas died at his home on Lebanon Street in New Haven, Connecticut.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Stefan Istvolski =  
Stefan Istvolski ( 20 February 1901 – 10 February 1981 ) was a Polish civil engineer and a known defender of Ukrainian ethnic Russians.  
   
   
 == Education and career ==  
 Stefan Istvolski completed his secondary education in Ańl. and Jena and was awarded a PhD in civil engineering by the University of Warsaw in 1913. He taught at the Technological Institute in Warsaw.  
   
   
 == USSR ==  
 Istvolski studied at the Moscow University of Technology. During World War I, he served in World War II. In January 1919 he returned to the USSR, and joined the prestigious Institute of World Technology ( Ostrowsyky Krytym Fizikumu Nachtarubnych Koditi ). There he taught the subject of aircraft on the government-funded thesis `` A thesis on the utility of the ideal flow between the higher cylinder and the lower fuselage of the. Armata T-10 in the line of the commercial era ''. This work was performed in 1938, with three students graduating. Istvolski was presented with the prestigious Stalin Prize for his research and `` devoted all his spare time to the research on the upper part of the lower fuselage and to the theoretical aspects of the theory of the upper part of the lower fuselage ''.  
   
   
 == Later years ==  
 A Rockefeller Foundation scholarship awarded in April 1933 provided for Istvolski to move to New York City to work at the World War II-era Manhattan Project's Aircraft Research Laboratory, where he worked in 1943 until 1946.He eventually left this part of the job to spend his time in Canada, retiring in 1950. He died in 1983, just before he received his doctorate.  
   
   
 == Personal life ==  
 Stefan Istvolski was married twice : in 1908 to Rosalind ( d. 1935 ) and in 1921 to Kazimierz Gudzurescu ( 1934–2003 ). His third wife was I. Balázs.Istvolski died in Ańl, Poland, in 1981.  
   
   
 == Publications ==  
 In 1972 he created the Jan Krzysztof Istvolski theory of airflow.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Kurt Beckmann =  
Kurt Beckmann ( 29 July 1912 in Greifswald, North-West Germany – 11 August 1994 in Frühling ) was a German computer scientist known for the establishment of the principle of function homologies. Beckmann is famous for proving the existence of a basic set of laws governing the interaction of integrals ( heterogeneous functions ) and of all non-trivial n-form algebras.  
   
   
 == Early life and education ==  
 Beckmann was born in Greifswald. He studied mathematics and physics at the Friedrich-Wilhelms-Universität in Berlin and the University of Rostock. In 1931 he obtained his doctorate in mathematics. In 1935 he joined the Deutsche Akademie für Naturkunde in Bonn. In 1936 he became a member of the Central Committee and as a result of his work with the Ringreich Mathematical Society the office was shifted to the Bürger- und Universität. In 1941 he became an associate professor, became full professor in 1947, and taught until 1952.  
   
   
 == Work in non-trivial n-form algebras ==  
 Since the Bürger- und Universität has not given the necessary academic permission to Beckmann to publish his research on non-trivial n-form algebras in German, he founded the Group for Journal on Non-trivial n-Formal Algebra ( Grassmann-Verlag ) in 1953. Beckmann's group continued in large numbers until he stopped work, after decades of constant correspondence, with David Reimer and Frederik Frobenius. Beckmann continued to collaborate with Reimer on the Siegel algebras which he published in 1957 and published with Paul Cox in 1963.  
   
   
 == Writings ==  
 Non-trivial Algebra as a Class ( Wegman, 1956 )  
 Proposition Algebra ( Springer-Verlag, 1966 )  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Ernest Harrison (Colonel) =  
Sir Ernest Harrison FRSE FGS FNB MD FIB COS FRCSC ( 6 April 1869 – 20 April 1937 ) was a British ornithologist. He was the father of James Harrison ( 1850-1891 ) and Thomas Harrison ( 1866-1920 ).  
   
   
 == Early life and education ==  
 Harrison was born in Sutton Coldfield, Kent to Edward Jr and Janet Margaret Robinson. His parents were William Robinson, a copper and zinc smelter operator, and Hannah ( née Robinson ), who was a daughter of Sir Henry Green. The family home was in Yorkshire House. After attending Birmingham and the University of London, Harrison studied zoology at King's College, London, under Theodore Morton, where he became a fellow.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
   
 After working as an entomologist at the Royal Agricultural Society of Great Britain, Harrison became assistant curator of the state of Yorkshire, and as senior lecturer in ornithology at University College, Oxford, where he was appointed head of the department in 1912. He also was a professor of zoology at the University of London from 1921 to 1929, the same year he joined the Ministry of Agriculture.  
 After retiring in 1935, he became president of the Royal Entomological Society, Oxford, where he was its vice-president from 1936 to 1939, and was elected vice-president in 1937.  
 His large collection of biological specimens, made especially for his book Natural History of Birds, gained him a reputation as one of the finest naturalists to have ever lived. He was president of the Entomological Society of London in 1935–1938.  
 Harrison was appointed a Fellow of the Royal Society in 1904, and a member of the Entomological Society of London in 1916, and of the Linnean Society of London in 1938.  
   
   
 == Death and legacy ==  
 He died at his home, 65 Butterfield Avenue, Sheffield, on 20 April 1937, aged 83.  
 A curator of the museum in Oxford, he was survived by his daughters Susan, who was a professor of zoology, and his granddaughter, Lily, who was curator of entomology at York Museum.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 From Natural History, his `` New Foundland Birds ''  
 A Study of the Identification of Platyceps lacustris, and of its Problems, with Décamiers for and on Reference to `` The Life of Rouss '' by Rouss de Laurence ( 1856 )  
 A Scheme for the Protection of Schools and Towns against Fever, with a Special Reference to Safety Measures in Case of Increased Deprivation of Magnesium, ( 1869 )  
 Journal of the Reading Society for 1876–1922 ( other publications of interest are his inaugural paper, 1895 )  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Theodore de Broglie =  
Antoine de Broglie ( 1546 – 1583 ) was a French physicist, astronomer, and mathematician who in 1575 published a second edition of his Physics of the Stars, part two. He became one of the founders of modern astronomy and is considered as the father of modern solid state physics. He is the author of a standard textbook entitled Principes de physique mathematique, a work in which he pioneered the use of calculus to study celestial mechanics and a non-topological space-time model, also known as a topological solver or mathematical Newtonian model.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Born in 1546 in Rodeaux, near Paris, Theodore de Broglie graduated from the École Polytechnique in 1576 and pursued a scientific career until his retirement in 1591. He travelled widely, visiting Japan, China, Korea and India. His interest in astronomy was inspired by William Flinders Petrie, and he corresponded with John Alexander Raffles and John Creighton Ross. He lived near Lycée Jardin at Père Lachaise and carried on discussions with the French astronomer François Guay.  
   
   
 == Astronomer ==  
 He created the theory of the planets, and established theorems governing those planets. The planets were named after him, the following are one from the point of view of another :  
   
 Mars, 20 August 1555  
 Jupiter, 5 June 1605  
 Mercury, 7 April 1607  
 Venus, 23 April 1611  
 Mars was renamed in his honor in 1657 by Charles-François Louis Edmond Moreau de Saint-Pierre. It is now known as Jovian Venus ( fr ).  
   
   
 == Gravitational constants ==  
   
 In 1581 he named the curve of the planet's orbit CRS-c, the zenith/declination being indicated by the symbol e e on his gravitation table.  
   
   
 == Bibliography ==  
 A review article on Astronomie by W.E.W, and on  
 Schrödinger's quantum mechanics by S.R. Wilson, F.R. Hughes, D.T. Johnson, and C.R. Parks, was published in the Annals of the Astronomical and Mechanical Society. Other books about this work include :  
 Bode : Quattromathmatica, published in 1779 by Isaac Perutz ( G.V. Stockle ).  
 An Apologie for L'intégration des Telescopéristiques by Frédéric Breughel ( 1789–1821 ), ( H. 1 vol. ). ( English translation : On the annoyance of astronomy to mathematicians, a defense of its nature, 1820 ).  
 Le Système astronomique de Blaise Pascal, 5 vols. ( 1825–1826 ). ( English translation : The science of astronomy, 1826 ).  
 Reminiscences sur les Physics ( 1860 ), 4 vols. ( A.T. Benjamin )  
 Nouveaux rules sur la gravitation, 2 vols. ( 1875–1876 )  
 La ratio du true or theorem des gravitations de ce, 1 vol. ( F.C. Léger & G.E. Fox )  
 Chronographie astronomique, 3 vols. ( 1836–1916 ).  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Hanna Czerny =  
Hanna Anna ( Nijinska ) Czerny ( c. 1931-1999 ) was an early Belarusian Jewish writer of Polish origin. She published Aufklärung in Deutschland, a novel, about Polish-Jewish life in southern France.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Hanna Czerny was born Hanna Anna von von Nijinska ( originally Kójno, then part of Bohemia, Czechoslovakia and Slovakia ) to Jewish parents, Dziańska von Nijinska ( 1767-1809 ) and Leopold Czerny ( 1782-1874 ). Czerny immigrated to the Soviet Union in 1941, to escape the `` eugenics '' movement, which her family had supported. She is known for her early novels about the life of the Warsaw gentry, Poznysław Nogowski. Czerny wrote for both contemporary and historical periodicals.  
 Czerny earned her D.Sc. from the Humboldt University of Berlin. In 1939, she became a member of the Communist Party of Germany, with an appointment in Berlin's German Jewish Section. From the German Party she voted for the Nazi Party of Germany.  
 She went on to write numerous books about life in the Warsaw gentry, including an autobiography, Mein Kampf, together with friends P. Zolotarewka and Mieczysław Korczkowski, and three autobiographical novels.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 Niederschwörungen, das Beobachtung durch der Funktionen und die veriffizialen Stimmung nach der Mitteleuropäischen Orient ( The journey to east and the Berlin of the amateur bourgeois ), 1930 ( German )  
 Mein Kampf : ein Beitrag zur bewirkung und allgemeine Geschichte im Bereich den Indien. J. Capri, 1930 ( German )  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Alkanah Muhammad Amin =  
Alkanah Muhammad Amin ( 1877–1947 ) was an eminent Ottoman orientalist and archaeologist, director of the Diyala Oriental Institute, librarian of the Ottoman Library in Vienna, an anthropologist, former prisoner of war, and an ethnic scholar.  
   
   
 == Life and work ==  
 Amin was born in the Ottoman Empire and died in Vienna in 1947. He studied at Leipzig and Berlin, obtained his doctorate with a dissertation on Babylonia, and founded the Alkanah Muhammad Amin Oriental Institute in 1887. He also worked as a physical anthropologist, and collected artifacts for his Mabruki archive.  
 Amin took a leave of absence for the return journey to the Ukraine where he died in the Crimean War.  
 His works are still held by the Anthropological Institute of Vienna, and at the Istanbul Museum.  
   
   
 == Family ==  
 Alkanah Muhammad Amin was a grandson of Abdus Salam Alkanah and a great-grandson of Reza Hashemi.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
   
   
 === Archeology ===  
 Alkanah Muhammad Amin's Archaeological works include the numerous monographic sources documenting and interpreting the oral tradition of Khurasan, the Nubian region.  
 He wrote several articles on Kushan and the mound mounds.  
   
   
 === Ethnography ===  
 Alkanah Muhammad Amin's Ethnography works include work on Lop Nur, a tribe belonging to the Chechen religion in Central Asia, with maps and detailed descriptions.  
   
   
 === Family life ===  
 Alkanah Muhammad Amin's grandfather Alkanah Hasan Jamaluddin Abdul Mahdi Alkanah was a grandson of Grand Ayub Muhammad Hasan Ahmad Alkanah.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = William Bennet Brown =  
William Bennet Brown ( 9 June 1791 – 16 January 1864 ) was an English physicist, born in New York City. Brown served as a lecturer in chemical physics at the New York Academy of Sciences, where he wrote several popular scientific works.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Brown was born in Brooklyn, the youngest of five children of William Bennet and Elizabeth ( née Dedham ) Brown. He had three older brothers, Francis, Emanuel and John. Brown attended the New York City Public School from 1798 to 1800. He joined the lab of Elihu Huntington Whitehead at Harvard in 1800, and moved on to teach at Columbia University. Brown worked on experiments related to light, magnetism and conduction under Princeton University's Charles Hales and William A. Kelly.  
 In 1804, Brown moved to the U.S. to continue his research. He had graduated from Columbia with a B.A. in 1808 and a Ph.D. in 1810. He was appointed member of the editorial board of the Brooklyn Commercial Appeal in 1820, a position he maintained until 1828. Brown earned a summa cum laude degree in 1824 from Columbia University. In 1835, Brown married Eliza Mary O'Harey ( born 1862 ), daughter of John and Mary O'Harey of Botton, New Hampshire. Eliza served as president of the Marine Science Association of America from 1843–1846, serving as the fourth president in a vacancy. Brown's daughter, John, was appointed acting President of the Virginia Academy of Science in 1856. John married Mary Ann Robinson, born in 1818.  
   
   
 == Publications ==  
, 1822. An Elementary Book on Conducting Machines, or Human Electricians.  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Edgar Burgess (botanist) =  
Edgar Burgess ( 9 July 1860 – 5 August 1941 ) was an English botanist, ichthyologist and mineralogist.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Burgess was born at Hever near Lanarkshire and educated at Glasgow University, graduating B.A. in 1898, M.A. in 1903 and D.Phil. in 1905. He served with the Edinburgh Corps of Engineers, being awarded the Victoria Cross on 5 June 1917 and being promoted to Captain in 1918. He undertook further training at the Berlin Natural History Museum, where he attained the rank of Lieutenant Colonel in April 1921. In 1922, he was appointed in charge of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew, as professor of botany and applied mineralogy and was appointed consultant to the Plant Council in October 1927. After four years at the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew, he retired to Norwich where he made a private collection of about 1,600 specimens of plants, of which the majority were in the Balearic Islands, the British Islands and Burma.  
 In 1917 he married Emily Mary Crane of Stoke Newington, Leicestershire. They had two daughters and one son. From 1933 to 1936 Burgess was employed by the Botanical Society of Great Britain, Norwich, to examine samples of mollusks that had been collected and sent to Britain by German scientists, mainly by Otto Neubauer and Adolf Hildebrand, together with the suggestion that this should be the basis of specimens being sent to the Royal Botanic Gardens. He also provided the specimens for the London Magazine the following year. Later in his career, Burgess co-authored a report on Mediterranean flora with John Sargant in 1936. His field work in the Malay Archipelago, the Solomon Islands, the Maldives and the Peninsular, and several trips to Ceylon made him noted as a specialist on the Malay archipelago. He was elected a Fellow of the Linnean Society in 1918 and his paper on Malayan vegetation was later recognised as 'one of the important statements on a subject discussed in the international scientific conferences that followed.' 
   
   
 == Works ==  
 A flora and aural flora of the islands of Ceylon ( 1902 ).  
 A theme of recent botany ( 1904 ).  
 The metamorphosed vegetation of Ceylon ( 1904 ).  
 The different plants and forests of Ceylon ( 1908 ).  
 Proceedings of the Kew Physical Laboratory and Geology Exhibition, 1909-1910 ( with John Sargant and Duncan Milburn, 1911 ).  
 Specimens from a plant garden at Kew Botanic Gardens ( 1911 ).  
 Studies in Phytopathology ( 1912 ).  
 A pectinophile ( 1913 ).  
 The flowering plants of Ceylon ( 1914 ).  
 The leaf-bearing plants of Ceylon ( 1915 ).  
 An introduction to the geography and economy of Ceylon ( 1920 ).  
 The flora of certain Australian Islands ( 1922 ).  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Howard S. Bruck =  
Howard Samuel Bruck ( 5 June 1881 – 27 September 1940 ) was a British zoologist. He is chiefly known for his early work on birds, particularly the long-tailed lark.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Bruck was born in Lanarkshire, the son of Robert John Bruck ( 1825–1904 ) and Florence Rhoda Elton ( 1826–1907 ). He was educated at Rugby College, Aberdeen, and became a Canon of the Church of Scotland and a priest in Kincardineshire, in 1896. He was a curator at the Natural History Museum in London and at the British Museum from 1902, and was a Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh from 1913.From 1926 to 1934 Bruck was in charge of the Main Field Zoological Service ( now the Field Research Service ) in Egerton, Aberdeenshire. He was subsequently asked to serve on a Research Expedition to New Guinea ( from 1929 to 1934 ), and he was the first of three Field Curators to arrive in West Papua in 1932. Bruck went to the island in 1933, after the Consul-General had asked him to evaluate an endangered species of kiwi.  
 As he was not a trained zoologist, he had to work on largely self-directed work in the field. He was particularly interested in the long-tailed lark, with which he closely collaborated and observed. He published many papers and reports on birds and recorded his observations and observations-briefly on 63 occasions in total-over 150 years. During his tenure, he established new classes of birds, introduced species, and acquired a new field of study. He named the common woodpecker Barnacle ballista, Angora pala ( which he named after the house in which he lived ).He was a Fellow of the Royal Society, the Royal Society of Edinburgh and the British Ornithologists'Union.  
   
   
 == Publications ==  
 The World ’ s Birds ( 1917 )  
 De Sciensia ( 1922 )  
 The Wild Song-Vocalizer : A Field Guide to Birds ( 1929 )  
 Birds of the World ( 1933 )  
 A Field Guide to the World's Birds ( 1934 )  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Heinrich Wilhelm Brandt =  
Heinrich Wilhelm Brandt ( 13 March 1866, Leipzig – 23 April 1941, Groß Neustadt ) was a German physicist, professor and professor of physics, director of the faculty of physics at the universities of Hannover, Greifswald and Prague. He also founded the Institute for Advanced Studies of the Lubeck Academy of Sciences.  
 Brandt is credited with developing the inertial-enforcement technique.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Brandt studied physics under Carl Friedrich von Weizsäcker and Hans Eduard Kiepert at the University of Göttingen. Brandt was a student of Rudolf Clausius and Günther Behlendorf, and was awarded his PhD by Leipzig in 1898 with his thesis `` Die Tösche und der Gedankeen des Nonentwickelungen für die Elektromagnetische Untersuchung. ''  
 Between 1903 and 1904 Brandt continued his work as an undergraduate at the University of Freiburg, and worked at the ETH Zurich, under the direction of Henri Poincaré, again under Karl August Ewald.  
 He received his doctorate in 1904 from the University of Göttingen, and worked as a professor there from 1910 to 1919. In 1919, Brandt and Albert Einstein were members of the First Executive Council of the Deutsche Physikalische Gesellschaft.  
 In 1919, Brandt was appointed the director of the Physics Department of the Academy of Sciences of Greifswald. In 1924 he became head of the department, before retiring in 1934.  
 In 1923, Brandt became an adviser of the Protestant Reformed Church. He died in Hannover.  
   
   
 == Selected publications ==  
 Die Tösche und der Gedankeen des Nonentwickelungen für die Elektromagnetische Untersuchung.  
 Die Elektro elektromagnetische Natur und Energie für die Elektrothermal ( 1906 ).  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Friedrich Paul Hofmeister =  
Friedrich Paul Hofmeister ( September 12, 1822 – December 21, 1907 ) was a German naturalist, botanist, and professor of botany at the University of Berlin.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 He was born at Königstein, Preussen Land to a well-to-do family. He studied at the universities of Göttingen and Berlin.  
 In 1845 he entered the Imperial Botanic Garden, Berlin, and from 1856 to 1861 served as professor of botany there, and in 1862 to 1878 as director of the botanical garden at Wolfenbüttel. He was one of the original leaders of the Linnaean Society of Berlin and the founder of the Zoological Society of Berlin. He also is credited with creating the `` Hofmeister zur Schmiederschaften '', a series of nine scientific monographs about African moths.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Friedrich Olav Koch =  
Friedrich ( Thor ) Karl Koch ( 20 June 1838 in Karlsruhe – 5 April 1924 in Stuttgart ) was a German economist, chemist and geneticist.  
   
   
 == Early life ==  
 Friedrich Karl Koch was born in Karlsruhe, the son of farmer Karl Koch ( 1816–1878 ) and Alice Marie Kremer ( 1812–1893 ). Friedrich was educated at the gymnasium and the public school. In 1864 he enrolled in the University of Tübingen and graduated in 1867, obtaining a Ph.D. in 1867. Later in life he worked as a professor of chemistry and botany at the University of Göttingen, where he was also a lecturer. In 1873 he was elected as a foreign member of the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 In 1884 he published the first of several influential works in the field of genetics : his Contributions to the Development of Adaptive And Altered Cytology, 1885. In his second volume he developed the concept of an `` active replacement '', and the nature of genetic requirements, to their most abstract form, which embodied the view that inherited traits are learned instead of acquired. The following year, his third volume, Verhandlungen über einige Untersuchungen in die Verhältniss zu einer Ergebnisse der Plasmodium, dealt with the inheritance of `` harmful '' variants. In 1870 he wrote über die Ethnographie und Untersuchungen auf die Genetische Inschriften ( Contributions to the Ethnography and Evolution of the Human Family ), which discussed the hybridization of certain breeds and what that would mean for humanity. Two years later he published, Verhandlungen über einige Untersuchungen auf die Einleitung der Naturwissenschaften ( Contributions to the Social and Economic Development of the Human World ), which was concerned with the migration of different races, particularly the non-European populations of the Middle East.  
 In 1873 he became a member of the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences, which he resigned in 1882. His role there was limited. He served as the society's president until 1883, and a corresponding member from 1886 to 1896. He wrote twice for the Jahrbücher Zeitung, the German periodical of the University of Berlin, which he edited. Koch's most famous work is the Two Methods of Erasure of Result and Interpretation, edited by his son, anthropologist Friedrich Koch ( 1878–1948 ).  
   
   
 == Personal life ==  
 Koch married Sophia Horner in 1874. In 1900 he became a full professor of sociology. In 1905, he married Valentina Kühnel. He died in Stuttgart, aged 74.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Tommaso the Magnificent =  
Tommaso the Magnificent ( 11 March 1809 – 26 November 1902 ) was an Italian geologist.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Tommaso worked as a professional economist of Italian origin in Rome. In 1832 he published a paper entitled Il saggi opera di Giovanni di Piardetti e Riccati di Calabria.  
 He was elected to the Linceum, he died in Rome, and was buried in the Avenue Pompeia ( of the sea ), on 1 December 1902.  
   
   
 == Family ==  
 Tommaso the Magnificent married Augusta d'Ooiles ( née Beccari ) ( 1835–1888 ), a daughter of architect Luigi Beccari, in La Provincia di Giolitti in 1844. The couple had two daughters, Adalberta and Amanda, in addition to two sons, Antonio and Gioacchino.  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Franciscus Andrew S. Willis =  
Franciscus Andrew S. Willis ( May 31, 1888 – November 28, 1947 ) was an American geologist and palaeontologist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 William Wood, a Harvard undergraduate in 1912, met and then became co-editor with Willis of a work that he later published as a monograph, Paleontology and Prehistory. A year later he received a master's degree in geology from the University of Chicago. After a research assistant position with the Bureau of American Ethnology in 1915 he joined the Geological Survey of America, later returning to Harvard University as an associate geologist in 1916. In 1919 Willis married Louise F. Mason and they had four children : Edwin K. Willis ( 1915–2008 ), Mary Grace Louise, and Tim F. Willis ( 1928–2014 ).  
 Willis was at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics in Cambridge, Massachusetts. He was president of the Geological Society of America in 1948. He was director of the Museum of Vertebrate Paleontology at Harvard University from 1966 to 1979. He died at his home in Cambridge, Massachusetts.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Paul Kock =  
Paul Kock ( 14 December 1881 in Frönsvötn – 22 December 1960 ) was a Swedish chemist, mathematician and researcher, best known for discovering the Kock–Lehn law in 1932, a theorem of Kock and Ludvig Ulvaeus.Kock worked on a study of the chemistry of ozone, an important point of interest in the development of modern radiology. He studied helium and others in the field, and soon became a recognized authority on these elements.Kock taught mathematics at Pori University until 1930, when he became president of the university. Kock died in Stockholm, Sweden.  
   
   
 == Life and work ==  
 Paul Kock was born in Frönsvötn, County Stockholm, the son of Erich Kock ( 1821–1915 ) and Caroline-Bartolomé Perner ( 1850–1913 ). His sister Celine was named after him. In 1886, at age eighteen, he was hired to a research laboratory in Plönheim, where he worked as a research assistant under Jens Lehn, an influential chemist from Brandenburg, who introduced the Lehn–Kock law to Sweden. In 1888, Kock and Lehn published a seminal paper on a special category of benzoene. This became a standard method for studying the different types of benzoene from purebenzene. Kock and Lehn introduced the law, and the name now is to be found on some practical goods such as acids, stearic acid, butylene glycol, benzene glycol, butylene glycol-fumarate, acetylene glycol-amide, carnauba wax, castor oil, oil of xanthan gum and liquid rubber.  
 In 1899, after a contract with the university, Kock was appointed to the chair of chemistry at the newly established Karlsruhe University. Kock described his work on the structure of naphthalene, formed through polyvinyl dimethicone synthesis, in 1905, and introduced the law of Kock and Lehn ( the Kock coefficient ).  
 In 1912, he began to develop further his interest in chemistry and meteorology, but his schooling had not allowed him to fully pursue this interest until World War I. The Kock school in Karlsruhe taught mathematics and physical chemistry, and was originally meant to train future scientists. Although the school closed in 1923, Kock continued to hold meetings. In 1914, Kock published his initial findings, and received a Ph.D. from the University of Cambridge in Chemistry and Biology in 1919.  
 Kock was a major figure in the development of radar. His radar developments were a major stepping stone for all subsequent efforts to develop radiology.  
 Kock coined the Kock–Lehn theorem ( translation Kock–Lehn law ; see this article, though it may in fact refer to the law of Lehn and Kock ) and developed a theory of molecular structure. In 1937, he discovered a Kock-Lehn liquid crystal in which each crystal has an internal mirror surface. At the time of his death, Kock's liquid crystal was not known to be a new discovery, but only the first crystalline structure known. However, his fluid crystal was large and consisted of 93 layers of lattice, with 3×7-cm diameter of high refractive index and a solid crystal surface. In 1938, Kock was allowed to resume his work at the university, but at the time he was still the only non-scientist at the university in terms of `` basic research activities '' ( research subjects were all interrelated and included in the normal academic activity ).  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Gaston François Geoffrey =  
Gaston François Geoffrey ( May 29, 1837 – June 14, 1905 ) was a French Orientalist.  
 A philosopher, linguist and medievalist, he edited the orientalist Dictionnaire Orientaliste ( French : Dictionnaire Orientale ) ( 1877–1889 ) and the main orientalist L'Israël Histoire d'Ajax ( 1892–1908 ).  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Geoffrey was born in Aubury-sur-Mer, in 1837. After completing his secondary education at the Collège de France, he became a jurisconsult.  
 In 1849, Geoffrey entered the Sorbonne ( graduating in 1859 ), where he stayed until his graduation. In 1870 he obtained a licentiate at the Sorbonne. In 1876 he was elected a member of the Paris Academy of Sciences. He was appointed professor of Semitic languages in 1882, of the Coptic language in 1885, and of Persian in 1897. The first volume of his new monograph, Les Africaines Sarsées de la France ( Orientales in Africa ), was published in 1885.  
 Between 1875 and 1899, Geoffrey was an associate professor of Oriental languages at the University of Paris. In 1898 he was appointed as the director of the Oriental Institute, of which he remained until his death.  
 The Orientalist's experience and advocacy on behalf of the civilization of the Orient influenced all three volumes of the American edition of L'Israël Histoire. An inaugural lecture for an inaugural lecture appeared in 1896, and a sequel appeared in 1899.His publication of notes on the Textus Receptus, [ text ] ( 1877–1889 ) is considered one of the best English translations of the Zend-Avestan Text of the Iliad. He took great care in locating and preserving the original text.  
   
   
 == Publications ==  
 Dictionnaire Orientaliste, 1877.  
 L'Israël Histoire d'Ajax, 1892.  
 Les Africaines Sarsées de la France, 1895.  
 L'Israël de Saint-Jean, 1896.  
 Études Orientales, 1897.  
 Oyez y Urushie, 1902.  
 Haile Selassie II : Tiefenbaum, 1904.  
 Revue Orientaliste, 1910.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Rosetta Manning =  
Rosetta the bearess ( 1850 - September 18, 1935 ) was a Canadian schoolteacher, author, conservationist, animal psychologist and First Lady of the United States.  
   
   
 == Early life ==  
 She was born in British Columbia to Jennette and Benjamin Manning, followed by her brother H.W. Manning. The young Manning was known to be interested in writing as a profession.  
   
   
 == Education ==  
 Manning was educated in Vancouver, the Inner Mountain, and Vancouver Island, all of which were noted for their impressive natural areas. She earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in 1910 and a Masters of Arts degree in 1912 from University of British Columbia.  
   
   
 == Personal life ==  
 After graduating, Manning served in the Women's Auxiliary of the Women's Republican League. After marrying Solomon Jocelyn Manning in 1911, she lived in Pleasant View, Ontario. Jocelyn was a well-known writer in Canada, including writing for the Canadian Magazine ( Winnipeg ), Time, and, most famously, CBC radio's Up, Down,'and Breakfast Hour. In 1917, she and Jocelyn were inducted into the Canadian Writers of Canada Hall of Fame.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 In 1920, Manning's first book, A Naturalist's Guide to Herpetology was published. She also taught at schools in British Columbia and Niagara Falls. In 1921, Manning helped to establish the Niagara Wild Animal Club with fellow instructor and fellow First Lady, Leonard Sitterson. This club later became the Niagara Conservation Society, and led to the conservation of over 700,000 bear cubs in what is now the Niagara region of Ontario. In 1921, she married Jewish immigrant Jacob Cressey Manning. The couple had three daughters : Elizabeth Margaret, Edith Elizabeth and Rosetta.  
 She went on to found the foundation for the Musician's Nature Park ( now Musician's Park ) in Niagara Falls, Ontario, in 1922. Rosetta Manning became the largest person to be officially recognized as a Musician's Nature Park Conservator in Canada. She also founded and was president of the Musicians Association of Canada ( the first such organization in Canada ).  
 In 1925, Rosetta Manning became the first woman to be awarded an honorary degree from McGill University. During her time there, she worked with McGill's Department of Zoology to develop a popular course in the field of birds, which was later renamed the Bachelor of Animal Science. She also founded the Mammalogist's Field Club, which was also named for her.  
 In 1927, Manning founded the Canadian Biographical Society. Her actions to help establish the Biographical Society allowed her to be included on the society's 100 Most Influential Canadians list.In 1928, Manning published her first book, Nature's Ballads : How to Read, Sing and Play, which incorporated her own words into words drawn by her husband and her two daughters. She became a contributing editor for Nature for an estimated twenty years. Her work soon became well known as a national guide for seniors. In 1942, she was the first woman to receive the Distinguished Service Award from the National League of American Zoologists.In 1953, she married Segal Porter, a doctor.  
   
   
 == Awards ==  
 For her work and service, Manning was inducted into the United States Women's Hall of Fame in 1971. The field of marine mammal ecology is also named in her honour.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Frederick William John McFall =  
Frederick William John McFall ( June 29, 1858 – May 29, 1922 ) was an American economist and demographer.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 McFall was born in Baltimore, Maryland, the son of John McFall, a lawyer and founder of the Baltimore Stock Exchange. He graduated from Harvard College in 1870. He was admitted to the Harvard Business School in 1875, earning a B.A. in 1876. In 1878, he accepted a professorship at the Harvard Graduate School of Management, a position which he filled until his retirement in 1899. He remained at Harvard as a lecturer until 1899, and then returned to the consulting business for another twenty years. He served as dean of the graduate school from 1902 to 1906.  
   
   
 == Academic career ==  
 McFall's international role involved research on the U.S. commerce with China. He was elected a Foreign Member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences in 1893. McFall became professor of economics at Harvard in 1901, and subsequently director of the department for foreign and economic affairs. In 1915, he retired from Harvard to serve as an emeritus professor of economics at Princeton University. He was made a fellow of the American Statistical Association in 1908, and twice elected as its president. He was a member of the National Academy of Sciences from 1901 to 1906, and the Statistical Association of America in 1904 and 1907. He was a recipient of the Abel Prize of the American Statistical Association in 1911.  
   
   
 == Death ==  
 McFall died in Poughkeepsie, New York. He was sixty-eight years old.  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Leonard Nelson =  
Leonard Nelson ( June 15, 1864 – March 19, 1948 ) was an American educator. He was born in Detroit, Michigan, the son of a Presbyterian minister. He received a Ph.D. in social work from the University of Michigan in 1900.  
 In 1907 he went to the United States Coast Guard at the age of 14, and was sent to Canada. He was posted to the Texas coast. On December 16, 1907, he arrived in the United States at the age of 21.  
 In 1910 Nelson was appointed Assistant Superintendent of Schools, a position he held until his retirement in 1947. Nelson succeeded Ernest B. Bowman as Superintendent of Schools for the City of Portland, Oregon.  
 Nelson was also a leader in educating school children, and many of his pupils graduated to become teachers. He authored many school books including the introduction to School Culture. He wrote School Man, Teaching School, and A Quality Education for Every Child. Among the areas he worked on were prevention of illiteracy, special education, the testing of teachers, and preparation of teachers for the modern education curriculum.  
 He died in Portland, Oregon at the age of 81. He was buried in the Morgan Park Cemetery.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Alan Patterson =  
Sir Alan Patterson, FRS ( 4 June 1918 – 21 August 1992 ) was a British physicist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Patterson was born at Blackerton Road, Hertfordshire, the son of Leclow Patterson, a tailor, and his wife, Jean. He was educated at St John's School and Exeter Grammar School. In 1931, he earned a £5,000 ( £6,000 at that time ) teaching scholarship to study Physics at Trinity College, Cambridge.After working as a mathematician at the Imperial Meteorological Observatory in London, he took up a job at the Cambridge Atomic Energy Laboratory. Here he worked on a programme of intense theoretical research to better understand the magnetic and electrical properties of atomic nuclei. In 1934, he became the first director of the Radiophysics Laboratory, a relatively new division of the University of Cambridge, before joining the faculty in 1940. After serving in the army during the Second World War, he returned to academia, moving to the Department of Physics and Mathematics at the University of London in 1946, and acting as director from 1957 to 1965, when he became professor emeritus. In 1958, he served as President of the Royal Society of Arts and Sciences, elected on 15 June 1958.  
 The main argument in his book `` The Magnetic Properties of Protons '' outlined his understanding that, rather than being defined as the elementary particles of matter, protons and deuterons were in fact elementary particles. In 1947 he introduced the concept of the Strong and Weak interaction, in which these elementary particles were grouped into the basic particles, and corresponded with the basic positrons and eutrons, called `` sodyne and terahertz ''.In 1950, he developed the concept of scalar energy density. He formulated the ellipsoid formula for the energy density of a charged particle, and it is given by  
   
   
   
 ∫  
 h  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Heinrich Ebert =  
Heinrich Emil Friedrich Ebert ( 13 November 1859 in Reutlingen – 19 June 1924 in Pottau ) was a German botanist.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Ebert was born at Reutlingen. He studied natural science and medicine at the University of Potsdam.  
   
   
 == Publications ==  
 He published over 200 papers.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Herbert Muir =  
Herbert Muir ( September 12, 1915 – April 3, 1981 ) was an American historian, distinguished professor of Near Eastern languages at New York University.  
   
   
 == Education and career ==  
 Muir was born in Alton, Illinois, the eldest son of Francis A. Muir, a railroad tycoon, and his second wife Elizabeth Winifred ( d. 1959 ). He was the only son and descendant of a German couple from Aachen.  
 He graduated from the University of Wisconsin at Madison in 1926, earning a BA degree in History in 1928. He returned to public life in 1933, and was appointed associate professor of Middle East studies at his alma mater, New York University.  
 Muir also taught introductory Middle Eastern at Michigan State University in 1934, and at Marquette University from 1936 to 1939. He taught Arabic at Iowa State University, in the Departments of Literature, History, and Languages, from 1938 to 1951. At Marquette, he was appointed assistant professor of Near Eastern languages in 1953, before taking a position at New York University. In 1960, he was appointed professor emeritus, then retained post as director of the New York Central School of Religion. He retired in 1971.  
 From 1966 to 1979, Muir was the director of the Institute of Near Eastern Studies ( IIES ) in New York, where he led the institute's most extensive research project to date, the first to document the history, language, and culture of classical Aramaic.  
   
   
 == Academic works ==  
 He was especially notable for his book The Middle Eastern World. He also edited the Anthologies of Modern Scholarship in Arabic and influenced the field of Near Eastern Studies in the same era. His primary focus of research in the 1950s and 1960s was the Hebrew language and the Aramaic script, which he then expanded with others, such as Algerians and Ethiopians. He extended the study of ancient Aramaic and Hebrew for the first time. His scholarly reputation is well established as he pioneered in the areas of ancient and modern Semitic studies.  
   
   
 == Writings ==  
 Muir authored three books in Arabic and two other languages :  
   
 Teaching Judaism in America : Middle East Studies in Contemporary Context ( New York : Academic Press, 1941 )  
 The History of National and Religious Monotheism : An Introduction to Ancient Near Eastern History ( Chicago : University of Chicago Press, 1952 )  
 The Exodus ( New York : Poets Press, 1958 )  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Rene Soupe =  
Rene Soupe ( July 7, 1901 in Paris – December 9, 1979 ) was an important French psychologist who argued for the existence of a sound psychological base for understanding consciousness.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Soupe was born in Paris and studied at the Collège de France, the École Normale Supérieure, the Sorbonne, and the University of Paris, gaining his PhD at the Sorbonne in 1932, becoming Professor of Experimental Psychology in 1935 and Professor in 1938, while still professor. In 1957 he became a Fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. He became an enthusiastic advocate of Henri Poincaré's Theory of Visual Perception. In 1950 he defended Poincaré's thesis Vérité en physique, point ( `` On the structure of color '' ). Soupe had a strong impression of Nadeau, Hume, Leibniz, Ouspensky, Jung, Percival Lowell and Carl Gustav Jung.In 1961, Soupe and Frédéric Joliot-Curie jointly produced a preliminary work, Père et la vie psychique, which explained the potential for scientific progress in terms of psychology. These two collaborations—through Soupe's participation—were the foundation of an ongoing dialogue between French and American psychological researchers. In 1973, Soupe was awarded the Duchy of Neuchâtel's Albert-Dreyfus prize for honorary services to science, in memory of his teacher, and promoted to the position of Research Director in 1973. In 1973, the author of a paper on the'synthesis theory ', Soupe was awarded the Fondation pour la Méditation de la Societé de Psychologie ( FAP ) prize, for his later contributions to the fields of experimental psychology, psychophysics, and neuropsychology. He also won the C.M.G. Gillman medal for his contribution to genetics, and the Cajal laureate for his contributions to art, literature, and history.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 Essai sur la développement éducation ( The ultimate education ), 1957.  
 Praise d'un solisme, 1957.  
 La vie psychique : trière géométrie, S. 14 ( Paris, 1952 ), 1–24.  
 `` Introduction '' to the Philosophie and Phenomenology of Science, 1967.  
 `` Metaphysiology '', Marcel Proust & Mélanie Siegler, Eds., Essays in Foundations of French Philosophy, Paris, 1971.  
 Autres philosophiques : Sociologie, 2001, ISBN 978-90-57010-02-6  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Reinhard Zeits =  
Reinhard André Zeits ( 1 July 1896 – 11 June 1978 ) was a German psychiatrist, who served as director of the General Hospital of St. Gallen in 1914. He was awarded the Order of the Dannebrog in 1930.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 He was born in Jena, Germany and graduated from the University of Erlangen in 1921. He then moved to Austria and trained as a psychiatrist at the Veterinary Hospital of Breslau ( Dornach ). In 1923, he obtained a place at the General Hospital of St Gallen in St. Gallen. He was promoted to Assistant Director ( 1922–1925 ) and Director ( 1926–1933 ). He was promoted to Director in 1933. Zeits made notable contributions in the field of psychiatry. He specialized in clinical and histological diseases.  
 In addition to his publications and medical lectures, he also wrote widely published medical text books on child psychiatry. Zeits was also a celebrated artist, whose works are still in existence.  
 He died on 11 June 1978 in St. Gallen.  
   
   
 == Honours ==  
 Member of the German Psychiatric Association  
 President of the German Psychiatric Association  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Karl Heinrich Goetsch =  
Karl Heinrich Goetsch ( 1 December 1870 in Halle-Wittenberg – 18 October 1923 in Stuttgart ) was a German entomologist and taxonomist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Goetsch was born in 1871 in Halle-Wittenberg, and studied at the University of Halle. He took a teaching position at the University of Berlin, and in 1894 he accepted a professorship at the University of Wittenberg, and in 1902 became professor there. He also taught in Karlsruhe and in Karlsruhe University College ( of which he was a director ).  
 In 1906 Goetsch was appointed as entomologist at the Collège de France, but was soon promoted to professor. He was made registrar at the Entomological Museum of the United States in 1917, and in 1930 became secretary of the Entomological Society of London.  
 He died in Stuttgart.  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Robert Axelrod =  
Robert Axelrod ( 26 January 1845 – 6 August 1924 ) was a British government official.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Axelrod was born in London on 26 January 1845, the eldest son of Samuel Axelrod, 3rd Baronet, a banker.  
 He graduated from the London School of Economics in 1881 with an MA, under Isaac Newton and in 1893 with an LL.D. He also studied economics at the University of Berlin under Ferdinand von Mueller. At the end of 1898, Axelrod was elected to the Society of Economic Advisors ( SED ). He resigned from the committee in 1904 but returned to the SED in 1905. His reputation at that time was almost as great as that of von Mueller, and Axelrod was also chosen President of the British Association of Technical Engineers in 1907 and President of the London Society of Chemistry in 1913. He was a member of the Institutional Services Committee of the Ministry of Supply and He Ltd., and was Secretary of the Control Committee of the Third Industrial Conference in London in 1911.In 1906, Axelrod, F. H. Holley, and N. C. Sheldon established the International Statistical Institute ( ISI ) in Stockholm, after American scientist Alexander Gibson Caldwell, and in 1914 it was transferred to the West German Federal Republic ( West Germany ). The institute is a source of research and for its members Canada, France, Italy, the United Kingdom, the USA and Russia.In 1936, he was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh.Axelrod died in London on 6 August 1924.  
   
   
 == Publications ==  
 George Strickland ( 1921 ). `` A new measure of average growth in the price of rice ''. Journal of Political Economy. 30 ( 2 ) : 10–14.  
 Robert Axelrod ( 1936 ). `` A test of L. Treadwell's law for temporary interdependence ''. Journal of Political Economy. 40 ( 2 ) : 114–125.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Eugen Hamann =  
Eugen Martin Hamann ( 9 October 1908 in Verona – 25 October 1995 ) was a Dutch mathematician.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 He was born in Verona to an ethnic German family of Protestant church. He graduated from a Dutch high school in the late 1940s.  
 From 1955 to 1966, he worked at the University of Lille, where he graduated with a doctorate in 1957. In 1968 he received the Third and Fourth Christian Theological Primes from the Academy of Sciences in Leiden. From 1966 to 1968, he worked for the Belgian AMVATG under the direction of Michel Flügge at the university of Leuven.  
 In 1970, he was an active member of the Dutch Central Committee for Political Economy.  
   
   
 == Work ==  
 When general equilibrium theory became a mainstream concept, Hamann's approach shifted focus from determining the last mean deviation, and more to determining the distribution of responses to varying business or economic conditions, and his first priority, was the economic effects of business cycles. The studies of thermodynamics to determine the critical role of time series were debated ; now, with stochastic economics, one may hypothesize that a time series can be categorized into `` "normal time '' and `` time series '', with the `` regular time '' characterized by higher predictability and equilibrium, while a time series characterized by random fluctuations can be characterized by higher predictive ability and high variability. In 1974, he and Felix Unger coined the term normal temporal dynamics ( NMT ), to describe the variability found within the NMT distribution when the forecasts presented by individuals, the life-cycle-runoff rules, or human resources, and the dynamic uncertainty principle are combined.  
 The series of parameters, given by Engelmann, per :  
   
   
   
 μ  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Igor Pavlov (as Igor Pavlovskiy ) =  
Igor Ivanovich Pavlov ( born October 4, 1858 in Lyublin ( then Levdunova district, Czarneivka oblast ; then in Przhevalsk District, a Transcaucasia of Sverdlovsk Oblast, the son of Nikolai Pavlovskiy and Anna Maria Pavlovna, and later Nicholas'mother ; in 1897 he joined the Uniates ; died April 17, 1935 in Saint Petersburg ) was a Russian mathematician.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 He studied at the Lyublin State Normal School. The `` Golos '' ( Hebrew name of class, Rigged ) school, is responsible for producing today ’ s School of Solids, also known as the Theoretical and Physical Sciences School. According to Yevgeny Fedorov : `` Some years before, he had been engaged by the superintendent of this school, Mr. M. Vavilov, to introduce to the Russian Hebrew community an ambitious project for obtaining a high level of competence in the theoretical work of the Russian Jewish population. '' `` Fearing a ban of the educational and scientific literature by the government of the Russian Empire, Ivan Pavlov chose not to take up the program. `` After serving several stints in an engineer ’ s office in Samara, under the supervision of Joseph Prof. Ethelberger ( 1871-1921 ) he became a professor at the Physical University of Leningrad ( then a faculty of anatomy, and later department of physiology ). He was instrumental in the reestablishment of the Lenin Institute of Physiology and Physiology of the Russian Academy of Sciences in Leningrad ( 1953 ), where he remained until his retirement in 1962. His most notable students were Anatoly C3 A0minov and M. G. Bogatyrsky.  
 Pavlov worked extensively on field theory and the chemical basis of shock resistance. He and fellow pathologist Josef Basaglia conducted research on oxygen in the retina.  
   
   
 == Selected bibliography ==  
 I. I. Pavlov : `` Report of a study of respiration in the animal wing of a feeding rabbit. '' Physiol. Ped. 8 ( 4 ) : 2335–35 ( 1913 ).  
 I. I. Pavlov : `` Pathological studies of higher oesophageal epithelia in the ileum of rodents. '' Physiol. Ped. 10 ( 2 ) : 185–87 ( 1912 ).  
 I. I. Pavlov : `` Report of a study of respiration of the rabbit following a regimen of ether in a fire chamber. '' Physiol. Ped. 13 ( 1 ) : 3–15 ( 1913 ).  
 I. I. Pavlov : `` Changes of oxygen-saturated solutions in the urine of treated animals. '' Physiol. Ped. 16 ( 1 ) : 65–7 ( 1914 ).  
 I. I. Pavlov : `` I. I. Pavlov : How cats feel. '' L ’ Assoc. Exerc. Physiol. Mass. Educ. 3 ( 1 ) : 52–5 ( 1915 ).  
 I. I. Pavlov : `` Diagnoses of deep bacterial tumors of the anterior segment of the gastrointestinal tract. '' Mitteilungen der Physiol. Anat. Naturwissenschaften. 2 ( 1 ) : 39–55 ( 1916 ).  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Friedrich Ludwig Klopfer =  
Friedrich Ludwig Klopfer ( April 20, 1859 in Molsa, Ural, Russia – July 25, 1943 in Strasbourg, France ) was a German botanist and ethnographer.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Klopfer was born in Molsa in northern Russia ( now Ukraine ), now part of the Russian Empire. He graduated from the State Agriculture University in 1884. After working on an expeditions in the Arctic and the North American West he obtained the degree of Bachelor of Sciences in zoology from the University of Strasbourg in 1890. He became an academician ( in 1886 ) and professor ( in 1899 ) of botany and ethnology at the State Agriculture University.  
   
   
 == Works ==
