 With Max Rodenberger he published several textbooks, and a journal, on botany and ethnology, the former of which is currently out of print.  
   
 The latest publications include a series of biographies of L. V. Ingabayev, F. A. Belousov, and L. V. R. Segev, two Siberian ethnographic adventurers who crossed the Ice Age in the 1890s and already established an important knowledge base on Native American plants.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Ernst Bloch =  
Ernst Bernhard Bloch ( 1 July 1904 – 29 November 1984 ) was an Austrian-American mathematical physicist.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Ernst Bloch was born in Vienna, Austria on 1 July 1904 to Ernst Bloch, a chemist, and Eugenia Shoenberg. He attended the Jesuit seminary in Düsseldorf from 1919 to 1923, and graduated in 1925 from the Göttingen Electrotechnische University, which was later renamed the University of Göttingen.Bloch received his doctoral degree from the University of Munich in 1926 and then joined the faculty of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology ( MIT ) in Cambridge, Massachusetts, where he stayed until his retirement in 1950. In 1952, he became a professor of experimental physics at the United States Naval Research Laboratory, Mersenne, New Hampshire, which now is part of the National Accelerator Laboratory.In his published works, he served as a research associate to geophysicist John Wilkins, along with Josef Strauss and Sergei Glinka. Among his other students were Georgy Alekseevich Pachachanov, Wilfried Kurtz, and Richard E. Wolk. In the 1940s he led efforts to develop the microwave cavity, and, more recently, the foundation of computers.Bloch was the author of the pioneer monograph on the nature of low-temperature oscillators, and the 1945 and 1946 book, The Physics of Radio Waves. He published the Operational Theory of High-Temperature Resonance Fields for Working Groups, and is credited with coining the term `` high-temperature ''. His books dealt with all the major topics in optics, acoustics, magnetism, and metamaterials, and included works on pressure waves in liquids, metal alloys, metal alloys in solids, aether, spectroscopy, and other mathematical problems. His textbooks on physics have been translated into English, German, Italian, and Spanish. He is now especially remembered for his work in ferromagnetism and photovoltaics, one of the pioneers of superconductivity. Bloch was also an expert on X-ray crystallography and optical imaging. He died in Cambridge, Massachusetts.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Reinhard G C3 BCller =  
Reinhard Güller ( 14 August 1904 – 6 June 1991 ) was a German bacteriologist and geneticist who published more than 300 scientific articles. He is considered to be one of the major fathers of gerontology.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Güller was born on 14 August 1904 at the Kirchhain-Kern she was educated at the theological gymnasium. He began his research in biological chemistry at the University of Karlsruhe from 1921 and transferred to the Gymnasium der deutschen Hochschule in Berlin, where he remained from 1925 to 1938. During the Second World War he taught courses at the Technische Hochschule in Berlin, where he worked as an assistant to Ernst Haeckel, and the Ruhr bacteriological institute.  
 Güller's main interests and influences are Karl Hermann Erich von Hippel ( 1893–1959 ) and his disciple Friedrich Gerhard Dietrich von Seidenhammer ( 1883–1950 ). His significant publications included :  
   
 Reichszüge des organismen Regens... Nachrichten von Wilhelm Löwin ( 1954 )  
 Optik der biologicalorganismen... Erinnerungen von Ignaz Rieger ( 1925 )  
 Biologische Betrachtungen der Urt. Einschluss der Biologie. Über die Anatomie der Demorphologie ( 1950 ).  
   
   
 == Selected works ==  
 Entwicklungen der acid-resorptionen oder intensierten Erkehrkunde. Zu ausdruckten. Ein Wissenschaftslehre der Deutschen Gesellschaft, Band 5, Königsberg 1936  
 Zum untersuchungen über die sehrlichten Blutscher Zaaligen der Epplerwirkung des Pfalz ( Rieger, F., 1906 )  
 Die Epplerwirkung des Pfalz, Felsen und Ebinger ( Güller, 1927 )  
 Berichte der europäischen Lebensprozeß der wahre Lebensproblem ( 1931 )  
 Funktion der Amerika : europäischen Skrifteriensorganisation der Gotthardtraum ( 1936 )  
 Naturwissenschaftliche Ersterung der römischen Haus ( Rieger, 1938 )  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = L'Ami Loquastère =  
L'Ami Loquastère ( 2 February 1844 in Sylvan, France – 10 January 1922 in Paris ) was a French composer. His music includes the symphonic César Franck and two operas.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Loquastère was born in Sylvan ( his father was a teacher ) in the province of Brittany, and educated at Saint-Denis de Languedoc, Cambrai.  
 He became a prose writer. He left prose writing in 1878, to become a professor of musicology at the Paris Conservatoire. In 1880 he founded and in 1881-1882 presided over the periodical Music at the Carnival. His last memoir, published in 1891, was entitled Description de l'éducation général. He died at Paris on 10 January 1922.  
 Loquastère is commemorated on an island in the Bay of Biscay, Réunion.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Harold Poulton =  
Harold Poulton ( December 31, 1884 – June 8, 1964 ) was an American economic statistician. He served as professor of public policy at Vanderbilt University and as director of the Office of Budget Research at the U.S. Treasury. He was also one of the leading intellectual proponents of private sector finance of public works, and published many books on the subject. Poulton received many awards for his work, such as an honorary doctorate from Wellesley College and the President's Award from the Ohio Conference of Economic Advisors.He was a graduate of the University of Chicago and attended the University of Berlin. He also held a Rhodes Scholarship at Leipzig University from 1915–18, and the Roffey Medal from the American Economic Association from 1919.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Marie Louise Nel =  
Marie Louise Nel ( January 12, 1853 – April 22, 1938 ) was a Scottish botanist. She was a British chemist and nuclear chemist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 She was born on January 12, 1853 at Portaberry, Fife and educated at Albert College, Oxford and the University of Edinburgh. She earned her doctorate in botany at the University of Edinburgh in 1882.  
 In 1887 she became assistant to Robert MacKinnon at the Scottish Department of Agriculture and worked on the domestic production of morphine in London. In 1891 she went to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to work as a lecturer in cytology. In 1913 she married Donald Eddy Norwood.  
 In 1918 she was elected a fellow of the Royal Society. She was a friend of Nicolaas A. Hooker and John Stevenson and helped him study the microorganisms which form `` edible plants ''.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Gordon Donnelley =  
Gordon Donnelley ( 22 May 1916 – 13 November 1988 ) was a prolific author who wrote well over 500 scientific articles.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 He was born in Grange, in the East Riding of Yorkshire, England, to Betty Mary ( Whetstone ) Donnelley and R. J. Donnelley. His father was a grain farmer, his mother was a lay preacher. His brother Tony Donnelly became an academic and later president of Trinity College, Cambridge. He worked in the general laboratory for the British Institute of Mining Engineers and was the first holder of the Henry Mead Award for theoretical physics by the International Union of Pure and Applied Physics.  
 Donnelley became Professor of Applied Mathematics at Cambridge in 1955 and Professor of Experimental Physics in 1962. In 1965 he was awarded the Fields Medal of the Royal Society. In 1970 he founded the Society for Advanced Study, and he also served as chairman of the COSSAAS ( Council of Societies for Scientific Analysis ) in 1983.  
 In 1974 he was awarded the Order of the British Empire for his contributions to mathematics. He was elected to the Order of the British Empire in 1970.  
 He married Valerie Bevans ( 1888–1988 ).  
 Donnelley retired in 1988, but continued his writing. He died in Cambridge.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Ren C5 82evi C5 84tw C5 84 =  
Renđević Tdušović ( 6 December 1928 in Jadlava – 12 February 2004 ) was a Croatian economist and a conservative philosopher. He is the author of the economic and political system called Socialist Unity or The Essence of Democracy, a critique of left-wing politics. According to Dori Zernicka, a professor at the London School of Economics, the book has an impact as it does not meet with much reception because it does not criticize mainstream economics ; nevertheless, because of its influence, the political and social implications of its vision of the future were elaborated by many prominent liberals such as Winston Churchill, Josip Broz Tito, Leon Trotsky, James Mill,, Jürgen Habermas, Joan Robinson, Elizabeth Fitch, Joachim Fischer, Rudolf Rocker, Alexander Goedel, Sir Max Kropotkin, Jean-Paul Sartre and Adolphe Massieu.  
 Renđević was a Marxist and among his mentors was Rudolf Fichte. A Marxist who was ideologically aligned with the New Left, he was one of the founders of Zizek's anti-theory movement and a critic of Nazism. In 1919 he made a common demand for an economic reform that would transform Yugoslavia from an autocracy to a state-controlled economy with a market economy. It has been argued that the economics of Renđević made him influential in some of the more radical groups of early twentieth-century left-wing Europe.  
 Renđević was a leading voice in the education and research of Slovenian political economist and communist Karl Klimentsov. He believed that education in the schools should be free of political indoctrination. He was an active part of the Yugoslav World Front, and was present at the invasion of Austria, Bosnia, Kosovo, and Abkhazia in the summer of 1945.  
 Renđević was a native of Stanko, Hricnik county, Yugoslavia. He received his Habilitation from the Slovenian state university in Yugoslavia. He then went to Zagreb and was awarded a PhD from the Slovenian University of Sciences ( KsiLod ) in Zagreb. In 1948 he moved to Strasbourg, in 1958 he joined the faculty of the University of Brussels where he became professor emeritus in 1960. In 1982, he returned to the university of St. Gallen.  
   
   
 == Political views ==  
 Renđević is thought to have been influenced by such diverse figures as Jacobin Samuel de Wolff, Károly Stošča, Immanuel Kant, Ludwig von Mises, Oscar Pareto, Benjamin Tucker, Karl Marx, and Leopold Kruse. He also studied the writings of the classical economist Niccolò Machiavelli. In reaction to the war in Yugoslavia, Renđević drafted an opposition to the war. He believed that a victory was possible only through a `` democratic dictatorship '' that would be based on national autonomy and strong states.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 Nenocidci school : Štičnar o razvza nadavđnti ( Free Education, Privatization ), Hodosko, 1993.  
 Wogenbecci, T. ; Wehlova, A. ; & Renđević, R. Idomnica ( Language of Mind, Crisis in the Religious World, Finally Liberation ), 2004.  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Harold Forrest (botanist) =  
Harold Forrest ( 3 July 1837 – 9 July 1942 ) was a botanist, who held research positions in New Zealand.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 He was born in Wellington on 3 July 1837 and died at Langley on 9 July 1942. He was an aunt to the artist Mungo Park and her daughter, the artist Maybourne Park.He was educated at Wellington Grammar School and established a botany and horticulture business before heading for New Zealand. He was an early advocate for the use of overseas sources for New Zealanders to obtain information about botany. He was a keen gardener, and in particular his bequest of plants to the government of New Zealand enabled the establishment of the Orkney Botanic Garden in 1930.In 1875, he was chosen by the Admiralty to establish a five-year research station at Atayere, the first working overseas botanic garden in New Zealand. The service took him to the United Kingdom, France, the Netherlands, India, and Japan. He participated in the founding of the Museum of Botany at the British Museum in New York and he died in the US.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 In 1882 he published a twelve volume work on the botany of North America which was extensively revised and republished in 1927 as Roots of Flora of New Zealand. He collaborated with the long-time botanical illustrator William Holland and the botanist Peter Merriam.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Edward Rice (mineralogist) =  
Sir Edward Rice, FRS ( 16 December 1868 – 23 September 1939 ) was a Scottish botanist and mineralogist.  
   
   
 == Early life ==  
 Rice was born on 16 December 1868 at Wavertree, but his father persuaded his mother to let him go to Cambridge University. He was admitted in 1891, and his thesis was On the structure and petrology of gyrite, mineral, and the sediments of South Wales. In the same year he married Anna Drysdale of Odon nGwy. He became a naturalist, lecturer, and director of the National Museum of Wales ( from 1906 to 1912 ). He also became a Professor of Mineralogy and Botany at Trinity College, Dublin.  
 Rice was a favourite pupil of Drysdale and helped her in developing the Drysdale collection.In 1911, he married Katherine Browne, daughter of William Browne, prebendary of Luggar and Arthour, in the parish of Bangor. The couple later had two sons and a daughter.  
   
   
 == Publications ==  
 He published mineralogical studies in the Manchester Journal and the Belfast Mining and Gemological Journal. Rice also contributed to the journals N. M. Drysdale ’ s, A. F. Browne's and the Belfast and Scrydenan Mineralogical Club.He was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society in 1909.In 1911, he was elected a foreign member of the Geological Society of London.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 `` The possible occurrence of trace in fossils : a tentative date from Lochinver ''. Journal of the British Association for the Advancement of Science. ( in Irish ). 6 ( 2 ) : 117–170. March 1912.  
 Proceedings of the meetings of the Geological Society of London. Proceedings of the Royal Society of London, Series A, Volume 148, Issue 1 ( Winter 1911 ), pp. 380–387.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Franz Ferdinand Ullendorf =  
Franz Ferdinand Ullendorf ( ; born on May 28, 1867 in Weitingen, Germany, died 2 March 1949 in Munich, Germany ) was a German mathematics professor who worked as the editor of the Russian Mathematical Magazine from 1918 to 1940, under the direction of Georg Marguerite Rosenberg.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Ullendorf was born into a wealthy family. He studied at the Tübingen University, receiving his doctorate in 1893, and teaching for a few years at the University of Tübingen. He lectured at Tübingen until 1897, when he accepted an appointment at the University of Berlin. He remained in Berlin until 1894, and then moved to Munich to become a professor of mathematics there.  
   
   
 === Cambridge ===  
   
 Ullendorf taught at the University of Cambridge from 1898 until his retirement in 1925. In 1924, he and Emil Godowsky published a comprehensive textbook on the theory of the real numbers, entitled Mathematical Theory of Number Theory ( Göttingen : Hermann Götting, 1925 ). In 1927, he became editor of the journal Mathematical Research.  
 In 1916, Ullendorf was elected a fellow of the Royal Society. In addition to his work on real number theory, he wrote numerous articles for a regular periodical, Deutsche Mathematiker Neue Berücksichtigung.  
 He held the chair of mathematics at the University of Munich from 1922 to 1923 and at the University of Berlin from 1922 to 1936. Ullendorf died on March 2, 1949, in Munich.  
   
   
 == Selected works ==  
 Anachtenmittelung in den Versuch einer theoretischen Untersuchungen eines einfachtragen der Einfachern der ( Linear ) Dirichlet zu den neuen Aufgaben der Kaltennierung ; 11 volumes ( Leipzig : Hans Christian Jacob, 1881–82 )  
 Mathematische Untersuchungen zur Zeitsgemeinschaften des Muksurvollers ( 1918 )  
 Homotopy theory ; essays ( Vienna : Carl Agassiz, 1906 )  
 A descriptive approach to combinatorial topology ( Florence : Franco Proco, 1907 )  
 Die Leben von Feynman ( 1900 )  
 Mathematical theory of number theory ; 3 volumes ( 1898–1905 )  
 Topology : algebraic geometry and topological topology ( Cambridge, England : Cambridge University Press, 1959 )  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Mikhail M. Maksimov =  
Mikhail Aleksandrovich Mezhizhnikov ( Ukrainian : Алекса́ндр Лейхимович Наси́мов ; 19 January 1871 – 18 February 1954 ) was a Ukrainian composer, music theorist, music educator, and editor. He died of lung cancer at the age of 82 in Selly Oak, Georgia in 1954.  
   
   
 == Early life and education ==  
 Mikhail Mikhail Mezhizhnikov was born on 19 January 1871 in the Russian Selly Oak village of Kutais, Transcaucasia, Russian Empire, now in Ukraine. He attended the Kutais Opera and Chamber Music School and, during the 1902–1906 holidays, pursued music studies in Moscow with L. A. Markov. In 1909 he won the participation in the competition held in Moscow to represent the Vasily Novikov-lucina concertos by recording them in the Akademiy Pravda.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 He was introduced to the Russian musical movement during the First World War by his uncle L. A. Markov. From 1924 to 1927 he taught at the Moscow Conservatory. In 1928, he became assistant director at the Conservatory. He published the quarterly `` Musici ergo '' under the pen-name of Peter Mcparash. In 1929 he began work on a new textbook of his own titled `` Arrangementos orthogonalis and orthogonoposias in tretes '' under the pseudonym of Hermann Waldgerd. In 1930, he was named professor of pedagogy at Moscow Conservatory. His students included Haydn Herzen, Szymon Tonon, Victor Lazarev, and Andrei Zverev. As a composer, Mezhizhnikov focused on instrumentalism. The subject of his compositions was equal parts varied, however, and the focus was often to preserve the traditions of the Armenian folk music.  
 Mezhizhnikov's interpretation of the ancient Russian folk music was that of Soviet folk music. The music is strongly influenced by early Russian dance music. His major pupil in the early 20th century was Konstantin Tsevko, a student of his in Moscow. Tsevko expressed, through his work, Mezhizhnikov's desire to honor the spirituality and musical integrity of these traditions.  
   
   
 === Mezhizhnikov's Theory of Intonation ===  
 Mezhizhnikov developed, to a remarkable extent, an idea that influenced the music theory of Ukrainian composers in the 1930s and 1940s, namely that of intonation. He taught that intonation refers to the harmonic qualities of a musical piece relative to the pitch of its original instrument, most especially the pitch at which the intonation first appears in the piece.Mezhizhnikov considered intonation to be a function of distance. The more distant, the larger the musical consonants in the string and the lower pitch of the vibrato. More distant consonants are more difficult to vocalize. The correct intonation for a piece of music is then a function of the distance from the original instrument to the upper or the middle register.  
 Based on the equal measure rule, the formula he developed for determining intonation, now known as the Mezhizhnikov formula, states :  
   
   
 F = F ( S )  
   
   
   
   
 S  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = August Heinrich Gallus =  
August Heinrich Gallus ( 15 April 1752, Silesien, West Prussia – 20 April 1803, Zurich ) was a West German entomologist.  
 Gallus'academic work focused mainly on Diptera, Formicidae and Coleoptera. He described 17 species of butterflies and the larvae of a number of butterflies. He also described 43 subspecies of Coleoptera, including new and returning butterflies.  
 Gallus ’ father was Hans Gallus ( 1711–1775 ) and mother was Adelheid. Both parents were physicians and served as foreign consuls at Nuremberg in 1745. August was reared at home by his uncle and uncle ’ s father ; his family used to call him Leiläu. From 1756 he was a deputy at the Imperial Prussian Institute, where he supervised the Anatomy Laboratory. In 1767 he was named a doctor of medicine.  
 His collection of butterflies is in the Schwazüge Museum and collections of Lepidoptera and Formicidae in the Natural History Museum in Hamburg, and the Hendrik Stielert collection at the Natural History Museum in Münster are also in the Schwazüge Museum.  
   
   
 == Eponymy ==  
 He was the namesake of the genus Gallusia, a taxonomic classification of new-flowering forms of Lepidoptera.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Murray W. Bailey =  
Murray William Bailey ( 12 June 1888 – 14 March 1971 ) was a New Zealand statistician.  
 He is perhaps best known for his book On the Funeral of the Deputy Lieutenant-Governor of New Zealand and Injuries to Civilians during Occupation of New Zealand during 1919–1924 and his investigations in the aftermath of the Second World War.  
   
   
 == Early life ==  
 Bailey was born at Wellington on 12 June 1888. His father, Joseph Bernard Bailey, was a printer and printer's apprentice. He was educated at Christchurch College and then the University of Wellington.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 In 1923, Bailey went to England to do lecturing. He became a lecturer at the University of London and joined the staff of the Statistical Office and an employee of the City of London Statistical Institute.  
 He became senior lecturer in statistics in 1931, and deputy principal of St George's College and Associate Director of the London office. He held these posts until 1954. Bailey was appointed to chair the Statistical Council in 1934.  
 From 1948 to 1952 he was president of the Mathematical Society of New Zealand.The President of the Statistical Council from 1952 to 1959 was professor Greg Maclachlan. He held the post from 1960 to 1963.  
 In 1965, the Auckland Mathematical Society granted him the Golden Jubilee Medal.  
 Bailey was a member of the Auckland Council from 1960 to 1963.  
   
   
 == Commemoration ==  
   
 On 9 June 1972 the Medical Times commemorated his 70th birthday and he was named New Zealander of the Year. He was an unofficially-acclaimed politician.  
   
   
 == Published works ==  
 Human Exposure to Coal, 1933.  
 Pest Management and Coal Fires, 1934.  
 Coal Production in the Northland, 1935.  
 Coal Fires and Low Temperature, 1938.  
 A Study of Dental Problems in the Towns and Nottawa Railways, 1939.  
 Air Pollution and Air Quality, 1942.  
 A test of a hydraulic steam hydraulic press ( September 1952 ).  
 An Experimental Approach to Coal and Iron Mining, 1943.  
 Australian Operations, 1944.  
 Part-Time Work in the Mines ( ANZMIN conference ), 1945.  
 Coal Cost Estimates : a General Accounting Review, 1946.  
 Managing Coal ( ANZMIN conference ), 1947.  
 Mining Act Requirements, 1952.  
 Energetic Geology ( 1969 ), a Dictionary of Mapping, an Authoritative Dictionary of Mapping : New Zealand compiled by Dr. David Stephenson.  
 Use of Digesters and Roadways in Acclimatization and Transit, 1953.  
 The Greenhouse, 1955.  
 The Transformation of Australasia ( 2002 ) by H. A. Hamilton.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Augustin Dalsgaard =  
Augustin James Denis Dalsgaard ( 20 September 1851 in Ghent – 3 April 1939 ) was a Belgian chemist, named as the inventor of pyridine synthesis and whose group of noble gases, the C/N hydrogen bond, is the basis for the modern distinction between the fission and fusion processes.  
 His interest in natural science began when his grandfather Alfred and sister Marguerite introduced him to Benjamin Franklin in the school on the Bergen Amt, where they taught chemistry and astronomy.  
 In the 1860s he worked as a patent agent, and for two years he headed a government commission in Russia. In 1873 he was elected president of the Belgian Association of Mathematics and Science. He was Professor of Geophysics at the University of Bruges, from 1876 to 1879 and 1879 to 1880.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Antonio Theodorus Vincenzetti =  
Antonio Theodorus Vincenzetti ( 1809–1893 ) was an Italian Roman Catholic bishop and canonist who served as rector of Osteria di Savona in Pietro Ceruzzi's diocese in Osteria and Diocletian's diocese in Rome.  
 Vincenzetti was the son of the Italian Jesuit and theologian Girolamo Vincenzetti. He was ordained a priest in 1822, but was suspended by the Vatican in 1834, following theological disputes with Lorenzo Maggi. During this period he also served as bishop of Pietro di Santa Marta, Osteria di Savona. From 1854 until his death in 1893 he also held the papal habilitation, again in Rome. He was canon of Osteria di Sant'Otto in Osteria, and of Osteria di San Severo in Rome.  
 Vincenzetti died in Rome on 11 December 1893, aged 79. His monument is located in his diocese's cathedral, Osteria di Sant'Otto.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 Vincenzetti published over 200 works and mainly sermons. The sermons on which he wrote include :  
   
 Sionis de luce volundum edificio in diversi Antiquità.  
 Ordinario del sacra travatori di Fausti, sacraminenti, quæ mi ventantur anno 1962, in pariventi  
 Nuove, orosi, priore eis sole filiali sopra, in factella sive e di Giambattista Cesi infestare mai mo. Avec vita piana ( Dr. Fornari, In 2 serm. Roma, 1969. 16 col. )  
 Istituto suo clericico della ritrovazione Cepha-Plana — Internazionale Franco-Italiano — Giuseppe Sannino : Ordinario del catholico nationale della Società Società di Storia Ecumenica e Sant'Angelo di Osteria, Giornale ( 67 : anno 1969 ).  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = John F. Donatello =  
John Francis Donatello ( August 12, 1910 – January 17, 1995 ) was an American economist and politician who served in the United States House of Representatives from Texas. He was a strong supporter of student loans, particularly for Ph.D. students, and was active in congressional oversight of higher education. He is considered a founder of the multi-party system of government.  
   
   
 == Life and career ==  
 He was born in Princeton, New Jersey, to John Donatello and Erlis McClintock ( née Klein ). He graduated with a Bachelor of Arts in 1938 from Iowa State University, earning a Master of Science degree in economics from Stanford University in 1943. He later earned a Ph.D. from Iowa State University. Donatello served in the US Navy, where he was a lieutenant commander in the Pacific during World War II, where he was caught up in the Pacific Campaign in San Francisco Bay. In 1943, he was awarded the Congressional Gold Medal. He returned to Iowa State University to earn his Ph.D. in economics.  
 He returned to the United States to become the assistant director of economic analysis for the Under Secretary of the Navy's Bureau of Ships from 1952 to 1954. This post provided him with the opportunity to work closely with the then Secretary of State James A. Garfield on Navy policy issues, and it gave him the opportunity to compare wartime military strategy with wartime economic policies. He worked as a political adviser to Republican Congressmen of the era, and later served as the first Chief Economic Advisor to President Gerald Ford. Donatello's memoirs Are You Happy Here? became one of the most influential books of the 20th century, and was published in 1998.  
 In 1955, Donatello accepted a position as director of the Russell Sage Foundation, an institution funded by the American Research and Development Administration ( ARDA ), one of the federal agencies charged with scientific research. ARDA spent $ 500,000 a year on research and development at the time, and Donatello was tasked with supporting the project's administrative, technical, and fundraising priorities. He remained with the project until 1976.  
 After serving as a senior adviser to President Jimmy Carter, Donatello joined President George H. W. Bush's administration as assistant secretary of labor. During this time, he shifted gears and directed the Office of Personnel Management. He was the first director of the Office of Personnel Management and he remained there until 1986.  
   
   
 == Educational legacy ==  
 Donatello was instrumental in creating the federal Student Loan Forgiveness Program. The first installment, which funded students from 1982 to 1986, was the largest of its kind. Donatello founded and served on the federal commission on student loans that negotiated the President's 1980 plan to eliminate student loan interest rates. After the program was established, he spent the next several years developing the Financial Aid Compensation System ( FSA CS ) and working to expand the possibility of assisting students with loans. The president, in 1980, introduced the first federal student loan guarantee program as the Priede Permanente Plan. In 1990, he joined the board of trustees of the American Association of University Women, which he chaired until 2001.  
   
   
 == Death and legacy ==  
 John F. Donatello died on January 17, 1995, at the age of 84 in Dallas, Texas, from prostate cancer. He was survived by his daughter Anne, his granddaughter Susan, and his three grandchildren. He was survived by his wife of more than a half-century, Ann Martin-Donatello.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Pedro de Passa =  
Pedro de Passa ( 1629–1693 ), was an Argentinian physicist, author, educator, mathematician, physicist, naturalist, educator, engineer, naturalist, mineralogist, meteorologist, explorer, cartographer, pharmacist, general and layperson of a number of international and regional honors and awards.  
 Born at Paris, he was the son of Maria de Passa and Francesco de Sà, a musician, during his early years. His grandmother, Margaret de Passa ( born in Rome ), was a notable astronomer. In 1661, he accompanied her brother Poggio to Chile, where he learned how to build telescopes at the age of sixteen.  
 Between 1660 and 1662, he studied at the École Polytechnique and the École Polytechnique des Inscriptions et Belles-Lettres, graduating in 1665. His studies started in the composition of mathematical equations. He also became the tutor of the young Poggio de Zuniga, becoming the pupil of his future brother, Francesco, a physicist. He showed great interest in astronomy, and he was made a member of the Academia Nuova Academia Belvedere, in 1672, the year after his father died.  
 Returning to Chile, he died at Santiago, on May 16, 1693, at the age of 76. His tomb lies in the Quirigua neighborhood.  
   
   
 == Publications ==  
 de la sigillagia tecnica ( 1684 )  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Theodor Z C3 BCllendorf =  
Theodor Zöllendorf ( 28 September 1814, Kirch-Buch – 23 January 1882, Berlin ) was a German philosopher and professor of theology at the University of Berlin. His mother Elisabeth published him a biography and his brother Ferdinand was his son-in-law. He wrote an account of the chief beliefs of the ancient Catholic Church and served as Bishop of Trier.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Zöllendorf was born in Trier, Germany. In the year 1820, as the middle of the Civil War, he joined the University of Heidelberg. The first few years were extremely hard for him, especially as he was forced to miss his seminary classes and forges, while he struggled with debilitating case of tuberculosis. At the end of the war, however, he was able to obtain a liberal education in the University of Göttingen. He then went to Freiburg, and at the request of his uncle, the Archbishop of Freiburg, he received a public benefice of € 5,000 for three years, which enabled him to learn various languages.  
 In 1842, he became a professor of theology at the University of Berlin, but not the University of Freiburg. That university was located in the under-developed region of the German frontier, and so it had little scope for such a person. In the event, at the instigation of a friend ( whose name was not disclosed ), Zöllendorf obtained a medical doctorate from the University of Freiburg for 17 and a half years, and he entered upon a literary and other preoccupations.  
 During this period, he also devoted himself to the study of Catholicism in his school ( `` Des Herrnfassungs-Verbreitungschule '' ) of the University of Berlin. He was, however, an atheist, who, despite his training, could never understand the philosophy and the nature of Christianity. In 1846, after having long suspected the cause, he gave up all religious discussion. With the creation of the Protestant theologian Friedrich von Ruitzel, he resolved to profess another religion : with Ruitzel he took the thesis of the necessity of distinction, in which he fully rejected the belief in the equal unity of all things, and in which he explicitly and especially refuted the theory of God. In 1849, he formed a religious union with the Protestant preacher Ernst Müller, and became an honorary member of the `` Christus Arbeitenbarkeit '' ( movement for the strengthening of Christian morality ) at Berlin. During his many travels in the speaking countries he visited Persia and Mongolia.  
 In 1859 he was elected to a sub-ratio of membership of the Prussian Academy of Sciences. Here he founded and conducted for twenty years the theological seminary. There he wrote almost four hundred sermons, which formed the basis of all later works of theologians such as Bernd Fränkel ( 1833–1882 ), Heinrich Hildebrandt ( 1833–1885 ), Johann Gottlieb Westermann ( 1833–1886 ), Julius Herrmann ( 1847–1927 ) and Robert Schwalbach ( 1867–1923 ).  
   
 In Berlin, and at St. Michael's church in Silesia, he wrote a voluminous, never-published autobiography, `` Professor Zöllendorf. `` In 1863 he gave his last lectures in Berlin, in the presence of the ministers of the Society for the Propagation of the Gospel and the St. Peter's chapel.  
 He died in Berlin on 23 January 1882, having been 82 years of age.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = David Porter Jordan =  
David Porter Jordan ( January 18, 1929 – August 15, 1998 ) was a theoretical physicist who taught at Johns Hopkins University from 1961 until his death in 1998, having taken the University's classical-theoretical physics major under the direction of Ray Lankester.  
   
   
 == Early life ==  
 David Porter Jordan was born in Hinsdale, Massachusetts on January 18, 1929, the eldest of four sons of the lawyer and businessman Stanley Jordan and Rachel Mandelein Jordan. Jordan's family was originally from the Limerick family, who settled in Massachusetts and later lived in Long Beach, California. At the age of fourteen, Jordan began studying electricity under the supervision of Fred Thomas. Jordan first completed his Bachelor of Arts degree in 1940 under Ray Lankester, and a Master of Science degree in Physics under Thomas in 1945 under the direction of Ernest Lawrence. Jordan completed his Ph.D. in 1950 under Lawrence, and returned to the Johns Hopkins faculty in 1951 under Lankester, continuing to work with Lawrence's collaboration with Ernest Lawrence. Jordan was awarded an honorary doctorate from New York University in 1952. During the 1950s, Jordan was a noted faculty member and Reader in Experimental Physics. During his seven years at Johns Hopkins, Jordan remained an active member of the mathematical and experimental physics department, and was known as `` a respected teacher ''. Jordan was the Dean of the Mathematics Department in 1962 and retired in 1984. In 1984, the American Mathematical Society awarded Jordan the Ray Lankester Memorial Prize, in recognition of his `` significant contributions to mathematics '' in his 30 years of teaching and teaching programs. Jordan was also a member of the US National Academy of Sciences and the National Academy of Engineering. He died on August 15, 1998, in Johns Hopkins Hospital, of a heart attack, from complications related to kidney disease.  
   
   
 == Academic career ==  
 Jordan entered the Department of Mathematics and Astronomy at Johns Hopkins in 1961. He was awarded a baccalaureate in 1967, and PhD in 1970 under Ray Lankester. He joined the Laboratory of Computational Optics under Ernest Lawrence in the same year, and the Laboratory of Physics under James Hammer in 1971. During this time, he was Associate Professor of Mathematics and Astronomy, and served as a visiting professor. Jordan's seminar work was not always fruitful for the subject matter, however, particularly in the mathematical physics department. Jordan's major work that bears his name concerned the development of the Lankester–Dahler theory. During Jordan's time as professor, the mathematical physics department at Johns Hopkins ( known as the Delmonico–Jordan Complex ) became the center for research in structural physics, specifically nuclear physics. Jordan would later leave the group because he found a primary concern to be the continuation of Lawrence's work.  
 Jordan's graduate student contribution in the mathematical physics department was Donald Beisstein, who became one of the best-known and most influential theoretical physicists of the 1960s and 1970s. Beisstein would go on to be the Director of the Joint Center for Computational Physics at the MIT.  
 Jordan served as Assistant Professor in both Mathematics and Astronomy until 1971. He returned to the Computer Science Department in 1971, and became the first full-time teaching physicist at Johns Hopkins. Jordan held the chair of the Mathematics Department until his retirement in 1988.  
 Jordan moved from Johns Hopkins to the Institute for Advanced Study in the Behavioral Sciences in 1990 and taught there until his retirement in 1996, completing a dissertation in the area of finite element models of decision problems.  
 Jordan's work was cited in a 1976 article in the `` Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences '' by Lankester, which highlighted Jordan's contribution to the development of computational physics. Lankester, who was known for his creative philosophy as a teacher, often said that Jordan's philosophy was akin to Newton's, and the two men were on the same page.  
 The role of the Institute for Advanced Study in computational physics is primarily to stimulate research and development of techniques that will improve our understanding of the physics of systems and forces.  
 Jordan was a member of the National Academy of Engineering and the National Academy of Sciences. He was a fellow of the American Physical Society, the American Mathematical Society, and the American Association for the Advancement of Science.  
   
   
 == Achievements ==  
 Jordan authored or co-authored more than 150 scientific papers and authored a book on statistical physics.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Johan August Neij =  
Johan August Neij ( born 1938, Helsinki, Finland, 21 January 1966 ) was a Finnish lawyer, policy expert and scholar on European issues. He served as Foreign Minister of the People's Republic of Finland from 1971 to 1984, and as Minister of Finance from 1986 to 1992.  
   
   
 == Background ==  
 Neij was born in Helsinki, Finland in 1938. He had two brothers and two sisters, and grew up in Marti in Jussu, Finland, and Hultin in Kjos, Sweden. He studied from 1960 to 1965 at the University of Helsinki, where he also had a summer scholarship. During his stay at the university, he met his future wife, Tamara Michalij, a music teacher. Together they started a family and had three daughters. They worked as art historians at the central Helsinki University ( 1968–70, 1971–73 ) and as professors at Aalborg University ( 1973–75 ) and the Center for International Law in Helsinki ( 1975–76 ). In 1977, he became foreign minister.  
   
   
 == President of European Council and of the Council of the Nordic Councils ==  
 On May 7, 1989, Neij was elected to the European Council and the Council of the Nordic Councils. Together with the Swedish MEP Aurivaldo Calcano, he voted against membership of the Single European Market and European Free Trade Association ( EFTA ). On April 22, 1990, the Council agreed to neuter EFTA's membership.In May 1991, the Council held a series of meetings, starting in the Netherlands, in which Neij addressed the issues concerning European issues. During the discussions, he announced that the Council would soon hold its first general summit, with responsibility for the passage of the Treaty of Rome as the main topic. As one of the few people of whom a majority of the Council approved the Alliance, the decision to give up the Nordic model in favor of a single European social and economic architecture, was not popular, although the majority of those present approved it.On September 13, 1991, he was elected President of the European Council and the Council of the Nordic Councils ( the Council elected under Chapter 7 of the Treaty of Amsterdam ). He served as chairman of the Presidency of the Council. He retired on September 15, 1998.  
   
   
 == Awards ==  
 Heinrich Böhmer Memorial Scholarship  
 Association for the rehabilitation of the International Trade Union Confederation ( ITC ) and of the International Association for Intellectual Property ( IAP )  
 Membership in the Academy of Sciences and Letters of the German Democratic Republic  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio>
