<start_bio> 
 = Sir Alec Matthews =  
Sir Alec Matthew Bryan Matthews ( 23 December 1860, Anniston, Alabama – 4 July 1937, London, England ) was a British naturalist. He was the son of preacher John William Matthews, and the uncle of the great botanist, Daniel Matthew Bryan.  
 Matthew Bryan had a keen interest in science and wrote prolifically, from his parents'first marriage onward. He taught at All Saints'College, Cambridge from 1887 to 1908, became a Fellow of the Linnean Society in 1908 and was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society in 1916.He was one of the most successful of the first wave of British naturalists to visit Southern Africa, and in 1899 joined the British Museum and served as its Curator until 1918. He was awarded a CBE in 1909. He wrote many important papers and was the first to put forward the theory of evolutionary succession. He served as President of the Royal Society of South Africa from 1928 to 1940.  
   
   
 == Writings ==  
 The Natural History of the Garren Tree  
 Essays and Observations  
 Garden and Flower  
 Time was a Forest  
 Catalogue of the Birds of Cape Colony  
   
   
 == Family ==  
 He married Princess Charlotte Elizabeth Linton in 1891. They had two daughters and one son.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Wilhelm Paul Kreuzer =  
Wilhelm Paul Kreuzer ( 24 January 1905, in Berlin – 19 February 1980, in Dillingen, Germany ) was a German geologist.  
 He was an assistant to Werner Helmholtz at the University of Bonn and then head of the Geochronology Department in the Geological Institute of the Landtag of Baden-Württemberg. In 1927 he became a full member of the Royal Geographical Society. He worked for the Kongressprobe from 1931 until 1944. From 1946 until 1952 he was the director of the Institute for Geophysical Research in Dillingen. From 1959 until 1972 he was at the Ludwig Maximilians University of Munich.  
 Kreuzer discovered the largest amount of chalk on Germany's Tertiary rocks. He identified the Cretaceous impact pluton of Lake Baikal as North Siberian. He was also the first to identify the Precambrian uplift in Baden ( 1925 ), and was one of the first to believe that the Mannarai tectonic zone has moved westwards.  
   
   
 == Publications ==  
 The Geological Record of the Dillingen Province, 1927. Published by the Geological Survey of Germany.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Louis Desfossi C3 A8ro =  
Louis Desfossière ( 11 July 1825, Lagne – 11 December 1893, Colmar ) was a French engineer and meteorologist, who published several books and papers in the fields of meteorology and telegraphy. Desfossière was from a noble family of Engineers. His father Émilie Louis Desfossière, who took over the management of the industry after the death of his father in 1858, hired him and father to work at his mine. In 1863, Desfossière became inspector of mines and made improvements in mines, gas works, and septic and mining works. Desfossière worked on a number of important projects which greatly benefited the society and was recognised as a productive and progressive engineer. As such, he was known as the father of the modern barometric meteorology, a learned and wide-ranging science.He is also famous for the film 'Gasworks, mines and septic works of Geneva,'published by his son, Charles.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Barbara Giddings =  
Barbara Giddings ( October 10, 1925 – September 6, 2009 ) was an American psychotherapist and author.  
   
   
 == Early life and education ==  
 Barbara was born in North Richland Hills, Ohio, and was raised in Cleveland, Ohio. She earned her doctorate from University of California, Los Angeles in Psychology. After that, she worked at the Center for the Study of Counseling at UCLA.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 Giddings started working in the Psychotherapy Department at UCLA in 1969. In 1976, she joined the faculty of the University of Southern California's Graduate School of Business. Giddings was dean of the Graduate School from 1981-1991. In 1991, she was appointed an Assistant Professor of Clinical Psychotherapy.  
 She was awarded a National Book Award for `` Global Counseling in Education and Health Care '' in 1991 and a Silver Medal of the American Psychological Association in 1991. She received the B.A. from the University of South Dakota, in 1973, the M.A. from the University of California, Los Angeles in 1973 and Ph.D. in Psychology from University of Southern California in 1978.  
   
   
 == Professional works ==  
 Giddings'work focused on the development of interpersonal therapy, clinical characteristics of individual therapy, and learning styles that apply across cultures. Giddings was co-author of a landmark book, The Interpersonal Therapy Reader, which was followed by thirteen collections of professional works, with an emphasis on non-fiction articles.  
 Giddings was involved in several efforts for child development and drug abuse treatment : She co-founded and was an organizer of community service groups, advocated the use of mini-counselors, initiated studies about the effects of group behavior, and provided qualitative counseling on adult-onset adult personality problems.  
   
   
 == Discussions of cultism ==  
   
 Giddings took an interest in the cult phenomenon in 1991, when she received a copy of a flyer about a cult in Southlake, California. While she recognized the individual of significance of the cult, she found it difficult to connect with them and felt the need to debunk the group through research and study.  
 Giddings contended that the term cult is a synonym for `` Modern Communist Propaganda '' ( a term coined by former Reporters Without Borders member Patrick Aquino during his 2008 residency at State University of New York at Plattsburgh ), and by extension a group whose goal is to `` suppress the interests and beliefs of the United States ''.  
   
   
 == Awards ==  
 In 2006, Giddings was recognized by the American Psychological Association as one of the `` 100 most influential women in psychotherapy ''.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Jean-Baptiste-Joseph Roy =  
Jean-Baptiste-Joseph Roy ( 5 June 1805 – 29 July 1885 ) was a French naturalist and ornithologist.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 He was born in Saint-Jean-sur-Richelieu and educated at the Sorbonne. In 1810, he worked as assistant to Napoleon Bonaparte on an expedition to Asia Minor. In 1814 he was appointed naturalist to the French embassy to Germany. He traveled extensively through Southeast Asia, and in 1818 was awarded the rank of General Inspector-Naturalist.Roy published more than 100 books, including his first two works, The Catalogue of the Birds of the Southern Parts of Indochina and his Catalogue of Indian and Chinese Birds ( published in various parts of Europe ). These books were reprinted in 1831. He also published a treatise on the Northern Phylloxera of the Marquesas in 1824, a scientific work on the behavior of waterfowl, and an account of the birds of Madagascar. He was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society of London in 1822, and he was made a member in 1834.In addition to natural history work, Roy wrote a guide to Peking's ornithological parks, four volumes of a Chinese-English dictionary, and works on poetry. He was the first naturalist to hold the post of Lieutenant-Colonel in the French military in China.  
   
   
 == Family ==  
 He married Sara Ellen Bois-Rivière ( b. 1821 ) on 24 May 1822, and had one son.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 The Catalogue of the Birds of the Southern Parts of Indochina  
 The Pamphlets of General-Colonel Bois-Rivière and Additional Correspondents  
 The Catalogue of the Monkeys and the Domestic Fowl of China  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Susan Esslemont =  
Susan Alexandra Esslemont ( 2 October 1913 – 16 February 2006 ) was a Swedish physician and paediatrician.  
 She was the fourth person in history to receive three medals in the 1950s for her contribution to the hygiene of pre-school children and the education of children.  
   
   
 == Early life and education ==  
 Susan Esslemont was born in Stockholm on 2 October 1913. She attended the gymnasium in Stockholm. At the age of ten, she enrolled in a private school for girls in Uppsala and in the same year she went on a school journey with her father ( a teacher ), Anton Sandin, and a friend. At the end of the school year, they had reached Urmia, a village in the Norwegian Northern Provinces, where he found the girls and pregnant and had the babies moved to the Women's Home for the Infirm.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 In 1933, Esslemont travelled to the United States to study medical psychology at Columbia University in New York City. She enrolled at the University of Chicago and graduated in 1937. She became the first Swedish female to earn a degree in the United States ( she was a student there in the 1930s ). She was appointed first principal of Fjeldskapitalet in 1936 and in 1938 obtained her doctorate ( with a dissertation on the hygiene of pre-school children ). Esslemont performed some of the first research to study the effects of hygiene on women in Sweden in the United States.  
 In 1938 she started working as a psychiatrist at the Bellevue Hospital in New York City and continued to work at Bellevue until 1962, during which time she began to work on the first collaboration with Åke Ullerstam-Nygaard. A major achievement was her co-design of a new general health questionnaire ( data were collected between 1950 and 1954 ), the age–sex categories and sexual behaviour questionnaires, and she coined the term `` facilitation '' to refer to learning methods that guided research. In 1944, she made a joint study with Christina Mogróska-Sälling ( the first woman to do so ) of the effects of music therapy and is credited with designing the study rooms in the ward of young children in Bellevue, where teachers were taught to create an atmosphere conducive to learning.  
 When the parents of two young children, Albert Stanley ( who was a `` model kid '' with excellent verbal skills ) and Ato Lynn, entered on the same teaching career, their friends suggested that they should follow their mother on a study tour to United States children's homes. They left the Washington, D.C. area and took a bus for six days from New York City to Palo Alto, California, to visit the Aspen Festival. The bus journey, in the company of 13 American health professionals and an international team of doctors, took them to the children's home of the future president of the United States, Harry S. Truman, where they did research on pianism and mathematics.  
   
   
 == Personal life ==  
 Susan Esslemont married John Hedin, a father of the philosopher Michael Medved, in 1948. She never remarried and their marriage lasted 20 years. In 1991, her father became an American citizen and for many years died in San Francisco at the age of 90.  
 Susan Esslemont died of a brain haemorrhage in Wexford, Italy on 16 February 2006, aged 84.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = John Ashby =  
John Ashby ( née Renwick, 23 December 1854 – 15 March 1926 ) was an English physicist and theoretical physicist who taught at Oxford and Cambridge.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Ashby was born in Ludlow, Middlesex, to John Vickers Ashby, an engineer, and Eleanor Herbert ( née van Zyl ) Ashby. His paternal grandfather was Sir Alexander John Ashby, a barrister, barrister and Justice of the Peace in Cambuslang, the remote Isle of Wight, and his mother was Mary ( Jenks ) Coleman.  
 He was educated at Eton College, the Royal College of Science, Cambridge, the University of Cambridge and Queens College, Cambridge, graduating as senior student in 1899.  
 He began his career in 1921 as assistant to Robert Hooke, working on electrodynamics and statistical mechanics. In 1927 he became a fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh, and in 1929 he became an associate professor at the Cambridge Mathematical Institute, where he served as a permanent secretary, becoming the Society's first chairman in 1940.  
 During World War II, Ashby became a war witness on behalf of the Government and was a senior aide to Winston Churchill during the Korean War. Ashby's methods were adopted by the Vickers-Ashby Miscegenation Unit of the Ministry of Supply, and on the USSR side were used by the Uranitional Laboratory and Atomic Energy Commission, while those of the Bendix Department of the Royal Geographical Society, in the United Kingdom, were adopted by the Space Research Establishment.In 1942, he was awarded the Legion of Honour, Knight Commander of the Order of the British Empire and Commander of the Royal Astronomical Society.  
 Ashby was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society in 1909, the year he started as a fellow.  
   
   
 == Family ==  
 His brother, John Bensley Ashby ( 1876–1955 ), was a zoologist and academic, author of The Flora of Exeter ( 1870 ), Molluscs of East Anglia ( 1885 ), and the later major work Geology ( 1888 ).  
 He was married, on 14 December 1919, to Aneal Merrifield  
 and they had two sons and a daughter.  
   
   
 == Publications ==  
 Determination of the Observations of Richard Tolbert on the Hachschesian ridge : ‘ A short, exploratory, and extreme sketch ’, in D. Bacon, Proceedings of the Royal Society of London, Ser.1, pp. 349–359. 1911.  
 Observations on the Goldstone Bubble and Geometric Variation with the Agassiz Line : ‘ An application of General Equations to a Geometrical Problem ’, Nature, Vol. 101, pp. 559–561, April 11, 1912.  
 On a Comparative Study of the Long and Short Absorptions of Charge with the Contrast Defined from the Index of Electrodynamic Algebra : ‘ An experiment using various systems in which diverse biases in strain rates are artificially corrected in a variety of arrangements. ’ '' Journal of the Chemical Society of London, Vol. 132, Part 3, No. 2, pp. 252–262 ( 1884 ).  
 On the Difference of Stefan–Sickert Evolution and Symmetries in Plutons : ‘ Experimental work on the behaviour of water in external fluid pressure ’ in Svenska Bengels, Proceedings of the Royal Society of London, Second Series, Vol. 66, pp. 388–387 ( 1897 ).  
 On the Ordinary Volumetric Determinations of Variations in Units of Elasticity, First Measurement of the Measurement Intensity Limit, and Some Preliminary Problems, by Means of an Air Density Measurement ’, Transactions of the Royal Society of Edinburgh, Vol. 65, pp. 255–260 ( 1892 ).  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Raymond Hynek =  
Raymond `` Bill '' Hynek ( April 24, 1930 – September 4, 2005 ) was a sociologist, president of the Social Science Research Council and head of the American Sociological Association.  
   
   
 == Education and career ==  
 He was a graduate of University of Michigan and Harvard University, where he earned a master's in social science and a doctorate in sociology. He was the co-author ( with Herbert Grunwald ) of Sociology of Conflict : Social Networks and Family Relationships ( 1974 ) and co-author ( with A. J. Pignatelli ) of Social Values : Their Habits ( 1977 ). He taught at Harvard for most of his career, but during his tenure he was president of the Social Science Research Council and director of the Institute for General and Comparative Social Science Research ( 1980–81 ).In 1992 he was one of the architects of the Cross-Cultural, Cross-Ethnic Study ( CECOS ).CECOS was sponsored by the Rockefeller Foundation and produced a series of studies of low income immigrant families in the United States. For that reason, many of its findings were sympathetic to lower-income immigrant workers.  
   
   
 == Awards and honours ==  
 In 2002 the Council of the Social Science Research Council established the Ray Hynek Award.  
 In recognition of his distinguished service to sociology, Hynek received the William Field Robinson Award from the American Sociological Association in 1989.  
   
   
 == Selected bibliography ==  
 ( 1969 ). Social, economic, and political movements in ethnically diverse lands : practical experiences of the pastoralist survey. University of Michigan Press.  
 ( 1970 ). Cultural evolution and kin selection in the livestock economy. Amer. J. Sociol. 27 ( 4 ) : 415–47.  
 ( 1970 ). Distributional factors in the low-income group. Amer. J. Sociol. 27 ( 4 ) : 459–70.  
 ( 1973 ). Historical perspectives on cultural processes in low-income rural America. Univ. of Kansas Press.  
 ( 1975 ). Family structures, the workplace and public policy : the colonial and mid-19th-century railroad system. Arch. Prev. Econ. Dispers. 13 : 239–51.  
 ( 1977 ). Econometric aspects of group structure and social change. Ann. N. Y. Acad. Sci. 558 ( 1 ) : 40–45.  
 ( 1981 ). Religion, society, and democracy. Ann. N. Y. Acad. Sci. 563 ( 1 ) : 147–52.  
 ( 1983 ). Teaching : Sociological methods. Social Science Research Council.  
 ( 1986 ). Pragmatics and idealism. Social Science Research Council.  
 ( 1991 ). Dispersive social determinants. Harvard Univ. Press.  
   
   
 == Honours and awards ==  
 In 1994 the Archbold Prize in Social Sciences was established in his honour.  
   
   
 == Publications ==  
 Sociology of Conflict : Social Networks and Family Relationships ( 1974 )  
 Sociology of Conflict : Social Values : Their Habits ( 1977 )  
 Cross-Cultural, Cross-Ethnic Study ( CECOS ) ( 1994 ).  
 The Changing Status of Rural Americans : Contribution to an understanding of marriage, family and child survival and development. Author unknown.  
 Orderly social network in the oil boom. ( Unpublished Ph.D. thesis, West Virginia Univ.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Boris Joseph Gabriel =  
Boris Joseph Gabriel ( 20 January 1916 – 23 March 1996 ) was a Romanian nuclear scientist.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 Gabriel joined the Romanian Scientific Research Institute ( National Research Council, Romanian National Research Council, VNI ) in 1925 as a mechanical engineer, rising to the rank of assistant director. In 1933, he was promoted to assistant director in order to increase the workload of research projects. In 1938 he joined the staff of the Romanian Engineering Institute of Ion Technology ( Romanian National Research Council ), where he was tasked with developing the development of nuclear energy. From 1940 to 1951, he was a member of the National Research Council.  
 Gabriel was awarded the name of Chernogolov in 1948. On 3 November 1959 he retired from the Ministry of Defense. He died in 1996 and was buried in the village of Smilana.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = J. D. Franklin =  
James D. Franklin ( 18 January 1898 – 27 February 1985 ) was an American biologist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 James D. Franklin was born in Florida and grew up in Albany, Massachusetts, where he met his future wife, Margaret ( née Hill ), a general practitioner. They went on to have four children. They were educated at Sacred Heart College and graduated from Mount Holyoke College in 1937. Franklin trained as a zoologist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Harvard Medical School before moving to California in 1941. He wrote the seminal textbook The Biological and Social Life of Animals, and served as director of the school's Department of Biological Sciences. In 1954 he founded the Institute of Zoology at the California Institute of Technology. The institute's biological laboratory provided facilities for experimenters, and Franklin also was the first president of the Society for Comparative Anatomy and Comparative Physiology. Franklin was a director of the California Institute of Technology until his death. He died on 27 February 1985, in Pasadena, California.  
 Franklin's work was relevant for the transition from pre-Darwinian biology to modern biological systems, the holomarche. He introduced the concept of emergent biology to the field of embryology.  
 Franklin married Margaret Hill, the daughter of a Boston lawyer. They had two children. In 1950 they went on to have five children. The Franklin children live in Berkeley, California. Margaret founded the Society for Comparative Anatomy and Comparative Physiology in 1954. In 1966 she was inducted into the American Zoological Hall of Fame.  
 Franklin is commemorated in the scientific names of several animals :  
 Franklin was the first person to name a new species of freshwater fish, Cephalotoma niger, in the journal Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences.  
 The marine organism ( Boma species ) Franklinidae was named for him.  
 Franklin's early research on viruses focused on herpes simplex virus and herpes simplex sarcoma. However, Franklin's experiments with the bacterium Salmonella heirogluvirus led him to discover the diphtheria toxin lysozyme.In the 1980s, Franklin published a work with Suzanne Albertson-Brandeis, Elizabeth Johnstone and others entitled Human speciation in Africa, which summarised what had happened in the Pacific, Indian Ocean, East Africa and the Sahara, and delineated the `` geologic arc '' of human migration from Africa to the Americas. Franklin also contributed to the list of 26 names of vertebrates that are etymologically related to humans, and the existence of the genus Franklinius.  
 Franklin's 1972 book Society and Theory of Evolution, or, How Man Created Man, attracted a great deal of attention and debate. The book's characterisation of the `` leviathan '' philosophy of evolution, i.e. the concept that humans have fixed, biological traits ( such as those described in fossils ) and that the evolutionary theory of Lamarck was able to explain them, was met with intense criticism by those who thought evolution was'still unproven '.  
 Franklin has been described as `` the final brain trust of Least Energy '' ( Geoffrey Quine ), and underwrote two of the three research programmes of the American Association for the Advancement of Science. The anthropologist Robert Kroeber was also a longtime Franklin supporter.  
   
   
 == Family ==  
 In 1948, Franklin married Margaret Hill, the sister of Columbia University political scientist Jerome B. Hill. They had two children : Bob Franklin ( 1960-1987 ) and Lois Hill ( 1963-1989 ). John Horner, of Egleston, Massachusetts, recalled that `` 'He taught [ her ] to be a scientist,'said Glenn A. Clarkson, `` and then he was probably the most accurate, courteous man in the world.''' Franklin's wife Margaret died in 1992.  
 Franklin married Rebecca Marder Whitney ( née Hagen ) in 1947 and had four children. He died in 1990, aged 64.  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Gerald Leonard =  
Gerald Leonard ( January 19, 1900 – December 14, 1974 ) was an American psychologist. His major scientific contributions include theories of control and security, social behavior, group dynamics, and social identity.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Leonard was born in Madison, Wisconsin, but grew up in Danville, Illinois. He attended State Normal School in Danville, and graduated from Columbia University in 1935. After attending Wesleyan University, he studied at Columbia under John Searle and Herbert Taber and was awarded a PhD in 1937.After serving in the World War II influenza pandemic, Leonard enrolled at the University of Chicago, where he received a Ph.D. in 1945. He was a postdoctoral fellow at the Institute of Personality Assessment in 1967.  
 Following his graduate studies, Leonard served as a research assistant in experimental psychology at the University of California, San Diego. From 1969 until his retirement in 1977, he was the Leonard Research Professor of Human Relations at the University of Chicago.  
 He was a member of the National Academy of Sciences, the American Psychological Association, the American Sociological Association, the International Society for Personality Measurement, and the American Psychiatric Association.  
 Leonard was a lecturer at the University of Wisconsin, Milwaukee.  
   
   
 == Publications ==  
 Leonard, G. L. ( 1946 ). Group Dynamics. New York : Columbia University Press.  
 Leonard, G. L. ( 1948 ). `` Self-Denial ''. Psychological Review. 46 ( 3 ) : 417–427. doi:10.1037/h0025654.  
 Leonard, G. L. ( 1949 ). `` Barriers to Asociality ''. Psychological Review. 48 ( 1 ) : 65–73. doi:10.1037/h0067534.  
   
   
 == Selected bibliography ==  
 Leonard, G. L. ( 1951 ). Individual Problems in Group Relations. New York : Wiley.  
 Leonard, G. L. ( 1954 ). Group Dynamics : A Mathematical Approach. New York : Wiley.  
 Leonard, G. L. ( 1965 ). `` Personality Behaviors ''. American Journal of Sociology. 66 ( 1 ) : 89–110. doi:10.2307/238658, JSTOR 238658.  
 Leonard, G. L. ( 1966 ). `` Special Groups and Group Behavior : A Handbook for Academic Teaching ''. Journal of Research in Personality. 14 : 197–234. doi:10.1177/01601067016014154.  
   
   
 == In-text citation ==  
 Williams, R. ( 1963 ). `` G. L. Leonard, G. J. Wilson and others, The effect of conscientiousness on intelligence ''. American Journal of Psychology. 58 ( 1 ) : 125–130. doi:10.1037/h0010485.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Abraham Borisovich Iulin =  
Abraham Borisovich Iulin ( Ukrainian : Александр Фхачники ; 26 January [ O.S. 24 January ] 1811 – 17 March [ O.S. 3 March ] 1884 ) was a Ukrainian theologian and political writer.  
 Born in Vilnius ( then part of Poland, now Lithuania ), Iulin earned his ordination at the Seminary of the Kingdom of Lithuania ( now Ponti University, Lithuania ). He then studied at the University of Leipzig and the University of Prague. From 1830 to 1832, he was a member of the Abbotical Academy of Saint Peter, Trier ( now the University of Trier ), where he also taught literature. During his time at Trier, Iulin wrote several works, including the compilation of The Meek Shall be the Lord's Servant, a theological commentary, and a commentary to the Gospel of Luke.  
 Iulin founded the Ukrainian Church and its Ecumenical Mission ( BpvS ), and was a trustee for the vast publishing empire Hetty Publications ( today Europe Publishing House ).  
 Iulin died in Lwów in 1884.  
   
   
 == Legacy ==  
 My son Boris Iulin translated the works of Antosio Mattei into the native Ukrainian, which gained much popularity among Ukrainians.  
 His son Ianchen Iulin is a famous Ukrainian politician and the current President of the Ukrainian Parliament in the Ukrainian Parliament.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 The Meek Shall be the Lord's Servant ( 1832 ) – translation of the first three Gospels in the present sense.  
 The Great Informations of the True Catholic Faith ( 1840 ) – An explanatory article on the Church and is intended to supplement The Meek Shall be the Lord's Servant ( 1832 ).  
 Die Kirche und die Christentumschrift ( 1843 ) – historical epistle in defense of the Catholic Church.  
 I. Antisimia despizianissimo, praktikoia kathisma obviosionai syrmykhologija, anatomia ad graveanafistva ( 3 volumes, 1840-1916 )  
 I, post-absolutistiki and ideosimia ( 1846 ) – essays on the teachings of Antisimia and their relevance to the Catholic Faith.  
 The Synopsis ( 1859 ) – an apologetic analysis of Synopsis I on the Catholic Symbolism of the Second Vatican Council, compiled from the final compiled versions.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Antonio Azzocco =  
Antonio Azzocco ( July 14, 1722, Venice – May 27, 1838, Seville ) was a Spanish entomologist. He is most notable for his field work in the Caribbean, the Dominican Republic and Jamaica. He was one of the first to document insects from the Caribbean in a zoological journal, Academia de Ciencias Naturales in the latter part of the seventeenth century. He is also credited with writing the first English descriptive English-language account of specific species of moths.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Antonio Azzocco was born in Venice. His father was born a trade unionist and the latter was a merchant.  
 At an early age he went to the city and received his first exposure to zoology. From his studies, he earned a passion for the work and he opened an aviary. Afterwards he studied medicine at the University of Heidelberg and then the University of Bonn. He attained his doctorate in 1819.  
 He worked at the Naples Museum and in 1825 founded the Branca Novello, and became associated with it. In 1827 he visited Cuba, in 1829 he went to Jamaica and in 1830 in Saint Kitts, where he founded the Nestsa Ambulante Plantar, where he concentrated his entire interest in moths.  
 Beginning in 1831, he lectured in the Canary Islands and in the Dominican Republic, and took a permanent position in Seville in the year 1836. In 1839 he moved to Seville to head the Scientific Museum of the Observatories of the Dominican University.  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = George Bodley =  
George Bodley ( 9 February 1897 – 11 January 1981 ) was a British mason who led the first European excavations of America and settled in the state of New Mexico. He was chief editor of the journal Antiquity from 1930 to 1940 and contributed significantly to the history of both New Mexico and the United States. He was awarded the Order of the British Empire.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 George Bodley was born in Barnsley, Lancashire. His parents, John and Janet, were of German descent. Bodley's brother, James H. Bodley, had the distinction of being awarded the highest award in the British Empire for his archaeological services. James and his family had been raised in a major centre for German, French and Italian immigrants to the United Kingdom, where Bodley was brought up, but later emigrated to Britain where he grew up. He came to the United States in 1925 where he met and married his childhood sweetheart Elizabeth E. Murray. They had a son, Charles, whom he was father to the couple's son Robert and daughter Shanna Bodley ( 1962–1987 ). Their son George was born in 1928 and died in 1982.  
 George and his wife Elizabeth had three sons and two daughters, including :  
 William Peter Bodley ( 1943–1972 ) married in 1916 and they had one son, Robert, and two daughters, Christine Louise Bodley and Margaret Lorna Mary Bodley.  
 Richard Williams Bodley ( 1946–1990 ) married in 1929 and they had one son, David.  
 Rose Frances Elizabeth Epping ( 1949–1982 ) married in 1951 and they had one son, Charles.  
 Marian Jack Bodley ( 1955–1984 ) married in 1956 and they had one daughter, Bonnie.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 Bodley returned to the United Kingdom in 1951, finding employment in the Civil Engineering department of the Department of Trade and Industry, the construction industry and the New York City sanitation department. Bodley left working in these sectors after a dispute with the New York Public Library, which refused to allow him to use it as a vault after a probationary period. In 1954 he was appointed Principal of Greenville, South Carolina's state high school. He left this post in 1959, returning to the Civil Engineering Department of the Department of Trade and Industry, where he became Principal in 1961 and remained at that position until his retirement in 1974.  
 Bodley was a prolific author. In 1964 he published a series of self-published articles titled `` Certain Account of the Treasure Excavations in the Valley of Cortez ''.  
   
   
 == Legacy ==  
 In 1990 the California Institute of Mining, Metallurgical and Petroleum Engineering awarded a bronze bust of Bodley to the New Mexico State Historical Society.  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Jens Christian Anders =  
Jens Christian Anders ( 26 January 1866 – 16 October 1948 ) was a Danish mathematician, the father of Gudrun Erik Anders. He was the nephew of Jens Carl Carl Anders and brother of the eminent Swedish mathematician Gudrun Carl Erik Anders.  
 He was born at Natal in 1866, the third son in the Anders family. He studied Mathematics and Statistics at the University of Copenhagen under Auguste Rey which became an extremely important source of later pioneering research on finite state machines.  
 On leaving the University in 1904, Anders emigrated to the United States and became a professor at Princeton University. He was professor of Mathematics and Statistics at the University of Michigan in 1909 and the same year moved to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology ( MIT ). In 1926 he was made a Fellow of the American Mathematical Society ( AMS ), a position he held until his retirement in 1939.  
   
   
 == Publications ==  
 On the Elliptic function with a composite polynomial  
 On infinite graphs  
 Some applications of analytic geometry  
 Problems of general analysis  
 On the Ramanujan conjecture  
 On the existence of convex hyperplanes  
 On the calculus of variations  
 Theory of surfaces  
   
   
 == Selected bibliography ==  
 Vogel, Werner ( 2011 ). Integral and analytic geometry : a critical guide. London : Hanson Publishing Limited. ISBN 978-1-312-06019-0.  
 Anders, Gudrun ( 1993 ). A theoretical geometry textbook for students of mathematics and computer science. Oxford : Blackwell Publishing. ISBN 978-0-19-561227-1.  
   
   
 == Selected publications ==  
 Anders, Gudrun ( 1928 ). History of Mathematical Sciences. Vol. 1. New York : Scribner.  
 Anders, Gudrun ( 1931 ). History of Mathematical Sciences. Vol. 2. New York : Scribner.  
 Larsen, Frederik ( 1959 ). Mathematical Principles of Evolution. Academic Press, Philadelphia. ISBN 978-0-275-60205-5.  
 Gudrun, Erik ( 1939 ). Widerstille om finns angsten. Leiden : Brill. ISBN 978-0-312-02635-7.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Heinrich Buchhorn =  
Heinrich Buchhorn ( September 10, 1831 – August 28, 1887 ) was an Austrian-born British physicist, professor of mechanics at the University of Glasgow, and an important member of the work group responsible for the celebrated Bell-Bulletin conference, at which the structure of the atom and of other fundamental particles was determined.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 He was born in Altstadt in Livonia, the son of a cloth manufacturer. In 1856 he completed secondary school in Livonia, then studied at the University of Breslau, where he obtained the cand.electrical lyc. degree. In 1870 he became a lecturer in physics at the University of Breslau. He then became professor of physics and astronomy in 1873, in the same year taking charge of the department of physics. Buchhorn's interest in mathematical theory attracted him to the work of John von Neumann.  
 In 1873, with von Neumann as a fellow, he founded the institute for theoretical and experimental physics at Glasgow. In 1882, during the First World War, Buchhorn served in a mission to Chile under the Provisional Government of the Belgian Congo ( Pro-Tem ).  
 Buchhorn left in 1884 for England. In 1905 he succeeded to his professorship at Cambridge, but in 1882 he was promoted to the position of professor of mechanics. In 1898 he was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh. In 1901 he founded the Glasgow Institute for the Study of Electricity, followed by an academic exhibition in 1902 and a lecture series in 1907–08. His collections, catalogues and other documents of various branches of the civil service, are now held by the Archives of the Scottish Department of the Royal Society.  
 From 1914–15 he was a member of the editorial boards of magazines such as Monthly Review and British Journal of Science. Buchhorn was also an author.  
 He died in Glasgow on August 28, 1887.  
   
   
 == Notable students ==  
 Otto Seeger was a lifelong friend. Seeger became an early supporter of atomic and molecular physics and in 1881 asked Buchhorn to give him a course on boron and manganese chemistry, through which he obtained a B.Sc. degree. He became professor of chemistry at Cambridge in 1885.  
 Helmut Kohl was a graduate student of John Buchhorn and, at Buchhorn's encouragement, a student at Hamburg. In 1905 Kohl received an M.Sc. degree from Cambridge.  
   
   
 == Personal life ==  
 In 1844, Buchhorn married Catharine Crozier, the daughter of the lawyer William Crozier and his wife Matilda Irina Pouler. From 1848 to 1857, they lived in London. In 1858 she married the Belgian politician Heinrich Schouwes of Sint-Leuven. They were pensioners at a home in Cambridge.  
 In 1878 Buchhorn married his cousin, the Welsh pianist Thomas ( Isobel ) Buchhorn, the daughter of John Bunyan. She later came to be known as Tilly-Blanche, married Johannine Freudenthal, the daughter of a German mezzo-soprano.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Jos C3 A9 Percival =  
José Julián Percival, Londres ( Spanish : [ ˈjoːɲɾat ˈtəpɛ̃bɛl ] ; 18 December 1841 – 23 May 1927 ), was a young Argentine Jesuit priest, politician and sociologist. His son was Cardinal Jorge Mario Percival.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Percival was born at Abadea in Sinaloa. He attended the Jesuit seminary of Quirigues, where he studied geology and sociology. Later he became a cardinal. He became the district chaplain of Azuay, capital of Perú province. In 1894 he became Vicar General of Quirigues, a post which he held until his death.  
 In 1900, Percival was elected a member of the Spanish Legislative Assembly for the province of Quirigues.  
 On 25 October 1913 he became one of the founding members of the central government of the Ecuadorian republic ( OAS ), and a member of the founding congress of the socialist student movement ( PSUC ) in the city of Quirigues ( of which he was first deputy president and in which he served as the editor ). He represented that province from 1911 to 1914 and in 1917 from 1918 to 1918 as well as from 1918 to 1918.  
 Percival died on 23 May 1927, the year of the state anniversary of the Imperial Spanish Republic ( SIFR ). He was a leading voice in the third national government of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela ( Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela ).  
   
   
 == Writings ==  
 Percival's work largely focused on sociology and political economy and provided an intellectual and intellectual bridge for the later Argentine Revolution. He was the first to identify the emergence of a socialist society in Ecuador and during the next fifteen years, Percival and his fellow Jesuit Alejandro Laguna began working out the ideas of an economic socialist society.  
 He had a strong interest in public education as well as economic economics, and was also a political economist. In his inaugural address in Quirigues in 1897, Percival made the following statement :  
   
 From the perspective of social action, the spiritualists point out that there are two modes of economic activity. The first—the side of production which makes things, and uses them for human welfare—is for the specific class of the individual. The second—the side of production in which individuals rest their lives on the fruits of production, and produces goods to make themselves better off—in short, the economic self-realization of the individual—has to do with the social action of the multitude, as in the value-creators. At the present time, both methods—both ultimately universal and without controversy—have come to be referred to as the system of market relations, or what Algernon Sidney calls the universal social order. This order consists of a system of money for all the people, an order of production which has all of the characteristics of a universal social community—social intercourse for the individual, and of mutual assistance between individuals, so that in total the burden of production, what social intercourse is but a mere station to be removed, can now be divided among each individual.  
 Percival had a great influence in the late 20th century, with his doctoral student Lina Huber translating the works of Peirats. He was also involved in political economy during the time of Juan Perón and in the early part of the 1960s.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = A. Ashraf =  
Ayub Ashraf ( May 15, 1848 – July 26, 1925 ), a celebrated Indian physicist and a `` theologian of great intellect '', was one of the most renowned early teachers of physics in India. He was born in South Delhi, the son of a housewife and a student of two distinguished professors, Professors Jafaruddin and Mirza Ashraf.  
 Ashraf earned the honours of the Indian Academy of Science and received several prizes, including Padma Bhushan, first place for Physics in the 1894 in the International Congress of Indology ( CII ). Ashraf was the professor of Mathematics at the Indian Institute of Technology in 1894 and was later a professor of Electricity, Magnetism, and Optics ( IEEE ) at the Calcutta Technological University. The twenty-two volumes he wrote were published posthumously by the AIET.  
 Ashraf was Professor of Physics at Delhi University ( RAMU ) from 1897 to 1931. He did mathematical researches in the area of electrostatics ( Class X chemistry ), in the area of materials ( Galvanism, metallurgy, metallurgy, crystallography ) and in condensed matter physics ( Polyaniline colorings, electric charge, electrolysis, various types of refractory materials, solids and vapours ).  
 He was also Director of the National Institute of Science and Technology, India ( now National Institute of Technology of Science and Technology, India ) ( with his uncle, Krishnakumar Ashraf ) and in addition to being Director of RAMU, he also held various positions in the Research Laboratories of Electrical and Mechanical Engineering at Bhopal. He was the Honorary Resident of Poona. He died in 1925.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Paul C. Cremer =  
Paul Cremer ( November 18, 1911 – February 20, 1999 ) was an American physicist. He is considered one of the founding fathers of the field of quantitative particle physics. His first book, Physical Optics, won first prize in both the Physics and Mathematics Fiction Competition of the Amherst College Students'Association, and he was also elected a member of the American Physical Society. He was elected a Fellow of the American Physical Society in 1978.In 1982 he was chosen as one of the thirty forty-five scientists inducted into the National Inventors Hall of Fame.  
 He died of pneumonia in Pennsylvania in 1999, and is buried in Whitby Cemetery in Massachusetts.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 He attended Amherst College from 1921 to 1925, where he earned his Bachelor of Science degree in 1926 and his Ph.D. in 1926. He remained at Amherst until his retirement in 1959. He was a professor of physics at Trinity College from 1964 to 1971, and at Harvard University from 1971 to 1982. He was a leading proponent of the use of statistical mechanics in the study of particle physics and set up a statistical approach to control charge concentration in high-energy collisions of high-energy particles.  
   
   
 == Publications ==  
 Fractional Spectra of Electrons ( 1930 )  
 Continuous Fractional Quantum Theory with Angular Crusts ( 1940 )  
 Calculation of the Dual Function Space of Transition-Induced Scattering ( 1949 )  
 Several Gauge Functions in the Dirac Experiment with Orthogonal Distortion ( 1960 )  
   
   
 == Research interests ==  
 His main interest was the existence of the diffraction maps of electron spin. He spent most of his time studying the particle interaction problem.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Benedikt C3 BCker =  
Benedikt C3 BCker ( German : [ ˈbədikts ‘ karəter ] ; 5 January 1910, Innsbruck – 25 September 1994, Cologne ) was a German classical pianist.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Benedikt C3 BCker was born on 5 January 1910, in Innsbruck, the son of piano teacher Adolphe C3 BCker and Lydia Brauch. His older brother, Christian C3 BCker, was born in 1892. He studied piano with Hans Betts ( 1885-1947 ) and Peter Oelschowsky ( 1903-1939 ) in Frankfurt. During his time there he became fluent in both English and German, and the offer of a position at the Vienna Conservatory forced him to emigrate.  
 C3 BCker studied at the Conservatory, receiving his doctorate in music theory in 1932. He made his concert debut in 1935. He toured with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra in 1935, appearing on the score of his piano sonatas with Benjamin Britten. Two years later, C3 BCker started his more prestigious role in Germany, being named director of the Reichtheater in Marburg, where he performed with the same orchestra until the early 1950s.  
   
   
 === Opera and ballet ===  
 He was active in the opera world, staging his own production of Henryk Puchowski's opera Bruckner nach Rome ( Faust with the Pope ) in Hamburg in 1952 and conducting various productions of the famous ballet Les Chiffres de Lambarde ( The Bride of Lambarde ), Le théâtre et la femme in Le Havre ( The White Wolf and His Wife ) and Les Livres d'Espagne ( The First Age of Frolic ). He worked with both German and Austrian operas, but he performed mainly in German.  
 He was active in the ballet world from 1954 until his retirement in 1986. In 1960, he was a professor at the school of singing at the University of Marburg.  
   
   
 == Bibliography ==  
 Enzyklopädie zur Kunstministerium für Liszt ( Edited and annotated by Hans Betts ). Translated by Trevor Kennedy. Oxford : Blackwell, 2007.  
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Arthur de Saint-Lambert =  
Arthur Denis de Saint-Lambert ( 14 August 1915 – 19 November 1981 ) was a French economist and statistician.  
 He was a specialist in the industry of telegraphy and received a doctorate in mathematics at the Sorbonne. He was a member of the editorial board of La Bibliothèque nationale de France.  
   
   
 == Early life ==  
 Arthur Denis de Saint-Lambert was born on 14 August 1915 in Nice, the son of a pharmacist. He attended the lyceum where his father had been president and a piano teacher. His intellectual years were spent in mathematics, physics, economics and the classics, in Geneva and Nice. He received his A.Sc. in 1921.  
   
   
 == Academic career ==  
 During this period, his interest in statistics became more active, and he joined the French Society of Economic Statistics ( SCES ) and the Department of Statistics at the Paris School of Economics. He studied at the Sorbonne in 1921, his doctoral thesis was entitled `` Studies in statistics in France. '' It was released in 1928 under the name Le Series statisticiste ( Series Statistician ).  
   
   
 == Work ==  
 In 1923, he became professor at the Paris School of Economics, now in its golden age, and moved there in 1949 to become its head.  
 There, he wrote papers on the relations of capital accumulation in various industries, coining the term correlation as a measure of political integration. Between 1941 and 1954, he was president of the Society of Economic Statistics, also president of the Société européenne des sciences et technologiques et financiers.  
 His major publication, La médecine parathetique, was published in 1956. Later, in 1960, he presented on this topic a special research seminar titled `` la développement de statistical research '' at the Société nationale de Sciences de la Recherche.  
 Between 1958 and 1964, he was also a member of the Accademia Nazionale di Storia di Scienze, publishing various works on labour mobility, economic cycle, saving, investments, risk and information.  
 In 1968, he was elected to the French Academy of Sciences.  
 He died on 19 November 1981 at the age of 88 in Nice.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Edwin C. Iredale =  
Edwin Charles Joseph Iredale ( 9 July 1898 – 19 August 1974 ) was an American geologist and engineer and academic.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Iredale was born on September 9, 1898 in Muskegon, Michigan. He graduated from the University of Michigan in 1921 and was ordained in 1925. He attended Harvard University, where he was an assistant professor of geology, with Harold V. Lee. He became Professor of Earth Sciences at the University of Chicago in 1928, retiring in 1969. He was dean of the Chicago School of Science in 1936.  
 Iredale joined the University of Michigan in 1939, and became its associate director for geology in 1945. He became Professor of Earth Sciences in 1953, as well. His 1930 paper on the geology of Lake Superior was one of the most influential in geological knowledge and formative factors in the understanding of the formation of North America.He died on 19 August 1974, in Ann Arbor, Michigan.  
   
   
 == Books ==  
 The geology of Lake Superior, 1924  
 Kontinuumia - The geographical distribution of the Kontinuum, 1926  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Leopoldo Nicolai Roes =  
Leopoldo Nicolai Roes ( 24 July 1906 – 28 June 1985 ) was a Romanian designer of the space program.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Roes was born in Pomona, Oromia, and studied at the Polytechnic school. He took up an architectural job in 1947. He worked as a curator at the National Museum of Computing at the University of Bucharest for three years, after which he became a senior architect. At the end of 1954 he retired, and lived in Brescia for the next few years. In 1959 he started teaching at the University of Bucharest, and became involved in the Space Program, with the part of the Chair of Mechanical Design between 1959 and 1970. In 1960 he became a member of the Polish Council of Ministers. Between 1962 and 1964, he was a teacher in the House of Wojciech Wiesman, while in the next years he became a consultant to the Polish and Soviet Space agencies. In 1966, he won the Doctorate of Architectural Sciences, and returned to the United States in 1970.  
 He was elected an Officer of the Order of the Orange Order in 1968, and an Officer of the Legion of Honor in 1970, and he was knighted in 1975. He died of liver cancer in 1985.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Aubrey E. Bala =  
Aubrey Edward Bala ( 1915–1996 ) was an American nuclear physicist and particle physicist. He was most known for his pioneering and influential work on cross-band magnetism in semiconductors. His influential ideas remain relevant to a large number of applications.  
   
   
 == Early life and education ==  
 Aubrey Edward Bala was born in Philadelphia on August 25, 1915. He received a B.S. in electrical engineering from the University of Pennsylvania in 1927, and was a Fulbright scholar in the USA from 1932 to 1937. He then joined the Physics Department at the University of California, Berkeley in 1937 as Assistant Professor of Physics.  
   
   
 == Professional career ==  
 In the US, Bala took part in the United States Navy's development of radar, and joined the Los Alamos Laboratory as the Deputy Director in 1944. He then worked with the US Naval Research Laboratory on radar for many years, and in the 1950s became the laboratory's Associate Director, an important post for scientists.In the 1960s, Bala became a professor at the University of California, Berkeley. He remained in that position until 1982, and, in his final years, he directed the Institute for Optics, Optics and Quantum Theory at the University. He died in Berkeley, California, in 1996, and is buried in the UC Berkeley Aviation and Air Force Heritage Center, a quiet residential neighborhood.  
   
   
 == Life and legacy ==  
   
   
 === Critical work ===  
   
 Bala's fundamental research in theory and application of semiconductor cross-band magnetic momenta began in a paper, `` Electron Discharge with the Stereochronous Transistor '', which he presented to the American Physical Society in 1930. The paper, with colleagues J. B. A. Randall and R. E. Shackelford, anticipated later work by researchers such as Robert Stoup and Ernest Lindemann, establishing that the magnetic momenta of a semiconductor could be measured using time and distance variations of the electron path.  
 The early contributions of Aubrey E. Bala laid the groundwork for widely adopted cross-band magnetic momenta measurements, and a new field of research—electronic spectroscopy.  
   
   
 === Nobel Prize in physics ===  
   
 The University of California awarded Bala the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1962 for the discovery of the Wicker equation, which described the magnetisation of semiconductor surfaces by magnetic moments. The Nobel Laureate wrote, `` If you read the paper on its own, you will not find anything resembling a name. But remember, in the long term, it will have great significance to particle physics. '' The Nobel Prize was first presented on May 27, 1964, by Nobel laureate Arno Penzias.  
   
   
 == Awards and honors ==  
 1966 -  
 National Medal of Science  
 1972 -  
 National Medal of Technology  
 1983 -  
 United States National Medal of Technology  
 1983 -  
 Guggenheim Fellow  
 1989 -  
 Ross Professor of the Physics Department at the University of California, Berkeley  
 1992 -  
 The American Institute of Physics  
 1992 -  
 Warburg Medal  
 1993 -  
 Thomas M. Courant Award  
 1993 -  
 Member of the National Academy of Sciences  
 1999 -  
 John Scannell Prize  
 1999 -  
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Fritz Jahn =  
Fritz Anton Jahn ( 5 August 1901, Tervuren, Saxony – 29 October 1997, Tallinn, Estonia ) was a German-born Estonian botanist.  
 He studied Medicine at the University of Jena, before working for the U.S. Navy.  
 He obtained his doctorate in 1933, and in 1934 joined the Botanical Survey of the Estonian Sailing Association, becoming a member of the new Department of Internal Pollution and Hardships ( now the State Environmental Agency ). He became a senior botanist in 1947.He was then on the staff of the Estonian Ministry of Agriculture and Food. He is best known for creating and popularizing the field of Estonian physical geography.  
   
   
 == Professional affiliations ==  
 1916–1991 Chair, `` Scientific exploration of Esperanto '' at the University of Marburg, Germany  
 1922-1945 Professor of Eastern Studies, Estonian University of Technology  
 1948–1951 Head, Department of Internal Pollution and Hardships ( Estonian government )  
 1953–1960 Assistant Chief Botanist, JFRK-UMSC Botanical Research Station in Helsinki, Finland  
 1959-1966 Chief, Department of Internal Pollution and Hardships ( Estonia government )  
 1966–1972 Director of the Institute of Geodesy and Geostatistics ( Estonian government )  
 1976-1988 Editor, International Journal of National Geographic, published annually in five volumes  
   
   
 == Selected publications ==  
 1936. `` Estonian Physical Geography ''. Estonian government. Vorsklader geografisk for Dordrecht. Asiatisch-forschungsblatt. 52 : 89–96.  
 1937. `` Fennia's Tamarid ecology ''. Estonian government. Regional Environmental Ecosystems. Vol. II. No. 1. 7 ( 2 ) : 34–41.  
 1938. The longleaf pine of Estonia. Estonian government. Regional Environmental Ecosystems. Vol. II. No. 2. 7 ( 4 ) : 325–332.  
 1938. Geographical study of Estonia. East Finnmark. J. J. Kristinnis. 1 : 45–56.  
 1939. The Baltic leafy vesicae. Fennian Department. Jäga Längmanskola. Vol. 20 ( 4 ) : 533–548.  
 1940. Ecology and distribution of the sun-loving Geranthus cafferii in Estonia. Fennian Department. Jäga Längmanskola. Vol. 20 ( 5 ) : 530–532.  
 1942. Temperate flora of Estonia. Geographical and Biological Survey of the USSR. 8 : 637–651.  
 1946. Handbuch der geoder Satzgeschichte. Budapest. Z. Buchen. Ed. W. Koch. 233.  
 1948. Systematische Übersicht mit Abhandlungen und Gegenstand der Katalog des Plantes den Nordfaden und Spitzenscheidland. Beschreibung. Tierlist. Fizikandaev : 32.
