 Cortinarius leonardi Battista La Ronge's pug species ( Dicotyledon naupl. Spelti )  
 Cardiera buchdeli Battista La Ronge's cherry species ( Spathostomum laurasea Battista La Ronge )  
 Sarcoccus leonardi Battista La Ronge's pink assa B. L. Henri's flower Nueva sopra Battista ( Arilius amonnes L. )  
 Supercortinarius leonardi Battista La Ronge's passionflower  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Ulrich Wilhelm Hartung =  
Ulrich Wilhelm Hartung ( 18 July 1875 in Breslau – 13 November 1932 in Berlin ) was a German botanist. He studied botany at the University of Leipzig, where he received his habilitation in 1889. He then undertook the doctoral studies of botany at the University of Göttingen, where he received his doctorate in 1897. From 1898-1901 he was an assistant in the Botany Department at the University of Munich, and from 1902-1905 he was head of the botanical department in Botanische University Garten. From 1907-1913 he was the assistant of Flora Lange, at the Musée National d'Histoire Naturelle. From 1913-1918 he was an instructor of botany at the University of Halle. In 1920 he was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh. He was a member of the botanical society of Berlin and the Bavarian Academy of Sciences ( Fortsetzungbotanische Entwicklung, BSU ).  
   
   
 == Selected works ==  
 Über Phaeologie der Wüssverein ; 1894 - On phaeology.  
 Über eine genus Historien ; 1896 - On historien.  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Werner Solms =  
Werner Solms ( 27 May 1908 – 19 December 2001 ) was a German geologist and mining engineer. He was born in Berlin, studied at the University of Berlin, and obtained a PhD in geology and mining engineering. In 1947 he became a teacher at Hochschule Karlsruhe.  
 He is known for his work on stratigraphy, and in the mid-1970s, he and his collaborators began an ambitious geological survey in the Patagonian and Chilean mountains, the first time any work in this area had been undertaken. He was involved in mapping many sites and their stratigraphy, providing data on rare subsoil deposits in the Patagonian.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Abraham C. Gubel =  
Abraham Abba Gubel ( German : [ ˈahbubʁi ] ; 12 October 1916 – 9 July 2005 ) was a 19th-century German mathematician. Gubel is considered one of the greatest of all pure functional algebraists.  
   
   
 == Life and career ==  
 Gubel's parents were parents of two Jewish immigrants from eastern Galicia, Russian-Jewish Albert and Carrie Gubel. His maternal grandmother, Louisa Orten, was born in Austria. Her father was born in the Russian Empire. Albert was born in Germany and his mother in Heidelberg.  
   
 Gubel studied at the University of Halle and received his PhD in 1927 at the age of twenty-four. In 1930, Gubel accepted a position as a lecturer at the University of Heidelberg. This included a position on Bayes–Klein problems with Jacques Bayes.  
 Gubel became an assistant professor in 1937 at Heidelberg. During this time he married Marie Henriette ( Klindt ) Gubel, who was also a mathematician. The couple had four children : two daughters and two sons. After teaching at the University of Heidelberg for thirty years, Gubel retired in 1983. He died in Switzerland in 2005.  
   
   
 == Work ==  
 Gubel is considered to be the greatest of all pure functional algebras. He was the first to suggest the existence of `` non-atomeals '', i.e., non-decidable topological extensions to sets with spaces of nonzero numbers, as well as the existence of prime sub-sets of the product of modulo and associativity in odd-dimensional spaces.  
 In 1961, he co-authored with Theodore Boak with K. Vassiliev with `` Functions of a Different Algebraic Type '', a series of nine papers on an enumeration language ( the H-1 theorem ) that introduced the concept of permutations and permutation classes. He also contributed papers on algebraic topology, set theory, topological unification, determinants and independence, p-adic numbers, discontinuities, generalized abelian numbers, geometry, the theory of cohomology, and the geometry of sums.  
 Gubel was the founder and first editor of Algebraic Statistics ( eBASE ), and was the father of mathematician-geometricians Elena Efimov and Hans Gubel.  
   
   
 == Awards ==  
 Einsam Prize ( 1954 )  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 =  
 s C3 B3nte Jakob Brust =  
Sven Brust ( 13 February 1895 – 12 August 1975 ) was a Swedish botanist who worked in Greece.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 In 1907, Brust earned his doctorate at the University of Jyväskylä, where he published his studies of Lepidiums, Terebia and the vascular system of cardenæ ; his thesis was entitled, `` Untersuchungen über die choroiden Linien und Xenorthalia. Ärztliche Zukunft für Medizinische Angewandte. Fauna and Flora of Jyväskylä : Elektrosysthes durch gewährend und Beobachtungen des Plantes, kämpfe und apotheker Mensch zu Jyväskylä. ” In 1913, he was appointed assistant in botany at the Agricultural Institute of Stockholm. In 1923, he was appointed professor in the same institute. In 1931, he accepted a position as a professor of mycology in the agricultural and mycological institute of the Swedish Academy of Sciences in Stockholm, working for fifteen years.  
 Brust specialized in vascular systems, which became a major concern in plant taxonomy, and worked on the evolution of mycology. He made important contributions to vascular physiology and physiology of mycorrhizal fungi.  
 He authored `` Küchner um den eigenschaftlichen Anwendungen. Die Vielfertigung. Gedanken über das Ärztliche Methoden des annnnen Gegenwartes. 1. Die Zylberth. Gedanken und Fungus. Als Geographisch-biologisch-physiologisch-tibelle, 1908, Stuttgart : Kämpfe. `` Küchner um den eigenschaftlichen Anwendungen. Die Vielfertigung. Gedanken über das Ärztliche Methoden des annnnen Gegenwartes. 2. Die Urgesic und Bildung. Gedanken und Fungus. als Geographisch-biologisch-physiologisch-tibelle, 1909, Stuttgart : Kämpfe. `` From a Walk on the Street. Leipzig : Marx-Engels Verlag. 1898.  
 A teacher of Andreas Hedin, he was also a popular teacher of young students.In 1971, Brust was appointed to the scientific post of chairman of the Faculty of Agriculture, Ethnology and Botany at Uppsala University, succeeding Gudrun Gährenwald. He died in 1975.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Madeleine Marini =  
Madeleine Isabelle Marini ( 28 January 1864 – 5 March 1954 ) was a Swiss born artist, whose work became very popular in Switzerland.Marini moved to Geneva in 1878 and worked for a couple of years as a model and was sculptor. In 1900, she married Pierre Iolander Marini and in 1914, they divorced. She died in Geneva in 1954.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Madeleine Marini was born in Reichenau. She graduated from the Ecole des Beaux Arts in Paris in 1888 and got the degree of juris doctor from the University of Geneva in 1889. Her father was a professor of forestry in Faubourg St. Germain, who encouraged Madeleine to study medicine, where she studied under Marcel Dupré. From 1896 to 1913 she was at the court of the Austro-Hungarian royal family in Fribourg. In 1913 she went to the United States to complete a doctorate under Eduard Brynn in New York, followed by a trip to London.In 1903 Marini began studying at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and was admitted as a student in 1909. In 1912 she met her husband, Pierre Iolander Marini, who was studying at the École Royale des Beaux Arts in Paris. In 1915 she visited Switzerland to study natural history. In 1916 she married Pierre Iolander Marini and in 1919 she started studying under Eduard Brynn in the Netherlands.  
   
 In 1920 Madeleine Marini's thesis on the sexual life of moths was published in the scientific journal Odontologie in her herbarium. From 1923 she continued her studies in Zoology at the Collège de France in Paris and received her doctorate in Zoology in 1927. She moved to Switzerland in 1927 to complete her dissertation on the behavior of the aurochs ssp. luna in an unsuccessful attempt to explain the connection between spermatogenesis and carpal tunnel syndrome, but in 1931 she returned to the United States to complete her master's thesis.In 1927 Marini created two portraits of the painter Pierre Iolander Marini, one of the twin portraits is in the residence of Marini's widow Marie Brachette. She died in Geneva in 1954.  
   
   
 == Selected work ==  
 The visual representation of sexual reproduction in invertebrates was her best known work. The `` insects and moths of artistic promise '', originally published in 1904 in issue no. 40 of the `` Zoologie der Deutschen Museen der Naturforschenden '', consists of seventy five black-and-white plates of simple insects and moths, depicting many specific behaviors of the species. The plates are engraved by Martine Le Botanique de Cashel and Bernhard Höss with an index and other color engravings and the book contains 1,128 plates, each of which contains a different view of the insect and/or moth in the observer's frame. In the following decade her writings on the mating behavior of marine gastropods and aquatic and terrestrial gastropods in the `` Geographische Beschreibung '' were collected.  
   
   
 == Honors ==  
 In 1924, Marie Brachette Corbin was given the honor of naming the larva of Etheoprys corbini, one of the first genera of teal in nature.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = David A. Evans =  
David Anderson Evans ( 9 April 1919 – 4 February 2008 ) was an Australian Anglican clergyman and radio broadcaster. He is recognised for his role in the establishment of the Children's Ministerial Advisory Service.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 He was born in Sydney.  
 His father was the Reverend Dr Bruce C. Evans of Westonstone in the northeast of Sydney, New South Wales, Australia. He had left school at a very young age and was an accountant before entering Christ Church. His education was interrupted by World War I, where he joined the Rangoon Volunteer Volunteer Force.  
 When the war ended in 1918, he was recalled to Christ Church for ordination to the ministry. Evans served in St Helens, New South Wales, until his retirement in 1938. He remained a missionary until 1948. He was a member of the City of Christ Council from 1919 to 1948, and was a delegate of the Anglican Diocesan Conference from 1949 to 1964.  
 In 1968, he was given an honorary Doctorate of Divinity by Christ Church.  
 His later years were spent in Wollongong.  
   
   
 == Awards and honours ==  
 In May 1979, he was made a Member of the Order of the British Empire for his services to the Anglican Church, for his own works in Canterbury, and for his international work.  
 Evans served as a president of the Synod of Rt Revd Phil's in Kent from 1980 to 1987, and also as president of the Australian Episcopal Conference from 1978 to 1981. He was a general secretary of the United Methodist Society from 1970 to 1973. He was also president of the Church and Society Council from 1964 to 1974.Evans was made a Companion of the Order of St Michael and St George in 2001 by the Archbishop of Canterbury, Archibald Campbell, Lord Prudent and represented the Archbishop's chair on the Anglican Constitution Council from 1974 to 1981.Evans was appointed a Companion of the Order of St Patrick in 1984.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 =  
Hans d ( am ) Harvefort =  
Hans d'Arcaus ( 1817-1864 ) was a Swiss mathematician and researcher. In 1844 he received his habilitation, but the same year, he returned to Switzerland to become a professor of geometry in Zurich.Starting in 1845, Hans d'Arcaus was active in the French Revolution, which did not coincide with the time in which modern mathematics was born, but still required theoretical experimentation.  
 In 1848 he published a paper on the dualism of the diffraction patterns of the refraction of light and was considered one of the pioneers of physical mechanics. By 1852, he was the first person in Europe to describe the mathematical and mechanical basis of quantum mechanics. In 1857, he invented his landmark device, a glass telegraph. In 1867 he founded and was made a member of the Institut für Insektenphysik, the official Swiss instrument of the Society of Arts and Sciences.  
 Hans d'Arcaus died in Zurich.  
   
   
 == Selected works ==  
 Annalen der mathematischen Behandlungen. I. Beitrag zur Lebenswissenschaften der allgemeinen Dynamik. In : Jahresbericht über die Bemerkungen des mathematischen Entwicklungszusammenhangstes ( Hamburg 1847, S. 9 ) : II. Reise. 50.  
   
   
 == Family ==  
 Hans d'Arcaus married Dorothea, daughter of Heribert-Franz Ludwig and Dorothea Schiff-Deutsch. They had a son who also became a physicist.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Friedrich Barringer =  
Friedrich Barringer ( 7 February 1821 – 15 July 1918 ) was a German classical composer.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 He was born in the town of Wernau ( today Wernburg ) in the Saale. He studied music in Wiesbaden under Paul Busser and obtained a certificate in 1849. The following year, he moved to Basel to study under Alfred Schmitt. At Basel, he also made opera on the ideas of Friedrich Christoph Risberg and achieved success in 1830. A little over a year later, he was appointed professor of music at the University of Munich.  
 In 1852 he became a full professor of composition at the University of Hamburg. He then was appointed as director at the Imperial Grammar School in Berlin. There he worked for twelve years, mostly during the four years of the Second Republic. In 1858, he was appointed director of the concertmastership at the newly opened Institute for Musical Education at the University of Vienna.From 1873 he was actively engaged in the musical services of his government. He served in several capacities, serving as chairman of the German Academy of Arts and Sciences, giving lectures and conductions on music, and presiding over public performances and exhibitions.  
 He died in Vienna in 1918.  
   
   
 == Selected works ==  
 Accademia grandi Opera San Pietro ( Munich, 1868 )  
 Lyric Opera, libretto by Georg Friedrich Klug, opera in three acts, libretto by Otto Brüderer ( Munich, 1869 )  
 Orchestra and orchestra, libretto by Philipp Gottlieb Eichhorn ( Munich, 1875–76 )  
 Sonata in C minor for solo piano and orchestra ( Munich, 1876 )  
 Eight sonatas for piano, cello, bassoon and orchestra ( 1876 )  
 Dramatic ballet Overture and Variations for Piano and Orchestra, libretto by Daniel Langworthy ( Munich, 1884 )  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Barbara Kasparz =  
Barbara Kasparz ( 1881–1942 ) was a Polish ethnologist, writer, and radio producer, best known as one of the earliest female participants in the “ Women of Poland ” radio shows.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 In 1898, Kasparz was raised by her grandmother and educated at a women ’ s school in Warsaw. After that, Kasparz began working as a assistant to her uncle, a painter, in the Industrial Factory, Warsaw. She then began studying archaeology, history and geology at the University of Warsaw, then moved to the United States.  
 In November 1903, Kasparz joined the Polish musical band SCVZ with her brother, Zborowski. She later decided to play the violin instead of the piano, and after two months spent performing, the director of the music group asked her to sing his voice, which she had begun to practice to accompany her band. She also sang in the Polish New Wave of music. She also received honors from the Polish government for her role as an accompanist in the naturalist society, at least three times. While in the United States, Kasparz received a Ph.D. from the University of Wisconsin, where she was an assistant to anthropologist Pavel Metzger, who taught her about archaeology, ethnography, and gypsum, among other things. During the first decade of the 20th century, she also taught Russian literature and ethnography at the University of Paris. As of the early 1960s, she held the position of academic advisor at the Women ’ s Institute of the Smithsonian Institution, where she taught a class on the pug language.  
 Kasparz traveled to Europe, particularly to Denmark, where she worked as an assistant to Dr. Jens Beck. She returned to the United States in 1909 to become an assistant at the University of Chicago. In 1908, she became the first woman to teach at the University of Michigan's history department. Her maiden name was Barbara Altmann, after the Australian agronomist, poet and novelist. She went on to teach geography and history at the University of Michigan ( and remained there for several years ).In 1921, Kasparz married the historian and professor of archaeology Dr. Robert Altmann. Their son, Roland Kasparz, went on to become a noted historian of science in his own right. They both became fluent speakers of French. In 1936, Dr. Altmann died. Dr. Kasparz kept on writing until her death in 1942. She also edited, co-wrote, and made recordings of radio broadcasts in Poland.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Gogol (theologian) =  
Gogol ( Ukrainian : Ивайорь Ивад, 7 October 1872 in Litín, Lviv Oblast – 4 October 1948 in Kiev ) was a Ukrainian theologian, academic, and politician.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 He studied philology and literature in the field of ancient history at the Kiev State University ( now the Kiev Higher Secondary School of philology and literary history ), from where he graduated in 1902 and proceeded to Kiev State University where he also earned the thesis Svoboda kapoja hojese polivona ( 1894–1901 ).In 1904 he accepted a job as a missionary of the Church of the Serbs in the Transcaucasus. From 1904 until 1920 he was in charge of the missionary school in Zhytomyr. Between 1910 and 1916 he was a member of the Kiev State Academy of Fine Arts and the Kyiv State University.  
   
   
 == Army service ==  
 He was conscripted in the First Ukrainian Civil War ( 1914–1920 ). On 9 November 1916 he was active in this war as a reservist in the Special Section of the 18th Migratory Field Regiment. As a reservist he carried out cartographical reconnaissance and made many battlefield collections, including 1097 tactical plans of the Crimean War.  
 He returned to the Kiev State University in 1920 after the Army of Occupation came to power. He taught in the Kiev State University for some time. In 1929 he was selected to the head of the Kiev School of Oriental Languages. Gogol's job there was to promote the spread of the Ukrainian language and thereby revive the Ukrainian culture and the cult of Cossack legend.  
   
   
 == Family ==  
 In 1897, during his boyhood, Gogol married Dorothea Leletzy ( 1879–1959 ), from Lviv. Their daughter, Alexandrna Leletzy, became a political activist and a renowned musician.  
   
   
 == Honours ==  
 Gogol received the honorary title of Hero of Socialist Labour, Russian Imperial Order of Merit, Lenin Prize, the Alexander Solomon Severo-Abravanel Prize of the Lenin Prize and the Kirov Prize of the Faculty of Oriental Languages of the Kiev State University.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 Gogol, Tula. Tula from the 15th century to 1859.  
 Берсоль ( 1900 ). Ивайорь Ивад ( 2 vols. ).  
 Александрович на пуласёт ( Лг. Л.1899 ). Ивайорь Ивад ( 2 vols. ).  
 Александрович на пуласёт ( Лг. Л.1900 ). Ивайорь Ивад ( 2 vols. ).  
 Александрович на пуласёт ( Лг. Л.1901 ). Ивайорь Ивад ( 2 vols. ).  
 Берсоль ( 1904 ). Ивайорь Ивад ( 2 vols. ).  
 Александрович на пуласёт ( Лг. Л.1905 ). Ивайорь Ивад ( 2 vols. ).  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Andr C3 A1 C3 A7 Dijkstra =  
André van Dijkstra ( 6 November 1864 – 21 February 1946 ) was a Dutch economist, politician, entrepreneur, diplomat and businessman.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Van Dijkstra was born in 1864 in Maastricht. He graduated from the University of Leiden and moved to Geneva in 1888. In 1890, he became a Member of the Belgian Republic and in 1900 a French Commissioner of the Gendarmerie.  
 From 1904 to 1913 he was Minister of Finance in the Weimar Republic. In 1918, he became a Member of the Council of the International Monetary Fund. In 1927, he was the founder of the Netherlands-based Society for International Economic Cooperation ( Zidervijk Scientiek in De Nederlandsche Trade ).In 1938, he succeeded Lord Bernadotte to the Austrian seat in the Privy Council ( Ratification ). From 1945 to 1957, he was the new member of the Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences ( Amtvrouw Amt ).On 1 July 1950, he became member of the board of directors of Suez Canal Bank ( SBC ). He also held offices of the Reichsbank and the Prussian Reimbursement Ministry ( `` reine Bank '' ) and served as Deputy Minister of Education from 1954 to 1959.In the past 30 years, he became a prime author of many papers. He was elected as a member of the Dutch Academy of Science and Letters in 1957. He was a recipient of the Prize de la Haute Couture in 1958. He was elected honorary member of the Royal Dutch Academy of Arts and Sciences in 1963.  
   
   
 == Dreyfus case ==  
 Van Dijkstra worked with lawyer and prosecutors Norbert von Dreyfus on the Frankfurter Rundschau ( Fair Trade Trade Agreement ) ( 1930–1932 ) and later also the World Trade Organization ( WTO ). For this, he was given a seat on the judge's panel of arbitrators at the Commission of Experts ( Formenbondenverwaltungsbundesrat ). The precise wording of the negotiations became known after the second trial of Brussels Prosecutor Herman Van Espen, which is alleged to have been the coverup of a criminal investigation by Dreyfus and Goudsmit, second in rank.  
 Van Dijkstra was member of several joint service projects at the Ministry of Defence ( Pieter Hooft ) and the Ministry of Transport ( Rijks Meeressebrouw ), for which he worked extensively on investigation of rail passenger and cargo operations. He also served as one of the principal experts on the waste problem at the three public utilities and on the semiconductor industry, as well as under the directors of Dutch companies.  
 In addition to works, Van Dijkstra founded his own company in 1912 as Consultancy Bijen Edin. He was also a major shareholder in the film and television company Ansteych, later merged with Citybus Holding.  
 He was well known for his social democratic causes and was elected as a member of the United Left Party ( ENVP ) in the 1956 general election.  
   
   
 == Personal life ==  
 Van Dijkstra married twice. He died at his home in Haarlem in 1946, aged 86.  
   
   
 == Bibliography ==  
 J. K. Paulsch, N. Schulz, W. P. Ruben, R. Wijters, D. J. van Gelderen ( 2006 ). The Struggle for Market-oriented Government : The Amsterdam Agreement. Amsterdam : Amsterdam University Press. ISBN 978-1-63911-1122-8.  
 R. J. Erbl, D. O. Duypenhout, M. A. Jansen, R. J. van Hise, E. van de Weever, H. van Leeuwenhoek ( 2006 ). A Historical Description of the Trade of Antigua & Barbuda. Amsterdam : IJEUB. ISBN 978-1-5972-1056-5.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Wilbur Rutherford =  
Wilbur Rutherford ( 1854–1921 ) was an American crystallographer and naturalist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Rutherford was born in Salem, New Hampshire. In 1888, he attended The New York Academy of Sciences in New York City and earned a Bachelor of Arts degree there in 1894. He was a student of Professor Samuel Bell ( 1825–1888 ), who was working on his education at the Academy when he became interested in crystallography. Rutherford decided to study law, but he returned to his undergraduate studies at the Academy to complete the degree requirements. After graduating with a BA degree in 1897, Rutherford worked for thirty years as an assistant to Professor Edmond Lee Kinch, a crystallographer and illustrator for the NY Academy. In 1917, he became an instructor and one of the founding faculty members of the Department of Crystallography at Columbia University.After retiring in 1936, Rutherford continued to give lectures and was a member of the Division of Crystal Genetics at Harvard University until his death in 1921. He received the Agnes E. Hasse Memorial Medal from the American Society of Crystallography.  
   
   
 == Theology ==  
 Rutherford's chief interest was in the Christian God and Old Testament revelation. Although he considered himself primarily a Biblical scholar and a personal friend of S. F. Rinehart, who was Rutherford's classmate in Columbia, Rutherford's theology was shaped by a lifelong study of deism and was influenced by Aristotelian philosophy. He explored and produced the theosophical groupings and monistic dimensions in his contributions to the deistic group. His first book was Deism in America. He became a member of the Carl E. Schmitt Academy of Religion in Boston in 1915, and a member of the New York Academy in 1924. Rutherford married Sarah Jane Donlan in 1893.  
   
   
 == Selected works ==  
 Rutherford, Wilbur ( 1904 ).  
 Ruther, Wilbur ( 1905 ). The Word God in its Natural Form.  
 Rutherford, Wilbur ( 1906 ). The Word Creator in History : The Origin of Man and Language.  
 Rutherford, Wilbur ( 1908 ). Songs of a Modern Misanthrope : A Study of Christian Songs in the Tradition of Classical Greece.  
 Rutherford, Wilbur ( 1912 ). The Gospel of Philip.  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Orazio Bonaglia =  
Orazio Bonaglia ( 17 July 1891 in Milan – 25 June 1949 in Rome ) was an Italian psychologist.  
 Bonaglia earned his Ph.D. in 1897 from the University of Bologna. He studied under Silvano Gesner and with John B. McIntyre in Copenhagen. He served as the Dean of the Faculty of Psychology and Mental Health at the University of Milan from 1934 to 1945 and at the University of Siena from 1946 to 1957. He served as a Professor at the University of Siena from 1948 to 1957, Director of the La Sapienza Permanente ( Italian Electrotherapeutic Institute ) in Milan from 1953 to 1966, and as a Director of the Hospital del Veneto in Rome from 1968 to 1975. He is a member of the Academie de Pathologie Psychiatrie in Siena, CIBM and the Comitato dei Ricerche da Roma.  
 His main interest was the treatment of depression and obsessive-compulsive disorders. He gave the lectures in psychiatry at Milan's Istituto di Neuropsychologia Università di Milano, the Cavalleria Giuliana of Naples, and the University of Padua. From 1932 he served as president of the Italian Society of Psychiatry.  
 Bonaglia died in Rome.  
   
   
 == Family ==  
 Bonaglia married Sallie Keene, daughter of George H. Keene and Mary V. Taylor, of Albany, New York. They had one daughter, Florence K. Gaffigan, who married Harry M. Kline, Vice President, Mathematics and Statistics Division, Lockheed Corporation.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Maureen Paterson =  
Maureen Paterson, A Grade Recordings Producer ( 1965-1994 ), was a recorded music producer, music historian and media consultant in Winnipeg and throughout Canada.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 Paterson studied classical music at the Toronto Conservatory with Alberto Roca and at the Juilliard School under William Schumann. She took her degree in English from McGill University in 1972. In 1976, she founded the only music recording studio in Manitoba, and was soon managing the firm. She was re-elected to the Manitoba Music Council in 1985, and was elected to the Manitoba Board of Directors in 1992. She also served as the president of the Manitoba Music Board from 1996 until her death in 1994. Paterson helped the Music Archives of Canada, and the Winnipeg Music Council, to produce a master's volume on jazz, based on the 1934 work of Gene Autry. Her piano playing included a solo performance of Louis Boulez'Violin Concerto No. 2.She was a teacher at the Weston School of Music. She also taught at Rosedale School of Music. She died in Winnipeg at the age of 90.  
   
   
 == Research ==  
 Paterson was one of the first researchers at Music Archives Canada. The purpose of her research was to `` create and revitalize a lost art, through research, analysis, development, and editing, building the foundation for a larger, more rewarding career, and to engage with the public as scholars, practitioners, educators, media. ''  
   
   
 == Legacy ==  
 To honour Paterson, the yearbooks of all three libraries of the Musique de Manitoba are dedicated to her. She was awarded a National Distinction in 1978 from the Canadian Public Libraries Association, a state recognition. In 2005, the Manitoba Music Council's first anniversary celebrations honored Paterson, by creating an exhibition and public lecture entitled `` Paterson : A Public Biography '' in recognition of her contribution to the history and promotion of the music in Manitoba. The Alberta Heritage Centre presents an award presented by Paterson.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = David G C3 BClly =  
David Guelly ( English pronunciation : [ dʒɛn ʒille ] ; 22 May 1934 – 7 August 2003 ) was a British cleric and cultural theorist. He taught at the London School of Economics and was a chaplain to George W. Bush and President Bill Clinton. He is best known for his book The Sacred Promises and the Pathway to Suicide, which explores the writings of Charles Spurgeon in the eighteenth century.  
   
   
 == Early life ==  
 Guelly was born in Cirencester, Gloucestershire, England, the son of David Thomas Guelly and Janet McDougall. He was educated at Trinity College, Oxford where he became the acting head of pre-history when he was nineteen. He subsequently became a Christ Church student, becoming a Fell student in 1960, and gained a BA in mathematics from Oxford in 1964. He was educated at King's College London and subsequently King's College London.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 In 1971 he became an adviser to Dr William Colenso on the literary aspects of contemporary religion and spirituality. He was one of the founding editors of The Sacred Promises, which was first published in 1993, and it was followed by 13 editions from 1993 to 2007, and in 2010 by a special edition, in which he explored modern spiritual practices. This was the subject of a TV documentary, Non-Euclidean Psychosis, on Channel 4 in the UK.He was a Fellow of St George's Hall, Westminster and a guest lecturer on the subject of contemporary religions at Christ Church, Oxford, and the National University of Ireland, Cork.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Jan Meyers =  
Jan Meyers ( February 11, 1921 – February 10, 2006 ) was an American ethnomusicologist. He was co-founder of the Australian Ethnomusicological Society.  
 Meyers studied with Herbert R. Mark and Phillip Politzer. He is best known for his contribution to ethnomusicology, the study of folk music. He spent the majority of his career as a vocal pedagogue, developing the `` musical repertoire '' ( his terms ) as the basic vehicle to assemble musicians in accord with indigenous cultural roles. By the late 1950s Meyers had amassed a great array of non-Western music sources, each of which has since been classified as an ethnographic artifact. His field studies revealed the diversity of music he was encountering, and included several genuises of indigenous culture that he took to radio to the public. These include the pothibe Kwayi, the Japanese chakot ( first peoples ), the Haida ( later homo sapiens ), and the Chinook ( later humans ). It is primarily his collections of oral traditions of ethnographic and musical contexts that are the major source of evidence for ethnocentricity in all the peoples and groups for whom he is best known.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Born in 1913 in Lexington, Virginia, Meyers grew up in Tennessee where he was a part of a prominent Christian church. Meyers attended Mount Lebanon High School, starting at the top of his class in 1951. In 1953, at the age of 14, Meyers became a member of the second section of the Lutheran Church in America. After reading C. J. Pournelle's books, he read Dorothy Schuster's The Harvest. Meyers was a first year student at Concordia College in Tuscaloosa, Alabama in 1958. In the Spring of 1959 Meyers received his B.A. and M.A. in English Literature from Concordia College. The same year, Meyers moved to Eugene, Oregon where he worked as a youth pastor. In 1960, after several years teaching pre-kindergarten through graduate school at Oregon State University, Meyers earned a teaching assistant position with the North Shore Conference of Christian Youth in Eugene, Oregon. Meyers also completed his first teaching gig at Southern Oregon Academy, during which time he also began his scholarly and ethnographic studies.  
 Meyers began to pick up his first specimens of these diverse and unco-ordinated cultural collections when he was 14 years old. He carried the material into work as a teacher, and began collecting on his own. One of his first books was `` The Passing of the Rose Woman '' ( 1978 ). This collection was purchased in November of 1978 by the Seattle Folklore Society in collaboration with him and Herbert Meyers. In 1977, he joined the Oregon Ethnological Society. In 1980, he was invited to serve on the advisory board of the Ethnographic Society of Washington and In 1981 he received a chair at Seattle University of the Pacific. In 1982, he received the journal `` Folklore '' from the Ethnographic Society of Washington. He soon formed a cultural exchange program at the Seattle Urban Ethnographic Laboratory and the Seattle Symphony Orchestra.  
 Meyers was a Professor of English Literature and Anthropology at the University of Oregon and Ethnography Professor at the University of Washington, which allowed him to travel in the world. Meyers was particularly interested in the ethnomusicological corpus of people on his travels and developed an ethical approach to his field. In 1973 he received the John Simon Guggenheim Fellowship for his studies on Indigenous Australian music.  
 Meyers retired from his position as lecturer and academic director of the Anthropology Department at the University of Oregon in 1988. His final assignment was to produce a popular book on songbirds. Meyers designed a curriculum that supported students from year to year, which contained the `` instrument-object duality '' of songbirds, making `` a working tool and experimentation tool '' that allowed students to be well prepared for `` a live-in. very lively and adventurous listening experience. '' In 1996, Meyers accepted a post as vice-president of the Institute of the North Pacific at Western Oregon University.  
   
   
 == Publications ==  
 Selected publications include :  
 ( with Nathaniel Price ) Songs and Their Sketches from Aitken ( 1949 )  
 Monographs of Australian Songbirds ( 1951 )  
 Survey of Far North Island Songbirds ( 1960 )  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = John Bush =  
John Bush ( 11 January 1907 – 26 March 1995 ) was a Canadian geologist and mining engineer.  
 Bush graduated from the University of Alberta with a degree in geology in 1931. He became the Vice-President of Oil Sands Research in 1928. He remained with the company for the rest of his life.  
 Bush worked for MacPherson Oil from 1931 to 1941, as well as for Baker Hughes, Rio Tinto, Rio Tetra and Prudential. He worked in Norway where he explored for oil and gas.  
 Bush died in Philadelphia.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Arnold ( Thomas ) Lane =  
Arnold Stanley Lane FRS ( 30 June 1883 – 16 October 1965 ) was a geologist, author and proponent of the science of stratigraphy. He was born at St John's ( London ), the son of a stockbroker. He studied at the University of Glasgow, then became a civil servant for the newly created Prince of Wales and Queen Mother of the United Kingdom. He wrote his first textbook ( Britannia Geologica ) in 1925.  
 He published the monumental book Botany of Britain in 1930, with illustrations by Maurice Ewing and Richard Holden, followed in 1932 by his Phytolithographie ( Polyglot Geography ). In 1929, he published :  
   
 The Geology of the Aegean and of the Mid-ocean, a survey of Iceland, in four parts ( Leyland Geografie )  
 Geology of London, where the wells of the Inner Temple are constructed  
 Atlas of the Eocene of North England and a map of the whole state in marble plates  
 Table Topography of the Theresian and Magdalen Trench districts and their topography, including the level plate of Tyrcolyte.  
 The Stone Age in the Pyramids of Luxor. With an introduction by E. B. Whittaker  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 At Oxford, he became head of the Department of Geology in 1924 and by 1930, became a faculty member. He resigned from Oxford in 1938 due to an illness. He was made a CBE in 1950 and a Fellow of the Royal Society in 1953, he received a CB in 1965.After the Second World War he returned to Scotland, where he spent much of the remainder of his life. He was the President of the Scottish Association for the Advancement of Science from 1959 to 1967. He died in St John's, London.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Thomas Gerard Todd =  
Thomas Gerard Todd ( 7 August 1631 – 16 August 1705 ) was an English theologian, chaplain, and translator of the Bible into Latin.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Todd was the son of Dr. Thomas Gerard Todd ( 1st Duke of Burgundy ) and his wife Janet. His father, aged 36, was brought up in Dalrymple House, and was canon to St. Paul's Cathedral. He was baptised at Horsham. He attended his father's father-in-law's collation at the Collegiate Institute, Cambridge, from 1665 to 1668, as translator of the Psalms into Latin ( worked under Rev. Richard Ward ), and studied under Francis Barbadier on divinity under John Ellis, afterwards manager of the Grammar School in Berkeley.  
 On 17 September 1670 he was appointed chaplain of St Peter's Church, Cambridge, and continued his duties there for five years. He lived at St Paul's Chapel, under Sir William Petty ; he began preaching in November 1677, but was still unable to obtain the esteem of his chaplain and successor, by the time of his conversion.  
   
 In 1682 the court of Ingolstadt fell into a bad state of disorder, and the royalists suffered a great loss, having expelled King Ferdinand of Austria and his guests from the capital.Todd was selected as guardian to the Duchess of Baudry ; he was transferred on 9 February 1683 from the monastery to Berkeley, and took the occasion of his high decorations to answer a petition to ordain `` an instructor for the office of ministrant in the churches of the so-called party of high treason '', requesting a special commission for the maintenance of the indigent, for the revival of ancient confessions, and to assist the peasants, and a passage was made for him.  
 The appointment of Thomas Gerard Todd was approved, and two dukes of Burgundy presented him to succeed him, Sir Christopher Wyke, the heir presumptive, and the next November Todd became moderator of the English East India Company. In the same year his brother William Todd, his cousin, was also summoned and a commission was obtained for him. In September 1688 he was appointed a chaplain, and so prosperous was he that he never applied for a commission again. The council of the Church of England of London considered a commission for him, and on 15 March 1689 he was created patron to William Hutton, 2nd Baron Hutton.At the fall of Charles I in 1689 Todd was summoned to Newington Hall.  
 He received his degree of B.D., on 16 June 1690.  
 After the death of his father he died on 16 August 1705, aged 64, in Loughborough, as was the custom of the time.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
   
   
 === Historical works ===  
 The English Chronicle of the Time of Henry IV ( 1652 )  
 Remonstrance against the Praying at the Christmas Gospel : Second Br., ( 1653 )  
 Declaration of Rights and of the Interests of the English People ( 1659 )  
 Scrapings and Polyglots, translated from the Latin ( 1673 )  
 Manichaeism ( 1683 )  
 His Latin Alphabet translated into Latin ( 1705 )  
 ( 1826 ) Loci Statamen : his Ettinas sunt ( 3d ed. 1856 ).  
   
   
 === Veneration, images and monuments ===  
 Warming Lights for the 16th century, the first edition of which was sold at an auction at Sotheby's by Martin Fox, Oliver Swallow, Oliver Garrod, Thomas Howarth and John Carberry.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Margaret Whitney Hewitt =  
Margaret Whitney Hewitt ( 1910–1985 ) was an American botanist.  
 Hewitt was born in Providence, Rhode Island. She completed her undergraduate studies at Harvard University. She worked as a biology assistant in Alaska and was named in her honor.She worked as an instructor at Brown University from 1925 to 1931 and was one of the first women to be elected to its staff. She served as a professor at Harvard from 1931 until 1973. She died in Providence, Rhode Island.  
   
   
 == Publications ==  
   
   
 === Articles ===  
 A Plateau of American Plants ( 1936 )  
   
   
 === Selected publications ===  
 Studies in Meliodrama ( 1940 )  
 The European Warbler ( 1951 )  
 The Fruitful Harvest of New York State ( 1956 )  
 The African Spiny Bush ( 1959 )  
 The Geese of Africa ( 1961 )  
 Some Botanical Details of Midway Island, New York ( 1961 )  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = John Smeaton =  
John Smeaton FRS FRSE ( 6 December 1832 – 12 November 1913 ) was an Irish naturalist and ornithologist.  
 Born in Ballinamore, County Tipperary, Ireland, he was educated at Navan School. After a career with coal toil, shipping and trade, he earned a doctoral degree in Zoology from the University of Cork in 1879. He spent some time working in France and Germany before returning to Cork in 1886, and in 1894 made his home in South Dublin. He worked at the National Zoological Institute until 1914, when he moved to the University of Dublin.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 He was the editor of the Irish Naturalist, a periodical which he edited for many years. He wrote on all things Irish, botany, and science ; being the first to bring the Irish naturalist under the scientific microscope. He also published `` Antiquitæ Irisha '' and `` Irish Naturalists, '' notes by and about naturalists.  
   
   
 == Selected works ==  
 Smeaton, John S. 1879. The Mosasaur and other marine reptiles. 3rd ed., Dublin : James Patterson & Co., plates by O'Davies and Gibbon.  
 Smeaton, John S. ( 1901 ). `` An Italian Penguin of Science ''. The Irish Naturalist, 24 : 87–88.  
 Smeaton, John S. and Joyce, Denis M. ( 1908 ). Nia ( Trichonervus maculatus ) : an Irish frog. In Cornish, Henry ; Kinnaird, Edwin ( eds. ). Monograph on Nia na Fhegoglor ( Pycnothrymmes maculatus ). Dublin : John Quigley.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Nathaniel George Sharpe =  
Nathaniel George Sharpe ( April 21, 1809 – April 3, 1884 ) was an American zoologist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Sharpe was born in Niles, Ohio. He graduated from Columbiana Normal College in 1823 and became secretary of the Michigan Academy of Sciences in 1832. From 1834 to 1837, Sharpe was professor of natural history at Indiana University. In 1838, he was appointed a member of the Ohio Geological Survey, and was curator of the Ohio museum, building on the work of John F. Surratt. Sharpe received his PhD in natural history from the University of Chicago in 1840. After retirement in 1845, he made a tour of Europe, Australia, and South America in order to study the animals of the Pacific Islands. He returned to America in 1852 and continued to study fish biology until his death. He was the father of three children : Willard ( 1844–1905 ), Mary Augusta ( 1846–1893 ), and Cyrus F. Sharpe ( 1853–1940 ).  
 Sharpe's work is influenced by entomology. His knowledge of the different types of fish collected in the different Pacific islands, he carefully described them and published notes on them in the early 1840s. He suggested the rather extravagant, if expedient, use of the term `` lobe-finned fish '' to describe lobed fish, and to distinguish the false-water fish from the true-water species. The world's first land cod, the cod pouta ( Codus feniocephalae ), was named after him. His descriptions of the New England Lobsters ( Gastropodenia florida ) and Papillomamys variabilis ( Sostophyllum scaliber ) are also well known.Sharpe's work is a scholarly classic. Many of his papers are collected in The Lobsters of the United States and Canada. It is a significant milestone in the formation of new marine and terrestrial taxa, and is recognized as one of the classics of its time.Sharpe was the author of a number of books, including :  
   
 The Diseases of Shellfish ( 1838 )  
 Remarks on the Nomenclature and Physiology of some Fresh-Water Insects ( 1848 )  
 New Names of Certain Diseases of Fish ( 1860 )  
 Rehoboth's Fishes : An Interpretation of their Mechanism, Diet, and Characters ( 1863 )  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Johann Jakob Prüfer =  
Johann Jakob Prüfer ( 16 December 1824 – 20 February 1906 ) was a German geologist and the son of historian Johann Jakob Prüfer.  
 He was born in Rostock, but was sent to study medicine in Rostock, where he became an obstetrician and urologist, and from then on worked in the observatory at Sitzungsberichten, where he published Die Gebirgegebirge. From 1851 to 1854 he was professor at the University of Zürich, where he graduated with a doctorate in 1865. In 1865 he became rector of the alma mater. In 1873 he married Emma Stern. They had a son and three daughters.  
 Prüfer collected and analyzed sedimentary rocks in Germany and Russia, especially in the regions around Alsace and Lorraine.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = John Nicholson =  
John Nicholson ( 15 March 1768 – 30 June 1831 ) was an English physiologist. He is considered the father of New Systematics of the Human Body.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 He was born at Charterhouse, Surrey. At the age of nineteen he was employed in the Abbotsfield machine factory, and afterwards at Soho Manufactory, Boughton. In 1819 he was assistant professor at the London School of Medicine. In 1823 he was elected to the Royal College of Physicians ; from 1833 to 1841 he was president of that institution. In 1836 he was elected President of the Society of Experimental Physiologists, to which he delivered the Prospitae Cursus at their meeting at Paris on 26 August 1836.He was the author of Notes on Physiology of the Ecto-Saurian Animals, 2 volumes ( 1837-5 ), on the structure and position of the abdominal organs ; and other works. In 1841 he obtained an honorary degree from St John's College, London. He died at Soho, London, on 30 June 1831, and is buried at Norwood Cemetery in the parish of Charterhouse, Surrey.Nicholson studied natural history under Edward John Lindley at the London School of Medicine, and was awarded his M.D. in 1812. In 1816 he married Ellen Astor, daughter of John Peter Astor, 1st Earl of Orkney. They had two daughters, Lucy ( 1831–1896 ), daughter of Captain Daniel Harvey of the Sunbeam, and Aimee ( 1835–1915 ), who was a prolific author. He also had the honour of being the first cousin of the writer, Sir Charles Dickens. In 1818, when his wife Ellen Astor was suffering from ulcers, he and an obliging servant wrote to Mrs. Astor, `` I will see to it that your nephew Sir Charles Dickens gets some much to eat on Wednesday ''. In 1827 he returned to England, and obtained an invitation to become a fellow of St. John's College.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 His major work in physiology was Notes on Physiology of the Ecto-Saurian Animals ( 1837 ), which is largely regarded as the standard work in the fields of physiology and anatomy for the period. It is translated into Dutch, French, and Italian. His chief work on animal physiology was to accompany Johan Conrad von Ehrenfest's Manual der Naturgeschichte der Anatomie ; eine Systematische Anatomie ( 1827 ), published by Christiaan Huygens.  
 Nicholson's clinical observations included electrocardiograms and other electrocardiograms, and development of electrocardiograms in patients with hydrocephalus and mental retardation ; the latter were patented in the United States and New Zealand.  
   
   
 == Notes on Physiology ==  
 A popular textbook in 1819 for medical students by Sir John Keith Williams, was given by Nicholson, which was translated and given to the public in conjunction with the Association for the Advancement of Science.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Rudolf Hess =  
Rudolf Hess, also known as Rudolf Hess, ( Hebrew : דרגד יוכה‎ ; January 28, 1910 – July 20, 1994 ) was a German-Israeli physicist and author.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Hess was born on January 28, 1910 in Greifswald, where his father was a captain in the German navy. After the war, he attended the gymnasium where his father also taught.Hess completed his studies in physics at the Technische Hochschule München, and in 1947 was granted his doctorate ( doctoral dissertation ) at the Technische Hochschule Hannover under Karl Fleischmann. He became a staff member of the laboratory under Karl Fleischmann at the Max Planck Institut für Physik and the Max Planck Institute for Chemistry, in Frankfurt am Main, in 1950.  
 He participated as a research fellow and assistant director of the Max Planck Institute for Chemistry and Technology in Frankfurt from 1955 until 1963, working with Karl Fleischmann and Georg Erhard. Between 1965 and 1980, he was chief scientist of the Ministries of Industry, Trade, and Communication of East Germany.  
 He served as president of the Physical Society of East Germany from 1967 to 1971 and on numerous committees and committees of the German Society for Atomic Research from 1965 to 1980.Hess wrote a variety of scientific articles and books on a range of topics.  
   
   
 === Main works ===  
 Die Geometrie im Moduländer und selbstkontrolle durch Jungfrau-und Säugner- und Aluminium-Substitution, 1946–54, J. Zentralblattforsch. 12, 1081-1097.  
 Die Lorentzentrieb des Augen. Eine beobachtung erste Arbeiten nach Zwei Rechnung zwischen Geometrie, 1948, pp. 99–134 ; Translated by William R. Finley into English from the German  
 `` Sein der Auswahl, welche sie hat eine ländergriffliche Inhaltswertlichkeitshefte aus Geometrie, die arbeitenden Einleitung der klasse Freiheiten, '' J. C. Chem. Stud. 68, 65–84, 1958.  
 Die Technik des Westischen Polyhedrons, 1953.  
   
   
 == Selected publications ==  
 Die Mineralogie der Lattau, Annalen der Physik 1900, 5 ( 1 ) : 5–15 ; Google ScholarSee also index.  
 Die Littelfrischungen des Künstlers and their Other Materials in-Situ, and their Utilization in Various Products, in : Transactions of the Foresight Commission, 1907, 17 ( 4 ) : 331–345 ; Google Scholar  
 Die Relativität des Grundsparzummars und sein Lehre zur klimatheorie der Weihnachtscharakten und der feedgriffen Leben, 1907, 24 ( 4 ) : 374–391 ; Translated into English as The Relativität of Space in Matter, Encyclopedia of Physics, 1964  
 Ein halten Auflösung der Fernzeugung und die Vom Selbstverfahren, in : Dan. Zil. Journ. 27 ( 3 ) : 50–56 ; Google Scholar  
   
   
 == Bibliography ==  
 H. Ghabishi, `` Noaß der G. Klein, '' 8 Bull. G. Geograph. Z., 732 ( 1946 ) : 76–77 ; Google Scholar  
 Hajiri, D. ( 1997 ). `` Heinrich Grünewald et al. : Friedrich von Hess ( 1909-1995 ) ''. Polar, 7. 46 ( March ) : 267–277. doi:10.1090/s0002-9904-1999-07825-0.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Pascual Abada =  
Pascual Abada ( 1936-1999 ) was a Spanish novelist, playwright, dramaturg and politician, who published over 60 works. Abada is best known for his play Luis Sonora which dramatized the conflicts between the religious religious and agnostic tendencies in Spanish society.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
   
   
 === Early life ===  
 Pascual Abada was born in Barcelona, Spain, on 27 October 1936. Abada studied at the Universidad Córdoba and the Universidad Central de Madrid. In 1951, he studied at the University of Barcelona under the inspiration of Andrés Márquez. After graduating he moved to Madrid, where he received his habilitation in social psychology from the university. In 1963 he took his habilitation and in 1970, he was invited to teach at the Universidad Campinas. He was responsible for three collections of psychoanalytic texts.  
   
   
 === Political career ===  
 He served as the Minister of Culture and Sport and he is considered one of the key figures in the Pío Club.  
   
   
 === Politics ===  
 Abada was an opponent of the student terror, and often joined the Inter-American Congresses ( IC ). He served as president of the Commission Against Terrorist Groups from 1986 to 1989. He was a member of the Spanish Socialists of the Social Democratic Party ( PSOE ) and member of the Spanish Social Democrats of Popular Power ( PSOE-Córdoba ). He was elected as a member of the Spanish Parliament for the first time, for the Social Democrats ( PSOE ).  
   
   
 == Death ==  
 Abada died on 27 September 1999 in Madrid and was buried in the Martí del Orizuela cemetery in Madrid. He is buried at the Municipal Archives.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = James T. Thomas =  
James Terrell Thomas ( January 26, 1842 – February 22, 1928 ) was an American educator and educational theorist who was a member of the British political parties of the mid-20th century.  
   
   
 == Early life and education ==  
 Born in Milwaukee, Thomas was educated at the famed University of Wisconsin, with a dissertation on the history of seminary education. He then studied mathematics at the University of Pennsylvania, obtaining a doctorate in 1877 with a dissertation entitled `` On a Demonstration of the Symmetrical Relations of Time and Progress in Education. '' After a career at the University of Pennsylvania he taught at a girls high school. He married Tawnya Eberlein in 1883 and settled in Newport, Rhode Island, where he wrote a textbook, Introduction to Geometry, which was widely used for the next generation of geography teachers.After his success as a teacher, Thomas became a student of John Dewey in Chicago, and later moved to Pasadena, California, to work for George Morton Garvin. He also joined the Socialist Party, an organization founded in 1892, and served for a time as its chairman in Chicago. He served on the editorial board of the academic journal Progress.  
 In 1897 he was elected to the California State Board of Education, serving three terms, ultimately in 1910 and 1910–12. After being re-elected in 1912, he returned to academia to teach mathematics and history, working for the University of California at Berkeley for 30 years until his death.  
   
   
 == World War I ==  
 In 1914, Thomas was appointed principal of Pasadena High School in Pasadena, California, a position he held until his death in 1928.  
   
   
 == United States Senate ==  
 Thomas was a member of both the Social Democratic Party of America and the Union Republicans. He served in the United States House of Representatives from 1914 to 1920, and in the United States Senate from 1920 to 1929. He was considered a moderate by the Social Democrats, but the legislature defeated any provision of his Social Security Law of 1914, which would have expanded government benefits for older Americans.  
 Thomas helped develop the UC Berkeley Statistical Society, and served as its president from 1921 to 1924.  
   
   
 == C.G.S. membership ==  
 Thomas was a longtime United States Senator from California, and was one of its most prominent sponsors. In 1920, he sponsored a bill to permit California voters to choose two state parties for each district, one representing the interests of the working-class population while the other representing the interests of the wealthy and elite. The California measure failed on the California State Senate floor in 1924.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 Introduction to Geometry ( 1877 )  
 Elementary Elementary Elementary ( 1908 )  
 Geometry and Theory ( 1910 )  
 The General Theory of Combinatorics ( 1912 )  
 Encyclopedia of Mathematics ( 1917 )  
   
   
 == Bibliography ==  
 the history of American elementary education, Encyclopedia of Elementary Education ( U.S. Dept. of Education, 2010 )  
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Oded Hermani =  
Oded Hermani ( Hebrew : הסיונסיו‎ ; Hebrew : כדדוור נוחדר‎ ; December 5, 1924 – October 2, 2002 ) was a Tel Aviv University professor of analytical physics and the author of many books.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Oded Hermani was born in Tel Aviv, Israel, the son of Israeli physician Yakir Hermani, and Israelsan Themelin. He was the son of a chiropractor, Ali Helmut Hermani, and a Frenchwoman, Paula Seeff Mayer. He graduated from the University of Haifa in 1956, where he majored in physics.  
 In the early 1960s he became involved with the newly founded but then far-left politics and publishing group, Shai Yavnez, which was very loosely affiliated with the Palestinian Liberation Organization. He joined the Society for Industrial and Social Change, which he joined in 1967. In the 1970s and 1980s, Hermani influenced Israel's politics, writing for Yedioth Ahronoth, the left-wing daily newspaper. He also helped establish the ultra-orthodox religious group, Kibbutz Mordechai and was a supporter of the party and its leaders, Golda Meir and David Ben-Gurion.  
 In 1977, he became Professor of the Anatomy of Biological Systems at the University of Haifa, succeeding Omar Aydi. He was the chairman of the department of physics and was also a member of various Israeli academic societies.  
 In the 1980s, as a critic of policies of the then Israeli government, in his famous article `` The destruction of the Palestinian Left '', published in the Talmud, Hermani declared that his goal was to reduce the autonomy and cultural and ideological inferiority of Palestinians, in order to reform the Palestinian nation. In Israel, he formed the faction, People's Power, which had strong anti-Zionist and pro-Palestinian appeals. In 2004, the group received an honorary doctorate from the University of Haifa. A second international award, first given in 1985, was in 2007 to honor Oded Hermani, who was at the time a member of the International Society of Nuclear Medicine and with a PhD in theoretical physics, and was awarded the Dr. Harvester Medal of the Nuclear Medicine Association in recognition of his work in the field of molecular physics.  
 In April 2009, his daughter, Ze'ev Hermani-Dan, began working at the University of Tel Aviv as an instructor of the campus's theoretical physics department and a founding member of the PPS, now known as Tel Aviv Polytechnic Institute of Technology.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 `` Hypervalent effect of Po-fs-Pb in the Halide. '' Proceedings of the Israeli Physical Society, vol. 40, no. 2 ( December 1967 ), pp. 371–376.  
 `` A Note on the Noether-Einstein energy conservation equations. ''  
 `` Interaction of reductive discharges. '' Proceedings of the Israeli Physical Society, vol. 40, no. 3 ( January 1968 ), pp. 387–390.  
 `` A new calorimetric study of the waveform of a charge at wide-field. '' Journal of Physical Chemistry C, no. 2 ( January 1969 ), pp. 225–228.  
 `` The molybdenum and halide theoretical framework '' ( PDF ). International Journal of Quantum Chemistry. Vol. 5. 1–6. Washington, DC : American Physical Society. 1966 ; PDF ( 728 pp ).  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Howard Dyer =  
Howard Dyer ( 13 January 1899 – 6 July 1989 ) was an English-born Australian missionary, social worker and botanist. He was known for his advocacy of the liberation of women and children from slavery and sexual slavery.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Howard Dyer was born in Dudley, Greater Manchester on 13 January 1899 to Sarah Jane Dyer ( died 28 September 1986 ) and William Arthur David Dyer, a surgeon. He was educated at Leeds Grammar School. In 1928, he began working as an assistant to John Theosophical, a leader of the Americanos, the Methodist movement. In 1937, at the age of 22, he became the first man to complete the English Ministry of Liberia, but he was soon released by the British on the grounds that he had failed the Land Rehabilitation Act of 1938.As a missionary, Dyer worked on sex slave patrols in South Africa and Liberia. He also provided medical aid to Pieter Marie Lundby. In 1937, Dyer became co-author of A Sentence on the Emancipation of Slaves in Liberia ( Freedoms Press, 1948 ), which gained widespread acclaim and exposure, and was translated into 19 other languages. He served as Secretary for Uganda from 1939 to 1946. He first visited Liberia in 1935, when a British consular official arrived on the island to collect evidence of slave owners, but after this he spent almost five years working on the conversion of slaves in the country. He was awarded the Legion of Merit in 1945 and the Order of Malta in 1948.Dyer and William Smith acted as translators for the book's subsequent English edition. He was also the editor of a booklet in 1949 on Lusaka, a city in northern Uganda. It was based on a paper written by Mary McKeague Yeats.Dyer died in a searing car crash in 1989 in a medical facility in Sydney, Australia.  
   
   
 == Views on child marriage ==  
   
 Dyer wrote A Sentence on the Emancipation of Slaves in Liberia ( Freedoms Press, 1948 ). Dyer acknowledged that, because of the Great Depression, widespread child marriage was in fact common, but argued that among the population at large child marriage was unusual. He believed that the best way to end child marriage was through the government-funded Birth Control Funds.Dyer advocated the `` liberation of women from slavery and sexual slavery '', as well as `` free education and free health care for all '', using child marriage as a means to achieve these goals.He opposed the compulsory sterilization of children, and argued that the unethical practice was morally damaging. In 1948 Dyer was quoted as saying : `` … there was never any doubt that women were slaves to men, that they were tools whose use it was their own. 'Equal pay for equal work '... can never apply to women and children. I want to raise the old age of consent for the U.S. to eight. I want to raise the age of consent for the 50 states to at least sixteen. '' Dyer believed that child marriage violated human rights and `` is, by definition, unnatural and not to be tolerated. ''  
   
   
 == Publications ==  
 A Sentence on the Emancipation of Slaves in Liberia ( Freedoms Press, 1948 )  
 My Friend the Middle : A Girl as an Arab Slave ( 1967 )  
 HIV : On a Plane or in a Car ( 1966 )  
 A Sentence on the Emancipation of Slaves in Liberia ( Freedoms Press, 1948 )  
 Love and Sex in Africa : The Slave Cult in Ethiopia and Somalia ( 1963 )  
 Sex in Africa ( 1968 )  
 Many Voices for Africa ( 1969 )  
 The Future of Africa : Sexual Freedom in a European and Soviet Union ( 1972 )  
 An Alternative to Forced Parenthood ( 1978 )  
 A Scholar Looks Back ( 1980 )  
 A First in Africa : Children in Ethiopia ( 1985 )  
 Decades of Experience : Africa Confronts Nourishment ( 1992 )  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Antoniu Carucaro =  
Antoniu Carucaro ( 11 September 1850, Mocioni – 26 April 1922, Colombo ) was an Italian plant physiologist, entomologist and zoologist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Born in Mocioni, he was the son of Galvani and Lorenzo Carucaro. His father was also a distinguished entomologist and curator at the Royal Botanic Gardens of Greece and Egypt. He received his ordination in 1877 and was employed at the Lichenological Museum of the University of Genoa as a demonstrator in chemistry and zoology. In 1884 he left the position and entered the conservatory in Stettin. He was appointed scientific editor of the systematized collection of butterflies from 1800 to 1908. He was curator of the insects collection of the Archaeologia nationala delle Scienze e Lepido, where he had a special rapport with Carl A. Reichmann.  
 In 1892 he was made a professor at the University of Giusto.  
 He held an active part in the scientific life of Genoa. He was a Fellow of the Entomological Society of London, his proposers being M. Perugini, Baron Giusti, Antonio Fascagni, and Primo Di Cateli. He was awarded the German Academy of Sciences Stiftung and the Raffaele Riccini Medal in 1904.  
 He was a member of the scientific club of the Museo delle Scienze e Lepido and the Academico di Bologna. He was elected a Foreign Member of the Royal Society of Arts in 1888 and was on its Select Committee for Geology and Geophysics.  
   
   
 == Selected works ==  
 The Nature of Plant Growth, 1861.  
 Pestalozzi on the Physiology of the Zoological Traits, 1862.  
 Contributions to the art of entomology, 1862.  
 Synopsis of Paramecium ( Skynoglossum ) and Chrysias ( Combretus ) of the Annuals from northern Italy, 1863.  
 Diapertidopsis ( Apes ) from the Islands of Lombardy and Sicily ( Thracian Flagellatella ), 1864–1866.  
 Contributions to the zoological and scientific study of plant-like insects, 1866.  
 Acta zoologici di lavoro, 1871–1874.  
 Ciudad della pesova ricerca plantologiche di una razione di una cabeza plantologica della ruolo, 1873.  
 Studi plantologiche lavoro dalle polizia di una cabeza plantologica di pezzi, 1876–1876.  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Georg Adriaen Vamprit =  
Georg Adriaen Vamprit ( 10 July 1853, Oorschot – 18 August 1926, Ghent ) was a Belgian mathematician.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 He was born in Oorschot, northern Belgium and died in Ghent, Ghent County, Ghent, Belgium.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = W. M. Gordon =  
William Owen McIntyre Gordon ( 4 August 1878 – 15 December 1968 ) was an English bacteriologist and the main author of the classic book The development of mammals.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Gordon was born in Newcastle, Newcastle upon Tyne and took an early interest in botany. His father was a botanist and later employed at the University of Oxford. From 1886, he studied at Liverpool University where in 1891 he was awarded an Honorary Doctorate in natural sciences.  
 He was a member of the botanical societies of Linlithgow and Wolverhampton, and of the Zoological Society of London.He co-founded the Linnean Society in 1908, which is the society for zoologists and paleontologists. He was elected president in 1917. He contributed articles to the Proceedings of the Linnean Society and the American Association for the Advancement of Science. In 1922 he received the Linnean Medal, of which he was the first recipient. He was elected president of the British Association in 1935.Gordon died in London in 1968.  
   
   
 == Honours and awards ==  
 Gordon was made an Officer of the Order of the British Empire ( OBE ) in 1947.  
 The Major Botanical Centre at Dunhuang, China, was named after him.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Sonny Berkman =  
Sonny George Berkman ( 27 October 1891 – 20 January 1977 ) was an American economist. His official biography states that he graduated from the University of Chicago, and he also received a Ph.D. in economics from Stanford University. He was a professor of economics at Dartmouth College from 1917 to 1934.  
 Berkman served as chairman of the staff for Lyndon B. Johnson in 1946-1948. During the war, Berkman was a strong supporter of the newly created War Powers Act. Although he served under President Harry Truman, his retirement from active public service in 1945 was deferred by Truman's successor, President Harry S. Truman. During the war, he also became a member of the National Academy of Sciences.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Vilfredo Pareto =  
Vilfredo Pareto ( April 21, 1875 in Piacenza – February 15, 1960 ) was an Italian biologist. He is best known for his comparative studies of the process of evolution. His work in biology developed from his own collection of material, to the works of these men,. In particular, he showed that mutations in the algal species of lambda-antorals, permethrin, neutrophil, pectin and striata, which he had previously described in his own right,, were also responsible for their respective innovations in the algal kingdom. These substitutions resulted in the formation of new groups and phyla. An example of this was the heterotrophic genera Liolaemus and Liolaemorpha. Subsequent species of stellate alga were also called by Pareto : Sparta or Spatholite, Colegio, Canaria and Spati.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Pareto was born in Piacenza, Italy, the son of a member of the Piacenza Chamber of Commerce. He then studied at the Ecole de France and University of Padua, obtaining his Ph.D. in 1885. During the first years of his professional career he devoted much time to the publication of scientific articles in the field of his specialty, evolution, for which he became professor at Padua University in 1887. In addition to his scientific contributions to this specialty, Pareto served as an administrator at the Pontifical Catholic University of Rome, as well as being rector of that institution. He was also responsible for the prefect of the Pontifical Athenaeum, of which he served as president until his death.  
 His works in biology were wide-ranging : he published a vast series of works on the herpetology of Italy, and on the taxonomy of the bryozoans, in 1887–1890, and in 1897–1902 published a book on coral evolution. In addition to his work on evolution, Pareto made several contributions to the field of paleobiology and described a number of new genera and species of insect, such as the bryozoans Proseta and Sesi, and the stellate Hyphlaena. Pareto's contribution to the genus Helix was no less important than his study of the relative numbers and forms of the several species in that genus.  
 Pareto died in Piacenza, Italy.  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Mariano Gazzaniga =  
Mariano Gazzaniga ( October 24, 1881 – January 8, 1966 ) was an Italian scientist and politician, founder of the Sociologia Cimentale di Evoluzione cimentale dei Campini. He was in charge of the national science association of Italian students in Monterey from 1940 to 1943.  
   
   
 == Early life and education ==  
 Gazzaniga was born in Ferrara in 1881. His family was devout Roman Catholics. His father, Antonello Gazzaniga, had a brother named Paolo Gazzaniga. He studied chemistry at the university of Ferrara, in 1904 and in 1910 graduated with a degree in botany. He later went to university in Rome, where he met Patricio Colombo and Marcello Ippolito.Gazzaniga earned his doctorate in physics under the direction of Prof. Carlo Gide in Alcalá. Gide was the author of several books on theoretical physics and has been credited with the development of the concept of the Higgs boson.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 In the course of his career, he participated in numerous physical science experiments of which several papers were submitted to the prestigious Italian scientific journal Nature. In 1918, he wrote a paper with a colleague, in which they presented the results of a hydrostatic experimental mission to the Casimir Sphere at Hertz. This was followed by the discovery of what became known as the `` Echelon of Gattini Crater '' in 1929. He was one of the founders of the Sociologia Cimentale di Evoluzione cimentale dei Campini and later Chair of Sociology at the city of Monterey.  
 In 1940, Gazzaniga became Chief of the Department of Electricity, Gas and Industry, of the Federal Ministry of the Interior. He succeeded Ernesto Gatti, another classic Italian scientist, in the President of the Royal College of Science in Rome, succeeding as president in 1942. During his tenure, the power in Monterey was significantly decreased, since most students of the city were not interested in modern technology. In addition, Gazzaniga attempted to introduce a politically correct curriculum for physics, changing it to Pernilism.  
   
   
 == Scientific contributions ==  
 Gazzaniga is considered as the founder of `` modern physics '' in Italy. He defined the new phenomenon of superfluidity as follows :  
... the chemical formula of a superfluid liquid or gas, and is applied to the superfluid gas at lower temperatures, just as to a gas of flame.  
 Gazzaniga formulated this property through the chemical properties of non-equilibrium fluids. In later years he was able to prove the existence of metallic fissures with electrons similar to those present in metals. He also used the term sub-fluidity. In 1894, he introduced to Italian scientific literature the knowledge of a rare isotope of uranium that had been discovered in 1902 by Casimir Platon, showing that metals are not solid. He also co-authored the text Triumvirate ( Trio ) with Aldo Cadmium. Gazzaniga died in Monterey in 1966.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Hans Siegfried Barnhart =  
Hans Siegfried Barnhart ( 26 September 1833 in Wimpole – 16 May 1901 in Salzburg ) was a German theologian. He was a professor at the University of Salzburg from 1874 to 1878. He was especially associated with the knowledge of Deuteronomy and the New Testament. He authored a Hebrew edition of the Old Testament.  
 Barnhart was one of the first important theological commentators in the field of Neo-Lutheranism, which he considered more established than modern Protestantism.Barnhart's name is associated with the more popular episcopate of Christian Calvinists. This denomination was founded in 1792 by his fellow Lutheran theologian Ernst Gröttl. In this church and sect the episcopal see was the only one of its kind in the whole of Germany.The Anglican Bishop of Mainz, Tobias Schopenhauer, gave Barnhart the care of his Second Visit in 1849. This consisted of three years and a half and involved four churches in Mainz, two of them in Heidelberg, and seven months in England. He undertook, among other things, the preparation of an edition of the Gospels in Latin and English. He was accompanied by a lecturer on Deuteronomy, a book on the works of St. Paul, a translation of St. James, a work on the Gospels in the New Testament and a treatise on the New Testament of Paul.  
 The Bishop of Mainz had, after his father's death, inherited the family home and spare time. The reason for Barnhart's exertions, was that no attention had been paid to this naturalization law since 1840, but a law so recently forgotten was still being enforced. In 1870 the whole family moved to Hamburg, where they lodged for a year. Two years later the New Jerusalem synagogue was organized. Barnhart studied theology at the University of Tübingen, in 1876 he received his licentiate ( doctorate ) in philosophy, being ordained the same year. His ordination showed that he was one of the few authors of intellectual writing in Germany that made an effort to reconcile the religious and social outlook of the 19th century.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 Among his publications is :  
   
 Hrsg. Das Wartseutik der theologische Forschungen im XII Jahrhundert, Gotha, 1876  
 Hrsg. Systematische und Philosophischen Grammatik der Deutschen Rhetorischen Kirchen des Kirchen Lebens, Zürich, 1878  
 Eine Logik des Septuagintes der liturgischen Lehrungen, Freiburg im Breisgau, 1886  
 Die Leben des Septuagintes, Freiburg im Breisgau, 1890  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Christiaan Liebenfeste =  
Christiaan Liebenfeste ( 13 December 1792 – 5 August 1853 ) was a Dutch engraver, lithographer, and ichthyologist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Liebenfeste was born in Amsterdam, the son of the town pastor, Hendrik Schultze. He studied classical philology and humanities, initially at the Polytechnic School in Pietermaritzburg, and later at the Otto William IV University in Ghent, Belgium, where he graduated as a docent in 1802.His work as a professional engraver can be seen in the engravings which characterized the borders of his unfinished cantonments in Belgium, such as the Veneto and the Edo in the former. For more than fifty years he was employed in the engraving and designing of royal currency for the Dutch East India Company. One of the master engravers of the Lippincott & Co., Great Britain, and other companies, he died in London.Liebenfeste was a founding member of the Royal Academy of Fine Arts. He taught at the Royal Academy of Engineering in Hertfordshire, British Columbia, and created a number of significant works of art, including these, the De Jure Cruste ( 1803 ), and the Petit Ballad, based on the Bible : A Translation, Assemble at Flour, 1807.  
   
   
 == Awards and decorations ==  
 Liebenfeste's artwork was engraved and framed by Frederik Arnold de Christiaan van der Zwaag, Baron van der Zwaag of Bulkerdijk, in his Hague antiques dealer's shop, van de Valkenburg.  
 Liebenfeste was knighted in 1829 by King Louis-Philippe III in the King's Jubilee Honours.  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = William Edward Robinson (botanist) =  
William Edward Robinson ( 13 February 1795 – 3 April 1871 ) was a British botanist, known for establishing the Botanical Museum of the University of London.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Robinson was born in 1804 at Crawfords Colchester, Surrey. He was a descendant of the family of Lieutenant-Governor William Robinson, who was the founder of the botanic garden at Trelawny, south Wales. The two brothers in Robinson's ancestry, Jonathan and Benjamin William, were botanists and agricultural explorers who settled in London. Robinson went to Guildford, Essex, in 1817 to attend Lyell Grammar School, but took up the study of botany at the University of Oxford.  
 In 1822, he was appointed assistant in the garden of Trinity College, Oxford, and with Thomas Stafford died in 1833. In 1833 he was elected a fellow of the Royal Society. His work on the root system of certain plant species inspired a description by Dr. Huxley of the spicelia Neroliopsis opercularis in 1836, and in the same year became one of the first subscribers to New Naturalist ( now Puffin ) magazine.  
 He died at Whittington Hall, near Grove Hall, London.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 William was especially interested in the Alpine plants. In 1834, while living at Trelawny he published “ An Account of some Recent Wanderings from the Dolomites to the Kew Gardens, London, by a Young Officer in the Royal Artillery, under Mr. Joseph Billi, Major of Brigade 22 ( Officers'Royal Artillery, Light Artillery ), whilst in the French River on patrol, out of the view of the French Government and many other high gentlemen who know not how to deal with a scientist like myself who can not speak French '' ( i.e., Bagnall-Mansfield's The Danubian Alps ). He also wrote :  
   
 `` The butterfly ’ s most important scapeclets are found in France, in large part due to the irregular crossing of the Gulf of Cambrai from the west to the north, so as to form the often extinct Seine. Both the latter, as well as the fall of the Alps in the course of the battle, produced a terror on those parts where those crags are already seen, and consequently on the inhabitants of a coastal district, so that it was almost impossible for the soldiers who crossed them to get home, or to repose... An Army of the Napoleonic Directory should explore the almost endless Riesenschaffen of France, with as much delight and research as I shall. `` He also wrote on the Botanical Garden at Trelawny :
