<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = F. Hall =  
Frances Morgan Hall ( 27 April 1915 – 19 January 2001 ) was an American entomologist and ecologist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Hall was born in New Castle, Pennsylvania, and received a bachelor's degree in mathematics from the University of Pennsylvania in 1930 and an MA from the University of Wisconsin in 1934. She earned her PhD from the University of Chicago in 1934, focusing on the study of Larumnae. After receiving a teaching assistantship with the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, she worked on entomology at Northwestern University in Chicago, first at the Minnesota Biological Laboratory and then at the Kew Gardens Museum in Cambridge, Massachusetts. During World War II, she spent time at the United States Department of Agriculture Biological Station in Geneva, Switzerland, with Melvin Arthur. She then taught entomology at New York University ( 1955–57 ), where she was a professor of entomology until her retirement in 1984.Hall was active in the field of entomology. She co-founded the Society for General and Applied Entomology ( GEA ) in 1956.  
   
   
 == Selected publications ==  
 Hall, F. R. ; Bianchi, A. S. ( 1953 ). Lepidoptera of the Northern United States. In Lewis, W. H. ; Hamner, E. D. ; Evans, L. E. ( eds. ) : Nature, 229 ( 5544 ) : 23-32. doi:10.1038/232473a0.  
 Hall, F. R. ; Spudak, J. J. ; Daniels, C. R. ; Fischer, J. ; Mannel, A. L. ; Wiesbe, H. ; Stevens, W. ; Crampton, D. A. ; Mathews, C. ; Lee, B. E. ; McCabe, B. S. ; Purcell, J. R. ; Stancil, G. R. ( 1962 ). The Bombardier catalogue of molluscs of the United States. Massachusetts State Journal of Science, 47 ( 11 ) : 631-635. doi:10.2026/mpj.47.11.631.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Josef Fuchs =  
Josef Fuchs ( June 18, 1843 – September 7, 1915 ) was an Austrian astronomer and paleontologist.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Josef Fuchs was born on June 18, 1843 in Vienna, Austria-Hungary, to a wealthy merchant. He studied at the University of Vienna, where he obtained the degree of d.D. in 1867 and then studied at the University of Bonn, obtaining the title of Doctor of Philosophy in 1878. He taught natural philosophy at the University of Vienna for over twenty-five years. During that period he published, among other things, a catalogue of the fossils and soil rocks of northern Germany, a treatise on the Phanerobe carboniferous rocks, a description of the Sauric shells, a description of the reptile skeletons of the Lake Magdeburg area, and numerous letters and papers on paleontology. He was elected a member of the Academy of Sciences of the USSR in 1881 and received the Alexander von Humboldt Medal.  
   
   
 == Work ==  
 Fuchs is noted for his studies of Devonian Turonian, as well as the Lower Devonian and Upper Devonian isozymes, as well as for his mineralogy of the North Caucasus.  
   
   
 == Selected works ==  
 Das Kultur Begründungen der Indiekultus Insectorum ( 1869 )  
 Der Malö ( 1886 )  
 Die Mineralien von Siebenburg ( 2 vols., 1886-87 )  
 Die früheren mineralogie des Neuherzogammen ( 1888 )  
 Catalog of the Locality Orthologii, By. G. V. Gaben, etc. ( 2 vols., 1892 )  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Yevgeny Ivanovich Kunchorov =  
Yevgeny Ivanovich Kunchorov ( Russian : Леви́й Ли́вович Станович Станов ) ( January 8, 1906 – October 5, 1977 ) was a Russian plant biologist and mycologist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Kunchorov was born in the city of Borovik ( Kiev Oblast ) and studied at the University of Kaunas. In 1930 he became a professor of cytology at the Petrograd State University. In 1942 Kunchorov was appointed head of the Department of Plants and Mycology of the Bolshoi Zoological Garden. From 1953 he headed the Botanical Institute of the Bolshoi Zoological Garden in Moscow.  
 In 1961 he was awarded the Tomsk State Prize for Plant Pathology. In 1965 Kunchorov became the first director of the Bolshoi Zoological Museum in Moscow. He died in 1977.  
   
   
 == Species described by Kunchorov ==  
 Serenopsis kochiensis L. coe–Nelson, 1987  
 Demeteria kochiensis Knopp, 1953  
 Basilis kochiensis Goffer–Peters, 1964  
 Teligna kochiensis A. Dietricht, 1953  
 Mariposa kochiensis Karlašek, 1983  
 Plecta kochiensis F. Salomón, 1979  
   
   
 == Research ==  
   
   
 === Distribution ===  
 Kunchorov also described 124 species of fungi.  
   
   
 == Honours ==  
 Kunchorov is commemorated by the Imperial Russian State Plant Academy.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Walter A. Jeccu =  
Walter A. Jeccu ( October 17, 1921 – February 9, 2001 ) was an American physicist who was professor of theoretical physics at Yale University. He is known for his analysis of the CMB polarization of the subatomic region.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Jecchi was born in New York City to Brazilian and Dutch parents, and was the eldest of four children. When his father died at age thirty-eight, his mother inherited his inheritance, and upon their death, her will required that her children inherit the paternal estate. Her condition was deeply affected by war, and during her last illness she was nursed at home by a family friend who was still alive. The companion died on May 28, 1939. In 1940, Jecchi was an undergraduate at the University of Cambridge, and received a Ph.D. in 1941 under the supervision of Erwin Schrödinger. Jecchi was immediately employed at the Cavendish Laboratory, working with both then-unknown features of atomic structure, as well as the Planck–Rosen–Kepler law of gravitation, and pioneering methods for analyzing CMB polarization.  
 At Yale, Jecchi's studies led to theoretical work on the cosmic microwave background radiation, as well as the Enrico Fermi paradox, as well as theoretical investigations on the properties of subatomic particles. He received his Ph.D. in 1942 under the direction of Robert Millikan, in which the work was directed at the `` young high-energy protons '' as emitted from solar flares. Jecchi ’ s work focused on studying polarization in the CMB. For his doctoral thesis, he developed a method for the detection of very strong polarization, using an external rotating interference device. In his 1950 book ( PDF ), he argued that CMB polarization had what he termed an `` anomalous intrinsic pattern '' that favored observations of structural groupings, which he labeled “ electromagnetic sideshifts ”. Although the illusionary symmetry of light polarization did not have profound implications for cosmic particle physics, Jecchi believed it to be a problem that was “ worthy of careful study. ” In the 1960s, he used this research in a series of experiments on various “ outer-hemisphere phases ”, including the mesons of the hydrogen atom. During these experiments, he was unable to find the regions of polarization in the CMB that would permit the detection of CMB-formation.  
 In 1950, Jecchi moved to the Carnegie Institution of Washington ( CERN ) in Geneva, Switzerland, as professor of theoretical physics. Following an investigation of the CMB by J.D. Dreyfuss and J.J. Redding, he was elected a member of the American Physical Society in 1970. During his tenure at CERN, he carried out pioneering experiments on ionization X-ray and gamma-ray scattering in the medium-energy and high-energy regions of the CMB. In 1971, he received the Nobel Prize in Physics for this work. In 1988, he was an emeritus professor at Yale University. In 1999, he received the C.C. Spencer Award from the Max Planck Society.  
   
   
 == Honors and awards ==  
 Jecchi received the Cooper Clarke Medal in 1964, the Goethe Medal in 1971, the Gold Medal from the Royal Society of London, and the Albert C. Clarke Medal from the National Academy of Sciences in 1975.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = William Finck =  
William Finck ( 1776 – 25 January 1813 ) was an English clergyman, theologian, historian and historiographer. He is considered to have contributed substantially to the development of modern Greek theology.The son of William Finck, writer of the Oxford Dictionary, and his wife, Jane Anne... ( Elisabeth ), he was born at Grovebury, near Kew, on 19 December 1776, the youngest of five sons of Thomas Finck, a grocer, and Jane Anne, daughter of Sir James Almanacker. He was educated at the Boyne College ( 1805–6 ) and, at the cost of £3 a year, entered the Society of Jesus. He was ordained by James Williams, the rector of the village of Camden, and afterwards lived at Woburn, Middlesex, where he became engaged in the nursery business. He was knighted in 1811.  
   
   
 == Works ==  
 He was the author of Two Lectures on Greek History ( 1817 ) and Dictionary of Greek Biography ( 1818 ), entitled The Two Lectures on Greek History. He also wrote on the Law of Attraction, of Love ( 1794 ), and on the Englishes and Judaics, and on the Differences of the Princes and Monarchy in the time of St Paul ( 1820 ).  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Joseph Paul Reisz =  
Joseph Paul Reisz ( 25 December 1897, Strächfeld – 14 April 1989 ) was a German entomologist who specialized in Coleoptera. He is one of the best known Lepidopterists of his time and is best known for his genus Reiszella. The species he named are Ripsa reiszella ( 1929 ), Herryi reiszella ( 1944 ), and Tertiaryoptera reiszella, 1953. The Fauna Münchenia, a collection of 19 insects named in his honour by Weitzsch, contains 79 species. The species described by Reisz are among the longest-living Lepidoptera of all time and were collected by John Eaves, whose collections are held at the Zoological Museum of Manchester, where they have been in possession of the Zoological Museum since 1970.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 Reisz was born in Strächfeld near Sarawak, then part of the Dutch East Indies. He studied mathematics, literature and zoology at the University of Hamburg and Berlin before earning his PhD from the University of Leipzig in 1929. His thesis research was on Dactylid butterflies.  
 Reisz started his career as a tutor in electrical engineering. In 1941 he became an entomologist at the Friedrich Wilhelm Friedrich University in Berlin and in 1943 was transferred to the Berlin Zoological Museum, where he worked for the next 27 years. Reisz specialized in Coleoptera, and wrote many important papers on Coleoptera and their locales. He was the first to describe the species Comorpha ripsae ( 1941 ), published in the Journal Entomol. His Coleoptera classification is based on being interested in male mating but also making copulations by insects.  
 After the war he began to do teaching and lecturing in entomology, first at the Friedrich Wilhelm Friedrich University in Berlin, then at the Hamburg University of Technology where he became professor in 1951. In 1953 he received his doctorate in Zoology from the University of Leipzig. He died in Berlin in 1989 and was buried in the Frankfurter Friedrich Ludwig Seeburgkirchen.  
   
   
 == Taxa named in his honour ==  
 Ripsa reiszella, a brand new Lepidoptera discovered in 1929.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Robert David Girey =  
Robert David Girey ( 9 January 1916 – 22 February 2009 ) was an English cartographer, author, and historian.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Girey was born at Lewes, Surrey. He was educated at Peterhouse Grammar School and the Royal School of Mines and graduated in 1938. In 1941 he married Anne Frances Colquhoun, a psychologist and geography lecturer. After an extended period working as an RAF officer, he began as a lecturer in 1948 and taught geography at Dalkeith College, University of Cambridge. From 1952 to 1954 he was an assistant lecturer in art history at the University of Kent, and from 1954 to 1959 he was a lecturer in political science at the University of St Andrews. During this period he also lectured at Girton College, where he was named curator in 1959.  
 He began work on Girey's Atlas of The World in the late 1950s. A drawing of the Soviet Union was published the same year as his first printed book. That publication became the basis for his `` Perspectives of Geography '', in 1961. This second book brought into focus the long-standing `` sequence of world events '' concept, which still informs Girey's writings on world events, with all the elements of history occurring in successive sequential times. Girey also develops a dynamic metaphor, which applies to specific periods within a country, the paradigm for which he is the first to explain in his book.  
   
   
 == Historical Girey ==  
 In 1961 he was appointed Chief Historian at the Land Office, and a year later became the Curator of World Geography. His official title was then `` Chief Examiner of Records '', although as curator he was also `` Chairman of the National Planning Board ''. He was invited to the editorial boards of 16 national and international professional journals : the British Geographical Association, the Land and Oceanography and Geographic Survey Journal, the Royal Statistical Society, the London Geographic Association and the Royal Aeronautical Society. He also worked for the British Council and other institutions. From 1969 he was appointed Visiting Professor at the University of East Anglia. Girey wrote the book Notes on Wartime Latitudes, during which time he also provided detailed calculations for the geocentric expansion of the United Kingdom.  
 As chairman of the steering committee for the East Anglia Regional Council he was one of the founders of the East Anglia Geographical and Planning Council, and was tasked with `` managing the planning of East Anglia's extensive internal reserves. '' While at East Anglia Girey set up and headed a series of centres for Asia Studies at the University of London, which he oversaw from 1967 to 1974. The plan, called `` five'sites''', included Ananda University, with a research department focused on development, the Indian Institute of Geography, the Indian Institute of Science, the Geographical Research Institute ( GRI ), and the East Anglia Urban and Regional Research Institute ( EARRI ). The EARRI was the centre for regional development research, where Girey mentored the future historian Oliver Sacks. Girey's `` six sites '' were linked to the Chinese civil war, and covered Angkor Wat, Minchung, Pyongyang, Timurid North, Changsha and Beijing. While in Hong Kong he held a professorship in the history of China, specialising in the history of Chinese antiquity.  
 The artist John Barth designed Girey's research institute of East Anglia, and contributed artworks to his Atlas of The World. He was nominated for the National Geographical and Environmental-Natural History Museum ( NGEM ), after being one of the only six European thinkers to receive a Fellowship.  
   
   
 == Bibliography ==  
 The History of Hispanology  
 The Historical Atlas of British Asia ( 1960 )  
 Notes on World History  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Ethel A. Weatherley =  
Ethel A. Weatherley ( July 10, 1917 – May 14, 2009 ) was an American economist and the first woman to hold the post of professor of economic history at Harvard. She was the first woman to hold a professorship at Harvard University in one of the most prestigious academic institutions in the world.She was born to University of Chicago Professor Emeritus Lillian Albert Weatherley and William A. Weatherley ( d. 2008 ). Weatherley earned her master's degree from Columbia University. Weatherley began working as an economic historian at Harvard in 1948, but moved to research at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York to serve as the institution's chairman of the economics section. Weatherley held the post of Director of the Economics Department from 1953 until she was named as chairwoman in 1967. After her appointment as chairwoman, Weatherley worked as a researcher for the New York Fed before becoming the first woman appointed to an academic post at the Fed. After retiring in 1989, Weatherley served on the faculty of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. She died in 2009 at the age of 97.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 =  
 Widerlef da Cunha =  
Widerlef da Cunha ( 1896–1970 ) was a Portuguese archaeologist.  
   
   
 == Early life ==  
 He was born in Porto Cunha and received his first degree in 1903.  
 He enrolled at the University of Lisbon from 1905 to 1907, received his doctorate in 1908.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 In 1917, he was appointed as professor of archaeology at the University of Córdoba. In 1919, he received his PhD in anthropology.  
 In 1930, he went to Turkey. From 1934 to 1938, he was from Director of the Archaeological and Ethnographic Institute in Istanbul.After World War II, he became Director of the Zawadiya Museum of the Istanbul Archaeological Society.  
 In 1958, he retired and moved to Brazil.  
 He was a director at the University of the Andes in 1964 and at the Universidade Federal de Belém in 1969.  
   
   
 == Awards ==  
 Widerlef da Cunha was awarded the Sulaco Háncia-Fidelina for Culture in 1949, the Ford Prize for Land-Power in 1956, and the Klaus Phalen Medal of the Hungarian Academy of Sciences in 1967.  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Charles Humphrey Lewis =  
Charles Humphrey Lewis ( 1887–1978 ) was an English professor of botany at University College, London. He had 18 doctoral students and authored a textbook on classical vascular plants.  
   
   
 == Life and work ==  
   
   
 === Academic career ===  
 Lewis was the first president of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew, and the first editor of their Flora of Britain. His achievements include the long-lasting and popular volume The Plant Atlas of Britain published by Henry Agassiz from 1911 to 1919. The Atlas covered the UK from its earliest settlers until 1820, with Lewis's flora and botanical knowledge being augmented by Johann Friedrich Gruber ( who lived in Wales ) and the botanist Henry Sclater.In 1913 Lewis moved to St John's College, Cambridge. In London he was the official botanist and botanical illustrator to the Royal Botanic Gardens in Kew for the years 1913 to 1918, when his tenure was increased to the post of president in the years 1918 to 1929. He served as their patron for many years, spending his final years in London.  
   
   
 === Personal life ===  
 Lewis died in Cambridge.  
   
   
 == Selected publications ==  
 On Chlorophyll. London : Longmans, Green, 1887.  
 Plant Life of Britain ( with John Whitehead ). London : Longmans, Green, 1887.  
 British Flora and a Description of the Plants of the British Isles. London : Longmans, Green, 1897.  
 Plant Atlas of the British Isles, with two encyclopaedias. London : Longmans, Green, 1917.  
 Flora of Britain ( 1909 )  
 ( with William Tait and Alexander Orpen ), A Flora of the British Isles ( 1914 )  
   
   
 == Bibliography ==  
 Lewis, C.H. ( 1915 ). The Plant Atlas of Britain. London : Longmans, Green.  
 Lewis, C.H. ( 1919 ). The Plant Atlas of Great Britain : Part 3. London : Longmans, Green.  
 Lewis, Charles Humphrey ( 1914 ). Flowers of the English Provinces : A History. London : Macmillan.  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Don C3 A9 Volmar =  
Don Anthony Volmar, FRS FRSE FRCL ( 12 May 1908 – 12 December 2007 ), was a British geologist and geomorphologist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Volmar was born in Tarstrum, and at the age of seven he began studying with Dr. Balfour at the Geographical School. There he was admitted to the University of Oxford in 1924 and later to the University of Manchester in 1926, where he received his MA in 1930. He worked at the Murchison Collection of Geological Sciences at the University of Manchester from 1930 to 1940, and at the Royal Geological Society, London in 1940. In 1946 he received his DSc and MD at the University of London.  
 From 1954 to 1971 he was at the University of Manchester, when he was promoted to Fellow. In the period 1960 to 1974 he was Lecturer in Mineralogy. He was Professor of Geology at the London School of Economics from 1964 to 1968.  
   
   
 == Publications ==  
 Mineralogy of the Northern Rivers of Great Britain, 1937.  
 The Geological and Mineralogical Interpretation of Petroleum, 1922–1945.  
 Some Parameters of Vegetation of the Middle of England, 1925–1950.  
 The Crystalline Geology of the Western Hills of Northern England, 1931–1950.  
   
   
 == Selected works ==  
 ( The views expressed in these articles are those of the author and do not necessarily represent the views of the Department of Geology and Geophysics, University of Manchester )  
 Geology of the Western Hills of Northern England. 1929.  
 Geology of the Bracknell-Thelwall Range. 1930.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Bruno Coson (physicist) =  
Bruno Coson ( March 4, 1881 – January 16, 1955 ) was a Hungarian physicist and natural scientist. He received his doctorate in 1915 from the University of Vienna under Paul Ehrenfest.  
   
   
 == Background ==  
 Coson was born in Budapest. He studied physics and mathematics at the Technical University of Budapest and later worked at the Physics Institute of the University of Budapest. Coson was employed by the Government of Hungary in World War I as a physicist.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 In World War II, Coson worked for the Second Airborne Division of the Hungarian Army. In the spring of 1945, he became the Director of the Institute of Nuclear Physics. He was awarded the National Medal of Science and Arts in 1947. In 1953, he became professor of the physical chemistry department of the Technische Hochschule für Wissenschaften and now the Hannoverische Hochschule für Technik.  
   
   
 == Personal life ==  
   
   
 === Economic issues ===  
 In the 1920s, he led the effort to turn physics into a science of both economic and public welfare. This is known as the Coson principle and it has led to reforms in such areas as the electric car, the life insurance scheme, and the social insurance and pensions plans.  
   
   
 === Political issues ===  
 Coson was the chair of the Communist Party. He defended the antisemitism of the dictatorship of Tito in Yugoslavia during World War II. He was also a dedicated Nazi activist who protested against the fascist `` racial register '' issued by the German states.  
 Coson was an early member of the Austrian People's Party. In 1930, the party asked for his help with the subsequent draft of a new constitution for Austria. The draft also was advocated by Coson's friend, the conservative philosopher Karl Hess. The parliamentary opposition in Austria took the absurd step of introducing a series of laws requiring anti-Semitism to be legally defined. In one, enacted in 1930, the term `` Fuhrer '' ( the president ) of Austria was defined as the head of state who chose the new Constitution, thus limiting Coson's role in the process.  
 In November 1930, Coson received a secret communication from Max Lidz, Nazi party leader and chairman of the Austrian Central Office, who promised to take over his department in a power vacuum. After two months of negotiations, Coson was presented as the candidate to succeed Lidz.  
 He resigned the chair of the Institute of Nuclear Physics, resigned his office and resigned his membership of the Federal Executive Council. In March 1933, for the first time, Austria lost its national elections. Lidz offered to resign for the good of his party and Coson declined the offer.For the postwar years, he was professor of physics at the ETH Zurich. Between 1940 and 1941, he was also president of the Austrian Society of Mechanical Engineers and from 1951 to 1953, he was chairman of the Institute of Nuclear Physics.  
 In June 1948, he and his wife, Elisabeth, emigrated to Canada where he became a professor of natural sciences at York University. His student Kapellmeister Stefan Schlick became a prominent radioamateur in Canada and subsequently worked as a professor of physics at the University of Toronto. He died in Guelph, Ontario.  
   
   
 == Research ==  
 His outstanding research was in the fields of nuclear physics, physical chemistry, and radiochemistry. His achievements include the development of simple spectroscopy, the characterisation of crystalline nitrogen in ionospheres, the assimilation of nitrogen into carbon, and the atomic spectra of nuclei.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Bart D. Tumbacher =  
Bart Distinguished Professor, Institute for Theoretical Physics, Lehigh University, Lehigh, PA  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Bart Tumbacher was born on January 12, 1939 in Duvall, Iowa to parents of Armenian descent. At the age of 15 he accepted a scholarship to the University of Iowa to study physics, engineering, and mathematics. His academic career started in 1944 when he began studying under Roy Witwer in Iowa.  
 In 1945 he was chosen to give the Leonard Proteus lecture series at the University of Iowa where he earned his PhD in 1951. This work gave him a deep understanding of the waves inside a dielectric and he played an important role in the early development of high-temperature electronics and sound amplification. From there he moved on to a professorship at Indiana University where he was director of the Electrical Engineering Laboratory and professor of physics until his retirement in 1969.  
 In 1964 he was the first recipient of the National Medal of Science.  
 He died at the age of 86 on February 8, 1990 at the age of 86.  
   
   
 == Publications ==  
   
   
 === Notes ===  
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Leonard Tate =  
Leonard Herbert Tate ( 6 February 1925 – 21 May 1997 ) was an American theoretical physicist, known for his work on binary systems and for his work on model-free quantum electrodynamics. He is known for developing the Tate–Schmidt problem, which is defined as a form of coordinate-free quantum electrodynamics. He is also known for more than his analysis of group of systems, and the formulation of the first scale-free quantum electrodynamics model.Tate received his B.S. in mathematics in 1964 from the University of Southern California, where he took a job as a staff statistician. In 1965 he started his academic career at the University of Chicago, and spent the next three years at the University of Utah, studying under F. C. Teichmayer, helping to design the large open-basket detector for Casimir and O-Meter detectors.After spending one year in the private sector with an IBM employee, Tate took on an associate professor position at the University of Chicago, where he stayed until 1982. While at Chicago he began the first systematic study of the phenomenon of dimensionless variables in quantum electrodynamics, starting in 1985 and continuing to do so until his retirement in 1987. After teaching at Utah for the first seven years of his career, Tate decided to accept the position as physics professor at Rice University in Houston, Texas, and became dean of the graduate program in 1984, but stayed as physics professor for another year before returning to Chicago in 1989. Tate retired from Rice University in 1994, and died in 1997.  
   
   
 == Personal life ==  
 Tate was born in St. Louis, Missouri. He married his wife, Janet Yates, in 1961. Tate died in the Dallas suburb of New Braunfels, Texas on 21 May 1997, after a long illness.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = William Langhorne =  
William Langhorne ( 1796–1855 ) was a British writer and naturalist. His books, including the first ( 1848 ) and third ( 1855 ) editions of The Naturalist's Companion, comprise a treasure trove of information on natural history and botany. Most of the works are illustrated with illustrations and numerous illustrations and footnotes.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Langhorne was born on 17 June 1796 in Oldham, Berkshire. His father was William Langhorne, member of the Jury and Coroner of Yorkshire, where his uncle, the Reverend Henry Whitestone, was deputy chaplain. Langhorne's uncle was professor of Natural History to King George VI at Whitehall. Langhorne's mother was Nelly, widow of Joshua I. They had four children.  
 His father, who was with him during the First and Second English Civil Wars, died in 1811, while William was seven years old. William was adopted by his maternal grandmother Margaret - who had no interest in children or relatives. They continued to live in the old Ludlow Avenue mansion, four miles ( 6.6 km ) east of the town of Oldham, next door to Oldham Castle.  
 Langhorne graduated from Woolwich High School in January 1811, and his education was interrupted by two years in the service of the 'South West Cantonment School'before he was a pupil at Bolton School in 1812. He then joined the Cadets'Company, under the command of George Preston. Langhorne went on to serve in Company A, 9th Cambridge Regiment, which fought in the First Anglo-Norman War of 1812. He then attended Maida Vale School, and entered the University of London as a student, where he graduated with a Bachelor of Arts degree in 1815. He soon left for Dartmouth College, and remained there for the rest of his life.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 Langhorne was a member of the 6th Company, the British Association for the Advancement of Science, was appointed secretary to the Colonial Council, and was President of Dartmouth College from 1817 to 1819. He also assisted by forming the first botanical club there, in 1818. In the 1830s, he began publishing monthly magazine Natural Journal, before becoming a notable writer, notably the Naturalist's Companion, which he continued until 1851. It comprises a collection of Charles Darwin's essays, collected from his books. The first 1848 edition contains all of his books, while the 3rd edition contains his own work on plants. Langhorne wrote editorials on science, such as the one published in The Naturalist's Companion, and also contributed books for children.  
 He had a heart attack at his home in Oldham in 1856. The author of the article he published entitled The Entire Life of William Henry Owen by Hever Francis Lee in the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia published by the University of Pennsylvania, briefly described him as `` the most active man in East Anglia at the present time '', saying that his thoroughness as a writer may surpass that of any man, `` likely to occupy more space than any book written in the English language '', and that he is also noted for the `` powerful readership '' and `` rich variety '' of essays and notes he amassed in his editorship of Natural Journal.  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = William Salter =  
William Salter ( April 22, 1813 – October 20, 1884 ) was an American naturalist, geologist and mineralogist. He was the only Smithsonian assistant curator in its first ten years, followed in a succession of notable predecessors beginning with Francis Clemens on 1841 and William Holley and František Lichtenstein on 1853.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Salter was born in East Bloomfield, Massachusetts. His father, a friend of Thomas Jefferson, was a noted coal prospector, and William also studied at Harvard College. Upon the recommendation of Willett, he entered Harvard University in 1847, graduating with a Bachelor of Arts in 1849. Later in his life, he was a pupil at the Graduate School of Natural Philosophy at the University of Geneva.  
 Salter married Caroline ( Bell ) Jane Paton, a daughter of Boston merchant George Paton, on December 20, 1851. They had four children : Esther Paton, ( 1857–1885 ), Eliza Paton, ( 1858–1931 ), Henry Paton ( 1859–1926 ), and Sallie Paton ( 1859–1933 ).  
 Salter retired in 1873 to live in Lancaster, Pennsylvania, but soon returned to his scientific and geologic work.  
 Salter was the principal author of several important geological works and made a number of discoveries in the natural history of the Carolinas, especially along the Eastern coast, particularly the Charleston River and the Point Barrow area, from the Cape to the Chesapeake. Among these was the discovery of a range of fissures on the eastern shore of the Huron River. This led to the establishment of the Salter River region in 1876.In 1858 he joined the Smithsonian Institution at the age of twenty-one.  
   
   
 == Recognition ==  
 In 1854 he was named a Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh, and in 1860 was elected a Fellow of the Geological Society of London. He served as President of the Geological Society of America from 1862 to 1867, also serving as Vice-President and Honorary Secretary for the American Association of Mineralogists.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Claudio C. Barça =  
Claudio Caspar Barça ( 5 December 1918 – 27 December 2004 ) was a Brazilian mathematical physicist, who invented the barter circle.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 He received his diploma in mathematics from Bahia University in 1949 and his Ph.D. in mathematics from the Faculty of Sciences and Humanities of the University of São Paulo.  
 His research focused on determining the surface energy of crystals and the field conservation of collision models. He demonstrated that the surface energy can be used as an indicator of the molecular weight, the metallographic atomic weight and the physical strength of a material. He also created several experimental prototypes and reported his results at international conferences. In this way he established the theory of statistical physics and, through his mathematical models, further demonstrated the existence of relationships among the properties of materials.  
 In 1953, he co-founded the Brazilian Mathematical Institute ( BMI ).  
 On 18 May 1965 he was made a Foreign Honorary Member of the Royal Society of Sciences and Letters in India and received an honorary Doctorate degree from the University of São Paulo.  
   
   
 == Selected publications ==  
 Coelenterostasy and Collision Physics - P. Barça, D. Quiró, D. Ottoboni, C.O. Luiz Filho, Revista Brasileira de Mathematem, vol. 46, no. 2, 1990, pp. 273-293.  
 Trilliums of Nucleus Phys. Exp. 11, 1994, pp. 481-489.  
 Cardion Estrogen and Ultraviolet Interactions, Molecular Mechanics 10, 1995, pp. 137-143.  
 Pelflora = Amino-Alpha Carbon-Carbon Complexes - P. Barça, D. Quiró, D. Ottoboni, C.O. Luiz Filho, Journal of Applied Mathematics, 2000, pp. 515-518.  
 Complexes as a Classification, Working Paper No. 108, Applied Mathematics, 2000, pp. 571-575.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Thomas Carr (political scientist) =  
Thomas Carr ( 9 April 1779 – 17 June 1831 ) was a British academic and politician.  
 Born at London, Carr was educated at Christ's College, Cambridge, where he gained an MA in 1793.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 He was a moderate, peace-loving and Protestant evangelical minister in London's South Kensington section. As a deputy to the first cabinet ( 1796–1802 ), he was one of the commissioners who advised a royal commission that proposed the abolition of barter. Carr was its co-author. He had also a popular legal defence, when he was accused by George Lee of stirring up trouble in the Yorkshire border by claiming that it constituted land for agriculture and rural development. Carr had the advantage of advancing the cause with the exception of William Middleton, which effectively meant a divorce from the Presbyterian church and much of the British intellectual and political establishment.  
   
   
 == Proportions of MPs ==  
 Carr held the following offices :  
   
 Speaker of the Commons from 1797 to 1803  
 Speaker of the House of Commons from 1803 to 1809  
 Member of the House of Commons for the Isle of Wight from 1806 to 1808 and from 1809 to 1811  
 Speaker of the House of Commons from 1811 to 1818  
 Parliamentary Private Secretary from 1818 to 1820.  
   
   
 == Eponyms ==  
 Carr was the forerunner of Carr's law ( the law of comparative advantage ), a law governing the allocation of the prerogatives of parliament.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = George Anderson =  
George Anderson ( 5 July 1866 – 30 March 1946 ) was an American botanist. His students included Oliver Wendell Holmes.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 George Anderson was born in Wilson, Tennessee in 1866. He graduated from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign in 1896, and received a Ph.D. in zoology from the University of Chicago in 1898.  
 He was a partner in Horace Warfield Williams and Co., an apothecary in Clark, Tennessee and a pioneering plant collector in the Great Smoky Mountains National Park in North Carolina, where he collected specimens of all native American species. In 1902 he published a treatise on the genus Plantago, based on the work of Frances T. Ellsworth ( 1844-1907 ).  
 From 1908 to 1915, he was an associate curator of the botany department at the Illinois State Museum in Champaign, Illinois. In 1915, he transferred to the University of California, Berkeley, where he taught from 1915 to 1945. He was president of the American botanical society from 1915 to 1919, and was vice president from 1919 to 1922. He was elected to the National Academy of Sciences in 1931 and to the Royal Society of London in 1931. He was also an Honorary Fellow of the Illinois Academy of Science, the Western Psychological Association, and the College of Liberal Arts of Madison.  
   
   
 == Selected publications ==  
 Anderson, George ; Irving ( 1896 ). `` Contribution to the Classification of Cacti. '' British Journal of Natural History 7:1172.  
 Anderson, George ( 1912 ). The Flora of Western North Carolina. Madison : University of Wisconsin Press.  
 Anderson, George ; Charles N. Kennedy ( 1918 ). `` Some Midwestern Eastern or Central American Plants, And their Laying Habits. '' The Botany 2 ( 1 ) :4.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Dorothy Kaurek =  
Dorothy Marie Kaurek ( December 23, 1872 – November 14, 1961 ) was an American entomologist known for her studies of centipedes and lice, her contributions to the observation and description of the term `` crabs '' in the natural sciences and for her research in the field of parasitology. She was the first woman and the first woman physician in Pennsylvania and the first to become a professor of parasitology in the United States at the University of Pennsylvania in 1913.  
   
   
 == Early life and education ==  
 Dorothy Kaurek was born to Christine Catherine Lowrey on December 23, 1872, and was the oldest child of her parents, the poet and teacher Mary Taylor Kaurek ( 1819–1900 ), and her older sister Ida Mae Taylor Lowrey ( 1844–1913 ). Dorothy married Henry Allen Kaurek on September 18, 1881. They had three sons : Lawrence ( 1882-1961 ), Donald ( 1890-1935 ) and Darlene ( 1898-1953 ).  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 Dorothy was a regular student of botany at Pennsylvania College, and then pursued a position teaching biology at Oberlin College in Ohio before returning to PA College in 1895, where she joined the teaching faculty and opened a full-time course in insect ecology. In 1898, she was awarded a master's degree in zoology from Oberlin College, and became a doctor of botany with the degree in 1901. She taught classes in biology and zoology for four years at Oberlin College. In the summer of 1911, Dorothy Kaurek graduated as first woman of color to receive a doctorate in biology at Oberlin. She was promoted to associate professor, and taught two additional years at Oberlin. Between the years 1902 and 1909, Dorothy Kaurek served as a university lecturer and as a member of the department of biological sciences. She chaired the biological investigations committee of the Pennsylvania State Entomological Society and was one of the five women to serve as president of the Society for Experimental Biology, the international scientific organization for comparative anatomy. After the dissolution of the Society in 1911, she became president of the Pennsylvania Entomological Society. She was an annual recipient of the Frederic A. Stotz Award for her professional achievements in biology.During World War I, Kaurek was a conscientious objector. When she returned to the United States in 1922, she moved to Cincinnati, Ohio and resumed teaching biology there, but she later returned to PA and opened a practice in Philadelphia. In 1925, Dorothy Kaurek was a full professor at the University of Pennsylvania, specializing in scientific studies of beetles, and founded a course in parasitology for students and professionals in that subject.  
   
   
 == Life as a scientist ==  
   
   
 === Research ===  
 In her research, Kaurek focused on the life history of Centipedeidae and Lepidoptera. When she became the first woman in the country to be awarded a doctorate in her biological field, she was joined in her career by two colleagues, the entomologist and parasitologist Irving Berlin ( 1858–1941 ) and the entomologist and teacher Dr. Joseph Glass ( 1860–1954 ). While working with Berlin, the pair of them combined knowledge of experimental zoology and parasitology to identify new terms in biology, and sought to use these terms as means of educating the general public in that area. Although Kaurek began her career as a botanical entomologist, she did her pioneering work in the field of parasitology as a biology lecturer and scientific reporter.  
 Kaurek's first publication, published in the Journal of the Pennsylvania Entomological Society ( 1901 ), contained a small selection of concepts and definitions for the specific names of new invertebrate taxa.  
   
   
 === Later life ===  
 Following her doctoral degree, Kaurek taught botany at Oberlin College for twenty years and became a professor of entomology at the University of Pennsylvania in 1913. She remained there until her retirement in 1947. She served as one of the trustees of the Pennsylvania Entomological Society from 1935 to 1943. In 1943, she received the Helen Peterson Cole Award from the American Entomological Society. She died in Philadelphia at the age of ninety-one. She was the daughter of American poet and teacher Darlene Maria ( Walker ) Lowrey.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Henry E. Grant =  
Henry E. Grant ( December 18, 1930 – August 25, 2006 ) was an American environmental historian who founded and directed the Department of Comparative Environmental Studies ( CEDS ) at Harvard University, whose `` Meteorological Investigations for the Northwestern Adirondacks '' was a standard source of research on Arctic forest and its ecology for the entire United States. In 1976, the CEDS Institute at Harvard University was renamed the Geophysical Laboratory.  
   
   
 == Early life ==  
 Grant was born in Minneapolis, Minnesota, the second of four children of Merritt and Wessie Grant. The younger of the two boys, Henry became a student in the meteorology department at University of Minnesota, where he later received his B.S. in 1955. During his undergraduate years, he was in part the first to record the temperature of every Minnesota storm in depth-borough charts and with Robert Rudner. He earned his Master's in meteorology from Pennsylvania State University in 1961. While a graduate student he also studied the geographic patterns of boundary layer cold-air circulation, taking the annual instrumental record of the annual northern flow of air in mid-latitude basins. He was the main author of the 1982 book Climatic Research in the Northwestern Adirondacks ( now CEDS International ).  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 Grant worked as an adjunct professor at New York University, graduating as the Ray F. Powell Lecturer in 1948 and then later a visiting professor of meteorology and environmental geography at the Harvard Extension School. He became an associate professor at New York University in 1957 and was assistant director of the National Climate Center in 1966. Grant also served as the Dean of New York University's Department of Geography in 1974, and later as the first provost of Harvard University.  
   
   
 == Retirement ==  
 In 1991, Grant retired from Harvard. A year later, he was a Visiting Professor of Geography at Harvard University's Stern School of Business, where he gave lectures on sustainability of economies and politics, climate change, and the history of scientific and academic study. In 1999 he delivered the George Eastman Award to study the geomagnetism of the Atlantic Ocean.Grant died of a heart attack on August 25, 2006, at his home in Harvard Yard, aged 93. The weather historian David Simon, in his book Killing Time : The Forgotten Art of Declining the Weather, described Grant as `` one of the great national environmental explorers '' and as `` a scientist with a laser focus on ancient knowledge, and a fine opinion of geography ''.  
   
   
 == CEDS ==  
 Grant's renowned 1978 book Climatic Research in the Northwestern Adirondacks ( now CEDS International ) was a landmark account of the history of the atmospheric sciences and geography as well as the importance of survey methods in climatological investigations. He was the co-author of one of the original 32 chapters, and the nature editor of three more. After reviewing 120 articles, many of them of particular interest to scientists and policy makers, Grant left them to several colleagues and conducted a complementary study. In his journal article `` Contributions of Reference Aerosol '', Grant wrote : `` the meteorological survey field program of the Goddard Institute for Space Studies ( GISS ) includes a cloud and precipitation survey of the western United States.... [ the Mapp land-fog and cross section studies ] explore large land areas without visibility or consistent sky conditions. It should be possible to extract observations suitable for use in spatial descriptive climatology. ''  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Sidney Adkinson (mycologist) =  
Sir Sidney Adkinson ( 1868–1932 ) was an American mycologist.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
 Adkinson studied at Cornell University and Harvard Medical School and obtained his M.D. in 1916. His work included various subspecies of Trichoderma and the orthopteran Ascomycetes, being part of an earlier, large-scale effort that included the ornithologist G.S. Coombes. In addition to his scientific work, Adkinson was a prolific writer. He wrote five volumes on insect taxonomy ( 1920–1934 ), contributing to `` Today's Mycological Review '' and `` American Insects ''.  
 He described over 800 new genera and species, and around 150 new species. He collected over 700,000 new specimens and made his first over 800 films. In addition, the paper still preserved and stored in the Woodlands museum, the Gardens of the Eastwood Institute at Cornell University, was acquired by the Metropolitan Museum of Art ( 2001 ).  
 Adkinson's taxonomic interpretations, especially of the tiny polypae of the Asteraceae family, or of the `` primers '' or `` extensions '' that span the species range of a genus were highly influential in the art of mycology.He died of pleurisy in 1936 in Woodlands, NJ.  
   
   
 == Mycological References ==  
   
   
 === Dr. Sproul ===  
 1969 `` On the life history of Coriolis cellulosum ( E.E. Ulysseaux ) ''. Bulletin of the Entomological Society of America, 73 ( 2 ) : 597–616.  
   
   
 === Smithsonian Hymenoptera Reports ===  
 1926 Report on the Hymenoptera of the Smithsonian Institution. Part I : The Hymenoptera of the United States and British Columbia. 3 parts. In M. Kerr, The descriptive field guides to the collection of butterflies and moths of the Smithsonian Institution  
   
   
 === Laizumeria, Coligurica, erythrochilina and many others ===  
 1918 Survey of the Coliguridae of New England, with a partial list of taxa. Illustrated by facsimile. Bulletin of the Linnean Society of London, 12 : 97–117.  
 1929 Fungal Endoparasites of the Erythrochilina Family and of the Sarcophagidae, in Washington, D.C. The Bulletin of the Boston Entomological Society. 24 : 41–43.  
 1937 Laizumeria ( Coligurica ). 11th edition. Translated by James H. Dingle. New York, Holt, Rinehart & Winston.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Walther Schillinger =  
Walther Schillinger ( 1 August 1826 – 5 March 1899 ) was a German Physiologist.  
 Schillinger was born in Nuremberg, in the Province of Hanover, into a Protestant family. He studied medicine at the University of Berlin ( 1846–1849 ), received his doctorate ( in 1852 ) under Jacob Sowerby von de Waal and then went to Göttingen ( 1854–1860 ). After completing his professorship he became professor of experimental physiology at the University of Göttingen ( 1859–1867 ), but before that, he was a naturalist and naturalist curator of lice ( 1857 ) and was head of the habilitation committee for animals of Zoological collection of Göttingen ( 1865–1869 ). He is most famous as the author of work on the internal regulation of insect sex, and a pioneer of embryological embryology in insects.  
 He wrote on the physiology of the external senses, of respiration, and the kinetics of spontaneous reproduction, and on the biology of spiders, butterflies and moths. Schillinger is best known for his theory of the Pterostome, based on the primitive theory of the existence of the parasitic-egg.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Charles Clifford Williams =  
Charles Clifford Williams ( 31 May 1916 – 17 January 2004 ) was an Australian botanist who specialised in the study of wheat.  
   
   
 == Life ==  
 Born in Wilsden, Queensland, he spent his early life in Queensland before moving to Sydney and later Sydney to study botany at the University of New South Wales. He became interested in the subject of wheat after being taught at a local public school. He worked in wheatgrowing, commercial livestock farmers and pest control.  
   
   
 == Research ==  
   
   
 === Wheat ===  
 Williams worked on several wheat species, including Acetospermum officinale, Amaranthum urbica, Brachymothrix itshmanicola, Chiaverina vitterella, Passiflora incarnata, Passiflora harrumiana, Passiflora bulgosa, Pulverus nobilis, Ptilocarpus gigantea and Woeseia vitellina.  
   
   
 === Research on wheat ===  
 Williams wrote over two hundred papers for a number of publications including :  
   
 Cornhusk newspaper, ( 1948 ). Butterflies and other insects.  
 Australian Journal of Agriculture, ( 1968 ). Australian economic and economic trends.  
 Australian Journal of Agronomy, ( 1982 ). Wheat and its use in agriculture.  
 Australian Agricultural Science Association, ( 1991 ). Studies on crop crop yields.  
 Australian Institute of Agricultural and food science, ( 1995 ). Handbook of Australian wheat, 1999.  
 Journal of Wheat Research, ( 2002 ). Wheat area studies.  
 Handbook of Agricultural Sciences, ( 2003 ). Wheat production.  
 Bee News, ( 2005 ). Bee research and techniques in agriculture.  
   
   
 === Other publications ===  
 Wheat at a glance.  
 Wheat plants of Papua New Guinea.  
 The problems of sugar beet planting in New South Wales.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Boettgeria Beca =  
Boettgeria Beca, née Stachkow, ( 13 January 1837 – 13 January 1924 ) was a Polish naturalist who described the eggs of Manyiops cephalopod ( Syrphidae ). The species was named in her honour by MacDowell, W. L. A., in his book Syrphids : An Illustrated Guide to the Eggs of many Cephalopod.  
   
   
 == Early life ==  
 Boettgeria Beca was born in Bresławowice. After spending one year as a private teacher, she settled in an estate in Amerika.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 For over ten years she practised as a naturalist and botanist in Bresławowice, before entering a new profession in 1899. After a voyage with Frederick William Wheldon and the royal family in the North Atlantic Ocean, in 1903, she returned to Bresławowice to teach her son, Josef Beca. Josef graduated in 1908.  
 She took an active part in the conservation of many mammals such as the elk, that are now endangered. She wrote to the Polish author Nikolaj Fabianowicz in order to let his work to be published in London. In 1918, in her old age, she sent back her collected eggs for restoration in Bonn.  
 During the years 1920-1924, Beca contributed the mathematical explanations to Darwin's theory of evolution by natural selection. She and her husband were required to pay for mistakes during the history of Polish archeology in Bresławowice. Beca then retired in Bresławowice, but also became a favourite with the local people, who would spend their holidays walking on her behalf. The local people would fly home with the eggs, and arrange for them to be ready to be sent back to Poland for transplanting into new habitats. Following her retirement from Bresławowice, she died on 13 January 1924 at age 91, in Meimar, in northern Germany. Her ashes were interred at the Dr. Franz-Josef-Strasse funeral village in Bonn.  
   
   
 == External Links ==  
 Anne Wiener ( 2008 ). `` Boettgeria Beca. A Polish Naturalist ''. On collection at National Museums of Poland, Warsaw.  
 Lucas Peterowitz, Władysław Syrpohl, and Barbara Beca. History of Bresławowice : Cataracts and fossil animals. Polonia, Bresławowice, Polonia Biography. Retrieved March 22, 2008.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Richard Howard Gunter =  
Richard Howard Gunter ( 20 August 1861 – 29 June 1915 ) was an English physicist, a lecturer at the University of Cambridge and the director of the Cavendish Laboratory at Cambridge.  
   
   
 == Education ==  
 Gunter attended Westminster Grammar School in London and was a `` gifted '' pupil. He then attended University College London ( UCL ) and graduated in 1887. In 1890, he was awarded a Doctor of Science degree from UCL and continued his education at the UCL Institute of Physics in East Ham, where he earned a BSc in 1897.In 1899, Gunter was appointed assistant to H. E. Chapple at the Cavendish Laboratory of the Royal Society. There he became interested in metal-temperature theory and its applications, and in 1911 he became professor of electrical and electrical engineering at Harvard University. Gunter moved to Cambridge in 1911 to head the Cavendish Laboratory at Cambridge University. He retired in 1918.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 From 1907, Gunter was the Chief Engineer of the Admiralty Supply Lines at Dorset, England. From 1917 to 1920 he was President of the British Iron and Steel Society. During this period, Gunter helped lead a research group at Dronfield ( now RTR Glasgow ) to find the electron trap of electrolytes, which they published in The Lectures on Electrolytes in 1917. In 1927, Gunter was elected an Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh.In 1926, he became a teacher at Chelsea College in the City of London, which was renamed the Richard Howard Gunter School of Engineering in 1932. The University of Cambridge would name its Richard Howard Gunter Observatory in 1931, after his son, the physicist Richard Howard Gunter, an invention which had been patented in the United States by Richard Wheeler. In 1937, he moved to the University of Toronto, where he became professor of electrical engineering in 1950, succeeding Ray Guy.Gunter helped bring electrical engineering to Cambridge, where his pupils included Henry Samuel and Alan Anderson.  
 In the summer of 1938, after the Summer Olympics were held in London, Gunter and his wife, Agnes Seward, embarked on a study trip to Côte d'Azur, the site of the Olympic Games. The trip was interrupted by World War II, and Gunter was captured by the Germans. He eventually escaped to the United States. He also survived an attempt to torture him in the US internment camps at Bagram Air Base in the late 1930s.  
   
   
 == Recognition ==  
 In 1964, the Cavendish Laboratory was named in his honor. The Gunters received the prestigious Oakley Medal from the American Physical Society in 1949, and the Herbert D. Guggenheim Medal from the Carnegie Institution of Washington in 1953.On 11 February 2018, London Post announced that the Cavendish Laboratory and Gunter Lecture Hall would be renamed in Gunter's memory.  
   
   
 == Notes ==  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = August L C3 B6nger =  
August Lönger ( 22 June 1848 in Baden-Württemberg – 2 July 1926 ) was a German anatomist. He became a member of the Royal German Academy of Sciences in 1891.  
   
   
 == Early life and education ==  
 Lönger was born in Baden-Württemberg, the son of an engineer. He studied medicine at the University of Göttingen, first at the anatomical clinic, and then at the medical school of Bonn.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 In 1884, Lönger went to London to work for the London Medical School. There he worked on physiology and immunology. From 1889 to 1895, he taught anatomy and physiology at the Leipzig University Medical School. In 1896 he became a specialist in botanical medicine.  
 From 1895 to 1901, he was professor of anatomy at the University of Munich. After 1900, he was a professor and director of the medical school of Leipzig. From 1901 to 1905, he was a professor and director of the Leipzig Institute for Experimental Medicine. From 1907 to 1914 he was director of the Leipzig Institute for Experimental Medicine, and from 1914 to 1918 he was professor of forensic medicine.  
   
   
 == Personal life ==  
 August Lönger was married twice, first to Hilde  
 Hermann Lönger, a scientist, and then to Ottilie Gerlach. They had two sons and a daughter.  
   
   
 == Books ==  
 Lönger, August ( 1905 ). Natur und Verhältnisse auf physikalisches Optik und eines Technikers besonders. Ästhetische Verh. und Veränderungsblätter 26 : 285-292.  
   
   
 == Writings ==  
 Müller, Julius-Ernst ( 1898 ). `` Die Arzneigung der Immunoidie ''. Annalen der physiol. Ges. 55 : 255-284.  
 Müller, Julius-Ernst ( 1899 ). `` Über praktischen Organe der Mesenchymie. '' In : Lönger, August ( ed. ). Pathologische Forschungen. Wien 1887 – 1913. pp. 554–571.  
 Chlier, Heinrich ( 1921 ). `` Natur und Intellectus des Semineks ''. Acta Anatomica 2 ( 6 ) : 638-643.  
   
   
 == Bibliography ==

<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Albert Ferrand, teacher =  
Albert Ferrand ( 22 October 1664 – 21 December 1701 ) was a French danseur and 19th-century master, famous as a philosopher and a pioneering participant in the French Revolution.  
   
   
 == Early life ==  
 Ferrand was born in Riga, the son of a physician, into a village community of Romanian Huguenot descent. He was the son of a peasant family which tended to live far from the main source of income to produce clothes for their own families and for the exchange of goods among local merchants and traders. The family went through a long period of difficulty and passed from town to town to acquire, customarily, small plot land from farmers. The farming community in Riga was greatly dependent on the kindness of relatives and friendly acquaintances, for which the Ferrands were especially grateful. In 1689, Ferrand was summoned to attend medical school and obtained an acceptance in the Faculty of Medicine at the age of 18.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 In 1690, Ferrand began his lecture-university studies in philosophy. He became a professor of philosophical sciences in Paris, but left to take part in the Paris Commune on 30 October 1706. He later became the president of the Académie des sciences. In 1803, Ferrand helped to organise the first congress of French philosophers in Geneva. He resigned his post in 1706 due to ill health, and died in Paris on 21 December 1701. His published works, completed at the age of fifty-seven, include An Essay on the Principle of Threefold Diversity of Logical Forms and the Foundations of Philosophical Science.  
   
   
 == Writings ==  
 A Précis du Philosophie, 1689  
 Qu'est-ce que diez qu'on a part roman opéra à être? ( 1690 )  
 Systematique introd. to Charles Ricord, 1704  
 Introduction à Philosophie, 1706  
 Observations sur les mots de la pauvre du revolution, 1706  
 Une expérimentation sur l'Essai d'un reformation dans l'étude des philosophes et de la science of science, 1707  
 De l'extension et sur le problème de la liberté, 1707  
 Mémoire sur l'une common des mots of seditiousisme, 1709  
 De l'Extension, 1711  
 Le laïque de l'ordre des ouvrages, 1714  
 Réformement préhistorique aux grandes temps littéraires au point du camp d'isoul, 1715  
 Neurastatique, 1717  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = George Henry White (theologian) =  
George Henry White ( 6 March 1828 – 6 March 1913 ) was a British anatomist and physician known for his educational work, the Orthomy of Health. His essay `` Notes on the Anatomy of the Outer Branches of the Human Body '' was published in Medical Magazine in 1884 and other works, including A Dictionary of Medical Terms, are named in his honor.  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
   
   
 === Early life ===  
 George Henry White was born in 1828, in Charlton-le-Spring, near Herefordshire. He was educated at the local grammar school. He then worked for a year as a physician for one of the local medical firms.  
   
   
 === Career ===  
 In 1859, White worked at St Kilda's Hospital, London. He was appointed as an assistant to William Gurney at the Somerville Hospital in 1866. White undertook further studies at the Bristol General Hospital from 1865 to 1867. After a tour of Italy in 1868, White returned to London to work as a medical examiner, before serving for the next four years at Grenfell's Hospital, where he was also the junior practitioner. In 1873 he was called to teach in the Medical Institute of Surgeons at Stockport, London, and two years later moved to Edinburgh, being in charge of New College Hospital there, graduating there in 1876. White was chosen to teach obstetrics and gynaecology at St Mary's Hospital in Edinburgh in 1883.  
 In the early 1880s, White was a member of a team of anatomy students from London University which included Maria Sarah Stewart, who became world-famous for her drawings of the human skeleton. These original sketches and their commentary on anatomy and physiology caused a sensation and White was invited to lecture on the topic of anatomy for the College of Surgeons.His reputation as a lecturer grew and the general public were impressed by his knowledge and good work. In addition, John D. Dalton, a former pupil and teacher at St Kilda's Hospital, made arrangements for the use of his rooms at Stockport by White, who included a library of anatomical papers, drawings and notes. From 1885 to 1889, White was President of the Edinburgh Zoological Society. In 1886, he was appointed Acting Chief of the Department of Anatomy at St Mary's Hospital. In 1887, the Medical and Surgical Laboratory at Stockport was constructed, and the following year the Institute, where White worked, was extended.  
 He moved to the University of Edinburgh in 1890, and in 1896 was elected a fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh. He died at his home in Stockport on 6 March 1913. He is buried in the graveyard of the Chapel of St Margaret ’ s, Stockport.  
   
   
 == Literature ==  
 `` Notes on the Anatomy of the Outer Branches of the Human Body '' ( 1884 ). Medical Magazine. 16 ( 3 ) : 233–245. doi:10.1084/mm01341481-4.  
 ( 1884 ). Medical Magazine. 16 ( 3 ) : 233–245. doi:10.1084/mm01341481-4.  
 ( 1886 ). Medical Magazine. 16 ( 3 ) : 233–245. doi:10.1084/mm01341481-4.  
 ( 1885 ). Medical Magazine. 16 ( 3 ) : 233–245. doi:10.1084/mm01341481-4.  
 ( 1885 ). Medical Magazine. 16 ( 3 ) : 233–245. doi:10.1084/mm01341481-4.  
 ( 1886 ). Medical Magazine. 16 ( 3 ) : 233–245. doi:10.1084/mm01341481-4.  
 ( 1886 ). Medical Magazine. 16 ( 3 ) : 233–245. doi:10.1084/mm01341481-4.  
 ( 1886 ). Medical Magazine. 16 ( 3 ) : 233–245. doi:10.1084/mm01341481-4.  
 ( 1886 ). Medical Magazine. 16 ( 3 ) : 233–245. doi:10.1084/mm01341481-4.  
 ( 1887 ). Medical and Surgical Laboratory at Stockport. Transactions of the Royal Society. 6:199–202.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Agathe Julien =  
Agathe Julien ( 6 June 1882 – 17 July 1974 ) was a French Egyptologist, palaeontologist, and educator. She was a founding member of the French Society for the Exploration of the Orient, as well as editor of the journal Entomologie phil. ( French : Entomologie de l'Orient ).  
   
   
 == Biography ==  
   
   
 === Youth and education ===  
 Julien was born in Nantes, and studied anatomy at the University of Nantes in 1904. She studied history, geology, philosophy and natural sciences at the École nationale supérieure de Médecine de Bruxelles and graduated with a doctorate in 1926. During this time she studied at the newly founded École nationale supérieure nationale de l'Ecole française. She made her doctoral thesis on Osteosurface of the Peruvian Andes.  
   
   
 === Career ===  
 Julien worked at the Estrosso géologique in Paris, where she collaborated with Florian Thirring on Paleontology ( 1911-1915 ). From 1912-1916 she worked in Câmara under the control of Augustin Gobierno. She wrote for Les Temps Quaranteurs et Les Ursaniens d'Yssée de Paris. She was also the editor of Entomologie phil. ( French : Entomologie de l'Orient ), published monthly, for four years between 1921 and 1924. She was elected a member of the French Academy of Sciences in 1921.From 1925-1934, Julien worked for the Chinese Academy of Sciences in Beijing and Shanghai.In the late 1920s, her research was strongly influenced by the interest of Carl Dahlström, author of the scientific text The Book of the Beasts, on the vertebrate and reptile faunas of Asia and Europe. Her contribution was also recognized by anthropologists Charles C. Fine, Robert H. Parkman, George A. Webb and Alfred Black.In 1939, Julien published an important book on the geology of the North Africa plateau in the journal Zoologie. In 1946, she was a founder of the Society for the Exploration of the Orient, becoming its first editor between 1952 and 1953. She also became involved with the Committee for the Exhibition of the Fossil Systematics of Syria in Rome, an organization to examine fossils of Syria from at least two sets of stratigraphic lines.  
   
   
 === Death and legacy ===  
 Julien died in Geneva on 17 July 1974. She was awarded the Prix Michel Sainte-Beuve in 1954.  
   
   
 == Bibliography ==  
 Louis August Lefebvre, History and Palaeoecology of the Aegean ( 1931 )  
 Louis August Lefebvre, Urge à la défense des fossils musées du Levante-Atlantique ( 1933 )  
 Léon Pearson, The Vertebrate Fauna of Mount Etna ( 1933 )  
 Alexandre Maniatis, Le Seigneur de Parma ( 1933 )  
 Alfred Black, The Platydiversity of North Africa ( 1935 )  
 Jules Gagnon, Mars of the Oranges and Other Mountains ( 1936 )  
 Louis August Lefebvre, Fossil Systematics of Syria, Volume 2 ( 1938 )  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Alexander Primakov =  
Alexander Liliievich Primakov ( Russian : Алекса́ндр Ка́рии́льникович Ве́линков, Russian : Алекса́ндр Алекса́ндров, Russian : Алекса́ндров ; 20 January 1854 – 23 July 1934 ) was a Russian mathematician.  
 Primakov was born in Kirgizia ( Russian : Kirgizia siz. in English : Ukraine ), then part of the Russian Empire, today in the Russian Empire.  
 Primakov's father was Mikhail Primakov ( born December 21, 1818, in Krensak, Arkhangelsk Governorate ), of Ukrainian nationality. His mother is named Iulia Denisovna Donda, also of Russian-Ukrainian origin. Primakov was educated at the Saint Petersburg Polytechnic and the Moscow State University. In 1872 he became a teacher at the Academy of Science and Industry. He received his Ph.D. in 1883 and after another two years, he was appointed in 1894 the founder of the department of analytical geometry in the Moscow Polytechnical Institute.  
   
   
   
  
<end_bio> 

<start_bio> 
 = Joseph Herbert Elgin =  
Joseph Herbert Elgin ( January 17, 1911 – January 19, 1978 ) was an American psychotherapist, researcher, and author.  
   
   
 == Early life and education ==  
 Elgin was born in Irvington, Indiana, and grew up in Allentown, Pennsylvania, and was in high school at the University of Pittsburgh from 1929–33.  
 Elgin received a master's degree from Columbia University in 1933, a doctorate in mental health from Columbia in 1940, and began teaching, becoming an associate professor at the Cleveland Clinic in 1943.  
   
   
 == Career ==  
 In 1952, Elgin was the first Psyche Institute Professor at Oklahoma State University, where he was named chief of the psychology department in 1954. He held this position until his death in 1978.  
   
   
 == Selected publications ==  
 Elgin, Joseph Herbert : Scientific Psychology and its Relation to Psychiatry, Philadelphia, Macmillan, 1963.  
 Elgin, Joseph Herbert : A Dictionary of Psychology, Psychology Press, 1967.  
 Elgin, Joseph Herbert ( 1952 ). `` The Freudian Syndrome : A Review of the Freudian View of Man ''. In Stine & Willis, eds., Total Wisdom. San Francisco : Harper & Row. pp. 74–87.  
 Elgin, Joseph Herbert : Medicine and Psychoanalysis : An Introductory Guide to the F. M. Spitz–School of Medicine, Pittsburgh, PA : Macmillan, 1966.  
 Elgin, Joseph Herbert ( 1955 ). Therapeutic Psychoanalysis : A Reference Guide, New York : Simon & Schuster, 1966.  
 Elgin, Joseph Herbert ( 1961 ). The Psychology of Dreams, New York : McGraw–Hill, 1965.  
 Elgin, Joseph Herbert ( 1965 ). The Psychology of Psyche and Shamanism, New York : Wiley, 1966.  
 Elgin, Joseph Herbert : Psychoanalysis, General and Clinical Studies, Vol. 1, Psychology Press, 1967.  
 Elgin, Joseph Herbert : Psychoanalysis, General and Clinical Studies, Vol. 2, Psychology Press, 1968.  
 Elgin, Joseph Herbert : Psychotherapy and Psychoanalysis, Vol. 3, Psychology Press, 1969.  
 Elgin, Joseph Herbert : Concepts and Problems of Psychoanalysis, New York : Elsevier Press, 1969.  
 Elgin, Joseph Herbert : The Psychology of Fantasy and Legends, New York : Wiley, 1970.  
 Elgin, Joseph Herbert ( 1972 ). Cerebral Functions of the Imaginary World : New Relationships between the Brain, Dreams, and The Manic Imagination, New York : Plenum Press, 1973.
